text: This comprehensive 3 CD collection of Gerry Rafferty recordings should not leave any doubt in the listener that Rafferty was very fine songwriter; who at times wrote some great outstanding songs. The reason he never reached sustained star status,  may be due to his vocals which often appear a little too "nice" and rarely come out daring or just slightly provocative. He voice is by no means weak or bad and it can recall both Emitt Rhodes and Rick Nelson to your mind. Rafferty's personal image was in many ways reminiscent  of his vocal; the nice and comfy. Paradoxically, when you consider that Rafferty private life often was marked by major personal problems.Rafferty's first golden period was with the group Stealers Wheel with whom he released three albums. Logically, this CD collection leaves room for this period with six songs from the excellent debut album, especially remembered for "Stuck in the Middle" and "Late Again". The also excellent second album "Ferguslie Park" contributes five songs while the last, and slightly paler album, "Right or Wrong" makes do with three songs.From Rafferty's long solo career much emphasis is put on the classic and well-rounded album "City to City", which even contains the classic "Baker Street". There are fine songs on all Rafferty's other albums, but the only threat for the title of the best must be "North and South" from 1988, which also contributes with six tracks.Among the later and lesser-known albums "Over My Head" is also worth noting; not least because of the Marshall Crenshaw like "The Girl's Got No Confidence".The earliest songs recorded with the group "Humblebums" are quite good, but may appear a little fresh and unfinished; Rafferty also chose to re-record several of these songs for later albums.

This new 5 CD box with the Kinks covers only their Pye period from 1964 to 1971. Many may wonder how there may be need for yet another compilation/box with the Kinks. The answer to this question I will leave up to the individual music listener, and simply note that I personally am very pleased with the release. As other reviewers have noted, the packaging is not particularly convenient for keeping the CDs ngood shape, but it is quite handy and containing a nice colorful book with important information about the individual tracks.To protect CDs from the very narrow cardboard pockets, I recommend that you get for them five seperate jewel-cases.The music is, of course, excellent, and many tracks are found in new clearer mixes giving them a more open sound.There are several previously unreleased tracks and various other rarities distributed over all five CDs which are chronologically set up.For me, the biggest scoops are "Pictures in the Sand" for the first time here on CD in the vocal version. Also 'Till Death Us Do Part' has not previously been released on CD. Most tracks from the legendary collection "The Great Lost Kinks"are incidentally included. Also "Did You See His Name" from "The Kinks Kronikles" is here with an alternative ending.Some tracks contain a little studio chatter, and there is an interview with the group from 1964 and one with Ray Davies from 1968, where he talks about "The Village Green Preservation Society".For new fans of the group, this must be a treasure trove of fine music, from one of the greatest acts of the 1960s; I will not hesitate to equate them with the Beatles, while connoisseurs of the group will be able to enjoy the previously mentioned rarities while getting an opportunity to re-consult the many great songs Ray Davies wrote during this incredibly creative period of his career.

My first impression of "Ghost Stories" was that it was actuall a very nice album, but also a little uninteresting. Besides the single "Magic", which I had heard a few times before, there were not really any songs that really hit me. But, as is so often the case with Coldplay's music, the songs grow on closer acquaintance.Without being right up the side of the group's greatest albums "A Rush of Blood to the Head" and "Viva la Vida" this is still a very nice and also a rather subdued album. The album starts off nicely with four strong songs with "Ink" as my immediate favorite. After these the albud loses the a little momentum and it not until "A Sky Full Of Stars" that it for a short while regains power. So, granted; a few numbers are actually a little boring.

This was the American version of The Small Faces' first Immediate album. As was often the practice at thetime, the precaution was taken in America to ensure that the artists’  singles were includes on the albums and moreover there were often fewer numbers on these albums. This meant that in several cases more albums could be released than in Europe. This phenomenon is known from many of the greatest acts of the time like The Beatles, The Rolling Stones and The Kinks. Whether there was similar ulterior motives behind this Small Faces release is uncertain;  in any case, there were no extra Small Faces albums released, although actually only 12 tracks were put on "There Are But Four Small Faces" and seven tracks from the European version were omitted.At any rate, "There Are But Four Small Faces" is a great album; one of the greats of this era. The three singles "Tin Soldier", "Here Come the Nice" and "Itchycoo Park" are great classics, and the two B-sides "I'm Only Dreaming" and "I Feel Much Better", which were not included on the European version, are both charming psych-pop mixed with a good portion soul. This applies by the way to the whole album, where no tracks fall through.But is there really a need for this release when now all tracks are also found on the deluxe edition of the European album. Maybe not – but personally as a big fan of the group, I think it is fine and lovely addition to the music collection and to a very reasonable price.  Some bonus tracks are previously unreleased versions or at least hard to find.There are both a stereo and mono CD, and in some case there are quite marked differences between the two versions. Also a fine booklet with relevant and interesting information. And yes, the music some great – as crystal clear as it gets.

As a longtime fan of Leonard Cohen and his songs, I must admit that I was a bit disappointed with his 2012 album "Old Ideas" - not that it was any direct weak album, but it somehow lacked something – perhaps there were too few really memorable songs.  So, my expectations for the sequel "Popular Problems" were not the greatest.Fortunately, there was no new disappointment.  With his latest album Cohen delivers a fine little album with good songs delivered in tasteful arrangements by Patrick Leonard. The counterpoint between Cohen's deep and somewhat worn vocals, and the beautiful female voices is one of the characteristics that I have always greatly appreciated.Sharon Robinson, who played a key role on many of the previous albums, both vocally and in her songwriting, is not credited with any involvement this time. In return, we get fine vocals from Charlean Carmon, Dana Glover and Donna Delory. The reason I feel the urge to highlight the female vocals is obviously recognizing that without these a Cohen album would hardly work - his voice is simply not what it once was."Popular Problems" is a cozy, sounding album with catchy songs, which can be enjoyed many times without becoming tedious. It can be difficult to highlight individual songs, as most of them are really good; maybe if I must I'd pick "You Got Me Singing", "Slow" and "A Street"

It was, of course, due to the contribution from Clarence White that made me buy this obscure live CD with the group Nashville West. In addition to the five original members Clarence White must be the most prominent personality who came into the Byrds during the many line-up changes of the band.Both his brilliant guitar playing, which is very easily recognised, and his also very distinctive vocals were important ingredients in the group from 1968 until the its dissolution in 1973.I seems obvious that these live recordings were hardly conceived as sanything worthy of commercial release; the sound is not very good, and had it not been for Clarence White, they probably would never have been released.In spite of the below sonics, it is possible rejoice White’s fine and always inventive playing. Unfortunately, we do not hear much to his vocals, which for me was something of a disappointment. The lead-singer Gib Guilbeau is at best ordinary and even though the rhythm section sounds experienced, it is never really exciting.This is obviously a release that appeals mostly to fans of Clarence White. Best tracks are "Sweet Susannah," "Ode to Billy Joe," "Sing Me Back Home", "Louisiana Rain" and of course White's own "Nashville West"

Apart from the movie soundtrack "Percy"  which I would call a solid 4 star album, I won’t hesitate to rate all the Kinks's Pye albums for sure 5 star albums. "Lola Versus Powerman & the Moneygoround" may not be in the category of  "The Village Green Preservation Society" , but it has more than enough to deserve all five stars.Like its predecessor, "Arthur" the album is  a concept album with a critical focus on the music industry. But the important thing is that the album contains a wealth of fine songs. In addition to the two classic hits "Lola" and "Apeman" you will find the very beautiful "Get Back in the Line", which was regular on the group's repertoire in the 1970’s. Also, "This Time Tomorrow" and the ballad "A Long Way From Home" are personal favorites. Among the more thematic songs "The Moneygoround" is both funny and biting. Dave Davies delivers one of his very best songs, "Strangers", which both musically and lyrically is simply great.Among the bonus tracks the two "new" songs are surprisingly good and sound pretty finished. They may not add anything decisively new, and it easy to understand that they were not selected in the first place; both numbers, though,  could easily have lifted on the sequel "Percy". The slightly pompous ballad "Anytime" is not bad, while "The Good Life" is more like a classic Kinks rocker."Percy", which in this deluxe version of the "Lola" functions as bonus CD, is in itself an excellent album which, however, is weakened by some uninteresting instrumentals; particularly the version of "Lola" is somewhat annoying.Otherwise, I prefer to focus on the marvelous songs "God's Children", "Moments" and "The Way Love Used to Be". Also "Dreams" belongs in the fine end. "Animals in the Zoo" with its Bo Diddley beat, also works fine while "Willesden Green", sung by John Dalton, is a good song that might mostly have been recorded for fun.Among the lesser-known tracks the waltzy "Just Friends" is a typical soundtrack number. "Completely" sounds almost like a "Fleetwood Mac" instrumental, while "Helga" really is both melodic and catchy.As a whole, this release is really a scoop with alternative single versions of familiar songs and a few outtakes.

The second album from "The Incredible String Band" is often categorized as psychelic folk. Apart from the interesting album-cover, I think probably that there is more folk than psychedelia on this album. Also, you don't sense a clear focus or direction of where the duo is headed.The group is at this time was reduced to the duo Heron and Williamson, who, as the debut  share the songwriting equally between them. As with its predecessor, it is clearly Heron’s songs that appeal most to me, and I will among those I will highlight "Chinese White", "Painting Box" and "Little Cloud". Part of his songs suffer somewhat from being exposed to pretty messy arrangements; with weird conga beats and guitars working in different directions.Most of Williamson's songs seem sketchy; some almost unfinished; Only in a few cases, you sense a clear and tight melody. His greatest contribution is probably "The First Girl I Loved", which has a fine chorus.As a whole, I think the album is disappointing. Very much a time-piece; sounds to me very dated.

I must admit that I do not have any big picture of the career of The Incredible String Band's career or of the group's many albums. However, I have over the years been presented to quite a few songs by the group and I have always felt that the music just lacked the last bit. Having recently re-listened to Mike Heron's two fine albums "Smiling With med Bad Reputation" and "Mike Heron's Reputation", I thought I’d give the group the "serious" new chance. I felt it natural to start from the beginning with the group's first selftitled album from 1966.I hardly know what to think; the album is pretty pure folk, with some inspiration from traditional music and artists like Woody Guthrie.It’s Mike Heron's songs that hit my taste in music the most with "Maybe Someday", "When the music Stars to Play" and "How happy I am" as some of the best. Robin Williamson's songs are also quite good; especially "October Song" and "Dandelion Blues", but I have a preference for Heron's; not least because of his much more interesting and personal vocals.The group was at this time a trio with banjo-player Clive Palmer as the third man; but the two main members Heron and Robinson are obviously the driving forces.

Mike Heron's second solo album from 1975 is not to the same degree as his debut "Smiling Men With Bad Reputation" characterized by many prominent guest appearances.On "Mike Heron's Reputation" the list of musicians is equally long, only many of these are less known than people like Pete Townshend, Ronnie Lane, John Cale , Richard Thompson and several others who contribute on the first album.Richard Thompson appears here only on a single track "Down on My Knees", which in turn is one of the highlights. Mike Heron's songwriting is generally fine and inspired; interesting that he on several numbers, both vocally and in his songwriting is similar to Cat Stevens. This goes, for my ears at least, for "Down on My Knees," "Angels in Disguise" (my favorite) and the equally fine "Meanwhile the Rain".Style-wise, Heron spreds over several genres and the folk-roots he is known for with The Incredible String Band is only obvious to a modest degree.Besides the already mentioned songs, the ballads "Evie" and "One of the Finest" should be highlighted. Basically "Mike Heron's Reputation" is a fine little album without direct weak or filler songs.Vocally Heron is nicely backed up on several songs by Linda Thompson, while teammate Robin Williamson is in the backing vocals choir on two songs. An interesting, but unfortunately not very significant Melanie, is also in the choir on two tracks.

I love a good fantasy/romance but I'm not sure exactly what this book is supposed to be.Some chapters seemed to be straight fantasy then the next is more about romance then it seems like the author veers off into yet another feel that I'm not sure how to explain.There are a few scenes with rather graphic violence which may be upsetting to some readers.I would be interested in seeing more from this author; I think she's seeking her "true voice" and look forward to her finding it.

I bought these after I got the purple ones and had lived with them a couple of weeks.The strips of water hyacinth look sort of like super thin pieces of bamboo woven with the colored threads.They lie nice and flat and don't have any bumps or bits that make plates feel wobbly,They spot clean very nicely ( dabbing gently with cool water on drips ) and don't show any stains or water marks.My set's color is pretty true to what is shown here; it's a very pretty turquoise and I love 'em!I plan to also get a set in red when they're back in stock.The thinness comes in handy when storing them in kitchen drawer; and they look really nice on my dark brown wood table.It's a good natural look which is right up my alley; I recommend them to anyone seeking a set of mats that are easy to clean, easy to store and VERY easy on the eyes!

I like this seasoning but it wasn't what I was hoping for.What I've been seeking is the old McCormick Vegetable Supreme. That seasoning got my picky hubby to actually like asparagus and broccoli!That had sesame seeds and a more buttery flavor than this; but I'm not saying this is bad.This is just different and not exactly what I was looking for.This has red bell pepper bits and no sesame seeds and it doesn't have the buttery flavor, but that's easy to compensate for by adding a dab of butter to the cooked veggies.I guess it's more like a blend of finely minced dried vegetables instead of something meant to enhance veggie flavor.My hubby still eats his veggies when I use this so I'll stick with it and look forward to trying it with different things, not just veggies.I think it's worth a try if you're seeking a flavorful seasoning for veggies or maybe chicken or fish. It definitely lifts the taste out of the usual and you don't have to use a lot.

These placemats are even better than I expected.The water hyacinth gives them a look and feel almost as if they'd used very thin pieces of bamboo interwoven with the colored thread.The color of the mats I received is true to the photo. And I really love how the dark purple/light-ish brown hyacinth strips look on my dark brown wood table. It gives it a very nice natural vibe.They lay nice and flat and there aren't any lumps or bumps that make plates, etc feel wobbly.I also like that since they're thin, they don't take up much room in my drawer. Makes it easier to order more colors ;-)I've been using this set for about 2 1/2 weeks now and they spot clean very well so far. The drips I've had to clean come right off and there aren't any obviously "dabbed at" marks. No water stain visible.And in 30+ years of marriage this is the ONLY set of placemats my hubby has commented on without my prompting! He really likes them!I was so happy with these purple mats that I ordered another set in teal and want to get the red ones when they're in stock again.All in all I recommend these for anyone wanting a lightweight, natural looking, easy to clean placemat set.

This is classic Nora Roberts romantic suspense with a touch of the supernatural.Yes, if you've read a few of her books the overall plot and outcome are predictable but what a fun way to spend some time!There's just enough suspense to keep things interesting without getting all dark and intense.What I really enjoyed is how she gives an older character a shot at romance; just cuz someone is over 40 doesn't mean they don't need romance and love and excitement.I wholeheartedly recommend this for NR fans or anyone seeking a rewarding few hours curled up with a fun book.

My cats love Cosmic catnip and I used to be able to get the larger sizes in local stores but no longer.I've tried many different nips and this seems to have to least waste in it; ie sticks and stems. It also seems fresher; it's not as dried out and old looking as some others I've tried. I get the big size because I'm owned by 4 cats don't want me to run out of nip!And because it's cheaper than buying it by the small bags which are all I can find locally as of now.A bottle this size lasts us around 6 months or so; and that's not bad for living with 4 unabashed nipheads...LOL

This is the third time I've purchased this desktop and it's because l really love it.Why buying for the 3rd time? Because I'm a heavy user of the keyboard and I have a bad habit of wearing the letters off.Hubby doesn't touch type; he hunts and pecks so he gets cranky when he can't see the letters.I also like how comfy this is; both the keyboard and mouse. Some of the more "curvy" ergonomic styles are awkward for me.Honestly, the ONLY reason I replace this set is for the missing letters. Otherwise they still work just fine but gotta keep my man happy...lol.

IMHO this is the best reusable water bottle EVER! At least in my experience of trying many, many reusable bottles and I've tried lots; including other stainless steel ones. Knocks plastic ones out of the game.It doesn't sweat, it doesn't leak if it gets knocked over; it truly does keep cold beverages cold as long as it says; ditto for warm beverages.It's very easy to wash and keep clean and the only reusable bottle I've had that doesn't develop that funky stale odor/taste that some made of other materials do after a while.To top it off the design is so cool! It's listed as navy but it's got enough purple tones to make this purple loving cat happy!Oh and it just happens to fit perfectly in the cup holder in my CRV. Bonus!

My hubby received one of these as part of a holiday gift bag from a TV show he works for, with the show's logo on it so that was cool.It's the best reusable water bottle I've ever seen! I don't know how many stainless steel and plastic bottles I've purchased over the last few years and they all were disappointing in many ways. Even the insulated bottles I bought wouldn't keep water cold in my car on a hot day for an hour. Almost all of them would sweat, even some of the insulated bottles. And after a few hours the water would taste stale or with some of the plastic bottles, it would get that funny "plasticky" taste. I wasn't thrilled with how well they washed either; some got nice and clean but others had spouts or other bits that were really hard to get to.This bottle doesn't have any of the above problems! And I recently discovered a great use for it.I got bitten by an evil flu bug and was running a fairly high fever so I was drinking a lot of water. After a few hours my hubby got tired of bringing me a fresh glass every hour or so, so I told him "break out that fancy new bottle you got and let's give it a try".He filled it with chilled, filtered water and boy did that bottle work great! I set it on the floor beside my bed and used it to refill my glass all night long. I didn't want to drink directly from the bottle since I was sick. Every glass was fresh and cold and tasted like it had NOT been sitting in a bottle. Since it was on the floor my cats knocked it over a time or two and not once did it leak even a tiny bit.It was so much better than having a carafe of water on my nightstand and not nearly as messy.I'm thrilled to find it on Amazon and plan to purchase at least one more so we each have one. IMHO it would also make a nice gift for just about anyone, not just fitness buffs. I'm hoping that it won't be long before Amazon has it available in more colors; I see them available from other sites but will wait to use my Amazon Smile account.Oh and I wanted to mention that the finish is nice and smooth but not shiny. It's a matte finish. The bottle my hubby got is much darker brown than this one and the wood grain stands out nicely; just enough to look almost real.All in all I highly recommend this product!

I'm going to be honest. Fans of Nora Roberts will love this!In so many ways it reads like her other trilogies but for NR fans that's a good thing!I got the Kindle version and have no complaints.This and other NR books really came in handy when I was laid up with a broken foot...great entertaining reads!

I'm going to be honest. Fans of Nora Roberts will love this!In so many ways it reads like her other collections but for NR fans that's a good thing!I got the Kindle version and have no complaints.This and other NR books really came in handy when I was laid up with a broken foot...great entertaining reads!

I'm going to be honest. Fans of Nora Roberts will love this!In so many ways it reads like her other trilogies but for NR fans that's a good thing!I got the Kindle version and have no complaints.This and other NR books really came in handy when I was laid up with a broken foot...great entertaining reads!

I don't believe I'm giving this only 4 stars.As a long time hardcore Stephen King fan, and a more recent fan of Joe Hill's I really looked forward to this.However, in the spirit of honesty I have to say this read like a Children of the Corn redux. It's not identical but anyone who's read The Children Of The Corn will recognize many elements.I got the Kindle version and I'm glad I did.Sadly I have to say if I'd paid more I'd have struggled between 3 and 4 stars...I'm giving 4 in part to the e-book savings.If you're new to SK and haven't read Children of the Corn yet, you'll probably get a nice creepy thrill from this story.But I doubt I'm the only old-time SK fan who would love to see a more creative and fresh collaboration from him and Joe.

I got the P-Touch label maker for hubby for Christmas LAST year...2013.He wanted white on black tape for it from the start but it wasn't until a couple months ago he found it.I don't know the exact model # of his P-Touch; I'm just happy he finally found his white on black tape!!We'll def come back for refills.

Hubby has searched far and wide to find tape for his Brother label maker that's a light color on black background and was thrilled to find this.Our order arrived on time and I'm sure when he needs a refill he'll come back.Sorry I don't know the model of his P-Touch off the top of my head...all I know is it's hard to find a variety of tape colors that fit it.

I am absolutely thrilled with this lamp!The pictures don't do it justice; when it's lit the intricacies of the metalwork really show. The hummingbirds' wings especially show off just how nice it is...they almost look like filigree. The glass behind the wings and in other trim is clearer than the moderately opaque quality of the other...the contrast is lovely.The colors are spectacular and the glasswork very well done. This isn't a cheap plastic wanna-be but a true work of art that should delight you for a long time.The shade is real metalwork and glass; not some cheap piece churned out by the thousands. I don't know enough about stained glass to determine if this was handmade but IMHO it sure seems that way. Someone somewhere had to put all the pieces together.One note; it says it recommends 60 watt bulbs but the lamp I received has 3-way ability. I started out with a 60 watt incandescent bulb but after trying the switch a couple times I realized it just might be 3 way! YAY I love it even more! I currently have a 3 way CFL bulb in it. It's the equivalent of a 30-70-100 and it works great.The light from the lamp is so warm and adds such a lovely feel to my living room.Honestly I didn't expect it to be so beautiful and of such high quality; only because the photos don't really show the detail and how well it's built. I also had a great experience with customer service. Prior to purchase I asked a question about the lamp and got email notification of a reply in less than 15 minutes! That's a first!The lamp does need to be assembled but it's super easy to do and it's very sturdy. The base is nice heavy metal; the deep bronze finish is so much prettier than the photo shows.I've been pleasantly surprised before on Amazon but this seller has set a very high bar with their combo of excellent service and a superior quality product.I've wanted a really nice Tiffany style lamp since I was old enough to know what a Tiffany lamp is. This lamp lives up to my dream and at a much more affordable price!And no I don't work for the company yada yada yada....I'm truly an over-the-moon customer.

Margaret's story overlaps other books Philippa Gregory has written about this time period but she gives it a fresh point of view.Speaking as a fan of Philippa's other books about the Cousins War and the Tudors I really enjoyed "hearing" Margaret Pole's voice.She endured so much and sacrificed so many loved ones in her effort to keep her family line alive...her efforts simply to survive were amazing and she deserved a better end.Her courage and discretion and strength in face of so many foes is admirable.Even if you've read "The Other Boleyn Girl" or "The White Queen" or "The Red Queen"  or "The Constant Princess" you'll enjoy Lady Stanley's life story.

YESSSS AC/DC is BACK! I've been an AC/DC fan since the 1970's and this is the best album they've done in quite a while.This truly recaptures their glory and energy from the first couple of albums with Brian Johnson as their lead singer.It sounds like classic AC/DC which is what a true fan wants and expects.I think I can sum up my feelings best by saying this CD makes me hope that AC/DC will be doing a tour in the US soon!!I would love to rock out to these songs live!

I'm embarrassed to say I'd forgotten about this album until I saw CSN in concert on October 4, 2014 and they performed the song "Cathedral" live.I had one of those "OMG I remember this song" moments!I came home that night and searched and found this.What a trip down memory lane once I got it! I don't know why I forgot about this album, other than it was one of many vinyl LPs ( 400 + ) that were stolen over 20 years ago and there was so much to do in the ensuing years....getting older means time goes so fast!I'm super happy that I re-discovered this and I'm not going to do a song-by-song critique...suffice it to say anyone who loves the first CSN album or CSNY Deja Vu will love adding this to their collection.

This is a lovely cotton blanket; super soft and not too heavy, not too light for my needs.I live in So Cal so wanted something for those cool nights when you don't want a heavy comforter or a wooly blanket but want more than a sheet.The thickness is comparable to an unlined knit fabric; kind of like a woven non-fleecy sweatshirt I guess. If that makes sense...LOL!I ordered the light blue and in reality it's a little more on the aqua side but it's still beautiful.It comes in a plastic zipper bag and when I first removed the blanket it had a funny smell.  But it went away after I left the folded blanket on a shelf overnight.I ordered a queen size and it's perfect for my Tempurpedic mattress which is thicker than some, so yeah it works great on deeper mattresses.All in all I'm really very happy with my purchase and just might get one in green, too!

This is one mess of a textbook.  It stands as evidence that, if someone prostitutes their intellectual services for a dumbed-down product and do so cheaply, then big-industry will repay in nepotism and continued royalties via numerous editions.  This is certainly a book that should not have made it to a first edition, let alone a sixth.The objective of such a book is impossible to say: it’s supposed to posture as some kind of introduction, yet what student will take away is minimal, if anything at all.  I have a good example from the first chapter.  Without even giving a reasonable introduction as to who Plato is and what his philosophical project entailed (and its objectives), Palmer goes into talking about how scholars have noticed a way of breaking down Plato’s dialogues into three parts.  Who cares?  The book certainly hasn’t established a reason for caring about this information at this point; they don’t even know who Plato was!What is the books objective?  Apparently, it is supposed to be an unimposing introduction to philosophy that is not imposing.  However, the author doesn’t develop much in the way of context when dropping little –very little– bits of information.  The book is set up as an amazingly superficial introduction topics, though it does get (too) convoluted and nuanced on topics that the author probably holds near and dear.  To be clear, the author does not develop a sense of what philosophical argumentation is, he doesn’t establish a strong historical thread (actually, he likes to revisit Greece in just about every chapter, as if he’s established ancient Greek philosophy as a basis for perspective and context), and he impotently presents philosophical issues.The book is written with cartoons smattered throughout, which makes for a lot less actual room for text.  You think your students are getting 300 pages of philosophy text, but you are getting slightly better than half that page count.  Finally, the book reads like mix between a comic book, a newspaper, and a scholarly work, often times chameleonically switching styles.  This book gives every bit of a feeling that the author went away to a country home in the summer, wrote continuously for 30 days, without much reflection about the product, and then sent it in to the publisher.  What’s more, being in the sixth edition, I expect that the project is too much of a mess to improve, so they probably make minor alterations semi-annually, so that they can continue to profit off of students.For professors (or students, for personal use) seeking an historical introduction to philosophy, I can recommend Enoch Stumpf’s text.  If a topic-based approach to the introduction of philosophy is the goal, then I can recommend Rauhut’s text.  These texts are probably not the best, but they are far-and-away better than Palmer’s text, here.

Finally, the book reads like mix between a comic book, a newspaper, and a scholarly work, often times chameleonically switching styles.  This book gives every bit of a feeling that the author went away to a country home in the summer, wrote continuously for 30 days, without much reflection about the product, and then sent it in to the publisher.  What’s more, being in the sixth edition, I expect that the project is too much of a mess to improve, so they probably make minor alterations semi-annually, so that they can continue to profit off of students.For professors (or students, for personal use) seeking an historical introduction to philosophy, I can recommend Enoch Stumpf’s text.  If a topic-based approach to the introduction of philosophy is the goal, then I can recommend Rauhut’s text.  These texts are probably not the best, but they are far-and-away better than Palmer’s text, here.

This is one mess of a textbook.  It stands as evidence that, if someone prostitutes their intellectual services for a dumbed-down product and do so cheaply, then big-industry will repay in nepotism and continued royalties via numerous editions.  This is certainly a book that should not have made it to a first edition, let alone a sixth.The objective of such a book is impossible to say: it’s supposed to posture as some kind of introduction, yet what student will take away is minimal, if anything at all.  I have a good example from the first chapter.  Without even giving a reasonable introduction as to who Plato is and what his philosophical project entailed (and its objectives), Palmer goes into talking about how scholars have noticed a way of breaking down Plato’s dialogues into three parts.  Who cares?  The book certainly hasn’t established a reason for caring about this information at this point; they don’t even know who Plato was!What is the books objective?  Apparently, it is supposed to be an unimposing introduction to philosophy that is not imposing.  However, the author doesn’t develop much in the way of context when dropping little –very little– bits of information.  The book is set up as an amazingly superficial introduction topics, though it does get (too) convoluted and nuanced on topics that the author probably holds near and dear.  To be clear, the author does not develop a sense of what philosophical argumentation is, he doesn’t establish a strong historical thread (actually, he likes to revisit Greece in just about every chapter, as if he’s established ancient Greek philosophy as a basis for perspective and context), and he impotently presents philosophical issues.The book is written with cartoons smattered throughout, which makes for a lot less actual room for text.  You think your students are getting 300 pages of philosophy text, but you are getting slightly better than half that page count.  Finally, the book reads like mix between a comic book, a newspaper, and a scholarly work, often times chameleonically switching styles.  This book gives every bit of a feeling that the author went away to a country home in the summer, wrote continuously for 30 days, without much reflection about the product, and then sent it in to the publisher.  What’s more, being in the sixth edition, I expect that the project is too much of a mess to improve, so they probably make minor alterations semi-annually, so that they can continue to profit off of students.For professors (or students, for personal use) seeking an historical introduction to philosophy, I can recommend Enoch Stumpf’s text.  If a topic-based approach to the introduction of philosophy is the goal, then I can recommend Rauhut’s text.  These texts are probably not the best, but they are far-and-away better than Palmer’s text, here.

I grabbed this book from the library, thinking that it would be a suitable read while pedaling on the recumbent bike at the gym.  I thought this because I am reasonably obsessed with chess –“reasonable,” in the sense that I don’t have chess piece soap or chess underwear, or anything crazy like that; you understand if you are familiar with the USCF tournament scene.  The book turned out to be a massive dud.  Many would dislike the academic manner of writing that Fine uses, though I actually enjoy the precision of this manner of writing.  However, the glaring problem is in the function of the book, i.e., what it intends to do.  My impression when grabbing it was that it is a book on how chess builds culture, in a value-oriented sense.  That is not so.  The book discusses how chess builds a chess culture, in an anthropological sense.  Though this approach would interest me slightly less, the idea of the project is still fairly interesting.  The problem, beyond that, is that book is horribly organized.  The book feels like a smattering of thoughts that were written down as notes, and then Fine left himself to write a book much later, but could not organize the information.  I doubt anthropological method dictates this kind of “organization.”  Worst of all, much of the book is a trite collection of anecdotes, quotes, and so forth –all of which are more than familiar to anyone involved in the spoken-of chess culture; and it is painfully obvious that the author really isn’t a part of this culture.The writing is not interesting, the function is dubious (i.e., I don’t know what the book truly intends to achieve or who the audience is supposed to be, considering the lack of academic polish), and the organization was plain bad.  There was a little bit of interest to me that I found in this book, which is the reason for two stars.  However, I can’t recommend this book to anyone.

I got this device as a gift long before I ever took up chess. What's most impressive to me is that more than 10 years later, this gizmo still functions as well as it ever did. I have no clue what the other reviewer is talking about, whenever he says the pieces are shoddy. The only problem I've had with the pieces, or the game in general, is that the magnet in the bottom of the pieces sometimes come unattached. However, a little dab of crazy glue has held the two (of thirty-two) in without fail. The pieces are very hard plastic, which have not cracked. My USCF tournament set has only last 3 years by comparison; so the Excalibur set is really remarkably well put together.One con to the product is that it is significantly smaller than a tournament board. (Note: a USCF tournament is designed to stretch across the entirety of most 2-person table spaces, while Excalibur is designed to sit comfortably in one's lap.) So if you want big pieces, this isn't the set for you. However, a major pro is that it is small, and since the piece are strongly magnetic, I have been able to us the board while on a Greyhound bus, sitting in the passenger seat of a car, and in a hammock.The playing strength of the set ranges from 1600-1900, but I'd say 1700 is a good estimate. If you are casual player and don't know what this means, take it to mean that the board's playing ability is much greater than yours.Excellent product. I'd recommend it to kids and adults alike.

This book is just bad.  I think it may only be acceptable to a casual player, but the problem with saying that is that I know better books for casual players looking to get some broad and general exposure in one book.  Examples of much better books for casual players have been written by authors like Pandolfini, Alburt, and Reinfeld.  I would say that the other negative reviews are right on.  This book is a rambling collection of games and fragments with no overarching purpose.  It’s not a step-by-step process, as the title suggests.  I didn’t even see many (any, possibly, because I can’t recall one) general nuggets of information to help one on the quest from casual player to mid-level Class player, let alone Master.Forget this book.  If you want legitimate suggestions, and you are a Class player already, look at Soltis’ “What It Takes to Become a Master.”  If you are a casual player, look at books by the authors I have mentioned above, as well as other titles that have “complete chess course” or similar in the title.

“Silman’s Complete Endgame Course” is easily the best, most pedagogically sound, and systematic approach to endgame study.  What’s more, it is effective for any player at any level, save GM.  My first introduction to endgames were Reuben Fine (a good book, but not a good first book) and Pandolfini’s book on edings (a good book, but not a great first book).  Silman very mindfully made the necessary adjustment to the arrangement of content, which is the primary failing of these other books I’ve mentioned, namely, that most books are just compilations based on type of endings (e.g., pawn endings, minor piece endings, etc.), not differentiated on the basis of difficulty and relevance.  I can’t tell you how many endings in Pandolfini’s endgame book I’ve never seen, or Fine’s, for that matter.  I went through Silman’s manual, first as a 1400, and I was seeing endings I had actually lost in USCF tournament games!  This is because he’s broken the chapters down into classes (Master [2200-2399], Expert [2000-2199], A-Class [1800-1999], B-Class [1600-1799], C-Class [1400-1599], D-Class [1200-1399], and so on).  In addition to that, not only does he give the most commonly seen and necessary(!) for a given strength, but he also has a pedagogical mind towards building knowledge systematically.  He first teaches the Philidor position in one section, then in a much later section (Expert, I think), he explains how to still achieve a draw when the Philidor position wasn’t quite possible to set up.  He also has this brilliant idea of “flow chart” thinking –and I mean this is just BRILLIANT!  In this kind of thinking, he takes a super complex position, even one that is still in the middle game, and asks you to imagine types of endings that might arise out of it, what forcing exchanges might move into that ending, and then explains how to put all the basic known endings into perspective with respect to the complex position.  I gained so much out of this that it is unreal!Another item I must comment upon is the tidbits of advice that Silman gives, which might cost someone hundreds, if not thousands, of dollars in one-on-one coaching time.  For instance, Silman says that, in his experience, he’s only had one time in which a game has resulted in a K, N, & B vs. a K, and most players never learn how to mate with just a N and B; so, if in dire straits, it could be a strategy to force a much stronger opponent into an ending of that kind.  I used this strategy, and it’s worked out twice!!  If you look at my USCF statistics, I drew a 1914-rated player as a 1445 player, and I drew a 1983-rated player (almost Expert!) as a 1526 player.  Both told me something like, “eh, I sort of know how to do it, and I thought I could do it if I needed, but obviously I couldn’t get the mate.”  These nuggets are strewn throughout the book.I should say something about the limitations of the book.  If you had to get one endgame book only, this is it.  However, I highly recommend supplementing it with “Practical Chess Endings” by Keres and “100 Endgames You Must Know” by de la Villa.  The reason is that there are important endings that are not covered by Silman, and he gives you some advice as to what you want to look for –he’s very, very aware of what he’s doing as a teacher, and the holes in his text are noted, as well as the reasoning for the existence of those holes.  For instance, he thinks the payoff for learning certain rook-and-pawn endings is too little for the amount of effort that would go into learning them; but he tells you what they are, which is of immense value.  He says the same of mating with a B & N.  In my experience, which is somewhat extensive in endings, the two books I mentioned are the best supplements to this text.In short, if there are only 10 books a Class player (1999 and lower USCF rating) could ever afford or own, Silman’s manual would be on my list of must-haves.

“Silman’s Complete Endgame Course” is easily the best, most pedagogically sound, and systematic approach to endgame study.  What’s more, it is effective for any player at any level, save GM.  My first introduction to endgames were Reuben Fine (a good book, but not a good first book) and Pandolfini’s book on edings (a good book, but not a great first book).  Silman very mindfully made the necessary adjustment to the arrangement of content, which is the primary failing of these other books I’ve mentioned, namely, that most books are just compilations based on type of endings (e.g., pawn endings, minor piece endings, etc.), not differentiated on the basis of difficulty and relevance.  I can’t tell you how many endings in Pandolfini’s endgame book I’ve never seen, or Fine’s, for that matter.  I went through Silman’s manual, first as a 1400, and I was seeing endings I had actually lost in USCF tournament games!  This is because he’s broken the chapters down into classes (Master [2200-2399], Expert [2000-2199], A-Class [1800-1999], B-Class [1600-1799], C-Class [1400-1599], D-Class [1200-1399], and so on).  In addition to that, not only does he give the most commonly seen and necessary(!) for a given strength, but he also has a pedagogical mind towards building knowledge systematically.  He first teaches the Philidor position in one section, then in a much later section (Expert, I think), he explains how to still achieve a draw when the Philidor position wasn’t quite possible to set up.  He also has this brilliant idea of “flow chart” thinking –and I mean this is just BRILLIANT!  In this kind of thinking, he takes a super complex position, even one that is still in the middle game, and asks you to imagine types of endings that might arise out of it, what forcing exchanges might move into that ending, and then explains how to put all the basic known endings into perspective with respect to the complex position.  I gained so much out of this that it is unreal!Another item I must comment upon is the tidbits of advice that Silman gives, which might cost someone hundreds, if not thousands, of dollars in one-on-one coaching time.  For instance, Silman says that, in his experience, he’s only had one time in which a game has resulted in a K, N, & B vs. a K, and most players never learn how to mate with just a N and B; so, if in dire straits, it could be a strategy to force a much stronger opponent into an ending of that kind.  I used this strategy, and it’s worked out twice!!  If you look at my USCF statistics, I drew a 1914-rated player as a 1445 player, and I drew a 1983-rated player (almost Expert!) as a 1526 player.  Both told me something like, “eh, I sort of know how to do it, and I thought I could do it if I needed, but obviously I couldn’t get the mate.”  These nuggets are strewn throughout the book.I should say something about the limitations of the book.  If you had to get one endgame book only, this is it.  However, I highly recommend supplementing it with “Practical Chess Endings” by Keres and “100 Endgames You Must Know” by de la Villa.  The reason is that there are important endings that are not covered by Silman, and he gives you some advice as to what you want to look for –he’s very, very aware of what he’s doing as a teacher, and the holes in his text are noted, as well as the reasoning for the existence of those holes.  For instance, he thinks the payoff for learning certain rook-and-pawn endings is too little for the amount of effort that would go into learning them; but he tells you what they are, which is of immense value.  He says the same of mating with a B & N.  In my experience, which is somewhat extensive in endings, the two books I mentioned are the best supplements to this text.In short, if there are only 10 books a Class player (1999 and lower USCF rating) could ever afford or own, Silman’s manual would be on my list of must-haves.

The only negative things I have to say about this book are: 1) the organization is bizarre as heck; and 2) I don’t think Yusupov has a very good sense of what is and what is not difficult.  The first point is more of an oddity than it is a serious detractor.  Each lesson is internally complete, so it is just weird that one finds the collection of topics in this book that one does.  As far as content, this is probably the most important content one needs at the high intermediate level to improve.  On the second point, Yusupov gives many reasonable problems, but I don’t think the exercises are always given the correct number of difficulty stars.  Some of the 3-star problems deserved 4, and some of the 2-star problems deserved 3.  There were also a number of 4- and 3-star problems that I thought should have been a star (or 2) less in rating.The book is all around exceptional.  The most important thing to know when considering this text is that it is difficult, and that I’m not sure that the intended audience is really the audience that should seek this book out.  I’m not sure what my USCF strength is (officially, my rating peaked at 1608, but I am very likely much stronger), but among myself and two friends --one rated 1660, the other 1780--, both of them had difficulty solving the average problem, while I was occasionally stumped.  If this book is intended to move players from 1500-1800, then it has a bizarre quality of being extremely difficult for players that are just about there and who are on the way.  The topics, themselves, are not out of the ordinary of what you’d expect for 1500-1800.  However, the degree of difficult makes me believe that the end goal of this first series of “1800” might be FIDE, not USCF; or maybe the end goal of this series is really 1850 FIDE, i.e., approx. 1950 USCF.  These are certainly not complaints, but clarifications for potential buyers and readers.  Let me be clear: this is the best system I have come across, and it is the most information dense.  I only wish to provide a caveat lector and caveat emptor, because I’ve spoken with players in the 1400’s and 1500’s (USCF) who said this book was horribly difficult, and they scored 3pts out of 22 on the sections with exercises (e.g., the book rates results as: 12 pts is “pass,” 16 pts “good,” 19pts is “excellent,” and these vary among chapters).The book includes content, as I said, that seems basic in name, but Yusupov makes it quite complex, rich, and sophisticated.  These areas included are tactical motifs, opening principles, Steintz’ strategic principles, and endgame concepts.  I really can’t believe I got so much out of this book, looking at some of the lesson titles, but I did.  I think that’s a testament to this book’s quality in developing sound fundamentals, even in advanced players.  About the only complaint I have on the content is that Yusupov claims that forced moves are the same as combinations.  While this is true for a professional player, I think the distinction has pedagogical value, and so it is legitimately a downside of this book.  That aside, this book is endlessly informative, and very deserving of the Bolaslavski Book Award –and it should be noted that Yusupov beat out some of the biggest names in chess teaching for the award, e.g. Dvoretsky.All in all, I have to recommend this to anyone around USCF 1500.  Despite the fact that much of it is easy for me, I see rapid improvement in my game, and I can only conclude that this system is shoring up my holes.

This is an excellent book.  The EDITION, NOT THE BOOK ITSELF, receives four stars instead of five because of the fact that I can’t stand the descriptive notation and Keres seems to be equally inefficient in the notation, give all of the errors in the text, which is the major reason I could not give the text five stars.Keres does a great job of supplying rules and theory, then giving concrete and very practical games where the theory and rules are applicable.  I think this is one of three books you need if you are U2200, the others being Silman’s “Complete Endgame Course” and “100 Endgames You Must Know” by de la Villa.  (Reuben Fine’s book might be added.)  The strength of this book is that it has a lot of the most important content that Silman and de la Villa are missing, but that is needed as a basis of endgame knowledge.  I have played countless decent club players (USCF 1500), who were able to play very savvy middlegames, and then not know that the middlegame was either drawn or lost for them.  This book rectifies those issues of basic knowledge.  I highly advise doing Silman’s manual, then doing de la Villa and Keres simultaneously.  Silman’s manual explains why this book is not as effect on its own, stating in his introduction that grouping all pawn endings and all rook endings, etc., is not very effective, because you are lumping all sorts of levels of information together, some remedial, some very complex, when doing so.All in all, I think this is one of the must-have/must-read texts.  I only wish they’d come out with a new edition.  Great book, sub-mediocre edition.

The reviews commenting on the numerous errors in this book are accurate.  However, I think there are plenty of positions in this book that are worth trying to work out.  If you can get this book for shipping costs only, then I recommend it.  If spending a buck or two won’t bother you, then you can go ahead and buy it for $2 or less but no more.One of the good aspects about this book is that the authors have a very good sense about how strong a player should be in order to correctly answer these problems.  There are three primary tactics sections (chapters) with increasingly difficult problems.  At the beginning of each, they let you know how many problems an advanced beginner, intermediate, and tournament player should get correct.  When I first went through this book in the December of 2007, I had learned how the pieces move two or three months prior, and I was able to hit just below the marks that the authors gave.  For example, an advanced beginner, for the first and easiest section, should be able to solve 64 out of 100 problems.  I solved about 20, indicating that I wasn’t an advanced beginner –and I wasn’t my USCF strength was about 1000.  Two years later, when I made it to 1600, I scored 80 out of 100, which is what they deem an intermediate player capable of.  Their “tournament player” strength distinction is probably in the A-class to Expert range (USCF 1800-2199), since I have been able to get just about 100 out of 100 on all three sections 5 years after the second attempt.  It’s difficult finding books with accurately rated tactics sets, so I think this is a very good book in that respect.Additionally, there are a few brief chapters on interesting topics like defense.  They are anything but comprehensive, but many might find that they add a little value to the book.Overall, the errors in solutions are a shame, especially considering that Mensa was willing to put their name on it.  In fact, some of the problems have better defenses that the authors did not see.  I would say that about 8% of this book has errors, to give you some idea.  For weaker players, this will be frustrating.  However, stronger players who are looking for a text to slowly work through and calculate might find it beneficial to examine whether the authors are wrong in some cases.  “Is there a better defense?” has been the question that I have asked on this last pass through the book, and I think it has helped me develop better defensive analysis.  All in all, reader beware.

I have a love-hate relationship with this book.  I love it because it is far-and-away the single best strategy and position-assessment book I have read.  I hate it because it could have been so much better, and Grooten is certainly good enough to have made it better in the ways that I think it could have been better.  Since the review is 5-stars, you can stop here and consider my recommendation for this book superlative.  However, I am going to start out by saying what was wrong with the book, after which I will talk about what’s so great.The negative comments made in some of the other reviews are spot on, such as the lack of organization of the book.  I really felt like some publisher or editor saw an instant classic in the works and rushed it to sale for the sake of dollar signs.  The biggest substantial problem with the book, which truly indicates to me that it was either rushed by an editor/published or for the sake of winning a chess book of the year award is that there are many, many critical places in the text where Grooten doesn’t answer this simple question: why?  I don’t think there’s a chapter where Grooten says something, makes some assessment, or the like, and takes the reasoning as tacit.  I’m becoming very strong amateur player (officially USCF tournament peak of 1608, and probably getting close to A-class or Expert strength), and I’ve absolutely never had this problem before.  This problem isn’t so chronic that it ruins the book.  Grooten is definitely teaching a great many things, but the punch line from a number of mini-lessons is simply missing.  I’ve been training with a GM, so he’s been able to fill me in on what Grooten was trying to say.  I think this all could have been avoided by having an A-class or Expert read the book, so that he or she could let him know that there was some critical piece of explanation missing.  There is a general explanatory problem in a couple of his chapters, such as the one on piece harmony, in which case a little bit more detail was needed on a few points; but this is not as big a concern as the previous concern.  Another big issue with the book is that some of Grooten’s examples have multiple themes working, not just the one that is being emphasized.  In fact, sometimes the emphasized theme isn’t the most important aspect of the example.  This could have been rectified by picking less complex examples where the theme is exhibited in greater isolation –and this can be a problem very easily, given the holistic nature of chess, with all the intertangled themes in so many positions.  Grooten also contradicts some notable authors on a few things, and probably didn’t realize it, and so he never explained.  For example, in the chapter on passed-pawns, he talks about the side with the passed-pawn wanting to exchange the minor pieces.  What?  Lev Alburt and Jeremy Silman both said that minor piece push and halt passed-pawns, so keep them on the board!  I did not think for a minute that Grooten was wrong, but that there was something different about Grooten’s examples and those of Alburt and Silman’s.  The difference was how advanced the pawns are.  With a space advantaged generated by a far passed-pawns, activity of the opposing pieces are reduced if those pieces are rooks rather than knights and bishops.  (Notice how I’ve just mentioned that space and activity are thematic in this chapter, though it is supposed to be about the passed-pawn.)  It took me and my coach about an hour to examine Grooten’s, Silman’s, and Alburt’s examples to figure out what the deal was.  All of the other issues I had with the book are much less than these.What’s great about the book?  The book is structure around Steinitz’ elements; which is to say, the objective and idea behind the book is really solid, and it lends to the effectiveness of the text.  I also think that the book is enjoyably written –Grooten is anything but a boring writer, so that should not be a concern.  I’ve read a number of strategy and position-assessment books, and this is by far the best.  This area of chess is lacking in quantity and quality literature.  In a space almost exclusively dominated by a few classics, this book is the most in-depth and expansive book I have come across.  The amount of quality ideas and content this book contains is unreal; it really is.  Not only that, I think it serves a large field of readers.  Ideally, I think the book is best for 1600-2200, but it is very easily accessible to any player under 800.  Even at a USCF rating of 800, a great many of the concepts this book teaches can be assimilated.  The thing is that, as with all classics, the book requires reading and re-reading.  I am very confident that, with each pass through this book, I will develop much more knowledge than I previously possessed.  For the unclarity that some parts of Grooten’s text suffers in some places, it more than makes up for in other places.  That’s why I am disappointed in some regards, because most of the book is simple exceptional and crystal clear.  To give you some idea, if you thought “Chess for Post-Beginners” by Srokovsky was good, this one is world’s better.  In fact, that book purports to be aimed at players 1400-2200 (and it’s received rave reviews), yet the analysis in this book is much deeper, more thorough, and the explanations a bit lengthier for clarity.One thing that should be noted is that this is a difficult book in a number of ways.  Grooten even says that the reader should not sweat it if he or she does not get the solutions to exercises.  One friend, a very positional 1500-level USCF player, said that the book was tough but manageable.  A very tactical player (1850’s USCF) and friend, who is weak positionally, said that the book was extremely tough.  For me, I thought the book was challenging because Grooten sometimes assumes that you see the tactics that are forcing situations.  Finding the tactics, whenever he doesn’t fill in the details, can be seen as a tactics puzzle.  You can tell that this text is fairly high-level, because positional strength and weakness is tied in very closely with the tactics and threats required to achieve strategies; again, chess has a kind of holism at work.Excellent book.  I recommend it to any player under 2200.

In fact, that book purports to be aimed at players 1400-2200 (and it’s received rave reviews), yet the analysis in this book is much deeper, more thorough, and the explanations a bit lengthier for clarity.One thing that should be noted is that this is a difficult book in a number of ways.  Grooten even says that the reader should not sweat it if he or she does not get the solutions to exercises.  One friend, a very positional 1500-level USCF player, said that the book was tough but manageable.  A very tactical player (1850’s USCF) and friend, who is weak positionally, said that the book was extremely tough.  For me, I thought the book was challenging because Grooten sometimes assumes that you see the tactics that are forcing situations.  Finding the tactics, whenever he doesn’t fill in the details, can be seen as a tactics puzzle.  You can tell that this text is fairly high-level, because positional strength and weakness is tied in very closely with the tactics and threats required to achieve strategies; again, chess has a kind of holism at work.Excellent book.  I recommend it to any player under 2200.

I have a love-hate relationship with this book.  I love it because it is far-and-away the single best strategy and position-assessment book I have read.  I hate it because it could have been so much better, and Grooten is certainly good enough to have made it better in the ways that I think it could have been better.  Since the review is 5-stars, you can stop here and consider my recommendation for this book superlative.  However, I am going to start out by saying what was wrong with the book, after which I will talk about what’s so great.The negative comments made in some of the other reviews are spot on, such as the lack of organization of the book.  I really felt like some publisher or editor saw an instant classic in the works and rushed it to sale for the sake of dollar signs.  The biggest substantial problem with the book, which truly indicates to me that it was either rushed by an editor/published or for the sake of winning a chess book of the year award is that there are many, many critical places in the text where Grooten doesn’t answer this simple question: why?  I don’t think there’s a chapter where Grooten says something, makes some assessment, or the like, and takes the reasoning as tacit.  I’m becoming very strong amateur player (officially USCF tournament peak of 1608, and probably getting close to A-class or Expert strength), and I’ve absolutely never had this problem before.  This problem isn’t so chronic that it ruins the book.  Grooten is definitely teaching a great many things, but the punch line from a number of mini-lessons is simply missing.  I’ve been training with a GM, so he’s been able to fill me in on what Grooten was trying to say.  I think this all could have been avoided by having an A-class or Expert read the book, so that he or she could let him know that there was some critical piece of explanation missing.  There is a general explanatory problem in a couple of his chapters, such as the one on piece harmony, in which case a little bit more detail was needed on a few points; but this is not as big a concern as the previous concern.  Another big issue with the book is that some of Grooten’s examples have multiple themes working, not just the one that is being emphasized.  In fact, sometimes the emphasized theme isn’t the most important aspect of the example.  This could have been rectified by picking less complex examples where the theme is exhibited in greater isolation –and this can be a problem very easily, given the holistic nature of chess, with all the intertangled themes in so many positions.  Grooten also contradicts some notable authors on a few things, and probably didn’t realize it, and so he never explained.  For example, in the chapter on passed-pawns, he talks about the side with the passed-pawn wanting to exchange the minor pieces.  What?  Lev Alburt and Jeremy Silman both said that minor piece push and halt passed-pawns, so keep them on the board!  I did not think for a minute that Grooten was wrong, but that there was something different about Grooten’s examples and those of Alburt and Silman’s.  The difference was how advanced the pawns are.  With a space advantaged generated by a far passed-pawns, activity of the opposing pieces are reduced if those pieces are rooks rather than knights and bishops.  (Notice how I’ve just mentioned that space and activity are thematic in this chapter, though it is supposed to be about the passed-pawn.)  It took me and my coach about an hour to examine Grooten’s, Silman’s, and Alburt’s examples to figure out what the deal was.  All of the other issues I had with the book are much less than these.What’s great about the book?  The book is structure around Steinitz’ elements; which is to say, the objective and idea behind the book is really solid, and it lends to the effectiveness of the text.  I also think that the book is enjoyably written –Grooten is anything but a boring writer, so that should not be a concern.  I’ve read a number of strategy and position-assessment books, and this is by far the best.  This area of chess is lacking in quantity and quality literature.  In a space almost exclusively dominated by a few classics, this book is the most in-depth and expansive book I have come across.  The amount of quality ideas and content this book contains is unreal; it really is.  Not only that, I think it serves a large field of readers.  Ideally, I think the book is best for 1600-2200, but it is very easily accessible to any player under 800.  Even at a USCF rating of 800, a great many of the concepts this book teaches can be assimilated.  The thing is that, as with all classics, the book requires reading and re-reading.  I am very confident that, with each pass through this book, I will develop much more knowledge than I previously possessed.  For the unclarity that some parts of Grooten’s text suffers in some places, it more than makes up for in other places.  That’s why I am disappointed in some regards, because most of the book is simple exceptional and crystal clear.  To give you some idea, if you thought “Chess for Post-Beginners” by Srokovsky was good, this one is world’s better.  In fact, that book purports to be aimed at players 1400-2200 (and it’s received rave reviews), yet the analysis in this book is much deeper, more thorough, and the explanations a bit lengthier for clarity.One thing that should be noted is that this is a difficult book in a number of ways.  Grooten even says that the reader should not sweat it if he or she does not get the solutions to exercises.  One friend, a very positional 1500-level USCF player, said that the book was tough but manageable.  A very tactical player (1850’s USCF) and friend, who is weak positionally, said that the book was extremely tough.  For me, I thought the book was challenging because Grooten sometimes assumes that you see the tactics that are forcing situations.  Finding the tactics, whenever he doesn’t fill in the details, can be seen as a tactics puzzle.  You can tell that this text is fairly high-level, because positional strength and weakness is tied in very closely with the tactics and threats required to achieve strategies; again, chess has a kind of holism at work.Excellent book.  I recommend it to any player under 2200.
