This is an excellent book, and I’d like to start by addressing one of the nonsense reviews for this book.  A one-star review notes that the publisher chose the “wrong” author to write this book.  The reasoning was that this player doesn’t believe in the Caro-Kann.  If there’s anyone who you want to write a book on an opening, it’s either an expert who plays that opening or someone who is an expert in busting it –and who, therefore, does not believe in the opening.  When you got the a book on the Caro-Kann or any opening, I hope the reader is seeking out the theory of how to play against it as much as play it.  These are separate theories, but are one single theory, where black tries to defeat white strategies, white trying to bust black’s.  Claiming that Gallagher is the “wrong” author is flat out moronic, and it also demonstrates the lack of so much as one iota of understanding about chess.  If anything, as a starting out player, I want to know how I can expect to be busted so that I can work against those ideas over the board.  If anything, an author like Gallagher is a plus for a starting out book.  I no longer play the Caro-Kann as balck, but this book’s content is still with me, as I have become a strong player against the Caro-Kann.  I score exceptionally well on both sides, and I’ve never looked at another Caro-Kann source, so I think it is safe to say that this book did the trick for me.  On to the content of this book.I absolutely love the “Starting Out” series.  I really don’t think it is worth the time for players under 2000 to look at openings much, but some superficial knowledge, mostly in the form of ideas for strategic purposes, can go a long way.  This was my first opening book.  When starting out as a 1000-level player, avoiding the tricks and traps of other weak players can be a nightmare.  Learning the ideas and basic moves of this opening helped me get into a middle game where it was simply my playing ability against the others’.  This book has the mainline theory at the start of each chapter, a breakdown of ideas and possibilities, and then it gives practical applications of those ideas in the form of practical games.  This is the layout for most all of the “Starting Out” books, and I think it is a recipe for success.This book should be for any player USCF rated under 2000, but I know all too many booked-up A-class players, so I will simply say that this book geared toward those who have no grounding or formal familiarity with the Caro-Kann.  I played the first 3 Lopez moves for quite some time before learning any of the opening’s ideas, learning some of the ideas on my own, but this book kicked me into a state of solid, basic theoretical understanding of the opening.  This series’ recipe certainly works for me, and I expect it will work for players who aren’t booked-up class players, but are similar players who have focused on tactics, positional play, strategy, endings, and so forth.

I absolutely love the “Starting Out” series.  I really don’t think it is worth the time for players under 2000 to look at openings much, but some superficial knowledge, mostly in the form of ideas for strategic purposes, can go a long way.  In preparing for a particular Expert level player (I was only 1477), I needed some ideas for the white side of the Lopez, and this book gave me everything I needed to get a draw (USCF rated G/120) –a fine result, given the rating disparity.  This book has the mainline theory at the start of each chapter, a breakdown of ideas and possibilities, and then it gives practical applications of those ideas in the form of practical games.  This is the layout for most all of the “Starting Out” books, and I think it is a recipe for success.This book should be for any player USCF rated under 2000, but I know all too many booked-up A-class players, so I will simply say that this book geared toward those who have no grounding or formal familiarity with the Ruy Lopez (aka the Spanish Game).  I played the first 3 Lopez moves for quite some time before formally learning the theory of the opening, learning some of the ideas on my own, but this book kicked me into a state of solid, basic theoretical understanding of the opening.  This series’ recipe certainly works for me, and I expect it will work for players who aren’t booked-up class players, but are similar players who have focused on tactics, positional play, strategy, endings, and so forth.

Still one of my favorite books.  I read this book when I was a 1000-level player.  I had read the first few pages of Silman’s “Amateur’s Mind,” and I learned that it is very important to annotate games that have already been annotated by a National Master, International Master, or Grandmaster.  Chernev’s book is fantastic for that, especially for the simple fact that it annotates every move of every game.  (If you want to use Chernev’s book for this, cover up subsequent moves, try to decide the reason for the first move, decide upon plans and candidate moves, then see what the text move was; then try to figure out why it differed from your candidate moves or choice before looking at Chernev’s annotation.)  I’m not sure what Chernev’s background is, but he most certainly has a love for pedagogy, so he may have been a teacher, professor, or chess trainer.  His games all have some very isolated, very interesting and valuable lesson.  Some of the games have a couple of important themes, which Chernev makes clear, such as the weakening of a square, followed by a well-layed out explanation of the tactical pressure that it creates, and then the interesting endgame part of the lesson.  The clarity of Chernev’s ideas and discussion is really remarkable.  I found this book to be so worthwhile that I devoured it within a very short time, and I saw the benefits in my own game and an increase in my USCF rating.As I return to the book officially rated 600 pts higher (and probably with an unofficial strength of 1000 points greater), I come to the same games with positional and tactical knowledge that I didn’t have before, and I am finding that there are still concepts I can glean from Chernev’s book.  I can’t go as far as to say that players in the USCF 2000-2200 (1900-2100 FIDE) range will get too much out of this text, but it certainly is an enjoyable text, even if you haven’t much to gain.  Since the games are classics and some of the lesser known classics, it’s a great collection, regardless of whether you are looking for annotation or a collection of interesting classic games.  Players under 1700 will get the most out of this book.Note to Experts, 2000+ USCF and 1900+ FIDE: the annotations are not the typical of the depth you are looking for.  All of the relevant sidelines are not examined, only the major variations which a club player would probably find, as well as some of the more important (i.e., critical) lines.Note to players closer to beginner level: As I said, these games are classics, so don’t get too hung up on the openings, trying to learn opening theory from this.  The opening moves are logical, but most of them are no longer played, or at least have some variation upon the ones in this book.  Therefore, this book is great for learning opening principles, but forget about trying to memorize the moves for your own games, unless you play casually and not very competitively.

The back matter clarifies who the audience is intended to be: “Helps beginners to develop a solid understanding of fundamental opening ideas.  Gives casual players the ability to choose the opening that suits their style and taste.  A tool for club players to test and review their opening repertoire.  A reference to which advanced player keep returning.”  As a club who has unofficially become advanced (possibly near Expert strength), I don’t know that I will be returning to this set except for when I begin using new openings, but this set is very good for giving some of the ideas in certain lines.  Any inkling that these volumes are sparse on explanations is not far off.  I have complained to myself in a number of places in the text about the omission of an explanation for moves.  I think the set does a good job of commenting effectively on most of the critical moves in lines.  There are a number of things I like about this set and some things that I don’t like, but, overall, I think you are getting a decent value out of these, if you are using them to begin the learning process or want a compendious reference set.  I have waited really until very late to begin learning openings, and so I can’t say for sure, but it seems to me that this set is fairly exhaustive over all openings and variations.  For this reason, the expansiveness of the volumes, one cannot expect in-depth commentary from relatively so few pages, especially considering that the volumes include games to illustrate the openings.  The illustrative games are one of my complaints about this set.  There is no explanation given on the moves in the illustrative games.  For this reason, I highly, highly, highly recommend that opening-learners use this set in tandem with Everyman’s “Starting Out” series for the openings that you want to play in tournament games.  That is to say, this set is not a one-stop-shop for tournament-strength players.  However, if you want to get an idea of how play lines that you have no interest in studying, this is a great set.  It elaborates in a way that most wish the “Modern Chess Openings” would.  In that way, this is much better than the ever-cryptic MCO, though the MCO has more lines evaluated, if you are looking to do your own research and want to be a little creative in your next tournament.The text in these books is fantastic.  The pages are nice to look at, they have clear printing, and make use of different colors in text and in the diagrams to highlight and emphasis different ideas or key things to pay attention to.  If you are familiar with the aesthetically pleasing nature of Lev Alburt’s later books, and you like those, then it is worth knowing that these volumes are on about the same par.  My only complaint with the text is that the authors denote where every piece is coming from in addition to where it is going.  For example, the first two moves for white in the Sicilian are written as “e2-e4” and “Ng1-f3.”  I found this horribly annoying and distracting, sometimes making the wrong piece moves on the board or in my head, because I tend to glance at the book to determine move orders. I imagine that they’ve done this to better serve the beginner, causal, and weaker club players, because the cost of the extra ink must have been noticeable in their bottom line.In short, the set is a good companion for studying openings for USCF/FIDE tournament play, but it could be a good one-stop-shop for beginners and casual players who seek less explanation than upper-level club and advanced players desire.
