Ram Dass says that Swami Muktananda used to eat from 24 carat gold plates and drink from solid gold goblets.Being enlightened, Swami Muktananda was above even gold. Swami Muktananda must have ordered his devotees to go out into the world to get the solid gold wears to place on his table, so he could show people that he saw gold and mud, and the world, with One vision.When Ram Dass told this story, I thought, where the hell do you find 24 carat gold goblets in Southern India?Ram Dass probably made it all up.Anyway, people report powers coming out of the Swami Muktananda and this is what this book is all about. The Swami spills the beans, as it where.. They say Adi Da Samraj also had the power, so even if it isn't enlightenment, it is still a sort of magic that we in the west don't know about.It's hard to feel shakti from Swami Muktananda by looking at his picture. Many people in the book claim that they do. Maybe you had to be in His presence first for the link to happen like in quantum none-locality where you touch a person and you are forever linked. Well I can't get it from staring at His photograph so maybe this is the case.Its also hard to tell charisma coming out of the picture of a charismatic person. We've all met super charismatic people but if we take their picture, the charisma isn't in the photograph. This is why you have to stand next to the guru to feel the power.In this book, there is much guru worship going on but I'm not one to judge.Swami Muktananda gave Franklin Jones (Adi Da) his terrifying shakti powers and look how powerful Jones became? Many attest to the power of Swami Miktananda. There was mayhem and madness in the circus concerning the swami.Even if he wasn't enlightened, there is some heavy mystery surrounding the man. The answers he gives are educational and you can chew over what he says for ages. This is hardcore guru devotion so be prepared. However, this isn't a book that will inspire you to be your own guru.The book itself is printed on quality pages and you have over 500 pages of Swami Muktananda, so I'm glad I ordered it.

Philippa Rees has been unknown for way too long. I feel this travesty is about to be rectified, for this is the nature of genius. Who else has the right hemispheric power of epic poetry and the left hemisphere to tackle scientism?Indeed, the strangle hold scientism has on culture is loosening.With this book, I feel the key has been retrieved from the dudgeons of scientism.With the poetic splendour of Homer and the gravity of One who knows, Involution: An Odyssey Reconciling Science to God, dangles the keys to salvation in front of our nose.The awakened one, you see, is not a sleeper, like you and me. She's isn't a teacher; let alone a preacher. Neither a prophet, nor looking to profit. She isn't a snake, or an obvious fake. She is awake!

This book is about the hellish rape of the German women and children and the German soul. The allies were vicious. Hell has no fury like the allied revenge meted on the German people. You need a strong stomach read this book.As an aside, just think, all those little old men in our hometown. Those sweet old men we helped cross the road or held the door open for, those men were the 'men' Ralph Franklin Keeling describes in Gruesome Harvest, but aged like Jimmy Saville. A million Jimmy Saville's descended on defeated Germany. This is a terrifying image!

Ronald Regan was also seen as an insignificant puppet of the Zionist Overloads, like Tony Blair, but look how they promote the legend of Regan? Thatcher was also a puppet, but not of Zion, rather, of the Bilderberg gang, before the Zionists took it over in the 1990's.There is a video on You Tube, Ken Clark is being grilled in parliament and Ken admits he's been a member of Bilderberg for years, as have most ministers, and Clarke even names a few politicians on the opposite bench. You couldn't make it up!Anyway, even when I watch Thacher on You Tube I'm amazed how stupid and slow she was. At least Tony Blair was a fast talker. Just watch Thatcher. This woman was not articulate. They say that her handlers told her to speak slow so as not to seem too threatening. But you can't act stupid and slow for a decade. Thatcher was really slow! George Bush wasn't acting either and Thatcher was extremely stupid and those can't see her stupidity can't see the rigged electoral system and they are sealing their great grandchildren's slavery.For whom the Gods wish to destroy they first turn them into dummies!

Roman and Teuton is surprisingly very picturesque and brilliant. Here we have a writer, rather than an academic, so the story telling is very whimsical, with references to fairies, trolls and other tolkienesque moffits and, of course, teutons, the new kids on the block, so to speak.The man of olden times is Rome, the master for whom the Teuton will eventually replace with his mighty arms of youth.The Romans and the Teuton was written for the lecture hall so the writing is very rich in character, because it is directed at an audience, filled with dramatic tension and even if it is, what we call today, 'politically incorrect', this shows that it is us who are living in a mental straight jacket and not the Victorians.Tolkein was steeped in Medieval literature and Edward Gibbon and it shows in his books and this is what Roman and Teuton feels like.Kingsley sounds over the top in his descriptions, like a novelist, of fierce but beautiful Teutons rampaging over Rome and breeding fresh life into a dying world, but he knows the primary sources and he isn't an academic so he let's his hair down, so to speak.A word of warning, Kingsley is a Christian and they don't really exist in England anymore but that isn't a problem for me. I will rather have God in here that bloody Allah, any day of the week!Charles Kingsley was also a childrens book writer and these lectures far outweigh the scribbling of the devastatingly dry academic, choked by careerism, pseudo objectivity and relativism.

Ralph Metzner was there from the very beginning of time, before the Big Bang. Dr Metzner tripped with Timothy Leary, he knew Terence McKenna and, for my money, he was smarter than all of the psychedelic big wigs. This man was there, in the background, like Forrest Gump, waiting for the right time to pounce like a crazy leopard. Now he's spilling the beans about the meaning of life, which is what the Ayahuasca continuum is all about.

I like the name Rama kant. Rama is God and Kant is philosophy. Synchronicities are there to guide us and I like the name 'Ramakant Maharaj'. We can translate Ramakant as God-jnana.Kant, said, "Only the descent into the hell of self-knowledge can pave the way to godliness".  "Look", said Jesus, "The Kingdom is within you"!If we plunge into our self, we reveal the Divine.We are bliss machines and as Martin Heidegger said, "The person isn't a thing or a process but an opening from which the Absolute manifests itself". Selfless Self: Talks with Shri Ramakant Maharaj is the opening!Here we have the high road, the Devayana, of spirituality.

I like the scene where Miguel Serrano is in an ancient part of india, probably Westernised by now, where, Serrano writes, a cow is walking along the pavement, head held high, owning the way as the people move, and some even bow. Serrano comments that this snap-shot, so to speak, is the last of a 10 thousand year link where the cow is equal to man. The link is now gone.Miguel Serrano is very lucky to have witnessed this amazing miracle of a scene. As we 'progress', we will never see this scene again. There were once sages and heroes who's mannerisms were just as alien as this scene, to which the bowing to the cow is a last remnant of a vanished psyche. He wasn't to know, but on seeing the indians act this way, Miguel Serrano was transported to the age of Odysseus.It is written in the Vedas that the house cow was to give her calf the milk before the rest of the human family. I once came upon a cow on a farm path and her eyes showed deep intelligence. I can't explain, but the cow looked deeper than the stupid dog or the milky cat. There was something there that I couldn't dismiss. It seems today that many are blind. The definition of the kali-yuga is that humans lose the link and turn to weights and measures for their 'spirituality'. Only those with the link can see the cow in her splendid majesty.Serrano witnessed the last of the humans bowing to the sacred cow, before McDonalds moved in for the kill.

Edmund Burke wrote of the triumph of the psychopathic mind, and the death of the noble, "It is gone, that sensibility of principle, that chastity of honour, which felt a stain like a wound ... The age of chivalry is gone. That of sophists, economists and calculators, has succeeded; and the glory of Europe is extinguished for ever."The psychopathic mind craves revenge and the slaughter of women and children. Never in history has the petty thirst for blood be so pronounced and yet so normalized by a docile population, propagandized from cradle to grave to go along with the crowd.On February 10, 1944 the Yalta Conference ended, where Mr. Roosevelt, in private conversation with Stalin, had said he was feeling "more bloodthirsty" than before about the Germans.In 1944, Germany was a cinder, except for the ancient city of Dresden. Dresden, with her many churches, will be a refuge.The trembling women and children flocked together in the streets, like a herd of timid animals, as if the accumulated weakness could be productive of strength, or in the vein hope that amid the crowd each individual might be safe and invisible.From every point of the city the bombers flew over, like in the Pink Floyd video where the fascist eagle overshadows the city and the hammers march down the street, and in the space of an hour, those women and children were burnt in the Hell fires.

FH Bradley wrote a letter to Bertrand Russel explaining that, as he ages, he finds refuge more and more 'in the unknown and the unknowable'.Bertrand Russel didn't reply.This is the difference between East and West.Surely, Russel must have thought, the unknown is by definition void? This is logical.Why is Bradley claiming to be living in void?In India, the philosophical method of Bradley is jnana yoga. Indians claim that the path of knowledge can lead to enlightenment. But only the highly gifted philosopher can transcend.  The unknown and unknowable are known only to the jnani. So FH Bradley was really experiencing the state of the Buddha, a state beyond description, like the way a Bach melody is beyond description, not because it is impossible, but because it is of a higher magnitude of ponderance than that of logic. The Absolute is lost to Bertrand Russel because a giant can never fit into the shoes of a dwarf.This explains the cryptic statement of FH Bradley.As you can see, FH Bradley was born on the wrong continent.FH Bradley was ahead of his time. His meditations on the Absolute were lampooned by philosophers like Bertrand Russell but the terrestrial logical mind, forever in the dark, can only snigger like a Monty Python actor because, as Goethe wrote."I see the learning in what you say.What you don't touch, for you lies miles awayWhat you don't grasp, is wholly lost to youWhat you don't reckon, you believe not trueWhat you don't weigh, this has for you no weightWhat you don't count, you're sure is counterfeit".Goethe is describing the mentality of Bertrand Russel.Why else is idealism lampooned in the academy and not taken seriously? I'm reading chunks of Bradley's Appearance and Reality and even tho the wording is stiff and Victorian, I have come across these ideas in india.

James Lancia is telling the other side of the story. He sounds like a decent working class guy. The rich media people demonise people like James Lancia. I'm on the side of the workers, and so I'm supporting this cop.

At the end of Elementary Particles, the scene set in the future, an exhausted human race embraces technological nihilism. To be sheeple, forever herded by robots, was Michel Houellebecq's brilliant answer to nihilism. The singularitarian movement is based on nihilism. God is dead but we'll invent our own Gods! In other words, the true meaning, we cancel ourselves out, to be replaced by the void.Many transhumanists philosophers are so clever that they can paint the crazier ideas as life embracing. You don't get cleverer that Michel Houellebecq.In Submission, Islam is the answer. They say Michel Houellebecq was on the run because he was critical of Islam. That's marketing.The idea of artificial intelligence and robots is old hat. What isn't old hat is muslim demographics. Islam is the next big thing and the non muslim the birthrate has collapse anyway, and nihilism has crept into materialism, so why not?In all honesty, an Islamic France, and Europe, won't be all that bad and Submission is as realistic as you can get. I mean, it's not like modern materialism makes people happy.Houellebecq writes, in the form of the character 'Rediger', so why not a return to God? The family is broken anyway, Rediger argues, and the reason for the collapsing birthrate is that women have become slaves for the hourly wage. Who has time to make babies anyway?In the modern world, couples both work like dogs, until, like lead, they return home, almost dead! At least Islam embraces family values. Islam is a revolt against the modern world. The modern world being materialism, the slave mentality of the female, the corporate suite, the destroyer of the family.Michel Houellebecq explains all this very well.The last 40 pages is a philosophical treasure trove of high flying philosophy. Michel Houellebecq is a philosopher of the highest order.

In the Gospel of Buddha, we find these words: "He (you and me) will call resignation what to the Enlightened One is purest Joy. He will see annihilation where the Perfect One finds Immortality. He will regard as death what the Conqueror of Self knows to be Life Everlasting.The ego will interpret its negation as void. The ego is not That, it cannot go where the Buddha goes. We think we are ego.If the ego is seen as real, then Nirvana is a blowing away, a nihilism.You see, That, Nirvana, Brahman, beyond space, time and causation will necessary be seen as 'no thing', as unreal, as void, to the not-enlightened person.Thus death will be feared, dreaded, denied.It is only when the ego is seen to be dreamlike illusion, what is not this will at the same time be seen as what is.Void then is not your enemy, but your true self.It is the function of the ego to hide this from you.In the Gospel of Thomas, Jesus said, "Whoever understands these words will not taste death".

This is a wonderful book. Top scholars and scientists asked the Maharshi all sorts of questions about life, death, enlightenment and spiritual practice. This is a fascinating window into a real spiritual abode.The conmen and hucksters only baffle and strangle the spirit. Hearing the words of Ramana Maharshi is like taking a tight shoe off. You can breath a sigh of relief.

The way no reviewer notices that Tony Parsons stole the title from Wei Wu Wei, the same reviewers won't realise that whereas Wei Wu Wei writes about the unborn, the noumenon, who you truly are, Tony Parsons argues that the phenomenon is 'all there is'! All novices parrot the line, 'this is all there is'. But this is nihilism and goes against what Ramana Maharshi and Nisargadatta Maharaj said. If you tell a person that this all there is or that they are it, then the person will probably end up feeling like sh't!Anyway, I recommend David Carse's Perfect, Brilliant, Stillness. Then you can try Wei Wu Wei.

Wittgensein said, "How would it look if the earth revolved around the sun"? We can never say. The illusion of the sun orbiting the Earth is so solid. We can see it!The same can be asked about the brain.What would it looked like if consciousness was outside the brain. We can never say. The illusion of a brain producing consciousness is solid. We can see it!We see neurons firing and argue that the firing makes consciousness.But we never say this about electricity. We never say that lightning causes atmospheric pressure, rather, we say that atmospheric pressure causes the lightning.So does consciousness cause the neurons to fire rather than neurons firing causes consciousness?The same can be said about the science of combustion. Combustion causes fire. We never say that fire causes combustion.So claiming neurons cause consciousness is the wrong way round.  The way combustion causes fire and the way atmospheric pressure causes lightning, consciousness causes neurons to fire.

Kurt Godel was one of the few people who could terrify the brightest minds of the 20th century. Godel wondered why people can be so illogical in believing that the brain produces mind? Wittgenstein asked what would it look like if the Earth orbited the Sun! Well the same as this but people still believe the wrong way round. Kurt Godel saw the same sloppy thinking when it came to mind.See Rudy Rucker 4th Dimension. Bernardo Kastrup's Why Materialism is Ballony contains excellent critiques of the mind equals brain cult.

Terence McKenna said that DMT is the doorway to the post-death state. When you smoke DMT, you rip through to the ecology of souls. The post-death reality for which this apparent living world we now inhabit is but a shadow, is revealed, at last, by DMT. Those who've never dried DMT live in the shadows all of their lives, not noticing the reality there but hidden by the optical illusion of the consensus trance.The Catholics tried to ban Galileo's telescope to keep power. Today, the reason for the worldwide DMT ban is that the world government wants us to remain permanently in financial turmoil, like slaves on a wheel, shopping for the sake of shopping, eating burgers and sports, with nothing higher to strive for. For with nothing to strive for but mortgage payments, the modern human is getting more stuck to the forces of bondage. DMT will be the antidote.

I find little transcendental quality in reading the Quran. Much may be lost in translation, but I can't detect the creator of the universe inside this book. What I find is an Arabian Spirit, somewhat similar to the Spirit of the burning bush; an agitated, terrestrial spirit, far removed from the transcendental God of the Christian or the Indian.Even the description of the muslim paradise is merely a mirror of primitive human desires. Only in the Quran does God himself describe heaven. No other religion does this. But the description doesn't sound like what God would say.I can see why a paradise filled with running water and dancing girls will be luxurious to a seventh century desert tribesman, but coming from the lips of God himself, this is worrying! You will expect God himself to say more than big breasted girls in heaven, with you sat on a splendid jewelled couch, with fresh water to drink.The God in the Quran feels like the God of the Arabian man, living and fighting and riding camels, rather than the God who caused the big bang and who made the milky way.The women issue always comes up but the Arabian man has some sound wisdom concerning girls, no sarcasm intended. It does say that women must be treated with respect and dignity. Women are not equal in Islam but western feminists seem to agree!However, the imagination of the Arabian man falls down when it comes to paradise for women.Why isn't there a description of the female paradise? Maybe so the muslim husband won't get jealous? But what about the muslim wife? She's being told by Allah that her husband, if he's a good muslim, won't be forever faithful to her in heaven, and even if she loves her husband dearly, and he loves her, it doesn't matter anyway. There is no marriage in the Muslim paradise.Islam on Earth does have good points but it isn't convincing as the final word of God. To be honest, the quran is not as violent as they say it is. islam does help the poor and God commands men to show women more respect that, say, the Jews. Women are invisible in judaism. The wife beating is also in the Quran but there are many positive commands about treating women nicely. Indeed, conquered people are to be shown mercy too.In the Koran, Allah commands the conquered people to either convert or pay the tax and they'll be left alive.In the Hebrew Bible, YHWE commands that after you conquer the city, all the men, women and children must be killed on the spot, no mercy! Luckily for all of us, that isn't from the lips of God either.

All the years I read people like Huxley and Alan Watts I felt empty inside. These apostles force the reader to crave something.Franklin Merrell-Wolff makes you realize that God is within you!Also, Dr Merell-Wolff was before the 1960's, before all this became trendy, and so why would he make it all up?His writing is also rich and succulent, like a tasty morsel of 'what it feels like'.

Wittgenstein's said that philosophy is something like a disease and the job of the philosopher is to study philosophy as the doctor studies malaria, not to pass it on but rather to cure people of it.I never understood why Ludwig Wittgenstein called philosophy a disease. Bertrand Russell, who loved Wittgenstein, is also dismissive of philosophy, and even more so than Wittgenstein.Russell dismissively said that philosophy is what we don't know and science is what we do know. But when you read his History of Western Philosophy, you know he's calling philosophy primitive science.Scientists say that quantum physics is what we don't know and Newtonian-Einsteinian physics is what we can know.But scientists only admit their quantum ignorance because they are in awe of quantum physics. Bohr's 'shut up and calculate' comes from this early excitement over the uncovering of the tremendous mystery. There is no mystery in Russell.We all know what quantum physics is bigger than the macto universe, and as there is no time, space or causation in the quantum thing, it is eternity, but our ipads and lasers come out of this eternity. If follows, therefore, that if we are also made of the same stuff as this eternity, does this mean a part of us is eternal? This is why there is mystery.But Bertrand Russell didn't mean that philosophy is a profound mystery also, like quantum physics is, and that we can only tease out glimpses, rather, when you read the words of Bertrand Russell, he's dismissive of all mystery, like his finger tips are the peak of metaphysical speculation and there's nothing outside the 3 dimensional universe.Brian Magee writes in his autobiography that Bertrand Russell told him that he regretted getting into philosophy and he wished he did physics instead. Magee interpreted this as meaning that the great Bertrand Russell peaked in philosophy and wished now to do the same in physics. What hubris!So Bertrand Russell reckons he would have come up with his own Schrodinger equation or baffle top Nobel Laureates like Paul Dirac did? I doubt it.I'm reading a book by one Rudy Rucker: The Fourth Dimension: Towards a Geometry of Higher Reality. This is how one should mix philosophy and mathematics.I'm reading this guy and I know I'm in the presence of a genius. I don't get this from Russell nor Wittgenstein. Interestingly, Rucker's great great great grandfather is Hegel!

I put an onion in one of these bags today.  Now, I probably could put all manner of test-foodstuffs in a vacuum bag, but an onion or garlic is kind of the gold standard.  I'm sure you could come up with something worse (i.e. higher risk) to test your bags with, but for me it's easy to judge vacuum-bag-quality based on how onion-y things smell after you seal up a nice freshly chopped white onion.  Let me tell you, this one does the trick.  A bit expensive, but the quality is there - nothing worse than backpacking and realizing after three days that your smoked salmon has an air leak.  These are thick and beefy (and by beefy I mean thick, not "like beef").  They come pre-sealed on the opposite side and they'll probably work well for other challenging items.  They're also a great size for packing small take-along items like emergency medical kits, dog food, etc.

Worth having several of these around, especially for antique small-caliber auto pistols (e.g. 25 auto, 32 auto) so that functionality can be safely checked (including dry fire) without using live rounds or worrying about pin wear.

I haven't actually made it to Norway yet, but as far as guidebooks go, this is an excellent example.  The layout is trilingual (Norwegian, German, English) and the route photos and descriptions appear comprehensive and expansive.  Local beta is included (little did I know there's nothing in between fast food and gourmet when dirtbagging in Norway).

...and by holding them, I don't mean giving them a place to rest their weary heads and feel sheltered in the protective arms of the model 21405.  I mean, it just holds your stuff.  How complicated could it be?

Yes, it's true.  I am an engineer and a scientist.  I studied the theory.  I did the calculations.  I know the emissivity of cotton and the temperature of methane.  But now I can confirm my theory with SCIENCE.  It IS possible to see a fart on a thermal camera.

Inside are expensive canisters of seeds and dirt.  It's not the seeds and dirt that are impressive, it's what happens to them when you give them to your mother in law!  First, she is happy to have a pile of green things growing in her house, basking in the all-too-unnatural light of the AeroGarden.  Secondly, she turns them into tasty Italian food.  The transformation is a pure miracle.  That's why they're called Miracle-Gro!  Italian food and a satisfied mother-in-law?  Not so expensive after all.

I'm sure the original carving was pretty rad.  It came across in resin quite well.  The detail is superb.  The art is interpretive; there is a mix of classical styles in this piece.  If you are living in your mom's basement in Toledo and concerned about impressing the Aesir, they'll probably not take you too seriously.  For that I would recommend a pilgrimage to an Amon Amarth show instead.  \m/

Compared with a $100+ mount, given that it had four stars and a bunch of reviews, how could I go wrong?I went wrong.  It's mounted and it's holding my projector like a rebellious 13-year-old holds a lawnmower -- that is, halfheartedly, making it clear that it's not something it wants to do.The construction consists of an adjustable plate which will mount to your projector.  Typically, projectors have four screw mount points.  Some have three (as did mine). Some arbitrary hacking is required to make it fit using a combination of the stamped steel tabs that are provided.  The problem is that not all projectors will have their center of mass directly under the plate, meaning that a residual torque will always be present about the ball joint to which the plate attaches.  This results in one applying copious amounts of torque to the thumb screws to get the plate to stay level at the prescribed adjustment point, which is exceptionally challenging given the amount of play in the telescoping tube and the remainder of the mount (it's at least a 2mm difference in diameter -- the whole thing rattles like your grandma's lawn chair).  Ultimately one will discover -- when the ball joint has been tightened to its extreme -- that a failure mode exists where the ball joint steel stud is pressed into the plate.  Note I said pressed -- not threaded and screwed as far as I can tell -- your umpteen thousand dollar projector is being held in by what is essentially friction.  Given sufficient mangling to make up for the free play in the mount orientation, you're sure to break that off as well.  I'm just waiting to go and find my projector laying on the floor in pieces after enough thermal cycles (warm day, cold day) cause that thing to loosen up and eject its unwanted companion.I'm faced with a dilemma.  For what I paid, and having written this review, taking it down (in its haphazard configuration), packing it up, and returning it isn't worth the time.  Maybe I'll try and make some shims to rigidize the structure and tack weld the joint on so it doesn't sag in its mount orientation and/or give up the projector all of a sudden.*** Update 1/20/2014 ***I am pleased to report that just a few hours after this review was written, I was contacted by Cheetah customer service (via comment) as they were concerned about my product experience given the negative review that I posted.  A few hours after that, I was contacted via phone (a voicemail was left), and then a follow-up e-mail.  I figured this was quite a bit of persistence for an inexpensive product, but I respect good customer service, so I gave them a call back.  Apparently they have a relatively well-staffed customer support department (whether contracted or in-house) and someone picked up immediately at 6:30 ET.  The CSR inquired as to my dissatisfaction with this mount and then informed me that the subject plate is being redesigned "due to customer feedback" or something along those lines.  The CSR then offered me a full refund (which is commendable, thank you) as well as any other product in their Amazon catalog for free (which is also commendable, but unfortunately I have no need for other products).  It probably would have been helpful to send me a mount to replace the one I bought, or maybe a replacement plate only, but I was informed that no such mount was available (although all 30+ other products sold through Amazon are).The CSR encouraged me to reconsider my review given my experience with customer service (which I have).  I was sent a follow-up e-mail including step-by-step instructions as to how to log in to Amazon, find my review, and delete or edit it.Now, I realize that I've already spent more than $25 of my time and definitely more than $25 worth of Cheetah's time working on a review for the benefit of the Amazon buying community.  My purchase dilemma has expanded to a moral dilemma.  Reviews, insofar as they are objective and honest, provide a real value to Amazon and I rely on them extensively for purchasing decisions.  Cheetah obviously relies heavily on Amazon as a seller, and has a vested interest in maintaining their product image.  Honestly, it would probably be to Cheetah's advantage to invest less in their customer support and more in their product design and test.  I do appreciate the refund (although I wonder if it gives Cheetah the ability to demote my "Amazon verified purchase" status). However, lacking concrete evidence to suggest that the design has changed and the product quality has markedly increased, my recommendation remains to avoid this product and consider something else. At least be aware that the quality is commensurate with the price.  Also rest assured that in the event this product doesn't work out for you, a refund may be an option and their customer service is accessible.  In fact, they'll call you.

Original elements mingle with traditional myths and plot devices in a lively contemporary fantasy. The depiction of social dynamics at school are spot on. The voice includes welcome humor as well as tension and mystery. Two girls and a boy are equal partners in the adventure, so a thread of female empowerment runs through the story. The adult population is unbalanced, though; the women are caring and helpful while the men are either weak or evil.My biggest problem with the book has to do with the writing. The language needs tightening; in places it drags, and there's unnecessary repetition. Altogether too many editorial errors, too--grammar, typos etc. In a nutshell, this seems to be a rough draft, published before it was ready.
Too didactic at the expense of storytelling. The characters are just cute mouthpieces for a message that's obvious all along.

What a shame! This could have been a good story, if the author had a grasp of the art of writing a novel. Yes, I see she has received scholarships and awards. I also see that she doesn't understand such elements as point of view, voice, or character development. The style is rambling and disjointed, as if this were the author's rough notes for a novel rather than a finished book. Characters are "introduced" by paragraphs telling about them, resulting in flat cardboard figures rather than living, believable people a reader can care about. The clumsy attempts at POV increase the alienation, skipping randomly from character to character (sometimes in mid-paragraph) and even offering mass descriptions such as "the men thought ..." or "the women felt ..." I kept reading, hoping that it would get better, but no luck. This is a dramatic story and works as a dramatic movie. It should never have been transposed into a novel and touted as literature, because literature it's not.

Sometimes a writer is so wrapped up in teaching a "lesson" that she loses sight of what else children may internalize from her story. Normally Lester and Munsinger are right on target, but this time they unintentionally (yes, I'll give the benefit of the doubt) reinforced some dangerous misconceptions. A parrot is not a feathered tape recorder. The parrot in this story would never have repeated Penelope's abusive language because it would have been dead long before the prince arrived on the scene. Little children won't even recognize the way she treats the parrot as abuse because it's presented as funny. A cage so small the parrot cannot even open its wings? Dragging the cage across the floor with the parrot falling off its perch inside? A ball and chain on the parrot's leg? So ridiculous it's laughable, right? No, wrong. At the end, the princess loses the prince because of her bad language, but she's never challenged for the way she has treated the parrot -- who is so objectified it doesn't even have a name. And children don't know that having the parrot fly away is not a happy ending (prince or no prince). Releasing a caged bird outside is cruel. Very few escaped cage birds survive.Once upon a time it was considered funny when comics such as the Three Stooges hit each other over the head with cast iron skillets and poked each other in the eyes. I doubt many parents today want their children to think such behavior is funny. I hope parents, writers, illustrators, publishers will soon come to recognize that animal abuse isn't funny either.

What a downer! Starts out with some beautiful writing in the beginning, but as the book moves forward it's almost as if the author got bored ... the writing grows more perfunctory and loses the rhythms and the lovely descriptions. By the end, it reads like an outline rather than a novel. Cannot hold a candle to Sigrid Undset or O.E. Rolvaag.

Goes on smoothly and doesn't chip off, but for me the true test of a nail polish is what it does to my nails -- and you can't tell that until you take it off. I wore this polish for a week, then removed it with a gentle generic nail polish remover. I was pleased. Sometimes nails that have had polish on them look dull and unhealthy, but this time mine were fine. I left them bare, and it was more than a week before they started breaking again. (I have weak nails that break easily and often.) My nails do feel stronger. I'll continue to use this product.

Eight decades of memories! Even as a child, Willie had what he called "a natural and familiar relationship with music." In his musical family and his hymn-singing church, he absorbed the rhythms, the language, and the heart of music. At age 6 he received his first guitar as a gift. At 10 he took his first job playing music in a beer joint . . . and he's been traveling to make music ever since.Although the book is arranged more or less chronologically, the narrative skips back and forth in time when it's appropriate. Basically, this is a series of anecdotes, free-flowing but linked together in a kind of natural logic. The first-person account is plainspoken, told in language that is both blunt and beautiful, just like his songs.I was particularly struck by Willie's generosity of spirit. He's known and performed with and befriended some of the greatest people of twentieth-century American music, across a wide range of genres, yet I never felt that he was "name-dropping." He pays tribute to how these musicians influenced him, sharing what he learned from each. That's right, he kept listening and learning all his life, even in what some would call his old age.When he describes actually writing specific songs, the song lyrics are interwoven into the narrative of the book. Each song is in some way grounded in truth. It's a fascinating look into the power of creativity.The 400 pages sped by, and I was sorry when the book ended. Willie describes himself as a troubadour, a wandering musician who tells stories through his songs. As he says, "this book is a history of my heart -- and especially the ways in which my heart has been shaped by music."  Good story. Good book.

iPad at Work for DummiesAlthough this book contains a ton of useful information, it's not an introduction to the iPad. It assumes you already know what an iPad is and how to use it. That's to the good, because it gets down to business right away.The first three chapters do give the basics of setting up an iPad for professional use (as opposed to entertainment such as playing games, surfing the web, or sending emails). I recommend reading these three chapters straight through to help make the initial choices that will facilitate your work load later. Check out chapter 3 in particular, because that's all about security. If you're carrying around financials and other sensitive info on your iPad, you sure don't want it hacked somewhere!Once you get past these three chapters, the rest of the book is pretty much a buffet. Pick the parts that pertain to your business. For example, I skipped the whole section on Office 365, because I use iWork. On the other hand, I found the chapter on the Cloud to be very valuable because of all the practical details. In fact, the whole section on sharing is highly useful for what I do (working remotely with people all over the country). I've had some frustrating experiences trying to do presentations from a laptop, and this book gives clear, step by step directions for giving a successful presentation from my iPad instead.Two strong features of the book: the index and the table of contents. That's right, a user manual is no good at all if you can't find what you want. The index sends me to the exact page if I know the name of what I need to read. But if I don't, the detailed table of contents lets me search by subject, because I can see at a glance what's in each chapter and get a good idea where to start looking.I'll be using this as a reference and probably carrying it with me on trips. It's a big book but printed on a lightweight paper so it's not too heavy for a weekender travel bag.

The title, Paper Things, refers to the paper dolls and accessories that fifth-grader Arianna has cut out of catalogs and carries everywhere in her backpack. This paper family provides the only stability in her uncertain life.When Ari's widowed mother dies, leaving Ari and her brother Gage with an old friend they don't even know, things go downhill fast. Gage, who is 19, tells the friend he can take care of Ari himself, and the two set out together. But Gage is ill-equipped to care for his little sister, and the two of them are soon sofa-surfing with friends, sneaking into shelters (because Ari is technically too young), even sleeping in a parked car.This somber story shows the heavy effects of homelessness on a child. An honor student before her mother died, Ari sees her grades slip because she has no place to do homework. Her appearance suffers from not having the facilities to wash her hair or do laundry. She loses her friends, who think she's snubbing them because she never calls or invites them over anymore. She begins to feel invisible.The picture is not totally bleak. Ari volunteers after school at a local Head Start, where the children love her no matter what. She makes a new friend at school, someone who doesn't care what people think about him. A homeless veteran teaches her to make wishes on paper airplanes.The narrative voice is believable and the tone sympathetic. My main complaint about the book is the pacing. A mystery is involved, a family secret (beyond the deaths of their parents) that contributes to Ari and Gage's problem. But Ari doesn't find the first clue until page 224--which I consider much too late for a book to change from straightforward narrative into a mystery.Paper Things is likely to elicit one of two reader reactions: judgement or compassion. As an adult reader, I could see that the children's plight was exacerbated by choices they made. But I could also see that in their desperate situation, they did not know how to make things better. A reader may think, "Tough; it's their own fault." Or a reader may wonder, "How could I help someone like this?" Whether or not you like this book depends on which reader you are.

"Ours is a family of storytellers," claims Boyd Varty in sharing his family's four generations on a plot of "lowveld" (wasteland) 400 miles from Johannesburg, South Africa. Growing up in this natural setting, Boyd not only knew a wealth of stories about the land itself and his parents', grandparents', and great-grandparents' adventures there, but also had amazing adventures of his own to add to the saga.Once a failed cattle farm, the wild grounds were a place where the author's great-grandfather and grandfather hunted big game. In his father's generation, the family's focus shifted away from hunting, and the land is now the Londolozi Game Reserve. "Londolozi" is Zulu for "protector of all living things." This transformation came before conservation was a popular movement, and many people thought the family was crazy, but Londolozi became a blueprint for modern-day conservation efforts.The narrative resonates with respect for the land, animals, and people of South Africa. Some anecdotes are humble, such as ten-year-old Boyd carrying catfish, one by one, from a drying pond to release in a river. Others are terrifying, as Boyd's narrow escape when a crocodile clamped its jaws on his leg and dragged him into a river. And some episodes are awesome. When a national park in Africa was culling elephants, Boyd's father and uncle devised an ingenious plan to move several of the doomed elephants to Londolozi: the first live moving of elephants ever undertaken.Some of the stories are painful. The author does not shrink from revealing the terrible residue that remained even after apartheid was officially ended. Humans, he says, can be the most dangerous predators. Yet even here there is hope. Especially memorable is the chapter on Nelson Mandela; when Mandela was released after 27 years in prison, Londolozi was the place he came to recover and to restore his spirit.I was amazed when I realized how young the author is. "Cathedral of the Wild" is a mature and beautiful memoir, by turns wise, humorous, philosophical, outrageous, or barely believable, bound together by a rich reverence for life.

Office laminators I've used at work were clunky and caused wrinkles and tended to jam. This little home-use laminator has them beat hands down.First, I was amazed at how quickly it heats up. The "ready" beep went off in just a minute, while I was still gathering my papers together. I noticed a slight "hot" odor, but nothing offensive or troubling.It's very easy to feed the pouch into the laminator using the entry markings on the machine.The instructions say to be sure document is centered up against the leading edge, so I do that for single pages. However, I wanted to laminate several smaller items and didn't want to waste a whole pouch on each one (I only have the letter-size pouches on hand) so I v-e-r-y carefully placed three cards in one pouch, spacing them apart, and then v-e-r-y carefully fed the pouch into the laminator. Success! No wrinkles, no bubbles, they didn't slip, and I could trim them apart after the pouch cooled. I even had two different thicknesses: one was regular 20-pound paper and two were heavier cardstock. The laminator sealed all three neatly at their edges. (The manufacturer probably would not endorse this, but it worked for me.)So far I've only used the 3 mil weight pouches, and they've been fine for everything I wanted to do. Perhaps I'd go heavier for a sign to be used outdoors or something that will be handled roughly, but the 3 mil is good protection for things that will receive average everyday use.The laminator is lightweight and has a small footprint on my work table, which I appreciate.

Noted theologian Leonard Sweet here offers his perspective on what he identifies as "three of the most intractable issues of past half-century." He contends that seeing them as "issues" is part of the problem, since these are not either-or questions but aspects of life that need to be integrated into what he calls a "house and garden" spirituality--that is, both interior and exterior.The writing style is conversational, including the redundancies of natural speech. This friendly if repetitive text is enhanced by a generous number of quotes from classic and contemporary theologians and philosophers, set as call-outs on the pages. The book's end notes provide not only sources but also interesting comments on the text.In place of today's individualism, Sweet urges a "me/we" social gospel that embraces both the value of the individual and the necessity of relationships. "Jesus does not subordinate the individual to the community nor the community to the individual. Rather, Jesus understood every community to be comprised of uniquely important individuals" (page 25).Sweet addresses racism by going back to the Creation Story, then tracing the light/dark dichotomy through history and culture to show that black and white have no intrinsic moral implications and have picked up the "good/bad" connotations through usage.The section on consumerism is by its nature the most concrete of the three, since money and possessions are things that can be assigned concrete (economic) value, but Sweet addresses the more intangible environmental concerns as well. Here he takes on consumption, greed, envy, environmental repercussions, war and strife, power, distribution of resources -- you get the idea. He challenges readers first to recognize that we are all consumers, then to respond to consumerism with creativity.The minister looking for sermon quotes will find this a treasure trove. Sweet is a master of the neat turn of phrase that would work well as a sound bite or a bumper sticker. He bases his social gospel "not on kingdom-building but on kingdom-living." Regarding consumerism he says, "The issue is not the amount of our spending. The issue is the account of our spending" and "The empire of goods has become the empire of our gods." The section headed "Relationships Are Not Black and White" comprises long strings of anecdotes related to black/white, dark/light, as if he knew all these good stories and couldn't bear to leave out even one.As a work intended to make readers start thinking, the book fulfills its purpose. It makes clear that we live between God's ideal and the human reality, that there is work to be done, and that individually we share communal responsibility.

The book blurb gives the basic outline -- a fairy tale opening, then the stories of three different realistic children in three different mid-twentieth-century settings -- so I won't rehash the plot details here. Each of the stories is independent of the other two and could almost stand alone, except that after drawing the reader into a fascinating piece of someone's life at a clearly defined point in history, each narrative ends abruptly and without closure. Of course, the abrupt break is not the end of each story.The common element from story to story is the harmonica that is owned successively by each of the three main characters. The harmonica is not central, however; there is a deeper theme connected to the harmonica that runs through the three stories. The key to the theme is given in the opening fairy tale, but so cleverly woven into the narrative that it may be missed until it reappears and is emphasized in the conclusion. The ending brings closure to each story, ties the three together, and connects back to the beginning. I debated with myself about identifying the theme here, but that would be a spoiler. You'll enjoy the book more if you're allowed to discover it for yourself.While the transition from the fantasy of the opening to the realism of the central stories is jarring at first, I quickly became engaged in Friedrich's life and accepted the new situation. That meant I was ready for the jump to Mike's, then to Ivy Maria's separate stories. If I have one quibble with the book, it's that the concluding epilogue was entirely too much explaining. It was almost as if the author was checking off a list of all the things that happened to each child after his or her story ended. Hence my four stars instead of five.Despite my mild disappointment with the way the ending was so drawn out, I consider Echo an outstanding achievement that will undoubtedly be a contender for some major awards this year. I recommend it.

The art for this block set is absolutely charming, with balanced numbers of boy and girl figures from diverse ethnic backgrounds. A nice touch is there's a boy pirate captain, plus a long-haired pirate captain that reads (to me) like a girl wearing a beard, so very much gender-equal! Lots of props and creatures as well, though a mermaid character figure might have made a nice addition. (The figurehead of the pirate ship is a mermaid.)I like that a small desert island (for buried treasure) is included. A large shark and large octopus dwarf the small, 2-piece (head and tail) sea serpent, but perhaps the serpent is only to be glimpsed mysteriously in the distance?The PIRATES! picture book is a board book format and serves more as a suggestion on how the blocks might be set up for play. The story itself is fairly generic.My only negative comment is that while most of the smaller pieces are two-sided, the thicker pieces comprising the ship have art only on one side, so the ship can only "sail" right to left.Set fits into a dovetailed box without a lid, and could serve as a puzzle as well.

I like biographies. I like historical fiction. I expected to like this book--but I didn't. So why not?This novel was an ambitious undertaking, and it's clear the author has done her research. An author's note describes what she found as fact and what she created. The back matter includes 10 pages of endnotes plus a selected bibliography.I never warmed up to either of the protagonists, not the fictional archivist Anna Roth nor the historical figure Adelle Godel, wife of the famous logician. (Although this has been described elsewhere as a fictional biography of Kurt Godel, he remains a background figure to the two women who dominate the novel.) Alternating chapters set in the past and the fictional present follow Adele's experiences as Kurt's wife and Anna's visits to the widowed Adele in a nursing home. The chapters set in the nursing home also show the growing bond between the two women.The book begins well but becomes tedious as it goes on. While this is a translation into English from French, I don't think the monotony can be entirely the fault of the translator. At first Adele seems to be a character I could care about. She never quite comes to life, though. Somewhere about 200 pages into the novel she starts to show a little of the original promise, but it's too little, too late. Anna is a troubled person right from the start who fades in and out of focus. Fortunately, she does seem to end the novel a stronger person than she began.Kurt regarded Adele as stupid and avoided telling her anything about his work, but occasional visitors would provide tidbits in a very simplified format. The mathematical and philosophical content is therefore accessible to readers who have not studied in these areas. It was fun to glimpse other famous mathematicians and philosophers in a fictional setting--the Godels were friends with Einstein, Oppenheimer, Morgenstern, Russell, and other great minds of the twentieth century.I grew weary of talking heads: pages and pages and pages of unattributed dialogue that sounds more like narrative in quotation marks than like real people talking. Some of the dialogue was interesting, some of it was informative, but much of it was repetitious or trivial, and very little of it engaged me.I just stopped to look at some of the other reviews and see that quite a few readers loved the book. I wish I could say the same. Since I can't agree, I'd prefer to say nothing--but this is a Vine book and I'm required to post an honest review. Here it is.

What begins as black comedy moves into creepy mystery, shifts into high gear with suspense, and at the end offers hope, inviting the reader to meditate on what it means to be truly alive. Sound muddled? Not at all! The transitions are subtle and logical in the development of the troubled main character, Aaron Rowe. Although Aaron is high school age, his school counselor has placed him in a trial position working full-time for funeral director John Barton.The story starts on Aaron's first day at work, a day that includes two pickups. The grim humor (including a corpulent corpse that they manage to drop on the floor) is not something you'd want to read if you've had a recent death in the family. In contrast to this macabre on-the-job training, Aaron meets John Barton's cheerful family: motherly, be-aproned Delia, who makes pretty little finger sandwiches for lunch; sassy 11-year-old Skye, who immediately names Aaron "Robot"; and the ancient, incontinent cat Moggy. At the end of the day, Aaron goes home to the house-trailer where he lives with his grandmother, Mum, who shows symptoms of advanced dementia. As if these diverse elements weren't enough to build a complex plot, Aaron also suffers from horrific nightmare and walks in his sleep, sometimes for miles.Despite these bizarre juxtapositions, I found the book oddly endearing. Let me share just one sample. After a gristly motorcycle-truck crash, the police and funeral home folks have to pick up the pieces, literally. Aaron finds the cyclist's helmet with head still in it and picks it up by the chin strap "like an odd valise." After tucking it into the hearse, he muses, "although we'd been conducting the same search, the policemen and I had been looking for different things and for different reasons. They were hunting mortal remains to finish a job; I was hunting the still countenance of someone's son, perhaps a brother, maybe even a father, to bring him a final grace. By giving him grace, I found some of my own. The police protected the living, ambulance officers protected the injured, as we protected the dead. All as it should be."An unexpectedly beautiful book.Note: reviewed from uncorrected galleys; the above quote might not be exactly the same in the final published book.

Siobhan's name is pronounced SHI-vawn, which she shortens to Shiv. As the book opens, her father is driving 15-year-old Shiv to an exclusive mental health clinic for two months of residential treatment. Shiv blames herself for her younger brother Declan's recent death and believes her grief and guilt will be neverending.I really liked Martyn Bedford's book Flip and was eager to read another YA novel by him. I was not disappointed. Neverending is completely different, yet equally engrossing.Chapters alternate between the cheerless Korsakoff Clinic, with its unorthodox methods of treatment, and flashbacks to the happy weeks Shiv and her family spent vacationing in a villa on a sunny Greek island. Because the narrative begins with Shiv's ambivalence about entering the clinic, which she does voluntarily but out of desperation, a sense of foreboding shadows the vacation scenes even though the characters are unaware of the tragedy that's about to happen. Bedford builds this tension skillfully. At the clinic, Shiv struggles with her guilt and grief without revealing how her brother died -- and why she thinks she killed him -- until the very end of her two-month stay.Meanwhile, she meets other teens who are also at the clinic to wrestle with their own demons of guilt and grief. The focus remains on Shiv, where it belongs. The book is written in third person but the viewpoint is Shiv's. The reader gets to know the other characters only as much as Shiv does -- which means some of them are well developed, others remain background figures. The people who are important to Shiv, both in the clinic and on the Greek island, come to life as real.This is a book of many contrasts, which the author uses effectively. There's humor and fear; warmth and anger; family affection and sibling arguments. The methods at the clinic strike me as "kill or cure." Teens in a fragile psychological and emotional state could be helped or could be driven round the bend. Until the very end, I was never quite sure which way Shiv would go. And I honestly cared. That's a good book.

I saw an ad for this product in the AARP Bulletin and was curious, so when it showed up in Amazon Vine the next week I ordered it. After it came, I wondered how on earth to write a review. It's supposed to promote a healthy immune system and digestive balance, but how do you measure that? I'm never sick and don't take any other supplements (not even vitamins), so there's no measuring stick for feeling "better." However, I took this Metabolic daily for three weeks, and I must say I felt fine.Then here's the interesting part: I stopped taking it, and I had stomach aches for a couple of days. I started again, and the stomach aches went away. So apparently the supplement is doing something helpful regarding digestion.

* part pulse-pounding action adventure* part graphic novel* part intense psychological thrillerThese three elements are braided together into one story.I'd heard of freerunning, but I had no idea what it would feel like to run through a city this way until I read this book. I could almost see these three teenagers running across roofs and vaulting over fences, doing flips and handstands and twists. Exciting!Then comes the shooting. After they get out of the hospital, the two survivors aren't running for joy anymore, they're running in desperation. Running to forget what they can't forget. Running to fix what they can't fix.The narrative parts are mostly real life. When it gets too intense to say in words, the story jumps to graphics to show what it can't tell. Very effective.Two of the teens are a Chicago cop's kids. The third one is Indian, and there's some interesting Hindu mythology woven into the story.Friendship and loyalty are big themes in this book. The story doesn't end the way I wanted it to. It ends the way it had to. I finished it a couple of days ago, and I can't stop thinking about it. Good book.

Plan on reading slowly; you won't want to miss any of the beautiful, frightful details in this tightly-woven novel. Ostensibly this is a murder mystery. Two children find a dead body on the third page and, in satisfying symmetry, the killer is revealed on the third-from-last page. Between these two bookends, so many other things happen that at times it's possible almost to forget that a murder has taken place. Individual events seem unrelated, yet on a deep level they interconnect, affecting and influencing each other.While the book opens and closes with 14-year-old Frederika, who recently arrived in 18th century Swedish Lapland with her parents and little sister from Finland, she is not the only focal character. Indeed, there are no minor characters in this story. As in real life, every person has secrets. Every person has a past. The narrative moves from person to person, and in each viewpoint the reader knows only what that character knows. Yet we see tantalizing glimpses of each soul, and by the end even seemingly isolated characters have been significant in some way.The plot has more turns than a labyrinth; every time you think you know who the killer is, some new discovery twists the path in a new direction. The community is still a scattering of settlers, not yet a village. Christianity dominates, but hints of witchery linger. Frederika and her mother Maija both (at different times) see things that may or may not be there. The murdered man returns to talk with Frederika--or does he?The language is richly layered, evoking the almost unendurable conditions in this arctic region and the determination of its inhabitants to survive. The reader can feel the numbing wind and snow. Underlying tension between Finns and Lapps adds psychological coldness to the freezing environment. And in the background, heard howling, sometimes seen, always sensed, are the wild wolves.

I've been a fan of Slimfast bars for a long time. Unfortunately, they've discontinued several flavors recently, including my favorite, so I've been searching for a replacement. I was afraid that Greek yogurt and honey would be weird but took a chance on a sample package and was pleasantly surprised. These rather remind me of the lemon bars I used to love at PTA bake sales. There's no lemon listed in the ingredients, but they have the same combination of sweetness and tartness. Plus, the texture is lighter than most snack bars, so this really does feel like a treat, not a diet bar.If you're limiting sugars, be aware that each bar has 12 g sugars in it. That doesn't bother me because I don't eat a lot of sweets, so my overall sugar intake is moderate. The size of the bar is pretty small compared to a regular candy bar, about the same as other Slimfast snack bars. I was satisfied with just one and didn't get hungry again for a couple of hours. I'll buy more of these and keep some in my locker at work for break times.

The author has given herself an ambitious project indeed: write a mystery from the viewpoint of someone sliding into senility. The missing Elizabeth is Maud's best friend. Because of Maud's dementia, the reader has to wonder: is Elizabeth really missing? Or moved to a nursing home? Or has she died and Maud doesn't remember the funeral? Maud's confused yet urgent thoughts become tangled with other mysteries from her past, including the disappearance of her beloved older sister a half century earlier.The strength of this novel is how well the author shows the inexorable progression of senility. Maud narrates her own story in first person, even as her memory is slowly slipping away. Having lived through my own mother's descent into senile dementia, I can testify that the narrative perfectly captures the combination of compassion and frustration involved. That is, I could relate to Maud's distress (yes, she knows that she's losing her memory and tries to fight the loss) while feeling frustrated at the unclear communication, the rambling and the repetition.The beginning of the book spends a little too long establishing Maud's memory problems, and I found my attention wandering. The same effect could have been accomplished in half the pages.The middle of the book is the best part. Maud narrates her current experiences without fully understanding them, and at any moment a random word or sound or image may send her mind into the past, which to Maud is much more clear than the present. I particularly enjoyed these smooth transitions; they seem almost effortless. This is excellent writing.The conclusion does a good job of showing the solution to a genuine mystery even though Maud doesn't quite understand what has happened. Unfortunately it strained my credulity that Maud's narrative could reproduce so much dialogue by other characters. And I wondered if the apparent holes in the plot were actual plotting flaws or simply incomplete reporting due to Maud's dementia. The solution is shrewd but somehow disappointing at the same time.Readers touched by Maud's inexorable descent into dementia will also be interested in Thomas DeBarrio's honest memoir Losing My Mind, an author's journal documenting his own Alzheimers.

This story told in letters is an ingenious variation on the diary-style or correspondence-based novel. Rather than letters addressed to a diary (such as Anne Frank) or to a single individual (Dear Mister Henshaw and many others), these letters are written to a wide variety of individuals--all deceased, most under tragic circumstances.The intricate plot is not at all what I expected--it's much better. Laurel is starting high school without her older sister May, whom she worshipped. May died the previous spring, and the girls' parents moved Laurel to a new school thinking it would be less painful than going where everyone knew the talented and popular May. Laurel's new English teacher assigns her class to write a letter to a dead person, and Laurel quickly discovers that this provides a release for feelings she can't say out loud. She writes to an eclectic mix of famous people including film stars such as Judy Garland, River Phoenix, and Heath Ledger; rock stars from Janis Joplin and Jim Morrison to Amy Winehouse; poets John Keats, Elizabeth Bishop, and e. e. cummings; aviator Amelia Earhart; and even Allan Lane, the voice of Mister Ed. Note that she never writes to May. She also never turns in the assignment, which is too personal to share with the teacher.The narrative voice is pitch-perfect. It's touching to watch Laurel's letters move from Dear Mr. Cobain to Dear Kurt Cobain to Dear Kurt, as she slowly reveals thoughts that are more and more personal. At one point she begins a letter with the heartfelt plea, "Dear Kurt, Judy, Elizabeth, Amelia, River, Janis, Jim, Amy, Allan, E.E., and John, I hope one of you hears me. Because the world seems like a tunnel of silence." Gradually we learn the events surrounding May's death--events Laurel had blocked from her memory that return bit by bit--and with Laurel we wonder if she was responsible.There is of course a boy Laurel begins to like at the new school, and a tentative romance. Startling plot twists keep readers from guessing the ending. The conclusion does not resolve every question, yet provides both healing and closure.Highly recommended for teens and also for adults who appreciate a well written, compelling YA novel.

I ordered two flavors so that I could compare them. The one called Icy Fresh has the tag line "cool fresh mint," which is pretty accurate, and Enamel White has the tag line "luminous mint," whatever that means. Both tasted clean and minty, with Icy Fresh slightly stronger. I don't have a preference; guess that would be an individual thing for other users.The toothpaste is pretty dense, so I use less than I did with my previous brands. (It's also messier to clean up if you spill it on the sink or counter.)What about the whitening? The package says "whiter teeth in 1 week." I have a small enamel-colored filling between front teeth that matched my teeth when I got it. After a week my teeth were slightly whiter than the filling. I've been using the toothpaste for nearly a month now, and I haven't seen a lot of change since the first week, but I'm still pleased with the improvement.What I notice most about the Optic White toothpaste is neither the taste nor the whitening, it's how my teeth feel now. When I run my tongue over them, they feel smoother and more polished. That's enough to make me keep using this toothpaste.

This novel won't be published until September--I'm reviewing an advance copy--but given the author's name plus the marketing campaign, I'm sure it's slated to be a best-seller. The idea is sound: a coming-of-age story enlivened by ghosts, mystery, family secrets, and paranormal activity, not to mention a discreetly off-stage homosexual affair. Lush descriptions of the setting show a wonderfully decrepit old mansion replete with secret passages and hidden rooms, surrounded by forest primeval on a high bluff overlooking Puget Sound. I recognize echoes of Gothic classics in a successful modern setting. All of this is a formula for success.Unfortunately, the compelling material is often undermined by clumsy writing. The narrative includes pages and pages of talking heads. The story is related in first person by the protagonist, alternating between himself as 14-year-old boy and as retrospective adult. The two voices are not differentiated; Trevor at 14 sounds just like the grown-up Trevor except that the grownup keeps saying "I remember." When the narrator pauses the story to explain background, such as his own father's childhood, it's hard to know which Trevor is talking. The dialogue has a little too much preaching for my taste, with several characters offering opinions on everything from environmentalism to original sin. If you're so inclined, you'll find plenty of places to pause and ponder ideas such as the good of the few vs. the good of the many or the high cost of promises or the tangled web woven by deceit.In the haunted mansion, and also in a nearby abandoned cabin, Trevor finds trunks filled with hundred-year-old journals. Each time he picks up a journal, he reads an entry that is relevant to the current story. These convenient journals are filled with dialogue and description in much the same style as the main narrative, except that the journal entries add words like "dalliance" and "patriarch" and are printed in italic. Trevor's other sources of information include daytime eavesdropping and nightly supernatural dreams in which he seems to participate in events from the mansion's past.The characters did grow on me, but they contain just enough caricature that I was always aware they weren't real. At the big climax, when I think the reader is supposed to be surprised to learn who the true villain is, I already knew. The solution had been telegraphed early in the novel.I'm aware that I'm in the minority here, and most reviews will be glowing. That's okay. I do recommend the book to readers who like generational ghost/mystery stories with lots of threads to untangle. Let yourself be pulled along by the plot, and don't spend too much time looking for deeper meaning. Even though the writing is not up to the level of the concept, this is still an energetic and engaging story.

Stereotypes. Appearances. Expectations. They blind us to each other and skew communication in so many ways. Each member of the Lee family sees the world through his or her own experiences and cannot understand how this affects others. Nothing unusual here--we all have our viewpoints and unintentional blinders. What sets Everything I Never Told You apart and makes the book special is twofold: beautiful plotting and beautiful writing.The plot is a graceful blending of present and past. Page one reveals that sixteen-year-old Lydia Lee is dead, but she comes to life for the reader when Chapter Two asks "How had it begun?" The answer travels back two generations, revealing dreams and disappointments of her parents, grandparents, older brother and younger sister, while also showing the actions and reactions of her family in the aftermath of her death. Each family member has a different thought about what happened to Lydia, and we don't learn the truth until the very end. In this regard, it's a successful mystery. But it's also much more.Lydia's Chinese father, James, has felt defined by racial stereotypes all his life. Lydia's caucasian mother, Marilyn, has been governed by her own mother's need to maintain proper appearances. The unrealistic expectations James and Marilyn place on their own children have molded Lydia and her siblings, Nathan and Hannah.The writing is nuanced and gentle. No sledgehammers here--the reader is allowed to knit together the pieces of the individual characters' stories to see a bigger picture. These are people who are trying to do the right thing from their own perspective, and their conflicts come about because they don't realize that situations look completely different to someone else. Although the characters are all flawed, they are presented in a nonjudgmental way that lets the reader care about their struggles and their sincerity. Since different readers will bring different expectations and experiences to the story, it's safe to say the novel will be slightly different for each one.This story is haunting but it's not a ghost story, even though the main character is dead. Instead, it's haunting in the sense that it stayed with me after I had closed the cover. The beauty of the writing lingered, as did the spirits of the characters.Readers looking for a lively action-adventure or police-procedural mystery will be disappointed. Those who like a thoughtful, well-written, character-driven novel built around a central mysterious event will enjoy Everything I Never Told You.

From the description, I thought this product would replace the five or six separate graters and slicers in different sizes that I currently use. The Cuisipro is versatile, but it has some drawbacks.First, the packaging lost a lot of points with me. I had to fight my way into the hard clamshell, and then the labels were practically cemented onto the food platform of the mandoline. It took me three cycles of GooGone, Scotchbrite, Bon Ami, and elbow grease to get them off, and now the finish is permanently stained. (I took a picture for this review, but Amazon's web form won't let me attach it.)I started with something simple: grating carrots. The hand guard has four spikes to hold the food, so I stuck a chunk of carrot on each one and grated four at once, which went pretty quickly. (Wish I could attach another picture I took!) The hand guard fits over raised edges on the mandoline, and it has a plunger to push the food down the spikes. The plunger fit my hand comfortably, but I found it awkward to support the mandoline, keep the guard on track, and apply the right amount of pressure, all at the same time. The hand guard kept slipping off the track.It's convenient to have all the blades stored in the main unit. Changing them is scary, though, because they fit really tightly in their storage spaces. It took me a lot of tugging to get them out, and when I did, they came suddenly. I don't like being surprised when I'm handling sharp objects.On a different day, I tried making crinkle, waffle, and julienne veggies to dress up a salad. The adjustable thickness settings worked just fine, although I had the same difficulty changing blades. The results were attractive, particularly the waffle cut.It's nice to have so much variety available with a single tool. Using this on a daily basis would be a nuisance, though. I'll probably continue using my old graters and cutters unless I'm doing something really fancy for company. I'm glad I didn't pay full price for the sample product, because I don't think I'd ever get my money's worth of use out of it.

Layer upon layer of secrets are tucked into this intriguing and intimate middle-grade novel. Twelve-year-old Jewel was born on the day her brother died, and her grandfather has not spoken a word since then. Jewel's parents, too, are locked in their own worlds that Jewel cannot enter. Lonely and confused, she yearns for someone who will talk with her. When she befriends a new boy in her small town in Iowa, she is surprised by her grandfather's immediate dislike of the newcomer, her first friend.Jewel is a thoughtful child. In the absence of information from the adults around her, she is left to her imagination as she tries to understand the world. The family is a mix of Jamaican, Mexican, and Midwestern cultures, and this sometimes raises difficult questions for her. Her new friend is also of mixed heritage, a black child living with white relatives. Jewel is drawn to geology, seeing it as a fascinating foundation: "millions upon millions of years of earth were holding us." In contrast, her friend wants to be an astronaut, leaving the earth and its troubles behind and going far, far away.When I read a book to review, I jot down page numbers of things that particularly strike me: lyrical language or new insights or ideas to ponder. My list quickly filled my sheet of paper--too many to mention in one review. I can't resist sharing one excerpt. After a family crisis, Jewel's grandfather comes to her room. Although he is silent, she says, "hearts don't speak with words like how we think they do in movies or in songs; I think they need a lot more space than that. Anyway, all I really knew was that my heart had an awful, raging fever that day, and in the silence, Grandpa brought with him the cooling rain."The plot is intricately woven, deftly handling a profusion of complications without ever losing the forward momentum of the story. Bird is engaging both intellectually and emotionally. I can't wait for the author's next book.

Shelly Maddox is shot by the sniper who on August 1, 1966, killed 17 people on the campus of University of Texas at Austin. Badly wounded, she is rescued by cousins Jack Stone and Wyatt Calvert. Jack is also shot and maimed; Wyatt is not physically injured but has what would be called PTSD if that diagnosis had existed in 1966. (PTSD was first recognized as a disorder around 1980.)In the opening chapter, as Shelly and Wyatt huddle beneath the gunman's tower, in the scant protection of a flagpole's base, his hand tightly gripping what remains of her breast to keep her from bleeding to death, the reader knows their lives will be linked forever. The rest of the book simply fills in the details. But there's nothing simple about it. We follow Shelly and Wyatt and Jack for forty years, along with their spouses, children, and eventually grandchildren. The tower casts a long shadow.This is a difficult book to review. Before ordering it I read the free sample on Kindle and was engrossed by the opening chapters, which are rich with description, emotion, and action. But 30 pages into the physical book, the writing style went from lyrical to labored; the plot began to plod painfully, with way too many paragraphs, even whole pages, of unnecessary explanations that failed to hold my interest. At times the writing style slipped into a bad Hemingway imitation. It was as if the middle of the story was written by a completely different author. At 336 pages, the book felt twice that long, and the only reason I finished it is that I was committed to write a review.There are some nice spots. Wyatt is an artist, and in places art becomes a metaphor for life. His paintings are "almost as much about what you don't see, as what you do." At the end [mild spoiler ahead!] Shelly returns to the tower and muses on how everyone's lives were changed by one random act. Overall, however, my impression is that this novel is as endless -- and as shallow -- as a soap opera.

The world's "most watchable animals" are introduced here with a focus on their behaviors. Whether you're on a round-the-world safari or visiting the nearest zoo, this book tells what you may see and what it means. General arrangement is by the aniimals' natural habitat, with sections for African jungles, plains, and waterways; Asian forests; warm oceans; North America; and the Poles. To my disappointment, this omits all the amazing tropical birds in South America, but the book is already close to 500 pages long and something had to be left out.Despite its somewhat scholarly appearance (and its heft!), this book is very readable.
