The writing style is friendly and inviting, with scientific terms limited to the sidebars. Browsers can pick out individual chapters to explore in any order, while a reader with a serious interest in animal behavior will find plenty of meat when reading from cover to cover.Each animal description starts with an explanation of basic behaviors, such as how the animal gets around, eats, plays, grooms, sleeps. Next come social habits, which include friendly, sexual, parenting, and conflict behaviors. Boxed sidebars include a page on human interactions with the kind of animal and a checklist of behaviors to watch for in the wild or in a zoo. Where appropriate, another box headed "which behavior is it?" gives further detail on observations that may be hard to differentiate.The illustrations in the book are particularly valuable. Elegant sepia drawings go into fine detail, with at least one full-page illustration per animal plus a generous number of spot illustrations showing specific expressions. For example, one page shows six different wolf faces, distinguishing between stare, threat, play, and so on, as well as five sketches showing what different tail positions mean.Unique or interesting aspects of each kind of animal add to the appeal. The peacock chapter has a brief but charming description of communal roosting. For crocodiles, one paragraph tells how these creatures with "the lungs of a landlubber" manage their breathing. Under komodo dragons is a paragraph headed "rolling in smelly stuff."The final chapter, "Zoo Critique," addresses the question of how to tell a good zoo from a bad one, with checklists and a section on "How You Can Improve Your Zoo." A 12-page index provides access to the contents.I suspect this is a book I'll enjoy returning to repeatedly.

8:32 MinsIf you're looking for VERY comfortable headphones that pack plenty of Bass and get SUPER loud, then the Photive X-Bass headphones might be just what you're looking for.FEATURES & ACCESSORIESThese headphones come with a user guide, micro USB charger and a 3.5mm audio cable. This cable allows you to use the Photives as wired headphones (which means you don't need to battery charged to use them).These Photives also fold up so they can fit in the included hard shell ballistic nylon case. There are only three buttons on these headphones which means you'll be using two buttons for both the volume and track advancing when in Bluetooth mode.COMFORTThese one of the most comfortable headphones I've worn compared to other headphones under $100 as well as many headphones costing two to three times as much. You can definitely wear these all day long.SOUND ISOLATIONSound isolation is good. These will definitely block out quite a bit of noise while you're using these. The louder the volume, the harder it will be to hear anything going on around you. However, as you crank up the volume these will start to leak some sound.  If you've had headphones in the past that didn't get loud enough then I think you'll really enjoy these. I wasn't able to include the sound leak test and volume demonstration due to time constraints but you can view that here youtu.be/_oLTp5985MUSOUND QUALITYThe strength of these headphones is definitely the bass. You get a strong emphasis on the low end which sound really nice when listening to genres of music such as: dance, hip-hop, rap, electronic, house, etc. You can use these to listen to other genres of music but the mids aren't as detailed and the highs are a bit rolled off compared to other more balanced headphones.COMPARISON to PHOTIVE BTH3The Photive BTH3 are more balanced and have a slightly better sound stage. However, the Photive X-Bass definitely brings more pounding bass, are more comfortable and definitely get louder. So if you liked the BTH3's but wished they had more bass and got louder then you'll probably love these.BOTTOM LINEIf you're looking for a Bluetooth headphone that gets nice and loud, has great bass and is so comfortable you can wear them all day long then the X-Bass by Photive is a very good choice. Otherwise if you're after a more balanced, neutral sounding headphone you'll want to consider something else.

9:40 MinsThere are so many choices when it comes to Bluetooth headphones that it can be hard to stand out from the crowd. These headphones by August definitely stand out both in terms of sound quality and comfort.FEATURESYou can use these as wired headphones which is great. There are plenty of Bluetooth headphones that cost two and three times as much that don't offer that as a feature. Batter life is up to 10 hours but I found 8 to 8.5 hrs to be more realistic. Bluetooth range is 10 meters or 30 feet which is about right. These headphones do fold up which makes them great for portable use. You can also use these to make and receive phone calls. Call quality is good and you can easily hear whoever you're talking with. However, the person on the other line might hear a few pauses or a few muffled words. So this feature works great but it's just not crystal clear all the time.COMFORTOne of the best features of these headphones is how comfortable they are. I've personally tested and used about 50 different headphones so I have a real good idea of what to expect comfort wise at different price points. These are one of the most comfortable headphones I've worn for the under $100 category and they're actually quite a bit more comfortable then many headphones I've used that cost three times as much and more!You do get some heat build up around the ears but not to the point of getting sweaty.GYM USEI found these do work good for gym use but they're just not as light on the head as dedicated sport Bluetooth headphones. But they bring such energy and life to your music that these headphones definitely help you to push your workouts harder!SOUND QUALITYThese sound incredible considering they're less than $50. The thing to keep in mind is that they bring extra bass to your music and movies. If you're after a more natural sounding headphone then you'd want to consider something else. However, if you don't mind extra bass or better yet, prefer it then you'll love these!Genres of music that sound amazing on these would be anything along the lines of rap, hip-hop, dance, techno, house, electronic and so on.I wasn't able to include the sound leak test here because of time constraints but you can view the original here youtu.be/cd6Ih-fyQ1oVOLUMEThese should be loud enough for most people but if you need extra loud headphones they these might not be loud enough. The volume also can get louder using these as wired headphones instead of Bluetooth.SOUND ISOLATIONThese do a really nice job of blocking out surrounding noise, especially the louder you have your music. These work well on an airplane but especially on bus trips, or for use around an office. Just be careful because if you have your music turned up you may not be able to hear people that are trying to get your attention :)RECOMMENDATIONThese are one of the best headphones I've used under $50. They are easily more comfortable then many headphones costing twice as much or more. If you like having the presence of more bass in your music then you'll love these. Unless you have to have a brand name showing on your headphones, these are an incredible value that will bring a smile to your face over and over again :)

7:06 MinsWhat stood out to me most about this Bluetooth speaker by Mipow is the design. It's no surprise it won the "Good Design Award" in 2013 as it looks really cool in person. However, the sound quality isn't as impressive as other Bluetooth speakers in this price range.FEATURESBesides being a Bluetooth speaker, you can also use this as a wired speaker (using the included 3.5mm cable) for non-Bluetooth devices. The handle is removable (as shown in the video) which gives in a more sleek look when not attached. You can also use this speaker for phone calls and it does a good job, though people can tell you're not on your phone.There are three buttons on the top of the speaker which you use to control the speaker. They work fine but it can be cumbersome at times when you want to advance several tracks and have to hold a button down for a few seconds each time. There's also a pretty loud 'beep' every time you press the button which I found a bit annoying (as demonstrated in the video).SOUND QUALITYNow I've listened to lots and lots of different Bluetooth speakers as well as headphones (over 50 now) so I have a really good idea of what you can expect quality wise at different price points.The sound quality of the BOOMAX is just ok and there is really isn't any bass to speak. The volume gets loud enough to hear but if you want to blast your music or really crank up the volume then you'll want to consider something else. In terms of sound quality, there are better sounding speakers for the money but it certainly does a nice job of providing music for a room, office or even using outside.RECOMMENDATIONIf you're primary concern is getting the best sound quality for the money then you'll want to consider something else. But, if you are looking for something that has a very cool design, that's distinctive and attractive to have in your room, office, etc. then this could be an excellent choice.

7:19 MinsIf you're looking for a simple to use portable charger, this Power Tube charger by Mipow works very well.FEATURESYou have a USB output as well as a micro USB connector. This gives you a lot of options when charging different types of devices. I like that you can charge two devices at once. Although if you're charging a tablet, it works best to just charge it by itself.EFFECTIVENESSFor phones I found you're able to get at least one full charge, up to 3 charges depending on the phone. For the Kind Fire HD, you can get about two full charges. For tablets, you'll get about one full charge or just under or just over one full charge (depending on the tablet). What's great is the Mipow will charge your device at basically the same speed as using your normal standard charging process.I also like that the Mipow Power Tube holds a charge for a long, long time. So even if you don't use this for a while, you don't have to worry about it loosing it's charge.OVERALL IMPRESSIONI really like this device and use it for my kids all the time now. There are a few reasons you may want to consider something else though. If you want something you can put in your pocket you might find the size and weight of this is just a little too big. Also, I would prefer if they had used a design that didn't require a separate cable to charge the device. Although I don't find it a problem when charging it at home, I don't like having to keep track of another cable when traveling. Otherwise, this portable charger works very well and I wouldn't hesitate to recommend it.Please feel free to ask any questions or leave a comment here youtu.be/Q-T4RCFVr_o and I'll do my best to answer.Thanks for watching and I hope this was helpful! :)

8:50 MinsThese aren't headphones I'd recommend for everyone, but if you're looking for Bluetooth headphones that give you lots of thumping bass and can get plenty loud, then these might be just what you're looking for.FEATURESThese headphones come with a 3.5mm cable which allows you to use them as wired headphones. I love this feature b/c it means you can use these headphones even if the rechargeable battery runs out or if you just want to use them with a device that's not Bluetooth compatible.You can use these to talk on the phone and conversations are crisp and clear.The battery life is around 10 hours when fully charged and I found this varies depending on how loud like you to listen to your music.You use a swiping motion on the outside earcup to adjust the volume or advance a track forward or backward. This works well as long as you're pressing firmly enough. These aren't as sensitive as other touch control headphones but the upside is you aren't accidentally increasing the volume or advancing a track when you didn't mean to.These headphones also come with a hard shell case, cleaning cloth and micro USB charger. These headphones collapse (as shown in the video) so they work well as a portable headphone.COMFORTThe headband and earpads are super comfy. They give a nice plush feeling when wearing these. I found they did start to get a bit uncomfortable after several hours of use b/c my ears didn't entirely fit inside the earcups. So the outside of my ears were being pressed against and again, after a while that started to become uncomfortable.If you're a younger person or have smaller ears then these might work perfectly as a true over ear headphone. For me it was mostly over ear, but a little bit on-ear.Either way, I think anyone would find these quite comfortable to wear at least for a while. But if you're planning on wearing these all day it might start to get uncomfortable depending on your head and ear size.SOUND QUALITYWhat sets these headphones a part from other headphones in this price range is the amount of bass these provide. To get the most out of these headphones I'd recommend listening to genres of music like: rap, hip hop, techno, house, trance, urban, electronic, etc... anything that has a strong beat to it will sound awesome.However, because of the extra emphasis in the bass department I found the mid can become a bit muddy and vocals can sound congested. Particularly when listening to music that doesn't have have as much emphasis on bass. They still sound nice, but they're just not as balanced or natural sounding compared to other headphones in this price range.If you like headphones that get loud, these are some of the loudest bluetooth headphones I've used in the under $100 category. At full volume I could only stand to listen to these for a few seconds.VOLUMEThese get LOUD! In fact, these are one of the loudest Bluetooth headphones I've used in the under $100 category. I wasn't able to include the sound leak test in this video do to time constraints but you can view that here if interested youtu.be/0qTVf5m-UpESOUND ISOLATIONThese do a great job of blocking out noise from your environment. You could use these on an airplane, commute to work or anywhere that's noisy and still be able to hear your music or listen to a movie.BOTTOM LINEIf you're looking for headphones that give you lots of extra bass and can get plenty loud then these might be just what you're looking for. They're also very comfortable to wear though anyone with larger ears might find they're not as comfortable to wear for several hours at a time. If you find that most of the music you're listening to has a good beat to it and you want to feel the bass a lot more then these would be an excellent value and a very good choice for the money.

8:20 MinsSo far, this is the best multifunction Bluetooth speaker I have come across for the price. There are 8 different functions or features included with this Bluetooth speaker:WIRELESS BLUETOOTH SPEAKERThe range is 10 meters or about 30 feet. I found this to be accurate and it's pretty much the norm for Bluetooth speakers. It holds a Bluetooth connection well though occasionally I did get a few pauses will listening to music.STEREO AUDIO SPEAKERSThe sound quality is satisfactory but nothing exciting. The bass is barely noticeable but there's just enough to round out the sound a bit. The sound experience is definitely better than sound coming from your tablet, phone, ipod touch, etc. It also gets loud enough to watch movies with a friend (as I demonstrate in the video) or listen to music.However, if you're expecting more thump to your music or movies or if you want a more engaging sound experience then you'll want to consider more of a dedicated speaker system.BUILT IN MICAs I demonstrate in the video, the call quality is good. You can definitely have a clear conversation with someone. The quality isn't quite as good as a dedicated device for making phone calls but it still does a very good job.ALARM CLOCKYou can set the alarm clock for one time (as opposed to having more than one alarm set to wake you up). For me the alarm is plenty loud but if you need a super loud alarm to wake you up you might need to consider using something else.LED TIME AND DATE DISPLAYI love the way the LED looks as it shows through the wood. It's bright enough to see during the day but not too bright at night. I also found it makes a nice conversation piece as everyone who saw it sitting on my desk wanted to check it out. It has that "cool" factor just because of it's clean and distinctive look.Also, the whenever you turn the clock on it finds the time automatically. I find it's very accurate to within a minute.THERMOMETERThere is a build in thermometer which you can set to Fahrenheit or Celsius. It's very accurate and personally I love being able to know the temperate of the room.2.1A USB CHARGING PORTAnother feature I love is that you have a universal USB charging port on the back of the device. Because it's 2.1 amps you can charge tablets as well. It also charges devices faster than 1 amp charging ports.There is a competing product out by GoGroove that only provides a 1 amp charging port so SoundBot definitely did a nicer job here.3.5mm AUDIO PORTOn the back of the speaker you have an audio port which has universal compatibility for your PC, computer, laptop or non-Bluetooth device.For example, if you have an older tablet that doesn't have Bluetooth then you could connect it via the audio port (and supplied cable) to watch movies or listen to music.BOTTOM LINEThis is a great product that gives you a lot of value for the money. Each of the features works really well and it makes this speaker a very versatile unit. I love the presentation and look as it adds a bit of class to any desk, room or wherever you place it. One thing to consider is that if you need a super loud alarm to wake you up or if you need multiple alarms then you might want to consider something else or just get a separate alarm clock for that. Otherwise, this Bluetooth speaker is a great value and I highly recommend it!Please feel free to ask any questions or leave a comment here youtu.be/HQniQdgCsqU and I'll do my best to answer.Thanks for watching and I hope this was helpful! :)

9:24 MinsI've tested and used a LOT of sport headphones and these have now quickly become one of my favorite sport headphones to use!FEATURESThese have the latest technology such as Bluetooth 4.0 and APTX which helps give you CD like quality to your music (even via a wireless signal). The battery life is 10 hours (which is pretty accurate) and you have 250 hours of standby time. Charging is done via a micro USB cable. The bluetooth range is 30 feet which is pretty standard for bluetooth headphones.DURABILITYI contacted the company and found out that the ear pads are specifically designed to handle sweat. Although these aren't water resistant, they can definitely handle a workout (just don't go jogging in the rain with these).CALL QUALITYI've made several phone calls with these, both personal and professional and conversations sound great. You get a crisp, clean conversation. The other person can hear you just fine and can't tell your using headphones.NOISE ISOLATIONThese headphones allow you to still hear what's going on around you. I find this helpful for a sport headphone so that if you're going jogging or riding your bike through an urban area you can still hear enough of what's going on in your surrounding environment.SOUND QUALITYThese have above average sound quality for bluetooth sport headphones in this price range. The bass does feel a bit soft, but again that's not a surprise given the style and size of these headphones. But the mids and highs come through nicely and give you good detail in your music.In my opinion these sound better then the SoundBots and Kinivo's which are in a similar price range but sound about the same as the Motorola S305.These also get very loud. I wasn't able to include the sound leak test and demonstration in this video due to time contraints so you can view that here if interested: youtu.be/GxntpedUqJkCOMFORTThis is what makes these really stand out in my opinion, is that these are the most comfortable sport headphones I've worn using the around-the-neck style of headband. However, after an hour or two of use I do start to feel some discomfort at the tops of my years where the neckband sits.Still, I find these to be much more comfortable when lying down whether doing something like a bench press or just lying in bed listening to music or watching a movie. The neck band doesn't push up on the ear pads the way the Knivo's, SoundBot's and Motorola's do.BOTTOM LINEI'd highly recommend these for anyone looking for a light-weight pair of sport bluetooth headphones. You won't break the bank buying these but you'll definitely have a nicer sounding and more comfortable pair of headphones compared to many of the cheaper options out there.

7:20 MinsI recently learned about Acoustibuds and from all the great reviews I was curious to try these for myself and see how well they really worked.HOW THEY WORKThey basically attach to the end of your earbuds or earphones (include some bluetooth headsets) and provide two main benefits. You get MUCH better sound isolation and Acoustibuds help your earbuds, etc. stay in your ear and not fall out.DO THEY WORK?Absolutely! I was impressed with how comfortable these are. I was surprised by this b/c initially I though there's no way sticking these in my ear will feel good. I was wrong, they not only provide a really snug fit so your earbuds, etc. won't fall out but I found it was more comfortable to use these over longer periods of time then just the earbuds, etc. by themselves.PRACTICAL BENEFITSOne of the things I really like about using these is they give you a LOT more sound isolation. If you're ever tried using earbuds, or earphones on a plane or in any noisy environment it can be almost impossible to hear anything. However, these give such great sound isolation (by blocking outside noise) that you can actually hear your music or movie even when there's lots of noise around you.Using these also makes earpods, etc. much better for working out. I love using earphones for going for a walk or job b/c they're so light but I hate how they easily they fall out or start to slip out of your ear while going for a walk, jog, etc. The Acoustibuds keep your earbuds, etc. pretty well glued in your ear so they are going anywhere.Also, I noticed that because of the better sound isolation and the way the music is directed into your ears with these on that your earpods, etc. will actually sound better. Not only that but you'll use less battery power b/c you won't need to have the volume turned up as loud.RECOMMENDATIONI highly recommend these. They're a great value, they're easy to clean (with soap and water) and they do what they say they'll do. Just be sure to try the different sizes to find the one that fits best for you. I found the smallest size (size 4) worked best for me. I imagine most people would use a size 4 or 5. However, if you have larger ears you might want to try the size 6.Please feel free to ask any questions or leave a comment here youtu.be/-G56TPT9fXU and I'll do my best to answer.Thanks for watching and I hope this was helpful! :)

8:56 MinsIn the quest to find a nice pair of headphones for my daughter, I came across LilGadgets headphones. There's a lot to like about these headphones.FEATURESOne of the first things I look for now with bluetooth headphones is to see whether they give you the option of using these as wired headphones... and I'm happy to say these definitely do that. This means you can use these headphones when the battery is dead or to save your battery life for when you'll really need it.The headphones come with a very soft feeling carrying bag which you can also use to clean off your tablet screen, etc. from all the finger prints and smudges that so easily build up.Battery life is 10 hours and you get 180 hours of standby time. There is an auto-shut off feature that will kick in just in case you forget to turn them off.The bluetooth range is 30ft which I found to be very accurate. My daughter was able to run all around and we never had a problem with these loosing their connection or skipping, pausing, etc.I also like how the track advance and volume switch is easy for kids to access and use (definitely made for littler fingers).The headband is also made of a mesh that is designed to be easier to clean if kids get it dirty.You also can choose between a few different colors.COMFORTThese are designed for smaller heads but when I fully adjusted the headphone headband I was able to actually wear these. The padding on the ear cups is very comfortable and my daughter has been comfortably using these all day which no problem. She absolutely loves wearing these. They're also pretty light as far as headphones go so if you end up packing them up with you they won't add much weight.SOUND ISOLATIONThese do a nice job of isolation sound so that your child can use these on an airplane or in any noisy environment. While they're not active noise cancellating headphones, they still do a noticeably good job of passively blocking out sound.They also leak a bit of sound, particularly at louder volumes so that you can tell if your child is starting to play their music too loudly.SOUND QUALITYThese really shine as being a nicely balanced headphone. You can hear the lows, mids and highs without one dominating the other. Vocals sounds wonderful on these and there's plenty of detail so that your child will get to hear all the things in their music that they'd probably been missing before.My daughter loved how these sounded so much that she started listening to all her favorite music all over again because of how good it sounded to her.BOTTOM LINEEven though these cost a bit more then some cheaper $10 or $20 headphones, you're definitely getting your money's worth. Having a quality pair of bluetooth headphones (which can also be used as wired headphones) that are comfortable enough for your child to wear all day, as well as allowing your child to start to enjoy their favorite movies and music with more detail and clarity is a worthwhile investment. And these headphones were definitely designed with kids in mind. I highly recommend these for anyone looking for a great pair of bluetooth headphones for their child.**UPDATE 2/24/2015**So my daughter STILL loves these and they've held up great!Also, I wanted to mention that these are volume limited without the need of a special adapter, and volume limiting is important to help protect your child's ears.  So when you're not in the same room and your child cranks up the volume (whether intentionally or accidentally) you don't have to worry about the volume getting too loud and potentially damaging their hearing.Bottom line, just a really great pair of headphones. Of course I'm happy my daughter loves them and i think it's great the company is consciously trying to do things on a technical side to protect our kids hearing as well :)

I didn't realize how much more I'd like these over the other wood kitchen utensils I have. They're light and easy to use but also surprisingly easy to clean! I guess having good bamboo products make all the difference :)I read reviews about other similar types of products where people complained about harmful lacquers and such being used on their bamboo utensils but these look completely fine to me. As far as smoothness goes they are almost perfect. There are a few spots where it was just slightly rough but it's not a big deal. I love these though and they are quickly becoming my go-to kitchen utensils of choice!

I was impressed when I first got these. The carrying bag was great, which included straps to help hold everything in place on the inside (so things don't slide around so much). The assembly was fairly straight forward but I did have to consult an online video to figure it out. But once you get the hang of it, it's pretty easy to setup and take apart.Problem:The problem though was that only one of the softboxes worked. I tried all the usual things like trying different outlets and exchanging out the bulb but it was dead on arrival (just like the other review here mentioned). Also, I couldn't help but notice that the cable looked a little worn/used... it just struck me as odd in that it didn't look brand new. Either way this was quite bothersome as rarely do I ever get something brand-new that doesn't work when you first get it. This concerned me b/c if there are a couple of us now having this problem, does that reflect the longevity of these? Meaning, even if they are working when they arrive, maybe 9 months one of them will die (or both!).UsabilityFor the one that did work, it was great! It's easy to adjust the height and the front screen is VERY easy to attach or remove. The hold setup is light and easy to move around.LightingThe big question on my mind was how bright will these actually be? If you go in with the right expectation I think you'll love these. If you have a room that has a decent amount of light but you want to boost it up, these will work great. I wanted to use these for shooting video so the one that worked definitely helped (and having two working lights would really help).If you're shooting still photography and you can afford the luxury of a slower shutter speed then you could use these in lower light situations. But for shooting video, you'll want to have decent light in the room already.

I have to say; this is one of my favorite purchases recently, because it has been such a no-fuss everyday piece. It is simple, yet elegant and on-trend. When I received it about 2 weeks ago, I put it on and went straight to a week long vendor event during which time I was incredibly busy and didn't take the time to remove it at night. I continued to wear it throughout the week. during showers and bathing the kids. I kind of knew in the back of my head that I was taking a risk by putting it through the wringer, so to speak, but I didn't want to take the time to get acquainted with the latch and frankly; it was just easier to keep wearing it. I enjoy the simple design and I like to think of the word "love" as a verb so it was a reminder to do more of it every day. I just took it off last night for no other reason than we had gotten a new kitten and it had scratched my wrist in the area so I wanted to rinse the area with peroxide to clean the cuts and I didn't want to take that risk with it. It still looks great and although it has a tiny place above the letters that look like the finish it changing; it gives it character.As I was studying it after I squeezed the band to remove it, I was thinking about what I would say in my review and how I would rate it - I realized that I only love it more for that little spot that is different because it is quite symbolic of life and relationships. None are perfect and unblemished but we learn to love (as a verb) because of and not in spite of these changes and discrepancies. I purchased this item at a discount in exchange for an honest and unbiased review and all opinions are my own after personal use and inspection.

I am a lifelong cookbook collector. One of my favorite "me moments" involves settling down in my reading spot with a fresh cup of coffee and a good cookbook. "Twenty Dinners" by Ithai Schori, Chris Taylor, and Rachel Holtzman is a wonderful read, full of deliciousness, and it took me out of my normal "cookbook zone". The relaxed look and feel of the book, with its lovely photos and simple layout, is a perfect accompaniment to the varied dishes and drinks presented page-by-page. Chris Taylor learned to cook from his mother, and as he travels with his band, "Grizzly Bear", coming home to cook great meals with friends is a necessary comfort. Ithai Schori, a photographer and former restaurant cook, is in his element when cooking is "messy & satisfying", but he has learned to simplify with the best ingredients and techniques for the best results. "Twenty Dinners" is arranged by season, augmented with knowledgeable contributions on consumables, and stuffed full of helpful and interesting tasty tidbits. Here's a sampling of their tempting recipes: "Roast Chicken"; "Maple Panna Cotta with Candied Almonds and Buttered Bread Crumbs"; "Spiced Red Wine-Poached Pears"; "Butternut Squash Puree"; "Wild Rice with Celery and Pecans"; "Lemon Verbena Tart"; "Rib Eye Steaks Seared, Roasted, and Basted in Butter"; "Meatballs (and Spaghetti)"; "Smoked Earl Grey Hot Toddy"; "Radicchio Salad with Pears, Bleu Cheese, and Bacon"; "Pork Chops and Charred Applesauce"; "Lillie's Sticky Toffee Pudding"; "Tal's Potato Salad"; and "Tomato and Sweet Corn Salad". Gather family and friends, add great food and drinks, and you'll have the perfect recipe for memorable meals.Review Copy Gratis Clarkson Potter Publishers via Blogging for Books

I am going to eat all the candies in my little bag of Werther's Sugar Free Chewy Caramels, and I am going to enjoy them. However, I won't be purchasing them or recommending them due to all the warnings of possible side-effects listed on the back label of the package. The packaging states that these candies are sugar-free and gluten-free, and the calorie count is about 20 per piece. The caramels are soft and chewy and kind of sticky like salt water taffy. The taste is pretty good, with only a very slight aftertaste. What about those warnings? Sugar alcohols that may elevate blood glucose levels. Milk and soybeans that may cause allergic reactions. "Excess consumption may have a laxative effect". Is this Ex-Lax or Werther's Caramels? Don't leave these around where children can find them! Moral of these candies--be a label reader--and consume sweets in moderation.

I have always loved trying different hair and bath products, and I often find that shampoos, washes, and soaps made for babies and children are also fun and useful for adults. The Natures Baby Organics Shampoo and Body Wash, Coconut Pineapple, 16 Fluid Ounce, is a quality product that performs well, but for me, the price is prohibitive. It smells great in the bottle, definitely coconut-pineapple, but that scent fades when you actually use the product. The scent left on your skin is a combination of coconut, other oils, and shea butter. It's not an intrusive scent, and it does diminish within an hour, but it's not as pretty as coconut-pineapple. The liquid itself is silky and pearly, but it is thin--squeeze the bottle lightly to avoid using too much product. This is a shampoo and body wash, so I used it from head to toe. I experienced no irritation, and my skin and hair was soft and very clean. This product is called "organic, vegan and hypoallergenic", with the label telling you all the good stuff inside and all the bad stuff that was left out. Natures Baby Organics Shampoo and Body Wash, Coconut Pineapple, is very pleasant to use, and the quality is high, but, unfortunately, so is the price.

A cookbook from entertainer and Food Network star Trisha Yearwood is always a treat. Like most of her readers and viewers, Trisha is a cook, not a trained chef. Her childhood experiences blended with her career highlights and the camaraderie of her family and friends blend well with a love of cooking and sharing good food with good people. I am a longtime fan of Trisha's music, and I also greatly enjoy watching "Trisha's Southern Kitchen" on TV. Her latest cookbook, "Trisha's Table" reflects her traditional Southern cooking roots along with her new "80/20" food philosophy: 80 percent sensible & 20 percent splurge. While keeping with her Georgia born & raised food favorites, she has reinvented and reimagined many recipes--this book has a very fresh look and feeling to it. Trisha is married to singing star Garth Brooks, whom she says is also a very good cook. Her sister, Beth, along with other family members, frequently guests on the show. I really like the sisters in the kitchen together--they make great food and have a great time. As well as working on a healthier approach to eating, Trisha has been working out, and she looks fabulous! While Trisha is not a dietitian, and there are no nutritional breakdowns for the recipes, "Trisha's Table" may just kick-start your own new approach to a healthier lifestyle. Here are some wonderful recipes that offer "food for thought": "Cran-Apple Crisp"; "Spinach Frittata"; "Power Balls"; "Black Bean Chili and Rice"; "Tortellini Soup"; "Wild Rice and Mushroom Soup"; "Pork Tenderloin with Honey Mustard Glaze"; "Tofu Ricotta Lasagna"; "Spinach Stuffed Shells"; "Chickless Pot Pie"; "Grits-and-Greens Casserole"; "Chocolate Orange Cake"; "Hawaiian Cake"; "Key Lime Cheesecake with Raspberry Sauce"; and "No-Bake Peanut Butter Pretzel Squares". Look for her helpful "Trisha Tip" cooking hints throughout the book.Review Copy Gratis Clarkson Potter Publishers via Blogging for Books

I am a lifetime coffee drinker, starting with childhood cups of "coffee" that were more milk and sugar than coffee. I love all varieties of hot and cold coffee beverages, and my favorite flavor of ice cream is...coffee. However, for me, the all-time best way to enjoy coffee is the most basic: hot, freshly-brewed, aromatherapeutic, restorative coffee with a touch of cream and sugar. As a matter of fact, I am drinking a cup right now! The Mr. Coffee SK13 12-Cup Switch Coffeemaker is a great, reliable way to enjoy the unbeatable experience of a hot, freshly-brewed, classic cuppa joe. It's the same model that we used at work for years, until someone decided to replace it with a fancy, pricier model by a different manufacturer. Not a good idea--the new coffeemaker not only leaked, but it didn't keep the coffee nice and hot. We had to toss it and use our old standby Mr. Coffee until we could replace it with a newer version of the same model. When my own coffeemaker at home quit working--I was given the old Mr. Coffee unit to use until I could get a new coffeemaker. While years of use and abuse have dimmed its luster, it still makes a great cup of coffee, and it remains at my workplace as a backup for extra duty. This model offers brewing pause & serve, which lets you pour a cup of coffee while the coffeemaker is still brewing. However, it does not offer the automatic 2-hour shut-off feature. It stays on, and stays hot, until you turn it off. Brewed coffee is not only a terrific beverage, it's also a wonderful addition to many recipes. Here's a recipe that I am sure you will enjoy--it's even better served with a cup of coffee!Midnight Mocha Cake2 cups sugar1-3/4 cups all-purpose flour3/4 cup cocoa powder2 teaspoons baking soda1 teaspoon baking powder1/2 teaspoon salt2 eggs1 cup buttermilk or sour milk1 cup strong black coffee, cooled1 stick real butter (1/2 cup), melted1 tablespoon vanilla extractPreheat oven to 350F. Grease and flour 12-cup fluted tube pan. Stir together sugar, flour, cocoa, baking soda, baking powder and salt in large bowl. Add eggs, buttermilk, coffee, butter and vanilla; beat at medium speed for 2 minutes. Do not over-beat. Pour batter evenly into prepared pan. Bake 50 to 55 minutes, or until wooden pick inserted in center comes out clean. Cool 15 to 20 minutes. Carefully invert cake pan onto cake rack and let cake loosen from pan onto rack. While cake is still slightly warm, dust lightly with powdered sugar. Or, if desired, let cake cool and then drizzle it with a thick chocolate glaze.

A very nice quality mat, the  STAINMASTER Trusoft Lattice Design Bath Rug feels "cushy" to bare feet. This 100% nylon pile rug is made in the USA, and it does not have a strong chemical or dye odor. It absorbs well and dries quickly. The lattice design is more casual than it appears in the image with the product information, and it will blend with different decors. Most important, the rubberized backing is flexible, so it has some "grip", and stays in place. STAINMASTER Trusoft bath rugs are stain-resistant, and the company recommends machine wash cold and tumble dry low. I was so pleased by the look and feel of this product, as well as the lack of odor, that I checked out other products in this line here on the Amazon website. The larger area rugs are gorgeous! You could easily brighten and renew just about any room in your house with a fresh coat of paint and one of these beautiful area rugs. Start with a new Stainmaster Trusoft Lattice Design Bath Rug, and work your way through the house. A simple, economically feasible way to make an old house seem like new.

"Blue Stars", from author Emily Gray Tedrowe, picks the scabs from the ugly wounds of war and its festering, widespread devastation. A compelling storyline combines the horrors of combat for our armed forces with the stateside survivorship of their family and friends. Two very different women find their lives are changed forever when each must face the care and rehabilitation of their gravely wounded returned soldiers. Ellen, a conservative professor, and Lacey, a restless personal trainer, are drawn together by their shared experiences as "those who wait" at the Walter Reed Army Hospital in Washington, DC. Although the characters are fictionalized, the story is inspired by the real-life 2007 housing scandal at Walter Reed. "Blue Stars" will open your eyes, permanently alter your perceptions of war and its home front consequences, and linger long in your thought processes.

Seek the happiness that you desire and deserve, and propel yourself forward through a journey of self-evaluation, unexpected discoveries, and amazing revelations. This is "Happiness for Beginners", from author Katherine Center. In her early thirties and post-divorce, Helen Carpenter thinks a three-week adventure trek through the wilderness of wonderful Wyoming will make her a new woman--a tougher, stronger woman better able to chart and navigate the course of her own life. She certainly didn't plan on taking the trip with her younger brother's best friend, Jake, someone whom she had never liked, but Fate stepped in and changed the game plan. Jake, younger than Helen by a decade, has always had a serious crush on Helen, and this may be a chance for long-held emotion and attraction to come to full bloom. How will Helen handle an involvement with someone whom, for years, she had told herself she loathed? Going from your daily city-life routine to facing the challenges of the wild will definitely change the perimeters of your thinking-box, open your mind, and expand the horizons of your heart. Katherine Center's charming characterizations and involving storyline will captivate your reader's imagination, and it might just inspire you to take your own journey of a lifetime.

Author David Bez is a designer, not a chef, and he doesn't so much create recipes as he does combine marvelous mixes of ingredients to concoct sumptuous, satisfying salads. His gorgeous book, "Salad Love", has a clean, linear look that explodes with color from the beautiful salads featured on almost every page. Believe me, those food photos are fork-ready, and they are guaranteed to inspire you to think green and eat fresh. David wanted to incorporate food that is "healthy, fresh, tasty, and quick" into meals that would invigorate and energize him in body and mind. The results of his experiments are fabulous salads like these: "Mozzarella, Cherry Tomatoes & Spinach"; "Strawberries, Melon & Almonds"; "Oak-Smoked Cheddar, Peaches & Blueberries; "Roast Beef, Beet, Pomegranate & Orange Zest"; "Red Grapes, Celery & Walnuts"; "Apple, Celery, Walnuts & Pomegranate Seeds"; "Ham, Roasted Potatoes, Carrot & Dried Cranberries"; "New Potatoes, Peas & Red Lettuce". Each salad recipe is accompanied by a very simple to put together salad dressing. The salads are grouped by seasons, and dietary types are indicated, but the recipes do not include nutritional breakdowns. The time spent in the preparation of these lovely meals is time well-spent, indeed.Review Copy Gratis Clarkson Potter Publishers via Blogging for Books

I have spent most of the day unpacking and carrying pieces of this 100-lb unit up the stairs to the room where it will be used. The "Cosco The Avery Line 3-Drawer Classic Baby Changing Table, Dark Cherry Finish" came unassembled in a flat box. The package was quite heavy, and it was difficult for me to even get it far enough into the house to allow me to shut the door. On my own, with arthritic hands, putting this unit together proved to be a formidable task. I am usually able to assemble just about anything for the home, but this was a challenge. Let me say this: "How could something so heavy, with this price tag, have such cheap parts?". The image of the piece was promising, with the idea that this would be an attractive, useful piece of furniture which could be used not just for babies and children, but also for teens and adults--something that was made to last and was worth passing on to family members. The product info states that this changing table will hold a baby weighing up to 30 pounds. I would not feel comfortable using this unit to support a baby. The drawers don't seem as though they would hold anything but very lightweight items. I would not give this product as a gift to a mother to use for her baby, and I would not purchase another product from this company for my own use. I would say that this is a decorative rather than functional piece of furniture, but it was so heavy and so time-consuming to put together, at the end its looks had lost some of their appeal.

With "One Wish", I had another lovely visit "home" to author Robyn Carr's fictional community of Thunder Point, Oregon. Amid the rugged coastal beauty of this charming little town and its surroundings, longtime residents and newcomers find friendship, a real sense of belonging, and sweetly sensual romance. "One Wish" tells the story of Grace Dillon, who moved to Thunder Point to leave behind a troubled past and make her way to a happier future. Unbeknownst to those in her adopted home place, Grace was once a championship figure skater. She walked away from the fame and glory at the height of her career, greatly disappointing her hard-driving mother, who had also been a renowned skater. Grace wanted more from life than the punishing hours of practice and personal sacrifices that came with being on top in her profession--she wanted a real life, a life that offered her the freedom of making her own personal choices. Troy Headly, a popular high school teacher, had come to Thunder Point because the teaching position offered him a chance to be close to the water, where he could pursue his love of the outdoors. Grace and Troy had a mutual friend, Iris, from whom Grace had purchased the flower shop which, although demanding, gave her such satisfaction. Grace had a serious crush on Troy, but he carried a torch for Iris, who married her childhood friend Seth. Things change, however, and as awareness of Graces grows on Troy, she hopes that she's not just a rebound romance. Grace, for all her former celebrity, actually has lived a very sheltered personal life. Troy treats her with respect and gentleness, bringing out her fun side and her great laugh. Grace already knows she's in deep water with her feelings, and Troy is trying to sort through all of his unexpected thoughts about a real relationship with Grace. The things you run from always run right beside you--you can never really leave them behind until you face them down. When the past finds Grace, will the companionship and attraction between them prove to be something much more? Will a future filled with loving joy be theirs for the taking? Come home with me to Thunder Point. I promise you will enjoy the journey, and it's one that you will want to make again and again.

Bringing forward supporting character Officer Cassie Dewell from his stunning prior work, "The Highway", author C.J. Box moves Cassie from Montana to the "Badlands" of Grimstad, North Dakota. Assuming the position of Deputy Sheriff of Grimstad, Cassie faces the crimes and misdemeanors associated with the money, drugs, and power plays of the oil business. After two years of tracking, she will also come face-to-face with "The Lizard King", a heinous serial killer who used the miles and miles of endless asphalt as his own personal hunting ground. He had also murdered Cassie's partner, Cody Hoyt. Into the mix comes twelve-year old Kyle Westergaard--a newspaper carrier traveling his route on his bicycle who witnesses a life-ending and life-changing accident. While the world sees Kyle as "slow", he has greater perception and depth of observation than the world acknowledges. Kyle also has his own agenda. With his usual superb storytelling, C.J. Box parlays paralyzing cold, rugged landscapes, compelling characterizations, and an involving storyline into a winning feature tale for Cassie Dewell, whom we hope to see again in her own future adventures.

Superlative storyteller Susan Wilson tells a compelling, poignant, and ultimately uplifting tale in "The Dog Who Saved Me". While the story does not flinch away from abuse, hardships, and tragedy, it also celebrates survivorship and the triumph of the spirit, both human and animal. At the heart of it all is an extremely well-written, well-paced police story. Cooper Harrison thought he had left his troubled youth behind when he moved from small-town Harmony Farms to become an officer in a Boston K-9 unit. Unable to overcome his grief when beloved canine partner Argos is killed in a bombing incident, Cooper tries to drink away his sorrow and come to grips with the physical limitations of his own injuries. When his marriage and career come to an end, a call from an old friend, now the police chief of Harmony Farms, offers Cooper a chance to start over. He never imagined he would end up as the Animal Control Officer back in his home town, but that's just where he lands. Now he has to face his father, Bull, known as the town drunk, and his older brother, Jimmy, fresh out of prison after serving time on drug charges. Cooper's work as an animal control officer is vastly different from his duties as K-9 unit officer. He's now a lawman, a handyman, a counselor, a psychologist--both for humans and animals, and he's a tracker, a super-sleuth, and much, much more. Along the way he begins a romance with lovely woman, Natalie, who rescues and rehabs horses and has her own set of emotional issues. Linking all of these people together, in ways never anticipated, is a yellow dog. Not just any dog, but a purebred yellow Lab, a victim of abuse, and a survivor of severe hardship. It will take all of Cooper's skill, intelligence, and innate compassion to capture and revitalize this dog, but eventually dog and man will offer to each other the gift of hope. The characters are beautifully-layered and shaded--definitely beyond stereotypes--and you may find yourself rethinking some of your own relationships with others. The storyline is so involving that it will keep you intrigued until the last page is turned, and you will be thinking about all you've read far beyond "The End". With "The Dog Who Saved Me" author Susan Wilson reminds us that while some people are habitually rotten, beneath the crust of the crustiest humans there beats a heart, and above that heart is brain with a surprising variety and depth of thoughts. A highly recommended read from a very gifted author.

I was immediately drawn to "The Healthy Mind Cookbook" for two good reasons--the sumptuous steak salad displayed on the cover, and the descriptive terminology "nutrient-dense foods". That's right--more bang for the bite! Author Rebecca Katz has put together a remarkable collection of 100+ recipes that are meant to tempt, tantalize, and treat the appetites of your mind and body. A healthy lifestyle and diet will not only add years to your life, but also add life to your years. Boost your brain function and build your body with foods that are good for you and taste terrific. Learn about how foods affect your thought processes, your moods, and the many functions of that marvelous machine--your body. Check out the "Culinary Pharmacy", a rich resource of power-packed foods and ingredients. Once you reach the recipe section, you'll find yourself highly-motivated and extremely hungry. Satisfy your curiosity and your cravings with wonderful dishes like these: "Gingered Butternut Squash Soup with Walnut Cream"; "Robust Chicken Soup"; "Roasted Orange Sesame Carrots"; "Avocado Citrus Salad"; "Braised Chicken and Earthy Root Vegetables"; "Thai It Up Steak Salad"; "Triple Greens Frittata"; "Tart Cherry and Chocolate Crunch"; "Cranberry, Orange, and Apricot Muffins"; "Tricolor Pepper Salsa"; "Olive and Sun-Dried Tomato Tapenade"; "Pumpkin Tart in a Cashew Crust"; "Chocolate Cherry Walnut Truffles"; and "Meyer Lemon Pudding with Fresh Strawberries". Feed your brain with inspirational ideas and fabulous food.Review Copy Gratis 10 Speed Press via Blogging for Books

"Black River", with its immediate sense of place, compelling storyline, and memorable characters, is a remarkable debut work from author S.M. Hulse. Like the men before him in his family, Wes Carver was a correctional officer for the Montana State Prison, which was located not far from his small home town of Black River. During a prison riot, Wes was tortured and maimed, losing his ability to play his beloved fiddle. Wes and his wife Claire eventually moved from Black River, leaving behind not only the prison, but also Claire's troubled teenaged son, Dennis. Years later, just before Claire's death from leukemia, she requests to go home to Black River. Wes complies, but Claire passes away before they can make it, and Wes travels home with the silent companionship of Claire's ashes. A tense reunion with Dennis is compounded by the upcoming parole hearing for Bobby Williams, the man who had forever changed life for Wes and his family. Can Wes live with whatever the verdict may be, even if the outcome is the unthinkable? Will he find a way to begin healing himself and finding some sense of peace, or will the cycle of violence remain unbroken? "Black River" is a quick, involving read that will leave a lasting impression.

Richly-atmospheric, compellingly-detailed, and thoughtfully-characterized, "Deepest Roots of the Heart" is a splendid beginning to author Chautona Havig's "Legacy of the Vines" series. Set in the historic beauty of California's Napa Valley in the Post WWII Era, the story actually spans generations as the protagonist tells stories from the past while making plans for his future. Avelino Carrillo survived his horrific wartime experiences with the thought of returning to his family home, la Casa de los Suenos, as the guiding light to see him through. When he finally makes it home, he finds the house and property have been rented to Joe Kearns and his granddaughter, Amelia. Years ago, Avelino's older brother had borrowed money to keep the home, the land and the vineyards in the family. La Casa de los Suenos had been the collateral and the agreement with the money lender had allowed for tenants on the property. While Avelino is drawn to the lovely Amelia, he feels there are too many difference between them, and he most not be distracted from his quest to regain ownership of his ancestral home. However, the heart will have its way, and sometimes the heart is smarter than the mind. Will the growing love between Avelino and Amelia bloom into a harvest as rich and sweet as the fruit of the vineyard? "Deepest Roots of the Heart" is an inspiring historical romance, and I look forward to the next entries in the series.

"Bettyville", a beautifully-written memoir from author George Hodgman, will gently break places in your heart, and then it will tenderly patch them back together with warmth and humor. George Hodgman becomes the care provider for his elderly mother, Betty, leaving his life in Manhattan behind and returning to his home town of Paris, Missouri. Having reached the age of ninety-something by living in her own indomitable manner, Betty will not go quietly into old-age oblivion. As issues such as dementia, cancer, and increasing physical frailty creep into the picture, Betty remains a force to be reckoned with. At the age of ninety-one, she chooses to fight her cancer, and begins radiation therapy. Throughout all of their rumblings and grumblings while reconnecting and acclimating to once again living in the same house, it becomes clear that there is a great love between mother and son. Seeing Betty struggle, yet refuse to surrender her spirit, leads George to discover his own personal strengths and gives him the courage to move forward with choices for his future. My own mother's name was Betty, and while our life situation was quite different from George and his mother, much of our circumstances were similar. While George left home and then came back, I stayed with my mother for almost fifty years. My Betty and I were separated only when she passed away. George and his Betty remain together. "Bettyville" is keenly-observed, poignant, and written with great heart. A recommended read for caregivers, but also for those who receive the care.

Pretty and practical little teapot makes a lovely cuppa...I truly believe that finding joy in simple pleasures is one of the keys to finding personal happiness. Taking time to do something nice for yourself is uplifting and encouraging. The Tea Beyond PINK Glass Teapot Butterfly 710ml 24 Oz Non Drip with Infuser is not only pretty and practical, but it also makes a lovely cuppa. Made of clear tempered glass with an etched design around the pot and a delicately beautiful pink butterfly on the lid, this little teapot adds much pleasure to the tea-drinking experience. Heat resistant glass, an anti-slip handle, and a non-drip spout add functionality to the aesthetic appeal. I always recommend filling a teapot with hot water and letting it sit while you are waiting for the water to boil. When the water has boiled, drain the teapot, fit in the infuser, and add your tea. Pour the boiling water over the tea in the infuser and allow your tea to brew, and in the case of the flowering and blooming teas, watch your tea blossom. To serve, hold the handle with one hand, and keep the lid in place with the other hand. I hand wash the teapot and handle it with care. For a fully enjoyable tea time, indulge yourself with The Tea Beyond Tea Combo FLS-TCBO-FJEC001 Fab Flowering tea plus assorted whole leaf tea.Here's recipe from me to you--just right for "Tea for Two":AUNT GRANNY'S TEA CAKES1 cup butter (no substitutes), softened1 1/2 cups sugar3 eggs1 tablespoon vanilla extract3 cups all-purpose flour1 tablespoon baking powder1/4 teaspoon saltpowdered sugar for toppingIn a mixing bowl, cream butter and sugar. Add eggs, one at a time, beating well after each addition. Beat in vanilla. Combine flour, baking powder and salt; gradually add to the creamed mixture (the dough will be soft). Drop by teaspoonfuls 2 in. apart onto greased baking sheets. Bake at 375 degrees F for 7-8 minutes or until the edges are golden brown. Remove to wire racks to cool. Place on a serving plate and sprinkle lightly with powdered sugar.Review Product Gratis Tea Beyond

A totally tea-rific experience...The benefits of tea have been touted for centuries. Both soothing and stimulating, tea is therapeutic and bestows a bevy of pleasures for the senses. The Tea Beyond Tea Combo FLS-TCBO-FJEC001 Fab Flowering tea plus assorted whole leaf tea offers all that and more. Opening the box tied with a pretty purple ribbon was like opening a treasure chest, and it was packed full of teas which included Premium Earl Gray Black, Premium Jasmine Green, Premium Caramel Black loose teas, as well as the Fab Flowering tea pods in Fab Jasmine, Forever Love, Paradise, and Sunshine. The loose teas are exceptional, and my favorite is the Premium Caramel Black. The Fab Flowering teas are simply amazing--a totally tea-rific experience which transformed my way of thinking about drinking tea. My favorite flowering tea is Paradise. Tea Beyond states that their products are all natural, no artificial additives, and they optimize the tea drinking experience with premium ingredients which provide healthful benefits for mind and body. A lovely gift for yourself and all the tea lovers in your life. Also recommended for preparing and serving your delightful teas: Tea Beyond PINK Glass Teapot Butterfly 710ml 24 Oz Non Drip with Infuser.Review Product Gratis Tea Beyond

What a lovely idea--"The Soup Club"--made even more appreciable by the theme "Feed Your Friends. Feed Your Family. Feed Yourself.". Authors Courtney Allison, Tana Carr, Caroline Laskow, and Julie Peacock have taken a philosophy dear to my own heart--I believe in "The Kitchen Table"--and given it a modern, mobile twist. One day a week, each of the club members will prepare and distribute an edible blessing, and then they will be repaid in turn. The ideal of nurturing your family in body and soul, providing healthy, home-cooked food, and giving them the blessing of personal time spent together is often in great conflict with the pressures found in our contemporary society. Why not share your heartfelt goals with like-minded family and friends? "The Soup Club Cookbook" is filled with fabulous food, beautifully photographed in vivid color, and it offers ideas on how you can start your own "Soup Club". The recipes include sensational soups and sides, delectable desserts, super salads, bodacious breads, and a marvelous mix of old favorites with a new attitude. Foods are healthy, happy, and homemade--"soul-satisfyingly good". Hard-to-resist recipes include: "Potato Cheddar Soup"; "Borscht"; "Sun-Dried Tomato Soup"; "Winter Minestrone"; "Chicken Tortilla Soup"; "Cheese Crisps"; "Red Cabbage Salad"; "Quick Pickles"; "Maple Butter Carrots"; "Cheddar Cornbread"; "Jeweled Rice"; "Spinach and Onion Quiche"; "Garlic Herbed Cheese"; and "Cinnamon-Sugar Walnuts". This is one club where "lifetime membership" takes on a whole new meaning, and you will enjoy paying your dues.Review Copy Gratis Clarkson Potter Publishers via Blogging for Books

This book wasn't what I was expecting.  Its more a curiosity than anything else.  The spells are recipes that include real herbs, some dangerous, and then odd stuff that no one could be expected to be able to acquire (brains of an eagle?).  Some of the spells and listings are interesting, but I'd do more research before relying on them.  This seemed more a collection of the strange and spooky gleaned from other sources and then put together to appeal to the reader of the day...who expected icky, weird, dark spells and incenses and the like because isn't that what Witchcraft is all about?It makes a nice addition to the library as a look back at what was being published in the past, but I'd never recommend this book, especially not to a newbie to the Craft.  I've other books like this from that time period with the same focus.  This isn't a book about Witchcraft as a religion, but magical practices and, if you like collections of color associations, herbs, incense recipes (many of which you can't make) then you might like this book...but take much of it with a grain of salt.

Not really Wicca, not really Traditional Witchcraft, this book sort of falls in-between and is a mix of the author's experiences over many years used to express gnosis he achieved on what he terms the Rose and Thorn Path.  The primary deity of this path is "She of the Thorn-Blooded Rose," and he began with planting a rose bush on his land and then communing with it (with Her) and the Dingle, a nearby woods.  This all began he says in 2006 and he has been building on it ever since, this book being an off-shoot of the work.  As he puts it, this is not really new and not really old.  It is a new path, but one based on ancient ideas and with a framework that is recognizable to us today.The book includes rituals (some of which make use of names which are unknown and probably one of the things the author achieved through communion with the beings of this path), lists/attributes of plants, and tools.  One of the big differences immediately seen is the big use of the mortar and pestle as a tool.  Other tools are somewhat more familiar, including the stang from Trad Craft.  He also gives us a mythology (origin story) and talks about working with plants and the Faery.  He talks about how the center of the rose has 5 points and each of these points contributes to what makes a Witch, as well as how the "X" is the point where Witches and Faery meet and this point is the portal.  He also talks about starting by blood-sharing, drinking the "green blood" of the plant and offering some of your own blood to your rose bush.If this path appeals to the reader, I can see it as a good beginning.  It lays down a basic structure that you can build your own practice on.  It also can lend some ideas to you if this is not your path and so can be useful in that regard, such as making you think about adding the mortar and pestle to your work or working more closely with plants.  This path didn't jump up and make me feel its the right one for me, but that doesn't mean there aren't folks out there who will read it and find it calls to them.  Old paths can often re-appear through the gnosis and hard work of people who then find a means to put it on a basic structure that others can then take and run with.  This book is an example of that.  It has a familiar part-Wiccan, part-Trad Craft feel to it, mixed with something not before seen...something that has a ring of truth to it and, clearly, will work for those who are drawn to follow it.

I ordered these at the same time as I ordered "Trailer Park Wars," because the reviews of the game said it would last longer if you had extra flamingos.  They came quickly and fit in perfectly for the game, extending the play time.But I can see other uses for these, as well...such as using them to decorate gifts and party hats and generally using them to amuse and annoy friends and family.  I mean, who doesn't need a bag full of tiny pink plastic flamingos?  Go on...you know you want em!

Fun game that is not for the easily offended.  Trailer Park Wars involves you owning your own trailer park where you add amenities that are then worth points (the points being represented by tiny pink plastic flamingos, what else?) and good tenants who are worth points, while trying to give bad tenants to the other trailer park owners and make bad things happen to their trailer parks, like an alligator infestation, for example.  There are small cardboard name markers where you draw a 1, 2, and 3 to put together your trailer park name, then lay out your trailers that also have names and pictures ranging from nice trailers to rusting junks about to fall down.  You can have good folks in your trailer park or bad ones.  Some are worth more and some are worth less depending on your amenities and some of them can get "hitched."One thing I noticed was that, once you have your park going, you tend to get a lot of points per turn, hence having tons of flamingos all over the table.  Once all the flamingos are gone, the game is over.  I did buy the extra flamingos (because of the reviews here), but decided after playing the game to adjust it so that, instead of playing three cards per turn, you can only play one--thus having to decide if you want to improve your park or ding someone else's.  This results in less points per turn and so the flamingos last longer.  I'm also thinking of getting something else to represent, say, 10 flamingos so that you can turn in some and have something else sitting at your trailer park...such as a tiny garden gnome.I also think players should be allowed to use the 1-2-3 name cards to create their trailer park name or just make up their own.  You do get to add your own names to one set of the cards, which I did, but I think there is more room for creativity in allowing folks the pick of naming their own or using the name cards included.The instructions are pretty easy to figure out and anyone should enjoy this from those in their late teens to ?  Some might be a bit offended by it, but those people aren't my friends, that's for sure.

A brilliant movie that was as compelling as it was hard to watch at times.  Benedict Cumberbatch once again plays a mad genius wonderfully and Kiera Knightley was also terrific in this film.  The movie is based on the life of Alan Turing, a man called upon in WW2 to help break the German Enigma machine, the machine that they used to send all of their codes and that, if broken, could help win the war for the Allies.  He ends up working at Bletchley Park with other code breakers, where he alienates them due to his lack of social skills and his insistence that he work on his own machine to help them crack Enigma.  Joan Clarke is brought in to help out and she teaches Turing how to at least attempt to act more friendly to his co-workers and, together, they build his own machine...which turns out, as we suspect, to be the first computer off of which all our modern computers are based.The story takes place in the 1950's, where Turing is arrested for homosexuality (a crime in England at the time) with flashbacks to the 1940's and back to Turing's school days in the 1920's.  There are no easy answers in this film as, even if they break Enigma (which we all know they did from history) how and where should this information be used without giving away the game to the Germans?  Bittersweet at times, this movie was very well done and left me thinking how sad it was what happened to this man who helped save millions of lives in WW2 and why it took so long to acknowledge his contribution.

Generally, I liked this book, most especially that after all of the chapters about how bad things are and how bad things can get if this pattern remains unopposed, the author gives some ideas about to get actively involved in protecting our rights as Americans.  The writing did seem to repeat itself and come across as ranting here and there, but I admire the author's passion in this undertaking.  The book is a pretty quick read and some of it is already a bit dated, but the general gist of the book is still relevant--that there are movements in this country, in particular with the Republican Party/Religious Right, to undermine the Constitutional rights granted to all citizens of this country.  Rights based off the secular common sense and reason of the Founding Fathers and not off one religion or one religious book.The book contains examples of where children have been hurt by laws not affecting religious run organizations, such as day cares, and how allowing parents to not take their children to doctors/hospital when they in need of medical attention has allowed them to suffer and even die.  I have no problem, personally, with the idea of faith-healing, but I also don't think it means  you can't take your children in for medical attention at the same time.  The book states that those fighting against organizations who are attempting to make this country a Christian theocracy spend too much time battling the small problems while letting the big ones slip on by...such as fighting over nativity scenes being displayed in public areas in small towns rather than letting the Texas Dept of Education dictate what can amount to false science or false history in the majority of textbooks here in the US.One chapter lists 50 politicians who are, to one extent or another, involved in putting their particular religious views into law and undermining the separation of Church and State that allows us Americans to have our freedom of religion in the first place.  The quotes at the beginnings of the chapters were also very telling...and scary.  As was the chapter where the author gave quotes from Jefferson and Madison and how they would be received today, even though they played a huge part in the founding of our country.  He also quotes from Abraham Lincoln and a treaty from the 1700's that directly states that the US is not a Christian country...a treaty that Pres George Washington also played a part in approving.This book needs to be read, no matter how hard the truths are that it contains.

Dark humor in the best British tradition, "One Foot in the Grave" is the sad tale of Victor and his long-suffering wife, Margaret.  Victor is between jobs and spends his time getting into spats with the neighbors and just about anyone else he comes across.  If anything can go wrong in his life...it will, and he will spend eternity grousing about it.  The shows are about a half hour long each and they pack a lot into them.  Another long-standing character who appears is Mrs Warboys, who also ends up with her life crumbling down as often as not.This season includes a dark (of course!) Christmas special that involves radioactive allotment dirt.  Another one is about a battle over garbage/littering, and another sees the Meldrew's burgled so that they end up sitting on lawn chairs in their living room staring at the place where their tv used to be.  Oh...and bird's nest dropping on Victor's head during a wedding video, and trying to get a man in to shave off the bottom of their doors so they will close over new carpet.One wonders how Margaret has put up with Victor for so long, but then an episode happens where you realize they are, quite honestly, made for each other.  You also can see that they honestly do care for each other...in those instances (rare, though they are) when Victor's kinder (gasp!) nature comes through, albeit ever so briefly.Don't expect a light-hearted slapstick romp through the daisies and you might enjoy this show.  Victor is hilarious to watch, but he is definitely not the guy you want living next door to you.

Incredibly haunting and beautiful, the vocals will give you chills at times.  The CD also has some wonderful Middle Eastern style drum work.  Even though you can't understand most of the lyrics, the theme of the songs still come across.  The focus of this work is about the "Star of the Sea," and the first work is about Santa Maria.  The songs span the centuries, including traditional pieces from the 13th and 15th centuries and more modern works, and center around celebrating the feminine divine.Stellamara is a great band and I will be buying more from them in the future.  My only quibble with this CD (and its a minor one) is that I wish the CD had included more information about the traditional songs and, maybe, some translations.

This documentary revolves around three people who follow a mystical path--a member of the Spiritualist church, a Lakota man who Sundances, and a Witch who is part of the Feri Tradition.  It promised to be an interesting look at non-mainstream religions in America, but fell mostly flat.  The actual film quality was nicely done, but the documentary was way too slow and way too long.  How many times do we have to watch someone standing there looking out over the landscape while they play wind noises or some such?For someone who doesn't know much about the Spiritualist Church, the Lakota religion and modern Witchcraft, this documentary would have fallen short of imparting any kind of real understanding.  Perhaps, it would have been better to include a greater depth of background into the Spiritualist Church, Lakota ways and practices, and Feri Craft in order to really get where these people were coming from.  As it is, the documentary tried to tie all of this together in some way to comment on mysticism in America, but it was a very clumsy effort that didn't much succeed.  What was the real point of this documentary?  It seemed lost most of the time...If you wanted the documentary to be about mystic paths in America, there are many others out there besides these three, including more mainstream Christian religions that have mystical practices.  The same is true of Islam and Judaism.  But if the point was to look at less well known paths that the general population knows little if anything about, I would think this program would leave them more confused than anything.  It could also leave them thinking these people are just crazy.I can't recommend this documentary, both because it was too slow, too long, and way too pretentious and because its content didn't really leave you with a deeper comprehension of mysticism in modern America.

This soap came very quickly and was extremely well-packaged.  The bars are full-sized and have a nice floral rose scent to them, not too powerful, not too faint.  For anyone who likes rose-scented soaps, this is a great buy.  They also aren't very spendy, which is nice.  I first tried these soaps in Mexico and fell in love with them and it was wonderful to find them available on Amazon.I will definitely be buying more of these and also getting some for gifts.

This is a pretty good gluten free breakfast cereal.  If you're looking for something that will taste exactly like corn flakes, these are made of amaranth primarily and they do have a slightly different flavor to them.  They are crunchy and hold up in milk and aren't too sweet, as so many cereals tend to be.  This is not my absolute favorite gluten free cereal, but they are very good all the same.The best amaranth flakes I ever had actually were slightly blue in color and they definitely had a different taste to them, but I can't seem to find them anymore.  This one comes in only a touch behind those, though if you want kids to eat them and they really like super sugary cereal, it may take some getting used to.

Special K...I have missed you.  Imagine my delight, when I recently found a gluten free version in the store.  Chewy and only slightly sweet (it really is just a "touch" of brown sugar), this is a breakfast cereal I will be buying again and again.  I imagine this would also make for an excellent cookie when you make those that call for cereal in the recipe.This has now become my go-to breakfast cereal.  Kellogg's, please put out more of your cereals gluten free!

These fig and raspberry Figgies are absolutely fabulous.  They are pretty good sized and have a wonderful fig and raspberry filling surrounded by a moist cookie outer crust.  Honestly, I like these better than Fig Newtons and I love Fig Newtons.You would never know that these are gluten free.  They definitely don't suffer from the dryness that some gluten free products have.  They aren't cheap, but I'm willing to pay more for a tasty gluten free product that satisfies the need to be able to eat something you can't otherwise eat.  I would buy these for my celiac and wheat-sensitive friends any day.Way to go, Pamelas!

I have tried out many many gluten free breads and found a few that are worth raving over, but most of them are still only really good for a day and then you have to put them in the freezer and toast them to make them work.  However, this bread is different.  Not only is it sealed up in a closed bag within the outer bag, but it is fresh and soft and tastes more like real bread than any other gluten free bread I have tried yet.  After I open it, I then keep it in the fridge and it stays fresh for several more days, before I finally put it in the freezer just in case.  But, like wow!!! that first day of fresh gluten free bread that tastes like real bread is wonderful...This bread is not only terrific for sandwiches (finally!), but its good toasted and to bake with.  I would not hesitate to use this bread for stuffings and bread puddings.
