I've even used it to make French Toast.I have found it the store for about 5-6 dollars a loaf, but, that being said, I have a hard time finding it at most grocery stores at all.  So far, just the one store seems to carry it and its not local to me (sadly).

Overall, this was a good book and a decent thriller that kept me reading until the end.  But it wasn't a book that kept me so glued to it that I couldn't put it down.  The main characters were interesting and the plot was good, but there were just a few too many subplots that detracted from the main one and that we, honestly, didn't need.  It was like they were just there to make the book longer.Some spoilers.  Cam and Mike have broken up, but their teenage daughter Tess hasn't given up on them getting back together.  The main issue is Cam's broken home (her mom left when she was little and her sister committed suicide) and that her father is a drinker and that Cam has had visions of lost and hurt children for years...something she has kept from her husband and that drove her to drink, as well.  She thinks these visions are bad dreams, but it turns out she is actually psychic.  She and Tess go to their home on an island and, of course, that is the hunting ground of the serial killer in question.  Another psychic appears (this plot point seems forced) and Cam becomes involved with the police investigation for the various missing teenage girls and, no surprise, her own daughter also ends up missing.I did enjoy this book and would read another by this author, but she is no Mary Higgins Clark (much as the book blurbs try to make her out to be).

I was all set to like this book.  It had a great idea, but the actual writing and plot left a lot to be desired.  As a first time novel, this was a swing and a miss...maybe, the author needs to go back and take a few writing classes before their next attempt to undertake a novel.  Some of the plot went nowhere and were just dropped.  There were scenes that made no sense and didn't advance the plot.  Some of the descriptions were unnecessarily crude and offensive, especially anything to do with sex.Some spoilers ahead:  The plot was supposed to revolve around Conrad and his wife Joanna moving from LA to an old house in Wisconsin that used to be a "birthing house," essentially a place where women came to have their kids.  The implication was that this included un-wed women.  Of course, the house is haunted and the former owner hands Conrad an old photo album where one of the women of the past looks just like his current wife.  However, this intriguing plot point never really turned into anything so it was pretty useless.  Conrad also begins to keep snakes--unbeknownst to  his wife--and one of them lays eggs without the help of a male and this seems to reflect in the women in this house getting pregnant.  However, the plot with the snake also ends up no where and its never really made clear if the women are getting pregnant without a male or with one?  The idea was that the house wants to "birth" things, I guess.In fact, I was guessing a lot with this story as it left out too much that was needed and put in things we didn't need, such as Conrad's obsession with iced tea (?) and with the pregnant teenage girl next door, Nadia, as he interfered between her and her boyfriend.  Also, ghost sex anyone?  Or was it ghost sex?  All of this was confused.  If the point was to confuse the plot as to whether Conrad was just going crackers or being influenced by the house or ghosts in the house, then that would have been a good story, but it was handled so clumsily that you couldn't tell...and, by the end, you didn't care.  This book needed more editing and a good, strong, serious re-write to fill in the plot holes, cut out the extraneous details, and make more cohesive sense.

Absolutely love this cookbook!  These are definitely "Grandma" recipes, and from Grandmas who could cook up a storm.  So far, all of the recipes I've tried have turned out great.  I can definitely recommend them, though this may not be a book for the beginner cook as some of the recipes instructions are fairly minimal as the cooks who wrote them down back in the day expected that anyone reading them would have a basic knowledge of what to do and when to do it.The book also contains histories of the grandmas that the recipes came from and other tidbits of information.  For example, one recipe for a date cake was such a favorite that they served it at a wedding and another that a recipe for a fruit and nut jumble (a kind of cookie) was passed along during the 1920's.  When I read this book, it's like I'm looking at the old recipes I inherited from my grandmas and they even included a couple of pages of copies of the actual hand-written recipes to look at.The only thing I would have liked to see included in this book were some photos, as I would have liked to see the grandmas in question, their farms, their kitchens.  Other than that, this is a fabulous book for those who enjoy trying out old recipes.

I always worry about buying a perfume without being able to smell it first...but this one turned out to be a winner.  I am not into overly-floral scents since so many of them are too strongly sweet and some of them even smell more like a chemical replica of a floral scent than actual flowers, but this one was perfect.  I have tried Elizabeth Arden's regular Green Tea perfume and liked that one, too, but this one adds a slightly more flowery scent that still managed to remain subtle and light.  I'm not sure it really smells like honeysuckle, but it smells nice all the same.  I will definitely buy this again and get it as gifts for my friends.Now, if only they would make a Green Tea Lily of the Valley scent...that would be a dream!

Tastes good and good for you.  This is especially handly around flu and cold season, when you want to keep from getting sick or get over being sick faster.  Chock full of vitamins that help your immune system and keep you going, I have been buying these now for a while.  I've tried several flavors and Tropical was my favorite one, but this Raspberry one might be changing my mind.You can add one of these packets to regular water (iced, is best) or do what I do and add it to fizzy water.  Its just a touch sweet and not too overpowering.

Overall, I enjoyed this book, but I would have enjoyed it more if it had been cut by about 100 pages.  There was just too many characters who didn't have anything much to do with the plot and nothing really panned out in their stories that added enough to that main plot to make it worthwhile.  I must admit that I started skipping pages about half-way through when the focus was on these secondary characters so that I could stick with the much more interesting main story.Cathy Scarlet and Tom Feather want to get their dream, a catering company in Dublin, off to a start.  They finally find a site and, despite hints of some dark past with the location, they acquire it and fix it all up and get their business going.  The stories about their trials with various customers and their parties and events is one of the best parts of the book.  But their focus on the new business is distracted by Cathy's problems with her husband, Neil, a lawyer who chases after every good cause, taking up all of his time, and Tom's issues with Marcella, who wants desperately to be a model.  Also, Cathy ends up taking charge of two children, relatives of her husbands, whose own parents can't take care of them for a while.  Simon and Maud are also one the best parts of the book as they struggle to become reasonable children and learn some actual manners.  I also enjoyed Cathy's parents, Lizzie (who used to work for Neil's mom, who never got over the fact that her darling son married the help's daughter) and Muttie, who is always hopeful that the next horse he bets on will be the big winner.When their business, the Scarlet Feather, is broken into and items are stolen and the rest destroyed...real trouble ensues.  Can they pull themselves together again or will they have to close the business with their dreams shattered and disappoint their friends-investors?  Who is behind this awful event?  What happens when the children's parents return and are still hopeless to take care of them?If this book had just focused on Cathy and Tom and their significant others, plus Lizzie and Muttie and the children...the main part of the family, who had issues enough between them, this would have been a book worth 4 or 5 stars.  But all the side characters just distracted and, honestly, weren't really important or needed.  Skip those bits and not only won't you miss anything, but its a far better story.

Overall, I enjoyed this book and polished it off in just a few sittings.  What fascinating me the most were the glimpses into the main character's lifestyle as a big country music star and how that clashed with her small town upbringing and the life that her mother lives.  Tess (known as "Mac" to her fans) returns back to Wintergreen as she is guilted into going home to take care of her mother as she undergoes hip surgery.  One of her sisters is very nice and friendly, but the other is clearly jealous of her and causes trouble.  This could have been explained more and I would have preferred SOME resolution of this, but it didn't come as the focus of the story became the romance between Tess and Kenny, a former school-mate and former-nerd back in high school who had always had a thing for her.The interaction between Tess and her stubborn, practical mother was great...as Tess tries to persuade her that she can wear the nice clothing she has bought for her and that, yes indeed, she is rich enough to give her mother expensive things.  But her mother would, obviously and understandably, prefer to see Tess rather than get gifts.  The growing romance between Tess and Kenny was nice enough, though very predictable.  I also felt very bad for Faith, Kenny's girlfriend of nearly 10 years, and honestly what happened there made me not like Kenny very much.  Tess was also annoying at times as she made such a big deal out of not wanting to eat the food she grew  up with as she needed to remain skinny skinny for her business.  Yes, that makes sense, but she should have understood better that her mother showed her love with cooking and the book could have made one point about that and then let it go, but it kept showing up.The relationship between Tess and Kenny's talented daughter also was pretty predictable.  Of course, Tess needs a new back-up singer right at the same time she wants to bring Casey to Nashville.  It seemed just a bit too pat.Still and all, I did enjoy the book and the glimpse into the life of a country star and the interaction with where she grew up.  I just think the romance could have sparked more and been a little less contrived.  Not this author's best work, but I do enjoy all of her books and I did enjoy this one, but probably won't read it a second time.

Fabulous flavoring for your grilled chicken.  Spicy, but not over the top.  My friends put this on some grilled chicken for me and I went out and bought a bottle the next day.  It has joined my Grill Mates Montreal Steak seasoning as a "go to" seasoning blend.  So far, I've tried several of these Grill Mates and enjoyed them all.  I suspect that putting a batch of them together would make for a great gift for someone who loves grilling.

Overall, I enjoyed the book and polished it off in two days in my spare time.  I enjoyed the description of the high-paced and crazy world of fashion and of the super-thin girls who think they are fat (shades of "Top Model") and how everyone in the world seems to think the editor of some fashion magazine is so important despite her horrible attitude, simply because she has an eye for fashion.That being said, I liked the movie way better than the book.  Andrea, the assistant to Miranda, is much more likeable in the movie and even Miranda is more likeable (slightly).  The movie also gives us more of an idea why Miranda acts the way she does.  As for the plot, Andrea becomes Miranda's assistant at "Runway" and Miranda treats her dreadfully, but Andrea is only in it for the ability to get promoted at the end of one year and wants to be a REAL writer and thinks fashion is essentially stupid.  The rest revolves around this and the trials it causes Andrea and how her relationships fall apart as Miranda becomes the center of her world.By the end of the book, no matter how entertaining it was at times, I felt let down--I didn't like Andrea, I didn't like Miranda, I didn't like Andrea's boyfriend (and can't even recall his name, if that gives any clue as to his non-entityhood) and I really really disliked Lily, Andrea's friend.  I also had lost interest in them by the end, because if you dislike a character but find them interesting that's still a good character in my book.Good for one read and funny enough and entertaining enough for 4 stars and I can definitely recommend it for anyone into fashion and drama and drama about fashion.  But don't expect to like anyone by the end and don't expect there to be any kind of resolution.  Watch the movie for that.

We had these on grilled burgers and it was wonderful!  Spicy, but not too spicy, though it did add some zip to the burger.  There is definitely a good garlic and onion flavor and I could see using this on grilled chicken or as a spice when you make potatoes in those sealed  bags over the grill.  A definite MUST for camping and grilling events and weekends.

For some reason, I love this movie.  I have seen it multiple times now and it just captures me every time.  Perhaps, its the backdrop of the spectacular Niagara Falls.  Perhaps, its Marilyn.  Whatever it is, this thriller of jealousy and betrayal and murder is fascinating.Marilyn plays Rose, a beautiful woman married to George, who suffers from the after-effects of his time in WW2.  They are vacationing in Niagara Falls and end up bumping into another vacationing couple, Polly and Ray.  Turns out Rose is scheming to hook up with her secret lover and to have him murder her husband so they can run off together.  Polly gets wrapped up in their story as she helps George after a melt-down, and then becomes far more deeply involved as the plot unfolds.  You end up feeling bad for both George and Rose as they clash and, clearly, their marriage was doomed almost from the beginning.  One wonders why the seductive and clearly fun-loving Rose ever got hooked up with George in the first place.The vintage (now) clothing and vacation setting of Niagara Falls are fascinating.  Simpler times were never simply times.  The backdrop of the Falls is incredible and you almost feel like it reflects the inevitable destruction of both Rose and George Loomis.I bought a copy of this on Blue Ray and it was well worth it.  When you take an old movie and put it on Blue Ray, it can only get so much better, but it did make the colors pop more (can you say Marilyn's fabulous ever-red and always perfect lipstick) and sharpened up the picture a little, as well.

Rough, lonesome at times landscapes and windswept shorelines and crags are some of the backdrop for this murder mystery series.  Equally rough around the edges, clearly lonely in her life, but dedicated to the core is the police detective that the show is named after, Vera.  She is certainly no Hollywood star as she slouches around in haphazard clothing with her hair needing a comb at times and a hat often pulled down low.  She also is very plain-spoken, even harsh at times, yet you can still see it is all a shell to hide how much she cares within.Vera is a fascinating character as she unravels various murder mysteries.  Unlike many other tv shows, you never know whodunit until near the end and, often, the ending has its own bittersweet flavor to it.  Yes, they find the killer(s), but it won't bring back the dead or stop the pain of those who lost their loved one.  There are really no "happy" endings in this show, but should there be when murder is involved?  This show tells it like it is more than most.  Vera is definitely, despite her bulldoggedness (or maybe because of it) just the kind of cop you'd want on the case.LOVE this British series.  Am haunted by the landscapes and the people who are a match for it, including Vera herself.  These stories really stick with you...

I freely admit I read this book because I adored the movie.  It is one of my go-to movies to make me feel good, though I love the scenes with Julia better than the ones with Julie.  This should have been my first clue that I might not like the book "Julie and Julia" as much because the scenes in the movie re Julia and her husband in France where she learned to cook and the travails of getting the cookbook published as they moved from country to country and home to home didn't actually come out of this book, but was based on another book about Julia.I went back and forth between liking Julie in the movie and, as it turned out, I disliked her more in this book as we were exposed to more of her temper tantrums and hatred of where she worked (and Republicans) and issues with herself and her husband.  She came across as very immature at times, even insensitive in some ways...even as she was too sensitive in other ways.  Honestly, I didn't find the book funny and it was gross at times.  Did we really need that much detail about how nasty their plumbing was and how their lack of cleaning during her cooking project resulted in flies and worse?I think I like Julie better in the movie due to the sweet urchin appeal of the actress, not due to the character she is portraying.  I have no desire to read this author's second book or any blog by her.  Sorry to say, I love the idea of this book (loving cooking), but it pales in comparison to the movie that resulted.  Read "My Life In France" about Julia instead.  Maybe, if they hadn't made such a good movie I would have liked the book better.  I admire the author's willingness to put her life out for all to see, but I think a few more writing classes might have improved matters.  She has talent and a cook angle on incorporating cooking and life's lessons, but maybe needs to learn about what to leave out of a book as much as what to put in.

This is, hands down, my absolute favorite CD by Enigma.  I have all of their CD's and they all have a shared sense to them, a common rhythm even as times, so that they feel tied together...yet, each CD also has its own flavor if you will.  This CD draws from tribal music and the songs address native issues when another religion comes to destroy their own faith and take over (even destroy) their land "in the name of God."Favorite songs include "Out From the Deep," "Eyes of Truth" and the title song "Cross of Changes."  This song hits you hard and lingers on long after the CD ends.  It seems to refer not just to the Christian Cross, but to bearing a cross (bearing hardships), and being on a crossroads between one world, one time, and another.  The drumming and the native singing are wonderful and fit in really well with the work Enigma does on this song, and the whole CD.If you want to own just ONE Enigma CD, this is the one I would suggest.  Though, their earlier CD with Gregorian chants interwoven is also great if you enjoy Gregorian chant.  Enigma is definitely not just some New Age group with sweet happy sounds mixed in with whale song and cricket noises.  Enigma is a delight.

I still like more of the individual songs on "El Camino" better and that CD seemed to rock a bit more, but this CD has definitely gotten under my skin.  I now listen to it almost as often as "El Camino."  This CD definitely puts you into a certain headspace, something a bit dark and strange and wonderful and somewhat psychedelic.Favorite songs include Weight of Love and Fever, but really I listen to the whole CD as a single mood piece more than anything.  Great to play in the car on a long trip!

This book kept me reading, but mostly to find out what happened to the two girls and who was behind it.  The story is told from alternating points of view and jumps around in time, but I found that distracting at times and began skimming some of the sections because it just wasn't as interesting as the plot re the two missing girls.  Calli and Petra are friends and Petra tries to speak for Calli as Calli has remained mute for many years.  No one knows why.  Calli's mother, Antonia, used to go with Louis, the local sheriff, but then (and this point was a bit silly, I though) they fell apart and she married the local bad boy, Griff.  Of course, Griff is an alcoholic and is abusive.The story revolves around Griff taking Calli off to the woods one morning when he was supposed to have gone fishing with his buddy.  The why of this was confusing and never really cleared up.  It didn't make much sense.  That same night, Petra goes missing from her bed.  The rest involves the search for the two girls and all sorts of accusations, some of which go back to the relationship between Antonia and Louis.  Some of the scenes felt muddled so you weren't quite sure what had happened or was happening, but it finally resolves itself and, yes, there is a mystery as to Petra's disappearance.Overall, a good effort.  I think less changes of view would have been better and, maybe, fewer flashbacks.  Some of the characters felt a bit flat at times.  I preferred her book "Little Mercies" much better.  Be warned, this is a dark story around child abuse and not an easy read at times.

This is a series where normally the episodes are about a half hour long.  This DVD includes 2 episodes that are more like an hour long and includes the usual mix-ups, interweaving of odd plots and circumstances, and the familiar grouch who looks at the world with anything but rose-colored glasses, Victor.  He and his wife and their (poor) neighbors endure mishap after mishap, all of which leaves you laughing out loud.  Victor putters around and gets into trouble and you think you should dislike him--and probably would if he was actually your neighbor--but you really feel how much he loves his long-suffering wife.  These two episodes include such things as a supposedly haunted caravan, their neighbor's mother apparently being taken on trips by aliens, a mistake of identity that results in a supposed kidnapping, a man who takes up residence in their shed while they are gone who turns out to be something more than what they imagined...and Victor being cheerful, scary as that is!  And that's just for starters...  This is not a show for children, but for those who love British humor, "One Foot in the Grave" is well worth watching.

Overall, I enjoyed this book.  It was well written, easy to read, and contained a wealth of information surrounding the general theme of Walpurgisnacht...May Eve for most of us.  Clearly, the author had done her research and the book talks about the origins of Walpurgisnacht, including info about St Walpurga (including the false story that she is the daughter of a king who lived hundreds of years after her, which the author thankfully points out, so kudos for that!), woodwives and wild women, the Valkyries, all sorts of kinds of old German Witches.  One of my favorites was the Mist Witch.  Another bit I enjoyed was the material surrounding the Brocken, the traditional Witches' Mountain of Germany.The history and folklore I loved, but I wasn't so much into the craft projects she included which seemed pretty simplistic.  As for the recipes...eh.  I could see the old German pancake one as pancakes have folkloric associations with Paganism and Fae, but a salad recipe that she called a Witchy Salad?  But the one that lost a star for this review was the section regarding old flying ointments with all of their dangerous psychoactive substances…and then the author included 2 recipes for what she called Flying Ointments that were essentially party dips.  Why?  Why not just talk seriously about flying ointments and leave it at that, rather than calling party dips flying ointments?  A lot of the other recipes didn’t seem to have much association with the topic either, such as linking a French toast recipe to the topic about hags and hedges.  I would have rather she stuck to the topic, have a few crafty items that could be tied to the season, maybe even a recipe or two that clearly can be linked to the topic—such as the traditional German May Wine—than add in all these things that have little to no association with the theme of the book.  It began to seem like filler after a while.  Still…a good book that I can recommend as being on a topic that needed more focus.

The shirt was delivered quickly and came wrapped in an inner plastic bag with a cushioned outer bag.  The fabric is medium weight and hangs well and the hint of glitter on the bottom is very nice.  Love the soft green color and it fits perfectly, even the length of the sleeves.  This is dressy enough for work with a nice pair of pants or skirt and casual enough to wear out with jeans or leggings.  I've worn this to work and the long sleeves are a little short, but then I like sleeves that come down past my wrists so I imagine most will be okay with this.  The bottom is a bit flared, but not enough to look hippy, and the cloth was very comfortable.Now, I wish I had bought another one in a different color.

Absolutely fascinating and fabulous!  This show just keeps on getting better and better.  I find myself sitting down to watch one episode and then just keep going as I can't wait to see what happens next.  Action, betrayal, love, death, pain, plotting...this show is never ever boring and keeps you guessing.  No character is safe from death, as they keep proving.  The characters also are complex enough that I hated Jamie Lannister in the first season and now have grown to like him.  This season proves there are way worst families out there than the Lannisters (scary as that is).  My favorite story arcs from this season include Daenerys (as ever) with her growing ability to be a Queen and her focus on freeing all slaves.  Also, shockingly, the relationship between Arya and The Hound.  The introduction of Oberyn...I found him fascinating right off.  But the star of the show continues to be Tyrion and his trials (in this season, quite literally).  Beautiful scenery and clothing, great acting, terrific plot...can't wait for the next season!

I've never been disappointed by a Taste of Home cookbook yet...and this one is no exception.  I've been on the hunt for a decent slow cooker cookbook and this one is terrific!  It's broken into the four seasons, with appetizers, side dishes, main courses, soups/sandwich fixings, and desserts for each season.  There are recipes for all sizes of slow cookers, from 3 quart up to 6 quart, while some of the recipes are pretty simple (with only a few ingredients), while others require a bit more time and work.  There are also a lot of full color, wonderful pictures.If I was going to give someone a slow cooker as a gift, this is the cookbook I'd include with it, hand's down!

I was hoping to fall in love with this show, but I didn't even finish off watching the season.  I just didn't care enough to see if any big reveal re Bo's parents was coming.  This show had some great potential, but the scripts...eh.  I liked Kenzi, the human sidekick of Bo, a Fae who didn't know she was Fae but know something was up as she kept sucking the life out of her sexual partners.  Kenzi was more interesting to me with her ability to speak Russian and her background in theft and strange cybergeek friends.  Bo, on the other hand, never seemed to change and everyone acted like she was a Big Deal, but I just never saw it.  The Light Fae and the Dark Fae didn't seem to have much difference between them and the plots ended up devolving into more of a monster-of-the-week format after a while.  I also never saw any real spark between Bo and Dyson, her wolf-shifting on and off boyfriend.  Maybe, this picked up in Season 2, but I'll never know because I didn't make it to the end of Season 1.  This could have been hot and full of strange fantastical plots, but it just fell a bit too flat for my tastes.  Ramp up the oddity and get a main character who really can pull off Bo and I might have liked it better.

I haven't read the book or books, didn't even know they existed.  I just picked this up because of the idea of a vampire school.  That being said, this obviously is an attempt to latch onto the vampire craze brought on by Twilight.  Rose is a half-human, half-vampire who is being trained to protect the "good" vampires, the Moroi.  In particular, she is attached to Lissa, a princess in the vampire world who has yet to declare her magical power (earth, air, fire or water) and who is clearly in danger, both without and within the school, the Vampire Academy.Everyone, generally, is young and pretty in this movie and its a combo of high school issues (like who likes who and who hates who) mixed up with a hint of more adult politics, but barely.  I liked the relationship between Rose and Lissa, but everything really was pretty predictible.  I probably wouldn't watch this one a second time, but it was fun enough and, at least, no one sparkled in the sunlight.

This is a good adaptation, but I have to admit I still prefer the one for the stage.  Into the Woods is basically broken into two parts.  Part One is based on the standard fairytales of Cinderella, Rapunzel, Jack and the Beanstalk, and Little Red Riding Hood.  Only, in this case, they are all intertwined as they take place in the same area and the characters run into each other and interact as they go "into the woods" to seek what they need.  The main driver is the story of the baker and his wife who have been cursed by their neighbor, the Witch, and have to seek out a series of items in order for the Witch to relent and uncurse them, allowing them to have a child.Part Two of the story involves what happens after Happily Ever After, when the consequences of all their actions in Part One come home to roost.  The songs are terrific (though, difficult to sing I've heard) and, in this case, we actually get special effects instead of stage effects (which can be funnier).  All in all, this isn’t quite as good as the stage version, so if you get a chance to see it…see it on stage.  This is NOT a children’s movie, as the stories are closer to the originals.  Streep does a great job as the Witch.  Johnny Depp is marvelous as the Wolf (definitely NOT for children).

I had never heard of this movie when it was in the theatre, but found it a good watch on DVD.  Dench is my favorite and she does a great job as Mrs Henderson, a rich widow who decides to splurge after her husband dies and buy a rundown old theatre, the Windmill.  She hires Van Damm (played by Hoskins) to manage the theatre and they have a sparring love-hate relationship that amuses them as much as those watching it.  At first, they decide to stand out by running their shows all the time, but when other theatres follow suit, Mrs Henderson has the idea to have nudes in their show.  This is a huge deal in the late 1930's and, fortunately, she knows the powers in govt and sweet talks them into seeing the nudes as art, so long as no one moves and the lighting shadows them tastefully.The move is based off the real story of the Windmill Theatre and the crew of regular English girls who agreed to pose nude--called the Millerettes--and the additions to the DVD include interviews with the remaining real Millerettes.  Set against pre-war England and WW2, this illuminates a story that few of us knew anything about.  Dench gives a wonderful performance and her speech about why the Windmill should remain open is very well done and quite touching.

I liked this movie way more than I expected to.  I got it  because I love Judy Dench and Maggie Smith, but the movie turned out to be chockful of familiar British actors...and Cher, of course.  Its set just before WW2 and through WW2, where some English ladies in Florence have formed a group around loving the arts, while Cher plays a wealthy American woman who comes to Europe to buy art, with Lily Tomlin as her pants-wearing would-be archeologist sidekick.  The group ends up taking in a young boy named Luca whose father can't acknowledge him and whose mother has died.  The war comes along, but the ladies refuse to leave their beloved Florence, as the Maggie Smith's character thinks highly of Mussolini and even once had tea with him (hence the title) and they think it will all just blow over.  The ladies end up pulling together to help each other during the hard times of the war and being imprisoned as enemy-aliens and, also, to help save the fabulous art of Florence.The oddball crew of English and American ladies in the movie really are the heart of the movie, with their story set against the greater backdrop of the day.  Recommended.

This is a book that is sorely needed and one that I wish had been published like decades ago, for the same reasons.  The book is a series of articles (or blog postings) that have been put together in order to address the issues faced by pagan leaders, groups, and communities.  How to lead?  How not to lead?  What to do when there is a bad or abusive pagan leader in your community, including coming to understand that some things you just can’t do anything about.  This is the strongest message in the book—that there are just some people you can’t help and that you can’t fix, whether they are in your group or are leading a group.  As the author put it several times, some people are just above your “pay grade” and need professional help.The author talks about dealing with your own issues (your “shadow”) in order to be the best leader or the best member of a group you can be.  She recommends other books and courses in order to learn needed techniques of communication and handling group dynamics.  Much of what she says in this book can also be applied to non-pagan situations, such as jobs or families where there is a leader who is just not good in that role for whatever reason, from lack of training to the wrong sort of temperament to unaddressed personal issues to actual mental illness.She talks about learning how to say “no” when you are the kind of person who is driven to put on events or run a group, yet find yourself saying “yes” all the time to things that you really don’t have the time for.  She addresses the issues of “pagan standard time,” why it seems so hard to find pagans to step up to the plate and take charge and volunteer, and why most pagans find it hard to confront people in their group or running their group who are causing trouble.This book really covers a lot of territory and is very readable.  It gives some excellent advice and supplies additional resources to explore.  The biggest issue with the book is that it really could have done with a spot of editing, as the author repeats things several times in different chapters (occasionally word for word, so that it looked like the blogs/articles had been written at different times on a related topic and so overlapped here and there) and, sometimes, the structure of the writing got in the way of the message.  There were some sentences that were not well structured and there were some paragraphs that lacked spacing between them.  She throws out the names of other pagans, such as Selena Fox, with the assumption that her readers will just know who that is.  This is nothing that a bit more practice and a good editor/proofreader couldn’t fix.The only other issue I had with the book was the last part came across as a bit of a personal tirade, where she talked about how pagans say they are ecologically-minded, but consume much like everyone else.  Several times, she stated if someone handed her a paper or plastic cup during a ritual that she would refuse it and indicated that leaders who plan big rituals where liquids are handed out to everyone should be given glass cups or be asked to bring their own so they can be washed instead of being thrown out.  She also said we shouldn’t use wine or even fruit juice because not everyone can drink that kind of stuff and we shouldn’t use cookies or bread in ritual because of those who are vegan or gluten-free…instead, she says why can’t we just pour water over people’s hands and given them apples and celery sticks?  Of course, pouring water over people’s hands is NOT the same thing as offering them someone to drink and apples and celery are not the same as bread.  She didn’t seem to consider that is a change in symbology and meaning.  (Of course, you can make vegan and gluten-free cookies or bread for ritual.)  She also didn’t seem to consider—in her response to someone who said she can’t speak about the topic of being ecological if she uses toilet paper—that by using washable cloth for toilet paper instead of actual toilet paper that the carbon footprint from washing such cloth is greater than that of using toilet paper.  I agree that pagans (like everyone) should be mindful, but the last part of the book seemed to belong to another book or article than the first half of the book.Still, very much recommended.

The landscape in this movie was lovely and the plot was intriguing.  It revolves around two Navaho tribal police officers named Leaphorn and Chee.  Leaphorn is the veteran who is on leave due to his wife’s health issues and, obviously, has a lot on his mind even as he is called back to investigate claims that an archeologist is illegally selling pots.  Chee, on the other hand, seems a rookie as he lets a backhoe get stolen and keeps driving vehicles into the ground as he chases his tail looking the for thieves.  He’s also very traditionalist and so very worried about this investigation as it brings him into burial grounds.  The two stories converge, of course, as the suspected archeologist goes missing, we find a local Christian Navaho preacher might be behind some of the pot selling (great job by a favorite of mine, Graham Greene), and what does this have to do with the ghosts of the dead and the mystery of the disappearance of the Anasazi anyway?I enjoyed the feel of the movie, especially the hint of supernatural, but when it eventually became pretty much a straightforward murder mystery story, I found it not quite as engaging as in the beginning.  I also thought the subplot of one of the suspect archeologists hitting on Leaphorn didn’t seem to add much to the overall story and was kind of annoying.  There also seemed to be a missing plot point as two murdered men were found, but (unless I missed it) they never told us the results of the autopsies and so what killed them, leaving their eyes dead-white.But, overall, this was a very engaging movie and I didn’t figure out who was behind it until the end, which is a plus.

Admittedly, I only made it through half the shows before I shut it off.  I was expecting dark comedy and I normally enjoy dark comedy, but I was still waiting for the comedy when I gave it up.  Certainly, it was dark and gruesome at times, with odd turns such as the doctor running around with half his face shaved, and I could see an attempt to be funny, but I just never found it amusing.The premise is that a young doctor fresh from medical school goes off to some hospital in the middle of the frozen, ever-snowing Russian countryside back in the early 1900’s where he meets nurses who look down at him (favoring his dead predecessor at every chance), and other medical professionals (if you pardon the term) who don’t seem to have a clue half the time.  Supposedly, this young doctor got top marks in school, but he runs back to check his books every time a patient presents just about and is haunted by his older self, which is not explained and didn’t seem to add much to the story.The acting was great and the idea seemed good, so I’m not sure who to blame for the lack of humor.  Too bad.

As I'm always on the look-out for a good gluten-free cracker, I was really delighted with these.  So far, I've tried this Olive Tapendade and the Garlic and love both of them.  I really didn't get a bean taste out of them, which is good because I really am not much for gluten free products made with bean flour as, normally, you end up with that taste.The crackers are light, crunchy, not too salty, and have a great flavor.  They are good with cheese or with sausage slices or both, but I've even just eaten them without anything on them as they, honestly, don't need anything else.  You can even see the little bits of olives in them.  So far, the best pairing I've found with this flavor is a nice Brie.

There weren’t really any surprises in this movie, but it was fun all the same.  It had quite a few good laughs, mostly revolving around Oren, the grouchy old man who offends all around him and doesn’t seem to care, and his co-worker in the real estate office who tells it like it is.  Basically, Oren had lost his beloved wife and now is in the process of selling their home, but doesn’t want to reduce the price by even one penny from the 8 plus million dollar price tag.  It’s clear that it means more to him than just a home as it represents his once dream life with his wife.  In the meantime, he is hanging out in a small complex by the lake, offending everyone there as well, where he bumps into Leah, a woman who also has lost her husband.  You can see where this about to go…but it ends up a funny and touching romp all the same.What sparks the movie is Oren’s son having to go to jail and dropping Oren’s granddaughter into his lap to take care of in the meantime.  Leah ends up in the role of “grandma” to Sarah, even as Oren reluctantly (grouching the whole way) is drawn into caring both about Sarah and Leah.  He even ends up with a pet dog in the process, go figure!A movie about how redemption and romance can happen at any time and at any age.

Absolutely brilliant performance by Julianne Moore as Alice, a highly intelligent linguistics teacher who finds herself diagnosed with familial early-onset Alzheimers.  This is an incredible movie, but definitely not one that is easy to watch.  We go with Alice as she finds her greatest asset, her mind and memory, being stripped away from her.  We see the difficulties her husband and children face as the woman they knew and loved becomes more and more confused and lost.  I’m glad I saw this movie, but I doubt I could see it a second time—it’s just too real and too hard to watch—but it definitely made me much more aware of the pain and suffering of people who are going through what Alice in the movie was going through, and what their friends, family, and caregivers have to deal with.

This wasn't my absolute favorite of the seasons of Downton Abbey, but I'm still enjoying the ride.  A wonderful cast, great writing, interesting plots...it still has it all, even though this season didn't have as many of the highs and lows and great drama of some of the past seasons.  But I still love the characters, both upstairs and down, and will definitely be waiting now for the next season.Some Spoilers:  This season finds Mary still playing the field (and looking incredible in her new hair cut), Edith still dealing with the issues of her "secret" and her choices, Robert finding out that not only has he been taking Cora for granted, but that others definitely might not, and even the Dowager has some interesting details of her past come up, specifically a Russian Prince.  The Branson plot line seemed to be kind of blah, as its clear they are wrapping up his involvement in the show, Rose has met the young man of her life (and, again, shows that she doesn't give a fig about picking someone that society might frown upon), and the show ends with bang with a hunting party on the moor and, of course, our dear Christmas.I so love seeing the episodes with Christmas at Downton.Of course, the poor Bates family is still embroiled in issues from the last season and there are some twists there, most of which are not surprising, but I guess we'll have to wait until the next season to see them resolved.Cool note--having Mary use Thomas' nature to get back at someone who clearly needed it, hurrah!  Also, the developing relationships between our brusque butler and the head housekeeper and the caring between the head cook and sweet little Daisy.  Honestly, though, I was glad to see the back of Tom's sort of love interest, the local schoolteacher.Lovely scenery and clothes to die for!  Plus characters to fall in love with (or despise) and I honestly can say I laughed and cried, especially at the touching scene with Robert and Cora and Isis.  Hurray for Downton!

I had trouble reading this book and finally ended up just skimming the last quarter of it.  Partially, it was because it simply didn't hold my interest and, partially, because the author ended up getting on my nerves with how he was telling his story.  This needed editing badly to make the timeline cohesive as the author kept skipping around.  In one chapter, he talks about breaking up with his girlfriend and in the next chapter, they are still together, so his timeline kept jumping around and it felt very jumbled.  Also, there wasn't much description of place in the story so you had a hard time picturing where they were, which I assume is because the author needs more practice or could have benefited from some writing classes before finishing this book.  One of the basics of good writing is "show, don't tell," and this book was pretty much just telling.Whether you believe in evil or nasty spirits or not, this book left something to be desired, as the author's actions made little sense.  He relates how he as a child and his grandmother were accosted by some kind of evil spirit (they called it the Devil, but that's doubtful) in their home...but then he goes on to join up with some paranormal investigation group and go around poking at spirits in haunted inns and homes and graveyards.  Does this seem reasonable?  Not really...  The author is only in his early 20's during all of this, but suddenly decides he is being given signs from God that he is called to be some kind of "demon-fighter" and begins going around to people's  homes to bless them and drive out bad spirits.  Definitely, hints of an ego trip, especially since he had absolutely no training or mentoring in any of this.  Honstly, this is NOT the work for someone with no training or experience to undertake and this book makes it seem like you can have a feeling this is for you to do and you can just go and do it.  Of course, there are nasty consequences at times, but that's hardly surprising.The author is honest about his and his mother's drinking issues and his suicide attempts, but he attaches this to demonic activity...such as it was demons making him take sleeping pills and drink booze in order to die when he and his girlfriend break up.  He sends her a picture of the pills and the booze in order to get a reaction, but when there is no response, he tries to kill himself.  Please, this is a sign he needed counseling, not an exorcism.  Then, when he wakes  up in the hospital, and they want to send him to get professional mental help, one of his relatives says he didn't really mean it, so they just drop it.  This is highly unprofessional and also made no sense.The other strange story was when he and his paranormal crew went to this supposedly highly haunted cemetery and a car follows them in and they immediately think they are about to be murdered by Satanists and the author gets ready to rumble with them.  Only, it turns out the car is actually full of girls who also want to check out haunted stuff...this is just so paranoid and seems more like a bunch of teens and early twenty-something messing around with things and scaring themselves in the process.  It shows the mindset of the author and his friends that the first thing they think of when seeing a car near a haunted cemetary is that it must be full of Satanists out to kill people.  Really?  It couldn't just be the local cops out to keep teens and twenty-somethings from messing around in the cemetary and knocking over tombstones?  Or a bereaved relative?Of course, there is the proverbial we got a Ouija Board and something got into our house because of it...this urban legend has been around for years now, as much as the author insisting that even reading a book about demons and evil spirits will end up with one attaching itself to you.  (I guess no one should read this book then, either, or have the same happen to you...if you believe that sort of thing.)I can't recommend this book.  It really has no historical or folkloric value regarding the belief in demons or spirits, it misleads people into thinking they can mess around with bad spirits and ghosts with no experience or training in the matter, and it just wasn't even that interesting.  It read more like the kind of disjointed far-out stories that get told around the campfire to spook people.  The author implied this would be the first book in a series--I hope he gets in some writing classes before undertaking another book.  I would have enjoyed a good book about paranormal investigators, but this just wasn't it.

I loved Cherryholmes CD "Black and White" to pieces, so I thought I would order this one, as well.  Sadly, I ended up disappointed overall with the CD as it contains so many more quiet reflective ballad style pieces, some of them along a rather religious note.  The playing is still good and the voices and the lyrics have the general quality of the group, but it just seemed...well, more blah.  Pretty, but blah.I much more preferred the rousing harder-hitting tunes in the other CD.  I guess to each their own, but I can't recommend listening to this CD as a starting point to getting into this band.  I hope they go back to their older style in the next CD.  I'm not so turned off by this one not to buy another of their CD's, but when reaching for one of their CD's to listen to while on the road..."Black and White" just jumps into my hand, but "Don't Believe" remains behind.

I've really tried to appreciate the new chief detective Barnaby, but as the episodes go on the new guy just doesn't have the same interest as the old Tom Barnaby.  This set of stories were hit and miss, as the chess episode left me feeling flat, but the one centered around Midsomer's wonderful stinky cheese hit some of the old off the wall stride as the series is known for.  I expect Midsomer to have that hint of madness, of spookiness, and of not being able to figure out who the bad guy (or girl) is until near the very end.  I still love Ben Jones, but he can't hold this show all by his lonesome and the family of Tom and Joyce and Cully...well, I miss them more and more.  I think I'll go back and watch some of the older shows now.

I have recently learned to love headlamps. They are so useful in so many situations. My husband and son both have one and we use them all the time. It's an amazing way to have a lot of light but still keep my hands free. The Wolverine Headlamp is very comfortable to wear and easily adjustable. I can quickly go from my head to my son's with a slight adjustment. The straps are soft and don't dig into my head even after a long time of use. It's extremely lightweight so It can be worn for long periods of time without getting heavy or giving me a headache.The light is very bright and projects pretty far in the direction I'm looking. With three modes I can always find a light that  is appropriate for any situation. The flashing light is great for distress calls so this would be great for hunters to have. This one takes batteries where most I've seen are rechargeable. That could be useful when no electricity is available. But that also means you need to carry batteries around.The price is GREAT this would make a great gift for young boys just starting to explore.i received this product complimentary in exchange for my honest opinion but the opinion expressed is all my own.

I always have tension in my neck and shoulders so when I saw these I was very excited to try them.  When I pulled them out my husband tried to squeeze them because he thought they were stress balls. So that is the best way to describe them only much harder so you can't squeeze them.The Therapy Balls are a nice size and I can comfortably hold only one in my hand.I used them on my husbands back and he immediately started to relax. He then took off his shirt and bent down so I could get the lower back as well. They really do feel amazing and are super easy to use. Just roll across the knotty part of the body and the motion starts to work out the knots.I toss them on the floor and rub your feet on them to give myself a foot massage.  That works great as well they are smooth and roll easily under my arch, heel, and ball so all I do is move. The ball does the rest.I received this product complimentary in exchange for my honest opinion but the opinion expressed is all my own.

This pan was larger than I thought it would be which is always a nice surprise. The sides are very short to make it easier to flip the food. I know it says Crepe pan but it's good for all sorts of other foods. Like pancakes and eggs. The sides are high enough to keep the food from leaking everywhere so there is no need to worry.The pan is really lightweight which is AWESOME. I hate when my pans are heavy and clunky unless they are cast iron, then I get it. The heat does not transfer to the handle so it's not hot when I grab it. Nonstick coating works great, even the eggs didn't' stick.Be really careful because the pan is semi-fragile mine was delivered dented. My son was fascinated by the bottom of the pan and I agree it's pretty. I received this product complimentary in exchange for my honest opinion but the opinion expressed is all my own.

I have the most beautiful Aromatherapy necklace from ECOTT and I was very happy to see that refill pads were available. First of all that means I am no limited to the amount of fragrance I can use. Especially with 40 extra! But each color changes the look of the necklace slightly so now I have different colors to go with different outfits.These pads are small but thick enough to be a perfect fit for my necklace. They hold the scent for a long time and can be reused with the same fragrance. Or washed up to 6 times and used with different fragrances. So that's a LOT of use.I would highly recommend giving this/buying this set with the aromatherapy necklace. I knew immediately I would want more options for fragrances than the four pads that came with the necklace.I received this product complimentary in exchange for my honest opinion but the opinion expressed is all my own.

This blue is my new favorite color stone. I love the ocean every time I am reminded of looking deep into an ocean. The blue is stunning  and the shine is spectacular. This piece could easily worn by a bridesmaid or even a bride, since every bride needs something blue. But it's still good for everyday wear as well. The hearts are each a perfect shape they appear to vary in size from biggest int the middle to smallest at the end. I love that it's a bangle but it's ruined with a chain that needs to be fastened. The good part about the chain is the clasp is a lobster claw so it's not quiet as difficult to fasten by myself. I also feel more secure with a lobster claw because are not as easily opened as other type clasps. Keep in mind the bracelet does not give a lot so bigger wrist may have a hard time wear it.It seems well made and like it will last for a very long time. The stones are nicely set and won't get caught on my clothing or in my hair. This is an amazing bracelet and I will wear it at lot.I received this product complimentary in exchange for my honest opinion but the opinion expressed is all my own.

If you think this is pretty in pictures wait until you see it in person. It's an absolutely breath taking piece of jewelry. The stone is a great size to be an eye catcher and the silver snake/swirl like design really brings it out and makes it prettier. The chain is not a link design but more like a filigree instead. The pendant hangs from a beautiful silver clasps with the look of rhinestones on it.It's very lightweight and comfortable to wear.  The pendant is quite large but not gaudy or tacky looking. The color is stunning and an amazing shade of blue. The sparkle is quite stunning on both the pendant and the chain. The one complaint I have is the chain is not adjustable. The clasp only latches in one link but that won't be too much of a problem. The lobster claw clasps ensures the necklace will stay on.I received this product complimentary in exchange for my honest opinion but the opinion expressed is all my own.

These earring are super cute and they are a perfect gift for any little ballerina in your life. They are small so it's perfect for little ears but not so small that they would not be noticed.They are well made and since they won't tarnish like silver I won't have to worry about my girls wearing tarnished earrings. I hope they are just as hypoallergenic as sterling silver so they don't irritate my children's ears. The studs are not really raised so they won't get caught in hair. The pink bow is adorable and really makes them stand out. When I opened the Kiss lashes I saw a difference immediately, they were not super thick and coarse nor did they have that super noticeable band at the top like some lashes I have tried in the past.
