I truly enjoyed the brief glimpse we had of Wellie and Jo!It took me a few chapters to come to like Vera. She was too timid. She was too cranky. She was too...a lot of things that just didn't appeal to me. Then, on the slow ride to the end, she made sense. Her attitude at the beginning made sense, too. Her issues were hard ones. Real life ones. And then I liked her very much.Ms. Burrowes writes intimate scenes with a sweet, yet steamy, eloquence. It reads hot, but not ***porny***, if that makes sense! It also doesn't take over the entire book. It just fits the story and doesn't overpower it.This is another Five Bookmark review from me. I find I'm not even missing the Regency Era...although I am looking forward to more of those, too! The next book in this series, Kiss Me Hello, is calling to me. Mac is a farrier and visits a therapeutic riding stable at the beginning of the book. Our family volunteers at one, and this book is going to be fun! Mac needs to laugh a bit more and I hope he finds some joy in this one (of course he will!).Thank you, NetGalley and Sourecebooks ~ Casablanca, for the opportunity to read this book!

FOUR and a HALF STARS for this charming story!This was my second book by this author. It won't be my last. I read Wrong Place, Right Time recently. Her characters are charming and the situations sweet.Renee is pretty much forced to try out for the local Bachelor Reality Show. She figures she might as well try it, since she needs to raise her public profile if she's going to get a prime promotion at the radio station where she works. When she hears who the Bachelor is, she thinks about running. He's the local playboy. But doesn't he have pretty eyes? Yep, he does. She decides to stay in the running, well, as long as he keeps handing her dandelions! Yes, instead of roses, he hands out dandelions, because we are all pretty much weeds, aren't we?Renee is an accident in progress from pretty much the moment she meets Ben. She certainly catches his attention when she also catches her dress on fire! Ben wonders if maybe she really does need a knight in shining armor to keep her safe. She intrigues him, to say the least.It was fun watching these two find common ground with all the messes occurring. Never having seen the way one of these bachelor shows goes forward, this read like it could happen this way. A sweet read, for sure.Thank you, Brooke Williams, for the opportunity to read this book.

Now, I don't normally do SCARY...and I never watch those ghostie reality shows. They give me the creeps. Seriously, the heebie jeebies! But...this summary drew me in and I figured I'd give it a shot. I will admit to having my arm hair stand up a time or three, but it wasn't SCARY scary...just a bit of scary. It was actually quite FUN.Ava's aunt has died and left her the mansion that she's always loved. She wants to use it as a bed and breakfast. There's so much room, there's so much history, the view is spectacular, Ava is a fabulous cook...and there's ghosts. Like all over the place! Her family refuse to step foot inside the place. They figure she's going to turn into a cat lady with no husband or kids. Of course, the fact that many of the men that married into the family, and stayed in the house, either went nuts, killed themselves, or had "accidents". They are right to feel a bit worried. When they finally do step foot inside the place, THEIR heebie jeebies made me laugh!To get her inheritance, Ava has to solve the 200+ year old mystery of what really happened to Sarah, whose body was never found. She recruits the TV crew of Phantoms to help her out. When she meets the star of the show, Jackson, there is an immediate connection, on both their parts. Jackson has a bit of a secret, too. He's a distant relation to Sarah's family.There's a mystery to solve, there's UST to enjoy between the characters, and there's a supporting cast of characters that were a joy to read.The pieces came together very nicely with a great balance of BOO and science. I thoroughly enjoyed this one. It certainly made me want more from this author. Nice to know Ghost of a Promise is book one in a new series.Thank you, Netgalley and Entangled, for the opportunity to read this book.

This one came up in an email from one of the Kindle Alert groups I follow. They had the first three chapters up and I read them. And was immediately hooked.Eve Knight has a whole bunch of attempts made on her life in a very short span of time. I immediately wanted to know who was after her.I also wanted to see how the UST between Eve and Jake came to fruition. Jake is one of the FBI agents guarding her life. He has some deep hurt in his past and overcoming those issues is next to impossible. When the depth of the hurt is revealed, I was actually quite surprised.I enjoyed the unraveling of the mystery of who was after Eve. Although I did feel the perp kind of came out of left field. I prefer having clues where I can figure it out myself. But that might just be me.This also was heavy with #NaNoWriMoSyndrome. There was quite a bit of repetition in back story that I didn't think was necessary. Also, we had several scenes that I felt the author was setting up characters for other books in the series. It was pretty heavy handed, and while I like Roy Hanson very much (he's the focus of the next book) the way he and Manny were inserted really slogged down the flow of the story.Even with those issues, I was still pleased with the story and I'll definitely be looking at the next book in the series.

I saw the first portion of this for free and downloaded it. It was interesting enough that I bought the entire set. HUGE Disclaimer: I never have, and never will, buy a SERIAL book that is not complete. I've read literally hundreds of fan fiction stories and those are okay to read as WIPs (works in progress). But I'm not paying for that pleasure. I've been left high and dry several times as writers of fan fiction left the fandom and didn't finish their stories. So...I wouldn't ever buy a book that wasn't finished. I really wish Amazon would CLEARLY mark books that are serials. This author was kind enough to do so, and I give her props for that.Back to the review. This story was finished, and after reading the free bit, I bought the boxed set. It didn't take very long to read, and I enjoyed it. I am very fond of dragon shifters and was pleased that we got to see these characters as human and dragon, both.Ah, Tristan...he and his dragon are totally ALPHA, with Tristan being a bit of a jerk. His dragon is interested in a very short list of things: Food, Sleep, Flying, and Sex. With the emphasis on sex!Their clan has been given a "sacrifice" in the form of Melanie Hall. In this world, sacrifices are volunteers. In her case, Melanie has offered herself up so her brother will get a vial of dragon blood to cure him of a particular malady. It's worth it to her to spend at least six months with some hot guy, trying to get her pregnant, to save her brother. The human women are offered the option of staying with their child, should they have one, which I thought was a nice touch.Every so often, a dragon becomes "attached" to the human. Makes for some steamy scenes, that's for sure. Tristan's dragon really, really wants Melanie all for themselves. He was pretty sweet, finally!This is basically smut...with a nice story line. There was some repetition (#NaNoWriMoSyndrome) and quite a bit of info dumping, but beyond that I enjoyed seeing this world. Ms. Donovan dedicated her book to Anne McCaffrey, and I thought that was nice, too. She was inspired by her, but took dragons and made her own world. Yes, it was enjoyable. I will have to check out more of her work.

I loved this! It's a short story, but there's nothing missing here. It's a mystery, a romance, there's a bit of angst, and then we have a conclusion that's very satisfying.Georgia's daughter has to write a story about time before the internet...a time before search engines and social media. I laughed when she asked her mother if she had been alive then. Georgia then tells her a story about a search without our modern technology to help. A search that takes months, not just a few keystrokes.Just like her daughter, I was drawn into the story. I wanted these two starcrossed young people to find each other again. Then I wondered if they would find that HEA that we all search for. I was on the edge of my seat, right there with Sophie, as we waited to hear more of the story.Some short stories seem to be a prelude to a bigger novel. That's not the case here. We have a lovely beginning, a great middle...and a fulfilling end. If this is your first taste of a Suzanne Carroll story, I'm pretty sure it will make you want to read more! And, thankfully, she has more to read. Definitely a FIVE BOOKMARK rating from me!Thank you, WDA Publishing and Suzanne Carroll, for the opportunity to read this book.

I read the first book in this series, Loving the Marquess, and really enjoyed it. I was pleased to receive a copy of Beguiling the Earl from the author. Kerrick was a great hero. He was honorable and in a hard place due to a debt he owes to a fellow spy. Just when he was ready to court Catherine in earnest, he has to pretend to court another woman.Catherine wasn't all that pleased with the arrangement, either! Especially since she really likes Rose, who is her competition to everyone looking in. AND Rose has an "understanding" of long standing, to back her role in the eyes of the ton. Her parents are pushing for an engagement. Her father particularly. Rose was a spectacular supporting character and will be the star of the next book.I truly hate the trope of people not talking which brings about hurt feelings and misunderstandings. Especially when a few words would clear things up. That is not the case here. Kerrick doesn't let that happen, thankfully! And Catherine, while young, has a good head on her shoulders.They have to find a way through and over several obstacles in their path to happiness. Some of those things aren't totally cleared up by the end of the book. I'm pretty sure they'll be cleared in the next book of the series.One thing that bothered me, Kerrick knows how much Catherine's BIL cares for her. How protective he is of her. I'm not sure why Kerrick didn't clue him in over the fact that this really horrible man is stalking her. Nicholas needs to know.Other than that small issue, I thoroughly enjoyed the adult way these two carried on. It was refreshing to read! Now...I need that next book! The one with Rose and her Duke!Thank you, Suzanna Medeiros, for the opportunity to read this book.

This author is new to me. I'm going to be searching out her other books just as fast as I can! This was a fabulous start in a new series. In the acknowledgements at the end of the book, Ms. Tyler mentions that she and her husband came up with this idea and I really can't thank them enough.A whole pack of Alpha Wolf Shifters, wearing uniforms...yes, my kindle tried to melt. Ms. Tyler builds their back story naturally and I was quickly caught up in their lives.Mac wants to get THE STORY on the SWAT team. She figures there has to be something hinky with all those buff, too good to be true men. Gage, the team leader, decides that he has to keep her close just to keep her from finding out the truth. The truth is that the entire team is made up of Alpha Wolf Shifters. I wondered how they would get along, being all alpha. Ms. Tyler made it believable.The writing was clear, funny...and hot! I really can hardly wait to get more of these SWAT members. This was an excellent first book in the series. I'm going to want more details about the back stories of the guys, but I'm sure we'll get that in the coming books. I want another one NOW!Thank you, NetGalley and Sourcebooks, for the opportunity to read this book!

Anyone who reads this blog knows that I totally fangirl over the historical novels written by Grace Burrowes. One of my friends says that I'm probably her biggest fan. This is true. Her historicals are the books that once I get, I sit right down and read until I can't keep my eyes open any longer. Husband and kids are on their own for meals (good thing they can ALL cook!). I wasn't really worried about reading a contemporary series from this author, but I wondered if I'd like it just as much as her Regency romances.I began A Single Kiss...and was immediately swept right up into the story. For those who are wondering if Ms. Burrowes can write contemporary as well as she writes historical, worry no more! "They" say you should write what you know. This series is based around lawyers. The author is a lawyer and she brings insights to the story that can't be found by doing just a google search. Throughout the story we get legal information in a natural way. It's not a "tell" sort of situation. It fits the story and makes us understand what's going on. I was a legal secretary for years, and while I read from an understanding of some of the law already, I was not put off by hearing how things work. Again, it was very naturally done.While this is book one in the Sweetest Kisses Series, books .05 and .06 (reviewed earlier) give us bits of "prologue" in the supporting characters. Books 1, 2, and 3 are centered on the Knightly brothers.Once again, I laughed at several bits. There are two small girls in this book. Hannah's daughter and Trent's, as well. Little children can hear things and interpret them skewed. Yes, I laughed over the "teensy fly" a lot!We know from an early altercation, that things are going to heat up in the angst department. The foreshadowing nearly killed me. Something BAD was going to happen. Hannah has worries about her daughter. And as we hear from the BAD GUY, gah, I was worried.There are some twists and turns, with just enough hints that I was able to guess about the outcomes. That's so much fun for me. I like to be able to figure out "whodunit" but not until late in the game. And I did!A big appeal of Ms. Burrowes' books for me is the witty banter and narrative. This book reinforces that enjoyment. Her characters act like grownups, with no plot devices thrown in to extend the book. I do love that. Instead of going off on their own to "save the loved ones," they get help! Like people should!Small pet peeve, that I hope was fixed in the final edit (I read an ARC of this book), is the word "OK". Every time I saw it as "OK" it pulled me right out of the story. I always think it should be spelled out, unless you are referring to the state of Oklahoma in an address. And that may have been fixed after I read my copy.The prequel novels, Kiss and Tell (Sweet Kisses, #0.5)  and A Kiss for Luck (Sweetest Kisses, #0.6) have been reviewed here and here.I am definitely in this series for the long haul. Do I still love her historical novels? Yes, but Ms. Burrowes has shown that she can write contemporary romance equally as well. Please read, you won't be disappointed!Thank you, NetGalley and Sourcebooks ~ Casablanca, for the opportunity to read this book.

The first two stories were steamy, but didn't have much "heart". They were hot and well-written, but there was a bit of cheating in the second one, and while it worked out for everyone, not really my cup of tea. They are both geared to get your engines running, though!But the third one! I loved it. It wasn't just erotica, it was romance. I enjoy romantica much more than your straight erotica. This one certainly fits that bill.Nikki and Hunter meet twice. First, there may be a misunderstanding about phone numbers and lists. She walks off in a huff. Unfortunately, she can't walk off at their second meeting, as she's waiting to see her doctor...who is ill...when HE walks in with his doctor coat and stethoscope around his neck...while she's only wearing a thin sheet. Yeah, embarrassment abounds. And it was fun. The remainder of the story is about trust, romance, and allowing yourself to find that HEA. Well done!All in all, this is a short read that will keep your tea steaming!Thank you, NetGalley and Sourcebooks, for the opportunity to read this book.

I really wanted to like this one. Christmas and vampires and a second chance at love. Unfortunately, this one just didn't work for me. There was so much repetition, I just kept skimming. Also, plot devices abounded. Things weren't explained and then a plot twist would magically appear. Just not my cup of tea.Not every book is written for every reader, and that must be the case here, as many other readers enjoyed it.I do thank Netgalley and Entangled for the opportunity to read this book.

4.5 ReadWhile I enjoyed the first book in the series, Pretty Hot, this one is even better. We get to see Kai and Kate fight, grow, and find a way to be together. There are many outside forces that really don't want them to be a couple: His father, her clueless mother, her ex (who is SUCH a jerk!).This one is also much steamier as Kate discovers that there's more to intimacy than what she previously thought. Kai is an incredibly erotic lover and he's more than willing to help her explore that side of her character. Watch out, your kindle may melt.While there is still more of the story to tell, this one leaves a reader in a good place. Ms. Alam is already working on the final bit to this trilogy.Full Disclosure: I was the editor on this one. I honestly liked it, too!

This little gem is free, or at least it was at the time I reviewed it. This is another prequel to Ms. Burrowes newest series, a contemporary grouping called Sweetest Kisses. While the main novels are about the Knightley brothers, the first two novellas are about supporting characters. A taste, if you will, of the goodies to come!I have loved the historical novels by this author. Some say I'm her number one fangirl. That could certainly be true!In this story, Sadie is working hard to protect her sister and her nephew. They've had a very hard couple years and this is a new start for everyone. Gideon has moved into the apartment complex while his elderly farmhouse is getting a face-lift. Living with him is his very LARGE dog, Baby. Gideon is an investigator and he's looking for the young son of a client. We know where the lines are going to cross long before our characters do, and it kept me on tenterhooks. One of the best parts of this author's "tricks" is that she has her characters ACT LIKE ADULTS. They don't keep secrets, they work together...family is everything. I do love that. While she uses this "trope" in every book she writes, whether it is this new contemporary series, or her many historicals, this never gets old with me.There is a love scene in this book that was truly one of the most beautiful ones I've ever read. And there are no "f" words...or that horrible "c" word either. It's hotter than heck, and beautifully erotic, with no "bad" words. Whew...almost melted my iPad.While we can worry if things will work out, we also know they will. One of the reasons why I read this author. Her foray into contemporary romance is a brilliant one. And the teaser she shares of the third book in the series, Kiss Me Hello, has me panting to get my hands on it. Mack is an attorney AND a farrier. Can't get any better than that!I'm reviewing the first novel in the series, A Single Kiss, tomorrow. Please come by and check it out!

3.5 read for me.I generally LOVE the shifter books by Eve Langlais. When I saw this very short story was available for .99, I jumped at the chance to read it.Instead of shifters, here Ms. Langlais explores the Ghosts of Christmas Past, Present, Future...and Pleasure. Yes, that is a new one!This is basically a short little smut fest based on Scrooge...and three sexy ghosts with freaky eyes.If you are looking for short on words, long on steam, this is the one for you.

"Amid the ensuring insanity..." Yep, describes this very well! I laughed, a LOT over this one. It read REAL in the reactions of the towns' people. Scary, but real...and so very funny, too!Mark and Donna are older, but still not old. They have hated each other for years. The only reason they even had anything to do with each other was because of their love for her husband, John, who was also Mike's best friend. John's been dead for a while and the enmity has not eased. Now they just don't need to see each other because of him.Then some vans roll through town and up to the local home school family's home. The government? The law? ALIENS? And there go the rumors. Mark and Donna appear to be the only SANE people in the town, so they are deputized to go and find out some facts. This means they have to work together.In so doing more funny, and some sweet, moments enliven their relationship...and love grows as past hurts are laid to rest.This was a very enjoyable read, and the many belly laughs I felt made it more so. I look forward to more from this debut author.A review copy was generously given me by the author in exchange for an honest review.

This one was 1.5 stars for me.I have never bought a book suggested to me at Facebook, until this one. I love shifter books, the price was right, and it was somewhat short, so I tried it. I was disappointed in so many ways with this one.First, the shifter, Lex (and how did they KNOW his name was LEX when he arrived there? It's not like he was wearing a kitty collar) has been in captivity for SEVEN YEARS. He's shifted to human many times, and hasn't left. He's found his true love in Cass. Cass who has been verbally abused and propositioned by the circus owner, has been pawed (no pun intended) as she "dances" for the drunks, and who drinks herself into oblivion at least monthly.Lex enters her sexy dreams as a man and tells her they will be free "soon." Seems like if he loved her that much they would have left much earlier than SEVEN YEARS.Another thing I had an issue with, once they DO escape, and are on the run, Lex has to decide if he TRUSTS Cass. Really? She's been his love for SEVEN YEARS, they've LIVED together (even if he was a lion MOST of the time) and he doesn't trust her yet? That just seemed weird.Of course not every book was written for every reader, and this one, with its many glowing reviews, was not for me.

I loved this. It's that simple. I simply loved it. I realize Christmas was last week, but you can start your 2015 Christmas reading with this one. Or it might extend your 2014 Christmas Glow if you read it now!Lindsey likes Christmas, mostly, but she feels stressed, too. So much to do, so little time. I found myself thinking that Ms. Donovan must have been in MY HOME, taking notes, when I read some of the moments in this book. Christmas cards! They tend to STARE at me for ages and I find, just like Lindsey, that I keep putting them off. When she makes her famous fudge, she uses SIXTEEN marshmallows, not 15 and not 17. I have a cousin that uses 30 graham crackers for her cheese cake. Not 29 and certainly not 31! Yes, I laughed. I loved that Lindsey couldn't tell if she liked roasted chestnuts, even after eating an entire bag of them. I feel the same. Yes, there was a lot of ME in this book.One evening she's watching a very old version of Scrooge, and really enjoying what Fred looks like, when there's a knock on her door. She thinks she might be nuts when FRED is on the other side. The same Fred from the very old movie. Really, she has to be dreaming, right? When he says he's been sent from Headquarters to help her enjoy Christmas, she knows she's delusional.There's a bit of paranormal here as we don't know exactly what, or who, Fred is.  The joy is watching them both find out about each other.While I have marked this inspirational, it certainly doesn't beat one over the head with it. This line gave me warm fuzzies, as it's what I believe, too:"People come and go, they get older, move, have children. There's only one constant in all of Christmas." He nodded toward the nativity scene a few feet away. "And that's reason enough to rejoice."Yes, I loved this. The ending was sweet and suited the book very well. Now, I want a Fred for each of my two unmarried daughters!AND...I'm going to find more from this author. Soon!Thank you, NetGalley and Kensington, for the opportunity to read this book.

I've been looking forward to this one since I read Stop Dragon My Heart Around. We met Darius and Mei then, and I knew there were going to be some fireworks. SHE really does not want to give into the bond they have forming between them. She has some major issues in the way of a really bad past and she doesn't want to drag Darius into it.For his part, Darius' dragon is waning. They've found their mate, Mei, but if she won't accept the bond, his dragon is toast.Unlike a couple dragon shifter books I've read recently, we get to spend quite a bit of time with these dragons as they've shifted. We are with them as they fly, as they drool over their gems (Mei's got hers locked in a cage at the bottom of a lake), and as they fight. I loved that about this series.I was a bit confused when Mei nearly attacks this chippy that smelled of Darius. We know he used her to try and make Mei jealous, but that was ages ago...why would she still smell like him? Especially since they didn't actually do anything.I loved how they wanted to protect each other, once they've given in to the fact they DO belong together. They have quite a few obstacles to overcome, though.All in all, a lot of fun and I can only want more in this series.Thank you, Ms. Scott and Entangled, for the opportunity to read this book.

Wow, this one was intense. From the first moment we realize what Seventeen has lost, to her escape with a man who might be just using her, to her decision to search for the truth, this is one rough journey.Ms. Hoyle has built a future world that has moments of shining beauty...and monsters come to life that once were only in our nightmares.Seventeen has been bred and raised to give the fruits of her womb to the Unified World Order. She's a Breeder, and that's her only job. Until something happens and despair trickled into her perfect world. She's not even sure why she feels this way.Suddenly a man offers to help her. He says his name is Pax and he asks her for her name. She answers, Pria. He has to be a dream, but then the nightmare becomes truth and there's a death order on Seventeen's head. Escape is the only way for Pria to live.Freedom is scary, but fills her with something that she finds she longed for. She still wonders if she can trust Pax, but it seems like the right thing to do as they search for a home.Home comes with a cost and Pria has to decide if it's worth it.I really think I need to add a warning here. Not sure how to word it without spoiling anything. Here goes: There are some deaths here that affected me greatly. I'd actually put the tag "horror" on the book, as I was pretty horrified at some points. Don't get me wrong, this book is good, great even...and I want the next one now. And if I could get the third and final book the moment after I read the last page of book two, Criminal, then that would be even better. But do be aware that some scenes are beyond tense.(4.5 BOOKMARK GIF HERE)*Thank you, NetGalley and TWCS, for the opportunity to read Breeder.

This is a sweet little romance. The kind where you settle in next to the fireplace with a cup of cocoa with whipped cream and read until it's done.Kate has been secretly in love with her co-worker Brian for three years. She's finally going to tell him. But before she can gets the words out, he announces that he's heading to Vegas to marry his high school sweetheart. Kate is shocked. Then she decides to just fly there and stop the wedding. That is the extent of her plan.With a shout, she interrupts the wedding...and then realizes Brian is not the groom. You'd think the groom would be pretty upset that his bride just walked out, but he's not. He quickly asks Kate to help him out. He needs to be married by the time he's thirty, and that's two days away.Kate figures she missed Brian's wedding, she's not really happy with her life, and she has a pile of debt to pay down, due to the medical bills she accrued while trying to help her grandmother. So...she says yes, she'll marry the groom, Chad, in exchange for a cool million. Why not, right?Chad doesn't tell Kate everything, and she keeps being surprised. First by the paparazzi, then when they meet his parents, and the fact that Brian not might be as married as she thought he was.This story is very much like a Harlequin. That's praise, by the way! You know when you pick one up you are in for an hour of two of romance and an HEA. That's what we get here and I did enjoy it. BTW, I really liked Chad's dad, Hank!I'll be looking for more from Ms. Williams in the future.*Thank you, NetGalley and TWCS, for the opportunity to read this book.

Catherine is something else. She's certainly no lady, at least she doesn't act like one! Nick, the Duke, knows how ladies should act, and none of the ones he's met ever had a cutlass in their skirt.She's pretty intriguing that way. He never knows what she's going to do next. Catherine really tries to be the perfect lady, but she slips every now and then. She takes her shoes off every chance she gets! She's also been known to slip in through a window. Yes, definitely not a lady. She makes an offer on her ancestral home,that he has bought and refurbished, and he refuses. After seeing the cutlass, Nick makes a wager. If she gets a marriage proposal from an upstanding member of the ton, he'll let her have the estate.These two dance around their urges over and over again. That's always fun to read...wondering which will fall first! He keeps saving her from committing an unforgivable faux pas while in public, and he's hard pressed to keep her reputation from falling into tatters.Besides trying to earn a proposal that will win her the wager, Catherine is searching for a pink diamond tiara that is supposedly hidden in the manor. Unfortunately someone else is also searching, and Catherine is in danger.There was a nice balance of mystery, suspense, and some intense UST in this one. I enjoyed it very much and recommend it to you.*Thank you, NetGalley and Entangled Publishing ~ Scandalous, for the opportunity to read this book

This is the last book in the Dark Protectors' Series by Ms. Zanetti. I could hardly wait to read Janie and Zane's story. We've been seeing bits and pieces of it throughout the series and this book is the climax the arc. And what a climax it was! We got to see all the characters from the previous books. Everyone had a role to fill, and they did it marvelously.While I had my guess about who, and what, Zane would be, Ms. Zanetti kept the twists and turns coming. This was one continuous adventure. I am very impressed how she tied things up. I was left feeling satisfied, especially with all the little insights into our favorite couples the epilogue gave us. And then she gave us a hint for maybe another book later on! Ah, good times.There was humor, pages of intensity, moments of joy, paragraphs of fear...and it was all twisted up in a wonderful reading package. I read it in one sitting. Yes, it was that good. We have all been waiting for the culmination of the story, and it was worth the wait.But then she was mean. After the end of Marked, she gives us a teaser for her next series, The Realm Enforcers. I need it NOW!I highly recommend this book. In fact, you really can't go wrong with any of her series. Yes, she's that good.*Thank you, Netgalley and Kensington, for the opportunity to read Marked.

Wow...Kai. Yeah...Kai is pretty hot and he's what gives this book the tag: Steamy. The cover really shows him off, don't you think?Kate really doesn't stand a chance against his heat. She's just run from her ex-fiance. He's a total jerk. She's moved to the other side of the world to get a fresh start. And there are men nearly everywhere. Well, not at the all girls' school where she teaches, but definitely everywhere else. She's not sure she wants to jump back into the pool, but she's really enjoying looking at all that man-candy.Kai wanders through and she just has to give in to temptation. And she's happy she did. And we the readers are happy, too!There are some stumbling blocks to an HEA in the form of culture issues. Ms. Alam lived in Dubai and writes with expertise on the differences. Made for some very intriguing tidbits.This is the first in a trilogy, but she leaves us in a *mostly* good place and the next book is due out soon.I suggest that if you are looking for a steamy read to keep you warm during this cold December days, do give Pretty Hot a chance!*Time to be honest, I was the editor for this one, and an honor it was, too!

My boy is just 5 years old now, and about a year ago he was ready to move on from me reading picture books to him, to me reading chapter books to.  That category of books, "first chapter books", isn't great.  A lot of the proffered material is way way too mature for 4-year-olds.  I was so glad to've stumbled upon Anne Fine's book, as well as the books of Joanna Hurwitz, both of which I thought were delightful and age-appropriate.This story is gentle, non-violent, no serious villains to frighten preschoolers, and age-appropriate vocabulary.

I was glad I baked a few test cupcakes in these cupcake cups before baking the majority of my batch.  My son's 5th birthday was to be celebrated at school with these cupcakes.I think someone else mentioned that the cups "darken" upon use.  Understatement.  After cooking the test-batch, the images on the sides of the cupcakes were essentially unviewable (we were making chocolate cupcakes).  I resorted to baking my full batch of cupcakes in foil-paper cups, then once they were done, I inserted the cooked cupcakes into the robot cupcake cups resulting in double-ply cupcakes, not ideal but ok for my purposes.  I'm afraid that subjecting the robot cups to baking, with the heat and moisture that includes, ruins the effect of the graphics that you see.The toppers are whimsical and delightful.Recommend but with the above provisos.

I think my son was 2 when he got his first foam puzzle made by this company, Lauri. He now has a whole bunch of them, including this dump truck one. They are terrific puzzles that fit together so much better than most of the wooden-piece puzzles out there. I've had so many splintered pieces with those, particularly from Melissa and Doug, it's been complete aggravation. Plus the fittings of the wooden-piece ones are almost always so tight, it is frustrating for the littles. The foam-piece puzzles jettison that problem entirely. The pieces fit together perfectly, and hug together too due to the foamness.The Lauri foam puzzles come with a paper diagram that you can lay in the tray if your child wants some extra guidance in assembly.No criticisms come to mind - buy them!(Yes, the color you receive may be different than the picture, but it's no big deal)

I think my son was 2 when he got his first foam puzzle made by this company, Lauri.  He now has a whole bunch of them, including this backhoe one.  They are terrific puzzles that fit together so much better than most of the wooden-piece puzzles out there.  I've had so many splintered pieces with those, particularly from Melissa and Doug, it's been complete aggravation.  Plus the fittings of the wooden-piece ones are almost always so tight, it is frustrating for the littles.  The foam-piece puzzles jettison that problem entirely.  The pieces fit together perfectly, and hug together too due to the foamness.The Lauri foam puzzles come with a paper diagram that you can lay in the tray if your child wants some extra guidance in assembly.No criticisms come to mind - buy them!

My son, who just turned 5, received this puzzle as a gift just before he turned 4.  The quality is high and the pieces fit together well.  We are big fans of foam-piece puzzles in this house and this one doesn't disappoint.  The finished product is huge, I think more than 3 feet wide once assembled; glad we have a big area of hardwood floor to assemble it.  It'd be a little more tricky on carpet, but by no means impossible.  The little inset pieces depicting some special features of some of the states, ie the Statue of Liberty in NY, Old Faithful in WY, are fun and good-fitting.If I have any criticisms at all of this puzzle, they're these two tiny things:  I think it's the Michigan piece that is fragile due to the unique shape of that state, and I wouldn't be surprised if this piece doesn't last long.  Also, NO. IDEA. why this puzzle costs what it does.Overall, a huge thumbs up from my household.

My son, who just turned 5, received this puzzle as a gift just before he turned 4.  The quality is high and the pieces fit together well.  We are big fans of foam-piece puzzles in this house and this one doesn't disappoint.  The finished product is huge, I think more than 3 feet wide once assembled; glad we have a big area of hardwood floor to assemble it.  It'd be a little more tricky on carpet, but by no means impossible.  The little inset pieces depicting some special features of some of the states, ie the Statue of Liberty in NY, Old Faithful in WY, are fun and good-fitting.If I have any criticisms at all of this puzzle, they're these two tiny things:  I think it's the Michigan piece that is fragile due to the unique shape of that state, and I wouldn't be surprised if this piece doesn't last long.  Also, NO. IDEA. why this puzzle costs what it does.Overall, a huge thumbs up from my household.

I see some others have had some issues with this toy which I guess isn't altogether surprising given its price.  My 5-year-old boy has had tons of fun with this toy over the course of the last month and the toy has performed just as described.  It is hilarious to witness, too.  No complaints.

I have not been a huge fan of the other "City" LEGO kits we've acquired, as they've suffered from design flaws that make them unstable and quick to fall apart.  So I wasn't terribly excited when this one arrived in the mail for my 5-year-old son as a get-well gift after some surgery.Well, we were all very pleasantly surprised by this delightful kit.  The detailing is nice and attractive and very interesting to my son.  He loves that there are hinged compartments that open to reveal the inner workings of this fire truck.  It is also much bigger than we were thinking it was going to be.  I don't think it is a foot long, but very nearly.Highly recommend.

My boy just turned 5 and he's definitely had fun with this toy, but I wouldn't call the navigation overly intuitive, nor are the objectives of the games.  He got there eventually but it wasn't without some initial frustration.  I'm not wild about how many batteries this takes and would prefer if the unit drew its power from the TV (they can do that, can't they?) even if it meant the price tag were higher.Overall, definitely a cute toy especially at the new super-low price.

This is really nothing more than a birthday party favor...No way it's worth the nine bucks they're asking for it as I write this review.It's just a plain cardboard line drawing of the cars die-cut into a jigsaw puzzle.  The idea is to color it to make your own puzzle.  The crayons that are included are 100% useless in completing this project because the cardboard is glossy.  The crayons don't show up at all.  We switched to markers and that worked much better.It's just kind of a junky little doodad.  Pass.

One of the things that has gotten my husband and me through the last five years (our son turns 5 years old in 20 minutes) is our shared misery.  We both break out in hives when we see people out in public who have a very small baby, or worse, a woman who is in the late part of pregnancy.  We both have "you couldn't pay me enough to be back in that phase" running through our brains.  For us, parenting has been terrible.  We have a highly challenging little boy who is only now, within the last few months, someone we actually want to be around.What's hard in a situation like ours is, we feel like terrible people, freaks.  None of our friends with small children seem to have suffered as we have.  Facebook statuses full of joyous tales...photos of families smiling and enjoying a wholesome hike in the wilderness...posts from their parents-only trips to Hawaii...we have felt alone in being super bummed out by parenthood.Enter this book.  Senior makes it clear that we are way more normal than we'd thought.  Lots of statistics supporting the idea that having a kid depletes just about everyone's ability to enjoy your life, your spouse, intimacy, your everything.Which was reassuring.  I stopped feeling like we're awful, but then I felt sad that everyone is, apparently, whitewashing their experiences as parents.  It'd be a lot more helpful if we parents could lean on each other by being truthful about how hard and draining it is to be surrounded by the negativity that is the young child.A bummer/revelation of a book.

I agree 100% that it's a great idea to get kids involved in preparing healthier choices to consume, and this book does aid in that chore.  However there are lots of unhealthful ingredients in these recipes including lots of sugar.  I don't object to some sugar -- I'm not a health food freak by any means -- but it seems counterproductive to the book's mission, which is "get kids off sugar and unhealthy fats and junk food in general".  I agree that a fruit and milk-based shake is more healthy than a Twinkie, even if the shake does have added sugar.  It's just that many of the recipes in this book are more like healthier desserts than they are healthy diet choices.

This building set is good with lots of potential.  I have to say that the instruction book models are hard to assemble in just exactly the right way so that they function properly.  Unlike LEGO, these pieces can be assembled in what you THINK is a proper fashion, but if they're off just a tiny bit, gears won't mesh or wheels won't align or etc etc.It's a good toy, and I think there's a ton of potential for an imagination-filled child, but it's nowhere near perfect.

What was nice about this was that the pieces used to build the model are translucent and various colors.  You don't see much of that in LEGO kits.  You also don't see the light-up feature in LEGO kits that's prominent here.However.  The instructions with this kit  are very inferior compared to LEGO, and also the pieces don't stay together.  If you have a younger LEGO enthusiast (mine is 4, almost 5, and extremely literate in LEGO kits), they're bound to become frustrated with this kit.  Furthermore, although the kit indicates it builds 8 models, instructions are included for only ONE model.  Otherwise you have to go download them at the website which is a pain.

My almost-5-year-old received this from his grandmother as an early Christmas present. He was really anxious for this toy, having just gained an interest in Switch and Go Dinos after seeing a TV commercial. So far, he has definitely had fun with it, I'm not going to lie. BUT.I pulled it out of the box while he was in school so as to familiarize myself with its workings. I'm a smart gal but the instruction book had me flummoxed. I thought it was worded horribly unclearly. The instruction booklet is so tiny that the very intricate diagram was unintelligible to me. Add to that, the instructions only describe how to go from a vehicle to a t-rex (the reverse instruction is limited to "do these steps in reverse to go the other direction"). When I pulled the toy out of the box, it was in neither formation, but rather somewhere in between, further complicating matters. I gave up.My husband, who is literally a rocket scientist, was ultimately able to get it figured out (but not without sharing my feeling that the instructions included are deplorable) and train me on how to use it so I could be helpful with my son.Once my son had the toy in hand, the fun as well as the frustration began. He caught on pretty quickly as far as transforming the toy, but it's the voice commands that are a mess. The toy has a lot of trouble recognizing what is being said to it. You have to talk extremely clearly at exactly the right volume and cadence for it to understand you properly. This has held true whether it is an adult speaking, or the child. The toy seems to respond better to lower registers but yeah, my four-year-old isn't exactly a baritone yet. Thank HEAVENS the one command it seems to understand pretty much every time is "fire the drill!" which is probably the one main reason my kid wanted the toy to begin with.Another thing that I understand, but which is super dumb, is that before EACH and EVERY vocal command you give, you have to first "get the dino's attention" by saying "Hello, T-Rex!" (or "Hello, truck driver!" if it's in crane mode). That gets old right-quick.I was sent here to amazon to write this review by my husband, who urged me to title the review "ABSOLUTELY DO NOT BUY THIS TOY", because he is so disgusted by the failure of performance. I'm not quite that negative on the toy, because it's pretty nifty when it does work well, and when it does work well, my son is in heaven.This phase of loving SnGDs and Transformers can't end soon enough, I'll tell you that much!EDIT: OK well that didn't last long. My son was repeatedly frustrated by the performance of this toy so much so that it drove him to some of the worst tantrums he has had in months. He just turned into a broken mess of frustration and it was very hard for us to deal with so we had to put the toy in the basement. And then we had the joy of the tantrum that resulted after that, so it's been a very long day for us. Always nice when your child says to you, "You broke my heart."UPDATE UPDATE ONE MONTH LATER:  So we've had this thing for like a month now.  After having removed it from the scene per my review above, we gradually reintroduced it for brief practice periods.  Here is some of what we've learned.  To improve the performance of the voice recognition feature, it helps to pause a beat, or two beats, after the toy says "tell me what to do!".  If you immediately blurt out your command, as kids are wont to do, the toy isn't able to "listen" yet.  If the toy is unresponsive to your first attempt, ask a second time before the toy gives up and says "We'll try again later."  At this point, I'd say we're up to about 80% success if we are extremely careful in how we interact verbally with the toy.  I liken talking to this toy to when I have to attend an extended family Thanksgiving meal.  You have to be very careful how, and what, you say.That we've been able to achieve better results with performance does not soften my feelings toward this toy.  It's really more of a novelty than what I think of as a true toy.  It is so clunky to transform due to its size, my kid hardly ever wants to deal with that process.  He has been enjoying the voice recognition feature in recent days since we've gotten it to work better, but it's not really like he's "playing".I add a new criticism with this update, too, which is that the things the T Rex says when you issue the command, "teach me something!" are queued rather than randomized.  So, if you say "teach me something", he tells you something about the size of his teeth.  If you then ask him again, "teach me something", he'll tell you a second piece of info about T Rexes.  Ask him a third time in succession, and you'll learn a third thing.  But you only get to hear new information about the dino if you continue to issue the same command repeatedly without intermixing any of the other commands.  If you do interject a different command and then go back to "teach me something!", you'll be taken back to the front of the queue, the tooth thing.  No kid is going to repeatedly issue the same command so as to hear all of the many different educational statements buried in the microchip.  It's too bad because the educational component of these toys is really the only part of them that is redeeming.A similar-ish complaint:  The command "Go Wild!" only has 3 different responses from the dino, and I think the same is true of "Make me laugh!" which has the dino telling jokes.  Why only 3, and why not randomized?  I would think that it'd be easy peasy to include tons of randomized verbal responses without increasing the production cost of the toy.I do continue to believe that these Switch and Go Dinos may indeed be decent toys for kids who are really into creating imaginative scenarios, like the same kids who can play for hours on end with action figures.  Then again, a rubber dinosaur from the dollar section at Target should be just as good for that child.  But my kid, like a lot of kids, isn't often like that.  So again, this is why I give the rating I do.  I try to rate fairly based on the stated function of the toy as well as what its successes/failings are given what kind of kid I have.

My almost-5-year-old son received one of these as a reward for filling up a good behavior chart. He was absolutely ravenous for one after having seen a commercial on TV.We had one blissful day around here with him occupied with it pretty much constantly. Dinosaur, car, dinosaur, car, dinosaur, car. The sound effects are fine, not too annoying, not too loud.  My son actually chooses to have the sounds turned off entirely.After that one blissful day, my son has barely given this toy a second glance. There've been one or two little spurts of interest, and actually last night he concocted a Godzilla-like scenario using this toy that was pretty fun to watch. But by and large, this is not a toy for your child UNLESS your child is very into imaginative scenarios. My son is very interested in the mechanics of this toy, but he is generally not into imaginative play (last night notwithstanding), so for him it's not a toy with any legs to speak of.He has also reported to me that he no longer enjoys the transforming of the toy, because when it's in car mode and you're trying to switch it to dino mode, the snapping upward of the car's hood to transform it to the dino head is very hard to do. I tried it, and he's right. Also, when the toy is in dino mode, it doesn't take much for the head/neck to disengage and retreat halfway back into vehicle mode. This is a design issue, or it's a durability issue, not sure which, but it has caused headaches around here and more headaches, I do not need.Having said all that, for the price amazon's getting for this thing, it's not a horrible buy. It's just sort of meh.

This popcorn is nowhere near my favorite microwave popcorn.  It's greasy, flavorless, whatever the word is that used to describe popcorn that is the opposite of fluffy.  Tough, maybe?  It also did not pop well for me (700W microwave).  I've probably had worse microwave popcorn, but I've had tons of kinds that are way better than this Act II popcorn.  Pass.

Design problems abound with this LEGO kit.  Our family owns literally hundreds of LEGO kits dating from the '70s to present-day and I would say this is among the five most horribly designed kits we've ever built.The fuselage is constantly disintegrating because the primary means of keeping it all connected are two flimsy 1x4 plates.  The cockpit connects to the plane by means of a cross-bar on its aft side which snaps into a clamp.  If you dare to raise or lower the cockpit, as small boys are wont to do, {and I've just had to interrupt writing this review to tend to my son who has become so frustrated with this toy that he is in a complete STATE) you can expect it to come loose.We buy LEGO toys precisely because, unlike so much of the other plastic junk that's on the shelves these days, LEGO toys are typically reliable and work as advertised.  Not so, with this one (or with the other City kit we also picked up recently, LEGO City Police Helicopter 7741, which is also a disaster of poor design.)

Dell 5110 is my machine, and the battery that came with it lasted maybe 60 minutes before crapping completely out.  I specified this for my highest priority birthday present, and hubby came through.  It is huge and sticks out of the back of my laptop, but not in a way that impedes me at all.  It is functional much longer than the original battery, but don't expect 5 or 6 hours.  I'd say, oh, maybe 3.5 hours.  Which is FINE.  I don't need huge swaths of time where I'm not near an outlet.  3.5 is fine.  Just wanted to let people know not to expect miracles.  No 5/6 hour stints!UPDATE MAY 2014:  I've now had this battery for about six months.  I just wanted to add that it now holds a charge for just about 2 hours.  That's a pretty significant decrease in performance for only being six months old.  Snort.

I gotta say, something smells a little fishy to me with all of the five-star reviews of this company's products.  Whether it's this 24 piece set or any of its siblings, the reviews are all rave with just about nothing negative included.  Also none of the reviews are Amazon Verified Purchases which makes me strongly suspect there are shills among us.The truth is, these toys are quite shoddy in my opinion.  My four-year old boy selected this toy at the locally-owned mom n pop toy store, Timbuk Toys.  We got it home and it was immediately apparent there is a quality void.  The track pieces are cheap-feeling waxy plastic.  The "includes one car!" car has to be assembled (no instructions, no image on the box to figure out out) and it's of lower quality than something you would get as a cereal box prize.  More of that flimsy waxy plastic.The components are cheap, and the design is poor as well.  The box boasts "more than 1000 track combinations!" and I suppose that could be true.  But surely the number of track combinations that make functional tracks for a real kid to really play with are few.  In any event, the instructions included show but one lonely layout.  The instructions themselves are understandable if a little weird.  Once complete, the track layout is in the first place unstable and in the second place it is out of scale with the included vehicle.  The turns are way too tight for 1:64 scale vehicles (ie Hot Wheels).What I do like about this toy is that the connectors work well.  Also the track pieces can be connected not only end-to-end, but they also have connector ports on their lateral sides which is sort of an interesting idea.I'm just sayin.  Read the other reviews with a critical frame of mind because they are not at all reflective of what our experience was.  The one review that claimed these are better than Legos immediately provoked shill suspicion.  This toy matches Lego quality and versatility on absolutely no level.

My four year old son received this as a gift.  Starting with the Olympic feat of getting it out of its package up to forty-five minutes later when it is almost already forgotten, this toy is just bad.The concept is solid...take apart and put back together in fun configurations.  As usual, though, with most of the movie tie-in toys, the execution is a disaster.  Plain and simple, the parts are so difficult to remove and put on, even the adults in the house were becoming frustrated.  The recipient was in tears and ultimately said, "Mom,I think this might be a junk toy."Out of the mouths of babes.

A really lovely story about a 4.5 year old boy's day, spent in the countryside.  The maid at his Manhattan apartment has invited him to spend the day at her home out in the country and it is lovely.  Sweet, easy vocab and lovely illustrations make this an A+.  My 4-year-old boy really loved it.

I really wanted to love this toy.  My boy received it as a gift and is enjoying it in its initial novel stage, but it is very apparent this toy will not have any legs.If your child is super imaginative and has the initiative to make up stories and act them out, this toy might be more successful for your family.  My boy interacted with each of the elements of this toy, the hand tools and the power tools and the foam "wood" segments and was immediately like "what do you DO with all this stuff?"  He's a LEGO type kid and wants to know where the instructions are to tell him what to do.Now, there *are* instructions.  There's a sheet showing you how you can build a few different things with the wood segments.  But building those little projects require virtually no use of the workbench itself.The age range is shown as 4-6 years.  My son is pretty close to 5 and I would say this toy is quite a bit too young for him.  I would say 2-4 is closer to accurate.

I am the parent of a 4.5 year old boy.  He is an only child.  He has always been prone to negativity and it has been hard on the household, dealing with that day after day since he was a baby.  A friend recommended this book as a teaching tool to help him understand better how his behavior and attitude affects people around him.I'm pretty lukewarm on this book.  Some sections do a good job communicating this theme.  My son really likes the book.Here's where I think the book is very unsuccessful:  a whole lotta things get done by various characters in this book that are highly "bucket emptying" kinds of behaviors, but they go unacknowledged while every tiny thing Felix, the main character, does is either shamed or praised for its emptying or filling of buckets.  There are two main examples of this:- On the first page, Felix is nasty to his sister, who has asked nicely to play blocks with him.  On the next two pages, she pleads her case, "I'll be careful" etc.  Felix responds nastily to her and she responds by kicking over his block tower, blocks flying everywhere and the onomatopoeia "THWACK!" shown above her violent reaction.  Turn the page to see Felix summoning Grandpa.When Grandpa arrives on the scene, he is shown consoling...who?  Felix, whose block tower was just destroyed by an outright naughty behavior of the sister?  No.  Grandpa is picking up sister for a snuggle and bitching out Felix for "dipping from your sister's bucket."  Felix is in trouble for being nasty on the first two pages, but sister is being cuddled despite her far-greater-sin act of aggression.  It doesn't make any sense at all and I think it can really confuse the message for a small child whose parents are reading him this book. Grandpa should at least have said "Your sister should not have destroyed your tower, but the problem started when you dipped from her bucket" or something similar.- 2nd example: Felix takes the bucket analogy to heart while he's at school, experiencing both the hurt of having his bucket emptied by kids who tease him as well as the joy of having it filled by people being nice to him/him being nice to others.  Fine.  But when he gets home from school and sees the family dog has torn apart his sister's doll,  what goes through his mind?  " 'Bad dog!' he almost scolded.  But then he thought maybe dogs have buckets too."  What?  Having a bucket means there are no consequences for bad behavior?  Not that I think it's the child's job to scold the family pet, but the message conveyed is "if punishment is meted out for bad behavior, that's wrong because it empties the guilty party's bucket."I just find the message that is intended by this book is lost in its faulty logic and can ultimately just be confusing to a small child.There are two or three really great on-point pages that are good at illustrating the concept, so it's not a total mess but it's seriously flawed.

With this little book, you get about 60 different mazes of slightly varying difficulties.  You also get a sheet of 180 stickers, which were not a selling point for me as they are teensy tiny stickers.  I don't know about you, but I have somehow accrued dozens of random sheets of stickers over the years and they're frankly more of a nuisance than they are useful.It's a sweet little activity book and I would say 4 or 5 years old is the best audience for it.My main complaint is that the pages are not perforated.  I really prefer perforated pages in activity books and coloring books.  Otherwise I'm either mauling the book by trying to tear, or else trying to get my scissors in there near the staple to cut the pages out.  Unnecessary headache either way, but I will go ahead and give this book a thumbs up.

This little activity book is pretty sweet and well-priced.  Roughly half the pages have tracing activities and half have cutting activities.Difficulty-wise, I would say 4 years old is the sweet spot for these activities.What I don't like about this book is that the pages are not perforated.  It seems like perforation is the standard these days in activity and coloring books, and I was super disappointed to discover these pages weren't perforated.  Each page has instructions at the top (which, by the way, most preschoolers can't read), and many pages instruct "Cut along the line while holding and turning the paper with your other hand".  Not possible unless you remove the page from the book, and they don't easily tear or cut out.  Not a huge deal but it's the difference between me recommending, and not recommending this activity book.  I would probably recommend passing on this one.  There are a zillion other choices.

We have dozens of LEGO kits that my 4 year old boy can assemble independently, usually 100% independently.  This product drew our attention at the toy store because it's a sizeable kit of a monster truck and is supposedly "motorized".Where to start.  Every 5 seconds with the assembly of this kit, my kid had to stop and fall apart with the frustration of poor fittings on these bricks.  Or he'd get something assembled right and it'd literally just disintegrate into chunks.  When we FINALLY got it together, we gingerly carried it to our hardwood floor to try out the "motor!" which by the way is a pull-back motor, not a battery operated one, and it didn't work.  We wound that truck up by pulling it back, and then it sputtered forward less than one inch.Also the wheels just fall off.  Just off.This is so going back to the store tomorrow.UPDATE:  Later in the day, we saw that the wheels have to be put on in a very particular and fussy way, but if you're able to figure it out and get them on right, they do stay on.  Also the pull-back function does work, kinda.This toy still pales when compared to real LEGO kits but it's not as bad as originally thought.SECOND UPDATE:  My kid played with this just a little bit more and somehow just by rolling the thing around on the hardwood, the axles broke.  So the wheels can no longer attach and the toy is useless.  BOO.

We bought this for our 4-year old boy for when we were travelling.  It's so easy to transport and seemed like it has enough variability that it'd be a great toy for keeping his attention in the otherwise boring hotel room.  Well LOL it didn't really work out that well initially, and he ran amuck as usual in the hotel room.In the subsequent months, we would just pull this one out of storage periodically and each time we do, it's been a HUGE hit.  The boy will play with it (assuming he has a willing playmate) endlessly.  This past weekend, it was his primary plaything for 2.5 straight days.I don't have any complaint with the quality, as some have mentioned.  We have other play food, both plastic and metal, and the felt is by FAR the easiest to really work with. Yes hair sticks to it, and yes it's all more or less stuff you could make yourself if you had the energy, but for the thirteen bucks they charge for it, I think it's a bargain.For us, the success of this toy, like so many other toys, revolves around our keeping it out of the rotation most of the time to keep it fresh.  You can keep it out in the open all the time and have it be ignored, or put it away for 2 months at a stretch and then it'll buy you 2 days of fun.

We have a variety of MagFormers sets that have mostly been gifted to us.  They're all great and my 4 year old boy loves them.  You can do amazing things with them and there're instructions for how to make really interesting structures with them.  This set is great and very appealing to the preschool age group.I take off one star because for the love of PETE they are expensive!!  Good toys, but holy cow.

Hi folks -My little boy has always had the most sensitive skin and nothing topical has ever begun to touch it...my pediatrician told me that some people have luck combining probiotics with Omegas so I've had the little fella on that regimen for over a year.  It hasn't completely solved the problem completely but it's much better than it was.We use this brand of probiotics combined with L'il Critters Omega-3 Gummy Fish with DHA, 120-Count Bottles (Pack of 3).I drop a star because holy cow they are expensive!  4x as much money as the Omegas.

We bought one of these so that we could easily making single servings of ice cream for our little boy.  My husband and I aren't big ice cream folks so we don't like using the freezer space to store ice cream.  Also with this machine, there's never a meltdown because we've run out of ice cream.  As long as you have 3 simple ingredients in the house,  you've got ice cream.What I like about it:The bowl isn't huge and isn't much of an inconvenience in the freezer.Super easy to whip up one serving of ice cream.Saves money.  I think it's about 40 cents a serving.What I don't care for:None of the recipes I tried have worked except chocolate.  You're supposed to be able to dump yogurt into this thing and have it turn into froyo but it simply didn't work for me.It's a little hard to get clean because I assume you're not supposed to submerge the knob section which holds the batteries.Batteries don't last as long as the instructions indicate they will.The instructions should be super simple but I found they complicated the process due to being so horribly worded.Things you should know:1.  If you use reduced-fat or fat-free ingredients, the machine works much less well.  Reduced fat/fat-free means higher water content, so when you pour your mixture into the frozen bowl, the more watery mixture starts instantly freezing onto the wall of the bowl.  Then the agitator is unable to spin as well as it should, and then the agitator and lid start rising off the bowl as the frozen-to-the-walls product gets larger/thicker, creating less room within the bowl for the agitator to work.2.  The colder your mixture is before you pour it into the bowl, the better your outcome will be.

After Draw Something stopped working on my Samsung phone, I was super bummed out.  Shortly thereafter, I bought myself a Kindle Fire HD 8.9".  Delighted to find DS available in the app store, I downloaded it.  It was able to go thru the first phase, where it shows your opponent figuring out the drawing you'd last sent them, but immediately after that, it crashes with some "marmalade" error.  I tried uninstall/reinstall but got same problem.  A search of the internets indicates that many many people have this problem.BOO.

My little boy has never been a big fan of coloring.  His grandmother sent him a care package from Dover Publications, including sticker books and a few of these stained glass coloring books.  The paper is sort of translucent so you can see the completed image from either side.Anyway, my little boy has all of a sudden started really loving coloring and I think it's due in part to these lovely coloring books.  They work well with every kind of writing instrument he's tried, including not only crayons but also markers, ballpoints, and colored pencils.Highly recommended.  Also highly recommend this one from the same series:  Things That Fly Stained Glass Coloring Book (Dover Coloring Books)

This puzzle has been a mixed bag for us.  My son is four and has fun with this puzzle, but it also frustrates him.  Two things to note about the source of frustration: one is that the lenticular feature can make it hard to identify where the pieces go.  The other is that the pieces in our puzzle are warped and the fittings are poor as well.  I am inclined to believe that this is due to the lenticular feature but who knows.

I have a little boy who is 4 1/2 years old.  I would say his level of interest in this toy is sort of neutral.  Obviously he loved it initially because they love anything *new* at this age.  He had some trouble with the effects but not with the general act of taking pictures.Also he is a child like so many others who doesn't want a TOY, he wants the real thing.  Your kid *will know* this is a product for kids, so if they turn up their noses at kid-versions of adult stuff, you'll wanna pass.  For this amount of money, he really could have a real digital camera of his own.  The projector works decently, which sets this item apart from a digital camera, but you need to be in a really dark place.This toy does seem well-made (especially for Playskool - I have rarely had good things to say about Playskool stuff) and if your kid is super-interested in photography, it might be a good purchase.  I'm giving it 4 stars even though it wasn't a home run for my kid, and even though it's pretty expensive.

We use this product for hard water stains (soft water stains, maybe?  I don't know) that have accrued over the last few years.  We'd tried a few other Clorox/Tilex type products to little or no avail."Kaboom", as it is hilariously named, does work.  Does it work, like, KABOOM! fast? No, no it does not.  Kaboom is the opposite of how fast it works.  I am using it all over my left-side shower door, sort of evenly, for the last few months.  Then on the right shower door, I'm just using it on a like six-inch diamater circular spot to really be able to see how well it's working as against the rest of the filthy right shower door.Hard to tell on the left side, since I'm gradually cleaning this door in its entirety.  On the right side, yes, you can see that the spot I've been working for three or four weeks is definitely cleaner than the surrounding surface.I am glad I bought it, since nothing else seemed to dissolve the water stains at all.  BUT:  don't expect it to work in one douse.  No way will it make even a tiny difference if you have "tough stains".Also:  the color-changing business is malarkey.  It sprays on a sort of periwinkle blue and changes to white in 40 to 60 seconds regardless of the dirtiness of the surface.ODOR:  I am not sure what everyone is complaining about.  The Clorox/Tilex products I've used in the past have just about sent me to the hospital with their fumes, but I barely even notice an odor with this stuff.

My four-year-old boy received two of these as a reward for good behavior. The toys appealed to him because he is big into LEGOs right now and these toys tout their interchangeable parts and their rebuildability.This green car, as well as the other one he got, Ridemakerz Spiderman Xtreme Customz Starter Kit, Red/Blue do NOT in fact lend themselves to building/taking apart/rebuilding. It is very hard to put the pieces together and take apart and they simply do not seem designed for that purpose. It feels like you're forcing it each time you assemble or disassemble any of the pieces. It is certainly nothing my son can do on his own even though he has the ability to do LEGO models 100% independently, including those for ages 8 and up.We have not had any issues with pieces falling off easily, as some other reviewers have mentioned.The wheels/tires interchange reasonably well with the other car, as does the little projectile shooter thing that comes with the Spiderman car, but the hoods and spoilers do not easily switch in and out between the two sets.So what you wind up with is a cheap little car. It is really a shame because there's a really good idea here and it could be a whole system that you want more and more of, but it's just executed so horribly. Bummer.

My four-year-old boy received two of these as a reward for good behavior.  The toys appealed to him because he is big into LEGOs right now and these toys tout their interchangeable parts and their rebuildability.This Spiderman car, as well as the other one he got, Ridemakerz Xtreme Customz Starter Kit - Viper GTS, Green and Black Rally, do NOT in fact lend themselves to building/taking apart/rebuilding.  It is very hard to put the pieces together and take apart and they simply do not seem designed for that purpose.  It feels like you're forcing it each time you assemble or disassemble any of the pieces.  It is certainly nothing my son can do on his own even though he has the ability to do LEGO models 100% independently, including those for ages 8 and up.We have not had any issues with pieces falling off easily, as some other reviewers have mentioned.The wheels/tires interchange reasonably well with the other car, as does the little projectile shooter thing, but the hoods and spoilers do not easily switch in and out between the two sets.So what you wind up with is a cheap little car.  It is really a shame because there's a really good idea here and it could be a whole system that you want more and more of, but it's just executed so horribly.  Bummer.

My four and a half year old boy isn't a big colorer which is too bad because I love it.  But when a shipment of several Dover coloring books arrived as a gift for him, he was happy to sit down and give them a whirl.  He has really really enjoyed them and sat coloring for an hour.The pages are translucent, kind of like wax paper but of course more rigid.  I was surprised how nicely both ordinary crayons as well as colored pencils worked.  Also love love love the perforated pages.  Highly recommend.

Stories on CD are big in our house.  My four-year-old boy has been listening to stories on CD since he was about 2.  He does so while playing quiet activities in the play room.  It is a very calming experience for him, it seems, and after he has heard any given CD a few times, he really starts enjoying them even more due to being familiar with what's happening in the story.This Uncle Wiggily one may be the best one of our many that we own.  Uncle Wiggily stories only came into my awareness recently as I read Uncle Wiggily Bedtime Stories: In Easy-to-Read Type (Dover Children's Thrift Classics) to my son a few months ago.  The stories are ideal for four-year olds who are moving beyond picture books.  They are whimsical and sweet without much dark or negative content (stories where characters face great peril are still too much of a challenge for this age group).  The language used in these stories is neither too babyish nor too adult.  I long to read Winnie the Pooh stories to my boy but the language is a little too winky and wry for this age.So, start with fantastic content in the stories themselves, and then record them with a fantastic reader, and that's what you have here.  My only complaint is that there isn't a series of these CDs; there are hundreds and hundreds of Uncle Wiggily stories that are all in the public domain so please put some more of them on audio!For reference, here are the other stories on CD that have been well-loved in our house:Frog and Toad CD Audio Collection (I Can Read! - Level 2)  <-- that one especiallyFrances Audio Collection CD (I Can Read Book 2)The Mouse Tales CD Audio Collection (I Can Read! - Level 2)Arnold Lobel Audio Collection CD

The critical info you need when reading a toy review:A)  How old is the child using the toy?  My boy is just shy of his 4th birthday.  B)  Kids always love every toy when it's new - how has this one stood up with the passage of time?  Sorry - we've only had this puzzle for one day so I can't comment on its "legs".Usually I wait a while to write toy reviews because a parent can be misled by the child's initial reaction to a toy.  This puzzle, though, is so great that I felt moved to write a review after one day's play.  The graphics are great, the pieces are sturdy, they're not WARPED the way so many puzzles are even straight out of the box (I'm lookin' at you, Chuggington Bedtime 24 Piece Glow-In-The-Dark Floor Puzzle which basically ruined Christmas Day for us, with your insanely warped pieces), and it's educational.  My kid had a great time assembling this and was able to do most of the assembly without help from the parents.A+!

My boy is almost 4.  He weighs 36 lb and is 40".  I ordered 5T.  Usually pajama pants are way way way too long for him despite his being in the 50th percentile for height, so I was happy to find this mid-length style.  I am also delighted not to stare at Thomas or Buzz Lightyear.  The fit on my boy is just perfect, which is to say "not too clingy and not too loose". Go a size up from your kid's normal size and I think you'll be just right.

What can you say.  Ravensburger puzzles and games are always way better quality than the stuff you see in the toy aisle at a big-box store.  This one is no exception.  The tin is great for holding the pieces and the image of the various engines watching a fireworks show is handsome and fun.I think the price for a 35-piece puzzle is very high.  My 3-year old boy has "memorized", for lack of a better word, this puzzle after only two iterations so it doesn't seem like it will be a toy with a lot of legs.  All puzzles with this few pieces are prone to this problem, but that's why their costs really shouldn't be this high.One thing I absolutely love is that the pieces arrived within the tin, and within a plastic bag that also contained a silica packet to absorb any moisture.  So many preschooler puzzles that have large pieces are prone to having warped pieces which essentially makes them garbage.  34 of the 35 pieces were perfectly flat which was nice.I am loyal to Ravensburger overall but the price is a rubbing point.

What's good about this toy:1.  It is adorable.2.  The tracks are compatible with the common Thomas tracks made by Learning Curve.3.  It is a good size for people who, like us, did not want to invest in a huge train table arrangement.  Because my boy (almost 4 years old) tends to lose interest pretty quickly in any of these train sets, it's nice to be able to just pull it out occasionally, play for a day or two, and then load it all back up into the bag where we keep the components.What I like less about it:1.  Agreeing completely with the other reviewer about the scale issues.  The size of the wheels relative to the size of the train bodies is off, making them unstable on the tracks.  Even the smaller Thomas/Learning Curve train cars derail easily and the problem is even worse with these larger cars.2.  Personally I think the plastic bodies of the trains feel cheap, especially when you compare them to the wooden trains in the Thomas/Learning Curve set.3.  It's just not terribly fun for a very long period of time.If you're trying to decide between this set and the Thomas set, I would say the Thomas set wins for overall quality and functionality.

This puzzle features really cute sea animals doing various silly things.PROS:- It is cute.- It is really sturdy for a cardboard puzzle.- Fun to try and find all the "hidden" numbers and letters.- The 3D component was pretty fun.CONS:- This is probably only a con if your child is 3 (the lowest recommended age for this toy).  The puzzle is irregularly shaped so it is very tricky for a child this age to correctly identify which pieces are "edge pieces".  In our house, this means that the grown-ups have to heavily assist with the construction of the frame, and then Little One can take over to finish the innards.  Not a big deal but typically we like puzzles to be one of the things the child does independently.- I didn't personally feel the 3D effect was very noticeable or stark.- The packaging was a DRAG.
