Comparisons to Ray Bradbury by other reviewers left me skeptical.  As a Bradbury fan, however, I had to give this author a try.  And I was not disappointed.  It is a brilliant work of fiction pulling the reader to think deeply about the importance of relationships and what it means to be human.  It is a gut-wrenching end of the world tale that somehow gives one hope.  Very well done and we will be looking forward to more from Mr. Brooks.

Mr. Pearce has given all lovers of Shakespeare some solid food for thought in this thorough case for the bard's Catholic faith and convictions.  Any history enthusiast familiar with the English reformation will find fascinating tidbits of information that support Eamon Duffy's assertions in The Voices of Morebath.  The old faith refused to die despite the persecution and the way in which it survived is key to understanding why the question of Shakespeare's faith has been something of an enigma to historians.  Some have argued that he was an enthusiastic protestant convert while others attempt to mold him into the post-enlightenment anti-theist (the logical progression of protestantism).  But neither case is tenable in light of the questions raised in this work.  Others have gone before along this line but Mr. Pearce has provided the most readable and accessible form of the Catholic Shakespeare case.  My only disappointment is that the work focuses a lot on the life and influences of Shakespeare with few examples from his plays to support the case.  It is understood that the author intends to dig deeper into the plays with later works but this reader was hoping for some teasers in this work.  Such teasers might have convinced me to go immediately to the next book focusing on the plays.  However, without the appetizer, there is less sense of anticipation for what follows.  Still, that is hardly enough disappointment to give it less than 4 stars for being quite good.  We suspect successor volume(s) that focus on the plays will be rated with 5 stars.

With a complex plot reminiscent of Tom Clancy and an alternate history twist like Harry Turtledove, this fast-paced thriller is hard to put down.  The primary plot centers around a Nazi experiment in suspended animation giving a sense of a science fiction tale.  The experiment goes awry through unexpected events which leads to a complex web of interactions that give us insight into what might have been and a view of how much the world stage can change in a generation.  Technical details, especially submarine technology, keeps the most demanding techno-thriller fan involved.  Details of the German U-boats engages the history buff.  And the impact of small, seemingly isolated events will intrigue the alternate history and science fiction enthusiast.  A fun read that anticipates a good movie plot in the works.

Rich characters, authentic dialects, and meaningful dialogue spread across an otherworldly canvas that gives this a science-fiction feel makes this one of the most enjoyable fiction works encountered.  Is it a travel log, a western, a coming of age story, or something else?  The ambiguity of the mixed culture setting opens the door to unusual circumstance that lead the reader through an intriguing adventure tale.  The setting is a late-19th-century cattle drive led by Montana cowboys escorted by cossacks across the vast Siberian steppes to a hungry village.  But the story is far more than the sum of those divergent parts.  You will find the thought-provoking dialogue and likable characters difficult to set aside.

Professor Neidinger identifies the problem of faith affecting how one approaches this topic.  At the same time he asserts that it is possible to try to see past our prejudices into the documents themselves to see where the historical documents alone will lead us.  And, in this, he does a fine job of leading us.  Only one comment that seems an obvious oversight in his coverage and that is Tertullian's lines about the masculine/feminine wording of both Latin and Greek texts concerning Peter and his conclusion, therefore, that the "rock" Jesus was referring to was Peter's confession and not Peter himself.  The problem with that entire line of reasoning is that we can conclude pretty easily that Jesus was not speaking either Latin or Greek when he spoke the line about the rock.  Speaking those words in Aramaic, there would have been no masc/fem question involved and therefore the rock=confession case is untenable.  We would think Dr. Neidinger would have noted how that makes the entire debate problematic but he never corrects that issue.  Still, this is a great beginning and we look forward to the remaining 5 lessons.

Science fiction is well-suited to questioning the obvious and conventional wisdom.  It dispels what we think we know with what could be and challenges our assumptions in ways no other genre can.  That is what makes the genre such a powerful tool in leading us to think outside the box as good scientists and philosophers (professional or armchair) should.  That special nature of science fiction is the secret behind the brilliance of this publication.  Those of us with a love for science fiction generally love the way it makes us think deeply and in unconventional ways.  Good science fiction, to us, is not just the simple question of what kind of gadgets will be invented in the future – but will also strive to explain how those changes might affect how we think about what it means to be human.  The carefully selected short stories in this journal bring us back to the deep philosophical questions of life.  It gives us a sense of the mystical and transcendent.  If the first two issues are any indication, science fiction readers are in for some truly thought-provoking literature.  I hope they can keep this momentum.

We have used this trap several times with good results.  A little peanut butter in the trap door then the easy snap into triggered position makes this trap easy to set.  Most of the time it is easy to empty the carcass.  Only on one occasion did it not drop out of the trap when used as described and I found that the mouse had caught its teeth in the bating hole so releasing the trap and shaking was not enough.  So the solution seemed only to find a stick and push the teeth off the bate hole and then it dropped out as expected.  We only had that trouble once out of several mice and it was not pleasant but not worse than the old-fashioned traps that sometimes required prying the carcass out.  The big improvement on this over the old snap traps is that the guillotine mechanism just breaks the animal’s neck every time and the design prevents it breaking further down the animal’s back where it might cause a bloody mess.  A good design that improves on the basic snap trap idea that has proven so effective over the years.

Intrigue and action you would expect from such a work.  The plot has enough twists and surprises to keep you turning pages.  The characters have a great deal of depth making it easy to relate and be drawn into the plot with them.  Comparisons to similar works are inevitable.  If you are interested in this genre you will not be disappointed in the technical and historical detail provided.  Mr. Russell’s style and ability are comparable to O’Brian or Forester.  As some reviewers have mentioned, this work is less dark than O’Brian’s writing.  I would add that I find it a bit less action-packed than Forester’s Hornblower series.  The underlying love story is done with taste and without the gratuitous innuendo that seems so prevalent with many authors.  A very enjoyable read for anyone interested in the sailing ships genre.

One of the best biographies I have read in a while.  This parallel biography of two key American players in the cold war is at once a detailed study of their two lives and a gripping history of the cold war period.  Like a great novel with intertwined themes and plots, the stories of these men's lives join the themes of the cold war story in a fascinating way.  The author, a grandson of one of the subjects, does a fine job of not playing one subject against the other but lets the story speak for itself.  Very well done.

Economics is not one of my primary interests but more an occasional fascination.  Many economics texts, frankly, are dry and rather dull.  But occasionally a book comes along that causes me to rethink everything I thought I knew on the subject.  Years ago Henry Hazlitt’s Economics in One Lesson caused such a paradigm shift in me toward a longtime slant toward the Austrian school of economics.  Now I have another highlight in my readings in economics, it is this book.Mr. Mueller’s assertion that we have lost a key concept of economics when we ignore distributism has led me down a new direction of study in economics.  No other work in economics has given me quite the paradigm shift this one has and made me eager to learn more on this topic.  The early chapters provide a cogent and complete economic model or theory and later chapters provide practical implications of that model in modern American political policy.  While there may be some debate over the implications Mr. Mueller cites in the end, it is far more difficult to dispute the model he lays out in the beginning.  In that sense, I enjoyed the model description of the first chapters a great deal more than his explanations of where he thinks that model leads us in particular policies.Marvelous book on a topic too many of us have ignored.

A disappointing offering that builds on neither the blues nor rock genius of this performer.  The tracks are mediocre renditions of old middle-of-the-road and country classics without an original sound to them.  For instance,  Willie Nelson's cover of All Of Me plays on Nelson's unique vocal qualities and chord progressions but Clapton's version sounds like the dozens of tired covers by so many others.  "Still Got the Blues" almost raises us above the mediocre with a soulful vocal but it is not enough to carry the rest of the collection.  As a long time Clapton fan, I really wanted to like this album but there were none of the memorable guitar licks or humorous and moving lyrics of the past.  Instead it seems just an uninspiring collection that I will not likely listen to again.

So often historical study separates the religious from the secular.  But ignoring the religious convictions of a people which underlies the political forces that shapes that people will always leave great gaps in purely secular history.  What is lacking in a secular approach is remedied in this American history.  The political movements of the pre-revolutionary days through the moral questions that so often divide us into liberal and conservative camps have little meaning without the context of the common faith experiences that have shaped those movements.  Few other nations have been influenced by religious culture as has the United States.  In this series, PBS has given us the continuity of that religious experience from the earliest European settlements to the present day.  A fascinating study of how faith has shaped politics in ways we seldom realize or wish to acknowledge.  Very well done.

When I first saw this device I thought it sounded like a safe, humane, and clean alternative to traditional traps so I was anxious to try it out.  When winter came, we saw a mouse one night in our back room so we loaded the inside with a bit of peanut butter and waited.  A week later he was still running free and the peanut butter had not even been touched inside the trap.  I replaced this trap with a traditional trap having the same bait and in the same location/orientation along the wall and the next morning we had caught the mouse.  Chalk one more up for the low-tech mouse trap still out performing technology.  It may not be as clean or humane but at least it works consistently.

A good set of workouts that focus you on proper form to avoid injury and maximize your calorie burn.  The workouts can take you from beginner to intense workout levels of upper and lower body as well as some intense core work.  Each workout begins with some simple warm up routines.  The instructor stops periodically to explain proper form without interrupting the routines so you do not lose the heart rate just to listen to needed instruction.  The instructor is knowledgeable and informative without being dry and boring.  The routines are varied enough to keep your interest without being too difficult to follow along.  Great routines, good information, and great instructor makes this a winner all around.

This cereal is a very tasty and nutritious breakfast option.  In grams of protein it is comparable to Kashi GOLEAN Crunch! Cereal, Honey Almond Flax, 14-Ounce Boxes (Pack of 4) but not as hearty in texture.  The texture is more like the crunchy but airy texture of puffed cereals.  Perhaps the texture is why it does not seem to be as filling as the Kashi cereals despite the high protein content.  Or perhaps the Kashi cereals seem more filling because they are slightly higher in dietary fiber.  Whatever the difference, this cereal still has a winning taste and is more filling than one might expect on seeing the light composition and texture.

In the area of the ancient city of Caesarea Philipi is a huge stone that dominates and can be seen from all over the area.  At the foot of this rock are the remains of an ancient site dedicated to the pagan fertility god, Pan.  On the top of the rock are the remains of a temple to the Roman god, Jupiter.  From a crevice in the rock springs one of the source tributaries of the Jordan river that flows through and nourishes the barren landscape.  It was with this backdrop that Jesus affirmed Simon as the Rock on which He would build His church.  Many scholars have failed to grasp the significance of this location to the affirmation of Peter's primacy among the apostles.  But what better juxtaposition of the stability to be found in the life-giving church against the gates of hell?Fr. Jaki brings his thorough scrutiny as a scientist and theologian to bear on the history of the use of the name, Rock, for God alone in ancient Jewish tradition.  He affirms that a mere man being called Rock should lead us to humility and provide a basis for greater unity among different Christian traditions rather than prove to be a point of contention between us.In the final chapter, Fr. Jaki takes to task liberal Protestantism as it searches for the historical Jesus while denying His assertion to Peter.  Taken to their logical conclusions, Fr. Jaki observes, "any investigator of Jesus' life, who does not take for genuine Jesus' reply to Peter's confession, will not endorse a faith in Jesus as defined at Niceaea."  And so, in the end, the infallible Rock of the Catholic Church stands against the liberalizing influences of changing times and remains a bulwark of the one true deposit of faith.  Fr. Jaki's insights from scripture, philosophy, and common sense have given us a great work for meditation as well as apologetics.

Tried with our youngest who is just a little over a year old now.  It seemed to make him laugh rather than make him sleepy but there is nothing wrong with that.  The downside is that the batteries were dead after only two nights of use.  You will want rechargeable batteries to replace the ones included in the package.

Even without the phone app, this game is great fun for the grandchildren.  The only downside is that it is so easily broken.  The plastic cover over the map storage came off within a hour of 4-year-old use.  It snapped back on easily but continues to come off with normal use allowing the maps to fall out of their slot.  After a few days, the kids discovered how easily the pen could be pulled out of the PS2-like socket and their attempts to put it back in bent the pins.  After straightening the pens I was able to repair the problem but soon the pen was removed again and is now lost.  And, unfortunately, without the pen the game is useless.  A locking mechanism on the pen socket would be a great improvement as well as a simpler connector that is not so difficult for young children to fit back in place if it is removed.  If adult supervision can be provided continuously to keep curious hands from playing with the map enclosure and pen, it is a fun learning tool.

The past century has seen a trend in Eastern Orthodox theologians who have attempted to distance their own theology from that of the west with historical revisionism that questions St. Augustine as part of the authentic Christian tradition.  For a good detailed study of this trend see, The Revival of Political Hesychasm in Contemporary Orthodox Thought: The Political Hesychasm of John Romanides and Christos Yannaras.  But is Augustine's work truly a divergence from that sacred tradition or are his detractors too quick to dismiss his influence on the east?  This is the question asked at the Orthodox Readings of Augustine conference held in 2007.  The intent of the conference was ecumenical in that it sought to find the common Augustinian ground between east and west.  It is encouraging that an Eastern Orthodox publisher has taken up this collection but it is unfortunate that most of the essay authors are from the western tradition.Still, the case for Augustinian influence in the east that directly challenges the assertions of those Father Payne referred to as "political hesychasts" is thorough, scholarly, and convincing.  The articles range somewhat in depth with many that are difficult to follow without a good background in the ancient languages as well as philosophy.  Other articles are more conversational and easier to follow; professor Carol Harrison's article, "De Profundis: Augustine's Reading of Orthodoxy" is such an article, not only as a good play on the book title but as a refreshing understanding of sacred tradition as a living tradition.  Harrison's essay alone is worth the cost of the book and, though conversational in approach, is profound in content yielding a wealth toward meditation.Several articles take to task the influence of Augustine's work on Gregory Palamas and the Cappadocian fathers that has to make one doubt the dichotomy insisted upon by the "political hesychasts."  The dichotomy is only present in a shallow understanding of Augustine or of the eastern fathers if we follow these articles to their logical conclusions.  And again we are faced with the very real probability that the differences between east and west are not based in real theological disagreements but in a refusal to look to the other side with the goal of understanding rather than polemic.  We can only hope and pray that readers of these essays will be able to overcome those biases that drive us toward polemic and seek to truly find the common ground that has for too long eluded us.

There is little to dislike in these trimmers.  They are easy to use, easy to adjust, and easy to clean.  The ease was even misleading to the point that we gave them a try in a full haircut.  As a haircutting tool it was a little tedious but it did work despite taking some extra time.  As beard and sideburn trimmers they are outstanding.  The dial adjust feature is particularly nice and easier than some other trimmers that have to be pushed either direction to adjust.  The wet/dry design makes them safe to use on wet hair and make them easy to clean.

Whether you have an intolerance for gluten or you are just avoiding it in order to lose weight, this is a great book for you.  It is packed with many recipes including a delicious gluten-free flour that you will return to again and again.  This is a great book for keeping you faithful to your low-gluten or no-gluten diet.

An interesting trend emerged in the 20th century.  A backlash of religious fervor swept the world.  Fr. Payne identifies this trend as a reaction against the anti-theistic bias of modernism and globalization.  It has occurred in Islam and in the Christian traditions (Catholic, Orthodox, and Protestant).  Fr. Payne focuses his attention on the form of this religious backlash within the Orthodox tradition in the form of a revival of hesychasm.Hesychasm is based in the theology of the 14th century theologian, Gregory of Palamas and it has always had adherents and detractors in the various Christian traditions.  However, in the works of some 20th century theologians, such as Fr. John Romanides and Christos Yannaras, hesychasm became the primary means to distinguish the Orthodox from the Catholic tradition.  Indeed, some critics of the modern hesychast movement have claimed it is simply an attempt to distinguish an Orthodox identify and divorce it from the Catholic tradition.  Fr. Payne even asks the question, "can it be stated that the East-West divide is more about polemics and misrepresentation of theology than about theology per se?"  That does not imply that Fr. Payne, a Greek Orthodox priest, agrees with those critics.  Fr. Payne, in the end, does not see the revival of hesychasm as a reaction to Catholic tradition but as a direct reaction to globalization.  To flesh out this conclusion, Fr. Payne goes into great detail explaining the theology of Fr. Romanides and Christos Yannaras.  Fr. Romanides historical contributions to the identification of the authentic Christian tradition with a Roman identity is given particular attention in order to later draw attention to the possible implications of that theory.  Fr. Payne does not try to refute the (I think) dubious historical theories but instead points out their possible effects on a culture.  Carrying on the discussion Fr. Payne shows how the more political strain of hesychasm in the teachings of Christos Yannaras have led to a new theory of the rights of human beings in society and our relation to the state.  Christos Yannaras, like Fr. Romanides, attempts to distinguish the basis of those rights from the theories that sprouted from western Christian traditions.Fr. Payne avoids criticizing the modern hesychast theology but does point out possible dangers inherent in it.  He does express unease that the church seems to be becoming centered around hesychast theology and abandoning it's true roots in Eucharistic theology.  The hesychast theologians, Fr. Payne asserts, have claimed hesychasm is the mooring of the authentic tradition when in fact they have dislodged a great number away from the Eucharistic mooring of the early church.This is not an easy work to read but the investment is worth the time.  It is a scholarly work with a challenging case.  Unfortunately, such works tend to be read only by experts and go unnoticed in popular circles.  Do not let the nature of the work dissuade you from reading, it is well worth the time for a deeper appreciation of the eastern churches and relations with the west.

If you are one who takes their history very seriously you may find this one difficult to watch.  This is just fun alternative history that dishes up a lot of action-filled fight scenes that bring martial arts rather than history to mind.  There is a good deal of gore (of the low-budget special effects variety) and not a lot of character development but the action keeps things moving along despite the somewhat shallow story line.  If you are looking for serious historically based fiction or bone-chilling horror, you are looking in the wrong place.  If you are a fan of alternative history and science fiction with a yen for martial arts movies, you will find a fun diversion in this movie.  But fun diversion is about as far as it goes.

Though the shortest and final volume of the Jesus trilogy, once again the Holy Father has found a way to challenge unbelief and strengthen the faithful both intellectually and spiritually.  This volume is an exposition and discourse on the infancy narratives of the gospels.  Through Old Testament parallels and historical background these seemingly mythic stories are affirmed as historically reliable and spiritually encouraging.  Once again Pope Benedict does not shy from acknowledging the questions raised by those who have challenged the historical reliability of the gospels.  But with that acknowledgement he once again brings their methods into question and demonstrates the shaky foundations on which the criticisms have been built.But, it is not just critics and apologists who will find intellectual food in this volume.  Those everyday mystics who pray the rosary will find new food for meditation on the joyful mysteries in particular and for Marian devotion in general.  Evangelists will find fresh insight into sharing the joy Pope Benedict finds necessarily linked to grace.This work has been one we have anticipated for some time and though it is short it is no less profound and fulfilling than the preceding volumes.  I will be re-reading this one often.  And, I suspect it will become a favorite advent devotional for many readers.

Some events in history are so dramatic that they take on the character of myth and often with such force that myth replaces history.  Such is the myth that surrounds the end of the cold war.  The myth that America won the war alone and that it was led to victory by a tough confrontational approach led by President Ronald Reagan.  The problem with our popular understanding  is that it is almost entirely an invention of post-Reagan era neoconservatives with little relation to facts.  And basing foreign policy approaches to the problems of today on a fiction of what worked in the past can lead us to disaster.  Believing the fiction twists our foreign policy in so many ways it is difficult to estimate the impact that might result in our relations with those other nations.  The gritty reporting with story-telling style make this myth-buster work a great resource for understanding the real forces and people behind the incredible changes of 1989.  The stories of many former communists who were able to overcome their own prejudices and redirect their countries is inspiring.  The story re-invigorates one's faith in human nature without losing sight of the grim reality of evil in the world.  Well written, well researched, and clever analysis help us to reevaluate how the cold war was won.

The history documentaries of Michael Wood are well received and with good reason.  He has the ability to provide deep insights into the topic he pursues rather than just the old grade-school date recitation approach to history.  That deep analysis gives us a sense of being investigative reporters seeking the truth in the historical events.  This is history that finds the human element that shapes history.  This approach is especially well suited to biography.  Through the places and religious/political tensions of his time, Wood helps us better understand Shakespeare and his genius.  An entertaining and inspiring story of a man formed by a conscience suppressed by the Elizabethan police state.  For more on the religious persecution and the effect it had on Shakespeare's work, see also Quest For Shakespeare.  For more depth on the English reformation as it relates to art, see The Stripping of the Altars: Traditional Religion in England, 1400-1580.

Apparently, the point of this movie was to warn against the dangers of unfettered religious fanaticism and not to convey an historically accurate tale of the philosopher Hypatia.  The setting is in the early years following the edict of Milan that would eventually lead to the acceptance of Christianity as the Roman state religion.  However, the Christian bishops of this movie are not portrayed as the neo-Platonic philosophers they tended to be but as something more akin to modern Fundamentalist extremists.  Such anachronisms are expected from the movie business but then to build subtle error into outright inaccuracy, the script writers decided to pin the blame for burning the great library at Alexandria on these same proto-Charismatics.  Never mind that at the time of the movie setting the library had already been burned centuries before by Roman armies.  No, once again there seems to be an underlying agenda that must force the past to fit the modern bias toward faith as opposed to enlightened and morally superior reason and science.  History has many examples of injustice on the part of Christians (or any group for that matter).  But perpetuating the anti-faith myths such as the Hypatia incident and Galileo without an honest treatment of the historical context is becoming a modern film cliché.  It is unfortunate because the cinematography is original in recreating ancient Alexandria in the context of the entire world.  But average acting supported by original cinematography are not enough to cover the underlying prejudices implied in the story.

My wife, who limits her gluten, is very impressed with this product.  Interestingly enough, she does not like dark chocolate but she does like these.  Dark chocolate is one of my favorites and these bars provide a rich chocolate flavor with healthy whole grains.  Personally, I am not a fan of the texture but the flavor is good enough to overcome that dislike.  It is surprisingly tasty for a low-carb diet snack.

Comrades, you will like this video.  Pavel Tatsouline has been serving up stereotypical soviet supremacy with strength and flexibility training for years.  Before kettle bells were the latest fad, he was pushing his dry cold war jokes and Russian training methods.  Indeed, he is likely the original source of the kettle bell enthusiasm.  But there is more than fad and enthusiasm and silly jokes in this video.  Along with all the humor and stereotypes is solid instruction for kettle bell safety through proper form.  Pavel provides the basic exercises then adds to them in a logical progression providing a true full body workout.  The idea is to begin with the basic exercises to start to develop the muscle and skill you need to build up to more the more complex exercises.  Follow the advice and work them in the progression he recommends for best results.  If you are impatient and anxious to jump to the next more complex routines before you have mastered the first, you will likely end up hurt and fail in your goals in the end.  Let Pavel's goading push you on to greater effort but do not rush the training into injury.  If you really want to give kettle bells a try, this is a great place to start.  If you are not yet sure about spending the money on a couple of kettle bells (Pavel recommends men start with a 35-pound bell and women begin with an 18 pound bell) then try Pavel's body weight only workout in The Naked Warrior, Master the Secrets of the Super-Strong--Using Bodyweight Exercises Only with Pavel.

This is the second kettlebell I have purchased from this seller and I am quite pleased.  The list price plus shipping is the lowest you will find anywhere.  The kettlebell itself is a little rough and unfinished but not so much that it tears your hands.  If nothing else, it provides a better grip.  They are not pretty but they provide the work.  Only one minor problem I have found with a lot of use is that they can be a little unstable if you want to use them as a pushup platform.  As my arms get tired and start to shake, it is easy to accidentally turn them and hurt your wrists.  If you are like me and prefer to do pushups without the kettlebells as a platform, then this is no concern at all.

This seems to be a well built, high quality motherboard, with many features.  I purchased it on ebay for $128 with free shipping. I am able to overclock my  i5-6600k CPU to 4400 MHz simply by bumping the multiplier up to 44, while leaving the CPU Load Line Calibration at it's lowest level.  This keeps the voltage and heat low.  I was able to bring the clock up to 4600 MHz by bumping the voltage to a fixed 1.35, but this pulls more power and generates more heat and fan noise than I like.  4700 was too much with my limited knowledge, and my reluctance to go past 1.35v,  I was able to push the integrated GPU to 1400 as well. I imagine I could get more out of it if I knew more about the intricacies of overclocking, but it shows what this board is capable of with just a modicum of knowledge and air cooling.My setup utilizes an Intel i5-6600k CPU, an EVGA GTX750 Ti SC, 2x4gb sticks of Crucial 2133 DDR4, a Crucial MX200 2.5" SSD, a 3TB WD Green HDD, a LG WH16NS40 Blu-ray Disc Rewriter, an EVGA SuperNOVA 550 G2 PSU, Case ventilation is provided by a pair of Noctua NF-F12 PWM Cooling Fans on intake duty, and a Noctua NF-P12 PWM fan on exhaust duty. The case is a Cooler Master Silencio 352 mATX. Everything fits perfectly.This was my first build in over 10 years.  I built it to be a HTPC, and it is performing admirably.  The board connectors worked out ok for my build.  I do wish the battery was in a more open place, as my CPU cooler and video card block access to it.  Likewise, the CPU cooler fan connection is under the cooler when it is installed.  I would have preferred that the SATA connectors were oriented vertically, rather than parallel at the edge, but I was able to make it work.I did have trouble installing Windows 7.  Skylake drops Legacy USB support, so USB keyboards won't work without going into the BIOS to enable the OS/2 port simulator.  Due to the fact that I did not have a DVI-D capable monitor or DVI-D to VGA converter, I was unable to get into the BIOS.  I was unable to see the BIOS screen on my TV until I turned off the HD setting in the BIOS, once I had gotten a DVI-D to VGA active converter.  This would also not have been an issue with the GTX-750 video card, but I had not yet decided to get it yet.  I used the USB Patcher that comes on the driver CD and on the Asrock website, but that wound up getting me only to the first screen of the setup, where you are supposed to give the PC a name.  I tried many other workarounds, but what finally did the trick was buying a used PS/2 keyboard.  This allowed me to get into Windows, and then the driver disk did the rest.One issue I have been seeing is that the BIOS screen freezes up occasionally.  The mouse pointer will still move, but mouse clicks and keyboard commands no longer have any effect.  When this happens, I have to Control Alt Delete to reboot.  This seems to have no effect on Windows 7 stability, and some times it will happen repeatedly, and then other times, it won't happen for a long while.Overall, I am pretty happy with this board.  It represents a good feature set and quality for the money.
After only 6 months, the battery won't take a full charge, and shows as perpetually charging.  Not good....

It fits perfectly in my D830 and powers it and charges properly.  It seems to have the capacity that it claims.  The first time I put it in, it would not take a charge after I fully discharged it, but then I rebooted and it has been working properly since.I won't give it more stars until it proves itself over time.  The last battery I got, an $18 Coolgo, stopped taking a full charge after only 6 months...  I paid $36, more than the going rate for an aftermarket battery, hoping that the clams of Samsung cells are true, and that they will give better service.I will update this review as time passes.

I went with the NH-C14S due to advertised limitations on cooler height with my Cooler Master Silencio 352 mATX case.  I found out later that a taller cooler may have fit, but I don't regret the choice.I picked this cooler because I'm a big fan of Noctua quality and performance and its specs showed it was compatible with my setup.  Tests showed that this cooler is only slightly behind the big NH-D14, which is incredible when you consider the C14S only has one row of fins and a single 120mm fan, vs the double-radiator with 140 and 120 mm fans of the D14.  Another plus of the C14S is that it blows cooling air directly at the motherboard, so in the end, it may be a better choice after all.I wound up mounting it with the fan underneath, the way it ships, because there was more clearance between the fan and the board than the fan and the side of the case if mounted on top.  I feel the improved airflow makes up for it being in a less ideal spot.  My experience has been that the cooler works very well.  CPU temperatures do not exceed 20degC above ambient in stock form, and 30degC when overclocked to 4600, from 3500 stock.  The fan is fairly quiet at full speed, but with the CPU at stock clock, I find I don't need to spin the fan above 700 RPM to keep things cool, and at that speed its near silent.  I did find that the fan does not want to start if PWM is set to 300 at low temps, so I had to move the starting speed up to 400 RPM, still almost inaudible though.My setup utilizes an ASRock Z170M Extreme4 MB, with an Intel I5-6600k CPU, an EVGA GTX750 Ti SC, 2x4gb sticks of Crucial 2133 DDR4, a Crucial MX200 2.5" SSD, a 3TB WD Green HDD, a LG WH16NS40 Blu-ray Disc Rewriter, an EVGA SuperNOVA 550 G2 PSU,  Case ventilation is provided by a pair of Noctua NF-F12 PWM Cooling Fans on intake duty, and a Noctua NF-P12 PWM fan on exhaust duty.  The case is a Cooler Master Silencio 352 mATX.  Everything fits perfectly.It does seem that this cooler is more expensive at $90 than it should be, considering it has only one fan and is less complex than other, cheaper Noctua coolers.

Same bulbs that came with the 2006 Mazda Miata.  They lasted 9 years/120k before one burnt out.Replacing the driver's side bulb required removing the inner fender liner to get to it.  Unbolting and moving the wiper fluid reservoir eased access to the passenger side one from the top.  Make sure not to touch the glass part of the bulb when installing are they will burn out quickly.

One of my favorite shows ever.  Such a rich portrayal of the dustbowl era and a rich story as well.  I wish they would do a comic or graphic novel to finish telling the story, or that Amazon would do the continuation of the series...

I put this between the parking brake handle and the passenger seat in my Suzuki Samurai.  It is a perfect fit. It does move back and forth a bit, but I am planning to put some velcro on the bottom to prevent it from sliding around on the carpet.  Once can use screws to mount it, but I would prefer not to do that.

The bearings make as much noise as the ones in the 20 year old original.  It is charging nicely.  I was hoping for made in the USA, but it is made in Mexico.  It is nicely finished and it is a new part so there is no core charge.  I did not have to clean out any of the mounting holes or threads like with some rebuilts.  I do plan on getting the old one rebuilt at a local shop as back-up since I don't trust the noisy bearings.

Beautifully done with great acting and superb cinematography.  I enjoyed this for the "look and feel" it conveyed of an age I can hardly imagine, and for the overall portrait it painted of John and Abigail Adams.I do find it ironic that the John Adams, beautifully played by Paul Giamatti in this mini-series, berates a painter for taking poetic license with the past, when this mini-series takes so much poetic license and invents situations from whole cloth, when there were historical events that were just as dramatic that could have taken the place of said fictional events.It did get me interested in the real John Adams, and set me to reading about him.

I've been using this feeder for 3 years now. It has reliably fed my cat except for once, when I tried to switch to an Science Diet weight loss food.  I was able to get a new style dispenser and guard which accepted the electronics from the old one, and now it works fine with the new food.The only other problem I've had is that the clear bin that lets you see when the hopper has run out cracked.  It came with two, one of which I put at the top so it is easy to see when the hopper is full.  The first one broke after a year or so, so I moved the top one down to the bottom, and that one cracked recently.  Thankfully, they stock parts so I have new ones on the way.  I'm hoping the new ones are tougher.I would buy this again.

This EGR valve is ok and will replace your old worn-out egr valve just fine.However, there is a better EGR valve.  It is ACDelco 2145083 and is designed for the LT1 powered manual transmission Camaro.  The Camaro with manual transmission is much more sensitive to EGR problems than the automatic version, so GM designed a better EGR valve for it.ACDelco 2145083 looks identical to ACDelco 2145084, but lasts much longer without problems, and also solves EGR problems that can occur if you use a more free-flowing exhaust.

This tree is very beautiful, looks very realistic, and has the feel of great durability.  I purchased it direct from Balsam Hill, as it was not available at the time on Amazon.  It came the next day, even though I ordered ground shipping.  It did ship from Fremont though, which is fairly close.I purchased this tree to go on top of a table in my entry-way.  I went with un-lighted because I have vintage lighting to put on it.This tree comes in two pieces.  It has a bottom section with branches that are hinged and fold upward.  The top section is not folding.When you first put the bottom section in the stand, you realize that this is a heavy tree, and feels very solid.  It also looks very scrawny when it comes to foliage.  You have to fluff the foliage out, and there is plenty to fluff out.I used a tip found elsewhere that was to use the ribbon that held the branches folded up, to hold all the branches up but the layer you are working on.  This worked out very well.  It took me about an hour to get the tree looking the way I wanted it too, but when completed, I was VERY impressed.  I have no doubt that this tree will last the 10 years it is warranted for.

If you have a '94-96 Caprice, Roadmaster, Fleetwood or Impala SS with 4-wheel disk brakes, you probably want this.GM used the same proportioning valve whether the car was equipped with rear drums or disks.What this means is that there is a variable amount of pressure sent to the rear brake, depending on how hard you push on the brake pedal and the pressure is delayed as well.This means that, if you have 4 wheel disks, upon a light activation of the brakes, the rears do almost nothing, the bias being about 95/5.  Under heavy application, the rear brakes do their share, with a bias of about 65/35.These brake bolts make the front/rear application stay about 65/35 all the time and remove the delay in rear brake application.The benefit of this is that your front brakes will last longer, and trail-braking is much more effective.The downside of this is that you will be replacing your rear-brakes more often and cleaning brake dust off your rear wheels more often as well.DO NOT apply this modification if your car has rear drum brakes.

I purchased two of these because I have a American Apparel T-Shirt that is 100% cotton and is so soft and comfortable.These are just as soft and comfortable, but they wrinkle very easily.  My t-shirt does not wrinkle like this at all.I don't expect to wear these much.

My favorite knife so far is the Benchmade Griptilian in D2 steel from Cabelas.  I've had a few Kershaws over  the years, but they have never really grabbed me.  This one caught my eye so I had to pick one up.The Strobe has a solid, weighty feel in the hand and opens fast and smooth with a bit of resistance at the beginning, which keeps the knife closed when it is in your pocket.  I've not had it long enough to know if it won't open by itself, but I feel like it won't.  My previous Kershaws would open in my pocket unless I locked them closed.  I really did not like having to lock them closed and that was one of my main problems with them.The Strobe feels nice and secure in the hand, well balanced and comfortable to grip firmly.  The blade is fairly thick, wide and very sharp, right out of the box.  Once open, the frame lock looks and feels like it is very secure.  There is no play once locked, no impression that the blade will fold unless you unlock it.  The Strobe seems to have about the same stiffness, side to side, as the Griptilian, which is very good.For me, the Griptilian is still my first choice for every day carry, but if the Strobe were the same size as the Grip, the deciding factor would be the Axis lock of the Griptilian, which I prefer.All in all, a very good knife for the money, and I expect it will see plenty of use.

Plenty of good reviews here on this generator, so I won't repeat them.  For the same price, you can get the same generator from Tractor Supply Hardware, but with 200 extra running watts and 300 extra starting watts.  That may not seem like a big deal, but it adds up to much less worry about the loads you run.  The Champion model 42432 has the same run-time and fuel capacity as this one, but has a 1400 watt running and 1800 watt starting capacity and is the same price as this one.  Shipping winds up bumping the price up a bit, but it is well worth it.
I use these in a Litter Robot.  They are a good size for it.  I have had a few open up a bit at the seams, but not too bad.

Initial Review;This is my first smoker, and I've only cured it and used it one time.  I'm afraid I jumped on this due to the price, before I had researched smokers.  This is rare for me, but I was mainly looking for something with more flexibility than my Son of Hibachi.  The Son of Hibachi is great for grilling, but I wanted to do some smoking as well, with the ability to also grill larger quantities than the Hibachi will handle..What I have found, is that this smoker has all of the short-comings of typical off-set smokers, and that all of those short-comings are made worse by small size and relatively thin metal.I cured it, as per the directions on page 3 of the manual, using charcoal in the firebox.  I then added more charcoal, and rolled right into smoking some boneless chicken thighs, a pork roast, and a tri-tip.  I used a mixture of hickory and cherry chunks.  I put two 8x8 aluminum pans underneath the grills, and a 4x8 loaf pan as well, to catch drippings.I found that, with charcoal, I was having trouble getting the temperature up on the grill.  I found that the grill temperature, right underneath the thermometer, was much lower than the temperature indicated on the thermometer.  300 on the thermometer resulted in 200 at the grill surface.  I found that the area next to the firebox cooked very quickly, cooked more like grilling than smoking, while the area opposite the firebox remains pretty cool, to the point I could touch the grills.  Until I pushed the temperature to 350 with a resulting 225-250 at the grill, the food in the middle did not cook.I wound up relying solely on wood to keep the heat up, and had no issues with temperatures being too low once I did this.  Due to the small size of the wood chucks I was using, I wound up having to use a lot more wood than I expected.  After a couple of hours of this, I wound up with perfectly cooked chicken thighs, but the other meat had an interior temp of only 120F.  If I had had more time, I would have continued smoking and eventually gotten the tri-tip and roast up to temp, but instead, I put the remaining meat in the oven and finished it that way.All of the meat turned out delicious.  The roast and tri-tip had very nice smoke-rings.  I was very pleased with the way the food turned out.If I did not plan to try some modifications, I think I would use mainly charcoal for fuel, and put some charcoal in the smoker chamber to bring temps up in the far end.My plan is to try putting a baffle in, mainly to shield the food from the direct heat of the firebox, but also to move the heat entry point more toward the middle of the smoker area.  I also plan to extend the smoker chimney down closer to the grill, to force the smoke down there.  I also plan to find a basket so I can use the Minion Method of fueling the smoker.  I feel that these additions will greatly aid the ease of use of the smoker.I do wish Char-Broil would cure the paint in-house.  I feel it is impossible to cure the paint at home from the inside nearly as well as could be done in an oven big enough to hold the parts.  I feel that curing issues are a large part of the paint complaints received.I'm not sure that, had I done more research, that I would still buy this smoker, but for the money, I feel it is worthwhile.Update;I have since smoked a 4 lb pork shoulder and smoked and grilled some burgers.To smoke the pork shoulder, I took two disposable bread-loaf pans, of the 4x8 variety, punched holes in them for ventilation, and loaded each with charcoal.  I tilted the pans and laid the charcoal on it's side in a sort of chevron pattern.  I then put another layer of charcoal on top of that in the same pattern.I also cut 3/4 of the bottom out of a mini-loaf pan of the 3x6 variety, and bent the flap of remaining material up to extend the heat shield/baffle.  I then put the loaf pan in the hole between the fire-box and smoker chamber with the flap portion up, and expanded the pan to lodge in the opening.  This made a nice baffle and heat shield.I then put the two pans in the smoker and lit one end of the briquettes using a blow torch.  I lit the 4 briquettes on top at the end closest to the smoker chamber, so the flame had to work back toward the vent.  After those briquettes were well lit, and the temperature started coming up in the smoker chamber, I put the un-seasoned pork shoulder in the middle of the smoker, over a foil pan to catch the drippings.  I put some cherry wood on the lit briquettes as well as the unlit ones, and let the meat smoke.  After about 30 to 45 minutes, all of the briquettes in the pan were lit, and I had to use the air register to keep the heat down.  Occasionally I would put a couple of pieces of wood on the briquettes to keep the smoke going.  Occasionally I would put a chunk of hickory in, but the smoke was mainly from cherry.With this method, after 3 hours of smoking, the charcoal was still going.  I would have left the meat in the smoker, but it was bed time, so I put the pork shoulder in a slow cooker on low while I slept.  I put a half cup of water in as well as the drippings from the pork.The next morning, the pork shoulder was fork tender and was easily pulled apart.  I had some for breakfast, gave some to a friend to try, and had some more for supper.  It was one of the best I've ever had.  It was hard to believe the flavor was only smoke and natural pork juices.  My friend raved about it.For the burgers, I just put about 30 briquettes in the firebox, lit them, and when fully lit, spread them out and put 8 seasoned patties in the smoker chamber.  I smoked the patties using mainly cherry with some hickory, for about 30 minutes.  The patties closest to the firebox needed to be flipped at 15 minutes, and were pretty much done at 30.  I finished grilling them in the firebox grill, and then grilled all the rest of the patties in turn in the firebox, returning them to the smoker to keep them warm when they were finished.  These burgers turned out fabulously!Update2;I smoked a brisket this weekend.  This time, I made two additions to my smoker.The first is a Maverick Et 733 Wireless BBQ Meat Thermometer.  This lets me see the actual temperature the meat is seeing, as well as the meat internal temp, without having to constantly go out to the smoker.  This is a must have item, no matter what smoker you use.I am very much enjoying this purchase.The second was a FDS-875 Stainless Steel Floor Drain Strainer.  This is a perforated pan that fits into the firebox and allows one to put a lot more charcoal in for 4 hours worth of heat.  It also makes cleanup easier.  I have put a photograph of it in the customer images section.  I purchased this off of ebay for $20.I have settled on a method of smoking large cuts of meat, where I smoke the meat until the heat dies off, and then put it in a slow-cooker to finish it.  This has worked great for pork shoulder and brisket.

I purchased this lamp because it was about the same price as other 2-bulb lamps and has glowing reviews. I also thought it would have bloom and vegetation bulbs included. I see now that the description shows 6500K bulbs by default, and one can request mixed or only bloom bulbs.My lamp was poorly packed and was damaged in shipping, but I see later reviews are saying it is well packed, so maybe they have improved. The lamp was much flimsier than I expected, but because it is so flimsy, it is very light for the amount of light it puts out. The seller did offer a refund, or would send new ballasts to get the lamp working. I took new ballasts, but still faced hassle either way, either of returning the lamp, or having to install the ballasts.The seller did respond quickly and gives good support.When faced with the buying another lamp, I chose to try a more expensive and hopefully better built one(hasn't arrived yet), but I will keep using this one as well.Pros;Very high output for the money.Can be switched to have 0, 2 or 4 lamps on at a timeCan be daisy chained together, only needing one cord to plug into the outlet or timer.LightweightCons;Very flimsy constructionEasily damaged in shippingCould be good or bad, depending;Puts out a good deal of heat

The Fox Run 5-3/4-Inch Stainless Steel funnel is perfect for getting cat food into a Super Feeder CXF-3XL Automatic Cat Feeder.  I've had trouble getting food into the hopper since I started using it, and this gives me a bigger target, while still letting me see inside the hopper so I don't over-fill.
I love the smell of this, but it only lasts a couple of days.

I have a set of Old Man Emu springs on my Suzuki Samurai.  These springs have pads on the springs to help them slide, to give a better ride and more flex.  After a while, the lubrications goes away and the ride becomes rough.  I did not want to use grease on the pads due to the grease attracting dirt.I tried this product out and it worked great.  The ride is now much smoother, like when I first put the OME springs on.This product should work great for any application where a dry lubricant is needed.

This soap is practically a pimple eraser. The way it works is to get your pores opened and moisturizing your skin naturally.  Google The Oil Cleansing Method.  This soap IS the The Oil Cleansing Method in a bar soap!This is the only soap I use at home.  I have given it as gifts many times.The only downsides I have found are;It tastes NASTY!  And it easily gets in your mouth.It sticks hard when it dries.  I always put it on its side or on the edge of the soap dish, not in it.  Otherwise it can be very hard to pry it lose.

I have an '88.5 Samurai.  This distributor had the wrong plug on it.  I swapped the igniter and ignition control module from my old distributer and it worked.  This was fine since I needed the mechanical parts only, but if you need new electrics for an '88.5 or '89, you will need Cardone 31-526 which is, of course, almost twice as expensive as this one. The key is the plug.  If you have a round plug, this is the correct alternator.  If it is an oval plug, you need Cardone 31-526This distributor seems to be a quality piece and comes with the electrical parts and vacuum advance.  It does not come with the gasket or dust shields.

It pains me to write this review.I use a Litter Robot and my cat has only peed outside the box one time.  That was when the Litter Robot stopped upside down so she did not have a box to go in.  She peed right in front of me.  So one time, in 7 years, and that was for cause.I've mostly used Ever Clean Extra Strength Cat Litter, Unscented,  I loved the original formula, but that is unavailable now, so I've tried others, including Precious Cat Ultra Premium Clumping Cat Litter.  Nothing has really been better though, so I stick with Everclean.2 months ago, I started replacing her litter with World's best.  I did this by putting it in one scoop at a time to replace the litter that the Litter Robot scooped out.  After 2 months of this, the littler is mostly World's Best, and that was enough for my Sofie.  She started peeing on the bath mat in the guest bath.So I dumped the World's best litter and replaced it with Everclean.  The next morning, there was a urine clump in the litter and no pee on the bath mat.I really wanted this litter to work, as I feel it is a healthier and more environmentally friendly choice.Maybe it just doesn't work well in Litter Robot service.

This review is for the "Original OEM 5 Foot White Samsung USB Sync Data Cable Charging Cable for Samsung Galaxy S II/2 Skyrocket HD, Galaxy S Aviator, Galaxy S Blaze 4G, Rugby Smart, Galaxy Nexus, Captivate Glide, Focus S, Samsung Galaxy S3, Samsung Galaxy S4" sold by Ms.CellShopThe cable I received looks, feels, and performs exactly like the cable that came with my Samsung S4.  It even had the same plastic tape around it.I've been having trouble finding a good charge only cable to replace my failing Naztech Micro USB Charging Cables, which are no longer available.  This is not a charge-only cable, but does charge the Samsung S4 at 1.9 amps, which is the maximum it will accept.I ordered 4 more from  Ms.CellShop

I bought this charger for it's long thin cable.  I had another one like it that lasted over a year.  This one lasted about a month.I contacted Amazon about it and was told it was past the return date, so too bad and so sad, but we can't help.

With my Pentax battery, I can run it down until the charge indicator is blinking red before the camera shuts down.With this Wasabi Power battery, it can show a full charge and shut down on me.I keep the Wasabi as a last resort battery, and don't expect it to give me more than 100 frames.

I have been trying to keep my yard green for years now, using organic fertilizers and other non-traditional soil enhancers.  I have been successful, but it still requires a lot of "stuff" sprinkled onto the lawn.  I kept thinking about the yards of my youth.  My father and grandfather never fertilized their yards and they looked fine.  Why is it so hard for me to keep my yard healthy?One day I found out that clover is a nitrogen fixer.  It takes nitrogen out of the air, and puts it in the ground.  Wait, what!?I remembered that clover always grew in the yards of my youth.  Where did it come from?  Where had it gone?It turns out that clover is great for a lawn, but broadleaf herbicides kill it.  Time to plant some clover!I ordered this clover from Nichols Garden Nursery last year and planted it in the late summer.  I also planted some indoors in potting soil in a 12" square plastic pan and it germinated and started growing very quickly.  It was very close to 100% germination, so the seed was certainly good.I simply sprinkled the seed all over the yard, hoping that enough would germinate to get a good start, and then it would spread.  I did water it in and watered it every day for a week, but got no germination.We had a very dry winter and nothing happened until the late rains and warmth of late winter.  As soon as we had a few warmish days, I started seeing clover germinating in patches in the yard.  Much less germinated than I had hoped for, and it mostly germinated in places where the grass was growing well already.  I suppose this is to be expected, but I had really hoped it would germinate in the bare patches in the yard.This clover seems very hardy, and is growing profusely in the spots where it took hold, and slowly spreading, as I had hoped it would.  It is not at all "micro" though.  It quickly grows much taller than the grass, and the leaves are as big as the clover I am used too.This is not a deal-breaker for me, but I had hoped that it would not be so tall and big as normal clover.

So far, only Samsung cards have worked for me in my phones.  When I have tried other cards, such as Sandisk, they always fail. I've yet to have a failure with Samsung cards.  I won't run anything but Samsung now.I replaced a Samsung 32GB card that I have been using for the past year in my Galaxy S Epic 4G and then Galaxy S4 with this card.Firs, I put the new card in the phone and let the phone format the card.  Then I put the old and new cards in USB 3.0 card readers, and inserted them into USB 3.0 portsWhen I copied the files from the old card to the new one, the files copied at 10-20 MB/sec, averaging around 12 MB/sec.  The copy process went off without a hitch.When I inserted the card back into the S4, it took a few moments to see it, but then it became visible and the phone is now working with the card with no issues.I ran the A1 SD bench and the card clocked in at 17.6 MB/sec Read and 9.5 MB/sec for Writes.Using SD Tools, it clocked  in at 19.8 MB/sec Read and 11.1 MB/sec for Writes.

Based on a review of 5 battery maintainers in Wing World magazine, I purchased a Yuasa 1.5 amp battery maintainer. I have a 2001 Honda GL1800 Goldwing with a battery that is at least 2 years old. I have an Argus Battery Bug that showed the battery was at 48% of life, and that the voltage would fall to 12.2 volts over the course of a day.I put the Yuasa on each night for a week, basically until several days past with no further improvements, and then reset the battery bug. I then rode the bike to work for a week and found that the battery was holding 12.5 volts and was at 77% on the battery bug.I then discovered another review in Wing World magazine on the Pulsetech Xtreme Charge, which indicated that it brought batteries to a higher state of charge than other battery maintainers. I decided to give it a try.After using it every night for a week, I again saw no further improvements, and reset the Battery Bug and rode it for another week. At the end of that week, the battery was maintaining 12.9 volts after the course of a day, and the Battery bug was indicating that the battery was at 91% life.I have since used this charger on all of the batteries in my household.  I rotate it around so that each vehicle "gets a hit" at least once a month for a few days.  It helped the battery in my Burgman 650 last over 6 years.  That battery was still firing off like new when I sold the scooter.So, in conclusion, the Pulsetech Xtreme Charge appears to perform as advertised. It brings batteries to a higher state of charge, giving shorter cranking times, which wastes less fuel and ensures a longer starter and alternator life.

I'm using this on a 2007 BMW F650GS.  It fits like it were almost tailored to the bike.  I hate big tank bags, and this one is just right to me, having enough space to store gloves, cap, camera, phone... with room to spare, but not interfering with the full lock of the bars in either direction, nor sitting too tall.The three pont strap mount is perfect as well.  It was a bit difficult to get the strap threaded through for the part under the seat, but the strap can stay there even if the bag is not mounted, so that is a one time job, unless you want to move from bike to bike with the bag.It seems very well made, mounts securely, and has a non-slip, non-scratch neoprene base.The rear pocket is perfect for keeping the rain cover in.One gripe I have is that the entrance to the map pocket is pretty narrow.I've heard that the clear plastic will yellow from UV, so make sure you treat it with UV protectant.  I'm using Honda spray polish.

I used this to replace an old Docsis 2.0 Motorola SBG900.The SBG900 worked well enough until I purchased a Logitech Revue, which has issues with the SBG900, such as dropping connections which required a reboot of the router, among other things.After doing my research, I found that the Zoom 5341J was Comcast compatible and capable of connecting to 8 download channels and 4 upload channels, compared to the much more common 4Down x 4Up configuration.  Keep in mind that the Zoom 5341(with no J at the end) is a 4x4 configuration.The Zoom 5341 is a modem only, not having a wireless router embedded like the SBG900, but I already had a Linksys WRT54G router, which I had already pulled out to try and rectify my problems with the Logitech Revue.  The SBG900 kept dropping the wired connection to the Linksys though...  The Zoom 5350 is compatible with Comcast and has the same specs as the 5341J, but also has a wireless router and 4 wired ports as well.  I considered it, but decided to go with seperate pieces for modem and router duty.The evening that the Zoom 5341J arrived, I installed it in place of the SBG900, and plugged my laptop in.  Once it had established a connection, the Comcast device activation page came up in my browser, and I was able to switch the activation from the SBG900 to the Zoom 5341J in minutes, with no need for phone calls to support.The configuration of the Zoom 5341J is very simple, and I made no changes to the default configuration.  I did check the connections, and found that I had 8 download connections and 2 upload connections.  It appears that Comcast in my area will only provide 2 upload connections.I plugged the Linksys WRT54G in and had WiFi a minute later.  I found average speeds to be about the same as before, but peak speeds to be about 30% faster, and this resulted in snappier browser performance, and quicker starting of streaming video.  I also have found that the connection is more robust, as I have not been getting the rebuffering and disconnects streaming video that I was getting with the SBG900.My problems with the Logitech Revue have also been solved, and the Zoom 5341J has not been dropping the wired connection to the Linksys WRT54G.  That, combined with the performance enhancements, has left me very happy.

This is, by far, my favorite hot sauce.  It is pretty mild, but packed with jalapeno flavor.  I use this in almost every soup, stew, and gumbo I make, as well as many other dishes.I just bought four bottles of it, and wish it came in a larger bottle!

I've been drinking this tea for over a year now, and it is the main tea I drink.  I prefer other teas for flavor, for sipping and savoring, but this is what I drink the most of, as a refreshing and healthy beverage, and it is very good for that purpose.The Amazon description, saying this is Bai Mu Dan, is incorrect. It is actually fannings. Fannings is the second to the smallest leaf size. Fannings are used in tea bags because of their small size and economic price. On the Uncle Lee's tea website, this tea is shown just as white camellia sinensis. The Uncle Lee's Organic White tea that is described as Bai Mu Dan on the Uncle Lee website is $5 for 18 bags.The only other pure white tea I've had is Republic of Tea's Emperor's white tea, which I find superior to this tea, having a milder and sweeter flavor that is even more pleasant to drink without sweetener than this one. The Uncle Lee's white tea is closer to an oolong in both color and flavor than the Emperor's, with just a hint of bitterness and none of the herbal tones of a green tea.That said, the RoT Emperor's White is almost 6 times more expensive than this tea, and Uncle Lee's is still easy to drink without sweetener, so I'll save the Emperor's for special moments and use the Uncle Lee's as my "daily drinker."Having more flavor, I find that this makes an excellent iced tea.  I usually use 4 bags of this, and one bag of Republic of Tea's Cherry Green Tea, to a gallon of water plus 2 heaping teaspoons of natural cane sugar to provide just a hint of sweetness in a very refreshing iced tea that everyone loves.
The Santa hat I received was nothing like what is pictured.  I have uploaded a picture of the actual hat.

I find this works pretty much like a two-bladed edger blade, with a couple of important differences.The first is that the action is much smoother and has less vibration.  This is very nice since I'm using a stick edger attachment for an Echo SRM-210.The second is that the edger is much less likely to come out of the "groove" now, in heavier going.I will be purchasing this type of blade from now on.

This product is composed of 100% corn meal gluten.  Corn meal gluten is a non-selective pre-emergent herbicide which also has naturally occuring nitrogen as well, so it makes it a great product to put on your lawn in the fall, BEFORE the weeds start growing.Being a non-selective pre-emergent herbicide means that it keeps ALL seeds from germinating.  This means that it needs to be applied to lawns that are already esablished, and care needs to be taken to not apply it where seeds have been planted which you want to grow.As a fertilizer, corn meal gluten is rated at N-P-K ratio of 9-1-0, or 10% nitrogen by weight.It should be applied at a rate of 20-40 lbs per 1,000 ft-sq.  Rates above 80 lbs per ft-square will interfere with the growth of healty plants and grass, so don't go above 40.  I used 20 and had good results.Corn meal gluten is not 100% effective either.  On first application, it is around 60% effective, but that goes up to a maximum of about 80% after multiple applications, about 4-6 weeks apart.Corn meal gluten needs to be watered lightly after use and allowed to dry after, so don't apply it if rain is forecast before the lawn can dry.It must also be said that if you already see weeds growing in your lawn, it is too late for this product, at least as a weed killer.  It will still prevent more weeds from germinating, and it will fertilize the soil, as well as helping to make future applications more effective.So, you will still see some weeds with this product, but because you are not damaging the soil, and are making your lawn healthier, there will be fewer weeds just due to the thicker grass.Another thing to take note of is that this often can be found at feed stores and is finding its way into the nuseries and other places that carry lawn care products.  It generally goes for half the price at sources other than Amazon...  That said, if I can't find a local source, I will be purchasing it from Amazon again.

I really can't vouch for any of the claims that are made for this product except that applying it as directed worked to make my grass greener, thicker, lusher, and grow faster.I have a 3 year old lawn on poor topsoil in a new development.  I have been using only organic products such as Dr Earth Supernatural Lawn Food, Medina Hasta Gro, and corn meal gluten.  I also use a Toro Super Recycler mulching mower so my fertilizer is not thrown out with the clippings, and I cut the lawn tall.  My lawn has steadily improved in appearance and health since I started using these products.  I use much less water than my neighbors to keep my grass looking healthier.That said, it never consistently had that lush green look.  There were areas that had it, and areas that did not, but it was not until I tried measuring my soils moisture content that I realized how hard the soil was.I originally bought a quart to use on high traffic areas of my lawn and give the rest a light dose.  It worked well enough for me to get another gallon to repeat a month later.  I put a half-gallon down next over the entire yard and was rewarded with a greener lawn in less than a week and was needing to mow it more often.  I was also able to cut back on the amount of water I was putting on it.There were still spots that were not as nice as the rest, so I hit those spots and wound up overdoing it, as those spots are now much greener and the grass is denser and faster growing.  The grass is denser than I've ever seen in those areas.  It is simply amazing to me what this liquid is doing.  It has a much more pronounced effect than any other product I have used.  I am guessing that at least part of this is due to the fact that I have been applying fertilizer as directed, and that the fertilizer is now being used more effectively as the soil health improves.I plan on putting down the rest as a very light application on the rest of the lawn and hope that will get me to consistancy.I am very happy with this product and will be ordering more for next spring.

The original battery that came with my Samusung Moment lasted over a year, before shortened run times caused me to seek a new battery.I ordered one of these, and Received it at the end of March.  A month ago, I got a pop-up that the battery was not approved, and these messages began popping up more and more frequently, so that now,  they are popping up every few minutes, and if I don't notice, it locks the phone up.I sent the vendor, Wirester, a message about it, and was told there is nothing they can do.Guess I'll just pony up the money for a Samsung battery.

“Cop Car” is not a movie with a huge scope. In fact, it’s quite the opposite. Like so many of my favorite films, it takes place between a few select characters and depicts a single incident or situation that sets them all off. These kinds of movies tend to give the audience tons of room to interpret their own meaning. They aren’t often rich in character development right off the bat. We have to learn about these characters as the situation evolves, and that can be the most exciting thing as a viewer. This film is no different.It opens very suddenly with two young boys wandering in the fields of Colorado who find an inconspicuously parked cop car. Them being daring kids with nothing to lose, they hop in and set in motion both the vehicle and Kevin Bacon’s character after them (the sheriff who’s up to some shady business in the isolated area). He needs the contents of the car, which will most definitely incriminate him if in the wrong hands, and the boys need to satisfy their boredom in a huge way. What begins is an engaging interplay between the two as everything unfolds.It’s not a flawless film, instead embracing a ‘B-movie’ quality that’s meant only to thrill and entertain us. The skillful direction from Jon Watts goes a long way, and it’s obvious that he takes real care with his actors. Kevin Bacon as the sleazy, immoral cop is worth the price of admission alone, but he’s certainly not the only thing keeping this film together. The recognizable character actor Shea Whigham, along with the two boys played by Hays Wellford and James Freedson-Jackson, deliver solid support. It’s simple filmmaking, but effective in every sense.
