Very nice. Easy rinse! I hate when it's late and I'm getting ready for bed and the soap won't come off my face in the sink. By the time I feel rinsed the floor is full of water. Now I have to clean the floor. Now I'm wide awake. Not this product. Cleans well, and rinses clean also.
Very cute! You have to fluff the hair when it arrives. Purchased as one of the plush Despicable Me characters for my Grandtwins. Seems well made.

This cream has a really wonderful consistency on the skin. Many vitamin face creams with coconut oil and vitamin E are heavy and greasy on the face. When you open the jar, it is very thick, so I thought another heavy greasy cream, but no! Very silky and light on the skin. Soothing. Soft. Good ingredients. Very nice!

WOW! These are so nice! Very pretty and feminine. Waited till they were washed and worn before I wanted to review. I'm 5'6" and weigh 125. I carry my weight evenly. I normally wear a size 4 or 6 misses, or a 5 junior in pants. I always wear a size 7 in underpants, and so it is what I ordered with these. The size is right on. Not too tight, not too loose. Perfect. I machine washed on warm gentle, and machine dried on low gentle, and they came out perfectly, no pilling, or wrinkles, or shrinkage. They don't ride up. The top doesn't fold over. They don't settle in any cracks, and they don't show under clothing. Just a note, the "pink dot" color shows as a pink beige. They are a pink beige, the dot is only on the edging on the inside of the leg opening. I am back for more! I really love these!

This is a good price for this size. Vitamin D is known as the sunshine vitamin, and is known for being a necessary vitamin for your bones and teeth, but it is also for your hair and skin! I purchased this to mix with my shampoo, and bath soap.

I purchased this and the spray by the same company. I used the spray first and the itching stopped, so have not needed to use this product yet. I think that this is a good company, and knows what they are doing with our pets. If this works as well as the simple spray, then I'm very impressed.The spray is : SynergyLabs Veterinary Formula Clinical Care Antiseptic & Antifungal Spray for Dogs and Cats; 8 fl. oz.
This company knows what it is doing! Stopped the itching and scratching in moments! Also purchased the shampoo, but haven't found that I need it as this product is impressive!
Very concentrated, but when mixed smells like a forest. Very nice.
Large! Cute! Purchased for my Grandtwins along with others. Seems well made.

Make no mistake, these are not superb.  However, these are good headphones with a clean sound.  The build quality is good too, considering the low price.  These are the headphones you can take on a trip with you for the kids, or even yourself, and not have to worry about losing or breaking them, but they'll still make it enjoyable to listen.

I used this on a 6 cylinder car with 150,000+ miles on it.  It hasn't been cleaned in a while, so I thought I would give it a try since I trust the 3M brand very much.I have not noticed a huge improvement, but I have noticed some.  The engine is a bit more responsive.  I'm going to run another bottle through it to see if I get even more gains.

These placemats are pretty nice for the price.  They are a good size and the pattern and design color go well with many color palettes.  They washed well and feel like they'll last for quite a while.Stains from food (pasta sauce) came out easily too.

I'm no stranger to Streamlight.  If you are, you don't know what you're missing.  I've been using their products 20+ years.  Nearly every light they make is built to endure for years and years.  (Their knucklehead light being the glaring exception).This little powerhouse is a rechargeable version of the Stylus Pro.  It's  small, pen style flashlight that fits nearly anywhere.  Mine came with the AC/DC adapter, which puts out 5V 1A.  The light is very bright and the clicker on the bottom has very solid action.The clip prevents it from rolling on a flat surface.The only thing that I didn't like --and it wasn't even enough to deduct one star-- is the sliding cover for the USB.  Although it slides smoothly, if you hold it by the sleeve and bump up against anything, it does have movement.  I would have preferred a more solid, snap lock at the full closure of the sleeve or maybe a twist and lock mechanism to prevent accidental movement.  Nonetheless, it's a small annoyance that occurs seldom.I still love it.

While I have tried about a half dozen brands of LED bulbs, I have never tried Kobi.  Although some bulb have a dark spot in them (Cree), others have a delayed start (G7) or have funky looking casings (Philips and GE).  The Kobi has none of these problems.To my surprise, I found an aesthetically pleasing --both in shape and light color-- bulb that distributes light easily across a room.  It turns on instantly and feels very well made.  Unless you see it before it turns on, you'd never know it wasn't incandescent.  The nice design also allows it to be placed in a coach light, ceiling fan, or other light with pleasant results.5 stars *****

Love this cord.  We have the gold iPhone 6 and it perfectly compliments the color.  It is well made of Belkin high quality materials.  I don't see this wearing out for a long time.  The 4' cord is a perfect length too!

I love horchata.  I drink it a lot a restaurants.  I also love energy drinks.  This drink, in spite of the high price and high calories, sounded like a dream come true.I received the drink and chilled it.  I decided to replace my morning coffee with it one day.  The consistency is there.  The flavor was not good.  Although it is sweetened with sugar, it had a bad aftertaste --some would call it a 'twang'-- like a cheap, nasty piece of sugar-free candy.  I wasn't able to finish it, so I shared the remainder with a friend of mine.  He said the same thing.I found the pick me up wasn't there at all.  Given how expensive these are, I would rather have a Monster, Red Bull, Rock Star, or almost anything else besides this.

This is my second Wilson cellular amplifier.  My other one was contained in a dock for an iPhone.  I found the installation requirements for this to very particular.  I thought I could get away with a bit of adjustment, but I got no signal improvement when I did that.So, I installed the antennas exactly as directed and I was able to pick up an extra bar.  I personally felt it should have been more than that.  Another thing I was not overly happy with is the distance from the inside antenna you have to be.  You have to be very close to it.. like 18" close.  This could be an issue for those who put their phones in cradles on the dash or even in the console.  You lose the benefit very quickly.  I even lost my 'extra bar' several times when switching from my left ear, which was closest to the inside antenna, to my right ear.  I really felt it should be more sensitive than that.If you are able to live with those quirks, then this is for you.

I've never used a Wilton product before, but I'm quite impressed.  I got this vise so I could use it with our aerial lift in the field.  We commonly have rods, tie downs, pipe, and other needs where one hand --or even another person-- just won't do.This vise has some serious bite to it.  It's been able to hold whatever I throw into it... from 3" steel pipe to tie down rods.  It tightens smoothly and I like the pull out handle so you can rotate it if you have something in the way where the handle won't rotate 360 degrees.It's got a bit of chipping in the paint, but so will any vise you buy if it it put into field use.  With the fit and finish of the product body and movement, as well as the quality materials, it should last a long time.  I'll be sure to update if it doesn't.As a side note, the bench mount clamp does have a bit of play in it when the vise is mounted in it.  However, given the numerous positives they overcame my impulse to deduct a star for it... but I thought I would mention it.

This is a very good printer.  I have used dozens of B&W and color laser printers at work but never could afford one for home.  Having this at the house to print up business brochures or the occasional card or certificate has been a joy.I have found that HP has greatly improved their Windows software.  It's not buggy or clunky anymore.  This also has CUPS support for you *nix people.It prints quickly and beautifully except for photo paper.  I found my inkjet still has holds the crown on photos.  However, using bright white presentation paper produced very good photos too.The scanning is fairly good.  I would get an occasional skewed paper when scanning multiples through the ADF.  I'm not sure why.  I'm also not sure why there's no duplex tray.  Sorry folks, you'll have to flip your pages manually in the ADF.Faxing is quick and painless... toner costs are acceptable.  The airprint works flawlessly and the direct WiFi print is great to have too.I really like this printer, but it has the following minor annoyances.  I knew most of these going into it though.*  No duplex ADF*  Memory not upgradeable (256MB)*  No memory card option*  No manual sheet feed (envelopes, photo paper, etc. must be put in the tray)Overall, I really like this printer and I would recommend it if you are okay with the above.

This is my third portable A/C (2nd De'Longhi).  They all still work, I just have two offices and the garage to cool.  The other De'Longhi is the PACC120E and the other A/C is another brand.  This is by far the best one out of them all, heating functionality aside.Also others may think this is a large unit, it's actually smaller than the A/C only units.  The unit is more quiet than the others both in operation and cycling of the compressor.  (The other De'Longhi actually has a louder 'clank' when cycling).  I found it cools very quickly even though it is is much more quiet.The dehumidifier works well and the heater will keep you warm.  The thermostat goes up to 81 degrees, so if you want it warmer than that, I don't know what to tell you.The unit is stylish, well made, and the LCD display has a very nice contrast, so it's easy to see.  With the programmable timer and different fan speeds, this unit does it all.My only negative, which seems to be a common theme with De'Longhi units, is the vents are not movable.  I didn't really need to move them to get the temps I wanted, but I like that option.  My other A/C has movable vents, so you can direct the heat away from a plant or something or you can direct the A/C at you if you want.Nonetheless, I really love this unit.  It's the best one I own.

This timer is useful for anything from lights, to sprinklers, to various electronic gadgets.  No matter what your reason, be it to make the house appear occupied, or to give that problematic electronic device a nightly reboot, this will suit your needs.It has dual outlets, which can power a TV or radio and a lamp in a room.  It also has buttons that are fairly easy to push for those who hate mashing on those small ones.  The buttons do not give tactile feedback, so you'll need to keep an eye on the display for your results.  Speaking of display, this one is 'pretty good'.  I would have preferred larger digits or a backlight, but it is quite readable.When it operates it is nearly silent.  Many timers have a click noise to them.  This one is so quiet you can plug it in next to your bed if you want to automatically power a fan or something and then kick off.I have used it several times now and I really like it.  I will post an update on the durability at a later date, but I don't expect that to be an issue.  I have used the mechanical Intermatic timers before and they last forever.  Even though it's digital, it should be fine.Wish list:* A tad bit more responsiveness after pressing the button.  It's not slow by any means, but it's not as 'instant' as I'm used to with other consumer devices.* Capability to operate outlets independently.For the price point, this is a great timer.  I recommend it.

I ordered this phone for an aging relative who has never had a cell phone before.  I wanted something they could easily use to call in case of a medical emergency.I received the phone already programmed for some other area code.  It didn't make sense to me that the area code would not match my mailing address.  I also wanted a number that was local.  I emailed tech support and asked for a local number and assistance with activating my phone.  The website said 24-48 hours for email support response, but I found it was 36-48 hours at the minimum.  After 4 contacts back and forth with email support, I was forced to call.The phone rep (state-side) was very polite and was able to get my situation fixed immediately.I tested the phone a couple of times when I accidentally dialed the emergency operator. One time they answered almost immediately and the other time I hung up thinking I beat the operator, but they called back to make sure I was okay.In spite of the slow email response, the great phone support and prompt operator response gave me confidence in giving this to my relative.He likes the phone and is able to navigate the menus easily.  The "Yes" and "No" options make it extremely easy.

Having shoulder problems for years has gotten me familiar with physical therapy.  One of the most common techniques is the use of a TENS machine.  The stimulation, combined with heat, exercise, and cool down has always helped.  I have the exercises down, but could never replicate the TENS stimulation, until now.This is an inexpensive device that offers good build quality, a wide range of programs, and replacement pads that are acceptable in price.  The pads stick well and the directions for use are clear.  It will save me money by avoiding physical therapy when I have a flare up.

Having about a half dozen smart home products in the house, I wanted to try this one out to see how it fares against the front runners in this category.I found the setup to be extremely simple.  I didn't have to create any online account or even try to connect via WiFi to the device.  It found it and began controlling it automatically.  There's something to be said for easy setup!I have been able to control the device on WiFi and via cellular without issue.  It's very easy to set up a schedule for it too.One thing you should realize is this is simply a remotely controlled outlet.  Nothing more really.  It doesn't integrate with other services or anything like that.I feel the marketing is a little misleading as two of the four functions they advertise for it are essentially the same function.  (e.g. "Anti-theft timer" is the same thing as "schedule".... you're scheduling a time for the outlet to turn on/off.I also wish it was a different color.  I won't put this where it's visible since it stands out so much.I also think it's priced a bit on the high side.  For around $5 more, you can get a Wemo outlet and integrate it with other services and really maximize its functionality.  That said, the Wemos tend to be a bit more finicky.  So, it you want just a remotely controlled plug that you can schedule or count down --one that works everytime-- then this one is it.

This is a nice unit.  I have a several of them (Koldfront, Delonghi, etc.) and this one is pretty good.  It is definitely the most stylish one, but as far as cooling, I rank it as 'pretty good'.I have to say I'm not a fan of the dual exhaust.  I did not find it to be advantageous to have dual exhaust over a single exhaust.  (Both 5" and 6").  It gives me two hoses to deal with and since I vent it out of the of the garage wall, it took a little ingenuity to adapt it to the 4" x 10" exit hole.I really do like the 3M antimicrobial filter.  I come in contact with enough germs at work and through my kids.  I don't need any help.  It is moderately quiet.  It doesn't have that loud clang that other A/C units have when the compressor kicks on/off.I also like the backlit display. (Not that I'm running around with the lights off, but it does help visibility from a distance).Overall, I give it 4 stars.  I took away one star for the dual exhaust.  I don't like that part.

I was a bit hesitant of the claims of these headlights.  So I did a before test night drive and an after test night drive through the same area so the memory would be fresh.I first did the test night drive around 9pm.  I went over hills, through open areas and city streets, and through more rural areas with roadside trees/shrubs.  I also parked approximately 5 and 20 feet away, facing a wall to see how much of a difference it made.I then switched out the headlights which were very easy to do on my Toyota Camry.  I had been using stock, OEM bulbs.I then did another test drive.  WOW.  What a difference these can make!  They are a bright white light.  Not yellow and not blue.I immediately noticed during my drive that I could see further out in front of me than before.  I also noticed that the flood spill was significantly more.  This gave me better peripheral view to see the edges and shoulders of the road.  It was even more apparent in the rural areas where the light was shining outward onto the shrubs, grass, etc. on the side of the road.  I drove past many cars and no one flashed their brights at me, so I don't think anyone will have a problem there.I really like these and it actually makes me feel better knowing I can see more at night.  I would recommend these to everyone.  I'm getting a set for a family member who has poor to fair night vision.  This will help them alot!  I'll update with her comments too.GE REPS:  I almost deducted a star because mine arrived with the bulbs loose in the packaging.  Somehow they can come loose from their mounts during transit.  However, I love these so much I'm keeping it 5 stars.

Easy to install automatic flusher keeps your hands clean.This Kohler touchless kit is a really neat device.  The directions were very easy to follow (not that they were really needed) and installation took about 15 minutes.  It offers a plug to cover the handle hole if you remove it or you can install it and keep the handle too in case you have an old school person in your family that doesn't want to use the 'new technology' stuff.I'm very happy with it and will get more for the other toilets too.

One would think that after 20 years of internet, we would get less junk mail.  Unfortunately, we don't.  A lot of these are credit offers and such, so we like to shred those.  We usually have to take those to another area in the house where the main shredder is located.Fortunately for us, Swingline has come out with a very nice, compact shredder that can power through almost all of the junk mail at one time.The crosscut pattern is sufficient security for our needs.  The small footprint of the shredder allows us to place it under the sink.  Then when we come in from getting the mail, we shred away!I like the compact disc shredding.  I removed the shredded CD 'basket' because it took up too much room in the main basket area.  I just let them fall into the paper shreds and it gives me more room.It's fairly quiet as far as shredders go and it's easy to empty.  I really like it.

If you're like me, you always like to be prepared.  That is why I ordered the PhysiciansCare 99 piece kit.  After receiving this kit, I can say that it is a good quality kit that will do well in your office or in the trunk of your car banging around.  I also like that it is wall mountable.  That said, I felt like there should have been a bit more in there for the price at which it sells... and there is plenty of room for extra.Adding a few packets of hydrocortisone and maybe a cold compress would make this a winner.

The SKLZ Quickster Chipping Net is overall a very good and efficient golf accessory. It's easy to set up and can be disassembled quickly. Not to mention it doesn't take up much room once stored in the carry bag. The three different target locations allow for good aiming points from different yardage and types of chipping. Only one small drawback, the fabric can sometimes give around the edge of the chipping holes. Overall, this is a good golf accessory to have around the house in order to work on your short game.

I own two other laser measurers (both Bosch), so my experience with these will be contrasted against this.I run coax and cat5 cables, do basic cabinet installs, and paint.  I use laser measurers often to estimate jobs.  Using this device, I found the quality of it to be adequate.  It's not bad and it's not great.  The buttons feel a little cheap.  The instructions were obviously written by someone whose first language is not English.  They should improve that.  The grammar and format are fair, at best.The backlit screen provides a great contrast for viewing the screen, although the fractions may be a bit small for some.  My operation of it found the device responsive and very accurate when checked against a tape.The interface of the device could use a bit of work.  The calculator function, as well as other functions can be a bit clunky.  Review of the manual will be necessary as its not as intuitive as you think.Overall I am fairly please with it.  However, I found it to be a bit high in price for what it offers.  I prefer the Bosch and a phone calculator, but if you would like to have an all-in-one, this would be it.

I wasn't sure what to think about this when I first saw it.  However, my inner-geek felt like it would be something fun I could do with my son.  I'm so glad we got it.The packaging reminds me of Apple quality.  They didn't skimp.  The box is very sturdy and can serve as its storage container for years to come.I unboxed everything and read the directions.  Installing the app was simply and it easily found all of the cars.  I like the fact it can update the firmware of the cars via the iOS app.  That makes life simple.It took us a bit to get the hang of it, but before you know it we were racing like crazy and upgrading armor and weapons.  The cars last a while on a single charge and they recharge quickly, getting you back into the action fast.The technology behind this still amazes me.  These cars are able to maneuver around you, skid off the track when killed, and even pull into the winner's circle if they win.We play all of the time and his friends come over and have fun with it too.  I love it.

This is my second portable A/C, but my first DeLonghi brand. I got this for my office area due to computer heat issues.The package arrived fairly dinged up and one strap busted, but everything seemed to be intact.  (BE SURE TO WAIT 24 HOURS AFTER RECEIVING BEFORE TURNING IT ON.)After the 'settling' period, I was cooling down my office in no time.  I love the timer feature because I can set the temp and then the timer for 9 hours and it turns off right after I leave work, so it saves money by not running all night.  I was going to buy a digital timer or a Wemo plug, but that feature saved me some $$.It's not the quietest A/C I've seen and it's not the loudest.. it's kind of medium in loudness when running.  I can have a conversation with someone while it's running, but if there is a need to keep our voices down, I turn it off for a bit as it can be a little bit hard to hear.  It sits about 6 feet from my desk.I took off one star for two reasons.  1)  The vent is not adjustable.  It simply aims out.  2) When the compressor kicks off it has a somewhat loud knock or clank.  It shouldn't have such a hard 'off' cycle.  Nonetheless, I am very happy with it so far.

Belkin did well with the design of this.  I use one to hold my iPad 2 as a Spotify tablet.  It is steady as I swipe across the screen choosing playlists or songs.The non-slip material holds them in place and it is wide enough to accommodate a tablet inside of a case.  No removing the case if you just want to stand it up for a while.Simplicity and functionality have the perfect relationship with this little guy.  I highly recommend it.

Overall I was very pleased with the system.  The contents were well packaged and everything was included to install the system.Cameras -  Camera cables were 60 feet in length and were long enough for my application.  The aiming adjustment system for each camera were easy to adjust and makes it where it is easy to aim and will work in virtually any application.  The camera housings are metal, not plastic and seem to be well made and rugged.  The PTZ camera came with an arm mount and a ceiling mount.  The housing was metal and very sturdy.Recorder – Very easy to set up and get going.  All cables, for different applications, were included.  The instruction  guide was awesome!  It was very easy to read and understand and included screenshots for each step of the way.  The system comes with a mouse so all you had to do is follow along and click.Performance -  Cameras have great coverage with their 59 degree arc with little or no distortion.  Images are very sharp and identifiable.  The IR throws plenty of light out to an advertised distance of 85 feet.  I’m able to get every bit of that with mine and the image is still nice and sharp.The recording ability is motion activated.  An icon appears on the picture frame of your monitor indication which camera has been activated and is recording.  During testing, the activations triggers quickly, as soon as there is movement in the frame.Playback is a breeze, using the provided mouse and screen icons and menus.The iPhone app works great and it was has novel way to transfer the settings from your DVR to the app... just scan a QR code!  The settings then appear in your app and you're good to go.  The web app worked with IE, Firefox, and Chrome.  Unfortunately, you have to be an admin on the computer to install the web software.  I really wish they had a MJPEG push option for viewing so you could at least see what's going on without having to be an admin.One more picky thing I would improve on is the type of screw they use on  the camera angle adjustment.  It is a very small Phillips head screw.  One of the cameras had this screw tightened down pretty tight and was difficult to get out without stripping the shallow head out.  I think an Allen head screw would work better and less likely to strip out the head is torqued down tight.  Also, an Allen head screw can be tightened more easily and it can be reached more easily in tight spaces or against a wall with an Allen wrench verses a screwdriver.Overall I am more than please with the system, its capabilities and performance.

I primarily bought these because they said "Made in USA".  I try to buy American made when I can.  However, these are awful.  The cotton/fiber absorbent material is not evenly spread across the pad.  This leaves bare spots with no absorbent material.  Most of them were like that and I was not able to use them because urine pooled in those areas.As an FYI, they don't have adhesive tape on the back either, so the pet can easily bunch them up when moving on it.I threw them away.

After spending time in the Southwest, especially in Tornado Alley, I purchased an Eton emergency radio.  While I did love it, the features of this Midland have caused me to switch to this as my primary emergency radio.The radio is very versatile, running off of a rechargeable battery, regular AA batteries, solar charging, or crank charging.  There's simply no reason to have a dead radio with all of these power options.The display is easy to read and the local stations came in very clear with the digital tuning.  (My Eton had manual tuning).  I even got down into the storm shelter and closed the steel door and could pull in signals quite well.The LED light is plenty bright to light your way around.  In the small shelter, it gave us a good amount of light to read by or see each other very clearly.A unique feature I've not seen before is the dog alert.  It's an ultra-high pitch tone that is similar to a dog whistle.  It is supposed to indicate to rescue dogs that you're located in a rubble or a storm shelter.  I tried it on my dog and I got that 'head-cocked-to-the-side' look like "what's that noise?".The USB charger works as advertised, but I would only use it to power up your phone enough to call out.  Save the juice for your radio, SOS beacon, or dog whistle.I'm very pleased with this radio.  The included case makes it perfect for the trunk or the storm shelter.  I definitely recommend it.

I used these on both faux stainless steel as well as regular stainless steel and I had very good results with both.  I like the fact the wipes are sealed in a bag inside the tub.  It keeps them from drying out when sitting in the store.  This stuff is pretty oily, but it buffs out and looks great.  Smudges have been reduced as well.I'll try other Tub O Towel products.  I hope to have the same excellent results.

I really wanted to like this!!  I got this device not so much as a 'wallet tracker' as a general 'stuff' tracker.  I was considering putting it on my son's iPad case because he's always losing it.  Unfortunately, I never got to that point.  I am VERY well versed in iOS operation as well as Bluetooth procedures such as pairing, etc.When first putting it together, the instructions say to never fully pull out the battery tray.  I imagine this is because the tray fits in upside down or right side up... if you happen to drop the battery tray, as I did, you run a 50/50 chance of putting the tray in correctly.  They should have printed or cast something on the tray to avoid this issue.The iOS app is pretty clean and easy to navigate.  It took me a few tries to discover the trackr.  After getting it paired to the phone, I found the option to turn off 'separation alerts' did not work.  Even in the off position, I would get alerts for getting too far away.  I tried this several times, to no avail.To stop the separation alerts, I had to remove the batteries from it over the weekend. After putting them back in after the weekend, I found out the phone and wallet trackr had forgotten their pairing.  I'm not sure why.I was never able to get the device paired again.  The app would hang on the 'connecting' screen (longer than 20 min) or would not find the device at all.  I finally gave up.  I wished this worked as advertised... it would be extremely useful.

There's not a whole lot to write about a dry erase board. That said, I'm very happy with the board.  It is the perfect size, comes with multiple mounting options (I wish velcro was included) and the marker writes smoothly on the surface.It's just what we needed for our 'to do list'.  Recommended!

I have to say I was extremely disappointed with this grill.  I have owned several brands, from cheap to nice, and this one falls short of the Hamilton Beach standard in my opinion.  I've had great luck with other items of theirs, but the grill I received was damaged in several places and poorly packed.COSMETICALLY:  Large dents in the edge of the left door kept me from closing it initially.  The side panel and the frame that holds the main grill box were dented.  Where the lid handle was mounted to the lid appears to have been ground with a rough surface around 1" of the hole, then painted over.  The shipping box didn't really show any damage which leads me to believe the packing system isn't sufficient.ASSEMBLY:  The instructions are pretty straightforward, with  many diagrams.  It took me about an hour or so to assemble everything.  However, several of the threaded nuts that are pressed into the sheet metal stripped out.  They would just spin with the screw halfway into it, so I couldn't back the screw out or tighten it.  Other than that, the assembly went well.FUNCTIONALLY:  After assembly, I was able to fire the grill up very easily.  It took about 10 minutes or so to get to searing temp.  I cooked some burgers and some hot dogs and all went well with that. There's ample room to move around with a large spatula or tongs.  I tried to cook some beans on the side burner, but the wind kept blowing the flame out. Granted, it was a moderately windy day, but I was on the patio.  I gave up on that after a few tries and used the stove.QUALITY:  I was not impressed with the quality of this grill.  Although the finishes are nice, the metal is extremely thin and bends very easily.  I would take a sturdier grill over the fancier finish.  I was also disappointed that the towel bar (described in instruction assembly) was missing.Hamilton Beach can and has done better than this.  I hope they improve the quality and shipping/packing.

As an IT admin, I've had my share of situations where I had to IPCONFIG /RELEASE /RENEW, etc. time after time... then plugging my laptop in, doing it on that, trying to determine cable or port failure, etc.I came across the LinkSprinter and my IT world has changed.  Fluke has done a remarkable job putting together the all of the essentials for diagnosing basic network failures.  I've used it many times without having to bust out my laptop.  I can determine whether it's a gateway failure, internet service, LAN failure, and more.  What a time saver... and with Fluke, I know it'll last virtually forever.I cannot review the cloud service as I don't use it.  I simply join the LinkSprinter WiFi and touch the shortcut to it's web server on my iPhone home screen.  BAM!  Instant results.I highly recommend this tool.  IT peeps will love it.

If you don't already have a device for detecting primary or secondary line voltage, this is one you should consider.  I've used it numerous times lately and I'm still amazed at how well it works.  It doesn't matter if you're testing a three phase drop, a couple of 240V cans, or whether you've got it on a hot stick detecting primary voltage, it should suit you well.The case clips on the tool belt or bag for easy access.  The volume is sufficient to hear over bucket hydraulics or up high on a hot stick.  The LED is bright for night time use too.Quality matters when your life depends on it.Highly recommended.

I've never tried a Volo brand before, but I decided to take the chance and give my Camry a little more pep.  Considering the cost difference over other chips, I figured any improvement would be worth the money.  Volo's website has a chart that gives you expected HP improvement for your particular vehicle.Installation was pretty straightforward.  You basically have to splice into four of the OBD2 diagnostic port wires.  Unfortunately, these wires can be very fragile and I didn't have much slack in mine to 'splice' into.  So, I found a 'splice adapter' which extends your wires by about 6" and I spliced into those instead.  It made install MUCH easier, giving me the slack to work with and I didn't have to worry about accidentally chopping a factory wire.  I got it from the website OBD2POWERPLUG (add .com to the end).After installing it I fired up the car and got all of the LED indications that showed it was working.  I put it all together took it out for a spin.  After hitting the floor at about 35MPH, I was able to break the tires loose.  I was not able to do that before.  I noticed it appeared to hold its shift a little longer too.  The shifting was not any harder like you experience with some chips or tranny shift kits.I waited the recommended 125 miles to see if it 'learned' improvements, but I didn't notice any difference between first start and the 125 mile mark.Overall I am very happy with this chip.  It's nice because it is streetable and allows 'normal' driving without high RPMs or hard shifts, but it gives you a good boost when you want it.

I got this keyboard for my iPad Air due to the numerous emails and searching I have to do for work.  This thing is a speed demon.  It has great response time after typing and it stays put on the table... even at angle... due to rubber feet.  It holds the iPad well when it is in the slot.I think it protects it well and it is easy to remove (using two hands).  The battery holds a very long charge, even after repeated use, and Kensington has programmed the most useful keyboard functions into hotkeys.  I love it!If anyone from Kensington is reading these, I have a couple of suggestions.  Nothing big, but just a thought.One end has a lightning port cutout and the other end has a hole for earphones. Why not have both cutouts on both sides so it can be placed into the case either way?The other thing that would be neat is a combo cable with microUSB and Lightning.I'm extremely happy with this.

Having used Miralax for a long time, with great results, I was happy --yet hesitant-- to find a less expensive alternative.  I found the Good Sense Clearlax to work just as well.  It mixes and dissolves perfectly just like the brand name.  I'll no longer have to spend as much money for my health.Definitely get if you need a regular laxative.

I've used Fluke, Extech, and other brands of multimeters for 20 years.  The Amprobe ACD-14 combines the functions of several into the convenience of one.Whether you're a DIYer installing an extra outlet at the house, or an HVAC tech testing capacitors or motor amperage, this tool will serve you well.  It has the following pros and cons in my experience:PROS:1.  Auto ranging.  No more choosing!2.  Comfortable to hold/easy to grip with greasy hands.3.  Small clamp head can get into tight spaces.4.  Dual display for voltage and amperage.  SWEET!5.  Many features in one (microamps, capacitance, diodes, temp)6.  Nice, flexible leads.  Not too sticky either, so they don't snag on stuff.CONS:1.  Not backlit2.  Icons for function (e.g. AC, DC, etc.) are too small to read for older eyes.Overall, I'm very happy with this meter and I anticipate years of use.  I highly recommend it.  You won't be disappointed.

Got this for my daughter as a reward for good behavior.  She was SO excited and could not wait to get everything out of the package.  Of course, I had to put the Barbie DVD on the TV too.She spent the next couple of HOURS playing with this set and having a blast.  it is still the first thing she goes to when she comes home, even weeks later!  Now that's an accomplishment.You can't lose with this one.

To help organize my bird's nest of USB cables and wall worts (square DC power plugs), I decided to get the CHIL PowerShare Reactor.My concern about it charging my various items was soon alleviated.  I have an iPhone, iPad, Sony digital recorder, an Android phone and a Bose Bluetooth headset charging on this nightly.  I used to have problems with the Sony.  It wouldn't charge on just any charger.  However, whatever circuitry CHIL built into this works flawlessly.The fact you can wind up excess power cable into the bottom of it is great.  Couple that with the 1ft micro-USB and Lightning cables I use and it is night and day difference.Great product!

I have been using Kaspersky for several years and I've always been happy with their products.  KIS 2014 is amazing as well.  It provides a nicely finished product with a multitude of features that can be easily turned on or off.I really like the way they have designed the interface.  With two clicks, you can turn off features.  With three clicks, you can get as granular as you want with those features.  KIS always does well in independent anti-virus comparisons and it makes me feel safe that I can keep my computer, documents, photos, and kids secure.I would definitely recommend it.  They offer a 30 day free trial on their site if you want to try it out.

I have used several iPad keyboards before, but this was my first iPad Mini keyboard.  Kensington always puts out a good product, so I got this one.  It is very lightweight and it charged very quickly.  The keys had a good feel to them and the response time was excellent.  It also works excellent as a stand (on a flat surface).Unfortunately, I found it difficult to type.  I realize they're small, but I have medium sized hands and figured it would be okay.  I ended up typing incorrectly too often because I would hit multiple keys with one stroke.  I also found that while it offers great protection for your screen, it was difficult to unsnap from the iPad.I wish I could use it.  I do like it, but my hands are too big!  :o(

Aside from the 'gadgetiness' of this brush, my son was happy to have an electric toothbrush like his Dad's.  It actually makes him want to brush his teeth (for the most part).  It is aesthetically pleasing in his bathroom and feels well made.  The part I like the best is the audible timer.  I don't have to argue or keep track anymore.  It signals him to switch areas of brushing and it eventually goes for two minutes.  I liked the fact it works 'up' to two minutes of brushing over time. It didn't do it immediately.  Two minutes for a young one is eternity, but this allowed him to adjust.  Well done Philips!The only con I have is my son said he wished the head was a little smaller, but he said it wasn't a huge deal.

I thought this would be a fun gift for my son.  However, the design has changed and the instructions have not been updated or they are using new instructions with an old design.  (e.g. Instructions tell you to look for the + and - marked terminals on the motors, but they are not marked at all.)The suction cups are so cheap they don't hold it to any surface for long before the vibration begins to move it around the table.Additionally, the battery pack we got came with a broken switch.  No way to turn it on and off.  It just runs until you take out the battery.I would give this no stars if I could.

I can't remember the last time I had a problem with a 3M product.  They always do well with production and quality.  This screen protector is no exception.Installation was very easy and instructions were clear and concise.  I will note that it is bubble free because it does not fully touch the screen, so you have to press a little harder than normal on the screen, but you get used to it.Some people may not realize this is not an all in one privacy screen.  If you hold the iPad in landscape mode, people will be able to see from the side.  I wish it did both portrait and landscape, but it doesn't.I love it and I can surf at the coffee shop without worrying about the nosy neighbor at the next table.

I'm a gadget guy for sure, so this device is definitely down my alley.  I've also been curious about MPG and driving habits since gas prices began fluctuating significantly several years ago.  Automatic seemed to fill both needs, so I ordered it.Installation was very simple.  It automatically detected my car (Camry) and synced with my phone.Using the app I was able to program in up to three emergency contacts to text in case of an accident.  It sends them a text message asking for confirmation.  That is very reassuring.  It's kind of like a poor-man's OnStar.The device communicated well with the app.  It produced beeps during hard braking, fast accelerating, and other bad habits.  You can turn the audio warnings off.  I did find that it was not consistent in warning.  Sometimes I would intentionally take off as fast as I could from a stop and it would not do anything.  The same occurred with braking.The app takes a few seconds after you turn off the car for it to process your trip.  The GPS tracking did well as did the parking.I was disappointed that the Bluetooth 4.0 still used a lot of battery on my phone.  It caused me to charge it once per day when I did not have to do that before.  I don't drive that much either.The trip feature is neat and the cost estimation will make you think twice before just 'driving around'.  I liked it, but the erratic error recording and significant battery drain caused me to think it is just 'okay'.  If you can overlook these two obstacles, then this might be for you.

We ordered this game in hopes of keeping our kids a little more active.  Well, it's keeping ALL of us more active!UBI Soft has come through with a fun, exciting experience you can enjoy with people all around the world.  Have dance contests with other Wii U dancers from other countries.  We also have our own 'family dance night' contest.  Even though it requires you to follow the dance moves, it is generous enough the little ones can score decent too.Definitely order it if you want some dancing fun to popular songs.

This clamp was exactly what I needed for a recent framing project I had.  I'm no pro, but I do quite a few things myself.  I found this clamp very easy to use and it does not feel cheap. It grips very well and I think it will be very useful and last a long time.I like it so much I am looking at other Bora products now as well.  They quite obviously care about producing quality tools.

I already own a different Chamberlain opener and got the internet gateway with it.  I was easily able to intergrate it into the same account and I can now control both doors remotely.When Chamberlain first went public with the My Q site, it was not very reliable.  However, the past 6 months or so have been rock solid... No connectivity issues at all.  I really love the fact the internet gateway can tell you the current status of the garage door.  If you forgot to close it, just press the button and it's done.  It can also send a notification if the door is opened or closed and you can schedule what hours it will do that.As far as operation, this opener is smooth as can be... And so quiet!  The motion sensor built into the switch turns the light on and off. That is very nice so that I can tell if somebody has entered the garage.The installer said this was a great brand and was impressed with the feature set.  He said they are very easy to install.Overall, I'm extremely happy with this opener.  It's my second Chamberlain, so I definitely recommend them.

The WordLock Stor-More Key Storage box is very sturdy and very well built.  It has a good amount of room for securing small objects.  It provide a wall mount option or a door knob option that could be placed around a pole, bike frame, etc.I was actually quite impressed with it.  The only issue I was curious about was the word possibilities.  I visited their site and most of their WordLock products have only 2-3 dozen word possibilities.  If you used something common, chances are someone else would guess it too.  If you could try a word every few seconds, they could have your combo in a few minutes.I would suggest instead of using a word use the first letters in a phrase.  It makes it MUCH more difficult to guess then.  (e.g. Don't Take My Stuff = DTMS)Other than that, I very much like this product!

I ordered these for my 8 year old.  He wanted a pair of cool headphones and I wanted a pair that wouldn't blast his ears when he plays his iPod.We got them in and they were a no-brainer to use.  I like the volume limiting, so they satisfied Dad.  However, after the novelty or looking at himself in the mirror wore off (about 10 min) then they became just another set of headphones to him.  He'll occasionally look in the mirror or a friend will ask what he's listening to because of the beat, but most times he ignores that part of them.These are okay kid friendly headphones, but the novelty wears off quick.

This camcorder still amazes me and I've had it for weeks and used it dozens of times already.  The technology Sony has packed into this is incredible.The tiny size of this camcorder is great for large or small hands.  The buttons are easily accessible.  The touch screen icons could be a bit sensitive for larger fingers, but with a small LCD that's to be expected.It charges fairly quickly and the battery life is phenomenal.  The fact it turns on and off by simply opening the viewing screen is a very nice touch.  I really like that.It gives you various recording quality options when setting it up and the higher end modes shoot drop dead gorgeous video.  It has an 'internet' video mode for easily shooting clips for YouTube and other social media.The zoom is fantastic.  With the built in stabilization it is not a problem to zoom way out and still shoot quality video.The crowning jewel of this camcorder is the built in LCD projector.  It is not extremely bright, but it is plenty to show everything in a dark room and clearly see the video.  I hook up my Kindle Fire to it via HDMI and project Netflix and Amazon Video for family entertainment.  We like to lay out blankets and project it straight up on the ceiling and just lay back and relax.The camcorder is very responsive.  It doesn't lag when changing modes or turning off/on.The software installation was easy and it immediately updated to the latest version.  I am still getting used to Sony's memories software and using its features.If you can't tell already, I absolutely love this camcorder.  I would (and have) recommend it to anyone looking for a quality compact camcorder with entertainment value to boot.

This review is for the Boostcase Hybrid Battery case for iPhone 5.The face I spend hours a day on my phone caused me to look for a little help on the battery side.  I don't like having to charge twice a day.I ordered this from Amazon and it arrived promptly, of course.  The case has two pieces.  A snap on shell and the battery part.The snap on shell protects the phone well from bumps and low drops.  It's not a shock resistant case.  It has two small round discs that protrude slightly from the back and those lock into the channels on the battery part by fitting them in and sliding it up.The slightly tacky feel is great for not losing your grip on the phone, but it also make for a slightly unpleasant task if you try to separate the battery and case.  They grip together and it is not easily pulled apart.  Since the battery part is held on by friction, rather than a snap/clip process, I could see this wearing out over time and becoming loose.The snap on shell also has numerous holes in it for looks and these began to quickly fill with dust after repeated use in my jeans pocket.The battery does provide a boost and it charges fairly quickly.For the $70 price tag, I would have expected a little better.

Got this charger to replace the stock one I got with my iPhone 5.  It is very well made, I would say Apple quality, and the cord is a good length.It charged my phone up much faster than the stock A/C charger.  I could do without the neon green band around the charger, but functionality-wise, I could not be more pleased.Highly recommended!

The Belkin Wemo products have proven very versatile with the addition of If This Then That rules.  This switch saved me time and effort by allowing me to turn it into a dusk/dawn switch for my porch instead of having to install a photo cell in between the light and the switch.Using IFTTT.com rules, I have it set up to turn on at dusk and off at dawn.  However, can also program other options if we are on vacation, or I can remotely do it with the Wemo app.This compliments the Wemo outlet I bought about 6 months ago.  I love the Wemo stuff and can't wait for them to come out with more time saving devices.

I've had several inverters, from super cheap ones to the higher end true sine waves.  For what this inverter provides, it is well worth the money.  It is powerful enough for most needs and they provide both battery clamps and standard wires.The item is well built and cords plug into it and remove easily.  It has bright indicator lights so there is no question about what's going on.The fact it has 2.1A USB ports is great.  However, be aware that that is shared between both USB ports.  So you cannot charge two higher amperage devices, such as iPads, simultaneously.  You could, however, use the USB port for one and the AC charger for the other and that would solve it.  I don't really charge two at the same time, so it's never an issue.The included  mounting hardware make it a snap to put in.  I would recommend one for every car.  They can be life savers!

I liked this paper cutter.  It is heavy duty and most of it is well built.  The Microban protection is an added bonus.  When you chop paper it has great cutting action and doesn't move around when cutting.There were two things I did not like about this.  First and foremost, the board does have a safety catch to keep kids from raising the handle.  However, the plastic guard that covers the exposed blade edge does not come out far enough to keep small fingers from touching it.  Adult fingers would have great difficulty getting it, but my 3 year old has tiny fingers and the opening is wide enough for her to touch it.  If she ran her finger along it the edge, it would get cut.  That's significant and could have been easily remedied by making the plastic 'rib' that guards it extend out further.The second thing I was not crazy about was the paper guide.  It is plastic and snaps into place with two square pressure clips on the bottom of the guide.  It wobbles easily due to this and I felt they could have done better.I am satisfied for the most part, but I felt the blade guard issued should have been solved during design phase.

I own three other Bose headsets, so I am a little biased already.  No need to tell you about the phenomenal quality or incredible sound.  Their reputation is well known.What impressed me most about these is the noise cancellation.  It's quite amazing.  I spend a lot of time in the shop with large fans going and with these headphones on active, I hear nothing but music.  Nothing!  It's like I'm sitting in a library listening to my headphones.I also wore these out while mowing.  It did not completely block out the sound of my ZTR mower, but it made it sound like a little model airplane off in the distance.  What a great experience.  I always thought I would be limited to ear blocking headphones because noise cancelling was just not portable.  However, Bose has really advanced this technology and the rectangular plastic piece containing the circuitry is very light.The silicone ear pieces are similar to the other Bose headsets I have.  They are extremely comfortable, even after extended use, and they do not slip out during activities.I do have one small complaint about the design.  The headphone plug is a 90 degree plug... so when you plug it into the phone, the cord comes away from it at a 90 degree angle too instead of straight like most headphone plugs.  I didn't like that.  I think straight plug is more functional and puts less stress on the cord, but maybe Bose has already considered that.Nonetheless, I would not hesitate to get these headphones.  What an amazing piece of technology!

You know some things just don't go together... oil and water... Congress and approval ratings... and pets and carpet.  After we converted our 'outside' dog to an 'inside' dog, the carpet just didn't stay the same.  We vacuumed with our Dyson, but that doesn't do anything for the stains.  Between occasional accidents and dirty paws, we had to do something.  I have rented carpet cleaning machines from the box stores, but often times they were more nasty than the carpet.  Enter the Bissell DeepClean Premier Pet Upright Deep Cleaner... <whew>.The cleaner came mostly assembled and it was easy to finish out.  It came with a trial size of Bissell 2X cleaner which we liked very much.  A quick read of the directions and a fill with water and cleaner and we were good to go.  We focused on two high traffic areas in the living room.  The heated solution was able to lift the stains in a couple of passes.  It was amazing.  A more stubborn stain took a few passes, but pet tool cleaned it up well.  I found it easy to maneuver around objects in the house despite the large cleaning head.After several dumps of dirty water and a hair basket emptying, our floors were looking much better.  I did find small Lego end pieces in the hair basket and, to my son's delight, was able to rescue the little stowaways.It's amazing how much stuff gets brought into your house on shoes, boots, pets, etc.  However, with the DeepClean Premier, you can begin to feel clean again in your home.  We'll be getting some frequent use out of this between the kids and the pets.Well worth the investment!

There's not a lot you can say about a fabric folding chair.  However, everything I've got to say is good!  I've had several types of sports chairs and they weren't nearly as nice.  I've listed the best things I like about it below.PROS:*  Feet are large enough that they don't push into ground easily (I weigh 220lb)*  Umbrella blocks sun well AND does it with UPF 50.  Stands up to mild wind fairly well too.*  5 second fold out or fold up.  Easy.*  Leg support is comfortable, not cramped feeling as I expected.*  Sturdy, yet light.  Makes it easy for hauling to games.EH:*  Umbrella arm could be a little more sturdy, but it does the job.CONS:* NoneI will be getting another one of these for my wife.  She keeps stealing mine.  You should grab a couple too... they're a nice luxury to have at an event.

The covers I've been buying the last few years from the box stores are a single piece of plastic with an elastic around the bottom. They get brittle and crack after just a year. The one I have now is falling apart. Once you start using it a lot in the Spring it rips easily.This Classic Accessories cover feels more supple. It really is woven, not just stamped. And it's got a rubbery inner liner, like a good raincoat. It also has a storage bag attached to it. I cut that off - it isn't for me. We'll see how it fares after a Winter exposed to the elements. But so far I really like it. I think my local Stinkbugs will enjoy it too.

Did not work at all. Stayed latched in the permanent on position. This can often be the case with these cheap electronic items, so I also bought this: - Coromose Quality Automatic DC 12V-24V 8A Infrared PIR Motion Sensor Switch For LED light.It has an adjustable timer (1 - 10 min.). And it's about 1/2 the size. It's the one to get.

4:51 Mins Seems like an OK heater. Some assembly issues out of the box. It will get a better test this Winter. Call it 3 1/2 stars so far.Watch the video - if you have any questions, let me know.Thanks for watching.

What caught my eye was the 'permanent' adhesive. Masking tape tends so slip off after 6 months or a year on things like plastic storage boxes in the basement. We'll see how these hold up.These are intrended for crafty people doing craft things. I can't speak very well  to that aspect.I did go tho their website and try to download an Avery template for word or Photoshop. I easily found their online link to create my labels online with some cutesy drawing. But not one to download. So I followed the links to the downloadable templates page. Still no luck. You can't just enter the label #, you have to choose a category. It wasn't one of the categories.Then I acted impetuous and actually clicked on the "Need help using templates?  Learn how now..." button. It tells you to go to the Avery.com/templates page and enter your label #. I went there, and ... you can't do that. They must have changed the website. After a few more promising clicks, I was back to the page where I could search for MS Word templates - by category.Enough of that. If there is one, they've made it too hard to find.  I pulled out a ruler I made my own template.I was pleasantly surprised that the paper fed with no problems through my Brother HL2270 Laserjet. I was leery - a reviewer on the website was furious about having to buy a new drum.  I did inspect each label to insure that there were no curling corners.Bottom line - these are fine looking Krafty labels for the Crafty person.

Like others that received these through Vine, it is too early to report on their lifespan. I have found no online sources comparing them to other brands. Nor do I feel the need at this point to investigate further. Getting these has inspired me to learn more about Alkaline batteries than I ever thought I cared to know.I will now saddle up my High Horse.Did you ever see on the back of an aerosol can "No CFCs." They fail to mention that CFCs were banned decades ago in the US. But you think buying that can is good for the environment. That's one of the many ways that companies differentiate themselves falsely from their competition. It's taking advantage of peoples good nature, ignorance, and affection for symbolic gestures. With that in mind, let's take a look at these GoGreen batteries.I hate to burst the bubble of all those well meaning individuals that give these batteries such a glowing review because they're GREEN. GREEN, I tell ya! But here I go.Let's compare theses with Duracell and Rayovac, the 2 most popular brands. Since they have virtually identical specs, we'll group them together as OG (Other Guys). GoGreen will be GG.Claim.........................GG.............OGMercury Free..............Yes............Yes (for 20 years)Lead Free..................Yes............Yes (lead acid(car) batteries have lead)Cadmium Free............Yes............Yes (They're not Ni-Cads!)Made in USA...............Yes............YesRecyclable..................Yes............Yes (Sort of. See below.)Shelf Life....................6??............10  (GG just says best by 2021)Word GREEN on label ..Yes............NOGreen Color................Yes............NOAmerican Flag.............Yes............NOIf you don't have that flagpin on, you don't love America. GoGreen supports VetsCanDo. A quick glance at their website and they don't seem to do much. It was last updated 3 years ago.As for recycling, there just isn't much in an alkaline battery worth recycling. It's not the same as recycling single ingredient items like aluminum cans. They point out in their copy that nothing in the batteries is harmful to the environment. And they also state on their website that sending the batteries in has a carbon footprint. Sorting, transporting, separating and cleaning the different materials all have a carbon footprint. It may actually be worse for the environment.Marketing strategies like this may be common, but that doesn't make it acceptable. GoGreen batteries merit a 'Dishonorable Discharge'.Dismounting...

My review is based on comparing it with the 3M Speedglas 9100V (3M Speedglas Welding Helmet 9100 with Standard Size Auto-Darkening Filter 9100V- Shades 5, 8-13, Model 06-0100-10SW). I've had it for 5 years and it cost almost 3 times as much on Amazon.Both are almost exactly the same weight at about 20 Oz.The ADF lens on the Jackson is almost everything you could want. The lens is  2.36 x 3.9  vs. 1.8 x 3.7 on the 3M. Up close to your face, that little bit extra gives a much larger field of view. The LCD readout is easy to read and you know right where you're at. It's only shortcomings are no Lock in Dark mode, and only shade 4 is available in Grind mode. Minor drawbacks.When it comes to the helmet, that's a different story.First, it's a really soft plastic. No doubt it's durable, but it feels like you could cut it with scissors. In a welding environment, you don't always have just bright arcs. There's angle irons to run into, concrete to get drop-kicked on, sparks flying. My 3M helmet has protected more than my eyes.Which brings me to the 2nd point: Head coverage. The Jackson feels cramped. My ears actually touch the sides (and no, I don't have Dumbo ears). That's with the strap adjusted all the way out - the way I like it. With it in, my nose hits the lens. I wonder how it will do in really hot humid environments, as it feels so close in.I know I'm being picky here - just passing on my observations. It's not bad. The narrower profile might be preferable to some people. Any decent ANSI rated helmet will protect your eyes (stay away from those HF ones, you eyes are worth more than that). I would be less inclined to use this for grinding (See photo as to why). And If I welded all day for a living, I would spring for a more comfortable and sturdier option,

This thing is HUGE!. I wasn't paying attention really. I do make multiple loaves of bread at a time - it could easily proof 4 or 5  loaves. Or maybe 40 dinner rolls. Or you could carry around 50 lbs of tomatoes in it.It's got just enough flex that you feel like you can't crack it - ever. But it's real solid and seriously reinforced at the corners.It doesn't make sense to me that the lid is more expensive than the box. I didn't need a lid, but I might regret that later.If you need a large dough box, for whatever reason, this one will do the job.
Pretty much your standard test strip. What sets this apart is that every 10 strips are in their own foil pack. Much better shelf life. Especially if you have a little spill.

If you buy this thinking you're going to get any cooling effect from it, I have a bridge or 2 to sell you. A small desk fan needs about 100 watts minimum to give you a nice breeze. That would take a solar cell at least 30 inches square. So the first use for this is a lesson: that you don't need to know a lot of science to get by. But you should have some idea how to Google the right questions so you don't get duped.The second use for this is to give it to a kid about 5 or so. When he or she takes it out into the sunlight and it starts to spin, all kinds of curious and joyous neurons begin to fire. They don't need it to cool them, they have plenty of imagination to have it do whatever they want it to.For that- it's five dollars well spent..

If I really like something, I give it 4 stars.But I was just looking at my pasta pot and thinking how good it looked after at least 15 years. I had burned it a little browning onions and peppers in it. It cleaned up with BKF and looked almost brand new. I decided for fun to look it up on Amazon.The one I got from Costco years ago also included a steamer. I never use the strainer - I prefer to pour the pasta into a colander in the sink. But I've made a ton of pasta, Corn, soups, Clams, Mussels and small stews in this over the years. It still looks great.I have a few sturdy, large (up to 10 gallon) restaurant style cook pots. But this one really takes the most frequent abuse and shines like new.

After 4 years of throwing trash at this, it still looks great. The sensor is starting to act squirrelly, though. Time to get a new one a send this one to the basement.This is my 3rd one of these - 2 of them still in use. A few things I do to help the life of it:Oil the pin hinge occasionally to prevent rust.Take the top outside to wash it and air dry.Train people not to dump something nasty in it (like coffee grounds) when it's real full .I started composting last year, which I feel helps a lot.I do wish they would make one small improvement. A removeable/washable  plastic guard in front of the hinge and gear assembly would help extend it's life.

I've been a homeowner for years, and watched Orbit products go downhill. In the case of this manifold, the brass keeps getting cheaper, thinner and more brittle. My guess is they are reducing the copper content since it gotten more expensive.The machining gets sloppier. The 4 male ends have gone from 4 turns to 3. The edges are sharp instead of flat, so it cuts into the washer. I've had the threaded end snap off, and not from freezing.I would pay more for better quality. Is there any out there? Or is it just a race to the bottom.

1:52 Mins As you'll see, I installed these in a cabinet for holding pots and pans, replacing cheap European style glides. I'm sure it's easier to use these in new installations, where you can use jigs and be sure everything is square. It took me a bit to get it right because my cabinet was slightly out of square.There are a number of good woodworking forums that provided me with tips for proper alignment. If you're like me - not very experienced in this work, I highly recommend reading up a bit.
I wanted to use an older monitor with my new PC. This filled the bill. Also, I chose this one because there were ample photos on the page, unlike a lot of items on Amazon anymore.

This is the heaviest, and most heavy-duty colander I have ever seen. It's very well made, like most Oxo products. The plastic is 3/16" thick! The snap-open leg assembly is attached with Stainless Steel screws. The whole thing weighs 1.5 lbs. I think it was originally designed to pan for gold.The legs are handy for spanning even a large sink. It's a nice feature I guess, but having the colander down on the floor of the sink never bothered me before. The legs do add a substantial amount to the storage space.So I give it 4 stars for being a quality product. And I highly recommend it if that's what fits your need. Maybe you're running a cafeteria, a soup kitchen, or you cook for a small army. Or you just like having a huge heavy colander that just might outlive you.But here's the thing: After using it for the first time, my wife said "What the heck? This takes up half of the dishwasher!" After draining pasta or rinsing some fruit, that's pretty much what I want to do - toss it in the dishwasher and not have to mess with it. So for every day use, I'll stick to one of my lighter colanders that takes up a lot less space. This giant colander will get stored in the basement, with my restaurant stockpots and my prospecting gear.

This started out for me in a 4" pot back in August, 2011. It only had 3 or 4 leaves and I didn't have much hope for it. But I've watered it carefully, and  brought it in every Winter. I re-potted it several times, and managed to keep from killing it. I've even used some leaves in sauces and soups.The plant itself has reached about 32 inches tall and looks great. Now every spring it comes out of dormancy and starts putting out shoots like gangbusters.

When you're talking about plant  saucers.Maybe this is obvious to some, but it seems confusing just how big any given plant saucer is. I finally figured out that the actual size is determined by the base of the pot made by the same manufacturer in that same style. It all depends on the taper of the pot.I got double lucky with this saucer. I went with the 14 inch saucer hoping it would fit my pot that has about a 9 1/2 inch base. It turns out this saucer can handle up to 10 1/2 inches max. It also fits just exactly into this plant dolly Devault 3012B Plant Dolly, Black, 12-Inch.

Maybe too small. I generally cook for 2 - with the coffee grounds and the tea leaves and an onion or two, and this bin is full. When making a big stew or similar, one bin just isn't enough.Of course, that's not a bad thing if you don't mind traipsing out to the garden once a day. And you don't want this stuff hanging around your kitchen too long.So I bought 2 and we'll see how well this works over the winter. But if one of them breaks, I'll replace it with something larger. If you're cooking for a family, I wouldn't recommend this.

A couple in the car. A couple in the office. A couple in the suitcase. A couple in the kitchen. Now the wife won't ever have to as where to find a USB cable to charge her phone.I like the 1 ft length of these - plenty long enough for most situations without a bunch of extra cord dangling around. The only exception might be a hotel room that doesn't have outlets on the desk, but most do anymore.
Roomy. Warm. Soft. I got these for wearing around the house on those cold Polar Vortex nights. they're a really thick weave, as if your grandmother knitted them for you.

I'm a big fan of Loctite usually, but this is a poor version of marine epoxy. It's not stiff enough to be useful for anything except perhaps filling horizontal cracks that can sit level for 2 hours.After it sets up it looks and feels like a good product. Tough with just a hint of flexibility. I think it might be handy in a situation where you need an epoxy that will flow into cracks. But as a marine epoxy, this doesn't cut it.

I've had the Rosle Right-Handed Swivel Peelerfor several years and liked the feel of it better than several others in the drawer. I wish I had found this Cross peeler sooner. It's great for peeling large fruits like Butternut Squash and Eggplant. I also use it to peel slivers of hard cheese. It's especially handy on the Bleu Cheese I keep in the freezer (else it would turn to furry cheese before I could use it up). When I need a little to sprinkle on a salad or over broccoli, I pull it out and use this tool to scrape off just what I need.A tool well done.(Note: the title is from a Bob Seger tune}.

At first these seemed like too expensive for the quality. But they've held up well. The finish and the swing joints have stayed good as new. The biggest complaint with Halogens is that you can cook your head with them. Or burn yourself. That's why they come with the handle, so you don't touch the lamp. I replaced the original bulbs with 20W bulbs, which were plenty for reading. But they still got pretty hot. Recently, I converted them to 12V LEDs(see photo), reducing the surface temp of the lamps from 132 degrees down to 80. Problem solved.Edit: Apparently Amazon has removed the 'Notes' feature from customer photos. In the picture, the one on the right is the 20W halogen bulb, the one on the left is modified to LEDs using:Ledwholesalers Disc Type G4 Base Side Pin LED Bulb with 15xsmd5050 for Rv Camper Trailer Boat Marine, Warm White, 1114wwLEDwholesalers LED Strip Lights PWM Dimming Controller For LED Lights or Ribbon, 12 Volt 8/10 Amp, 3301HiMart New DC 12V Switching Power Supply Adapter For 110V- 240V AC 50/60Hz 2.1mm With HiMart RobbinThe bulb looked great but did not do well trying to dim it to low levels. I have since replaced it with this one:BrightChoice Tower Type G4 18 SMD LED 5050 12V Ac/Dc Warm White Color.It's not quite as bright, and not quite as warm. But it dims all the way down, which is nice.

I used this to retrofit my swing arm wall lamp over the bed.Nickel Halogen Plug-In Swing Arm Wall Lamp It uses a 20W halogen that doubled as a hair dryer. The bi-pin on this is G4, 120V bulbs are typically G8, so I had to do some careful bending. And of course, I switched it over to a 12V supply and a LEDwholesalers LED Strip Lights PWM Dimming Controller For LED Lights or Ribbon, 12 Volt 8/10 Amp, 3301 (removed from the case).The dimming range is limited, but that may be the fault of the dimmer. The real benefit is the lower temperature. In the 72 degree room, after 45 minutes I measured the surface temp of the lamp - 80 degrees. The temp of the lamp that had not yet been modified was 132.My wife and I can now read comfortably at night without scorching our foreheads.The color is definitely a Warm White. It may not be all the way down to 2700K, but it's darn close. Reviewers that got a different color did not get the correct part number. The seller would most likely correct that problem for you without hassle.Edit: Well, I guess you can't look at the photo. It appears that Amazon has stripped the customer photos feature from their product pages.

I have 2 of these, to keep deer out of my garden and Blueberry patch. Small, inexpensive, and plenty of sting.I could have done it with one, but at this price it was easier to buy a second one than to run a hot wire the 300 feet between the 2 gardens.I wasn't too impressed with the shock on this at first. I touched it a few times, and it stung. But not too bad. Still, as a deterrent, most animals will avoid pain. And it did light up a fluorescent tube, so I was confident it was working.When I touched it previously though, I had been wearing my usual sneakers that I work around the house in. Thick rubber soles. This evening I touched it accidentally on damp grass while wearing Crocs. YIKES! It sent me somewhere into next week.The best way I found to train deer on this without running 6 ft high wires is simple. Put a small piece of aluminum foil on the wire in a few places with some peanut butter wrapped in it. Deer can't resist peanut butter, and they steer clear after one taste.

3:05 MinsI was really impressed with the sound from this portable Bluetooth speaker, the Philips BT 2500. Rather than do a technical review of it (there will be plenty of those), I decided to showcase where and how I've been enjoying it. It's just the right size for travel, and handy around the house and yard.A note about the audio: in order to get better sound levels I did additional audio takes on some of the clips. But all of the sound on the video is directly from the BT 2500(except for a couple of bird chirps), in the locations and positions that you see.The recordings were made with either a Nexus 5, or Galaxy Tab 4.

If you love Cilantro, this is the way to buy seeds. Plant a thimbleful every week, and you will always have fresh Cilantro. Plus, there's plenty to use as Coriander for cooking too.I've purchased many seeds from Everwilde Farms, always been pleased with the quality of their products.(By the way, the 'plant a thimbleful' idea was Thomas Jefferson's).

Simple, effective, slim case. It may not provide as much protection as one of those armored cases that look like an armadillo. But it also doesn't add a lot of bulk to your phone.The buttons operate well, without extra force.The clear plastic will get scratched up, which may be a problem for some. I think it's a good testimony to just how much we abuse our phones on a daily basis.

I've got chargers aplenty sitting around the office. I've bought several with the hope of satisfying our travel needs in one package. But my wife always complained about her ipad charging way too slow.Leave it to Apple to over-complicate something else about their devices.Her ipad recognizes this charger and juices up at full speed. At the same time that I'm charging my Nexus 5, my Galaxy Tab, an her Kindle.It's small enough to toss in a suitcase or stay plugged in by the kitchen counter.Good job, Anker.
Not much to say. Well made. Worked great . Snug fit. I used them for both US and EU (type C) plugs.

Taylor makes a lot of perfectly good thermometers, about 50 different digital choices from what I can make of their website. I have several of them, and they all seems to be reasonably accurate within a degree or 2.  It's easy to test by putting them in ice water and boiling water.  This seems to be their only one with LED readout. LEDs have been supplanted by LCDs for good reason. They use a lot less power, and back-lit LCDs solve the problem of reading in the dark.The 9835 does have a nice large and bright readout. The downside is that you can't read it at all in sunlight. So don't plan on using for grilling out during the day.Two other reasons not to like this one. It is not water resistant, as some of the other models (such as the 9842, that I have used for years). Also, because of the concern for battery life with LEDs, this model 9835 shuts off after 15 seconds. Even if you hit the HOLD button. I find that annoying and unacceptable.Bottom line - the only reason to want this one is you only plan on using this in the kitchen, and prefer or require a larger (1/2") bright LED readout. AND you can live with it shutting off every 15 seconds.

I have several Foscam cameras. The indoor 18916 is a nice design and never given me a problem. The 2 18905s look like they came from different factories - one has been fine, the other needs resetting regularly. This 18904 needs to be reset all the time, which is a problem. I'm not home to reset it.All the the cameras came with different wall  mounts, ranging from barely adequate to totally useless.One of the common questions people ask is what is the real viewing angle of the camera. Mine seems to be 67, based on my crude measurement. But that doesn't mean you'll get the same thing. I've seen the same one advertised as 50 degrees, and sometimes as just 'wide angle'.I was surprised to find out that this camera has no audio. Why not? All the other ones did.
