Shame on me for not checking the specs closer, I guess. But it says right on the box: "View and listen to your world anywhere...anytime."  I do not think those words mean what you think they mean.Foscam definitely competes on price. But their quality is inconsistent. The marketing bizarre. And all the fake reviews a real shame. If you need reliable surveillance, Foscam isn't the answer. Too bad, because they have the potential to be real good.Edit 11/15/14: After less than a year, it's dead. And it was well sheltered on a porch out of the elements. I'm looking for cheaper alternatives that at least have an excuse to be unreliable.

When IR thermometers first came out they were hundreds of dollars. Now you can get a basic 'non-contact' thermometer for under $20. This similar looking but much more expensive option is a major step above that, and a step below the Star Wars military imaging you see in the movies.Fluke products are industrial quality. This one is no exception. It's got a good rugged feel, fits nicely in your palm.  They claim it will fit in your pocket. It could go in a hoodie sweatshirt pocket, but I wouldn't try cramming it into your jeans.It takes about 15 seconds to start up, then gives the camera view and temperature readings. So it's very easy to get started. Using the advanced features such as parallax adjustment, time lapse and emissivity require spending a little time with the manual.The image is good, especially inside about 4 feet. It functions at greater distances, but it's not designed for spotting critters on your lawn (although I intend to test that).  It's very precise with it's aiming - aim just to the side of a light bulb and get the room temperature, move to the bulb itself and it quickly counts up to the bulb temp. One feature I like is the Image Blending. You can start with just the visual image, then gradually add in the infra-red image. This allows you to find the right 'contrast' when looking for a hot spot.Another feature, which I have not tried yet is the Time Lapse Image Capture. For example, you can mount the unit on a tripod and take a picture every 30 seconds for up to 8 hours.You can see from the price that this is aimed at the professional market. The target user would be a contractor, electrician, or manufacturing operation. Electrical and mechanical maintenance needs can be spotted before they become breakdowns. I could also see an auto repair shop finding a use, such as a bad bearing, or coolant and exhaust leaks. Being able to take a picture and show the customer a hot spot can go a long way to building customer trust.The average homeowner thinking of getting this to save on energy bills, might do better to have an audit done by a contractor or utility company.As I have time to experiment, I will update this review with more info and some photos.

These Actiontec Powerline adapters are tiny. About 2.5 x 1 7/8 x 1. Set up couldn't be easier. Just plug them in and start using them. How fast are they? I devised a little ad hoc test.I created a half gig zip file (502 MB) on my Zyxel 221 NAS, which is attached directly to my (Netgear G) router  .Baseline Test 1: Copy test file to a laptop over wireless. No extra traffic on the network. Excellent signal strength.Time 1: 4:01Time 2: 3:49Baseline Test 2: connect same laptop through ethernet cable and copy the same file.Time 1: 1:01Time 2: 0:58That's to be expected.Actiontec Test 3: Attach the Powerline adapter to the router and plug it in. Plug the other one in at the other end of the basement, through a sub-panel, a 25 ft extension cord,and a second 6-ft (very old) extension cord. About 110 feet total.Time 1: 1:24Time 2: 1:26Actiontec Test 4: The toughest test (or so I thought). Move the laptop out to my shop - 60 AMP service 340 feet away from the house, through an underground line, through another subpanel, and into an outlet about 30 feet from that sub.Time 1: 1:20Time 2: 1:19Very impressive. Clearly these are a big improvement over wireless G, and not that much slower than direct Ethernet cabling. So for getting a signal to a remote location (such as my shop) without the hassle of running a cable, this is the way to go.If you have 400 Amp service, bear in mind that these adapters generally have to be plugged into circuits that are on the same main panel.

My wife didn't like it. I got it for her as a Christmas gift. It works fine, fits OK, so it could be a 5 star just what you're looking for kind of case. But as Melissa said in her review, it's Clunky. It weighs 1lb 8 oz (681 g), and makes your ipad 1 inch thick at the bracket.So if you really need the keyboard and a hardshell case, this might be worth the trade-off. But my wife likes to carry her ipad around in her purse all the time, and decided that she'd rather deal with the on screen keyboard than lug the extra weight around.Just keep that in mind when making the choice.

I've installed a lot of these on tablets and phones. Never one this large. And it never goes quite right.But this one went on bubble free. Like I said - I'm shocked.Besides cleaning it thoroughly, I sprayed water around the room to get the dust down. I did it in the afternoon with low sunlight streaming in, so I could see the surface of my screen along the edge and make sure it was speck free.I ended up with one tiny dust bubble near the edge. I was able to peel the cover up and pick the dust speck off  with a toothpick.This protector seems stiffer and thicker than other ones I've had. I think it will hold up well. The holes lined up perfectly. I would give it 5 stars if it were available in anti-glare.

Well, OK, it's just a lid after all. The main reason I got this is that I have a drawer full of lids - 4 metal and 2 glass. But when I replaced my Calphalon frying pans with the exact same size pans, the newer models have a slightly different slope to the sides. . So I'm stuck with lids that that don't quite fit. This universal lid solves that problem nicely.The construction seems sound. The silicon appears to be molded to the glass - I tried to peel it off. The lid is held on with a Stainless Steel screw, If it gets loose, don't make it too tight.The only slight negative I have is the graduated aspect of silicon rim. This is unnecessary, IMHO. The lid is still only going to fit tight if the pan is exactly the right size, But the drawback is this:  the larger the pan, the lower the lid sits. Not a big issue, but sometimes you want that extra clearance.In all, a worthwhile addition to the kitchen. I would give it 5 stars, but it is after all just a lid.

I have a Jura Capressa F7. Of course they only recommend using their overpriced tablets for their machines. I've been using these for years now with great results. Because they are so reasonably priced, I clean my super-auto every Sunday using 2 tablets. One jar is good for a year. I'm at over 8,000 cups on my F7 with no major problems.Note: These do not descale. You must descale your machine occasionally, even if you use the filter and have soft water.Edit 11/20/14: Now that these are available on the Subscribe and Save plan, they're even less expensive. And at every 6 months more than I need for my Jura. But that's OK. I've found these work great on my anything relating to tea or coffee - My wife's teapot, her tea strainer Finum Brewing Basket, medium , black, and the various go-cups we use that all pick up stains. She carries her tea to work every day in one of these Nalgene Translucent Wide Mouth Bottle With Blue Lid. Cafiza tablets keep them looking pretty new.

Are there any decent mounts out there? The one that came with my Foscam 18905 - why did they even bother? Useful only if you don't care where the camera is aimed.These are actually a big improvement. But they still don't work very well.The modular design and all the pieces screw together in lots of possible configurations. It's a cool idea, really. But the weak link is the most important - the ball joint. It just won't hold like it should. A heavy camera like the 18905 will get pulled by the wind or the ethernet cable. Makes for a precarious situation.Another example of that Wal-Mart mentality. Make it cheap and the heck with the functionality.Edit: I tossed out the ball head that comes with it and replaced it with a decent one - Professional Mini Ball Head Camera Mount. Sure, it triples the price of the total mount, but it works great. And it's still under about $20 each. It's a shame to have to go to that extreme, but it solves the problem.

The Neptor battery pack has a nice feel. It's a great ergonomic shape for any pocket. And, it has a flashlight ! What more could you ask for?I'm not a huge power user on my phone ( I don't talk all day or watch Netflix). I do use the GPS about 1.5 hours every morning plus moderate usage throughout the day. I have to charge my Sprint Nexus with (so-called) extended battery every night.So I did the following experiment:Sunday AM: Started with a fully charged phone. I only used the Neptor to charge my phone starting Sunday night. It charged fully Sunday, Monday, and Tuesday nights. On Wednesday night the Neptor was totally pooped out. Decent performance, for it's size, really.Other aspects of the design are pretty slick. It seems to shut itself off after fully charging the phone. The LED gives you some idea of it's charge when you press the on button. Also, did I mention it's a flashlight?My other experience with this type of charger is the Energizer Universal Multi-Port Smartphone Rechargeable Charger with 2 USB Ports, Micro USB Cable, 10W and 5W Charger. It's more expensive, and I was not too impressed with it. Also, it was bulkier.If you really need one of these fairly often, then I guess it's worth the steep price tag. If you don't travel a lot, or just need to make it through the occasional emergency call when your battery is dead, consider something like the Burro Mobile Charger - AA-Powered, USB Power Pack - Building Better Lives in Africa. Not as slick as this product, but a lot cheaper and uses AA batteries.Edit: It's been about a year.I just spent a long time traveling, and this was a real benefit to have. Phones keep getting more power hungry, and it's nice to have that back-up.

I bought this with reservations, due to the mixed reviews. I mainly wanted charging capability, but data would be nice sometimes.On my Nexus, this cable works fine for both. Makes the charging station in the kitchen more tidy, and the car as well.These thin cables won't take lots of abuse. But at this price, it's easy to keep a few spares around.Edit: One of the Micro USB plugs was loose. On careful inspection I realized that these are snap on housings, not molded. A minor detail, but it helps reduce their cost as it also reduces the durability. Still - 4 stars so far. We'll see how they hold up.

As others have mentioned, this armband will fit most arms. But if you have massive bulging biceps ( I don't), this might just be too small.Although fairly comfortable, I don't like the neoprene against my skin. I prefer the nylon bands that my other phone holders use.Although you can work the controls, it is awkward and not always responsive. But if you're walking or running, you generally just put it on play and off you go.If you got caught in the rain, I think this would keep your iPod dry, for a while anyway.

I've used a number of abrasives on Stainless. With 3M you get a consistently good product. These hold up well compared to the cheaper import brands. The backing is noticeably thicker. It's hard to do a scientific comparison, but I'd rather pay more and change discs less often. Consistent grit size is also critical - one oversize chunk can scratch your work in a second.The Indasa Rhynogrips are decent and less expensive. Some of the other imports, such as Keene, are just plain junk.

I was fascinated by the people that use this to make soap. Cool! I was honestly wondering what the heck I was going to use it for. But I'm always looking for things to make large ice cubes in. I thought this might come in handy if I had a large batch of chicken broth or similar, and wanted to freeze it for later use. Large ice cube trays such as Tovolo KING Cube Ice Trays, Blue have come in quite handy for that.As it happened, my daughter was home from college one day and said: "Let's bake something." So we whipped up some peanut butter chocolate chip muffins from a recipe off the web, and went at it. We don't consider ourselves bakers, but these pans took some of the stress out of the process. After removing them from the oven, we let them cool a little and they popped right out. They came out so clean we just tossed it into the top rack of the dishwasher.I'm still a bit of a traditionalist - I like my heavy metal pans for baking bread. But my experience with this silicon pan tempts me to try it.

I have a shed next to a corn field. As you can imagine, there are plenty of mice. I thought it would be nice to use something besides poison to keep the population down. Just killing one mouse in several months isn't going to do the trick.I was surprised to read that this can kill 3 mice without emptying it. Maybe if they are really young tiny mice. My one dead mouse took up the entire chamber.I've gone back to the poison, but am keeping this set in case another mouse is looking to get a charge out of life.

Not the sellers fault - Chapin advertises this as fitting the 61850. The piston seal is way too big for mine. I got 5 good years out of the sprayer, so no complaints there.So if it says it fits your model, do a little research first to be sure.

At least they're consistent. Mine just arrived - Both broken into many pieces. Since they were out of stock I got a full refund. I'll keep trying until they get it right. These small ones are perfect for serving on. I love doing tapas and the presentation on a salt block can be a real treat. I have large ones (8 x 8 x 2) for cooking on. At least one website recommends the 2" for cooking and the 1" for serving, for longevity reasons.Five stars if I get a set not broken!

I'm only into my second season and I just discovered cracks in the tank. For this kind money, that's just unacceptable. I'm willing to give a company a break if they have an occasional failure. But judging from the reviews and all the HVAC bulletin boards, this unit is a lemon.I posted a picture of the tank.

This laser measurer works surprisingly well. I tested it in my basement, where it reflected and gave accurate readings against wood, plastic, just about everything I tested it on. I also shot some measurements outside, getting readings of 40 - 80 ft without trouble against smooth and rough objects.I was impressed with how sensitive it is, and the fact that you don't have to aim it at a perpendicular surface to get a reading. I shot an 8 foot reading at a matte finish surface.Right next to the dot was a metal bracket 1/8th thick. When I slid the dot over to the bracket, it detected the difference.I was disappointed at how hard it was to see the laser dot outdoors. Even with red 'laser glasses' on, it was hard to find at 60 ft. against a light tan background (it was a bright but overcast day).If you need to estimate a run of pipe, electric cable, or how much fence to buy, this will do the trick. It won't replace your tape measure for cutting a 2x4 to length, or anything like that.So if your in construction, I could see having this in your toolbox. It would be money well spent. Although I would want one with a brighter laser.For the average homeowner, it's a cool gadget that you can show off to your buddies, but probably won't use that often.

There's a couple of reasons you might choose this over a solar powered light. Maybe you don't like the look of an ugly solar cell. The soft olive drab finish on this makes it pretty discrete looking. Or maybe you want a light in a place that doesn't get much sun. Both reasons apply to me. I think the choice of using C cells to power this is a good trade-off between size and battery life. One set of batteries should last quite a while.There is an option to have it run all night on low power. Of course that will eat up the batteries quicker - I won't be testing that function. I recommend Paradise GL28100BS6 Low Voltage Metal Deck Light, Brushed Stainless Steel, 6-Pack for a nice dusk to dawn, soft lighting solution.On the regular setting the single LED is quite bright. I'll post a photo.The remote works at about 30 feet. Since the lights have motion sensors, I'm not sure how useful the remote will be. It's not like you can use these for illuminating a large area.So far, there's been one annoying flaw. The method to make the battery compartment water resistant uses a 1 mm gasket that loops around in an overly complicated shape. This choice is notorious for working fine until the seal pops out, and it gets stretched. When I opened the first unit, I noticed the seal was installed out of it's slot. After 20 minutes of trying to 'get the toothpaste back in the tube', I gave up and went on to the second. I later went back and sealed it with silicon caulk, but of course that should not have been necessary.I would also like to have seen them use captive screws for the proprietary screws on the battery cover. If you lose one of these while changing the battery, you're out of luck.In all, a pretty nice design.

I bought this just to play with the vibration detector. Then I decided to annoy a cat that was scratching where it shouldn't. I set it off about 20 times while testing it. Once it settles in, the slightest jolt will set it off. It reminds me of the old game 'Operation' - see how far you can move it without triggering it.The siren is not only loud, but an ascending sine wave that hurts the ears in less than a second. It shuts off after about 20 seconds, but believe me, you can't stand it that long.Back to the cat story: I rigged it up with thread to scare the cat when it went near that spot. Trouble is, I go there too. After accidentally tripping it about 6 times, I got mad and kicked the hell out of it. It flew across the room, bounced off the dresser, battery and battery cover flying off. Still works fine with the same battery.It's not waterproof. It might be OK outside in a ziploc bag. I'm thinking of testing it on the resident deer population.No question, if you need something to attach to a door or window (or several), this is a cheap solution. A string or anything to knock it over or make it wobble is all you need.It 'could' work as a personal alarm, but I  don't recommend it. After you turn it on, it takes 15 seconds before it's armed. That's a long time if someone is attacking you. On the other hand, if you want to let some stranger knocking at the door know just how you feel about him, that 15 seconds while he's introducing himself might be perfect timing.

I bought a few of these locally to give them a try. At first I thought these were for non-electricians that didn't know how to use a wire nut. Plus, they were kind of expensive.Then I did a lighting project that had me working on the ceiling, running lines to multiple fixtures from 1 box. between the reach, and the box filling up fast, it would have been a drag. But these EZ Connectors (as I call them) made it go much quicker and kept the box neater. I had some of the 4 wire connectors (these are the 2 wire option). It was a lot nicer using those than twisting 4 wires into a large wire nut. Especially as my basal arthritis does not appreciate applying torque with my thumbs.Another nice feature: At first I only needed 3 of the 4 connections. When I decided to add another fixture, It was a breeze to just slide the new wire in instead of disassembling the twisted wire assemblies.I realize it seems like I'm reviewing the 4 connector instead of this item. But my point is the same. I don't think I would pay for the convenience at the price these were available locally. When I saw these, it was a no-brainer. It's almost impossible to get a bad connection with these as compared to a wire nut, especially if using different gauge or stranded wire. So pick up a box of these, and the Push Wire Connector 773-164, and save yourself some time. And possibly some finger pain.

I had to wait until late Fall to give this a fair review. The herd of about 13 deer around here have plenty of forage from my cornfield (and others). Starting in October they start eating the tree shoots, giving me a Bonsai garden of Japanese Maples. Sadly, Deer Off did not seem to hinder their taste for Maple, Cherry, Dogwood, and Mimosa branches. But then, my deer don't even flinch when you fire a loud pistol in their direction. I've gone back to putting fence around the trees I don't want stubbed any further. Which is a real pain.Maybe your deer are more picky, and will be more deterred.I was impressed by this little sprayer. Most battery powered sprayers are junk, but this one works well. I'll be finding some use for it around the home.

I looked at a few other short iPod cables like this. Reviewers pointed out that they had little or no flexibility at all. This one is short, but as you can see from the photo, it is capable of a u-turn. That sold me. I'm using it with a 5th Gen NANO. A lot less clutter around the USB port Gear Head USB 2.0 4-Port Hub with Energy Saving Switch (AC Powered) (RoHS) (UH5500ESP).I also like the way this cable is reinforced at the ends. It gives me some confidence that it won't separate like some of my other ones.

I have keyless entry to my car, or I would never lock it. I installed a Schlage Keyless deadbolt on my front door 4 years ago, and it still works fine. The batteries last about 2 years.This FE5576 model went on the basement door. It has a lot of features that the deadbolt does not have, such as the alarms. They are mostly overkill for my application, but I can see how they might be useful to some. Like other models, you can set up temporary codes for contractors, etc. Installation was smooth and simple.Regarding the construction, this thing is built like a tank. I measured it at about 12 gauge steel for the housing. It feels like it would stop a bullet. Or a sledgehammer.Along the same lines, this has a clean industrial look to it. I can't really cal it 'stylish'. My wife said it definitely would not be going on the front door. I agree - if you have a nice wooden door with beveled glass, etc., you might want to consider the other models with more decorative handles. Hence the 4 stars, not 5.We'll see how the finish holds over the years, but out of the box, this is a winner.

I'm surprised at all the 5 star reviews, maybe I got a lemon. Some people talk about "at it's lowest speed". My PC doesn't have speed control, so that's no help.It's supposed to run at 17db, which is pretty quiet. I definitely don't hear it when music is playing, but I can hear it now across the room. I even moved the PC down off of a shelf behind a wooden barrier. All 17 db (at least) are a hum that's about A below middle C. Which is great if I'm in the mood to hum "In the Hall of the Mountain King." Overture to "The Magic Flute", not so much.I may try a controller, or another fan. The white noise of air whooshing would have been much more acceptable.

I've been using a couple of cheap plastic turkey platters for years to cart piles of burgers, etc. up from the big grill. They were looking shabby, so I found this substitute. Rectangular, it's a more stable and effective shape than the oval platters. Not for fine dining, but if you want to hold a dozen burgers or several pounds of brats, it's great. You're not adding a couple pounds to the load, like you would be with a similar porcelain platter.One thing I'm bad about, is using a knife on something like this. If you avoid scratching it with knives or turners, it will stay easy-to-clean much longer. I will no doubt ignore my own advice. For the price, replacing this every grilling season is no big deal if it gets gunked up.I bought just one to see how flimsy or brittle it is. It has a little flex to it, about 1 inch if you twist it. The stiffness and feel convey a pretty good tradeoff between brittle and flex. I think it would withstand a fall onto gravel or wood. But drop it loaded onto concrete and it just might crack. Of course, a porcelain platter would fare much worse.So I'm buying a second one and I'm all set to grill for a crowd.Edit 5/22/15: Another one cracked. I ordered 2 more, and one arrived cracked from bouncing around the box (shame on those Amazon packers). Bought 2 more and BOTH were broken (double shame). I give up on these. Does anyone make a more resilient one?Edit 8/24/25: Another one broke on the corner. If these were $2.00 I wouldn't mind them being so short-lived. They have no flex at all anymore and might as well be porcelain.

My Asus brags that it has Altec Lansing speakers. So what. I can hardly hear them. My laptop is really my everyday, sitting on the kitchen table desktop, so I want to be able to hear a YouTube video while I'm cooking, or whatever. This addition has made that possible.Some reviewers have complained about the strength of the spring on the speaker clip. I was all set to use my second favorite adhesive - Velcro - to solve that problem. But I don't move my computer much, and my laptop 'top' is only about 1/4", so that seems to be a non-issue.Regarding the volume control, it works smoothly, so that is definitely a function of your driver. But here's what was weird for me: At first I thought it wasn't going to be loud enough, despite some reviews that claimed it was really loud. Playing around, I turned on the 'Loudness' on my Realtek driver, and the volume more than doubled. I've had other issues with Realtek drivers on other PCs, so don't give up if you're not happy with the sound at first. Mess around with those sound settings.Another reason I went with this low end brand was the built in cable. Just one less thing to keep track of. If you are on the go, it stores nicely into the back of the case.If you want to talk about Bass response, get over it. Frequency response at the low end is a function of size. If you want Bass, carry around a subwoofer, or a Boombox. If you want to hear decent sound out of your laptop, this is a reasonably priced, compact option.Edit 11/17: My laptop doesn't have a USB port on the back. This might seem a bit picky, but to keep the cable hugging the side of the keyboard, I added this to the setup: HDE USB 3.0 Vertical Male to Female Adapter. I just know I would hit the cable with a drink or something otherwise.

I have an old New Trent, which I never use. It has a dedicated charger, so that means you have to pack another charger.At least this Energizer uses Micro USB, which is the new standard everywhere (except Apple, of course).I have found that it barely charges on some wimpy USB ports or chargers. Nor will it charge my phone when plugged into a charger that's less than 1 amp, even when it's full.My phone is a Nexus, which I know is a hungry device. I get about 24 hrs out of a charge, less if I'm using Navigation. I believe the extended battery is rated at 2100 Mahr.I tested this a couple of times to make sure I was getting the same results. When the phone got down to under 15%, I charged it with this Energizer charger. It successfully charged it overnight, but at that point it was crying out to be recharged itself.That's OK, I thought. It could still come in handy in an airport, or similar situation. I looked at the product page to see if other reviewers shared my experience. Since I received this through Vine, I had no idea of the price.WOW! I have no compunction about spending too much on something that's truly handy. But this just doesn't meet my price/value expectations. I would hope to get at least 2 full charges out of the stated 5000 mahr battery in this.Your mileage, of course, may vary.

I just bought a third one of these.The first one I got in 2006. It's downstairs with my big grill, and doesn't get used much. It's bent, it's dirty, it's got Silicon where I sealed the probe back to the body after breaking it off. I have to press the button a few times to turn it on and off. But hey - it's 6 years old!!My second one just crapped out after 3 1/2 years. But I used it almost every day in the kitchen, and I'm not shy about getting it wet or sticking it in the oven for a minute where it doesn't belong. I've left it out in the rain and melted a bit of it here and there.Your mileage may vary. I'm going for another one and we'll see if the quality has changed.Some have complained about the response time. I don't get that. There's no such thing as instant readout, except with a IR thermometer such as HDE Temperature Gun Infrared Thermometer w/ Laser Sight(which is also very handy for measuring pan temps - 700 degrees for the best Carne Asada).I feel lucky that I haven't had to dink around trying different models to get the right one. This thermometer has just always worked for great for me.

Actually this is a great little blower for certain circumstances. Like a mini-Leaf Blower, it churns out a pretty nice blast of air. But not enough to blow everything over. So what's it  good for?I bought one to feed air into a heat exchanger for an air roaster. Since that isn't done yet, I've been using it to blow dust off my workbench. It clears the bench without creating a huge storm, or sending small tools flying. The leaf blower would be overkill for that task. You can blow the sweat out of your shirt, the sawdust out of your chopsaw, or get your charcoal grille going in a hurry. I'm picking up a couple of these for future use.I did not have the oily smell that one reviewer mentioned. It was quite loud with a high pitched whine, but that seems to have calmed down with about 10 minutes of running.I expect this to last with intermittent usage. I would not build it into any design where it ran for hours on end.Revised 10/12/2012:Ok, I've never had to downgrade a review as much as I have to with this one. I bought a second one. They are loud enough to warrant earplugs. Ouch. Then I dropped it from less than 2 feet onto gravel and it died. Tried taking it apart to find the loose wire, but no luck. Honest - less than 2 feet.First one - even giving it the benefit of the doubt: I tried it on my heat exchanger as mentioned above. Under a restricted airflow, I know it's not meant for that. But after just under 5 minutes, it burst into flames! Literally caught fire! Ouch again.So, I realize I'm not very kind to my equipment, and take that into consideration when reviewing them. But this is a shop tool, and although it's the perfect size, it's just not that well made. Even for Chinese HF quality, it doesn't cut it.

These germinated quickly, and grew pretty well in my lousy soil (if it wasn't for the compost I have brought in, it would be all rock and clay).Around the middle of August, all my cucurbits petered out and died. But before they went, these Minnesota Midgets gave up about 8 or 10 tiny melons per plant. They were very mild tasting. Not too sweet, not a real strong 'Canteloupe' fragrance. Of course, I can't say whether that's a characteristic of the melon, or my growing conditions. I've never had great success with melons.Nice texture - we ate them right down the rind every time.Regarding the size, they are like a large grapefruit. It's perfect to serve a half or to even eat a whole one by yourself. I posted a pic to give you a better idea.I will definitely do them again next year. My soil will be better, and hopefully so will my gardening skills.

It's hard to get excited about Post-it notes. But I have a lot of crap, and crap needs labeling. So I liked the idea, especially for organizing things in Rubbermaid containers in the basement, etc. So I was hoping this would do better than mailing labels that tend to fall off over time.No such luck. On really smooth plastic, they seem to stick well. On the standard Rubbermaid container that has a little textured surface to it, they fall off in seconds. So it definitely could have a place in the kitchen drawer. But it is limited as to what you can use it on. So it may be a useful product, or it may be a solution in search of a problem.I'm still searching for the perfect label for those Rubbermaid containers...

I bought this just to try it, and can not use it for metalworking. The shield is a full inch shorter than a standard Sperian type shield 3M AO Safety/3M Tekk 90028 Professional Faceshield, and even they don't really keep particles from coming up from underneath. So for preventing straight on flying debris, this one is adequate. But not much more.The real deal-breaker is that the shield attaches to the mask in a proprietary way. So you can't buy a handful of standard shields to replace it. Nor did I see any on Amazon. You drop it, scratch it, and you have to throw the whole thing away.It is light and comfortable to wear. The shield is very thin compared to Sperian type masks. I would not consider it high-impact resistant.So I don't recommend this one for much of anything, except maybe the reviewer that rides a scooter in winter. Even then, their are better masks out there for a few dollars more.I just splurged on this oneSperian Protection S8500 Bionic Face Shield, which really comes down and covers your chin area. And it's surprisingly light. That may be more than you want to pay, but I bet eye surgery can run into some big bucks.

There's a lot of LED strip lighting out there. It seems like everyone in Guangdong or Shenzen is either making it or selling it. So far all the strips I've bought appear to be from the same factory or same process, even ones that I paid a lot more for before they became more widely available. Some of them are mis-represented here on Amazon, either on purpose or because the seller doesn't know what he's doing.Everything I've bought from this vendor has been exactly as described, at a good price.  These 2700K LEDs most closely resemble incandescent lighting, and may even be a little too warm for some. That's because LEDs have a narrower spectrum than a filament bulb.For hallways, under cabinets, I think these are the best.I've done some projects where the brighter double density or 5050 LEDs are needed to squeeze a lot of light into a small space. But for most accent lighting, these 3528s are more than sufficient. I'll post a couple of photos where I used these.Don't scrimp on the power supply. Don't use some old wall wart you have laying around. They often put out up to 20% more voltage, which will cook your LEDs.If you're going to do a lot of these projects, splurge on a good soldering, too:Hakko Soldering Station, FX-888, 65W

I just finished a big LED project with a $10 iron. What a pain. Why work with marginal tools? I ordered this the next day, and am already loving it. The design is nice (even signed!). Three levels of tip cleaning. Solid metal iron holder. Small footprint power supply. But most important:Plenty of heat - when and where you need it. Heats up quickly, and recovers in seconds. I was amazed at how quickly it got up to 700 degrees.I weld stainless, so this is like mini-welding. Get in and get out, before you burn something. With this iron, you're not cooking the circuit board waiting for it to melt the solder. Crank it up and heat the joint in a second or 2. No cold solder joints with this iron. It's refreshing to use a tool that works so well.Even if you do the occasional hobby soldering, this is a worthwhile investment. You might spend this much on a night out, right? Spend it on a great tool that will make your workbench time more satisfying.

The original valve on my Cub Cadet was a slightly different design, and a pain to get open in the location it was placed. So I managed to bust one of the side clips off that holds it closed, making me not trust it. This looked like it would fit so I took a chance. It's the newer design that even Cub Cadet is using now - a quarter-turn instead of the friction clips. Seems much more secure when closed. I installed it with a 3/8" nipple so it sticks out from the engine housing some.

All I can say at this point is I've got excellent germination. Virtually every seed I planted has come up in a few days. I finally got a fence around them, and I'm starting to see blossoms on the ones that survived the attack of the "rabbits with munchies"They haven't bothered anything else in my garden, so they must be sweet. I'll report back when I get a harvest.Update 8/21:The rabbits have gone on to finer pastures. And these are doing great!Thomas Jefferson said "Plant a thimbleful of Lettuce every Monday." I'm using that strategy (more or less) with these. Every week or so I put out about 5 seeds. I now have some plants that are 4 feet tall and I'm enjoying peas (mostly my daughter is moseying out there and scarfing them). But I also have others at various heights, so I'll be getting peas well into the Fall.Very sweet and crunchy, much better than what you can get in any store (of course).

The wife's Tide Stainbrush finally died after all these years. They don't make them any more! I tried several replacements, but she complained that the bristles on all of them were too stiff. I stumbled on this by accident and figured if it's meant for your face, it must be soft.She thinks it works great on laundry stains along with ShoutShout 30 Oz Trigger. I have no idea about using it on your skin, though.

I was in the store looking at these belts the day after this one arrived. I can not see any difference at all in the build between this one, the Cub Cadet belt, and the "Arnold" belt.Because this mower uses an electric clutch, it's meant to be tight all the time. Cub Cadet could have made the installation easier by putting a well-placed slot in the idler pulley arm, so you can pry it open easier. It required stretching that idler spring to it's max to get the belt over it.If you're doing this alone, and having trouble, try this:1. Wrap the belt around all the pulleys except the idler. Use a little duct tape to hold it onto the clutch pulley if it keeps falling off.2. Pry open the idler with a crowbar or a 2x2 from the left side of the mower.3. Slip it over the idler. Watch your fingers!Good luck and be careful.

If you work with your hands - whether it is wood, metal, plumbing, in the garden, Mr. Fixit, you're always dinging up one of your favorite fingers. You're in the middle of a project - you can't just take the rest of the day off.Band-aids are great, but they don't soften that next blow or keep the moisture out as well.Here's my First Aid arsenal:Neosporin: Neosporin + Plus Pain Relief, Cream, 1.0-Ounce TubeIt really cuts down the healing time and prevents the cut from getting infected.Liquid Bandage: New-Skin Liquid Bandage -- 1 fl oz Great for those small cuts. Apply with the skin stretched and pour a coffee first. It take a while to dry. Also a dizzying smell. But it last about 2 days, which is just about right.Heavy Duty Band-Aids: Band-Aid Brand Adhesive Bandages, Tough-Strips, Finger-Care, 15-Count Bandages (Pack of 6) Sometimes you just need a band-aid.And this Nexcare First Aid Tape. It wraps and sticks just the way you want it to. It tears where you want it too. It protects your wound during that first critical day while you're trying to work with it. And it comes right off when you're ready.Because it's foam-rubbery, it really cushions that tender wound without having to immobilize your whole digit. You can wrap a knuckle, or a whole finger. And you can put on as many layers as you deem necessary - Each layer adds protection from pain at the expense of flexibility. It's your call.Along with the other items mentioned, these are indispensable.Okay, I'll mention one more thing - finger cots.

Would have been a great product if the horn itself wasn't so flimsy. Bent out of shape on it's first use. I guess if you're really careful when using it it would be OK.I had a larger, heavier steel shoe horn that I retrofitted into the spring. So now it works great. But of course, you shouldn't have to do that. I would gladly have paid a few dollars more for one that was more solidly built.

It took me a long time to get into this book. I love evolution, history, and biography - all of the things this book was. So why did I have so much trouble getting through it?The premise seems reasonable - plot the 'history' of evolutionary thought as determined by Darwin's list of those he felt should be acknowledged. But as Aristotle's biography developed ("Aristotle's feelings toward Philip must have been complex at this point. Even if he had fond memories of the prince ...). Already by page 27 I'm thinking TMI. It reads like historical fiction. Which may be good or bad, according to your taste. Another example: "Sometime in 1493, a family of Italian peasants pushed a handcart into the courtyard of a grand but faded palace in the center of Milan" ...). The prose scores well for imagery. Not my preference for a science book generally.But as I labored further in time, I found it more absorbing. Stott has unearthed a lot of information on some interesting, not-well-known characters. She does an excellent job of highlighting the challenges of heretical thought during the 18th and 19th century. One is not likely to seek out biographies on the likes of Robert Grant or Abraham Trembley, so these vignettes are refreshing and fun. I never felt that it developed into a cohesive theme, but the theme was arbitrary from the start.So if historical fiction interests you, this non-fiction book might be right up your alley. Definitely 4 Stars. If you prefer a more prosaic style in science writing, then 3 Stars. But unless you are a Ken Jennings, you will find something of interest that could be a jumping off point to further reading.

Dames Rocket is a great addition to a field or road frontage. It does well in poor soil, sun or shade. It comes up in early Spring and blooms for about 6 weeks. Plant it with Larkspur, which will bloom just as the Dame's Rocket is fading.This is a bag of 100% seed - no filler. If you buy seeds at a box store, you're lucky to get 10%. So don't balk at the price - it's worth it.I've purchased several packages of bulk seed from Everwilde Farms and been very happy with all the products.

Not too often you need a 20MM tap. But I did, and it was just a few clicks away here at Amazon. It's stamped 'CHINA', but what isn't these days. The machining was quite good on it though. I was able to repair some dinged up threads easily.I could not have obtained this locally at any price.

When I first received this it already seemed a little stretched out. I'm sorry I didn't measure it then. I clamped it to my workbench and pulled on it as if I was using a power tool. It stretched out easily to about 8 feet without pulling too hard. I think I would have had to uncoil it to go 10 feet.But when I relaxed it, it was over 4 feet long after only one pull. Not at all what I was hoping for.I ended up not using it.

You might enjoy this book. But it's not a primer on wines, nor does it claim to be. It's a memoir, plain and simple. It could have been called "The trials and tribulations of living your dream and opening a wine shop." It follows roughly ten years in the life of the author, as he tries to make a go of starting a new business in New York City. Starting a new family at the same time give the story some dramatic tension. There's some interesting tales about wine marketing and the wine industry that are interesting, as well.I can't recommend that this is a book you 'just have to read.' It's just a good story and a quick read. For me it was a fun diversion from my usual weighty tome. Being somewhat familiar with the part of Manhattan where they opened the store gave it a bit more charm for me, also

There a lot of nesting prep bowls out there. Many of them (like these), are available in bright and strange colors. That's why I didn't buy any of the ones I saw at Sur La Table. These are available in 'Natural', which is a light tan.Also, the ones at Sur La Table all varied in size in order to nest. Which could be an advantage I guess, but I found the small ones too small. Although these nest well, they are all the same size, and perfect most of the time. There are definitely times when I need something much bigger, but there are plenty of other bowls in the cabinet for those situations. However, if you are always cooking for a crowd, you might find these too small.When you're cooking at very high temps, timing is everything. Plus, I like to get my prep done before guests arrive and we start drinking. These are great for that home version of Mis en Place. I've attached a photo that hopefully gives a better feel for the size.

Now that I've found this SSR at a great price, many control circuits are easier to do. Just about any application where you need a switch, but don't want to run a 110v wire. Example - I wanted to replace the noisy but ineffective fan to my Jenn-Air down-draft range. I installed this beefy exhaust fanHydrofarm Active Air 6 inch In-Line Fan 400 CFMoutside,about 20 ft from the range. When I flip the fan switch on the range, it triggers a small wall wart instead of the original fan. I ran a control line through the floor and along the garage ceiling.If I had to run 110, it would have been a major pain, and I never would have tackled the project.Because if the small size, this SSR mounts in a standard wall box and other tight places. For example, I put one inside an outdoor box like this one RAB VXCW Weatherproof Round Box 1/2 - White Color W/O Cover. When the garage lights come on, it triggers additional lighting.Both of these circuits use less that 10% of the 25A rating, so I did not use a heat sink. If you plan on burning a lot of amps through this, there is also a 40 amp version that is only slightly larger.

This is my first Bluetooth headset, so I'm a late adopter. I was pleasantly surprised at how easy it was for me to use this. The instructions are pretty simple.  I thought the voice prompts would be weird, but I prefer them for now. It lets you know if you hit the right button. It synched to my phone right away. I use Greenpower to manage my phone's battery. With it controlling the bluetooth, it turns it on when a call is made or received. It syncs faster than I can answer the call.The sound quality is good based on the feedback I've received. I'm a little deaf, so I wish it had more gain. But it's adequate in most situations.I tested the range with my LG Optimus. I set the phone down and walked about 45 feet away before it dropped the signal. Taking a few steps back, and it picked it right up again.Some have mentioned the port cover. I've already ripped that off.Finally, as for comfort - it could be better. I wear earplugs all the time, and it seems like this would do better if it had a more tapered shape. I don't talk on the phone a lot, so no big deal. But I would not want to wear it for long periods of time.

I've had this for 2 months now, so I feel ready to give it a review. I started with a primitive crock-pot hack, and quickly decided I wanted the real deal. If you have the counter space, this looks a lot nicer than a crock-pot with a bunch of wires everywhere. As an appliance that I use about twice a week, it merits a prominent spot in my kitchen.I've done pork chops, pork and beef tenderloin, short ribs, Delmonico, whole chicken, chicken breasts. All of these early experiments have ranged from decent first attempts, to amazing.Chicken (145 with fresh Rosemary)is the tenderest ever - white meat that explodes with juices when you poke it. I'm looking forward to trying some free range birds, hoping for some real intrinsic flavor.Pork loin (134) has been especially good. I get local meat that isn't pumped with liquids. Prepared simply and cooked all day. Ready to sear when I get home from work.I've also used it to keep liquids at 105 for a yeast based batter.I haven't mentioned seafood - I will try it, but feel that broiling or grilling will still be my preference for that. The utility of this is clearly geared to meats. Some people use it to achieve the perfect egg, something else that isn't my thing.My latest adventure was a local grass-fed sirloin tip. Seasoned with old bay and pepper, it cooked for 48 hours at 131. Sliced thin and served cold, it was quite a treat for a weekday meal.The design is perfectly utilitarian. It's a simple concept, and they didn't over-complicate it. The appliance looks fine enough to leave out, and is light enough (without water!) to pull in and out of a cabinet. The handle placement is perfect for pouring out the water.It's not a panacea. You still need good ingredients and a sense of proportion in use of spices. Generally, less spice is better. If you use something permeating like Cumin seed, better to count the seeds (like 5).Regarding the Ziploc/Foodsaver debate, I don't see much difference. Ziplocs do leak some of the aroma, but that's not a bad thing, is it? I use vacpacs for smaller items, especially because I have a lot of them. A 3 lb chicken fit nicely in a 2 gallon Ziploc. I do recommend keeping the zipper draped over the side just in case you didn't zip it perfectly.There's lots of info on the web, if you're looking for some guidance on a particular cut. At least you can see what other people have tried. Google 'Dave Arnold' for some Culinary fun.Some people balk at the price. I don't agree, considering there is no competition at the consumer level. I'm not saying it's a bargain, but either is a Kitchenaid mixer. What does a Kitchenaid do? It saves you time and gives you consistent results. That's the way I look at this Low Temp Cooker.  The ability to do Sous Vide in my own kitchen has changed the way I think about cooking and meal planning. It allows me to focus on the other dishes and not worry about timing the meat. It allows me to serve meals on a weeknight that would otherwise not be possible. Assuming it lasts a long time, it will be money well spent.

Like others have said, it works well the first time. Maybe the second or third, if you're lucky. I'm not sure what the point is.For a semi-permanent sign I guess it would be more professional looking. Since you leave the backing on, you get little or no show-through. At a 1.20 a sheet, you've got to want that bad. Otherwise, I see little advantage to these over plain paper and careful use of tape.

The title says it all. I'm using a 3+ year old Inspiron. Read and write at 8X. 100 successful burns in a row.And I don't even like Memorex. Their electronics are Walmart quality junk. But these work for me.Edit 2/1/13: OK, I've just checked my history. I'm about to buy my 7th order of these. I've had maybe a couple of coasters, but I'm not even sure they were the disc's fault. I've used several computers, some old, some new. But always the same software: CloneCD. I use a low write speed, and just don't have a problem. Hope it stays that way.

You get what you pay for sometimes, and this is one of them. But if you're expecting quality cookware at this price, I've got a bridge for sale.Still, I could see some virtue in this pan. Camping maybe. Or if all you care about is price.In my case, this caught my eye because I wanted an 11" square pan for my toaster oven. I like to to biscuits, etc., without using the big oven. So I bought this as an experiment. I drilled out the handle rivets, and it fits well in my Cuisinart TOB-60 Convection Toaster Oven Broiler. Since I'm not using it on the direct heat of the stove, I think it will do just fine for my modded application.I've attached a couple of photos.

There are a lot of light duty brakes out there. But this is the first one I found that seemed heavy duty enough for me, without going to that next level in the thousands of dollars. It's made with pretty thick steel - 10 MM in most places where it counts. I only work with SS -  I've bent some 16 and 18 gauge without trouble. Twelve gauge I scored first.The adjustments for the Press Plate are easy and seem to have enough precision. I give it 4 stars for it's overall design and strength. The precision of the build is about what you expect from some unknown Chinese factory, maybe even a little better.But:I bought mine as an assembled floor display - I could mostly see what I was getting but for the thick red paint. If you've ever bought HF tools, etc., you know that it can be a bit of a gamble.The one problem I had with mine is after a few uses, a weld on the Press Plate Stabilizer broke. I could have chalked it up to abuse, except when I cleaned the paint off the weld area I discovered deep rust. The kind you get from leaving a piece of steel outside for the winter.Despite that, I still think it deserves 4 stars. For the money, it's a solid tool. The quality control of any particular bender is something you can only judge when it's in your hands.For adjustments, you'll need a 13, 17, 18, and 24MM wrench. The 24 you might as well buy hereTEKTON 21411 24mm Combination Wrench. It's not a common size to find in your local tool store, and a standard set only goes up to 19.

About 5 miles from my house this morning, at about 50 MPH, something hit my windshield. I wondered what it was for a second. But when I got to work, I went OH NO!Left my Optimus S on the hood of my car last night.With the help of SeekDroid, my wonderful wife wandered along the highway and found it in about 3 minutes. She couldn't hear the alarm because of the traffic, but it pinpointed it on Google Maps right along the edge of the shoulder.Unscathed, also thanks to this inexpensive case: Green Silicone Skin / Case / Cover for LG Optimus S LS670 / Optimus U / Optimus V VM670What else can I say? Worth every penny.

First let me say that I'm not an 'athlete'. Nor am I a huge fan of earbuds. Also, when I think of Monster, I think of the company that convinced people a $100 HDMI cable is really worth it.I waited a while to do this review, for a short plane trip to test them out. Of course they did not block sound as well as my active noise canceling headphones, but they were adequate for listening to my ipod on a 90 minute flight. They were also quite comfortable. I ended up not using any of the Sportclips, but with the right tip it stayed in by ears. I'm not sure if the little swivel adjustent really helped, but they are the most comfortable earbuds yet. The sound is decent, and the case holds my Nano as well. I've had a few other brands with replaceable tips, which turned into loseable tips. These tips feel like they will stay on and not disappear.The controller worked well with my Nano, and surprised me when I held a button ( I never read instructions), and a strange voice said "Billy Strayhorn Rain Check"As for value - I got these as a VINE item. I had no idea of the cost until I went to write this review. Are these really 15 times better than $10 earbuds. Will they last 15 times longer in harsh environments. I'm not the one to judge that. I see that these are not the most expensive earbuds you can buy, So I'm clearly out of the zeitgeist. I spent $1200 for a coffee maker, so I guess $150 earbuds aren't too outrageous.

These scissors are light heavyweights. You're not cutting chicken bones, after all. You don't have to be an idiot savant to get these, the secret to peeling shrimp is no longer an open secret.Seriously, they're not for deboning or cutting coins. But they are sturdy and precise enough to warrant a spot in your kitchen drawer. You might find yourself snipping herbs and practicing origami. I haven't tested them on crabs. But they made easy work on 14 -16 count Jumbo Shrimp. Much cleaner than my standard deveining tool.If you're finding it hardly easy to decide, just buy it.Sight unseen.

I've had this drill for over 2 years. I had one of the same issues as reviewer Martin Snider - I almost broke my wrist a couple of times. I work mostly in SS, and this drill gets a lot of abuse. I've left it out in the rain occasionally. My wife uses it with a 3" bulb bit to plant bulbs. It comes back to me filthy - I hose it off and keep on going.I've dropped it more than a few times. Eventually the tab broke that holds the battery in. I can't blame PC for that. Using plastic epoxy, I refashioned the tab and it'd good as new.I know that Lithium cells are all the rage. I have a Hitachi DS10DFL 12-Volt Peak Li-Ion 2-Speed Drill/Driver, and it's great too. But this Porter Cable drill has pretty much eliminated my need to pull an electric (you know, actually plug in) drill out of the tool box. Only when I need a hammer drill. The battery life is starting to fade a little, but not much. With 2 batteries, it's never been an issue.Finally, the service: When I brought this home, the charger light did not indicate it was charging. I called customer service, and they had a new one on the way in the time it took to give them my name and address. Hassle free service. Can't beat that.I hope Santa brings me a new one. Then I'll let the old one spend it's retirement as a deburring tool by the drill press.

My daughter is away for college. I can shell out $16 and 2 days later she gets a note saying there's a package for her. Big smiles and a grateful text message home to papa.I'd rather she eat these than random junk food while staying up late. Plus, plenty to spare for her roommates.Thanks Amazon, for making my life as a college parent easier.

This is a beautiful necklace at an unbelievable price!  When I saw the picture, I immediately fell in love with it, but for the price...I really didn't have high expectations.  When I got the necklace in the mail and opened it, to my shock, the necklace was even more beautiful in person than it was in the pictures!  The colors are gorgeous and vibrant and it feels well-made - I'm not at all worried about the various stones falling off (like I've worried about on some necklaces in the past).  I think this necklace is going to be a great addition to some of my outfits...and I know that it will be bringing compliments!  I received this product at a discounted rate in exchange for my honest review.

Impressive product for a great price!  I can't believe how inexpensive it was to get this attractive set of paper photo frames in three different colors (black, white, and brown) with the twine and colored clothespins to hang the photo frames.  The set is gorgeous and great decoration - absolutely beautiful hanging in my guest room.  I used various colored magazine cutouts to put in the frames to add an extra color pop to the bedroom and think that it did an amazing job at adding extra flare to an otherwise boring wall.  If you are even considering this product, I would definitely take the jump and make the purchase, you won't be disappointed!  I received this product at a discounted rate in exchange for my honest review.

I'm impressed by the temperature aspect of this water bottle - touch the cap to see the temperature of the liquid inside.  I thought that this was an impressive and unique aspect that puts this water bottle above others.  If you find that a certain temperature is perfect, then you can continually have your liquid (coffee, tea, whatever!) reach that temperature prior to drinking so you can be completely satisfied!  The water bottle includes an infuser - put fruit in the infuser to give your water an added bump of flavor (personally, my favorite to add is strawberries!).  This insulated water bottle is reported to keep cold liquids cold for 24 hours and hot liquids hot for 12 hours.  Although I can't personally attest to either since my liquids don't last that long, I can say that the cold/hot has stayed until I've finished my drink without issues!  As the company reports, I've not had any issues with condensation or leaking either, which is definitely a win.One issue I do have is that the temperature only shows in Celsius...I wish it had an option to change between Celsius and Fahrenheit so I could choose how I want to view the temperature of the contents.  I received this product for free in exchange for my honest review.

As other customers have said, it's very important that you look at the sizing information to make sure you order your needed size - you WILL need to size up as these are not the standard US sizes.  If you look at the sizing information and you order as you should, you shouldn't have any issues...unfortunately, I ordered the largest size available and they didn't fit me (and I'm VERY sad about this), but this is no fault of NEOSAN.  When I received the underwear, I was immediately impressed with the quality - these felt like comfortable and breathable fabric and look absolutely stunning.  I really wish these would have worked for me, but since they didn't, I passed them on to someone that they would fit - and they said that they are in LOVE with these underwear!  They are impressed with how beautiful, comfortable, and breathable these underwear are...and the lace is seriously gorgeous!  NEOSAN, please make larger sizes so I can order me a set of these gorgeous underwear!  I received this product for free in exchange for my honest review.

This necklace is gorgeous...the color is insanely beautiful and it's the perfect size as I love large, bulky, and beautiful accent pieces!  I didn't expect it to be this beautiful for so inexpensive.  The chain is strong/secure, the necklace feels well-made, and I seriously think the color is incredibly gorgeous in person.  When wearing this necklace, you are sure to receive tons of compliments!  I received this necklace at a discounted rate in exchange for my honest review.

Super beautiful necklace!  I didn't know what to expect for such a reasonable price and was happy to see that this necklace feels so high quality and looks so perfect in person!  The colors are gorgeous, the necklace is perfectly constructed, the chain feels strong/secure, and I love how delicate, elegant, and beautiful this is.  I have received so many compliments on this necklace!  I received this necklace at a discounted rate in exchange for my honest review.

I bought this as a gag gift for my sister for Christmas and am definitely not disappointed!  Price is great and this "Poop Emoji" is super soft, well-made, and doesn't smell like it looks (LUCKILY).  I think this will be a huge hit at Christmas and that she will definitely get a good laugh out of getting this emoji for Christmas!  High quality pillow that is actually surprisingly comfortable.  Lol.  I received this product at a discounted rate in exchange for my honest review.

Handles are perfect on my side tables.  They look exactly as I expected and were a good price for a good product.  These don't feel cheap and...were definitely inexpensive!  Color is as shown in the pictures.

Low quality and not what I expected based on the pictures.  I had hoped that these would be a great addition to my nephew's toy collection, but these are very cheaply made, easily break, and were a disappointment overall.  Some of the pieces were not even cut properly.  I received these products for free in exchange for my honest review.

I wear a size 22 in jeans and the Queen size fishnets fit without issue!  I've bought tons of tights in the past that said they would fit...but they didn't (highly disappointing!), but this pair fit perfectly.

Very pretty crown that feels well-made and impressive quality for under $17!  Looks gorgeous in person.  Only docked one star since I didn't realize that it wouldn't come with something to keep it on my head!

This is exactly what I expected, especially at this price.  Super cheap and works great as part of my Halloween costume!  I'll agree that this isn't the highest quality; however, at this price, the quality is exactly what I thought it would be.

Super cute bar stools at a reasonable price.  The bar stools are modern in appearance and feel high quality.  The bar stools were also really easy to assemble - only just a few steps!  No regrets regarding purchasing these awesome bar stools!

For $3.99, this cosmetic bag is decent quality.  The color and pattern are pretty, although it does appear a little blurry and doesn't look super sharp.  I'm a huge fan of floral so that is one major plus that this cosmetic bag offers!  On top of being pretty, this cosmetic bag is waterproof and will be easy to wipe clean - which is a major plus for a cosmetic bag since you never know what might spill in (or on) the bag.  Easily opens and closes.  One small downside is that the bag really won't hold much, only the bare essentials.  I received this product for free in exchange for my honest review.

Great, high quality baking/cooling rack at an expected price range.  When you spend this price on a baking/cooling rack, you expect it to be good quality and this definitely meets expectations.  When I went to order this backing/cooling rack, my husband stated that he has been buying them at the dollar store and didn't see a reason to purchase this one - then I reminded him how many of those cheap ones we may go through when we can instead spend more and get a higher quality item.  He agreed that this is the better option!  Baking/cooling rack feels well-made, heavy duty, and I have no worries about it breaking in the future.  I received this product at a discounted rate in exchange for my honest review.

The headphones look nice in person - I received the red pair and the coloring really does look nice; however, they don't feel like they are the best quality and, as other reviewers have said, these will definitely not fit my nephew (four years old) that I purchased them for.  The tightest setting fits my head...and I don't have the smallest head.  The star on one side was already scratched and the red could be seen.  If this happened prior to me even receiving them, I have to wonder how well they would hold up to being used by children (who aren't notorious for taking good care of things).  I think these headphones would be more accurately described as being good for TEENAGERS (not children) and only to play around with, not as well-made, high quality headphones.  I wore for a short time and I do think they are fairly comfortable, but the ear pads (and all other aspects of the headphones) really do feel cheap.  I understand that at this price range you can't expect perfection (and that's why I gave the product three stars), but I do think there are probably better options out there at this price.In addition to some of the other issues discussed, my husband also noted that, when at the smallest setting, they fit awkwardly on the head because spacing and angles are incorrect.  Also, I think it would better if buyers could CHOOSE the color they want instead of getting a random color.  I received this product at a discounted rate in exchange for my honest review.***Color does not show accurately in the pictures.  Red in person.

All of these look super cute in the pictures, but I just had to get it in the "Crochet Burgundy" option!  I am incredibly glad that I ordered this one as it is cute and is going to be perfect to add to many of my fall outfits - I've already been brainstorming great options for outfits around this new scarf!  On top of this looking beautiful, it is also going to add some much needed warmth as the winter months approach!  This scarf is soft, warm, and beautiful.Crochet scarf is 100% Pashmina, thick, and warm!  It's also a great size - 53" around and 11" wide. Great gift idea for the tea lover(s) in your life!  (Apparently, according to this Amazon page, Mr. Tea fell in love with Mrs. Tea and both got married...so maybe these will be best for the lovers!) I never really thought about buying a "bracelet box" and honestly didn't even know Amazon would have them that could be purchased (well, I should have known though since you can buy EVERYTHING on Amazon!). I am an organization fanatic and most people close to me know my obsession with storage boxes!  With that being said, I usually focus on purchasing inexpensive boxes so I can get several instead of spending $20+ on one storage box. The storage box also feels very well-made and heavy duty (I wouldn't worry about it messing up anytime soon!).If the price was lower, I would definitely be giving this storage box five stars, but since I would hesitate purchasing because of the price, I can't justify five stars - although this is a fantastic storage box, don't get me wrong! My husband has been working outside a lot lately and I worry about his body temperature rising and worry about heat-related risks as he does this.  I was excited to get a chance to test out this cooling towel to see if this could help keep his body temperature down while working outside in the heat (80 and 90 degree F days!).  The cooling towel is easy to use - all you have to do is soak it in cold water, ring out the excess, and it's good to go!  I am impressed with how long the towel stays cold and it gives me some piece of mind as he is outside working in the heat.  In addition, he's reported that this helps him stay cool for an extended amount of time before having to re-wet it.  Although the product has worked well, I do think that the towel could be manufactured to look more appealing - like another reviewer stated, mine also has rough edges and isn't completely even.  I received this product at a discounted rate in exchange for my honest review.

I previously reviewed another Pleson Qi Wireless Charger and I'm just as impressed with this one as I was the previous!  Since my husband and I both own the Samsung Galaxy S6, I wanted to make sure that we had plenty of these chargers laying around - two in the bedroom and one in various other rooms of the house...and additional for traveling.  Maybe we don't *need* that many wireless chargers, but having that many is definitely something I get excited about!Just like the other Pleson I tested out, this one works fantastic.  I lay my phone on the charger and it immediately begins charging without issue.  I did not notice any heat issues with extended use and I did not have to move my phone around repeatedly to find the charging "sweet spot" like I've had to do on other Qi Wireless Chargers.  The wireless charger has a nice modern look and is lightweight (without feeling cheap).  I would definitely recommend this wireless charger to others!  I received this product a discounted rate in exchange for my honest review.

My husband was so excited when I showed him this Helicopter Landing Pad!  My husband has a small (or...large) obsession with remote controlled helicopters/drones/everything. These baby bandanas are so cute, soft, and stylish!  I was initially interested because of the appearance of these bandanas - the ducks and bears are so adorable! My husband enjoys a specific brand of water and, since the company is in the same city as we are, he can get his hands on the large jugs of water. I suffer from knee pain at times and am always happy to try something out that can help relieve any of the aches and pains that I experience on a semi-regular basis.  I had never tried a knee strap before, but was happy to test it out and see how well it would work for me.  I was immediately impressed with the quality - I can tell that the product is well-made, but also felt soft and didn't make my knee area sweaty when wearing it while moving furniture.  I did notice that I seemed to have less pressure on my knee (maybe the tendon underneath?) and my knee didn't get as sore as it normally does during high levels of physical assertion.  It felt flexible, moved well with my body, and fit my legs without issue (which isn't always possible when you're a thick-legged girl like me).  I think this would fit a wide range of leg widths without issue.  Overall, great quality and did notice pressure reduction...hoping with extended use I'll notice even less knee aches! Even though we try our best to give our dogs regular baths, I have to admit that occasionally they probably go a little longer than they should!  Although they don't normally have an odor issue, there are some times where they start to smell more like a *gasp* dog!  When this occurs, I might not always have time to give one of my precious pups a bath...but I also don't want that stink all in my bed...so what to do?  That's why I'm a fan of odor eliminators that can be sprayed on my dogs to reduce odor issues (yes, I know...baths would work too, but sometimes life is rushed!).My little girl Papillon wasn't particularly smelly today, but I decided to give her a spray of the Tangerine Tree Natural Daily Odor Eliminating Spray to see how well it would work...and I must say that it smells fantastic!  Thank goodness I can spray this on my dogs without it smelling "chemically" or unsafe for them.  The smell wasn't overpowering at all, which is another major plus in my book.On top of smelling great and eliminating odors (both on my dogs and off!), I am really impressed that it is 100% plant and mineral based, natural blend that is non-toxic, eco-friendly, hypoallergenic, and safe for my "furbabies"...I'm not using anything directly on them that doesn't fall in these categories.  I also have a male Papillon with sensitive skin issues and I feel confident that this would be great for him as well!  I received this product at a discounted rate in exchange for my honest review.

Overall, this is a really good value - you get a decent case with a clip, a stylus, a screen protector, and a cloth to wipe the screen...all for only $9.99!  Seriously, good luck finding another set at that price that includes all of THAT.  For someone looking for phone accessories at a reasonable price, this set will not disappoint.  The case fit the Galaxy S6 perfectly and was easy to put on and remove from the phone.  The "kickstand" on the back of the phone case was sturdy and held the phone up without issue.  It was also easy to pull out and put back into place.  As far as protection goes, I would think it would offer a decent amount of protection for most everyday issues that may arise, but I wouldn't throw it around in this case or run over it to check quality. I received this product for free in exchange for my honest review.

Very impressive!  I'm a huge fan of organization and of any products that can help me keep things that go together in the same area.  This vertical stand has really been a winner for me - I stand the PS4 on its side which takes up less space and I can put the controllers on the stand as well to keep them next to the PS4 (and it makes it where they have a designated spot to go after use!).  Also, it charges the controllers as well, which is fantastic since I have a history of using controllers until they are dead before taking time to charge them.  With this, they charge every time that I finish using them and place them on the dock!  Just in case I forget to place them on the charging stand, it also has four USB ports on the front (easily accessible!) in case I need to plug the controller in via USB cord.Overall, I love it!  Organizes while charging without taking away from the modern look of the PS4.  This is a great stand/charging dock that keeps everything in one place without distracting from how great the PS4 looks.  I was also impressed by the fact that the controllers fit so perfectly on the stand that when you put them in their designated spot, they controllers are immediately plugged in.My only downside (although it wasn't enough to dock a star) is how bright the blue power light is on the front of the stand.  Oh my god, it lights up the entire room!  Making sure that everything is turned off before going to bed is a must as the light is so bright that I'd never be able to sleep if it was visible.  I do think future purchasers would appreciate the brightness of the light being significantly toned down!  I received this product at a discounted price in exchange for my honest review.

Been using this lotion for years and very happy that Amazon now carries it. I use this together with the Eczema calming cream when the air is especially dry and the Aquaphor. I even use it on my face and people are surprised when I tell them. They think I use some expensive moisturizer.

Got this at a bargain price of $25. The text isn't appealing at first look but it is actually well-organized and tackles problems pretty straightforward. Lots of sample problems. The workbook is a must-have.I have an Engineering background so Math is a piece of cake but I have older classmates that are quite challenged with simple Math and they tell me that this book is quite helpful.
Lots of practice problems and there's an answer key provided at the back so you can check if you're on the right track.
I gave this as a Christmas present to a friend who loves turtles. She loved it!
For $35, this speaker set is a gem. Now I enjoy playing Pandora while I work on something on the computer. It wad easy to hook up, too.

I saw this on tv last night. Unfortunately I did not see the very beginning where it must have said that the show is fictional. The scientist's account of his experience at the dead zone at the Algerian desert piqued my interest. However, as it went on, it started sounding weird and scripted. Comcast listed it as a "documentary," so I thought I would stick it out until the end. It was a 2-hour show that ended at midnight and I struggled to stay awake (it was a weeknight). I only wish that I had googled the show sooner and so have gone to bed sooner. I am a fan of the X-files and sci-fi but this show was marketed as a documentary by none other than "History" Channel so it was really disappointing and a total waste of time. I am pissed. History should stop making shows like this and leave it to SyFy.
Exactly as advertized. Great replacement, couldn't find anything like this in local stores like Lowe's and Home Depot.

The Nook HD has a 7 inch screen which is considerably a big surface, so it was somewhat difficult to install this film without getting some lint underneath. I ended up with a few trapped underneath but whatever. They can't be seen when the Nook is on, thank goodness. The anti-glare is great and it actually makes swiping the screen much easier, both by hand or with a stylus.

Great roomy bag with 3 equal size compartments. I'm able to fit my Nikon D60 in the center compartment with the 18-55mm lens attached, the 55-200mm zoom lens on one compartment and accessories on the other. The bag has 2 front pockets, 2 side and 1 back. It has no emblems on it so it could be mistakenly thought of  as a lunch bag. Great camera bag for a great price!
Nice product but it requires the permanent removal of the shoulder strap. I needed the shoulder strap more so had to return this.

Got this for my Nikon D60. It wouldn't work no matter what I did with my camera. I found the exact same one at ebay from a Chinese seller for only 99 cents so I decided to try that. Guess what, it worked! So if it wouldn't work the first time, have it replaced.

This lens is gray market (from Hongkong) but works just as well as the US version. The seller offers warranty but NikonUSA doesn't for gray market items. So if this is a big deal for you, don't buy this.

Thick fluffy pillows have always given me a strained neck so I find this pillow perfect for me. The thinner edge measures only 3.5 inches high and slopes up gently. I wish it's a little wider than 12 inches, though. The 20-inch length for queen is fine. I first got the My Humble Abode brand which is similar, but firmer than this, but that one was even smaller both in length and width so I decided on keeping this pillow instead.
