This bag is roomy & pretty sturdy. Every week I put my 75-lb GSD to work. We go shopping for produce which is a 15 min walk and she happily carries the veggies home for me. We both end up having a good day! She also carries her & our water on hikes as well as other stuff that would fit.

I bought it due to its adjustability but it's too flat (horizontal) for me. Even after the removal of the top layers, I still felt my neck propped at an awkward angle. I prefer the contoured kind with a slight angle (made by Sleep Innovations) which happens to be half the price of this one.  The company has a great return policy.
Great for 1 serving smoothies. I used to not make smoothies as much because of the cleanup. Best christmas gift to myself. Haha
Great but sadly does not work with Nikon D60.

My husband was having trouble with the 569 jeans because of the inconsistent sizing but these ones are true to size. He absolutely loves it and wants to buy more. The deep lichen green looks khaki in the photos but it's actually olive green. I hope levi's comes up with khaki ones.

My husband calls this pillow a brick but I actually like it. It doesn't feel like laying on a pillow but curiously it makes me sleep real good and wake up free of any kind of neck pain. FYI, I'm not a fan of high firm pillows. What I don't like about it is it's too tiny - length and width-wise. During the night I unconsciously raise my arm over my head and because the pillow is too small, I bang my hand on the headboard and startle my husband. If the manufacturer is reading this, please make a proper queen size pillow. Sadly, I decided to return it because of the size. $29 is also too much for such a tiny pillow.For those who want a bigger one, I found the Linenspa brand queen size to be similar. I got it for $15.
My HP 110 mini wouldn't charge and I thought it was broken. All it needed was this charger! Great value.

I have a 4 year old German Shepherd who's always been addicted to walking fast. She knows "heel" but she prefers to walk ahead of me. I learned about the slip leash from watching the Dog Whisperer and I've been using a double-handle leash as one. My dog is much easier to control as long as the leash is at the top of her neck but it tends to slide down after a minute or so and then she'll start pulling again. What's so nice about this leash is it has a sliding leather that keeps the leash in place at the top of my dog's neck. It is also thick, smooth and soft. It doesn't chafe my hands like some nylon leashes do. The color is a nice olive green. I liked it so much that I got another one for my brother's GS puppy.

Really glad to find a matte screen protector. There are 3 pieces in a pack but I used only 1. It is VERY easy to apply. I cleaned the screen thoroughly with the cloth provided and then removed the bottom film of the screen protector. I laid it down slowly onto the GPS screen from right to left, smoothing out air bubbles as I did so. I did not even use a credit card to remove bubbles. Very nice product. No one can tell that the screen protector is there.

I've been training my 3-year old out-of-control German Shepherd to heel and her old leash would chafe my hands. I love that this thing has the short leash built in because it is much more comfortable to hold during our walks. When we're out walking in the woods this leash works great with a harness. The material is also very soft and not abrasive at all.

My husband got the Campingaz single burner from REI back in his backpacking days. Unfortunately, REI has stopped carrying Campingaz entirely. We're glad we found it here. We went camping for a week recently and we used the burner everyday for breakfast and for boiling water for coffee. We didn't finish 1 canister which is great.

I have an energetic 65lb 3-year old German Shepherd who has always loved to pull until one day she dragged me onto the ground when she saw a couple yappy little dogs. So I said, that's it, I have to be the pack leader a la Cesar Millan. The past couple of weeks I've been using Cesar's techniques on her (and on my husband!) and I must say she's improved a great deal. No more walking on a long leash and sniffing and peeing whenever and wherever she wants. Now that she has learned to heel, there's really no more need for a 6-foot leash so I switched to this one. It is not as pictured but it works well. The material is very thick and is comfortable to hold. It's great to use with a regular collar but since my dog still isn't a 100% well-behaved walker (she lapses to her old wild ways when she sees small yappy dogs), I use it with the Premier Pet Gentle Leader Headcollar, Black, Large. As I've learned, these products don't work magic on dogs. We have to train them and these products only complement the training.

I crave donuts every now and then but since I'm in my 30's I have to watch what I eat. I researched how to make baked cake donuts and yeast-raised ones. You don't really need a pan for the yeast-raised but they do tend to flatten out at the bottom so this pan addresses that problem. The pan is so easy to wash by hand and stack nicely with each other. For a batch of donuts (2 cups of flour), I use 3 pans.

The ceramic pot looks small but it holds a little over 2 cups of liquid or a fondue recipe with 16oz of cheese. The instructions say that it should be immersed in water for 2 hours before use. I don't know if it's a one-time thing or it has to be done before EACH use. Since it's not a lot of work, I immerse it in water before each use just to be safe. There are holes at the base of the feet where water can get into the interior of the pot - which is probably what prevents the pot from cracking due to heat.I cook the fondue in a nonstick pot and transfer it in the ceramic fondue pot just before serving. The tea light does a good job of keeping the fondue hot and in the liquid state. Even with the traditional Swiss fondue pots, cheese tends to burn/form a ball close to the heat source, so I give the fondue a little swirl with my bread every now and then. In the end, my husband and I were able to eat only half of the fondue - so this size pot can definitely feed 4 people. I covered the leftover fondue (still in the ceramic pot) with a cling wrap and stored it in the fridge. To eat it again, I heated the entire thing in the microwave a minute at a time, 2 to 3 times, giving it a swirl with a spoon after each minute.

This is my first hard anodized pan and I am very impressed. It does not scratch easily like regular nonstick teflon pans. The size is perfect for cooking for 2 to 4 people. There is no helper handle but not a big deal. I just use a mitt on that side so I could carry the pan with both hands. It hangs too which is great. I am Asian so I do stir-fry's a lot. I am not a big deep-fryer but whenever I do, I stick with cast-iron. I got this pan with an open-box deal so I'm very happy. I could see this pan lasting a really long time. I use a silicone ladle all the time.

The standard size fit my 2003 VW Passat perfectly but I returned it because it does not filter out much sun. My husband uses a similar blue-colored one for his truck and it does a better job of keeping the interior cooler and darker. The silver is a bad idea because it reflects the sunlight into the interior. I sat behind the wheel while the sunshade was on and I felt I needed sunglasses. So I went back to using an accordion sunshade.VW's have uniquely-sized windshields but I found this one which fits pretty nicely: Auto Shade - Zebra White

I got this cover because I park my 2003 VW Passat in my driveway and it gets dusty pretty fast. Aside from that, leaves from neighbors' trees get in the trim of the windows, doors and windshield. I also see a lot of yellow spots...until now I don't know if it's from tree pollen or bird poop. I would have liked a waterproof cover but the price is outrageous so I settled for this one. During the rainy season I plan to just keep the car uncovered.I did not know there was a marking on the front end of the cover which says "Front." So after taking it out of the box, lay it out first inside your house to locate the marking. That simple step will make life easier. There's a string included in the bag but I did not even use it because the elastic hem was enough to keep the cover firmly in place. We had a really windy night right after I put the cover on but the next morning the cover was still there.***UPDATE: 08/15/2013: I really liked how this cover fits on my car but sadly, after only 1 month I began noticing a significant thinning of the material. Eventually, it started shedding powdery lint. The last straw was when it ripped on several spots on the roof area while I was putting it back on the car. I emailed Budge customer service and they were very helpful. I was instructed to send in my invoice along with a cutout of the label/tag. In less than 2 weeks I got the replacement. Sad thing is it will happen again because this cover just can't stand outdoor conditions.

Good quality and easy to install. I don't really like rolling the window all the way down so this is perfect. It's fine mesh so even if the window is rolled only 2-3 inches down, it still lets a lot of air in. Does not obscure blind spots too. I don't know why people complain that it does not completely block out sun. If it's too opaque that you can't see out, then you'll get in trouble with the law!

I have a 2003 VW Passat which has a peculiar size windshield (27x50 inches). Most sunshades for sedans that I've seen were under 24 inches in length. I found Amico 50.8" x 27.6" Car Rear Window Reflective Bubble Aluminum Foil Sunshade which looks just right but it ships from Hongkong and has no Amazon guarantee. So at the end I chose this one which is slightly bigger but has a nicer design and ships from CA. I live in northern CA so I got it in the mail in just 4 days. It fits perfectly in my windshield, however, the rearview mirror sits a little low so I couldn't tuck the center V portion of the sunshade beneath it. So I just put the 2 visors down to keep the sunshade propped up. Overall, for the price and quality, I'm very satisfied. Even my husband likes it.

My husband is prone to back pains and he has the 36-inch which he uses in the house.  I got him the foot-long one so he could keep it in the car and be able to use it wherever he is. For $10 it's so worth it. It's well made too.

I'm so glad I found this product. I couldn't find it anywhere else, even Petco. My German shepherd dog already has a harness so I really don't need the harness car strap that is quite expensive. This one is great because it's $5 and the fact that one end inserts into the seat belt slot is really cool. Now I keep it inserted in the slot all the time. I just unclip my dog's harness when she gets out and clip it back when she gets back in. It's so hassle-free. I highly recommend it for dogs who like to walk/crawl all over the place. It prevents her from jumping onto the front seats too and most importantly, from falling down and getting hurt on sudden stops.I got this seat liner for her too which works really well: Back Seat Pet Hammock, Black By Zone Tech.

I recently bought a sedan with leather seats which my German shepherd can easily puncture and rip. She drags a lot of mud and dirt as well when I take her out running. I must say this pet hammock does a really good job of taking care of those problems. Hair does escape the hammock but I vacuum the interior once a month anyway so it's not a big deal.There are no instructions but it's easy to figure out from the pictures. The short side obviously attaches to the back of the front seats. There are 2 disks that you insert in the back seats so the hammock stays in place. I must say the 4 corners of the hammock do not stay in place like in the photo. They droop because there's no means of attaching them onto the top of the seats.My dog likes to walk/crawl all over the place so I got her a leash seat belt as well (P26o Adjustable Pet Cat Dog Safety Leads Car Seat Belt). It prevents her from jumping onto the front seats (the hammock can't prevent that if the dog is really determined). With her strapped in, she's content to rest her head on the edge of the hammock in between the front seats.I have never washed the hammock since getting it. There was a new nylon smell at the beginning but it went away after a couple of trips with the windows open. I give it a good shake after each trip to get dirt and some hair off and that's it. When my dog is really muddy, I wipe her off with a towel first before I let her in the car.

Very sturdy and well-made cast iron wok. I followed the instructions for seasoning and the wok came out golden brown. I followed one reviewer's suggestion to heat up water in it to remove the waxy substance. To save gas, I filled the wok 3/4 full with water and placed it in the oven while it was preheating. By the time the oven reached 450 degrees, I could see the wax mixed in the water. I brushed it after that (no soap) and then I coated it with a thin layer of vegetable oil. The oven would smoke even if you use only a thin layer of oil so I lined the bottom of my oven with foil to catch the drippings. I think I seasoned it pretty good because after a wash, I let it drip in the sink for a couple minutes and then wipe it off with a paper towel. I don't even bother coating it with oil anymore. Of course, I never use soap/dish detergent. A good soak and brushing would do.I have cooked rice noodles in it and didn't experience sticking or any other problems. Like any other cast iron utensil, it takes awhile to heat up but once it is hot, it stays hot. I am sure this wok would outlive me.

I bought this grate for stovetop use. It fits nicely atop my stove burner. I use it for grilling veggies that don't drip like eggplant and zucchini. I love grilled veggies but if I don't have meat to grill at the same time, then I don't feel it's worth firing up the gas grill outside. It takes awhile for the grate to heat up but once it's hot, the veggies cook up pretty quick.

Bought this replacement bowl for my KitchenAid KSM75WH Classic Plus Tilt-Head 4-1/2-Quart Stand Mixer, White during an online home sale at Sears for only $34. I think it flares out more than the original so it has a bigger diameter. It is nice to have the handle which the original bowl doesn't have. Now I can make cookie dough days ahead and bake a bunch of goodies all at one time.

I bought this product based on reviews. I have also read that calcium citrate is the most absorbable form of calcium. I have been taking these pills for a month now and I'm hoping that they are indeed doing what they are supposed to do. It doesn't say anywhere in the label that it has to be taken with meals but for me, I've found out that if I take it with an empty stomach, it makes my stomach churn and I feel nauseous. It gives me diarrhea too. If I take it with meals, though, none of that happens. For the price and quality, I think this is the best Calcium pills in the market right now.Info from Costco site:Supplement Facts:Serving Size: 2 TabletsServings Per Container: 125Two Tablets Contain - % Daily Value:Vitamin D3 800 I.U. - 200%, Vitamin B6 10 mg - 500%, Calcium 500 mg - 50%, Magnesium 80 mg - 20%, Zinc 10 mg - 66%, Copper 1 mg - 50%, Manganese 1 mg - 50%, Boron 1 mg - **.**Daily Value not established.Ingredients:Calcium Citrate, Cellulose Gel, Magnesium Oxide, Talc, Hydroxypropyl Methylcellulose, Croscarmellose Sodium, Titanium Dioxide (artificial color), Pyridoxine Hydrochloride, Magnesium Stearate, Zinc Oxide, Vitamin D3 (Cholecalciferol), Mineral Oil, Sodium Borate, Manganese Gluconate, Cupric Gluconate, Triethyl Citrate, Polyethylene Glycol, Corn Starch, Polysorbate 80, Soybean Oil, Carnauba Wax.

My high school nephew introduced me to this book while we were out shopping one day. I thought the book was funny so I bought one online. I've had the book for over a month now but I still haven't finished it. I only read it on those days when I have to kill time, i.e., waiting in line at DMV, airport terminal, etc. This book is perfect for those occasions because it doesn't require my full concentration and it makes me laugh.

I have both the Burgmuller etudes and the Czerny opus 599. However, those books don't really tell you what the etudes are specifically targeting. They are effective but I don't really know what the focus is on. This exercise book addresses exactly that. I'm not a big fan of Hanon but Clarfield chose some of his useful exercises in preparation for a Burgmuller etude. All I can say is it's great. I was at intermediate level when I stopped playing the piano over a decade ago so I'm pretty much picking up where I left off. I don't think this book is appropriate for a beginner.

This 105-page volume contains all 3 opuses by Burgmuller. Normally, each opus costs $8 to $11. Pages are crisp and white and notes are easy to read. Typical Schirmer's look. Very happy with this book!To those unfamiliar with Burgmuller's works, these opuses are etudes which are stand-alone pieces in themselves since they are so melodious. I enjoy playing them so much. I actually heard a CD of Opus 100 and that motivated me to get this book.

I've always liked Schirmer music editions because their layout is always nice and easy to read. However, one reviewer mentioned that this volume is not the absolute complete collection of Songs Without Words. So I compared it with Complete Songs without Words for Piano (Dover Music for Piano) and Schirmer in fact has 49 songs. Dover ("Complete") only has 48.  The 49th song from Schirmer's is the Venetian Boat Song published posthumously. I chose this book over the Dover edition because apart from the notes being bigger, the editor added some helpful fingerings here and there as well as pedal marks. I am not concert pianist caliber so I could definitely benefit from a little editorializing. The Dover book was purely notes from start to finish and contains more music in a page so it's 40 pages less than Schirmers. For my needs and skill level, this book is just perfect.

I have one of these for 2 years now that I bought from Target. I use it to store 5lb of sugar and so far it's worked great. I need one more for oats and I'm happy to see it here in Amazon. It seems a little different, though, from my old one. This one is slightly taller and the latch doesn't work as smoothly. I've seen lots of bad reviews but as with everything else nowadays, sometimes you get lucky sometimes you don't. I'm hoping this canister would last a long time because it looks really pretty and could store over 5lb of dry goods. I have the 4-piece set as well that I've had for a couple years already.

I used Opus 599 when I first learned to play the piano but now that I'm just reacquainting myself with the instrument, I thought I might as try something else. This book contains some exercises from Op.599 but not the particularly nice ones. It is a thick book, 108 pages, so it contains a lot of exercises. Unfortunately, the publisher did not indicate which Opus # each exercise was from. It would have been nice to know. My main gripe about this compilation is that exercises aren't categorized. It's just one exercise after another and there's absolutely no explanation of what the particular exercise is supposed to do. Hopefully, the publisher would improve this because it is a good compilation.

I used Opus 599 when I first learned to play the piano back in highschool. Interestingly, my mom happened to have a copy although she never played the piano and she convinced my teacher to use it on me. My teacher is a proponent of Hanon and I'm so thankful that she agreed to train me on Czerny. I'm sure Hanon is effective but I could never stand it!  The Czerny etudes are very melodic so I have always had fun playing them. Unfortunately, when I went to college and after that started working, I stopped playing piano entirely. Now, 15 years later, I'm home a lot more and my husband bought me a piano! I tried to find the Czerny I used in the past but couldn't. Luckily my mom still has it and she emailed me a photo. It is exactly the same as this version (Schirmer's) except it was published by Carl Fischer - probably out of print already that's why I couldn't find it. Anyway, I highly recommend this book... you won't need anything else. Unlike the super tedious Hanon, it doesn't feel like a drudgery to go through each exercise. I was never able to play this book to the end but now I'm determined to do it. I already have School of Velocity on standby.

My 4-year old Canon Ixus 80IS finally gave up the ghost late last year (after dropping it on the floor many times) and I've been hunting for a good deal on cameras ever since. Unfortunately, I couldn't find the Ixus model here in the US. I researched online and found out that its US equivalent is Powershot ELPH 100 series. I waited (around 6 months) for the price to drop to $102 and then I grabbed it. It's well worth the wait! The pictures are exactly like my old one used to make plus there's quite a number of new features. The body is also thinner, sleeker and lighter which is great! It also uses the same battery as my old one so now I have a backup battery. I have yet to try the HD video and I haven't bought an SDHC card. I tried my old regular SD card, though, and it works fine so far for photos.For $102 this camera is truly a steal! I remember I paid over $300 for the old Ixus back in 2008.

My 3-year old Canon Ixus 80IS finally died late last year (after dropping it on the floor many times) and I was hunting for a good deal on cameras. This model came on sale at Target in November for $80 plus a $10 gift card. I was happy when I took it out of the box... the red color was a nice touch. However, my heart sank as soon as I started taking pictures. Old cameras tend to produce grainy photos at low light settings, but even in a well-lit room the pictures from this camera were so grainy. Dismayed, I returned it to Target and researched the Ixus counterpart in the US, which turned out to be the Powershot ELPH 100 series. I waited (around 6 months) for the price to drop to $102 and then I grabbed it. It's well worth the wait. Stay away from this A2200 piece of junk.

This album contains a nice selection of favorites... however, 2 tracks are the same. The #71. Barcarolle in F Sharp, Op. 60 is the same as #11. Brandenburg Concerto No.3 in G Major - 1st Movement. I already noticed this while I was listening to the samples but I thought Amazon just made a mistake while uploading the samples. I will change my review to 5 stars if Amazon fixes this. I have yet to listen to the entire album and I'm hoping I won't find any other recording errors.
I bought this for my 4-year old underwater camera.  Works great so far and it hasn't died on me while the camera was in use.  It came in brand new packaging. Seller was Beach Camera.

I got the bread fever lately and I thought the baguette was pretty easy to make.  This pan is awesome because it eliminated some steps.  I don't even bother using a cloth.  The bread slides out of the pan when it's done which is great.  The small holes help the bread crisp up real nicely and they make little bumps on the bread which makes them look authentic!  Highly recommended!

Cuts butter quickly, however, the handle rotates when I push down. So I have to keep my forefinger on the top of the screw to stabilize it as I push down.  Other than that it works fine.  I prefer using it over the food processor which blows out flour when I pulse it.

I bought this printer back in October 2010 and I must say that it's a workhorse. No complaints whatsoever. It prints well, photocopies even with the computer off, and scans pretty clear pictures.  I printed my own wedding invitations and programme for almost 100 people and I did not encounter any major problems.  Paper on the thick side, like those fancy ones, do tend to jam the printer but if I do it only 10 at a time, no jamming occurs. The only thing that doesn't work too well is the paper feed tray for the scanning bed.  The copy always comes out crooked so I always place the paper to be scanned onto the bed manually. Not a big deal for me but I can see how this could be an issue for business owners.I recently started seeing the low toner warning and I bought this as a replacement: 104 Toner, 2000 Page-Yield, Black. It works fine so far.
Got this for my Canon ImageCLASS MF4350d Laser All-in-One Printer. It works fine so far and hopefully it lasts longer than the original. Not bad for $10.

I got these tongs as the free item in the 4-for-3 promo.  They get a lot of use during gatherings. Definitely much better than using a spoon.  I also use it for fishing out pickles, roasted peppers and olives out of the bottle.

I bought this snorkel set for our trip to Mexico.  I own another set that I bought 5 years ago and this one's definitely an upgrade.  I read the reviews that the mask is too narrow for taller people but for me it's just right (I'm 5'7").  My husband likes it too.  The lenses also don't fog up easily and I try to keep it that way.  I rinse it right after using and try not to rub it.I got these fins to match: Speedo Adjustable Dive Fin.

I've been baking scones weekly for my husband to eat for breakfast at work and he loves it.  However, scones have a lot of butter in them and I'm worried about my husband's cholesterol intake. I found a healthy apple muffin recipe by Ellie Krieger which is delicious but I needed a variation. This book is perfect! It has 100 kinds of muffins and they're so easy to make.  I do tweak the ingredients a bit to make them healthier, for example, I substitute butter with canola oil and use a 50-50 ratio of white to whole wheat flour.  I also use a teaspoon of baking soda to make it less cakey.There was a lady who said the title was misleading and I don't know what she's talking about.  There is a basic muffin mix which all the muffins have in common - flour, baking powder, salt, sugar, shortening and eggs.

My husband's dinosaur desktop computer originally came with a 360MB RAM and I could fall asleep just waiting for it to start up.  I have a laptop that we use more often so it wasn't worth buying a new desktop PC.  We're glad to find this here in Amazon and it has sped up the computer a lot more.  We actually use the desktop PC now quite a lot now.

I agree with other reviewers that this is the best can opener out there.  It is very sharp (I don't even have to clamp down first to incise the can) and glides smoothly.  My only disappointment is that the handles are hard plastic.  A rubber handle would have been much easier to grip especially that my hands are always wet while I'm cooking.

My husband and I bought this mount for our 42" LED TV back in November 2010.  The salesperson at Bestbuy talked us into buying one from them and we actually did.  Good thing Bestbuy has a great return policy because I wasn't happy when I compared it with Amazon when we got home.  Our TV had to wait for it for a few days but it's all worth it.  It was easy to install too. I could have done it myself but my husband insisted on doing it. Great value for the money.We also got this surge protector: Tripp Lite TLP606 6-Outlet Surge Protector (790 Joules).

Got this fryer for my husband last Christmas... he's been wanting one for the longest time.  I must admit I was surprised at first at how small it was inside but my first try was a success so I decided to keep it.  I made crinkle cut chips and french fries from fresh potatoes and they both turned out great!  For 5 russet potatoes I think I did around 10 batches.  I did not want to overcrowd the tank because the temperature would drop.  What's really nice was the potatoes cooked evenly so there was no need to babysit it.  Once I dropped the basket in I could do other things and check only after 5 minutes or so. It's also great that I could hook the basket onto the lip and leave it there for a few seconds to drain.  My only wish is that the tank could be removed for easier cleaning.  I cook for only my husband and myself so this size is perfect for us.  It is a cute little appliance that goes well with our tiny kitchen. Hopefully it would last a long time.

I used to bake breads back in highschool (over 20 something years ago) and the book I had back then was a basic baking cookbook with lots of pictures.  Sadly I don't have that book anymore and never wrote down my favorite bread recipes.  I tried some recipes from Foodnetwork.com and allrecipes but those sites don't really give good step-by-step instructions especially with regards to kneading.  I would always get a tough and heavy dough and I always thought that I was over-kneading it.  When I first skimmed through this book, I realized that I've been under-kneading the dough the entire time.  All the recipes I've made from this book have turned out great.  I've made the pizza dough, banana bread and cinnamon rolls.  My husband was really impressed.  Although this book has no pictures, the instructions are very easy to read and follow.  Besides, everyone knows how a bread looks like, right?  I just google the ones I'm not familiar with, like challah.  I also read the entire recipe first before starting in the kitchen so I'll know what to look for later on.  I especially love that there are instructions for a stand mixer.  Makes life so much easier.  This book has a lot of recipes and I'm looking forward to making every one of them.  I also recommend Bernard Clayton's New Complete Book of Breads and Bread: The Breads of the World and How to Bake Them at Home.  The latter has photos of all the exotic breads mentioned in this book.

I used to bake breads back in highschool (over 20 something years ago) and the book I had back then was a basic baking cookbook with lots of pictures.  Sadly I don't have that book anymore and never wrote down my favorite bread recipes.  I tried some recipes from Foodnetwork.com and allrecipes but those sites don't really give good step-by-step instructions especially with regards to kneading.  I would always get a tough and heavy dough and I always thought that I was over-kneading it.  When I first skimmed through Bernard Clayton's book, I realized that I've been under-kneading the dough the entire time.  The first recipe I made from this book was the Buttermilk white loaf and it turned out great!  I added 1/4 cups more sugar because I prefer sweet breads.  My husband loved it too!  Contrary to what one reviewer said, I don't think there's anything wrong with the layout of the book.  They're easy to read and follow.  Of course, I understand that it would be a lot easier for readers if there are separate instructions for doing by hand, mixer and machine/food processor, but that would double the size of the book.  I for one don't want a cookbook that's as big and heavy as the Jerusalem Bible.  I always read the entire recipe first before starting in the kitchen so I'll know what to look for later on.  I especially love that I could make bread using my stand mixer.  Makes life so much easier.  The book has no pictures but everyone knows how a bread should look like, right?  I just google the ones I'm not familiar with, like challah.  This book is indeed complete and you won't need any other book.  Well, I did get The Bread Bible: 300 Favorite Recipes but only because it has a few recipes (like cinnamon rolls and foccacia) that aren't in Bernard's book.  I think they complement each other.  Bread: The Breads of the World and How to Bake Them at Home is also a great reference and has photos of all the exotic breads mentioned in Bernard's book.

This is a nice book with nice pictures for each recipe but sadly I'm not thrilled with them.  My husband and I rarely eat savory scones and this book has 21 recipes for savory scones that I will probably never make.  Lots of sweet ones too (28 recipes) but only about a couple sparked my interest.  I found that I liked this book better: Sharing Scones and More.  It has no pictures and only has 35 recipes but they are more to my liking (dessert scones).Also take note that the author is from New Zealand so the measurements are all in SI (grams, liters, etc).  It is a minor annoyance and did not affect my rating, but to the publisher, it would be much better if the conversion in cups would be written right alongside the SI version.

My husband and I live in Sonoma County and are always looking for dog-friendly trails in the area. We first saw this book at REI but didn't buy it so we're glad to find it here in Amazon.  This book is nicely written and includes maps that are easy to read. We didn't know there are trails right behind a park we drive by all the time! We also recommend Day Hikes Around Napa Valley.

My husband and I live in Sonoma County and are always looking for trails we could take our dog to.  This book was ok but we thought the Day Hikes Around Sonoma County was much more readable and had better maps.

My husband and I live in Sonoma County and are always looking for dog-friendly trails in the area.  This book is nicely written and also includes trails in Sonoma which is great.  We didn't know there are trails right behind a park we drive by all the time.  The maps are a good size too.

I've been cooking since I was a teenager but sometimes I just run out of ideas.  Having grown up in Asia, I don't have an extensive repertoire for soup recipes.  This book is the perfect solution.  It calls for widely available ingredients and for those I can't get, I can easily substitute with something else.  The recipes are pretty simple and very doable.  I just hate recipes that have up to 20 ingredients!  I'm very happy to have this in my cookbook collection.

I was so happy with the lemon squeezer that I got this one too.  I have a navel orange tree in my yard and I thought this would make life easier for me.  As one reviewer noted, once you start squeezing, the lip of the orange half would get folded in.  I also think that because navel oranges are too meaty, the holes get plugged by the meat and juice doesn't come out.  I always finish up by hand.  On the bright side, since the orange has already been squished, squeezing it even by one hand is pretty easy.  I think this would work better if the diameter of the squeezer was made a little bigger.  It would prevent the lip of the orange from folding inward.

I've seen this bamboo holder in some home stores for displaying bakeware, plates, etc.  It looks good and does the job but if you're planning to use heavy plates on it, it would be a good idea to reinforce it with gorilla glue first.  Small pot lids are ok for this but for my big heavy ones, I got a chrome wire holder from Target.

I held off on the TC Electronic Dark Matter distortion for a little while, even after an impressive demo session a few months ago because: (a) I thought it would be redundant with pedals I already have; and (b) at $50 (or less), I really didn't think it could be that great.  Over time, though, the low prices for both the MojoMojo and Dark Matter got me, and I now own both.  It's a good pedal, but I think their marketing of it is a bit misguided, and that's reflected in some of inconsistent reviews.Let's get a few things cleared up.  While the name "Dark Matter" sounds evil and imposing, this is essentially a crunchy "Marshall-in-a-box" pedal.  It probably covers more of the "cranked Plexi" territory than the higher gain JCM, but it can get fairly gainy.  Paradoxically, however, the "Dark Matter", in my opinion, is a much brighter pedal than the MojoMojo.  Whereas the MojoMojo has a lot of bassy low frequencies and tube-like sag, the Dark Matter is more obviously British-voiced.  That means tight low-end frequencies and a clear-yet-sometimes-abrasive high end.If you watch the promotion materials from TC Electronic, it was clear that their goal with both of these pedals was to offer affordable overdrive/distortion pedals that do not cut out all of the low end you experience if you were plugged into a big amp.  The Dark Matter isn't hurting for low end by any means, but as I said, it's more of a tight, focused low end than a booming swelling bass.  I didn't do a A/B comparison, but I suspect that if your goal is to make a small amp sound "bigger", you may be better served with an OCD variant, like the Joyo Ultimate Drive or EHX Glove OD.  But on most 10" or 12" combos, the Dark Matter will do just fine.  It actually sounded great on my Vox AC10C1, even though that is an amp with a very non-Marhsall gain structure, and can be finicky with some pedals.The mod switch isn't as dramatic as the Hi/Lo switch on an OCD.  It's more of a subtle shift in the mid range frequencies to focus on higher mids (up) or lower mids (down).  TC Electronic mentions that if you are playing in a mix, you may want the switch up, whereas solo players may prefer it down.The Bass and Treble controls are neutral in the middle position, and there is a cool "notch" you can feel in the potentiometer when it is centered.  The tone controls work, but are not quite as dramatic as some of the new Baxandall circuits you'd find on a $200 boutique.  In other words, you can expect to boost some low frequencies, or cut the treble a little, but don't depend on the EQ to dramatically alter the underlying tone of the pedal.If this pedal cost $200, it would be a fairly average distortion that would likely get lost in a crowd of excellent boutique options.  At $50, however, it's a 5-star product in my opinion.  In fact, it makes me almost sick to think that people can have something like this for the same cost as the DS-1 I had in the 90's, when that was really my only decent choice at that price.  The Dark Matter may be a bit mismarketed, but it can do an excellent Marshall crunch and is a nice compliment to the darker MojoMojo.  Great pedal at a price almost any guitarist could afford.

One of the great ironies of the guitar gear industry is that much of what's popular is based on recycled technology (50's era pickups, tube amps, hundreds of overdrives based on Tubescreamer circuits, etc.), yet there's a constant hunger for the newest and best pedal on the market.  Sometimes, that phenomenon leads to pedals released a few years ago being overlooked.  In this way, I feel that 2011's Mojo Hand FX Rook Overdrive is vastly underappreciated.BUILD QUALITY - Mojo Hand FX pedals are very well-built.  The knobs and enclosure look very similar to JHS Pedals (another favorite of mine), and everything feels solid.  There is a 9V battery compartment, but it is only accessible by removing 4 screws.  I also added 4 rubber feet to the bottom of my Rook, but you could fasten it using zip ties or velcro also.  The 9V jack is center negative (BOSS standard), and is top mounted, which I prefer, as it keeps it away from the I/O jacks.  Top notch durability.TONES - The Rook actually has 3 settings with the center mod switch, and they are quite a bit different - we'll refer to them as "TOP", "MIDDLE", and "BOTTOM" positions.  Before I bought the Rook, I heard people say that the Top and Bottom positions were kind of like a modded Tubescreamer.  I see some similarities, but know that the Rook has CONSIDERABLY more low end and tonal flexibility than any Tubescreamer I've used.  If you're paying for a boutique overdrive pedal, it's a nice touch when virtually all of the settings on every knob offer something musically useful.  On the Rook, you get almost a true bypass sound with the Gain all the way at zero.  With my Vox AC10C1, I was even using the Rook as an "underdrive" - you could set it up clean up some of the tube distortion of the amp and play at lower volumes, while retaining a great deal of EQ control.  Very few overdrive pedals offer this flexibility - usually there are entire ranges of the gain knob that are either unusable, or don't sound particularly good.  The Rook's gain knob sounds great all over the place.TOP Setting - With the switch all the way up, you get a low to moderate overdrive that breaks up with the smoothness of a Tubescreamer, but can get much bassier.  I really liked some of the lower gain settings, which remind you of a tube amp just starting to break up.  The tone controls are very powerful, however, so there's plenty of high end sparkle also available.BOTTOM Setting - The switch's bottom position is similar to the TOP setting, except meaner and higher gain.  The Rook isn't really meant to be a heavy rock or metal pedal, but this setting will get you pretty close.MIDDLE Setting - The middle setting is pretty interesting - I've heard some people compare it to a Klon, even though Mojo Hand did not promote it that way, and only just released a separate Klon pedal (Sacred Cow) in November 2015.  The middle setting removes some of the clipping diodes, so the result is louder, cleaner, and more punchy/responsive.  Since there is less overall compression on this setting, the tone controls become even more powerful here.  At first, I wasn't sure if I liked it as much as the other settings, but when I got it home, I was really impressed with some of the subtle things it could do with the breakup of my tube amp.  It's a nice clean boost capable of some additional grit, and you can use Rook as an always on, simplified "EQ" pedal to fatten up or brighten up your tone.SUMMARY - Overdrive pedals tend to be very redundant, but I was actually surprised just how varied and different the Rook was given that I hadn't heard a ton of people raving about it.  The only pedal I've previously owned that it reminded me of was the Fultone Full Drive 2, which seems to behave similarly on its CompCut setting as the middle position does on the Rook.  But the Rook is about half the size, and I like it better than that pedal.  It's a definite keeper, and built to last.

This is an older piece of hardware, but so many people sang its praises and it was so cheap by the time I bought it that I figured "why not".  I already own an excellent guitar interface for iPad (the Apogee JAM) and I have cheap mixer and studio monitors, so it's already possibly for me to use iOS instruments through the headphone jack/line out.  So I wondered if the StudioConnect would be an all-in-one solution that would offer RCA connections for digital audio out.For that last purpose, it works fine.  For guitar, not so much.  I'm surprised more people didn't comment on the noise/feedback issues with using the 1/4" guitar jack in the back.  The Apogee JAM (which, granted, is a $100 device) basically eliminates all of this unwanted noise.  The noise came rushing back with the StudioConnect, which renders it basically useless for quality guitar recording.  It's a shame.The StudioConnect also ties up the 30-pin interface, and does not have a USB MIDI jack of its own.  What this means is that it is basically useful as a conventional MIDI jack interface and not much else.  You can't use a USB MIDI device at the same time as the StudioConnect, and nowadays, USB MIDI has really become the new standard.I didn't spend much on it, but given some of the limitations noted above, I basically purchased a glorified iPad stand that offers some interface capabilities for the traditional MIDI controllers I don't own.  It's possible it could be useful for a particularly subset of iOS musicians, but the prevalence of USB MIDI and abundance of other quality affordable guitar interfaces makes that an ever-narrowing niche.

What do you get when you find an old drawing from Leo Fender, and combine the pickups, headstock design, and 24.75" scale of a Les Paul with the basic body shape and feel of a Stratocaster?  If you're G & L, you get the Ascari, which is a relatively new set-neck creation with a mahogany body and rosewood fingerboard.G & L's branding can be somewhat confusing - most of their guitars are named using either acronyms or influences from foreign languages (ASAT, Ascari, Fiorano, etc.), but their basic form factor is usually pretty familiar.  In fact, G & L started in 1979 with the apparent goal of evolving on some of the vintage Fender designs.  But the Ascari is an original design, though not too dissimilar from many PRS SE, Washburn, or Schecter guitars already on the market.Everything about this guitar says "warmth".  Mahogany wood and a rosewood fingerboard are a warm combination as are the higher-output alnico humbucker pickups.  This guitar also has impressive acoustic sustain, thanks the upgraded TonePros bridge and tailpiece.One reason I often prefer single coils to humbuckers is that they can drive a tube amp too hard, and then get muddy when you try to mitigate that by rolling off the volume.  For this reason, I like the coil tapping feature on the Ascari.  It doesn't sound "like a single coil" per se, but retains the brightness while effectively cutting the output in half.  And these pickups do sound great - it's a nice balanced set that would be at home doing rock, blues, or even heavier genres.Even shipped in a box through an online order, my Ascari arrived set up quite well.  Low action with minimal fret buzz, and a very playable neck.  I've heard some people describe it as a thin neck, but it's not like a Jackson or Ibanez.  The medium jumbo frets are also appreciated.This is an excellent guitar that stays in tune and offers a good variety of tones.  The fact that it's "just a little different" than the Strats and Les Pauls that everyone else plays makes it all the more appealing to me.  But in function, it's a guitar loaded with traditional rock and blues sounds.

While the TC Electronic Flashback is hardly a "boutique" piece of gear, you'll see it featured on a lot of expensive-looking pedal boards because it's just so darn versatile! I've had a Boss DD-3 Digital Delay for some time - it's great at what it does.  I've used a couple of inexpensive "analog"-sounding delay pedals, and they're great also.  But the Flashback is a single pedal that can go from one type of delay to another with a flip of the selector knob.  And that's really why I believe this one will stand the test of time.To be honest, I'm likely to use a few of the delay settings much more than the others.  The "2290" delay appealed to me because I grew up as a fan of U2's The Edge, and in fact, he was my entire reason for wanting to check out delay in the first place.  The 2290 delay is a bright, percussive delay - it's not terribly unlike the DD-3, except the Flashback has added features of quarter note, dotted eight, or combined repeats.  So if you're looking for a compact, affordable way to get that dotted eighth delay made famous by U2 and featured heavily in many other types of music, the Flashback is a great place to start.A couple other features worth mentioning...  The "Delay" knob sets the time of the delay, and functions like it would on any other delay pedal.  But there is also an option to hold down the soft bypass switch for a few seconds, which kills the sound and allows you to strum out the rhythm on your guitar like a metronome and set the timing that way.  It does work, though it may or may not be your preferred way to set timing (strumming in the proper time silently is harder than it sounds!).Also, this pedal features a 40-second (mono) looper, which I've read some criticism about.  I tested it, and it works pretty well for what it is, which is a "throwaway" feature on pedal that otherwise focuses on delay.  Still, don't be too quick to dismiss it completely.  I actually have a dedicated looper pedal (similar to TC Electronics' own Ditto Looper), and while it's superior feature-wise to the looper on the Flashback, it's never going to be a permanent fixture on my pedalboard.  By contrast, the Flashback would be a pedal that would be affixed to my board and used frequently.  So if I'm just messing around and want to solo over a simple chord progression, the Flashback will be there to handle that.Finally, TC Electronic pedals have a "TonePrint" customizable delay slot, and you can edit this using a USB cable and a computer, or download artist signature delays from online.  I believe you can even use the "BEAM" feature from a smartphone - it emits a high-pitch screech that is picked up by your guitar's pickup, and funneled through to the Flashback.  I'm not kidding, this is how it sends the new preset to the pedal.  And it usually works, except when it doesn't.  The iOS app is a little buggy and needs to be updated more frequently.  Still, a pretty cool idea.This is a great delay pedal that is well worth the price.  It's well-built, versatile, and pretty easy to use relative to its insane feature set.

The Mooer Yellow Comp was recommended to me by countless people online and in guitar stores, so when I saw it go on sale a bit, I finally checked it out.  I actually have another affordable compressor (The Joyo Dyna Compressor) that I am quite happy with, though I believe it is an "OTA" (Operation Transconductance Amp) compressor similar to an MXR, BOSS, or Ross, whereas the Yellow Comp is an Optical Compressor.  I don't have the expertise to get too far into the differences between the two, but I've had it explained that optical compressors are a little slower in cutting off the attack and compress less, but are a bit more transparent and smooth as a result.I think the Mooer Yellow Comp sounds great.  Besides the Joyo, I have owned both the BOSS and MXR varieties.  All of them have their positives and negatives, but this is the first compressor I've played where I really felt like it could be an "always on" effect.  Even if you don't want a heavily "squashed" sound, mild amounts of compression are still useful for smoothing out undesirable volume spikes and generally adding sustain and saturation to clean tones.My current amp is the new Vox AC10C1 - it's a great amp, but extremely touch-responsive and can get too loud/bright with my heavy picking technique.  The Yellow Comp is great with this amp - I didn't want to turn it off!  The EQ knob on the Yellow Comp operates like the "Top Cut" knob that my amp doesn't have!  It seems to alter the amount of compression applied to low or high frequencies, so the result is similar to a high or low-pass filter, even though that really isn't what it's doing.Finally, I should point out that there's no volume loss with this compressor, which is something I noticed with some MXR Dyna Comp variants.  If anything, the Yellow Comp can make things louder by bringing up the level of those quieter notes.  Unity gain for me was probably around 11:30 on the level knob, and increasing compression seemed to make it louder, which is almost the opposite of how a CS-3 or Dyna Comp works.Compressors are very hard to research and review - everyone's idea of how they work seems to be little different.  I've used a few, and I think this is my favorite.  The Mooer pedals are Chinese made and affordable, but the build quality seems excellent.  This one's a keeper.

Reviewing the Mini Tubescreamer here because the other page blends reviews for the full sized TS9 and other variants...I like the Tubescreamer Mini quite a bit.  I hated myself for wanting one because it's about 75% novelty - pretty much every serious pedal nut has a Tubescreamer or cheap clone of one already, and the mini pedal craze is a bit overrated because after you cable everything together, there isn't much room that is saved on a pedalboard using minis versus a "BOSS"-sized pedal.Still, I sold my TS9 reissue after finding a number of clones (EHX East River Drive being the primary one) that worked well enough, plus I wasn't crazy about the switch on the fullsize model.  This TS Mini is a very nicely made mini pedal.  It has some heft to it, and the switch is soft enough that you don't to knock it over trying to turn it on.  The difficulty seeing the Tone and Level settings on the black mini knobs has been well-documented, but can be fixed with some silver/white paint.Tonally, the TS Mini had more power than I expected.  I felt like my original TS9 was lower output than this pedal, and that's a good thing for the Mini.  Even with lower overdrive settings, the pedal was boosting quite easily.  Not sure if the sound is more TS9 or TS808, but it's a great mids-boosting overdrive that works best with a slightly dirty amp or stacked with other pedals.

Pretty hard to fault the Caline Sand Storm for anything given its price and solid build quality.  But of the Caline pedals I have tried (Orange Burst, Pure Sky, English Man), this one probably impressed me the least, so I feel a 4-star review is appropriate.It's becoming apparent that certain Chinese brands (notably Donner and Caline) are rehousing and re-branding pedals that were sold as a different Chinese brand.  My assumption is that this is done for one of two reasons: (1) To generate false hype over a "new" product, that is actually just leftover stock; (2) To clear out inventory at a discounted price while protecting the brand integrity of some of the more reputable Chinese brands.  (For instance, Mooer pedals retailed at $88 for quite awhile, where as the nearly identical Donner pedals are closer to $30).With that in mind, I am about 90% certain that the Sand Storm is actually a rehoused Joyo Deluxe Crunch.  The giveaways are the Marshall-flavored tones and the position of "Pre" (presence knob).  This pedal actually sounds pretty good, but isn't as appealing at the higher gain Marshall tones as something like the Donner Morpher, and doesn't quite have the low end response to nail the chunkier Plexi tones.  Simply put, there are just SO many affordable options covering this type of sound, they can't all be "the best".  But the Sand Storm is a solid overdrive/distortion pedal, and given its minuscule resale value, I am likely holding onto it.

Purchased a matched pair of JJ EL84's to "upgrade" my Vox AC10C1.  The AC10C1 is a new amp, but I've heard that JJ power amp tubes are a great pairing with Vox-style amps, as they help bring out that trademark "chime".  The results with the new tubes have been quite good.  The amp really sparkles with valve/tube sustain and saturation, and it gets bright without being overly harsh or thin.  Even compared to the stock tubes, I feel that the JJ's were an improvement.  Installation was a breeze.  Would buy these again without a doubt when it comes time to re-tube.

I purchased a set of 2 Tungsol 12AX7's for an upgrade to my Vox AC10C1, which ships with generic Chinese-made tubes.  I think that sound differences in pre-amp tubes from brand to brand is probably a real thing, but also very hard to gauge.  I opted for the Tungsol's over some other options because I heard that they were well-made and had a bit more warmth to them.  Some other people have remarked that they are good for blues because they dirty up a little more quickly.I cannot confirm all of those things are true, but I am happy with the tube swap in my amp, and would buy this set again.  Installation was a breeze.  Many tubes nowadays are made in just a handful of factories and then re-branded, but I am happy with the Tungsols.

I was initially a little disappointed with the DOD Gunslinger Distortion pedal.  I picked it up based on some great YouTube demo videos and a satisfying low volume playing session at home.  When I got it home, I played it through two amps: a solid state Vox Pathfinder 15 and the all-tube Vox AC10C1.  On the solid state amp, the tone was a little difficult to dial in.  It sounded either muddy or brittle and harsh, kind of like the abrasiveness of a BOSS DS-1.  On the tube amp, the tone became a little too dark and mushy.  It wasn't a terrible sound, but not really what I was expecting.But the tone controls of the DOD Gunslinger are extremely powerful, and after playing with that and accounting for the fact that this is a very high output pedal, I started to pull some great amp-like distortion sounds out of it.  I think the Gunslinger has a nice warmth to it that is also very touch-responsive.  It should excel at warming up an otherwise bright amp.  Definitely more of a "square wave" distorted tone than an overdrive.  By turning down the Treble a bit, I got some almost fuzz-like lead tones out of it.  And unity gain on this pedal is probably around 9:00 on the volume knob, so there's no issue boosting your signal.  I read that DOD really aimed to make a pedal that works great with a clean or already dirty amp, and I can see that from my use of it.To summarize, the Gunslinger wasn't a distortion pedal that instantly reminded me of the classic rock distortion tones I expected.  It's not a pedal like the MXR Super Badass Distortion, where it's difficult to make the pedal sound bad on any setting.  The Gunslinger has a personality of its own, and I'm coming to appreciate that.  After all, if it were exactly the same as the other distortion pedals I have, what would be the point?  It doesn't have a mids control (and the pedal is probably a little "scooped" overall in sound), but it has plenty of low end and can retain brightness and string-to-string clarity at the same time.  Try it first before you buy it if that's an option for you, but I think it's another quality new product from DOD.

I am quite pleased with my purchase of the newly-released Vox AC10C1, a 10-watt combo amplifier featuring a 10" Celestion speaker.  I apologize in advance for the length of this review, but I did quite a bit of research on the AC10C1 and its place in the Vox lineup.  I hope my comments prove useful for prospective buyers, and I will amend my review if my thoughts on the amp change or evolve over time.BACKGROUND - The AC10C1 is in some respects a resurrection of a discontinued vintage product and, in other respects, a completely "new" product.  Vox manufactured an "AC10" from 1959 to 1967, but the similarities between the two basically end with the model name and wattage.  The original AC10 was a square "TV front" combo amplifier that was offered both in a single 10", or as a 2x10" "Twin" configuration.  The original AC10 featured multiple inputs, vibrato, an open-back cabinet, and an assortment of 5 tubes under the hood.FEATURES OF THE AC10C1 - In 2015, Vox released the AC10C1, but the amp is far from a "reissue" of this original design.  Rather, Vox seems to created a completely new design targeting something that the famed AC15 and AC30 do not offer - a sub-$500 tube/valve combo amplifier capable reasonably suited for portability, and home/studio use at reasonable volumes.  The feature set of the AC10C1 is somewhat limited, but mostly in line with similarly priced "entry-level" tube amplifiers.  There is a single input jack, and extension cabinet jack for 10 watts in a 16-ohm cabinet, a separate gain and master volume control, and knobs for bass, treble, and reverb.  There is also a main power switch but no standby switch (my understanding is that this is commonly missing on many modern lower powered tube amps).PROS - I had the opportunity to try out the AC10C1 a few times before I bought it, and I was instantly enamored with the tone.  It somehow marries the "chime" and "dirty cleans" of a signature Vox tone with a fuller low end presence - almost like a Fender Deluxe Reverb.  One thing important to point out is that this amp becomes loud fairly quickly.  I am using it exclusively as a hobbyist for bedroom/basement levels, but if controlling volume for your neighbors is a priority, there are other amps I would consider first.  But the nice about the AC10C1 is that it is at least capable of bedroom level cleans (or overdriven tones, due to the master volume control), while also having horsepower for keeping up with other instruments and possibly some smaller gigs.  I've been in love the tone of an AC30 for years, but it wasn't until the AC10C1 was released that Vox made an all-tube amplifier that I could realistically consider owning.The aesthetics of this amp nail vintage Vox, and I believe that is a step in the right direction for this company, which has spent the last 15 years or so releasing some decent products (Night Train, Valvetronix, etc.) that are either divisive or downright ugly in appearance, depending on whom you ask.  The rectangular shape not only makes the amp look like a smaller AC30, but I believe it benefits the sound.  Some 10" combo amps develop a "boxy" sound that can be quite directional.  The wider, closed-back cabinet deflects bass frequencies forward across a wider field, and I would argue that this amp can compete with some 12" combos in terms of fullness in a home practice setting.Vox advertises that the AC10C1 features the famous "Top Boost" circuitry made popular on the AC30 and popularized by players like Brian May and The Edge.  People who understand amp circuitry better than I do have remarked that the tube configuration of the AC10C1 is quite different from the authentic Top Boost circuit.  Whatever you call it, however, the amp is extremely warm-sounding and versatile.  Low wattage, single-channel tube amps seem to fail more often than not at offering a combination of clean headroom and rich, saturated overdrive tones.  The AC10C1 nails both, and can do so at a variety of volumes.  At 27 pounds (versus 47 pounds for the AC15), it is also surprisingly lightweight and portable.CONS - Despite my overwhelming positive impressions of the AC10C1, this is far a perfect product both in design and in execution.  Let's get the elephant in the room out of the way first - the amp is manufactured in China, much a like an increasing portion of affordable gear nowadays.  If your expectation for a tube amplifier is that it is hand wired in the US or UK, then those products are available for you, but usually at a considerably higher cost.  Chinese construction is a reality of globalization in 2015, especially in the more affordable end of the guitar gear spectrum.  My personal view on it is that guitar playing is a hobby for me, and my gear does not need to "perform" or be thrown into vans at 2am.  If it is built well enough to sit in my basement, I hope that I can take care of it and get many years of enjoyment, while saving money that I don't have to spend on $1,000+ amplifiers.  But the fact remains that this is the first run of a new product, so nobody can say for certain if there are any pressing design flaws.I have not removed the back of the cabinet, but have seen pictures of the amp's internals from other people who have.  The components, including the two pre-amp and two power amp tubes are arranged and fastened in a manner that seems more focused on keeping the size compact, as opposed to convenience or long-term durability.  Also, I have heard that speaker replacement on this amp can be quite difficult because there is simply not much room to install a speaker of a different size/shape.  So, if you are into modding, this is almost certainly not the right amp for you, but I like amp stock, and as long as it continues function for many years, I will be happy enough.Feature-wise, the amp does not have an effects loop, which is a bit disappointing for me, as I like to use effects pedals, and the loop can really expand the way effects are used.  The on-board reverb is digital, and I actually like the initial attack and quality of its tone.  But if this amp is ever revised, I hope they re-tune it a bit because it seems to favor long decay times even on very low settings.  I found that using the reverb on "1" or even less than "1" was all that I needed, but that setting would usually correspond to a "3" or a "4" on a Fender amp, for example.  At the end of the day, it's not a great reverb, but it's better that it's there versus not having one at all.  I do plan on using it, and an amp with on-board reverb is more tempting to plug directly into, which means it is more likely to get played.ALTERNATIVES TO THE AC10C1 - As written above, I bought the AC10C1 exclusively to use as a home combo amp.  I wanted it to get just slightly louder than I would ever need, while retaining fullness and clarity at bedroom levels.  I believe the AC10C1 does that exceptionally well.  It nails the character of "Vox clean", which adds in tube saturation and sustain to a tone that otherwise remains brilliant and expressive, walking a delicate line between "clean" and "overdriven".But if you are looking for a solid tube amplifier without being married to the idea of owning a Vox, there are other options out there.  The VHT Special 6 is one such option, and retails for nearly $200 less.  Vox offers the Night Train 15 for nearly the same price, and it has an effects loop and more tonal versatility (though I preferred the sounds of the AC10C1).  Fender offers a Pro Junior (10") and Blues Junior (12") which are quality tube amplifiers with a longer track record than the new AC10C1.  For gigging, the AC15 is a larger, louder relative of the AC10C1, and may be worth the additional money.  I do not recommend the AC4-112, which is slightly cheaper, but lacks the low end presence of the AC10C1.For a very affordable bedroom solution, however, I would also recommend checking out the Vox Pathfinder 15, which is a now-discontinued solid state 8" combo.  It can be found used for about $75 to $125, and is an absolute freak of nature in its ability to offer Vox cleans (and even some overdriven tones) in a portable, inexpensive package with no tubes involved.Time will tell if the Vox AC10C1 is a reliable amp.  But I think there is little question they have made a great sounding, 10" combo that covers the full range of classic Vox tones.  It offers the authentic warmth of an all-tube amplifier and manageable volumes and a decent price point.  I wish I was playing mine right now.UPDATE (10/08/15) - Posting a quick update only a couple of weeks after buying the amp to report that my factory-shipped model functioned absolutely perfectly and sounds great.  I did some research on the tubes (which are Chinese-made and of debated quality), and after verifying from Korg/Vox that these can be replaced without re-biasing, I ordered some Tungsol 12AX7's for the preamp and (matched) JJ EL84's for the power amp.  I will be leaving the stock Celestion speaker as is.  The tube change may or may not make an appreciable difference, but I'm going to try it out, as I have heard several AC10C1 users reporting a noticeable improvement.

This is my first BBE pedal, and I came away pretty impressed with this $50 distortion pedal.  I've read some comments that it is like a Boss DS-1 with a better tone control.  At first I thought that was a bit unfair, but the reality is that a better tone control would do a lot to help the DS-1!  BBE isn't particularly clear what they are marketing the 427 as, but I hear a moderate-gain distortion pedal suited for rock and blues.  It uses LED clipping, which results in a warm, amp-like distortion that retains a good amount of bass.  The tone control is quite useful - you can roll off a good deal of treble to pair with brighter amps, or add some high-end presence without turning your amp into an icepick.Construction is pretty solid for this price point.  Heavy duty metal chassis with reinforced jacks and an MXR-style switch.  I believe the pedal is Chinese-made to keep costs down, and there were some minor cosmetic blemishes on my unit.  But if you're looking at a $50 distortion pedal and it sounds great and is reliably built, you're unlikely to care about that stuff.  I own more expensive distortion pedals than this one, but the BBE 427 is a solid keeper.

I recently bought a DOD 250 reissue for the same reason I own a Boss DS-1 and SD-1, even if they aren't my "favorite" pedals of their type - it's a classic design that has been used by countless guitarists and has stood the test of time.  It's also increasingly going on sale, so it may be a nice value, as well.I have a few "booster" pedals, but the line between "boost" pedal and "overdrive" can get fairly blurry, and the DOD 250 is an excellent example of why that is.  The DOD 250 has both Level and Gain controls.  If you slam the front end of a signal with additional power, the result will be additional gain.  In other words, placing a clean boost before the preamp input of a combo amplifier is more likely to add gain than pure "volume".  However, you could use a 250 to boost the volume of an amp (or another pedal) by running it later in the chain, or even in the effects loop.But the 250 also functions like an overdrive pedal in that it has a separate gain control.  Therefore, similar to an overdrive pedal, you can use it to simulate a "cranked" amp sound at lower volumes.  The 250 does not have a tone control, but is transparent enough that you can do without one.  I am happy to report that the 250 is warmer than some other boosters (like the MXR Micro Amp, or even an OD like the EHX Soul Food), so it is friendly towards smaller combo amps.Construction on these reissue DOD's is excellent.  They are more "aluminum" than "steel" in weight, but solid, and I like the oversized knobs.  If you see a good price on one, and think you have a need for a booster or classic overdrive sound, consider checking out the 250 reissue.

I want to make clear that this review is of the Mackie Mix5, which is the smallest and most affordable of the Mix series (the review page is combined between the Mix5, Mix8, and Mix12FX, but the latter two have some additional bells and whistles that the Mix5 does not have).  So if you are like me and have a very elementary knowledge of mixers, hopefully this review of this excellent budget mixer will be of some help!I had two primary reasons for seeking out an affordable mixer.  First, I am a guitar player and effects pedal enthusiast, and there are a series of preamp pedals (Tech21 SansAmp/Tri-AC/Character; Joyo Sound series) that are designed to go directly to a mixer and played through studio monitors or a PA.  I have a single M-Audio BX5 studio monitor but had the realization: "Wait, how would I even hook up a second one?"  Second, I have an assortment of iOS music apps, ranging from virtual synthesizers, to drum machines, to guitar modelers, and needed a better way to play those apps through the same studio monitor(s).  To a lesser degree, I also was interested in the XLR hookup to use with dynamic or condenser microphones (but with some limitations on the Mix5, which I will discuss).The Mix5 is solidly constructed.  It has a mostly metal casing, and is more compact than some of the similarly-priced alternatives from Harbinger and Behringer.  The Mix5 ships with an 18V power supply unit, though as many people have noted, there is no On/Off power switch. This is an annoyance, but the unit is so compact, that I suspect many people will only bring it out when they want to use it anyway.The dashboard is fairly straightforward and free from clutter.  They promote the mixer has having 5 channels, though 2/3 and 4/5 are stereo inputs, so it is arguably more like 3 channels.  Channel 1 accepts either an XLR mic input or an instrument cable (guitar, etc.).  There is also a bass/treble EQ control, which is nice for an entry-level mixer.  One thing I noticed about using the guitar through the mixer was that there was considerably more volume available as compared to running the preamp pedals directly into the speaker.  Of course, the mixer is also a necessity for adding a second speaker and then having a L/R channel setup.  The connections can be balanced or unbalanced - in my case, I believe I have a cable that goes from TS (instrument cable) to XLR (plugs into the monitor).  If you want a mixer with XLR outputs, consider the Yamaha MG06, which I nearly bought, but which costs over twice as much.  Guitar sounded great running through the Mix5, and you can of course throw reverb pedals and other effects in the signal chain before the mixer.  I was also pleasantly surprised how good the guitar sounded simply monitoring with headphones - this was something I could not do with that setup before I had a mixer.The RCA (red/white) in/out connection is quite useful for mixing in different types of audio sources.  3.5mm-to-RCA cables are very inexpensive, and allow you to hook up MP3 players and other audio sources like the aforementioned iPad instruments.  The overall sound levels are displayed colorfully by the green/yellow/red display and to help prevent "clipping" of the audio signal.The drawbacks of this device have been noted in other reviews, and they notable criticisms, but also part of the give-and-take of buying an entry-level device.  In addition to no main on/off switch, there is no on/off switch for phantom power.  Also, phantom power offered is around 15V, instead of the 48V needed to use many condenser microphones.  The Mix5 also does not have any on-board effects, such as offered by the Behringer and Yamaha models for a little more money.  Finally, please note that this is a mixer, NOT a recording "interface" with USB output to a computer.  If you are looking for a USB interface, I considered the Behringer Q502USB, but decided that I did not need an interface for my PC.The Mackie Mix5 is very basic, but seems to suit my limited needs perfectly.  It retails at $50, so I consider it a great "first mixer", and I would always have the option to upgrade to something with more features, if needed.

It's really hard to go wrong with any of the Wampler overdrive/distortion pedals - I own a Pinnacle and Black '65, but there are literally a dozen in the Wampler catalog I'm sure I would enjoy.  But the Euphoria might end up being the one I use the most.  It's incredibly smooth, surprisingly versatile, works well stacked or by itself, and sounds great placed in front of a clean amp, or driving one that's already breaking up.Let's get a couple items related to the pedal's description out of the way.  The "Euphoria" is the new name for what was originally the Wampler "Ecstacy" (I believe there was a minor quarrel with Bogner over naming rights, since Bogner has a well-known amp called "Ecstacy").  But I believe the design and sound are virtually identical.  The Euphoria (in "Smooth" mode) is promoted as a "D" (Dumble)-style pedal.  Let's be real - I have never played a Dumble Overdrive Special, and neither have virtually anyone who will read this - they are custom-built amplifiers and are sold for absurd amounts of money.  But I had an "idea in my head" of what a Dumble tone and gain structure should sound like and, for what it's worth, the Euphoria met that expectation as soon as I tried it out.A "Tubescreamer" tone is a good reference point for starting to describe how the Euphoria sounds, though there is actually quite a bit of difference between the two.  Like the Tubescreamer, the Euphoria has a smooth, sustaining high end that operates in the low to moderate gain range.  Unlike the Tubescreamer, the Euphoria offers quite a bit of low end, which can be dialed in or out quite dramatically with a dedicated "BASS" knob.  The other reviewers were correct when they recommended to try the bass knob at around 9:00 to 12:00 first.  In front of a clean amp, the Euphoria can stay relatively clean while taking over the EQ structure of the amp to give it "Dumble" aesthetics, and still maintain or boost the volume quite a bit.  Turn up the gain in "Smooth" mode and you get a loose, tube-like response that can handle everything from rock power chords to bluesy solos.I bought the Euphoria primarily for the "Smooth" setting, but it's pretty impressive how varied the tone becomes simply by flicking the mod switch to one of the two other modes.  Wampler describes the "Open" (middle) position as the least overdriven and offering the most volume boost.  The bottom switch position ("Crunch") is the most gainy, and sounds more like a traditional overdrive or distortion pedal.  The three modes are not footswitchable, and I prefer the "Smooth" setting as the Euphoria's signature sound, but it's pretty cool that you bring this one pedal to a performance and have three fairly distinct sounds in one box.One of the great ironies of Wampler pedals is that they are $200 boutique pedals made with the needs of professional musicians in mind, yet the powerful EQ controls and low-end response of their dirt pedals really pairs well with smaller, less expensive combo amplifiers.  Many overdrive pedals are great provided that you play them through a cabinet loaded with 12" speakers and at a "cranked" volume level.  The Euphoria (and all Wamplers, really) seems to have been designed to perform at low and high volume levels, alike.  As for the "D-Style" tone, I tried a Mooer Rumble Drive and the Euphoria just blows it out of the water.  Even if you don't care about "Dumble" tone, the Euphoria is an excellent alternative to the sea of Tubescreamer clones, offering  something unique, powerful, and flexible.

I actually had a chance to try out an Earthquaker Monarch about a year ago, and came away very impressed.  So when I saw one on a closeout sale at a local guitar store, I thought it was too good to pass up.  The Monarch needs to be evaluated in light of its specific purpose, which was to mimic sounds of classic Orange amplifiers in an effects pedal.  While I don't have a deep knowledge of Orange amplifiers, I did come away quite impressed with the Monarch's ability to capture that style of tone, while offering a unique gain structure that sets it apart from many of the traditional overdrive and distortion pedals.This is my first Earthquaker pedal, but I have heard lots of good reports about their build quality.  This compact orange box seems to be very solidly constructed.  It has a bit of heft to it, and the switch, jacks, and knobs feel solid and built-to-last.  I also believe the pedal can be run at 9V or 18V for additional headroom.The first thing you will notice about the Monarch is that this pedal is LOUD.  Unity gain on the volume knob is around 9:00 with my setup.  Fortunately, this is they type of pedal that can be run at usable volume even with the Gain knob completely at zero.  I believe that the Bass and Treble controls are active, so they can operate as a boost/cut on those frequencies.  So there is a good amount of versatility in the tone.  At the same time, the pedal does maintain a thick, warm quality to it at all settings.  It could be described as a "bassy" pedal, except that the higher frequencies seem to shine through even with a fair amount of gain saturation.The Monarch does not sound like a Tubescreamer or traditional overdrive/distortion pedal.  Orange amplifiers can take on an almost "fuzz-like" character as the gain is turned up, and the same goes for the Monarch.  It's worth noting that while this is an amp-in-a-box pedal, the tone coming from the Monarch will never be completely clean.  I ran it through Fender-style amplifier with a completely clean bass tone, and the sound through the Monarch still had some "chunk" through it even with the Gain at 0.  But there are a lot of interesting blues and rock tones through the first half of the gain range.  The pedal gets more messy and "fuzz-like" as you continue to add gain, yet as loose as the gain becomes it still manages to shine through some of the higher frequencies.To summarize, the Monarch succeeds in fulfilling a somewhat niche goal of capturing the characteristics of a vintage Orange amplifier.  But even if that is not your goal, I think there's room to appreciate the Monarch as a unique tone-shaper that borders on "fuzz pedal".  This pedal has plenty of output, is unique from any other gain pedal I have played, and should be built to last.
