When the DigiTech TRIO was unveiled at Winter NAMM 2015, I was about as skeptical as possible.  While the concept behind the pedal appealed to me, I just didn't believe there was any chance it would be any good).  It took months of researching the pedal and reading amateur reviews from other people online to recognize that the TRIO is actually an amazing product.  Yes, it is overly ambitious, and yes, it does have flaws.  But the takeaway from my early experience with the pedal is that DigiTech put an amazing amount of thought into how their customers would actually use the pedal, and the end result is a terrific practice aid for jamming at home and simply learning to play better guitar.The interesting thing about reviewing the TRIO is that there is a kernel of truth to many of the "bad" reviews you find on this site and others.  The basic function of the TRIO is to "learn" a bass line and drum beat simply by playing the simple chord progression of a song (or, more accurately, one part of a song).  The process isn't always perfect.  The TRIO will create a loop based on the progression you train it with, but the timing and some of the bass notes will invariably be off a bit.  I think some of the bad reviews really expected the TRIO to understand what you are trying to do and to nail the perfect accompaniment for your guitar part every time.  If that's your expectation for this device, then yes, you may be disappointed.But the reason the TRIO works for me is that DigiTech gives you a large amount of flexibility to tweak the band accompaniment parts AFTER you play your training phrase.  You can select from a number of musical genres (rock, alt rock, pop, country, etc.).  Each of those can be tweaked further using a style selector knob with about 12 different options. There is even an alternative time button to double or half the timing based on the same beats per minute.  It's very true that TRIO comes up with bass/drum parts that don't quite fit your idea.  It's also true that with all of these different style options, you're almost certain to find something very close to what you intended, or something that works anyway.The flexibility of this pedal extends to the output choices you have for playing the bass/drum backing track.  You can run a single instrument cable into a single guitar amp.  Or, you can run a TS (unbalanced) cable into a mixer or studio monitor so that you have a separate speaker playing the band part along with the guitar output going to your guitar amp.  Big credit to DigiTech for providing volume knobs for the bass and drum tracks separately.There is even a third option, which allows you to monitor using a headphone jack on top of the device, and hear the bass/drum track along with your guitar playing all through your headphones!  The Guitar FX button on the top left engages a preamp and cabinet simulation so that you get a genre-appropriate guitar tone without having an actual amp anywhere in the signal chain.  For example, "Rock" setting will give you a distorted tone through a large cabinet, while "Country" gives you a cleaner, jangly tone with some slapback echo.  The tones aren't elite quality, but it's addition nonetheless, which allows the TRIO to be an all-in-one practice tool.  (There is even a headphone volume knob, which can be used in conjunction with the Bass and Drums knobs to control the levels of all three instruments through headphones).Oh, and the implementation of the tempo knob is brilliant.  The "1x" tempo is based on how fast you play the learning phrase.  But if the resulting product is too fast or two slow, you can easily adjust with the Tempo knob, and tracks will loop at that new speed.I've read some people describe the TRIO as a "glorified metronome".  The truth is probably somewhere between that description and DigiTech's own claim of "Band in a Box".  The one feature missing that surprised me a bit was that the TRIO does not include a looper for your guitar parts.  In fact, it has no memory storage options beyond the three song parts that you program at that time.  But now that I have owned and played around with the TRIO a bit, there might have been the issue of just "too much going on" if they tried to jam a looper into this device, also.  It should be possible to run the guitar output into a separate looper pedal, and then you would have a rhythm guitar part to go with the bass and drums, but I have not tried this yet.All in all, this was an extremely ambitious project that DigiTech put a lot of love and detail into - for the most part, I think they got it right.  It will be interesting to see if they continue to improve on the pedal with firmware updates through the mini-USB port.

Lots of reviews already for the Korg nanoKey2, so I will try to keep it short...  This is my second MIDI controller - my first is the excellent Akai MPK25 (version 1).  If you are primarily a keyboard player and are okay with the fact that the MPK25 is literally twice the size of the nanoKey2, then I think the Akai is a better option for a more traditional feeling keyboard and sample pad pairing.  (Note: it's also more expensive, retailing around $100, so perhaps not a fair comparison).But I like the nanoKey2 as the ultimate portable option for capturing ideas on-the-go on my iPhone and/or iPad.  Since it's smaller than a USB computer keyboard, you can slip it into a laptop case with the USB Camera Connection kit and the (included) USB cable, and you have everything you need.This does not have the traditional feel of a synthesizer keyboard.  The buttons are velocity-sensitive, but they do not have any real travel or "spring" to them.  They are more similar to a computer keyboard response.  The downside of this is that if you are a traditional piano player and accustomed to playing complicated passages knowing exactly where the keys should fall under your fingers, you may struggle to do that here.  But there are definite advantages to Korg's design choice as well.  First of which is that buttons can be pressed in rapid succession, unlike some piano keys.  So if you are planning to use this keyboard to tap out rhythms, it's capable of hitting 16th notes or triplets in quick succession, arguably better than a traditional keyboard.  Also, some reviewers remarked that they actually found it easier to play the black keys (sharps and flats on the upper row) with this type of slimline keyboard, versus a shrunken-down version of a traditional keyboard.  There may be some truth to that - it's nice that all of the keys are of uniform size and feel.At the end of the day, I think the nanoKey2 is well suited to do an adequate job across a variety of needs, ranging from simple monophonic passages, playing simple chords (and recording them as MIDI data), and tapping out beats.  It's not going to be the best tool at any of those things, but certainly an improvement on a small touchscreen device.  MIDI data editing and quantinization should also help to clean up some of the minor errors you commit using this type of input device.  And, best of all, it's extremely affordable and about as small and lightweight as you could expect.  The best controller you have is the one that you actually have with you when you need it, and Korg has made a device here that is actually practical enough to carry with you just about anywhere.

I'll keep this short, since I'm a pedal fanatic but pretty new to loopers.  I reviewed some of the different options, and the three main competitors in this price range are probably the TC Electronics Ditto Looper, the DigiTech JamMan Express XT, and the Boss RC-1 (and they were released in that order).  The total loop time for those three is 5, 10, and 12 minutes, respectively.  But realistically, it'll be pretty rare that I bother to loop an entire song, so even enough time to cover a cord progression of a few bars is probably sufficient.The JamMan Express XT and the Boss RC-1 are functionally very similar, but I opted for the JamMan because I was able to find a used deal and save some money.  The RC-1 has a visual loop indicator that this one does not have, so it's probably the "best" of the bunch now.  But all of these function quite well, especially if you practice by yourself and just want a simple practicing aid.The DigiTech has button that looks like an MXR, but is actually a soft press (which is becoming more and more prevalent).  This is important to point out because one concern I initially had was that a click-press button would be too hard to activate repetitively on the fly.  But that's not the case!  The controls are quite simple - first press starts record, press again to end the loop.  The loop will continue playing in "green" Play mode.  You can play along with your guitar, or press the button again to engage "yellow" overdub mode.  Double press the button to stop playback.  Holding the button down for a few seconds in play mode removes the overdubs.  Holding it for a few seconds while playback is stopped clears the loop.  That's really about it.  There's more challenge in the timing (and learning to play accurately) that there is in that actual operation of the device, which is fairly simple.This is a basic-yet-simple looper that will suit the needs of most people that just want to experiment, practice, or do some songwriting & sketching.  Effects pedals are tons of fun, but this pedal actually has the potential to encourage me to work on both my technical and creative guitar ability, which is long overdue.

Given that I listen to a fair amount of music and podcasts while working, exercising, or doing chores, I have a wide variety of (mostly) inexpensive earbuds that I stash throughout my house and at work.  Some of these are of the higher quality variety (like the Bose earbud set) that could almost compete with the sound quality of a pair of decent headphones, but most of them are budget options, like the kind that would ship with an iPhone or be sold at Target for $25 or less.  This Jadaol set was my first Bluetooth/wireless pair of any kind, and my hope was that sound quality would be somewhere between those extremes.At this price point, however, that was probably unrealistic.  Evaluating these against the other cheap earbuds I have at home (Apple, Sony, Phillips, etc.), these are actually towards the lower end of the spectrum.  The import packaging hilariously announces "Overweigh Bass" as a major selling point for the headset.  And there actually is a passable amount of low end for this style of lightweight, plastic earbuds.  But the overall balancing of the audio spectrum is a bit of a mess.  A bit muddled and lacking high end clarity, and just a pretty flat, uninteresting response in the lows and mids.  Listening to these versus a better quality set is kind of like hearing your favorite album on a car cassette player from the 1980's and then hearing it on a CD or high-resolution MP3 on a full stereo.So why not give it a lower review?  I felt it is still worthy stars because it gets most of its other marketing points right.  They ARE extremely lightweight.  In-ear comfort is very person-to-person, but the earbud an separate loop attachment (similar to the Bose) is a good, stable anchoring for the earbuds, and Jadaol includes a variety of different-sized replacements - no small feat for a $21 offering.  I actually felt that the Multi-Function button and +/- buttons on the right earpiece functioned well.  My iPhone 6 did automatically pair with the earbuds after I turned them back on a second time, though the 4-second hold time for the pairing button is a little annoying.Also, they do offer me a truly wireless connection for listening to content streamed from my phone, which I could see as useful for going on walks or working in the yard.  (There are times when you don't want a cord hanging in front of you, as it can get knocked off sweeping, picking things up, etc.).  This style of earplug does a decent job blocking out some surrounding noise, also (though they are not noise "cancelling" in any sense of the term).  I just think that due to the limited sound quality, it'd be better used for listening to spoken word/podcast content versus music.

Mini amps really aren't a "new" trend - there have been micro-sized amps from Pignose, Marshall, Fender, etc. on the market for several decades.  The part that is new is that some of these mini amps (yes, even the Fly 3 with its 3" speaker) actually put out quality tone to the point where you would actually want to practice with them.  By contrast, the similarly priced Fender Mini-Twin has become an attractive desk ornament.  But the Fly3 is absolutely no toy...FEATURES - As mentioned above, you are getting 3 watts of solid state power through a single 3" speaker.  The controls are very basic, but surprisingly versatile.  The clean channel will range from completely clean to slightly crunchy, and the OD channel morphs the tone into a much thicker, gainier overdrive.  Blackstar did not include a reverb because reverb circuitry is very power-hungry, but instead offer a simulated "tape delay" which can be adjusted for delay level and repeat time.  This is actually a terrific feature because the delay can be set to simulate almost a "room-like" ambient reverb effect.  Or, it could be used as a more traditional quarter or eighth note delay for soloing.  It doesn't have the features of a dedicated delay pedal, but as an add-on to a $60 amp, it's pretty outstanding.The Fly 3 also has a jack that doubles as a line out (with cabinet emulation!) and headphone output.  The Fly 3 really sounds excellent with headphones - plenty of fullness and power.  So, if the small speaker is a concern for you, keep in mind that the Fly 3 doubles as a pretty great little headphone amp.  There is also an MP3/Aux input for playing music with a 3.5mm cable, or jamming along with your favorite sounds.  (Note: the volume and other controls only affect the guitar input - MP3 volume controlled externally).The amp does not come with a power adapter, and it is 6.5V, so you can't use a standard "Boss" 9V power supply.  However, they sell an expansion kit for around $30, I believe, that has both the adapter and an add-on speaker cabinet to plug into the back, which doubles the output.  One advantage for the Fly3 over the ID:Core10 is that it is truly battery operated (6 "AA" batteries).  Blackstar claims that battery life can vary dramatically (4 to 40 hours!) based on volume of play.  But if it ends up being somewhere in the middle, I think that is acceptable.TONES - The "ISF" control is offered in place of a tone control, and I've actually been critical of it on other Blackstar amps.  I previously owned the ID:Core 10, which is basically this amp in 2x3" configuration, and with some additional effects and amp models - but felt that the ISF on that amp was a weak link, and missed a traditional tone control.  Currently, I have a Blackstar HT-1MC ("Metal") small tube amp, and the ISF control on there also leaves a bit to be desired.  But for whatever reason, I find the ISF to be much more effective on the Fly 3.  On the "0" side of things, it is supposedly doing an "American" sound, but to me it actually sounds brighter and more open.  The "10" side of the control they claim is "British voiced", though I swear it actually sounds more bass heavy and scooped.  I'm never quite clear on what the US/UK "tones" are supposed to be, anyway, but the good news is that ISF actually offers a good variety of tones here, especially noticeable through headphones.I'd be lying if I tried to convince you that a 3" speaker in a plastic housing is going to have anywhere close to the fullness and complexity of full-sized guitar combo.  But at the talk-over volumes this amp is designed to operate with, it's perfectly satisfying.  And the overdriven tones coupled with an ambient delay that can be set to very subtle levels make this amp sound larger and better than it really has any right to.There are some great mini amps now available on the market, but I consider the Fly3 to be a class of its own, given the $60 price point, and EXTREME portability.  This is an amp that could literally go anywhere, and is good enough and versatile enough that you'll actually want to play it.  It's really worth a look from any level of guitar player.

I kept hearing people on various podcasts (with no relationship to one another) talking about how much they enjoyed this album, so I finally checked it out.  At first, I was skeptical, primarily because I loved "Hot Fuss" by The Killers, but thought that "Sam's Town" and most of everything after it was a colossal disappointment.  Also, I'm not usually a fan of the result when the frontman of a group I like splits off and does a solo project.  Finally, I was hearing that the music was heavily influenced by a lot of 80's sounds and musicians that were not real points of reference for me.But so much for all those "rules" - "The Desired Effect" is just a terrific album from front to back.  You can hear a lot of the same songwriting techniques and chord progressions that were so effective with The Killers, but Flowers actually seems more comfortable in this pop role than he did as a "rock god" frontman. It's so good it has me revisiting Flowers' first album, as well as some of the later Killers stuff I had dismissed.

I purchased the Jensen Jet Falcon 10" (8 ohm) speaker to see if I could upgrade the sound of my Fender Super Champ X2, which is a $350 hybrid tube/modeling amp.  The stock speaker in that amp is a Fender Special Design 10", and it is by no means "bad" at low volumes, but I had story after story about people replacing it and being happy with the change.  However, it seems like the popular replacement speaker for that amp (and many American-voiced 10" combos) is the Eminence Ragin' Cajun, a super-efficient, LOUD, behemoth with a gigantic ceramic magnet.  What I was looking for was a more nuanced improvement to the stock speaker in the SCX2.  I did want or need the additional volume to play at home, but a slightly fuller tone, less harsh treble, and increased resistance to breakup/rattling were important to me.After months of research, enter the Jensen Jet Falcon 10".  The Jet Series is Jensens effort to preserve elements of their classic vintage tones (Jensen speakers were typical of Fender amps in the 1960's), but providing a slightly modern twist with some additional low end response and warmer overall voicing.  This appeals to me also because I have a great love for guitar pedals, so my SCX2 may be asked to cop a Fender tone one day, and then belt out a gainy Marshall riff the next.THE GOOD: Overall, I have to say that this is an excellent speaker.  If you already liked the tone of your Fender-style amplifier, the Jet Falcon is a fairly "safe" upgrade in terms of cost and staying true to the original tone of the amp.  Immediately upon installing this speaker, I noticed a fuller low end - not necessarily in the sub-bass frequencies, but in the lower mids.  I think this is a good thing unless your goal is to try and turn your Fender into a Mesa Boogie with a speaker change, which probably will not be successful.  Jensen also promotes the speaker as having a slightly rounded off high end, and I really like that aspect of it as a Strat & Tele player.  To be clear, the sparkling Fender high end is still there, but the high end is slightly warmer and more musical than the stock speaker.  The Jet Falcon also responds very well to gain - it was loving my overdrive and distortion pedals, and this will probably only improve as the speaker breaks in further.  Installation was a breeze - 4 screws in the exact same placement as my stock speaker and replaced the +/- connections by hand without having to modify anything.  It probably took 20 minutes (or less) to make the switch, and I have very little knowledge of how amps work.THE BAD: As happy as I was with the tones I described above, one thing alarmed me a little bit and almost caused me to give the speaker a 4-star review...I believe it is quieter than the stock speaker.  Now, for me, this is arguably a positive thing.  Tube and hybrid amps have a better quality tone at moderate or high volumes than they due at insanely low settings.  But many who make the effort to replace the speaker in their amp are hoping for more power, which is why the Ragin' Cajun is so popular in this amp, and I could see them being disappointed with this speaker.  As it is with me, the SCX2 already had more volume than I reasonably could need, not to mention both a "Line Out" jack and an extension cabinet output jack, so the Jet Falcon remains plenty powerful for my needs.Oh, and yes, the Jet Falcon does feature a magical green cone.  Worth mentioning since something like 95% of the speaker cones out there are some version of black or gray.  I think the color is cool and I can't see it through the grill of my amp anyway.  But buyer beware if cone color is a "dealbreaker" for you...The Jensen Jet Falcon is reasonably priced and delivers on classic American-voiced tones, with perhaps just a bit warmth and low end response behind it.  Do not buy this speaker if you hate everything about your Fender or similar amplifier, or if your goal is to be as loud as possible.  Do consider this speaker if you are interested in an affordable quality replacement or upgrade for your 10" combo or cabinet.

There is absolutely no shortage of "Marshall in a Box" pedals on the market nowadays.  Some of these are geared toward a vintage "Plexi"/JMP/JTM Marshall tone (Wampler Plexi Drive; Ramble FX Marvel Drive; Carl Martin PlexiTone), while others do a more modern JCM/Hi-Gain Marshall tone (MI Audio Crunch Box; Suhr Riot).  The ZVEX Vexter Box of Rock has been around for some time now, but I believe it does an excellent job of the former type of vintage "Marshall" tone.Two key things to note about this pedal.  First, it is quite bassy.  Original Marshall amps were basically modified Fender Bassmans, and the Box of Rock does a great job of shaping your guitar's EQ to match that aesthetic.  Second, unlike many other Marshall in a Box pedals, the Box of Rock explores the cleaner side of that sound.  There is enough gain available to handle classic rock, and the pedal cleans up quite well with the volume knob, which is useful. But I enjoyed setting up the Gain at about 9:00 and just using the pedal to do a "Hendrix" sound.I think the Boost option on this pedal is what really puts it over the top.  It can be run even if the overdrive channel is not turned on, and it offers a great clean boost.  Since it comes AFTER the overdrive effect, when you run the boost and OD in tandem the boost will actually raise the volume of your playing, not just the gain.  This is an excellent pedal and even if you own other Marshall-style pedals, there may be room for this one in your arsenal if you are looking for clean to lower-gain vintage Marshall tones.

I recently purchased a Tech 21 Trademark 30, and I feel that it is deserving of a 4-star review, though given some of the complexities involved in dialing in a particular sound, I will gladly revisit this review if my opinion improves over time.The TM30 is an entirely solid-state combo amplifier - no tubes involved.  However, it has a unique sound (which, at times, can sound "tube-like") due to the built-in SansAmp circuitry, which effectively serves as the preamp.  Tech21 debuted their original SansAmp pedal in the late 80's, and it is an extremely useful preamp-in-a-pedal for use with DI recording, mixers, and PA's.  However, they can also be run directly into the power amp/speaker section of a combo amp, and that is effectively what the TM30 does here.THE GOOD: One of the things that appealed to me about the TM30 was that it is extremely compact and lightweight (only 14 pounds!).  This is a huge plus for gigging musicians, obviously, but even home players and hobbyists like me appreciate having a more portable amplifier than can be tucked into a closet, and doesn't need to be permanently displayed like a concrete fixture in the home.  I believe the amps are American designed and manufactured, and the build quality - while a bit utilitarian - seems to be quite good.  There is a power unit affixed to the bottom inside of the cabinet (which is open back), so you have a perfectly square box to put away with the cord tucked inside.Even though this model is now at least 10 years old, it remains unique in the sheer number of options this amp offers for practicing, performing, and recording.  The TW30 has a proprietary 10" speaker to play as a combo amp.  There is a headphone jack for silent practicing.  There is an extension cabinet jack to use the TW30 as a head for an external speaker.  There is an effects loop (rare for amps of this size and price), which allows you to plug directly into the power amp section with other pedals.  And there is an XLR out jack for direct recording or plugging into a PA system.  One of the more complete selections of features you could imagine in a 10" combo amp.The tones offered by this amp are quiet varied, and generally quite good.  The preamp is basically the same as the SansAmp GT2 pedal, so you have TWEED, BRIT, and CALIF settings, which are basically Fender, Marshall, and Mesa/Boogie.  The Tweed setting is my favorite by far, offering full cleans to bluesy crunch to overdrive.  The British setting is alarming thing with knobs at noon, but can be tweaked with the recommended settings to sound convincingly Marshall.  The California setting offers even more gain and low end and can reach 80's and 90's metal tones.  So it's a good variety of sounds compared to more traditional solid state amps, which may have a fully clean channel with perhaps a single flavor of overdrive on a separate channel.The inclusion of an authentic Accutronics Spring Reverb was the amp's "almost too good to be true" feature for me.  Most small combos have gone digital, and while I have no problem with most digital reverbs, the spring reverb in this amp is terrific.THE BAD (or less good): Sometimes the amplifiers that promise everything deliver on almost nothing, and I do find the TM30 at times to be frustrating to dial in.  The tone controls are extremely powerful, almost to a fault.  Many amps - such as my Vox Pathfinder 15 - have a very specific idea of how they sound and how to dial them in.  This is not really a strong point of the TM30 - it's not an amp that lends well to setting everything at noon and making small tweaks so you can start playing.  You really need to take note of the Clean/Hi Gain/Hot toggle switch, as well as the cabinet selector (US/UK/Flat).  Tech21 provides a few suggested settings, and there are many found online.  The Mids control, in particular, can make a dramatic difference in the shape of the tone.I spend most of my time using the Clean Tweed settings, which are quite good.  But it's worth noting that the amp really does not offer meaningful clean tones on the British and California settings.  I don't feel like the speaker is a weak point of the amp, but it's also unrealistic to expect it to handle three entirely different amplifier sounds with equally good results.  It does seem capable of handling the low end of the higher gain settings without much speaker distortion or rattling.  But trying to find my own Marshall or MESA sounds by experimentation led to some muddiness.  Tone is subjective, but the best way I can describe my experience with the higher gain settings is that it captures aspects of that tone very well, but seems to "just miss" on other aspects.  In terms of volume output, the amp is sufficiently loud for me, but may lack clean headroom, and the volume varies based on settings, since the EQ is cut/boost.  (Note: The presence of the XLR out combats this in live settings, as you could run your 14-pound amp basically as a preamp for a PA system and have all the volume you need).The amp is also victim to a problem common with many analog and digital modelers, there is a fair amount of "hiss" or noise as you turn up the gain - mostly on the British and Calfornia settings.  Not particularly noticeable once you start playing, and perhaps not in a live setting with ambient noise, but it can be bit irritating in a quiet playing environment.  I'm fairly certain that the Tech21 preamp pedals have this issue on certain settings also.THE VERDICT: I purchased this amp primarily because I got a good deal on it and because I really missed having an amp with an effects loop.  I enjoy playing with the Tech21 Character/Joyo Sound pedals using only the speaker of the TM30, and the sounds I get with that setup are often better than using the dashboard of the combo itself.  In the early-to-mid 2000's, I think the flexibility of these different sounds was probably more unique than it is now.  Digital modeling amps like the Fender Mustang offer a much greater variety of sounds, and the tone quality has improved considerably since the time when the Trademark amps were a new product.That being said, it remains an incredibly versatile and compact product, and if you can find just one or two "go-to" settings that you like, you can generate a nice clean tone that works well with pedals.  The spring reverb is excellent.  I don't know that I would recommend this to many people as their "only amp" now in 2015 with the similarly-priced alternatives, but this is a quality product capable of a lot of good tones.

The Caline CP-14 "English Man Distortion" is a Chinese-made, extremely affordable overdrive/distortion box based on the tones of Marshall "Plexi" (or JTM/JMP-style) amplifiers of the late 1960's.  However, this description becomes less useful given that the English Man is an apparently clone of the original Carl Martin PlexiTone pedal, and more specifically, the high gain channel of that pedal.  For that reason, the English Man is focused much more on a "hot rodded", higher gain version of the Plexi.  This is so much the case that fans of cleaner, bluesier Plexi tones may feel misled or disappointed by the English Man.  Nevertheless, with a price point at around 30 dollars (including shipping), the English Man is a reasonably well-made clone that excels at it's specific tone of aggressive vintage Marshall tones for heavy rock.OUTPUT - I briefly owned a Joyo Hot Plexi, which may have been based on a similar or identical circuit, but I feel that the English Man is notably superior to that pedal.  The English Man has TONS of output - I found unity gain to be around 9:00 or 9:30 on the volume knob, so it offers plenty of headroom.  The original Carl Martin PlexiTone was popular, but it was a large pedal with a set-in power cord, which is almost unheard of for compact pedals.  Carl Martin has since designed a compact (gold-colored) PlexiTone that features more mids and brings the form factor more in line with other effects pedals.  I have not played the original (black box) PlexiTone, but I can confirm that the English Man has an extremely powerful sound, and sounds convincingly "big" with the slightly scooped mids.  It sounded great with several of my guitars, but even my Strat middle pickup produced a convincing low-end response with it, which is not always the case with OD/Distortion pedals.GAIN BEHAVIOR - It's probably unfair to criticize the English Man for how quickly it becomes "dirty", once you understand that it is cloned off of a specific high gain channel of another pedal.  This is meant to be a distortion pedal, not an "amp-in-a-box" covering the whole clean-to-dirty spectrum.  With the gain at "0" you do get output, but it's not a pure clean tone, and not particularly useable.  I also did not find that it cleaned up particularly well with the guitar volume knob, though I find that only a select few dirtboxes really do that "well".  But with the gain knob at 8:00 to 9:00, there were some very good, almost "Hendrix-y" light gain tones in there.  The pedal retains its signature fullness at all settings, which is nice.  Actually, if you are familiar with the Joyo Ultimate Drive, this pedal reminded me a bit of that one, at least in terms of output and the powerful low frequencies.I do wish that the pedal stayed cleaner a bit longer, but again, this is a clone of a particular channel, and presumably, there were lower gain channels and settings available separately on the original that would cover that.  I considered a 4-star rating, but it does the Marshall rock tones so well (and so affordably), it's better to appreciate it for what it does.  Although the pedal is a tad on the noisy side, I think it's particularly intriguing for people that use lower output pickups or single coils - it always seems to succeed in making your tone "bigger".  The tone control is also quite useful, working more like a high-end roll-off, as opposed to the horrible Boss DS-1 style of tone control that can only seem to introduce treble by subtracting bass.I've purchased three of the Caline pedals (Orange Burst and Pure Sky OD's, also), and none of them has disappointed.  The English Man isn't the most versatile distortion pedal ever made, but it does its job well and introduces vintage Marshall flavor with a more modern amount of available gain.

I HATE being out of tune.  I also tend to get a little heavy-handed with my playing style, and do a lot of string bending, so it's not uncommon for me to have to tweak a "G" or "B" string after a few minutes of aggressive playing.  So I have no idea why I didn't put much thought into finding a convenient, efficient, and affordable tuning option for my guitars.  Seriously, I own dozens of effects pedals (including two pedal tuners), but what about all of those other times when I'm not using a full pedalboard?Problem solved for less than $10: Enter the Snark SN-5.  This thing is crazy fast and accurate.  I guess I did not fully realize (or appreciate) that clip on tuners work by contact vibration, not ambient sound (like the way the free tuner on you iPhone might).  So you can tune an unplugged electric guitar before you even turn on your amp and hear those awful resonating detuned chords!I think my favorite aspect of this tuner, however, is the speed and stability of the reading.  That's a major problem with most audio-based tuners, as they tend to flutter all over the place.  The SN-5 identifies and holds a reading for the note you are playing, and responds smoothly as you tighten or loosen the string.  It's quicker, more effective, and more affordable than most of the alternatives.  When I ordered mine, I wondered why I didn't already have one.  Now, I'm wondering why I don't have one for every room I play guitar in!

After DOD pedals were absorbed into the DigiTech brand name, I always felt like the HardWire pedal series was a direct response to the reputation of DOD pedals as cheap, unreliable effects for bedroom players.  The HardWire pedals came with a very sturdy "BOSS-style" soft switch, and solid metal enclosure with a wide, low, and stable profile, and bells and whistles like Mod switches and metal knobs.  In short, pedals like the Valve Distortion and Tube Overdrive were boutique-caliber pedals at BOSS prices, and you could argue that the RV-7 Stereo Reverb was one of the better pedals they ever made.  As of early 2015, it still seems unclear if DigiTech has formally abandoned the HardWire line in favor of new products, but the RV-7 is a pedal that should stand the test of time.There are a lot of quality reverb pedals nowadays that can cover a variety of reverb styles - including the Boss RV-5 and the TC Electronics Hall of Fame.  Those are excellent pedals, too, but the RV-7 really does a nice job covering everything from vintage spring reverbs, to the subtlety of a room effect reverb, to the lush, deep effects of a hall reverb.  And each of these settings actually seems to range from the very subtle to the over-the-top, which is where many reverb pedals fall short.But what really sets the RV-7 apart in this price range is that the 7 reverb modes are supported by Lexicon algorithms.  Lexicon may be unknown to many casual guitarists, but they are a legendary name in the development of digital reverb and effects.  The rack-mounted equivalents of these effects cost thousands of dollars in the 80's, and even now are usually in a much larger form factor costing hundreds of dollars.  This is true-to-life ambient sound effects in the size of a stompbox, and sold for $150 or less.  Amazing.  I don't know that this is the "best" spring reverb I've heard in a pedal (the Catalinbread Topanga deserves some mention), but it's a very good one in a pedal that does 6 other things.  The Lexicon-supported Room and Hall settings are terrific, as is the Plate setting for a bright, 70's-like finish to your muted riffs.  The Reverse, Gated, and Modulated settings along the top are a bit more niche, but all done extremely well.  I truly believe this is the last Reverb pedal I will ever need, and that's not something a pedal addict can usually say with much confidence!A few caveats to point out - the pedal has a hookup for a 9V battery, but it's basically decorative in a high-powered digital reverb pedal like this one.  (By the way, if you were ever stumped how to access the battery compartment on a DigiTech pedal, as I stupidly was for awhile, the hinges on the footstomp portion double as release pins to kick off the cover - press inward with guitar plugs on both sides!)  You will get zero battery life with the amount of power this demands, so you will want a good power adapter.  The One Spot adapter puts out 1700mA, which is plenty of power, but some digital pedals run in parallel have issues with digital pedals.  If this is an ongoing issue, an isolated power source like the one from Voodoo Labs should do the trick.Whether or not these pedals are discontinued, they are still being stocked online and in many stores.  I think it's an excellent pedal with hundreds of dollars of value compressed into a compact pedal, and at a reasonable price.

I won't add too much given the volume of excellent reviews already available, but this is a very good, affordable burr grinder for coffee that I would rate 4-stars if not for the fact that the design problem with the top screw does seem to be easily addressed with a split-lock or rubber washer (as discussed/proposed in the review by "Bob M.").  Without that, the handle and top screw will back itself off very quickly, and I could see that causing it to fail with some use.  And I do notice some grind inconsistency as you get into larger grinds, but not so much at a setting appropriate for normal drip/pour-over grinds.If you are new to these manual grinders, as I was, people are not exaggerating when they talk about needing a few minutes to complete the grinding.  I tend to get distracted by things so I am not consistently grinding full speed, but I usually prepare around 4-6 tablespoons of grinds, and the average time to do that for me is probably 3-5 minutes.  Then again, this is not a grinder I use on a daily basis - there are times I want a quick cup of coffee (pour over, Mr. Coffee, or even Keurig), and there are times I want a "better cup" of coffee and will spend a few minutes on it (fresh burr grind into the Chemex).  For the latter, this is a nice product.

The Wampler Pinnacle is moderate-to-high gain distortion pedal that I lusted after for a long period of time, and despite the relatively prohibitive price tag (at least for a non-professional musician), owning one makes me wonder why I didn't just buy it sooner.  Unlike some of the other reviewers (and probably the strong majority of Wampler users), I did not immediately fall in love with Wampler pedals.  I tried a Wampler Sovereign, and it was certainly a good distortion pedal, but not necessarily "$100 better" than anything else I owned (returned) it.  But after buying a Black '65 (love it) and getting a chance to try out the Euphoria (likely my next Wampler), I gained a new-found appreciation for Wampler as a company, and gave the Pinnacle a second look.  Wampler comes out pretty hard selling the Pinnacle as a "Brown Sound" in a box pedal (even including a testimonial from the guy who worked on Van Halen's gear in the manual!), but if the idea of making your setup sound like that tone appeals to you, this is really about as close as you get just by adding a pedal.The standard version of the Pinnacle has about the same footprint as an MXR pedal, and is surprisingly easy to dial in.  Wampler is known for providing a lot of bells and whistles in the form of complex EQ sections and mod switches.  On the one hand, this offers a ton of value in a boutique pedal, which is appreciated.  But in the case of the Sovereign Distortion, I found the EQ options to be a bit paralyzing - there was so much interplay in the switches and adjustments to the mids that I didn't know where to start, or even how to recreate good sounds I stumbled upon.  Not so with the Pinnacle.  Basically, there is a single tone knob that operates as you'd expect, and the Contour knob goes from less to more "scooped" as you rotate clockwise.  The Vintage/Modern switch also does this to an extent - the Vintage setting has scooped mids and a darker sound, whereas the Modern sound has more mids presence and perceived output.  I agree with some of the posters that the Boost switch is a little unnecessary on some Wampler pedals, but I do like it here on the Pinnacle.  Brian Wampler indicates that it gives a bit more gain as well as some attack, and he demonstrated the difference with some palm muted chords.  I really did not have a need for the Deluxe version of this pedal, and actually preferred the smaller footprint over having a standalone boost switch.  (I think the double switch is more useful in the new Plexi Drive Deluxe, where the "Boost" switch is actually a standalone tubescreamer that can be engaged even with the rest of the pedal in bypass).I won't spend too much time trying to describe the sound of the Pinnacle - if you're familiar with Van Halen's tone from different eras, there's a good chance you find that somewhere in the Pinnacle.  There's a "sag" in the low end that really creates saturation in notes and chords, and yet the pedal refuses to be muddy or non-articulate.  Plenty of gain on tap, of course, but while I would not use this pedal to do bluesy vintage Marshall JTM/Plexi tones, the lower gain settings do get closer to that range than I would have expected.  Many Marshall-in-a-box pedals are "one-trick ponies" with a specific tone in mind, but the Pinnacle is not that.  It actually has a good degree of range of lower gain and crunchy, to scooped and completely saturated.Finally, for home players and users of smaller amps (which I feel is often an "underrepresented majority" in many pedal discussions), I'm happy to report that the Pinnacle does not require a massive tube-driven stack with cabinets to sound "authentic".  Obviously, amp voicing and speaker size will have a large impact on the final result, but my first demo of the Pinnacle was on a solid state Vox Pathfinder 10, and even at bedroom volumes with that less-than-ideal setup, the tone I had imagined was there.  The Euphoria, Plexi-Drive, and other Wamplers go a step further with an independent bass control (or bass boost switch), but the Pinnacle has more-than-adequate low end on smaller amps.  It's an excellent distortion pedal on smaller or larger rigs alike.

The Yellow Fall is my first Donner pedal, but I'm impressed enough with its value to consider buying others.  First, some background - Donner (along with ENO and a few other brands) are basically an effort to burn through inventory used for the excellent Chinese-made Mooer pedal line, and rebranding them as a cheaper alternative.  The pedal casing and chipset, from what I hear, are basically identical to the corresponding Mooer equivalent, though the primary knob has been switched and it would not surprise me to learn that a few other (cheaper) components have been substituted.Still at around 30 bucks, the Donner pedals offer incredible value for the price.  The Yellow Fall "analog delay" has a pretty good range of delay (I believe it goes up to 600 miliseconds - many cheap delays only get to 300ms).  The two micro knobs control echo and feedback.  Feedback is very clearly the number and duration of repeats.  "Echo" is described in the manual as affecting the tone of the delay.  I'm not sure if this is what it is actually doing or if it is acting more like a "level" on most delay pedals, which makes the overall effect more prominent.  However, it did seem to make the echos trailing off seem brighter.Yes, the pedal is digital, but "analog" is describing the character of the delay.  There are many modern delay pedals that use digital chipsets to simulate the analog or tape delays of the 60's and 70's.  I think the Yellow Fall does this quite well.  Some people have complained that the repeats sound "modulated", but that's sort of the point.  This isn't for a clean, exact digital replication of notes (similar to a slapback delay or U2-style dotted eighth delay) - it has a more warm, haunting character, and sounds great for ambient soloing and chords alike.Also, as has been pointed out, there is an error/mistaken reference in the Donner literature about the 9V jack.  It claims it is "positive tip", but what they actually mean is "negative center", which is the same as Boss, MXR, etc. and the vast majority of power supplys out there like OneSpot.  There is no "tip" on a BOSS-style adapter, either, but that's more an issue of semantics.  Rest assured, it will work fine with the BOSS-style adapters you may already have.  But you will need one, since this pedal is so compact, there wouldn't even been room or a 9V battery to fit in there.

This is my first JHS pedal and I am impressed by the care and thought that went into the Twin Twelve are absolutely top notch.  I will definitely consider buying other JHS pedals in the future.  There are just few shortcomings (or design choices) of the Twin Twelve that prospective buyers need to understand before buying.  However, please note that the bulk of this review was written to reflect a 4* rating, but later increased to 5* after I had more time with the pedal.BUILD QUALITY - Like I said, the quality of the JHS stuff is about as good as it gets.  No expense spared on any of the components, and everything feels solid and built to last.  If you appreciate the quality of a Wampler pedal, for example, the JHS is on a similar level, from the sturdy switch, to the firmness of the knobs, and the built-out 9V jack on the top, which I prefer as it avoids getting in the way of the I/O jacks.  This thing has roughly the same profile of an MXR pedal, but is higher and heavier.  I think heavy is a good thing with pedals, as the thicker case means better durability, and they are less apt to get kicked around when you are trying to step on them.  The unboxing experience (if that's your thing) with JHS is very satisfying, complete with red paper "confetti", documentation, a JHS catalog, and a bag with rubber stick-on footies and a JHS guitar pick.PEDAL CONCEPT - The Twin Twelve Overdrive is very directly marketed as a Silvertone "amp-in-a-box". More specifically, it is the Silvertone 1484, a 2x12", 60-watt, tube behemoth, which I have never played, but I understand needed to be played extremely loud to get it's signature overdrive sound.  Not even 15 years ago, the idea of a Silvertone-in-a-box would have been pretty laughable, but these very affordable (at the time) amplifiers from the 60's have had a resurgence with the indie rock genre, and specific artists like Beck, Jack White, and Vampire Weekend.The primary selling point of the Twin Twelve is two-fold.  First, owning the actual amp is unrealistic for most, since they are about a half-century old, large, and very loud.  So if the Silvertone sound is something you desire, a $200 amp-in-a-box pedal could be viewed as a relative bargain.  Second, the original 1484 lacked a master volume, so the signature "cranked" overdrive tones could only be achieved at insane volumes.  The Twin Twelve pedal adds a master volume to the gain knob, and includes baxandall tone controls that cut or boost bass/treble considerably.SOUND QUALITY & REALIZATION OF CONCEPT - There are definite positives to the direction JHS has gone with the Twin Twelve.  Viewed as a overdrive pedal, the Twin Twelve offers a unique crunch sound up to 11:00 on the gain knob, and becomes almost like a warm fuzz pedal beyond 11:00.  If you're unfamiliar with the Silvertone sound, it has an almost "lo-fi" quality to it.  The sound can be quite divisive with guitar players - these really were not considered high quality amps compared to the Fender, Marshall, and Vox amps of that area - they were sold at Sears.  The best description I can give is that the overdriven sound is almost like a Fender with a blown/damaged speaker with maybe a hint of a jet engine in there.  In other words, it's a loose, messy overdrive, yet somehow lends itself to chords and signing mid-rangey notes - just not in the way that more celebrate amps would do it.The primary issue I have with the JHS Twin Twelve is that it's a "cranked overdrive pedal", not an "amp-in-the-box" pedal - even though they so badly want it to be the latter.  Directly from the JHS website, they promote the following: "The Drive knob of the pedal is essentially the Volume control of the amplifier.  As you turn up the Drive knob of the pedal you get more overdrive and tube-like saturation just like you would by cranking up the Volume knob on the amplifier."  In my opinion, that's simply not true.  The entire pedal is skewed towards more gain and more saturation.  With the gain knob at "0" there is no output.  The only "clean" tones are probably from about 8:30 to 10:00 on the gain knob, even with single coils, and even there you'll find a bit of grit.  To be fair, the tone does clean up exceptionally well with your guitar's volume knob, but doing this also mutes much of the high end chime I suspect the original tube amp would have had.  Again, I have not played a 1484, but JHS's own claim that you had to turn them all the way up to get overdriven tones contradicts the fact that the gain knob on their pedal dirties up in a real hurry.If you can let go of the fact that this is marketed as a pedal that turns your clean tone into a Silvertone 1484, I think there's a lot to like here.  The tone controls are powerful and you can dial a thick, warm tone on small and large amps alike.  And it definitely does not sound like a Tubescreamer, OCD, or any of the traditional tones you'd imagine from a cranked Fender or Vox.  JHS have a unique concept here, and have executed parts of it extremely well.  This may be a bit of a niche product, but for fans of Silvertone amps and some of the artists that used them, the Twin Twelve is a noteworthy addition to the crowded boutique pedal market.UPDATE (04/20/15) - I am updating my review because I tried the Twin Twelve with a broader array of guitars and amps, and I feel that is worthy of a 5-star rating.  That is not to say that "retract" any of my earlier comments - I do wish that the pedal offered a wider range of clean Silvertone sounds, but using more vintage-voiced pickups and setting the gain around 9:00 with the volume up higher, you can get some pretty distinctive clean tones out of this pedal.  And, as I said before, it cleans up remarkably well with the guitar volume knob.  Most important of all in my decision to improve the rating - the pedal is very well made, and if you wanted this type of sound, I don't know where else you get it from.  It's a bit of a niche product, but increasingly, I feel it excels at what JHS were trying to do with it.

The influx of extremely low-priced Chinese clones of popular Western boutique effects pedals is really a somewhat recent trend.  Brands like Mooer and Joyo offer a wide array of effects pedals (essentially based off of "cloned" circuits) at price points as low as $30.  And while some of these "clones" are duds, some of them at least appear to be made well enough to last for some time.  I've now purchased two pedals under the Caline brand (Orange Burst and Pure Sky), and am somewhat optimistic that these pedals fit into the latter camp.DESCRIPTION - The "Pure Sky Overdrive" is apparently a clone of a early version of the Paul Cochrane "Timmy", which is a highly-regarded "transparent overdrive" that I have not played.  However, I have played and owned some other similar pedals such as the Klon-based EHX Soul Food, and the Joyo Sweet Baby.  "Transparent overdrive" is one of those musical "terms of art", but it basically means that the pedal is some combination of volume, gain, and dynamic expression while also retaining the essential elements of your clean tone.  By contrast, something like a Tubescreamer would also be a low-to-moderate gain overdrive, but would NOT be considered transparent, since it purposefully cuts out some bass, provides a mid-range boost, and tends to a have a rounding, compressed effect on the high end.  So, while you are unlikely to step on a Pure Sky Overdrive to go from clean tone to full-out rock overdrive, there are many other things a good transparent can do for you - an "always on" clean boost, adding just a bit of grit to your tone, or stacking with another overdrive to boost or emphasize parts of its tone.BUILD QUALITY - Reports of failing pedals are EXTREMELY anecdotal, so I tend to evaluate my reviews based on what I can see and feel during the expected use of the pedal.  Judged on this basis, I find the Caline pedals to be outstanding.  In fact, the jacks, knobs, and switch are superior even to the early Joyo pedals, and at least on par with the Mooer micro pedals (though a completely different form factor).  The metal casing is very thick and sturdy.  It's fastened by 4 screws that would need to be removed for 9V battery access, but this is becoming increasingly common (as battery compartment doors eventually break or become lost).  It sounds almost laughable to say, but the knobs on this thing feel similar to my Wampler in terms of resistance and stability.  I'm not under any delusion that the manufacturer hasn't cut costs wherever they could here, but at least from the exterior, you won't notice it.  See the excellent review from @rob for more discussion of the circuitry and other durability pluses and minuses.TONE & CONTROLS - While I need to try it out with a wider variety of amps and guitars, I've been generally pleased with the sound of the Pure Sky.  Again, this style of overdrive is meant to give your tone "just a little more".  It will not take your tone to entirely new sonic areas all by itself.  For this reason, I actually feel like the gain settings worked best from 0 to 50%.  Higher gain settings sound little fizzy and less appealing.  But my favorite feature of both the Pure Sky and the Orange Burst are the tone controls.  At the 12:00 position, they are neutral.  But you can then cut or boost Bass and Treble a fair amount.  And since this is a tonally "transparent" pedal, you can actually use the Pure Sky to "correct" an amp that is a bit too bright, or perhaps needs a little kick in the low end.  I've heard people say that it is effective as a stacking pedal for the same reasons.I will revisit this review later if I find problems or have additional thoughts on how it sounds.  But at $30, this Caline Pure Sky is well-constructed and quite useful for a number of different applications.  I will also note that most of the pictures do not do the aesthetics of the pedal justice - it has an attractive glossy finish is sky blue paint, and the blue LED finishes it off nicely.  Great value for tone experimenters and hobbyists looking for a good transparent overdrive, but want some money left over to own other pedals!

(Note: I was careful to be clear which of the 40+ Mooer pedals I was reviewing in the title, since Amazon reviews for ALL of their pedals get lumped together on a single page!)I recently purchased the Mooer Rumble Drive because I was while I have far too many overdrive pedals (it's addicting), I realized that one of those elusive tones I did not have represented anywhere was the Dumble Overdrive Special.  You would be forgiven as a newer guitarist if you had no idea what a "Dumble" even is...they were boutique amplifiers made in limited numbers, and original Dumbles now sell for $25,000 to $50,000.  Since that is obviously out of my budget, the idea of a micro pedal that could approximate those tones for less than $100 is fairly appealing.  You've likely heard Dumble tones from guitarists like Carlos Santana, Robben Ford, Stevie Ray Vaughan, and (now) Joe Bonamassa.  But until more recently, there were not a lot of "D-style" pedals on the market, and certainly not affordable ones.Enter the Mooer Rumble Drive, a Chinese-made overdrive pedal that was rumored to be a clone of the famed Zendrive, though actual Zendrive users seem to debate whether they sound alike.  This matters less to me, because I am actually quite happy with the Rumble Drive as it approximates what I THINK a Dumble would sound like.  Of course, since nearly 0% of guitar players will ever really play one, who knows, right?Original Dumbles were basically modified Fender "tweed" and "blackface" amplifiers, and you can hear elements of that American roundness and high end sparkle.  What I feel that the Rumble Drive captures well about the idea of a "Dumble tone" is the smooth, singing compression of the upper mids, combined with a low end that is bassy, but also very loose and saggy in terms of its gain structure.  I've seen some people criticize the pedal as sounding either "lo-fi" or "like a modified Tubescreamer".  This pedal has some similarities with a tubescreamer (and is green, which probably strengthens those impressions), but only really in the way it smooths and compresses the high end.  The low end presence is much more prominent than a Tubescreamer, and it's more reminiscent of an evolved (or devolved) Fender amp being pushed to the limit.  It's a great tone for bluesy rhythms and singing leads.  It's less of an ideal tone if you want tight, syncopated distortion.Finally, I want to add that this is the first Mooer pedal I have purchased, but it will not be the least.  These micro pedals are very sturdily constructed, and while they require an adapter (9V, center negative polarity; like Boss/OneSpot standard), I find them very well constructed and easy to store and use.  I stayed away from the Mooer line for awhile because they were a little more expensive than other Chinese imports and I wasn't sure about the micro knobs.  But everything feels sturdy and built to last, and the Mooers are considered in top tier of craftsmanship as Chinese clones go.  If you enjoy bluesy/crunchy distortion but want something different than "just another Tubescreamer variant", check out the Mooer Rumble Drive.

After a pretty lengthy search for a small, low-wattage tube amp for bedroom-level volumes, I had all but given up.  Then I came across a significant markdown for the Blackstar HT1MC, which is the "Metal" version of the HT-1 and HT-1R.  While many people are familiar with the HT-1 (and particularly the stripped down HT-1 "Special Edition" that is displayed at Guitar Center and often sells for less than $200), there was very sparse information in terms of reviews or video demos of the HT-1 Metal.So, I was taking a bit of a chance, even with the sale price.  But the HT-1 Metal did not disappoint.  Let's get the basics out of the way first - this is a genuine "tube" or "valve" combo amp (ECC82/ECC83).  With only one watt of power, it fits into a recent trend of amateur and professional guitarists alike searching for low volume amplifier that can capture the rich saturation and overdriven tones of cranked tube amp, but at volumes you could actually practice with or play in a house or apartment.  In my experience, a lot of mini amps attempt this, but few get it quite right.  Often, the low-wattage amps become one-note, offering an overdriven sound but leaving little clean headroom (this was my experience with some of the smaller Vox tube amps).  In many cases, the sound simply doesn't translate well using a speaker of 8" or even less.  And even if the tone is passable, many of these amps lack basic features like reverb, master volume/gain controls, headphone jacks, and cabinet out jacks.  The Blackstar HT-1 Metal has ALL of the features, but how does it stack up otherwise?SOUND QUALITY - Being exclusively a home player/hobbyist, I've played and owned a number of combo amps with 8" speakers.  No matter how good the speaker, there is an unavoidable compromise of the lower end bass frequencies with a speaker of that size.  That being said, the HT-1 Metal handles lower frequencies quite well, and considering that this is an amp made to play at or near its maximum volume, there was hardly any rattling or sign that the speaker was overwhelmed.  The clean tones on this amp are outstanding.  Blackstar claims there is a metal "voicing" to this model, but with a Strat (or even a hot set of humbuckers) and the right settings, you can get the high end to sparkle.The "Clean" channel ranges from completely clean to fairly thick crunch, and it excels for rock and blues.  The "overdrive" channel has a nice, thick tone, but does not get so muddy that it loses its harmonic qualities.  I should point out at this point that I am NOT a metal player, and did not purchase this amp because I wanted a "metal" tone.  While this amp is certainly intended for low-volume metal, it offers far more than that.  Actually, the overdriven tones on this amp remind me as much of a cranked JCM800, as opposed to a Mesa, Soldano, or other more "modern" sound, and for me this is a good thing.This is not an amp for gigging.  While the one amp of power will stay clean enough at decent volume, the most volume you will get from this amp is what I would describe as "one level above talk-over volumes", and that is by design.  I have not heard another low-wattage tube amp that does as good of a job as this one at conveying that "saturated tube" sound at low volumes, while offering that with both cleaner and overdriven sounds.BUILD QUALITY - I am a big fan of the aesthetics and general quality of the HT-1 Metal.  By comparison, the HT-1 Special Edition feels a bit cheaper with compromises in the tolex, grill, and piping.  The most noticeable feature of the HT-1 Metal is the matte finish black metal grille on the front.  Everything seems to be fastened securely and nothing rattled when I started to push the amp.  The knobs are high quality and the three jacks are metal, not plastic.  Given that the whole point of this thing is to be able to tuck it away in a closet or storage bin, it feels to durable enough to handle that treatment.The amp actually does weigh around 15 pounds, but I set it up next to my Vox Pathfinder 15 (an excellent solid state amp also with an 8" speaker), and the HT-1 Metal looks literally half of the size of the Pathfinder.  It almost defies logic how they fit the speaker, two tubes, and circuitry for the control panel into this small package, but it makes for a very compact, sturdy little beast.FEATURES - In lieu of an EQ control, many Blackstar amps have a single knob called "ISF" (Infinite Shape Feature).  This is supposed to morph the equalization/voicing of the amp from a US to a UK style amplifier.  It isn't without its problems (discussed below), but I will say that amp offered usable tones while avoiding excessive darkness or brightness on most settings.  On-board Reverb was a critical feature in earning my interest in this amp, and it covers a good range from very subtle to "ambient".The headphone jack doubles as a line out jack, and it includes a speaker emulation to make the resulting signal sound like you are hearing it through a large cabinet.  I own several modeling amps, and I actually think the HT-1 Metal is the best of the bunch using headphones.  Note that it uses a 1/4" jack, so you may need an adapter for some headphones, but those are cheap and readily available.  The sound quality was outstanding into my Sony MDR-7506 headphones.Finally, players wishing to use this combo amp as a "head" into a larger cabinet will be pleased to hear that not only is there a jack to run the signal out to a speaker cabinet, but it also works with 4, 8, 16-ohm cabinets.DRAWBACKS - I do not have many things to complain about with this amp, but the few complaints I do have relate to ISF.  While a three-band EQ may have been too much to expect for an amp of this size, even a single tone knob would have been preferable, in my opinion.  ISF claims to go from "US" to "UK", but especially in the clean tones, I do not hear it.  Instead, the "US" setting is just thinner and brighter, while going full "UK" can get a bit dark and murky.  My favorite settings are probably somewhere in the middle, and the amp does take pedals well, so you can experiment based off a (mostly) clean tone in that way.  I have not tried using an EQ pedal in front of the amp, yet, but suspect that may be of some help.It's also important to be clear that this is not a particularly loud amplifier.  Raw volume is certainly not the goal of the HT-1 Metal, but some users might expect just a bit more volume compared to other tube amps with an 8" speaker.ALTERNATIVES? - If you like the idea of an affordable, real "tube" amplifier, but need a bit more volume and depth, consider the excellent VHT Special 6.  Chinese-made and hand wired, it's a great amp for modding, and I seriously considered one, except that I thought it just got a bit too loud to reach that "cranked" sound I was looking for.Also, if you aren't married to the idea that you HAVE to have a tube amplifier, the Yamaha THR-10 (listing at about $300) really is in a class of its own in terms of what it offers for bedroom level practicing.  The THR-10 is a solid-state amplifier, but models classic tube amps in a very authentic way, and is even more compact than the HT-1 (half the weight and the size of a lunch box).  That being said, the two amps compliment each other well, and the HT-1 works better with pedals versus a modeling amp.I wanted to write a lengthier review for this amp because I feel as if not very people own it, and even fewer are talking about it online.  I took a risk in ordering one, and it has met or exceeded my expectations thus far.  That being said, I cannot say that I would have considered buying it at the full price of $350.  It is arguably "worth" that much in terms of craftsmanship and overall quality, but only at the sale price was I convinced enough to give it a try.  It's an excellent amp for home practicing and even some recording (either by line out or by microphone).  It's advertised as a "metal" amplifier, but it actually excels at a wide range of musical genres, and responded well to several different guitars that I tried with it.

I feel a little under-qualified to give a thorough review of the Full-Drive 2, since it has so many different settings and I haven't had a ton of time with it yet.  But this quite a versatile boost/overdrive pedal, so long as you understand that it is still fundamentally based on a Tubescreamer circuit, and therefore really is not intended to go from "clean tone" to "Brown sound" all by itself.The "CompCut" setting seems to be the feature that really pushes this pedal ahead from the crowded pack of overdrive and boost pedals.  The "Vintage" setting, I suppose offers a Tubescreamer-like overdrive with rounded highs and boosted mids.  It can also run at a pretty good volume even with the "OD" knob all the way down.  "FM" stands for "Flat Mids", and boosts the signal without altering the basic EQ structure of your clean tone.  "CompCut" is an entirely different animal - my understanding is that does a boost while bypassing the compression circuit.  So you basically a "clean boost" that can really accentuate the dynamics of your notes.  It is also noticeably LOUDER than the other modes.  Anyway, difficult to describe, but it's a good example of how versatile this pedal is - it really can cover a good range of boosting options from clean volume increase to smooth saturation.  Again, this is not a distortion pedal, though it has more gain on tap than something like an Ibanez TS-9, which is a classic circuit, but has some limitations in output and flexibility compared to some of the newer innovations in the last 30 years.I should mention the separate stage for the "Boost" switch.  Usually, the effect of this will be to add gain, not volume.  I will say that while a lot of people say that Fulltone pedals sound better at loud volumes and with higher-end equipment, the FD2 has a pretty thick tone to it, so it can absolutely pair well with a smaller amp.Build quality is terrific, of course.  Fulltone was once considered a "boutique" pedal, but they've gotten large enough to the point where you can find their stuff in stores everywhere, and they've been able to get price points for pedals like this and the OCD significantly lower than specialty pedals that push $200 and beyond.  Very versatile and useful overdrive pedal.

Like the other reviewer here, I ordered this as a replacement for a Squier Classic Vibe 50's Stratocaster, which is a beautiful guitar, but had some light damage to the 1-ply pickguard and appeared uneven.  Turns out this cream colored one was a much better match for the aged look of the pickup covers and knobs - this looks more like the pickguard the CV Strat should have shipped with!  Installation and fit were perfect, except that there actually is one screw whole off by the switch.  Didn't even require a drill to correct it - took a microscrewdriver to start a pilot hole through the finish and got a screw in there no problem.  Note that they sell a 3-ply (this one) and a 1-ply - I opted for the 3-ply because I just prefer the look and stiffness of it.

I recently purchased the Sony MDR7506 headphones after doing some online research on a good pair of studio monitor headphones to use for playing guitar.  Alternatively, I may use them to listen to music on an MP3 player or stereo.  Despite the fact that this exact product has been on the market since 1991, the MDR7506 is almost universally celebrated by audiophiles and music professionals as a professional quality product made to stand the test of time.  Really pretty amazing if you consider the proliferation in popularity of over-the-ear headphones for casual music listening over the past 10 years - Beats by Dre, Bose, and endless other companies are pumping out new products, and yet many will tell you that the MDR7506 is better.I won't do a "full review" because I'm not a true audiophile or expert, though I've heard and owned enough to have a decent basis for comparison.  So I'll start by saying that this is a set of headphones I really like, and then list a few things I like and then a few things I'm less sure about:PROS:- Comfort.  I have larger-than-average ears, so some over-the-ear headphones are problematic.  Nothing about the MDR7506 looks terribly comfortable, but something about perfectly balanced design, 180-degree swivel ear pieces and cushioned headband makes this set feel much lighter than it actually is.  Yes, your ears will get hot after wearing them for awhile, but there are replacement options for the ear pads, and they do not press heavily on your ears, which is what I find is usually the source of discomfort- Sound clarity.  Unbelievable.  I got a Bose AE2 set a few years back (which cost $50 more), and thought that set a new bar for me in clarity with headphones.  But Bose, somewhat controversially, does put their own EQ stamp on the reference material you are listening to.  The MDR7506's are ALARMINGLY clear.  As a guitar player, I'm hearing little details and volume dynamic that were never present with other sets of headphones.  In some ways, this is also a "CON" in the sense that it will not mask the shortcomings of poorer quality audio (or bad guitar playing).- Cord length & quality.  This is the only headphone set I have with a coiled cord, and for use with an instrument, it is nice to know that I have the freedom to move a few feet in either direction without ripping a cord out.  The cord also seems very durable and is of a much thicker gauge than my Bose or Sennheiser headphones.CONS:- "Dated" Aesthetics.  Look, you either care or you don't.  The design is the same as it was in 1991 - these are not meant to wow people in the street.  There is also an exposed cord on both sides that runs from the earcup into the headband, and this is usually covered on modern headphones.  But they are by no means ugly, and I have these primarily for playing musical instruments in my basement - so comfort takes precedence over appearance.- Cord weight.  While the coiled cord has the obvious advantages I cited above, it is something you will notice if you are used to earbuds or thin gauge wires in modern earphones.  Because it is thicker and coiled, there's some "heft" to that cord and it is noticeable if it bumps your arm while you are playing guitar, or if it rests on you for long periods of time.  The positive side of that would be that the coiling prevents it from dragging on the floor.- Not meant to "enhance" bass.  There are a number of questionable music trends to come out of the past few decades.  One of them is the "Loudness Wars", which is the tendency to push all recorded music to be louder and/or more compressed (for sustained loudness, at the expense of dynamics).  Another trend are powerful headphones that will emphasize the lower frequencies at music at the expense of upper end and overall balance.  Let me be clear - the MDR7506 has plenty of low end - I tested it on everything from classic rock to hip hop with 808's and it handled all of it.  But if your preference is rap/hip hop or electronic music that uses heavy drums and sub bass, and you want a set of headphones that will emphasize that over everything else, maybe another set of headphones is for you.  These are studio monitors, first and foremost.  They are meant to reflect the actual balance of musical frequencies in the source material as if you were hearing the same thing live, or through a set of studio monitors, and at that, they do an excellent job.

I'm new to the Caline brand, but based on this experience for a very modest investment of around $30, I may be looking at one or two others.  Caline is brand of Chinese clones/copies/impersonations of popular boutique pedals that usually cost between $150 and $300.  I've used a fair number of clones, most of them Joyo, and had very positive experiences all around.  I had heard that the Caline pedals were built similarly to the early Joyos, so I thought I would take a (pretty modest) risk on one.The CP-18 Orange Burst appears to be a clone of the Xotic BB Preamp, which was actually a pedal I had barely heard of before I came across this one.  I have not played the Xotic model, but the basic functionality of the Orange Burst is the same, and I'm pleased to say that it's quite good.  More importantly, it offers something a bit different that the boosters and light overdrive pedals I already have, which is terrific in a 30-dollar purchase.The Orange Burst, fundamentally, is a booster.  There's a lot of debate over the technical difference between boost, overdrive, and distortion (my unit actually says "OVERDRIVE" across the bottom, but the cliff notes version of that is that by boosting the input gain of a guitar signal, you can create an overdriven sound.Boosters, therefore, are relatively straightforward effects, and I would certain never pay close to $200 for one, as I am a hobbyist, not a professional, working musician.  But the Orange Burst has two features that I find useful and a unique.  First, it has independent volume and gain controls, which means that it operates more or less as a transparent clean boost with the Gain at "0" and the Volume turned up.  This is a nice feature, since other boosters (like my EHX LPB-1) may have only a single level or gain control, so you can only really add gain/saturation, as opposed to just boosting your level.Second, The Bass and Treble controls are independent +/-15dB  boost/cut controls for high and low frequencies.  What this means is that if you are using the Orange Burst as a fairly transparent booster, but your resulting sound it too bright (or dark), you can boost or cut the highs or lows without completely changing the overall tone.  I know that EQ control on boosters has expanded in recent years (notably in the MXR Micro Plus), but I'm not sure that some of the other options give as much control as this pedal does at shaping your sound.Plug this pedal alone into a relatively clean tube amp, and you get a pretty amazing range of tonal options - everything from pure clean boost, to bassy Bluesbreaker crunch, to "gainier" sounds you would associate with a more traditional OD or Distortion pedal.Oh, and the build quality?  I'm actually quite impressed so far.  The early run Joyo pedals (JF-01 to JF-17) are a fair comparison, though I think the footswitch on this one might "feel" even a bit more reliable.  There is a 9V adapter jack on the left side below the output jack.  And while assume there was a ton of cost savings done on the circuit board and pots, the 4 pots have a good resistance to them, and, frankly, feel more comparable to my Wampler than some of the other "cheap" pedals I have played.  Having said that, I do think that budget pedals like this are an "either/or" proposition: In most cases, you will get a perfectly functioning unit that will suit the needs of players who don't abuse their gear, but there is always the risk of a defective unit or some component failing that is some unknown percentage more likely than it would be on a unit from an establish company with better quality control.  At $30, I feel that's a worthwhile risk, and I'm really enjoying the Orange Burst.

I'm generally a fan of Squier guitars, having owned a handful since the mid-90's (some stock, some modded).  But the reality is that there is a quite a wide variety in craftsmanship and playability from Squier model to model, and even year to year.  All of that aside, the Classic Vibe line of Stratocasters really is in a class of its own.  If you imagined a world where the name on the headstock, price, and country of manufacture were completely unknown to the person playing it, I honestly think this Strat would compare favorably to the Fender-branded Made in Mexico and even the American Standard.  Which is not to say that the Classic Vibe is "as good" as those guitars, but more to the point that once you hit a certain level of quality, the differences between more expensive guitars are more about cosmetics and reputation than function or sound quality.The Classic Vibe 50's is meant to convey the form factor of a vintage Fender, but adding a few common sense improvements.  For example, the one-ply pickguard has been thickened to decrease bowing.  The truss rod is fully accessible through the headstock.  But it certainly captures the feel of what you imagine one of these vintage Strats would have looked like had you picked one up in the 1950's.The distinguishing feature of this guitar is the neck and fretboard.
