This grease gun brand has been around for a LONG time and is rock solid !!I have two of them: one with trailer wheel bearing grease and the other one with gimbal bearing grease for my Mercruiser stern drive.

A MUST HAVE  if you have the grease fitting at the END of your axle.I replaced all  4 on my trailer and installation was simple and straight forward.I place some medium strength LOCKTITE to the cap edge before installation and have never lost one on the road.

Product:The light is compact and easily mounted by twisting the lens and removing it.All around it is just ok and nothing special.  light is a light and I give it 3 STARS.Shipping:Usually AMAZON does a fantastic job shipping items in 2 days if you have Amazon Prime, but in this instance they truly dropped the ball and the item arrived a WEEK later!

I have had C.S. Harris's 'Sebastian St. Cyr' historical mystery series on my to-read list off and on for several years. I have read five of the writer's earlier romances under the name Candace Proctor and enjoyed her style of writing. Still, I was hesitant to start this series about forbidden love and second chances during Regency times.And now I could kick myself.WHAT ANGELS FEAR was an interesting introduction to the seamy side of London in the early 1800s. Sebastian St. Cyr, Viscount Devlin, had returned home from the war after selling out ten months earlier. He appeared to have a death wish and was biding his time when a young prostitute was murdered. Too soon, he became aware that an unknown person had chose him as the fall guy.Except the villain did not realize that he picked the wrong man.Like so many first-books in a series, a good amount of the story was spent setting up introductions to various characters. Some people that I am sure will return in the following mystery-thrillers. And while I slowly read each chapter capturing names and their importance, I found myself tempted to peek at the end of the story. But I didn't.Mrs. Harris's PhD in European history, her time spent at archeology sites around the world and having travelled abroad, gave her an edge when writing WHAT ANGELS FEAR. I felt I was actually with St. Cyr when he was jumping over roofs while escaping the constable and his men. Or at his side while making his way at the Rag Fair to acquire clothes to disguise himself. Or listening to his young protégée in the cold, frosty air.The author dropped little info-nuggets about the political battle between the Tories and Whigs before Prinny was placed on the throne. Maneuvers, subterfuge and ploys were found everywhere. But the murders that took place were gruesome and graphic; something I could have read with less detail.The 'Who Murdered Whom And Why' question provided plenty slivers of friction. Sebastian's socially-impaired family, an unforgotten love and some governmental conspiracies dripped from the pages. Watch for the clues!~"When one lived a life that was, essentially, a lie, appearances were everything.~

Velda Johnston wrote a number of mysteries with a clean secondary romance in the late 1960s and 1970s. Like THE PEOPLE ON THE HILL, many of them contained very dated material. I was actually surprised I didn't hear any of the characters mention the words, 'groovy', 'bell bottoms' or 'flower power'.The lingo was that outmoded.The mystery was tepid at best especially since the author revealed early on that the supposed hero was blatently involved in a murder. 'The People' were somehow engaged in the matter, too. The question that kept me in pursuit until the end was the big 'Why?'.Karen was written like many of the heroines of that era: alone, naive, and young and in love. David was smart, attractive and could easily bend others to his will. And then there was Bill Bailey. He was the intelligent outsider with just the right acquaintances to help him assist Karen. The actual romance was very low-key, it was practically nonexistent. The relative absence of cell phones, GPS and the Internet almost made this feel like a historical piece of fiction. The author did do a wonderful job writing an atmosphere that had an ominous presence and was slightly creepy; there was just enough doom and gloom for those of you that enjoy this type of genre.

I read this story at the 'math.cornell.edu' website for free.It began with the statement: May 7th - I love my garden.  Well, so do I.The story was first published in 1898 but the years soon melted away. Her memoir was loaded with those funny long sentences containing plenty of commas, semi-colons and dashes that were in fashion back then. It covered one year in the life of Elizabeth von Arnim. The moral to this story? Truth is often stranger than fiction.Elizabeth married a widower twice her age and referred to her first three children as the April baby, the May baby and the June baby. Her husband was called the Man Of Wrath. Elizabeth was considered by the villagers to be an eccentric because *gasp!* she could spend her day out of doors with a book. Apparently, during this era, reading was an occupation for men; for women it was a reprehensible waste of time. Shhh, don't tell anyone but I have been guilty of this.Like Elizabeth, when I am outside, my thoughts sometimes drift to my childhood. For her it was about daisies and daffodils and her eleven o'clock bread. Her father whom she passionately loved, her grumpy grandfather and her enchanted years between two and eighteen.In her garden she reminisced about happy frogs, owls having conversations and roses. In my garden you could find a murder of crows, a knot of toads and some gopher tortoises digging holes. With some beetles, crickets and spiders.I loved the author's first lesson on buying (too much) seed and trying to grow morning glories. The invention of cabbage salad and the superiority of the Teuton (her husband?) and 'the music he makes after eating his meal'. And her quick explanation of the dejected gardener who walked around with a spade in one hand and a revolver in the other. He went mad and was sent to an asylum. Fortunately no one was shot. Or buried.The utter randomness of Elizabeth's semi-autobiographical memoir may turn off some readers. She begins her tale in the present but regresses to the past roughly halfway through. She blends family and flowers, weather and food. Then she witnesses the treatment of women by their laboring husbands and was lectured by the Man Of Wrath on the acceptability of beating your wife. These women accept their beating with a simplicity worthy of all praise, and far from considering themselves insulted, admire the strength and energy of the man who can administer such eloquent rebukes. Further, the story goes on, with the politics, prejudices, vanities and weaknesses of the German people at the turn of the century. I am not sure what happened to that happy garden and when the diatribes became commonplace.Sadly, I don't have a housekeeper, handmaiden, workmen, painters, a gardener and his assistant, a cook, maids, nurse and someone to brush my hair in the evening but my garden is still a far-away corner in my kingdom of heaven.

Thoughts can be unhealthy when you assume you know the truth.~~~~~~Deliciously dangerous, Ruel MacLaren had but one goal: to become rich. He learned some valuable lessons in Australia, California and Africa before traveling to India. He knew Lady Luck was on his side; it was just a matter of time.With exquisite good looks, women loved his attention. No matter where his adventures took him, he never had a problem with the fairer sex. That is, until he met the practical and unassuming Jane Barnaby. Like him, she was a survivor.~~~~~~J A N E: A simple but not-commonly used name made up of four letters. In many ways her name matched her personality. She was strong, sensible and not afraid to say no when the need arose. Ruel was fascinated with her.~~~~~~Initially, Ruel came across as an unashamed but happy anti-hero. His older half-brother Ian, the Earl of Glenclaren, had finally found him after a long search. Now that their father was dead, he wanted Ruel to return home to Scotland but his brother's hardy response was the word NO.Opposites in both appearances and personalities, Ian understood that his brother was battling his own personal demons but he believed his beloved country manor would heal him. He had no intention of leaving until Ruel changed his mind. Ian would just bide his time.In the meantime, Ruel and Jane first met when they were locked in a room at a brothel. Even though Ruel would have loved for something physical to happen, he became aware very soon that Jane's thoughts were about escaping not only their prison but him. And the more often she said goodbye, the nearer he wanted to be with her.The chase was on.~~~~~~Ruel and Jane were deep, complex and wonderfully played. Their romance felt both gritty and strikingly sensual. Ruel was bewitched.The long and the short of this romance? It was 505 pages of not-so-large font. It covered several years with the (hated) misunderstanding. The chemistry was awesome at times, bordering on the erotic side. Ruel was scrumptious one moment and a cad later on. I had some issues with this.Jane? Why, Jane, why, is all I will say. Some reviewers mentioned this was a bodice-ripper. IMHO, it was not. Tension? Yes. A misunderstanding that caused unneeded angst?  Of course.  And all of those secondary characters with their secondary problems and their secondary solutions? Yes. Needless-to-say, there was a lot going on.~~~~~~For those of you that love exotic settings, some steaminess and can handle the length of the story, Iris Johansen's tale of soul-mates, **GOLD** and the island of Cinnidar was actually pretty good.

I can't believe this is the 14th book in the Gaslight Mystery series that I have read. And the author still has my attention!An acquaintance of Sarah Brandt's father was found murdered at the hoity-toity Knickerbocker club. And who does Mr. Decker call on to try and solve the case? *Gasp!* Frank Malloy. For those of you that are unfamiliar with their relationship, suffice-to-say, they tolerate one another for the sake of Sarah. But I wouldn't be surprised to know that the room they are in drops several degrees when Malloy and Felix are together.Besides Frank, Sarah, Maeve, Catherine and Mrs. Ellsworth, we get to see Mrs. Decker once again. Her personality is evolving, continually, for the better. I loved the sly morsels and innocent looks she imparts when trying to 'assist' Sarah and Frank. The big difference this time around is Sarah's father is more involved with the plot and I loved it! We get a few glimpses of the very formal Felix Decker and the byplay between him and his wife. I think he was actually jealous of Frank's attention to his wife for one moment. :))Decker glanced at his wife."No, I won't leave you two alone," she said. "And you might as will let me stay. It will save you the trouble of telling me everything later."Decker sighed, and Frank had to bite his lip to keep from grinning.As I mentioned in an earlier review, Ms. Thompson takes a look at the darker side of NYC in the late 1800s. The author takes you behind closed doors; it might be in a rich man's home or a slum-like tenement of New York. No subject is too tender for the author to cover. With MURDER ON FIFTH AVENUE I saw a turning point between Frank, Sarah and the Deckers, all for the better. There were even a few humorous moments not present in earlier stories.Just remember to read the books in order. Each story reveals important pieces of information that move all of the relationships along: not just Frank's and Sarah's. The continual change with Maeve and Catherine. The increasing importance of Mrs. Ellsworth. Mrs. Decker with her timely and educational visits to Sarah's home. And I loved when the author shared moments with Frank's son, Brian.I am even looking forward to seeing more of Felix Decker and the young Italian police officer, Gino Donatelli, Frank's intelligent protege. Like others, my only criticism is the oh-so-very-slow acceleration of Frank's and Sarah's romance. I wanted to see so much more before now!

Sandra Brown is known for writing about alpha males: dark heroes with a crack in their facade. Men whom have secrets but try to pretend that nothing is wrong. FRICTION was one such story.Crawford Hunt, a Texas Ranger, had gone back to court to retrieve his parental rights for full-time custody of his young daughter, Georgia. He had voluntarily surrendered it several years earlier after his wife had died in an accident. They were dark days and he was the first to admit he was not a suitable father at the time but he went through the necessary counseling. He also provided the other requirements to make a comfortable dwelling for his child. He was ready to bring Georgia home.Judge Holly Spencer was presiding at court when Crawford petitioned her to remove his daughter's guardianship from his former in-laws. They were good people but their bias prohibited him from taking a permanent role with fatherhood.Before a decision could be made, chaos broke loose. A gunman had entered the courtroom shooting the bailiff and attempting to shoot the judge. Before he had time to think, Crawford's instinct kicked in and he ended up saving the adjudicator.Unintentionally, Crawford gets involved with Holly.There were plenty of the usual plot devices but that was to be expected when the entire story took place over just a few days. I knew what to expect of Crawford but I expected Holly to be smarter and stronger; after all, she was a judge. Lastly, if you can get past the thought that for 99.9999% of us this would never be a part of our reality, FRICTION was a good-hearted but somewhat mellow blend of romance and suspense.

RETURN TO FOXDALE or Terra de Zorro, an ancient country estate in Spain, had all the makings of an entertaining modern-gothic romance. An beautiful young woman, a cynical Irishman attracted to her, an odd relationship with a vain mother that was used as a plot device and stolen art. First published in 1980, it has all the earmarks of an older contemporary romance with the exception of the foreboding atmosphere. Hence, the feel of a mysterious modern-gothic.Caroline Mesner’s childhood memories of a pleasant life at Foxdale with her Scottish father puttering in the garden were the foundation of her parents’ marriage. Vera Solane, an opera singer, loved her husband but needed the freedom to travel with little commitment. Somehow this relationship worked for the two of them. Unfortunately for the young Caroline, after her father died, she spent the next ten years with the Clarkes in London. With no word from her mother except periodic gift-giving, Caroline managed to lead a quiet but contented life.Then Vera suddenly needed her and Caroline returned to the elusive Foxdale.The upside to this story was the interesting ‘visit’ to Spain from long ago. It made me think that the author either lived there for awhile or had an extended vacation in the country. I enjoyed reading a romance with a different setting.Regrettably, it didn’t help with all the clichés. The mute driver, the slippery cliffs, sounds that only Caroline hears, the disappearing portraits, the odd attraction between Vera and her new husband and, of course, two men vying for Caroline’s love. Just who should she trust? I kept hoping it would get better. Eventually, everything was resolved with a much too-tidy ending.

HONOR'S KNIGHT is, literally, a continuation of FORTUNE'S PAWN, the first story in the Paradox series. Like FP, it is told in first person but I never had any issues with this. Be sure and start with the prologue as it contains a very necessary and interesting piece of information.This time around the stakes are higher and the action takes you up another notch. Devi Morris intends on finding some answers.The characters are well-developed, the suspense keeps you guessing and the politics of this world....oh, the nasty jungle of government.  I am looking forward to reading Heaven's Queen for a satisfying conclusion to this series.

Katherine 'Kate' Ralston was to inherit her parents' estate upon her 22nd birthday. Uncle Simon, her ruthless guardian, intended on selling it even though he did not legally have the authority to do it. Kate made some verbal threats but was sent to live with her godparents in London.Shortly after her arrival, she attended a ball and was saved from a nefarious nobleman by the Black Devil himself, the Duke of Sommesby. From there on out, just accept the author's premise with her version of acceptable speech and manners during the Regency era.I thoroughly enjoyed Ms. Enoch's ANGEL'S DEVIL but I had a hard time appreciating this story. If I can't connect to the heroine's personality or actions then I have problems with investment in the plot; it now becomes a romance deal-breaker.

Your assignment, should you choose to accept it, is to start this story on a Friday evening. That way you won't risk your job or school because of lack of sleep when you go in, if you go in, Monday morning.It is sometime in the not-so-near future in a galaxy far, far away. Deviana Morris or Devi as she prefers to be called, is a kick-a** heroine with plenty of moxie, just enough foibles and a smidge of deviation that attracts her to danger in hordes.And let's not even talk about her body armor.Ok, let's talk about it.Tight yet conforming with self-cleaning interlocking pieces that fit over her body like a shell. She even has a name for it: the Lady Gray because of its shimmery color. It adds six inches to her 5'6" height and 150 pounds to her weight. But she is in awesome physical condition so she has no problem with jumps, punches and kicks. Now add her state-of-the-art helmet that allows her to see around herself in a 360 degree circle and Sasha, her anti-armor pistol, with Mia, her plasma shotgun, and what have you got? One lean, mean, fighting machine. Oh, and don't forget Phoebe.Her goal? To skip the unnecessary years it would take to become a member of the Home Guard. She wants to become a Devastator; one of the super elite who work directly for the Sacred King: the Baddest of the Bad. And all she has to do is spend one year as security detail on the ship, The Glorious Fool.One measly year.I thoroughly enjoyed this riveting sci-fi adventure with all of its eclectic characters. The best way to sum it up is in the author's very own words:"One summer day in 2011, I decided I wanted to read an action-packed space romance. I looked and looked but I just couldn't find one that scratched the right itch, so I wrote my own."Just be sure to have Honor's Knight available to read when you are through with this story. It is the continuation, or sequel, to FORTUNE'S PAWN.

"Enter, sir; you are the first to arrive..."Initially mistaking the building for a tavern, a stranger was invited in from the cold. It was 1905 and the gentleman was welcomed; supper was to be served at nine. The young man, Hugh Austin, cheerfully observed the furniture, a painting and various knick knacks temporarily forgetting his hunger.Some others arrived until he witnessed and was enamored by a beautiful young woman, Eunice Westonhaugh. She appeared to be carrying a package. Before long, he learned that a will was to be read by Mr. Smeads, the lawyer. The doors to the rambling mansion were closed and locked with latecomers shouting to be let in.They weren't.The stranger learned that because he had not been invited, he was shuffled off to another area of the home. Though he could not see everyone he still could hear what was said. To inherit, each person had to be honest, righteous and lead stainless lives. He heard the young lady say she had "sinned" -her 'package' was an infant- and told to leave.The entire short story was told in four parts: An Open Door, With My Ear To The Wainscoting, A Life Drama and The Final Shock. The lesson learned was "shelter does not always mean refuge".It reminded me, somewhat, of an old Agatha Christie movie, 'Ten Little Indians'. The gothic-like eerie home, darkness, cold, and innocence vs evil. At ninety one pages, it can be easily read in one sitting. And it is free on Project Gutenberg.

Eighteen years ago, Maya Vega gave birth to a baby boy but she was told he was stillborn. Her extended family forced her to leave Columbia. Even though she was so young, she had never forgotten what happened to her.Respectable, smart Maya Velaquez was being primed to run for a local judgeship in her now-home of Texas. Before the day was over she received an unexpected visitor, Shepard Reyes, brother of the deceased Renaldo Reyes who was her son's father. He wanted to know if she was aware her son might be alive.Bitter anger surfaced on both sides with questions but, still, they parted; they were left with the uncertain feeling that things were not resolved. Those unforgotten memories and a photo would soon change Maya's life. She headed back to Columbia to find out the truth.I had a difficult time connecting with all of the characters. Shepard was 45 years old and had been an inquisitive and active family member but had never resolved this puzzle. He had preconceived notions of Maya; he judged her without knowing anything about her situation and I had issues with this. I wanted more suspense and fluency with the plot. Because of this and some minor editing issues I can't give the story more than three stars for 'okay'.If you are looking for a better romance with the 'jungle love' theme try Theresa Weir's 'Amazon Lily', Dana Marton's 'Camouflage Heart', Glenna McReynolds' 'River Of Eden', or Linda Howard's 'Heart Of Fire'.

To sum up GARDEN SPELLS with a sentence from the story: "You are who you are, whether you like it or not, so why not like it?"This whimsical women's fiction has a little of everything. Relationships with insecurities, the character-driven townspeople and some homespun magic. It is about an apple tree that blooms in the winter and throws apples when it feels like it. An elderly woman that gifts everyday items to various townspeople for a purpose: an explanation that will come to the receiver some day. A man searching for answers as to why his lover no longer comes home at night. And it is about growing plants with their healing properties.It is about the effects of gossip, the love of a sweet man and why children are sometimes more mature than adults. It contains more than one dysfunctional family, sisters learning to share their secrets and the importance of being a good mother.When I opened this book I felt as though I had tumbled into the small-knit community of Bascum, NC. I would have been friends with Claire Waverley, visited with Evanelle, babysat Bay and snubbed Arielle Clark. I would have listened to Fred, had Sydney cut my hair and had a serious sit-down with Tyler and Henry. And I think I would have been welcomed as their new neighbor.

"It was the best night of her life."Socially awkward but super-smart 'Liz' was determined to break out of her mold. With a fake ID, a short red dress, and a wild haircut she hooked up with her new friend, Julie, before entering Warehouse 12. She intended to dance, have fun and just plain enjoy herself: everything her rigid mother would not permit her to do.Unfortunately, before the night was over, her life would change. Forever.At the age of 16-almost-17, Elizabeth Fitch observed a couple of people murdered and one of them was a member of the Russian Mafia. On the run, she became a witness for the American government.  You can't help but love the fragile but respectable Liz.  Because of what happened, she was willing to testify and put her life at risk.Then something unexpected happened.Twelve years later, police chief Brooks Gleason met Abigail Lowery and her mammoth dog, Bert, for the first time. Both attracted and curious, he was well aware that something was just not quite right about this intensely quiet woman. Though Brooks could turn serious on a moment's notice, he also could be light and silly if required. And acting as the good Southern boy man that he was, he told his mama about their introduction.You can't help but love his mother, and free spirit, Sunny O'Hara. She immediately figured out how alone Abigail must be and decided to do something about it. And who else but Sunny would compare the color of Abigail's dog's eyes to her son's?Some reviewers had issues with Abigail's 'female Spock of Star Trek' personality but I had no problem.  She was raised under abnormal circumstances.  I liked that her character was quirky and I loved that Brooks accepted and dealt with 'her baggage'.I enjoyed the community of Bickford, Arkansas: the innkeeper who was running for mayor, the old family with money and trouble, the waitress, the town drunk and Brook's receptionist.  People with manners using 'sir' and ma'am'. I thought her characters' idioms were spot-on. Their expression and dialect matched what you would hear in today's old South including referring to anyone north of the Mason-Dixon line as a Yankee.I loved the chemistry between Brooks and Abigail/Elizabeth/Liz. I loved that Liz had anxiety issues and yet she was someone Brooks never wanted on his bad side. They played off each other but in a good way. It was exciting*steamy*interesting*believable. It reminded me of a puzzle with all the pieces fitting tightly together by the time you were finished. I just can't say enough good things about this story.  THE WITNESS is why I love reading romances.

KISS ME WHILE I SLEEP was the third book in the 'CIA's Spies' series but was a mediocre 'ending'. Like some of Ms. Howard's other stories, there was a slow build-up. Necessary information, an explanation of Lily Mansfield's past and the introduction of a new setting.  I had to read almost half the book before the hero and another assassin, Lucas Swain, were introduced.Lily Mansfield was a contracted agent (assassin/killer) with the CIA. She was suppose to follow certain rules. If you broke the rules, you were terminated; it was that simple.She broke the rules.Lucas Swain was sent to put a stop to the damage. He had a method to finishing the job or so he thought. And here is where I had a problem with the story: two assassins with years of being told when and whom to kill and yet they came across as very human. And the immediate chemistry and semi-trust they formed? For some reason I just didn't buy into the premise.The story was nice. It was pleasant but things just went a little too smoothly. I didn't feel the rush or sparks that a good romantic suspense story should have. The upside? I learned more of Frank Vinay's background; he was a character in the first and second books in this series. But if I needed to recommend this story to complete the 'CIA's Spies', I would say it wasn't necessary.

Let me just say that Linda Howard knows how to tease the reader before pulling her/him in.  KILL AND TELL begins, with what appears to be, a demented veteran bent on killing someone.  Instead, he is killed.Dexter Whitlaw was at one time a young husband and father.  Then he joined the Vietnam war and became a sniper; he was good at it, but something happened.  Years passed and his wife remained faithful but Dexter rarely returned home.  When he does he is not the same man.Karen Whitlaw, a nurse, had been notified by the New Orleans police department that her father had died.  She had recently lost her mother and the pain was still constant.  What little memories she had of this man were, at best, bittersweet.  But she knows her mother would want her to claim his body so she left Ohio for the south.Before long, she has entered into a world of intrigue and danger unlike she has ever known.  Ms. Howard's first story in the 'CIA's Spies' series builds slowly with the backdrop: a not-so-innocent package, paid assassins and politics.  Several characters are introduced  that will continue on in ALL THE QUEEN'S MEN.The suspense remained steady and there was plenty of action.  The downside was that it took awhile for our hero, detective Marc Chastain, to surface but when he does: watch out!  An uber-alpha male, he was not afraid to take on anyone and everyone to keep Karen safe.  The ongoing question was just who could Marc and Karen trust?There was some dated material but the story never suffered from it.  The chemistry was good and somewhat edgy; Marc had a caveman mentality.  At times, I was just shaking my head.If you enjoyed the earlier-written Kell Sabin series or any of her older books, you should enjoy this group of stories.  This was just what I needed after recently reading some duds.

This was the fourth space opera that I have read by Linnea Sinclair. She is known by her fans for following a formula in most, if not all, of her books: alpha male, strong smart heroine and at least part of the setting is held in space. Like in most sci-fi stories there is a familiar jargon unique to the plot that the reader must learn. Tel-Tal, biocybe, U-Cee, Psy-Serv, Novalis, characters with the last name of Kel-_, Galaxus, Definator and so on. And it took me roughly a third of the story to become comfortable with all of this space lingo.GAMES OF COMMAND was first and foremost an action adventure with a side of suspense and two moderate romances. The primary characters, Admiral Branden Kel-Paten and Captain Tasha Sebastian AKA Lady Sass, are old enemies from the days before the Triad formed a peace agreement. The title refers to the competition and one-upmanship between these two soldiers. Their 'love story' takes a long time to come into play. Poor Kel-Paten.At the same time Chief Medical Officer and empath Eden Fynn forms an alliance with renegade soldier and captive Jace Serafino. Who was also telepathic and had a dual personality. What a guy!Oh, and did I mention that Kel-Paten was humanoid but primarily made from cybernetic parts? Referred to as the Tin Soldier, he had pined for Tasha for years without her being aware of his true feelings. His 'innocence' and a damaged past formed his personality. He lacked the social skills that others were taught in childhood. He was expected to perform as an effective machine. Reading about Kel-Paten was the reason I finished this book.Then there were the kitty-like 'furzels', Tank and Reilly, whom refer to Tasha and Eden as their mothers. Protection was imperative. And lurking in the background was something invisible and nasty.My problem, as with all of Ms. Sinclair's stories, was the length. GAMES OF COMMAND is 525 pages and honestly, I thought the gist of the plot could be delivered in under 350. It was just way too long. Then I found out that "the characters and some scenes in this novel were originally part of the book COMMAND PERFORMANCE and several short stories that were part of the Alliance Command series". So I am going to put the blame on the editor of her publishing firm. If they did a better job, I would have rated it higher.

Allison Scott had all she could do trying to establish her name as a photographer in the greater Minneapolis area. Jason, her previous boyfriend and one-time model, left her high and dry after stealing her portfolio of his photos. Not to mention her heart. She was determined to get on with her life sans handsome men. That was, until Rick Lang entered the picture (no pun intended!).Allison had to complete the cover art for an upcoming book and she was on a deadline with very little money. Her friend and business-owner of North Star Agency, Mattie, recommended Rick along with several others. The moment Allison saw his black and white photo, she knew he would be perfect for this job.As different from Jason as night was to day, Rick was down-to-earth, unpretentious and just plain nice. He didn't put on any airs; what you see was what you got. Allison, on the other hand, was insecure and came across as childish. I found her unlikable.I read some of LaVyrle Spencer's historical romances years ago and I enjoyed them. FORSAKING ALL OTHERS was her first contemporary romance and was initially issued in 1982 as a Second Chance At Love publication.  It was her fourth book and you could tell that she was very much still working on her craft.  There might have been an enjoyable story in there trying to get out but there was little character development and the heroine's continued vacillation turned me off.

My husband and I had gone through a nightmare cold/flu season in 2013.  We are both healthy individuals and practice good hygiene but we still seemed to catch everything.  Both of us even had a flu shot!  The only thing I considered was that our resistence was low.  On top of it, what others were getting over in a few weeks, it took us months; this included several visits to the doctor.In early 2014, I saw an article by the pharmacist Suzy Cohen praising this product.  She wrote that the kill rate of FluNada was tested by 2 independent labs and found to be 99.9% effective.  I decided to look for it locally and found it at a Winn Dixie store.  I bought two bottles, one for each of us.  Every time our throats started to 'tickle', we felt head congestion coming on or either us began to cough I brought out the Flunada.  Within 24 hours whatever symptoms either of us had, they went away.I even told our adult kids about Flunada and the success we have had.  Two of them are in the healthcare field but none of them have tried it. Guess who was sick last year and in 2015?  Hint, it was not us.As others have stated, it burns for about 30 seconds when you first spray it in your mouth and nose.  We can live with that.  As far as being addictive as one reviewer stated, I know of no such problem.We follow the directions to the letter.  I always make sure the bottle is clean after use before I store it.  We have not had one cold or bout with flu since buying Flunada.  I swear by this product now.

Closer to 4.5 starsFrom the opening, the story grabbed me from the start. It was told in first person by a young mother: "We called him the Professor. And he called my son Root, because, he said, the flat top of his head reminded him of the square root sign." It was unusual in that all of the main characters were without proper names: the Housekeeper, the Professor, Root and the Widow.It was a beautiful, interesting story that captured every moment; I soon learned that time was a very precious commodity. It focused on the fascinating and complex relationships between vastly different members of one household.The Housekeeper was a young single mother with a latchkey ten-year-old son. The Professor had a head injury that allowed him only eighty minutes in the present time before everything started over. At one time, he had been a brilliant 64 year-old mathematics professor at Cambridge. Her son, 'Root', was the glue within this odd family. And the introduction of baseball became a common backdrop.Just imagine the extreme difficulty it must have been for everyone? Instead, the three formed some very special friendships. And the romance? Because it was very much a love story but not what I would normally consider. The romance was a love of numerals: the ability to look at numbers and glimpse at "the answers in God's notebook". It taught me that pauses, instants and spells could be explained with math and it showed me that nothing was trivial.I would have loved to have learned more about the Housekeeper's and the Professor's past. The author shared a few flashes of days gone by. They were brief and it left me with questions; it was just enough to hook me in but I wanted to know more.The story had a calming influence while I read it. I found myself trying to tackle the mathematical problems the Professor gave to the Housekeeper and her son. And though I am not a big fan of the sport, I enjoyed reading about their love of baseball. THE HOUSEKEEPER AND THE PROFESSOR was a refreshing, original and compassionate story that I would encourage everyone to try.

3.5 starsCLEAN AS A WHISTLE takes poetry to the next level. And it is another reason to never overlook old books. The scenery is drawn in muted browns and the author's love of natural history pours over each page. But the amusement of the story is in its simple goofiness. It appeals to the child in all of us.It is the story of three children who have fun getting dirty:"Isn't it funto be young and dirtyinstead of grown-upand cleanand thirty!"The three cousins continue running through a field and into the woods:"Let's say we're Badgersor Mice or Birdswho think a washclothtoo quaint for words,who just live freein the wild for yearswithout a washingbehind the ears!"They eventually get lost and come upon an elderly lady with a hearing problem. They ask if she knows of a path so they can return home. She thinks they want a bath. From there on out, the old woman shows the children that all animals clean themselves in one way or another. And, eventually, she misunderstands yet again and shows them the path to their home.

Closer to 3.5 starsVera, an orphan, was raised in the woods with a ragtag group of men during the 1500's. She was taught how to survive like the others. Then Tal, her adopted father and someone concerned about her well-being, sent her to a convent to be taught how to behave like a woman. She was seventeen but it was too little, too late. She escaped and returned 'home'.Before long, she devised a plan to bring herself back into the good graces with Tal. Instead, she was caught by Sir Giles, Lord of Rathborne. Her life would never be the same.At heart, Giles belonged to the sea and he wanted to return there. Instead, the title and lands he had inherited had become a weight around his neck. Vera informed him that his steward had ruined his tenants' lives through greed. Giles had a long road to bring everything back into repair.THE CYGNET referred to a young swan or swanling. Giles needed money and came up with a plan. It involved Vera. He believed she could be a lookalike for one of his rich but lost relations; she just needed to be taught some manners and acquire some polish. If he could pull this off, he could earn some much-needed funds. Vera was forced to help him or he said he would imprison her family.This story was not simply a romance. The author injected actual history within the plot. Queen Elizabeth, Sir Francis Drake and the Earl of Leicester were some of the characters that were mentioned. Times were tough for everyone. You were never guaranteed to be in favor with the queen.In some ways the story reminded me of the movie My Fair Lady. Giles was crotchety most of the time and it bothered him. Before, he had never had a problem enticing a woman to become biddable. Vera thought he was poking fun of her and did her best to make his life miserable. There were some funny moments including Giles attempting to teach Vera to walk properly or glide "like a swan". But the part I most enjoyed was when the two were verbally sparring with each other.I would have given this story five stars except the last quarter of the book felt muddled and somewhat rushed. I liked THE CYGNET; I just wish the author kept up the brisk pace until the end. Oh, and it would have been nice to have an epilogue.

Then Tal, her adopted father and someone concerned about her well-being, sent her to a convent to be taught how to behave like a woman. She was seventeen but it was too little, too late. There were some funny moments including Giles attempting to teach Vera to walk properly or glide "like a swan". But the part I most enjoyed was when the two were verbally sparring with each other.I would have given this story five stars except the last quarter of the book felt muddled and somewhat rushed. I liked THE CYGNET; I just wish the author kept up the brisk pace until the end. Oh, and it would have been nice to have an epilogue.

How could you not like a hero whose first name was Blue?Dr. Laurence 'Blue' Reynard "with a bourbon voice, smoky and gold and dangerous."  He was a charmer and a ladies' man.  He owned a "rat-dog" named Sasha and an elderly cat on death's door called Piwacket.  He was a guy that seriously grew and studied orchids and was a lover of old music.  His speech was loaded with "blurred Southern vowels".After corresponding with him in a blues music newsgroup on the Internet, biographer Ellie Connor took up Dr. Reynard's offer of a cottage on his property in Pine Bend, Texas.  She was a music historian.  She could research and write her story on native blues singer Mabel Beauvais: a rising star whom mysteriously vanished one day long ago.  Ellie was expecting someone much older than the devilishly handsome Blue.  And Blue found himself attracted to her."Ellie rolled down the window, letting in the thick midday air.  Wind blew her hair back from her serious, intent face.  Blue imagined she was imprinting details, and as if to give that theory credence, she inhaled deeply, lifting her nose like a dog scenting the air.  He smiled."Besides writing Mabel's narrative, Ellie had another puzzle to solve.  Tied with this land, she hoped to locate whom her father was.  Her mother was a product of the late 1960's hippie movement.  She had spent a long summer in Pine Bend, then returned home to western Louisiana: unwed and pregnant.  After leaving Ellie with her mother, she took off again.  She died from an overdose of drugs leaving Ellie to often wonder what her father's name was and could he still be alive?IN THE MIDNIGHT RAIN was a breathless romance between two unlikely characters.  It contained plenty of secrets packed with moments of angst.  The townspeople pushed the story along with sultry nights, haunting music and old-fashioned gossip.  In a few ways, it eerily reminded me of a modern-day gothic.Like molasses, I read Blue's and Ellie's story slowly. The author's strength was found in her crisp wordplay; the sentences flowed with spot-on descriptive words.  I sunk into the mystery of this enchanting story and didn't want to climb out.

Miss Clara Christopher was a rolling stone.  Orphaned ten years earlier and poor as a church mouse, she charted her life amongst relatives and friends.  Clara visited only those people whom needed her. At two and twenty, she felt she had roughly three years left before she would have to find work: perhaps, as a paid companion.At present, she was temporarily residing at the Lucker residence: Branlea.  Her cousin, Baron Oglethorpe, was marrying Lady Prissie Lucker and Clara was helping prepare for the wedding.Two years earlier she had met one of Prissie's relatives, Mr. Ben Allingcote, at a house party.  There was an instant attraction; they had formed a flirtation.  Or so Clara had thought, for the night ended abruptly.  Later on, Clara found out Ben's father had died and he was made the new Lord Allingcote.Now she had found out he was to attend the wedding ceremony but with another young woman, Miss Nel Muldoon.  Young, pretty Nel whom adored attention. Precocious, flippant Nel whose fits and starts were the bane of Ben's existance.Little did Clara know the various hoops Lord Allingcote had jumped through since their unexpected separation from two years before.  She was kept in a state of confusion for a good portion of the story while Ben was on a mission.WINTER WEDDING was a gentle romance. It started out slowly but like a fine wine, it got better with age.  I enjoyed the witty dialog and clever nuances that are not often found in traditional regencies.  Just don't overlook the hidden gems of conversation between these two people.  Jealousy rears its head in the most unlikely places but it will put a smile on your face. :-)

Read in December, 2014"The danger lies in keeping secrets."When I first started IN CONFIDENCE I wasn't sure whether I was going to like the story. I was looking for a good contemporary romantic suspense but I had never read anything by this author. It began with the prologue set five years before the remainder of the story: Cameron Ford, a true crimes writer had lost his teenage son to suicide. Divorced for awhile, he lived in New York while his ex-wife and son lived in Texas. When he arrived at the funeral he wanted answers and, in a nutshell, blasted his son's high school guidance counselor. Rachel Forrester should have known!Cam had settled in Rose Hill, Texas and five years went by when he witnessed his elderly neighbor pass out on her lawn. Long-story-short, the lady had a medical condition and was Rachel's mother. Rachel was now in the middle of a divorce from her lowlife adulterous husband. Before long, she and her children moved in with her mother.A very slow-paced romance built between these two unlikely people and I had no problem with that. At the same time, Rachel's son Nick was juggling high school and playing sports: the same thing Cam's son had done before he killed himself. Cam fought a war with his memories.This was a long story at 443 pages. When I read a suspenseful book I want to feel a rush and a fair amount of intenseness. I find it helps to keep the plot flowing at a rapid pace. At times, I found it lacking in the storyline. I knocked off one star because the author could have easily edited out, at minimum, about 100 pages. There was just too much unnecessary filler.The positives? I enjoyed seeing Cam's grumpy character get past his deep distrust of women and, in particular, Rachel. Once they acknowledged themselves as allies, their burgeoning romance was actually sweet. Especially the way Cam treated the sensitive Rachel; her husband had certainly done a number on her. Also, writing teens into a conspiracy can be tricky but I thought Ms. Young did a good job. And though I may have initially steered away from the very dark storyline, I found myself invested too far; the mild suspense was good.

Alistair Munro, the Duke of Bridgwater, was bored with his life. All of his friends, along with his sisters and brother, had married in recent years and had children. At thirty-four years of age, he had his title, wealth and possessions but little else.He was returning to London after being entertained by those same friends when he saw a young woman walking on the side of the road. Though her clothes were very plain, THE PLUMED BONNET she wore was garish. Because of the disinterest he was feeling, he had his coachmen stop and he offered her a ride.Miss Stephanie Gray knew it was wrong. But she had little money and was hungry. She could not afford to stay at an inn and she was very tired. She had nervously slept last night for only a few minutes at a time on the side of the road. So she accepted the gentleman's offer to take her to the next village.When they first met, little did Bridgwater and Miss Gray know how their lives would come together. He was entertained while he listened to her talk. After his initial kindness, he thought she had formed a ruse and was going to offer her his protection as his mistress. But she proved him to be out of line and so, instead, he asked her to become his wife.Miss Gray knew that it was wrong but circumstances forced her to accept his offer. The newness of their relationship, the gap in how they were raised and what each was expected to bring to the marriage caused issues with communication. At times it was heart wrenching. The weeks before the wedding were filled with angst and minor misunderstandings. The time afterward was bittersweet. Alistair wanted, no, needed Stephanie to love him but he had never been taught how to show affection. How to reveal his feelings. For Stephanie's sake, he was willing to learn. But was it too late?#1. The Ideal Wife#2. A Precious Jewel#3. Dark Angel#4. Lord Carew's Bride. **My Personal Favorite So Far**#5. A Famous Heroine#6. The Plumed Bonnet#7. A Christmas Bride

THE FAMOUS HEROINE was the fifth romance in the Stapleton-Downes series and was Lord Francis Kneller's story. At the beginning, Kneller was still having a hard time getting over his one true love, Samantha, from LORD CAREW'S BRIDE. He had proposed to her numerous times but she had always turned him down even though she dearly loved him. As. A. Friend. Instead, she happily married landscaper-extraordinaire Lord Carew.Kneller had returned to London and had been approached by the Duke of Bridgwater, another secondary character from LC'sB. He wanted Kneller to partner Miss Cora Downes on her first dance at a ball that all of them were to attend. The Duke's mother was sponsoring the young woman; she had saved her great-nephew's life. Cora, extremely rich but a tradesman's daughter, had become the lady's protégée. Her Grace was determined to find Cora a husband.Cora was Amazonian in height with large feet, attractive but not beautiful and had a habit of saying and doing things that, for lack of a better word, was non-plussed. Kneller was fascinated by Cora's common sense, her laughter and easy-going personality. Still somewhat depressed over Samantha, when he was in Miss Downes' presence his moodiness cleared.In turn, Cora had never met anyone like Lord Francis. Simply put, Kneller loved color in his wardrobe. The ton kept a careful eye on what he wore and he was emulated. The best words to describe him would be a clotheshorse, fashion plate, and a macaroni: a dandy. But not in the way you would typically think. He was also very much a man: he practiced at Gentleman Jackson's gym and had several mistresses in past years. Of course Cora did not know any of this; she innocently thought of protecting him.As I have said in some of my other reviews with this series, I highly recommend you read the books in order of sequence. Various characters are introduced and I believe most everyone would enjoy the stories if they are read in order. THE FAMOUS HEROINE was a tale of opposite's attract. I thoroughly enjoyed seeing these two good people suffer through quirky moments and eventually surrender to love.#1. The Ideal Wife#2. A Precious Jewel#3.  Dark Angel#4. Lord Carew's Bride. **My Personal Favorite So Far**#5. A Famous Heroine#6. The Plumed Bonnet#7. A Christmas Bride

When Blanche Amberley first met Sir Edmund Brandon it was loathe-at-first-sight.  Sir Edmund had bought the Amberley family estate when her father had capitulated to dire financial issues.  Somewhat unfairly, Blanche considered Brandon the enemy.Sir Edmund was a wounded soldier and had been searching for peace in his life.  He had recently considered marriage and was seeing Lady Hetherington.  She was lovely to look at but had a nasty and vicious temperament.  Up to this point, she had done a wonderful job of keeping it under cover.Blanche was also considering marriage but to the local banker's son.  Antony Mortimer was good-looking and a smooth talker but I sensed he was a shady character.  Blanche was initially unaware of his many deals that were under the table.This traditional regency had a fair amount of suspense.  Blanche and Edmund went full-circle with their feelings.  When push came to shove, Edmund was both judicious and fair.  Deprived of his assistance, Blanche would have been up the creek without a paddle.A CHRISTMAS COURTSHIP was a clean romance that shared a villain and a villainess.  These nasty reprobates did a decent job causing chaotic disorder to the Amberley household.  With a brother on the run, the military giving chase and various characters with no redeeming qualities, this historical fiction had something for everyone.

'TWAS THE NIGHT AFTER CHRISTMAS exemplified the emotionally tortured hero. Physically abandoned at the age of eight, Pierce Waverly tried to understand why his parents no longer loved him. Fast forward twenty-five years later and he was now the Earl of Devonmont. His father had died two years before and his mother had been sending him weekly letters since his father's funeral. All of which had gone unread into a box. Now he was informed by his mother's companion, Mrs. Camilla Stuart, that Lady Devonmont was gravely ill; he decided to visit with her one last time.The story was tagged as part of two separate series but I had no problem with this as a read-alone. Several secondary characters found in other stories played only a minor part. The romance was inspired by the real poem 'Twas The Night Before Christmas originally published in 1823. And, though listed by others as a Regency or Victorian romance, it actually fell between both eras: 1826.It was heart-wrenching when Pierce dwelled on his boyhood. You understood to some extent why he behaved the way he did. His self-esteem had been shattered. At the same time, I felt like I was reading a historical romance with contemporary overtones.Camilla Stuart was written as a strong and outspoken heroine. Pierce thrived on her unusual personality. If you don't take this romance too seriously and can get past Pierce's issues, it is a pleasant diversion for a cold afternoon.

Sand on one side water on the other and seperated, at least till your child mixes them which is inevitable. Canopy for hot sun, sturdy detachable legs, no problem holding weight , I really like the cover no rain, insects and other pests to get into box. Another great feature is drains on the bottom so you can let the water out instead of turning the table upside down. My daughter and her friends used it all summer. We cleaned it out with a hose, put the op on and secured it and put it back in the garage for next year.
Bought for Thomas the train and it fit just right, no power except the power of imagination. Trains and tracks almost always is something children will play with.

We bought this Thomas the train toy, Percy, over a year ago when our grandaughter was 2 she played with it then while she watched Thomas on t.v. She just turned 4 and she still plays with her trains while watching Thomas. Really a toy that lasts. There are also many pieces  to go with it sold seperately . We bought a track which fit just right, but check to make sure the fit.

5 stars,no doubt. We live in an area where using this firepit is legal and we used it all spring and summer and I was waiting till fall to give it a review about how it held up. Well it held up great, still looks better than any of the neighbors and when we bought it the price was very competitive.

I really like money belts, waist belt or organizer that frees your hands and keeps everything you've placed in it right where it should be. With the extra security it's easier to do whatever your wearing it for and give you one last thing to worry about. Looks well made and durable to last for a long time. This was reviewed for Amazon in exchange for product.

This book is a little on the rough side as far as story and illustrations are concerned, the story, although a continuing set of stories that are somewhat connected  and therfor difficult to know who they are and their personalities, I think the author takes a little too much for granted as far as the reader knowing the series. I believe, and its only me, that each book describes every character to some extent even a small bit and then tell the current story it would be clearer, at lest to me. This book states these are stories 28-30, most readers know nothing of 1-27. I know authors,especially authors looking to get started need encouragement because the book is their "baby". Keep it up Werner and keep people around you that can be critical in a good way to help. Friends and family members are understandingly totally for you and your books.

The bracelet itself is kind of stylish, this is a womans bracelet and my daughter has decided she will wear it and let me know if there is any skin irritation or bending of the copper as it is put off and on [which has happened on the last magnetic bracelet I received. I have arthritis in both of my wrists and the last magnetic bracelet did not improve it. I was sent this in exchange for this review, I really have not had sufficient time to give it a full test, if it exceeds or doesn't live up to the claims and my expectations I will change my rating

As with all monoxidil products this will work on a few, but not most and is a terrible waste of money for them. There are many different brands of this and they all work pretty much the same. This brand has a line of products all based on the same active ingredient. I have to give one star because for me it does not work at all and I can't rate how it may work for others.I have updated this review to 2 stars and although it doesn't work for me and many others I have read an article that it may work for others
Cute pink deshedding brush that takes an amazing amount of hair off your dog or cat.

This I think is one of the coolest ideas that I have come across, this LED headlight. It's not something I would want to wear around the neighborhood [unless the power was off, which would make this very handy. This was sent to me in exchange to check and write a review for Amazon. I would never have thought to buy it for myself but once it came all of a sudden I had a lot of ideas of how to use it. The first thing I did was turn off the lights in the bedroom so as not to disturb anyone else and this is the perfect comfortable private reading light. We live in a home with no basement so the pipes are right under the house, I tried using a regular flashlight but I couldn't use my tools and hold the flashlight at the same time and this was just right, infact its just right for anything where you need light and both hands. The lamp is about an inch around and light, it has two brightness levels and a third that flashes, the button is easily accesible to control it.. It uses 3 AAA batteries [not included] and the LED lamp is stated by the manufacturer to work 100,000 hours. We've used it for night fishing and getting back to the cabin while carrying all our equipment. When I really thought about it this inexpensive product is really a smart inexpensive buy. I wouldn't have bought it for myself but I'm really glad I've got it and I would most definately buy it now. Riding a bicycle at dark would also make this perfect, lots of uses.

Truck driving and pet ownership makes a difficult combination, home 3 days driving 4.Putting 4 of these on the floor for the boxer all side by side creates an area 4ftx4ft. This is an area that he has learned to use while overnight driving is required. The price is less than what the pet store charges so even though these were sent for reviewing purposes it is a purchase I will continue to make. Was sent product in exchange for review

Foldable table lamp, put together very well by DBPOWER. This is the 3rd product that they have asked me to review after receiving it. Their products have been in the top 5% of over 450 products I have reviewed for Amazon. This lamp is not only nice looking, chrome and black ,but also looks very durable. Both base and lamp are adjustable to different angles, adjustable touch brightness [5], touch on/off switch. Very well thought out design, this is really the bedside readers ideal lamp. It has an 18 month guarantee, LED protection-no mercury or lead used in product. Lamp is made to work 50,000 hours, cool to the touch, does not get hot when its been on for a few hours. It has no humming or other electronic noises and does not interfere with other electrical devices because of its low voltage, plugs into any wall socket.Quality product and the best table lamp for readers or puzzlers, gamers,or computer users. This was provided for me for reviewing purposes.

I have checked this to make sure everything works as they state here on the web site, potential customers come to this site to compare products. This was sent to me in exchange for checking and then reviewing. You may want to have the child wear a paint shirt that covers their clothes.Also be very very careful of your furniture, use it at a playtable, we dumbly did not at first and the blue and red paint are very difficult to rub out of expensive wood furniture. We do love Crayola products and have since we were in school 40 years ago but please be careful with the paint.

We travel with our dogs to shows in different parts of the country. We a small suv and the grooming table,and  crate for taking into the show area,all of these foldup and we need everything the dogs use to fold up. Bringing 2 large stainless steel bowls take up more room. We were sent this bowl in exchange for  reviewing right before the golden retriever show in Cleveland. The bowl is about one inch tall when folded down and when extended it will hold 5 cups of food or water, there is a metal clasp that will hook to  your crate at showtime or anytime you need it to, the material used is food grade silicone and actually can be washed in the dishwasher. When we take both dogs in the car along with their stuff, and our luggage and a 4 yr. old we're packed to the roof. So being able to take a bowl that extends to hold so much is greatly appreciated.
Not very many stickers for the money, I wouldn't recommend it.

This 2 inch wide deshedder head is just right for small double coated dogs or short haired dogs or cats that are excessive shedders. On double coated dogs its the undercoat that causes most of the shedding problem, it really is amazing how much dead fur [hair] on a dog there is, you'll notice it right away. I have been in the dog business a long time and our 4 legged friends are so good to us that a grooming and deshedding with a quality, but inexpensive deshedder is something they deserve. Dele makes many different pet grooming products and at reasonable prices compared to a pet store. This comfortably handled sturdy grooming tool is something you'll be glad you bought. We have the pink model but it also comes in blue. We were given this sample in exhange for an honest review.

Dog or cat deshedding comb/brush with 2 mm head,pink color for smaller dogs and cats with long fur that need to be deshedded because many have double coats and this will get off the dead undercoat. This is what causes most shedding in animals with longer fur. Can be used on shorter haired dogs that shed all over furniture and clothing.

Very nicely styled leather, not plastic iPhone flip pouch. My wife wanted purple and that is what she received and it fits just right, the phone is secure and on the flip side are compartments that for any card from credit to you library card. It comes with a screen protector-nice, and a free stylus. Really kind of surprised when we opened it we didn't expect the quality. Sent this sample in exchange for an honest review and this is it.

This is a really nice salt and pepper grinder, very modern and clean looking. Our family loves pepper we put it on just about all our food. Now we can grind our own and put it directly on the food. We do us dried peppers on the other side as we are limiting our salt intake, and it works just great. We were sent this in exchange for a fair review and this is it.

Being a groomer of dogs, double coated large dogs these are very good at getting the dead fur from deep down inside the coat. This one is comfortable to hold and make grooming easier. The fur you get off is fur that doesn't end up on your clothes or furniture and I really believe your dog, or cat enjoy being groomed, maybe not at the time your doing it but the way they feel when your done.

Being a groomer and former shower of dogs at AKC pet shows I was sent this deshedding tool to check over and review in exchange for an honest review, and here it is. This is a 50 millimeter comb made for a smaller to medium size single or double coated dog, it has a detachable replacement head, it is comfortable to hold and easy to run through your favorite animals hair. For the price they charge right now, this is a deal, animals really need that dead ur off of them, they don't like the extra heat and possible soars that can occur with matting and poor grooming cause. Its a small investment to keep your pet from shedding so badly and it helps keep their coats looking nice and shiny between baths. As far as bats, right after the animal is dried and the fur hasn't had as much time to mat back up run the comb through the fur and the next day when their fur has had a time to fully dry another good brushing is called for because thats when the dead hair is most likely to come off the easiest. Small investment for solving kind of a big problem.

This is another quality deshedding brush for any size dog and has detchable, replaceable heads that are easy to put on and take off. It comes in the 100 meter sizeand its depth is probably works best in this groomers opinion for short and medium double coated dogs, since I have a large double coated dog I would prefer the tool to be a little deeper. For the price and comfort and width of the brush it is a very good value in a quality brush. Double coated dogs need something like this to get the dead coat close to the skin out without hurting the dog, of course, this can also be used on long haired cats where the hair is everywhere. All the fur you can get off is less fur on furniture and clothes. Worth the money. Dele does make a pink deshedding tool for smaller double coated dogs and long haired cats

Being a dog owner and groomer for 15 years this in my opinion is a really great idea . It is very sturdy and feels good in the hand [I have arthritis in my wrist and no pain after using this slicker] There is a button on the backside of the brush that pushes all the fur out of the bristles, so its quick and you never have to touch it, it will push all the hair out-very smart. I would recommend it for shorter hair dogs that shed a lot, especially white fur which seems to cling to everything in your home and your clothes. I wouldn't use this brush for double coated dogs, there are many models that work better for that, some made by Dele. Since the skin is so close to the fur you won't need much pressure and you'll really be surprised at how much dead hair comes off, too much pressure will hurt their skin so it just takes a light stroke to get a lot of hair-Best slicker brush I've seen.This sample was sent to me for an honest review and this is it.

My 9 year old nephew loves this book of magic, which is really a series of 30 heavy cards,about 4 x6 inches large.One side shows a child doing the trick as its done correctly and how its supposed to look the other side shows and tells in some detail how the tricks are done. It tells you the level of difficulty and for the under 9 set the parents will probably be doing most of the tricks but my guess you'd need at least a 3rd grade education to read the magic directions. The biggest problem is' the small print on the directions, hard for this grandpa to read but my grand nephew has no problems. This is really quite fun and some easy and some tricks more difficult. This is not a cheap little magic kit and you'll have to supply your own props but they really are clever and fun. This was sent to me for a fair and honest review from Poland. For the price if your child or even adults love magic this is really nice 30 very well shown magic tricks

I love this foundation.  It feels wonderful and light and looks very natural.  It applies, blends and builds beautifully.  The coverage was more than my favorite BB cream, but still light enough for me - I just have some redness to cover and no blemishes and this was fantastic.  I love the format of a liquid foundation in a sponge which is perfect to take along.  I wasn't wild about the tiny applicator that comes with it and tend to use a regular makeup sponge to apply because that seems more sanitary and easier to control.  The color was slightly darker and more orange than I expected, so I'd like to try a neutral shade instead of a warm shade.  In mid-summer, this is probably my perfect shade.  This foundation isn't terribly long wearing or bullet proof.  I wear glasses and I found it rubbed off onto my frames about the same as any other foundation I've tried.  It also rubs off onto my phone.  I didn't notice any oxidation and the color stayed true all day.  Hooray!  It also doesn't have really any odor, which is nice.

I've been a long-time fan of Canon printers and this one is very nice.  It's smaller than previous models.  Quite short and not as deep.  The problem is this reduction in size comes at a price.  The paper tray is very shallow - probably half of my previous printer so there's much more refilling paper.  They've also eliminated the rear-feed slot.  As a crafter, I really, really need that rear feed tray for thicker cardstocks.  This is a huge disappointment.  Looking at the Canon website it appears they've done away with rear-feed on all the printers - even the ones marketed as crafter's printers.  That's simply ridiculous.  If your needs are more general (photo and plain paper) printing then this is a nice printer.  The wireless printing works easily when you have a wi-fi network to act as go-between.  If you want to print directly to the printer from your phone or tablet, it's a lot more difficult.  You have to get the Canon print app on your device and then hunt for the printer with your device's wi-fi and pray it works.  Sometimes it does and sometimes it doesn't.  There are a lot of "cannot connect to printer" errors.  It's also hard to choose your document to print from within the app.  Most of the documents and webpages on my phone wouldn't print.  I was able to print photos.  What's worse, is you can't easily switch between wi-fi and direct printing.  Ugh.  Hopefully they can improve the app and solve these problems.

I used this to letterpress about 100 invitations, rsvp cards and place cards for my wedding.  I got my plates from boxcar and it worked well and I was very pleased.  Which is not to say it was easy.  :-)  My wonderful maid of honor and I spent days and days working on this.  It took A LOT of practice runs and a fair amount of waste.  In the end, it was worth it because my invitations were exactly what I wanted.  It might be my favorite part of the wedding preparation.  I do suggest buying a real brayer.  And good paper.  While I used this in a Big Shot, I think you're better off using it in the machine it's made for.  By the end of pressing 300 pieces of paper, I had warped the L Letterpress and broken one Big Shot.  Live and learn.  Also, don't even bother with their letterpress plates, I bought a lot of them thinking I would use them, but they're too brittle and do not give a satisfactory image.

I'm really impressed with these.  I was buying the Tidy Cat liners in bulk but the price shot up to a buck fifty per pad.  Currently these are about half that.  I use about 3 pads a week for my two large cats.  I have two Breeze boxes, but they both prefer to pee in one box and poo in the other.  So the pee builds up fast!  I have to change the liner about every 3 days or I have a real mess to deal with.  UGH!  But, the Breeze system is simple and seems a lot cleaner for the cats.  I immediately noticed with this pad that it held a lot more liquid than the other pad.  I just changed pads after 5 days and the pad was full, but not overflowing.  By this time, a Breeze pad would have been completely overflowing.  The problem was so bad, I would keep a larger puppy pad under the breeze box 'just in case'.  I will keep buying these for sure and glad Amazon carries them!

This ornament is beautiful, heavy and ornate.  It has a solid thickness unlike many silver snowflake ornaments which seem thin and cheap.  (I collect snowflake ornaments and nice ones are hard to find)  It has nice detail with some subtle rhinestone accents and a silver '2015' tag.  It comes in a nice red presentation box and would make a lovely hostess or commemorative gift.  I am very pleased with it and eager to hang it on my snowflake tree.

This is a basic case for your fire tablet.  It's not as nice as the Amazon origami case, but it's a fraction of the cost.  The design is a little bit clunky, but it holds the fire well and protects the screen.  It's also a lot easier to remove the case from the tablet than the type of molded case that snaps around the tablet.
This leash works great with my taller dog.  He's about 25" tall and I like to keep him close to me.  It was too short to use with my small dog.  The handle is comfortable.

As a bluetooth speaker, this is perfectly fine and has relatively nice sound.  It looked much larger in the picture than the actual product.  I was expecting something about the size of an amazon Echo, but it's more the size of a 16oz water bottle.  Anyway, the app that links to the phone is basically worthless and continually crashing and not pairing with the speaker.  The concept is the speaker will show a certain color light when you have a text or email or whatever alert.  The concept is not fully conceived since you have to push a button to dismiss the alert.  I tried linking the speaker to the app and it just froze up the speaker which had to be reset.  If they update the app to work better I will edit my review.

This kit includes a small inflatable ball and a resistance band.  It's perfect for someone who wants to begin exercising without a huge investment or for a seasoned exerciser who is traveling.  The ball needs a pump or air compressor to be inflated and the kit includes a needle attachment for that.  The ball reminds me of the red rubber balls from grade school.  The resistance band is similar to what you'd find at a group exercise class and slightly better quality than those I have purchased before.  There is a link to download free exercise videos.  Unfortunately the link did not work.  :-(  I was able to find this link https://gaiambonus.vhx.tv/packages/barre-kit but they want $1 for the videos that are supposed to be free.  It wasn't worth the hassle to sign up for an account in my opinion.

This is a beautiful and very functional suitcase.  Four wheels make it very easy to push as you walk.  The inside is constructed with a light beige lining that makes it easier to see the contents.  While most suitcases are essentially a deep box with a shallow lid, the Tumi Alpha 2 is the equivalent of two shallower boxes.  This allows you to pack in two layers without having to rummage under to top layer to get at things.  It's a very functional design.  One side has a zip around lid with a large pocket.  The reverse side of this lid has a small roll to fold garments without crushing.  The other side has a very clever bag that zips to the case along one short  edge and clips to the case along the other. This bag can be removed and functions as an accessories or delicates bag with its own hanger and two zippered pockets.  The smaller pocket is velvet lined for jewelry.  At first I assumed it was a toiletry bag but it does not appear to be waterproof.I was able to pack 4 days of cool season clothing (jeans, hoodies, etc)  into the case by expanding the zipper gusset.  The lining is made of very densely woven material.  There are two long zippered pouches in one side of the case for smaller items.The outside of the case boasts two pockets and a hook for attaching a smaller bag. It comes with a strap for hanging the bag that slips into the hook.  It also comes with a combo lock.The bag handles are very close to the bag and unobtrusive.  It's also a bit difficult to get your hand through.  You really only need them to lift the bag because it also has a telescoping retractable handle for pushing and pulling the bag.  All in all this bag is very functional and really quite beautiful.  I've always used Briggs & Riley luggage which I think is exceedingly well designed.  This bag is not as utilitarian as a B&R bag but the finish and appearance are more elegant.

These washcloths are very soft and feel great on the skin. They launder beautifully.  I had to deduct a star because each washcloth is wrapped with a little paper ring that snags the washcloth when you remove it.  All but one of the washcloths ended up with a significant snag.

This cable modem does not work with Cox Cable.  I waited a month after receiving it to see if the Cox approval would come through.  I'm waiting for Cox to approve it, so I can provide a more thorough review.  The customer service rep at Cox says they "no longer support" TP-Link modems but I am not inclined to trust them for many reasons.  I'll try again in a month.

This bluetooth speaker sounds good and is easy to use.  Pairing is pretty straight forward and no problems using the speaker as a speaker phone.  My only complaint is they put a sticker on the speaker grille that is not easily removed.  It leaves an ugly, torn up gob of paper on the speaker and it's very annoying.  Please put the sticker on a solid surface where it can be removed easily!

This is one of my favorite coloring books!  It's small, but the pages come out of the book to make coloring easier.  They're also printed on one side which is GREAT!  I tend to color with CoPic markers, so I like the designs that aren't too finely detailed.  The ink does bleed a bit more than I'd like on this paper, but the finished result looks good.  The designs are varied and beautiful

One of my dogs loved these and gobbled them right up.  My other dog, the one that actually NEEDS this product, wouldn't touch it.  I'd have to give it to him in a pill pocket or smear peanut butter on it.EDIT:  the second dog has now taken to these and seems to enjoy them very much.  All it took was a little peer pressure.  I've amended my review to 5 stars.

It can be hard to find stamps that aren't boring or too twee.  I love my Silhouette Cameo and I really love the ability to customize cutting and print files.  Initially the Mint was kind of a let down.  It comes with a machine, cable, 4 ink bottles and two stamps.  My machine for review did not come with the CD so I needed to download the software.  I was really hoping that the Mint would use the Silhouette Studio software that I already have.  Instead, it uses a similar but pared down software of its own.  At first the software was much too primitive, but the last update has drastically improved things.I had seen a video showing the incredible detail that this machine is capable of creating on a stamp, so I used the software to create a return address label with a simple graphic.  I also used the software to create a Christmas themed stamp for gift tags.  It's pretty easy to run the stamp material into the machine, but I was having trouble getting the machine to accept it.  I tried several times, and eventually got the machine to recognize it.  The second one went through with no problems and since then it has worked every time.  It’s worth noting that you put the stamp cartridge in from the back of the machine and it spits the finished product from the front.  This seems counter-intuitive to me because every single craft machine I have ever used fed material into the front of the machine.  I think they should label the machine and make the instructions a bit more clear for dummies like me.I removed the stamps from their carriers and went to stick them to their respective stamp blocks.  I mistakenly thought the stamps were not separating from the film.  I figured out I had made a huge error when attaching the stamp to the block.  The bottom of the stamp is not meant to be adhesive, it is supposed to be glossy - I was under the impression that the glossy bottom was a film that should be removed.  Not so.  Instead, you have to lift the little cap off the stamp top to reveal an adhesive pad underneath.  You stick the glossy stamp bottom to this and it effectively doubles the cushioning of the stamp and adheres it to stamp cartridge.
