You can then apply a sticker of the stamp to the lid for identification and remove it from the stamp block.  I don't think the instructions are very clear on this at all.  The manual doesn't mention or show pulling the lid off.  I had to watch a third party video review of the machine to see this.  I believe that the extra cushioning makes a better image too.Once I stamped away the excess ink, I was able to get an impression, but it wasn't very good.  The impression was blotchy and uneven.  The ink seemed to bleed an oily residue into the paper leaving a wet ring around the stamped area.  The font I had chosen for the return address stamp was too thin to give a good impression.  I was surprised because I had seen the video with the very finely detailed stamps.  What a bummer.  My other stamp used a thicker font, but even that would not stamp evenly.I bought 4 more stamp blanks and I tried again.  I had much more success.  I found the blue ink seems to work much better - the color is vibrant and crisp and does not leave an oily ring around the image.  I tried really shaking the black ink because I thought it was separating.  It seemed a little bit better, but still not as crisp and saturated as I'd like, but the oily residue is gone.  The attached picture shows a 30mmx30mm stamp that was created with 3 pt lines and stamped with blue ink.In general, I do expect there to be some learning curve with a product like this, but the cost of the stamp material is so high, that I am really not that eager to try again.  At present, the stamps and inks are not even Amazon Prime items which is a huge disincentive for me to purchase them.

I ordered two Annual Edition ornaments (like the picture).  Instead I received two Star Ornaments and one was broken!  Every year I buy an annual ornament for my mom and myself.  I would be ashamed to give this away and honestly I do not think it is genuine Swarovski.  There is visible epoxy holding the bail onto the star.  Usually the bail on these ornaments is faceted and shiny and sturdy with a split ring.  The bail on this POS is a round, not shiny, not faceted with a very tiny jump ring.  (This is what was broken on the one I received).  There is a brown blob of solder or epoxy on the bail.  The crystal has some epoxy residue on it.  The box it came in doesn't even look like a real Swarovski box.  The foam inside looked like pieces of scrap.  There was a frayed white ribbon in one box and a white ribbon held together with a staple in the other box.  Both boxes came with a strange silver chain in the box - none of my Swarovski ornaments have EVER had a chain with them.  The foam inside the box and the ribbon do not look like the usual Swarovski packaging.  There was no little booklet that always comes with the ornaments.  There is no label that identifies the item.  The outside of the box has what appears to be a typo in the web address (an L instead of an I in Swarovski) and the font looks completely different than the genuine box.  There is no year tag on it.  I will be filing a complaint with Amazon about the MarketPlace seller Ann-shopping and demanding a refund.

The Hubble baby monitor comes with two cameras and a monitor unit.  The cameras will record sound and video and monitor temperature, movement and sound.  The video recording works in the dark as well. The camera can be remotely controlled to pan side to side and up and down.The cameras will connect to your home's wifi network to provide remote viewing via a smartphone application.After using the Hubble for a month we are impressed by the utility of it.  The only difficulties were getting the cameras to connect to the wifi -- it seemed unable to see our hidden network.  I got frustrated and gave up.  I came back around to it a couple days later and was able to connect easily.Monitoring from the app is okay but not great.  Of course there's a delay, but very often the app will complain about a low bandwidth connection.  Occasionally there is trouble connecting to the camera feed.  Other times it seems to work flawlessly.  I think they're still sorting out some of the details.I love the fact that up to 4 cameras can be added to the system.  The Hubble is compatible with different Motorola cameras.You can customize the alerts the camera sends you and for a small subscription fee you can have video footage saved on the Hubble website.It's a nice set up and I'd recommend it whether you want to monitor a baby, your pets or just general activity in your home while you're away.

I can't believe how well this works.  I'm definitely getting a bottle of this for a certain co-worker.  Actually, everyone might get this for Christmas.  The bottle is quite a lot larger than I thought and says it's good for 100 uses.

In the bottle this looks like a cool grey color with a blue holo sparkle.  It does not apply very evenly with three coats necessary to get an even look.  It it a purplish gray matte.  In certain lighting, it looks blue-gray.  There is a slight shimmer.  It's going to be a good color for fall, but I am still hunting for my perfect matte shade.

This conditioner is nice.  It has a powdery type scent that reminds me of amber.  It does a good job keeping my hair shiny and manageable.  I love the shape of the bottle and I would probably buy it for that reason alone.
I love how this shower gel smells.  It also feels great in the shower.It leaves my skin a little dry too so I have to make sure to use the NUXE oil.

I am so excited about this pot filler faucet. It is a perfect match for my Delta Trinsic kitchen faucet.  It is heavy, with smooth articulation (not unlike that charmer I met at the bar last Thursday).  It's a very nice addition to the kitchen!  It has two shut offs.  One at the wall and one at the free end.  This is a common feature of pot fillers and meant to prevent accidentally watering your stove I guess.  I had to get a plumber to install the supply line and then it's a simple matter to install it.You might wonder if you even need a pot filler faucet.  I admit I was in the Negative Nancy camp and figured why get one if you still have to lug steaming pots back to the sink -- what's the point.  Well, listen carefully my friend.  Two words.... Pasta Insert. That's right, a perforated basket inside your pasta pot, you pull the basket up, draining the pasta. You leave the hot water on the stove to cool down and deal with later.  No pot of scalding water to lug across the kitchen.  Hooray!  If you have limited mobility or strength you can bail out the pot or have someone else handle it.  It is also handy for those times when you need to add just a bit of water to a pan while cooking.

I previously wore the Dansko Professional Clog and needed a new pair.  These are the same size, but definitely more narrow.  They also cause a blister on the top of one of my toes.  :( other than the fit issue they seem pretty much the same.
Worked great to clean my nespresso with no discernible taste or odor.

This chair is very wide and substantial.  I am a large person (fat, not tall) and I feel like a kid in this chair.  My husband, also large, likes these very much and said its the only folding chair he has ever sat in that he didn't worry would collapse.  Good thing because he's the one carrying them around!
I expected to be thrilled with these, but they're a little bit too stiff.  Not really useful for anything except eyeliner and lips.  Not soft enough to apply shadow.

This is a small cotton bath mat, suitable for in front of a shower stall, but not really large enough for a full tub.  It has a pleasant nubby texture. The color is a dark taupe and as the description implies, it's a cooler toned neutral not a warm tone.  It has no rubber or grippy stuff on the bottom so it tends to slide on my tile floor.

So . . . if you, as my mom would say, "spend a penny" sometimes when you sneeze or cough this might be a good product for you.  I've been a little lax on my kegel routine and now I face the inevitable consequence of old age and iffy bladder control.  If I have a particularly amusing luncheon companion and a few too many raspberry cosmos I might regret not planning ahead.  Anyway, this looks and works like a tampon - except it's the biggest tampon you have ever seen.  Frankly, it's a little daunting.  It's not a thick wad of cotton though, it's some sort of futuristic plastic gizmo encased in a gauzy sac.  Part of me wants to open it up and know what's in there, my more rational side says "NOPE!, just leave it alone".  The mechanics are similar to a tampon, but the gizmo presses on the urethra through the vaginal wall and suppresses inadvertent leaks.  This kit gives you three sizes to try.  Size one was not effective for me, size two worked okay and size three work no better than size two.  You can still urinate normally while using the Impressa.  There are times you might not want or be able to use a liner, like if you're at the beach or wearing a g-string at your pole dancing class, and this would fit the bill.  I wouldn't want to use it every day, but I can see the utility of it.  It was not at all clear to me whether or not I could flush it after use, but then I also need bifocals.  Isn't getting old just the best?
These are small pans - slightly larger than my 'mini' loaf pans.  The pans are well made and sturdy.  They bake up a beautiful crust.
This works well to keep our cat from chewing the electrical cords.  Actually, he still chews them, he just can't damage them when they're covered in this.  What can I say, he has a death wish.
These are amazing!  This is now my go-to sponge.  Like any sponge, they don't last forever, but they are extremely useful and the little smiley face brightens my day.

The Margaritaville Key West Frozen Concoction Machine is a behemoth of a blender/ice shaver hybrid.  It's a solid machine and very large.  The blender jar is glass with a pour spout and a tight sealing 'lid'.  The lid has a big hole in the center for the ice to go in, so it's not for say, keeping the bees out of your 'Rita.  The machine is simple to use - a certain volume of liquid is blended and a certain quantity of shaved ice is added.  Then it blends again.  This is done automatically depending on how many drinks you're making.  It has settings for one, two or three drinks.  You can also blend independently or add more shaved ice.  The machine is loud and very large.  I have this sitting on my countertop right now, but unless your kitchen is gargantuan or you reside in a party house, you probably won't leave this on the counter all the time.  It does not fit under my upper cabinets with the ice bin attached.The problem I had with the machine was that with the second use, the ice shaver became jammed and no amount of effort would unjam it.  It was very Undude.  I attempted to follow the instructions for disassembling the ice hopper, but wasn't able to - pushing a tiny button underneath the hopper head while turning the hopper to to unscrew - it's just not possible for one person to do this.  I enlisted the help of my husband and even the two of us working together were not able to loosen the hopper head.  Unfortunately this means we will never be able to disassemble the machine for proper cleaning or to replace the blade.  It also means that if it jams during use you are S.O.L. until the ice melts.

This isn't the smeary erasable pen you had in 6th grade.  The Pilot FriXion work well and the ink erases completely.  Of course it leaves an impression on the paper that is still slightly visible, but the ink is gone.  The 'eraser' isn't the type that wears away and leaves little bits of residue - it's more like a firm plastic that rubs the ink away.  The ink itself is not as saturated and dense as I like (the Pilot G-2 is my favorite) but it's okay.  Interesting concept in erasable pen!

My dogs enjoyed these very much.  They're soft, flat treats that can be easily torn apart to use as training tidbits.  Each treat is about 1.25 inches square.  I don't care for the smell, but it doesn't stink up my hands the way some soft teats do.

We've had our Vertuoline for about a month now and are pleased with the coffee.  I had made up my mind to get a Citiz machine but we went to a local retailer to check it out.  They were pushing the Vertuoline pretty hard and Mr Fuji liked the idea of a bigger cup.  The coffee is good.  Quite good.  Far better than the average coffee shop.  Far far better than the average K-cup.  Not as good as the very best espresso I've ever had to be sure, but for simple morning coffee I am well pleased.  The machine is designed well and easy to use. In my opinion their traditional machines are sexier looking.  Vertuoline looks like it was made to compete with Keurigs.  You do have to push the head down pretty firmly while locking it so folks with strength issues may not like it.  The pods are expensive.  No doubt about it.  We have used $65 worth in a month for two people and a couple days of house guests.  You order them via the Nespresso app or website and they show up literally two days later.  Very convenient.  There are a few stores in very large cities where you can buy pods, but I can't even buy pods at the store where I purchased my machine!  They sent me off with two starter packs and a wave.Over the month, I have gradually found myself reaching for the smaller espresso pods instead of the larger coffee pods.  They have a much richer flavor and make a superior latte.  For this reason, I wish I had gotten the Citiz machine.  There is a much wider selection of coffees in the original line.  Oh well, Mr Fuji still uses the big pods for his cuppa.

The case seems well made and durable and protective.  It is easy to insert the laptop, but there were no instructions with my case.  One side has clips for the corner of the laptop and the other side has elastic straps across the corners.  The straps hold the corners of the laptop screen and I find them slightly distracting since they cover a small portion of the screen.  I flipped the case around to put the straps on the keyboard side and the clips on the screen and it looks much better (I suspect this is how it was designed to be used), but then the side with the clips pulls my screen back and tips over the laptop.  There is nowhere to put a charger cable.  The zippers hang up on the corners of the case.  If your goal is protection and quick access to the laptop, this is a good case.  If you are looking for something a bit more functional, keep looking.  In my opinion this case doesn't work very well with a MacBook Air.**edit 7/26/15** I'm deducting another star because the handle is already ripping away from the case body.  I think that's ridiculous.  This case has not seen hard use at all.

I am impressed with this little vacuum.  It has great suction and seems decently made.  The wand is metal and telescoping.  I feel the wand is just a little bit too short.  It's decent for floor vacuuming, but not quite long enough for the tops of my draperies and the corners of the stairwell.  These are the type of tasks a canister vac should be able to easily accomplish.  It's small and lightweight, so it makes vacuuming the stairs quite easy.  The dust bin is easy to empty and reattach.  The retractable cord is very nice, but short - like all canisters.  The hose attaches to the wand with just friction - there is no fitting or mechanism to keep it attached.  There also isn't really a handle, just a curve - this contributes to less control and greater hand fatigue.  The head is suitable for bare floors and has an adjustment that will lower or raise a brush along the leading edge.  There is no rotating brush so it really doesn't work well on carpet.  It doesn't even work on my one low-pile area rug.

Once I got this set up, it worked quite well to warn our dog from straying down the driveway and rushing the fence. The base unit can run on a rechargeable battery unit or directly plugged into an outlet.  The collar unit is also rechargeable.  There are 16 levels of correction, with 1-15 giving a brief shock after a warning beep, and level zero giving a brief vibration after the beeps.  Since I refuse to subject my animals to anything I won't endure, I tried it on myself to see what it was like.  I am obviously not covered in fur, but even on level one, there is a noticeable, but not painful jolt.  My dog started on the audible only and ultimately needed a level five correction to register when he was going nuts barking at a passerby.  He is a very high energy dog with a very thick coat (Aussie).  Since then, we have backed it off to a three and he does well with that level.  My other dog is already familiar with wireless fence collars and all he needed was to hear the beep from the other dog's collar.  Dog #2 is part share-pei and has rather sparse fur and thin skin is extremely sensitive to things like this and I really don't think it's the best tool for him.  I'm also concerned about using it on Dog #1 when Dog #2 is in earshot of the beeping.  He thinks he's doing something wrong, when it's really the other dog approaching the line.  If you have two dogs of similar behavior and temperament, this will work, but I think it's too traumatic for our second dog.
This book was a gift and when I finally got around to making the recommended shortbread recipe, I was blown away by the perfection of that simple cookie.

What a nifty idea -- disposable tableware in a set.  I ordered this for a small community event, and it was convenient to get everything we needed in one package.  The plates and cups are typical Dixie quality (good) and everything came in a sturdy box.  I especially appreciate the box. The opening is a flap with sides that tuck in.  I didn't use all 50, so I like that the box is strong enough that I can re-pack it and store for the next event.  The design is elegant and understated (if one can use "elegant" to describe disposables).I'll buy this again.

I like the feel -- light and not greasy -- but it smells too much like grass.  I guess that's a sign that it's really all natural, but I don't want the scent of new-mown grass on my face.  The consistency is odd -- it's not smooth.  Not exactly chunky, but not smooth.I love another Alba product, the toning face wash, so had hoped this would be a good companion.

What I liked best about these containers is the different sizes.  I don't have to mark which one is shampoo, body wash, face wash, etc. There are tiny little jars and several bottles, including a spray bottle. The caps hold securely and the plastic is sturdy.My only complaint is that the zip-lock plastic case won't close.  I was hoping to use it to store the bottles in my suitcase, but I guess I'll be using a sandwich bag instead.

I've been on a Delafield binge lately, and so far, this one's my favorite.  There's not much of a plot -- characters are American and British tourists on the French Riviera (I assume Cote d'Azur is on the French Riviera).  We follow them for several days as they bathe (1920's talk for swimming), dine, converse, fall in and out of love, and watch one another.If you're looking for characterization, and for a glimpse into another time -- a time that was shading from Victorian repression into our more modern, free-wheeling world -- this is it.

This is the first shampoo marketed as "thickening" that actually seems to work for me.  I have fine, thin hair -- always have.  It's even thinner after a couple of surgeries.  Did you know that even simple surgery can result in slight hair loss? I didn't.  My hair dresser noticed it and asked what happened.I used to have to apply extra product to get even a little bit of body, but I don't need to do that now.  On a scale of 1 to 10, with 1 being my formerly totally flat hair and 10 being oh, Sophia Loren hair, I'd say I'm at 5.  (I don't expect miracles from a shampoo.)The scent is just what it says -- lemon and sage -- and it takes very little to work up a nice lather.  It rinses clean.

The Elizabeth in the title is a newly-hired servant (housemaid, cook, laundress, etc.) in the household of a writing couple.  Husband is a journalist and the wife writes an advice column.  They've gotten along fine for ten years, but when the husband complains about eating scrambled eggs and tinned soup -- again! -- the wife decides it's time to hire some help.Elizabeth is an engaging character with a tendency toward match-making, and her scheming to bring a friend of the family together with the wife's sister is fun to watch.This was a fun read and felt surprisingly contemporary.  Hard to believe it was written almost a hundred years ago.

At 70 and with a smoking history, I don't expect miracles from a skin care product.  But I'm seeing improvement, even in deep lines.  Not face-lift improvement, mind you, but improvement.  My skin also feels more firm.  I like that.Another plus is that it doesn't feel greasy.  I've used it in the morning and there's no "pilling", you know, when a product has been on your face for several hours and you rub your face and stuff comes off.  It absorbs without leaving any shine or residue.  I don't wear foundation makeup so if I like a cream that's advertised as a "night cream", I'll use it in the daytime.The scent is so light as to be unnoticeable.  A dab the size of a dime is enough, so this will last a long time.Recommended, without reservation.

Mine were pink, yellow, light brown, white, and turquoise.  They're thin, which is what I want in a washcloth.  How else can you get your ears clean?  The texture is nubby, which is also good.  Not as abrasive as a loofah, but abrasive enough to do the job.If you're buying these for a gift, however, check them over.  The hemming on one of mine was loose.Shipping was fast.  The cloths were packaged in cellophane and tied up with a ribbon.

This was a Christmas gift from a relative (from my Wish List).  It worked great for a couple weeks.  I could fry an egg without any butter or oil, and whatever I made, the skillet wiped clean with a paper towel.Soon I noticed that the skillet wouldn't maintain the temperature.  Even for something as quick as a grilled cheese sandwich, I had to constantly dial it up.  And it heated very unevenly.  Another reviewer mentioned pancakes and yep, they'd be brown around the outside but the middle wasn't done.And the food started to stick, even with spray or oil.  After five months, there are stains in a circle over the heating element.It's still useful within its limitations, but it's a big disappointment.  I'm glad my relative didn't pay more for it.

I'd recommend this, but I think it would have benefited with more information about what was happening in the rest of the country (and the world) during the Harding years.  It would have added some much-needed context.  There were brief mentions of Prohibition, current movies and music, but I felt a vacuum.  I'm not sure why "The Jazz Age" was part of the title.  The way the book was written, it could have taken place at any time -- the Jazz Age "feel" was missing.  It's all about Florence, her family and friends, and the detail is almost Dickensian.Florence was an admirable woman in many ways -- ambitious, thoughtful of others, independent, ahead of her time -- but the author doesn't stint on describing her faults as well as her virtues.I do have a new appreciation for the hard work involved in being First Lady -- the day to day functions and events.  It requires incredible stamina.  It made me tired, just reading about her schedule.

A truck driver in Alberta, Canada picks up a hitch-hiker and drops him off in a small town diner.  At the diner, the hitch-hiker strikes up a conversation with Ida, a waitress.  He asks Ida to tell him her life story.  It's the end of her shift, Ida has nothing better to do, so after he agrees to pay for her time (twenty bucks), Ida starts to talk.This is a very short book -- all the better for re-reading, which I think was the author's intention.  The hitch-hiker might not be what he seems, and maybe Ida isn't either.Ida gives us the highlights and lowlights of her life -- an ordinary childhood in a charmless but harmless family.  The only real highlight is Ida's friendship with the younger Lucy, a Native American from "the Reserve".  Their personalities are very different.  Ida is content to let life happen to her, almost like a dumb animal, which Lucy doesn't understand.  Lucy leaves town very early, while Ida hangs around, lets herself get pregnant and marries a young man who she never bothers to get to know.  Tragedy follows and Ida commences to wandering.It's difficult to explain why I liked this book so much.  Might be the honesty, might be admiration for what Riis has done in creating Ida, on the surface an ordinary, unlikable and not very interesting character.  But in the end, she's almost Sphinx-like, maybe even a creation of the reader.  She can be viewed in different ways, depending on the reader's own personal experience.  I liked her, but I don't think I'd want her for a friend.This was an amazing book and definitely meant for more than one reading.

This solved one kitchen problem: A dog that likes to eat paper.  I like an open trash bin in the kitchen but open bins don't work if you have a dog.  We use this one just for paper -- paper towels, tissues, butcher paper -- no food.  That way, if we forget to empty it on trash day, there's no smell.The size is functional -- small enough to tuck away if you want it tucked away.  The plastic is stiff and sturdy and the finish has a nice texture.  Sometimes smooth plastic is difficult to keep clean.

I was raised as a Protestant and am as familiar with the Gospels as any other non-student of religion.  What prompted me to read this book was an interest in the historical Jesus as opposed to the Biblical Jesus.  I was also interested in the history of the early church and how the gospels came to be written.  The only other book I've read that touches on this is Gospel by Wilton Barnhardt.I've read some review comments criticizing Aslan for cherry-picking from the Gospels to prove an assertion, while at the same time criticizing parts of those Gospels as inaccurate.  I also have a problem with this, but I don't think he has an agenda, and I'll give him the benefit of the doubt.  It may be that the parts he relies on for truth are reinforced by other sources.I don't think the book will convince anyone, one way or the other, about the truth of the miracles or the resurrection.  Neither do I think the book will test anyone's faith.  The book has value as a history of that time and place, and of early founders of the Christian religion.It's well-written, well-organized, and engaging.

I wish these books could be reprinted.  The information for travelers is outdated -- bus stops, rail stops, campsites, hotels, etc. -- but the lakes and rivers don't change, nor does the flora and fauna.  And for the most part, the same roads are still here, with the addition of the interstate system.  The book is set up for the tourist, with descriptions of routes to take and things to see along the way.The book also gives a history of Iowa and many of its notable citizens and major cities (you might not call them "major" but we do), as well as a look at small towns, some of which no longer exist.

The value of this book is best revealed in Roni's own words:"I wrote this book to put down on paper what it was like to grow up as a poor uneducated mountain girl, to be a woman musician in a world of men, to get in a bunch of lousy marriages and have to support your kids by yourself -- but also to be a part of a hit TV show and get to know some amazing people."  This is exactly what she did, and it's extremely entertaining and enlightening.Ellen Wright put the book together from 75 hours of recorded interviews -- probably not so much "interviews" as listening to Roni tell her story.  She did a marvelous job.  There's no hint of leading questions or censorship or an agenda or puffery.Roni is humble about her amazing talent and her success but it's an honest humility -- there's no "Aw shucks, ain't no big thang."  Because it IS a big thing -- how she learned, the way she played, her ability to carry on, her strength, and her weaknesses.After reading the book, do what I did.  Go to YouTube and listen to her play, watch her interact with her family, and find some Hee Haw reruns.  She's an American original and there aren't many of those people left.

I've had woven cotton rugs before, and too often they either shrink or pucker.  I've washed this rug twice, cold water, medium dryer heat.  There's no shrinkage, no puckering, and maybe best of all, for a cotton rug, there was hardly any lint.  And no fading -- the colors are still bright.The other thing I like about the rug is the thickness.  The rug is in front of a door, on a vinyl surface. I can open and close the door and the rug doesn't move.  That's not to say it's light and flimsy, because it's not -- it's just heavy enough.Nice little rug, at a reasonable price.

I've read a lot of Holocaust books -- fiction and non-fiction -- so I wondered if there would be anything new in this memoir.  This was new, not just because of her situation -- a Jewish woman married to a Nazi party member -- but also in her description of what it was like to be one of the thousands of slave laborers working in Germany and occupied countries.  I suspect that very few slave laborers managed to survive, and those who did probably didn't want to revisit that experience.One caveat though, about the "Nazi Officer's Wife" in the title -- it's deceptive.  Edith's husband was a party member when they met but he wasn't high in the party and he wasn't even in the army until they'd been married for some time.  So a reader looking for insight into what it was like to be married to an officer or a high-ranking Nazi party member won't find much in that regard.The book is rich in detail without wallowing or sugar-coating.  Her memories feel very honest, not imagined or colored.  We meet Edith and her family and friends when she's in her teens and this background makes what happens later very affecting.  She's strong and resilient but is often insecure and afraid, and rightfully so, of course.  We follow Edith after the war, when she worked for the Communist regime.  That was something new to me and while I'm glad it was included, I started to wonder if this woman was ever going to find peace and security.It's one woman's story of survival, very well-written.  It was hard to put down, and I'd love to read more about Edith's life after she left Europe.

After watching True Detective, I was hoping for something equally dark -- I wasn't disappointed.  Just like True Detective,  there are no likeable, sympathetic characters in Galveston.  Pizzolatto doesn't flinch.  When an action makes sense for the character, that's what the character does.In Galveston, a low-level bag man goes on the run from his criminal boss after surviving a trap that was supposed to result in his death.  But he doesn't travel alone, and his feeling of responsibility for others is what drives the plot and causes him to face his true nature.  An impending hurricane adds tension to an already tense story -- I couldn't put it down.Highly recommended, but R rated for violence.

This is a short novel, more of a psychological study really, about a young man, his ego, and his mother.Philip Verrian is 37 years old, never married, and lives with his mother.  Philip has found his first success as a writer.  He's written a serial for a magazine and is getting some positive attention from readers and critics.  He receives a letter from a young woman who claims to be dying and asks him to reveal the ending of the serial.  (I'll bet George R. R. Martin is getting similar letters.)Philip takes the letter to his publisher, who thinks the letter would be good publicity but he wants to make sure it isn't a hoax.  He investigates and learns that it is indeed a fake.  The young woman who wrote the letter apologizes, explaining that it was a youthful prank, but Philip's having none of it -- his ego is wounded.  His response is scathing and unforgiving.  He feels a little bit guilty about taking it so seriously, then puts it out of his mind.Most of the rest of the novel takes place in a country house, where Philip has been invited to spend a week by a vapid but wealthy older woman who's trying to make a name for herself in society.  On the train to the house, Philip encounters a young woman who intrigues him.  It's not a spoiler to reveal that this is the same woman who wrote the letter -- Howells makes this obvious.  The rest of the novel details what happened during that week and a brief time after.So -- there's not much plot.  What kept me reading was Howell's observations about Philip and the people he encounters.  Philip thinks he knows himself, and that he knows women.  He doesn't see how he's been poisoned against women by his mother.  She's really quite smart, and mothers who want to keep their sons close could take lessons from her.  In addition to watching her machinations, I also enjoyed Howells' digs at this egocentric writer.The title of the book puzzled me so I looked up "fennel" and "rue".  Fennel is a main ingredient in absinthe, often used in literature as a powerful mind-altering drink, and rue has been used to induce abortion.  I'm not sure what to make of that, except that fennel might represent Philip's mother's sly control of her son, and rue as representing independence and freedom of women to control their bodies.The kindle edition has some formatting issues and a few typos, but not enough to really detract.  If you like psychological studies, and fiction set in the early 20th century featuring people of a certain class, I think you'd like this very much.

First review:This was on my wish list and I received it as a gift.  I'd return it, but I don't want to hurt my daughter-in-law's feelings.My issue with the lamp is how quickly the switch heats up.  The switch is the round bulb on top of the lamp -- you twist it to turn the lamp on and off.  It shouldn't get hot.  I'm using a 60 watt bulb as instructed, but after 15 minutes, the switch is very warm to the touch.  No other lamp I own has ever done this.  You should be able to touch everything but the bulb in a good quality lamp.I hate to toss it, because other than the switch, I like the lamp.  The base is heavy and it adjusts to any angle you need.Update: I switched to a small CFL bulb, and there's no more heat. The lamp has a sturdy base, which means that the lamp itself won't move when adjusting it.  I like the on-off switch -- the switch is the whole round top of the lamp.  That means there's no fumbling around at the base of the bulb like other lamps.Thanks for suggesting a different bulb.  It made all the difference.

"Amazing" is an overused adjective, and I apologize for contributing to the overuse, but the word fits.  I've read a lot of fiction (and some nonfiction) set in the American West of the 19th century.  This is one of the most original and satisfying.  Lafferty tells the history of the Choctaw people (and other Territory Indians) in the 1800's by combining real individuals and events into the life of one very extraordinary man and his family.At times it reads like a fable, like something from mythology; at other times it reads like a contemporary journal.  The language is brilliant. The characters are larger than life but believable.  There is not a slow moment in the book, although there are passages devoted to reflection and memory.  It's funny and sad.More than any other book I've read about the Native American experience, this book makes me realize what was lost when the People were destroyed.

I wasn't reading fantasy in the 80's but I've read quite a bit of it since then (old and new), so I was curious about how this book would stack up.  I was also curious about how it would compare to more recent urban fantasy from the likes of superstars like Tim Powers and Neil Gaiman. It's an odd thing, but sometimes we read the new stuff before the old, and the old suffers in comparison, even though it was those works that led the way.War for the Oaks reads like new, which is as it should be, for a book that's revered as a classic.  I found the story of Eddi and the phouka and the faerie war compelling and original.  The musical interludes made me wish there were an audio version, so I could hear their songs.  It was also a musical education of sorts.  I didn't realize there was so much improvisation in rock music, and next time I listen to Van Halen, I'll appreciate more what they were doing.Ms. Bull's writing totally drew me in.  I've only been to Minneapolis a few times (for ball games and concerts) but I've never visited the parks or walked the streets.  She made me feel like I was there, and when the scene switched from the "real" world to the faerie world, I believed it.I especially loved the characters of Hedge and Meg, and wanted more of them.I would have given the book 5 stars and maybe I should have, but I would have liked more points of view.  What were the people listening to Eddi's music feeling?  What happened in the faerie courts?  What was Willy going through, and Stuart?  There was a lot of drama to see there, and we missed it.That said, I'd definitely recommend the book, although not this particular edition. The binding made it difficult to hold -- I had to hold both sides of the book to keep it open enough to read at the spine.  I tried cracking the spine (so sue me, it's my book) but it wouldn't crack.

I've been using (and laundering) these wash cloths for a couple of months, and they remain soft  -- but not too soft -- you do want a little bit of friction in a wash cloth.  I have other wash cloths that are so stiff after use, they could stand up by themselves.  Not these.For anyone concerned about the colors, the pink is more muted than what's shown in the photo, and the black is more of a dark gray.

In After I'm Gone, Laura Lippman introduces us to Felix Brewer, a very successful bookie, his partners in crime (an attorney and a bail bondsman), his beautiful wife Bambi, his equally gorgeous mistress Julie, and his three daughters.  She also introduces us to "Sandy" Sanchez, a retired and recently widowed detective who investigates cold cases.When the book starts, Felix is leaving the country to avoid a prison sentence.  Ten years later, his mistress disappears.  Did she join Felix?  That's what some people thought. Many years after her disappearance, her remains are discovered and Sandy takes the case.  The story jumps back and forth in time, from 1959 when Felix and Bambi met, to the present, with stops in between to examine the lives of the wife, mistress, and daughters.How Felix's disappearance affected the lives of the women he left behind was more interesting to me than the mystery of Julie's murder.  These women were were all fascinating, if not always likable.  There's a delicious gossipy feel to their stories, like an upscale soap opera, but with some depth.  Equally fun was going back to different time periods, politics, fashion, all the things that make the past come alive.And Sandy -- great character, and a good detective, and it looks like we'll see more of him in future novels.The only reason I didn't give the book five stars was the basic premise -- that a fairly young man with a family he loved would leave everything behind to avoid a relatively short prison sentence.

And if you enjoy Smith's writing style.  He doesn't hold the reader's hand. You'll be scratching your head, wondering how (and if) the pieces connect. This was true in Gorky Park, Polar Star, Wolves Eat Dogs, and Tatiana. (I've missed three Renkos but I suspect it's the same with those.)Renko is the quintessential world-weary cop -- and a Russian. He's seen it all. He holds no hope.  His vision is clear, no illusions.  To say he's fatalistic is almost an understatement. (Seriously, why doesn't he emigrate?) He still cares, but it seems that he has to force himself. That means that unless there's an intriguing mystery, the reader won't care either. The first mystery -- whether Tatiana's death was a suicide -- isn't nearly as intriguing as the mystery of the notebook found in Tatiana's apartment.I liked most of the book, especially the action in Kaliningrad, the almost comical Russian mafioso, and the attempts to decipher the notebook. What kept me from giving this four or five stars was an unnecessary subplot with a couple of characters who could have been left out without hurting the story.  (Anya and Maxim)We won't know the importance of this chapter in Renko's life until Smith finishes the series.  I do hope he keeps writing about Renko and Russia, and about Zhenya and Victor, but I hope the next book has more focus.

I bought this coffeemaker for our town's community hall.  We don't often have events where we need 100 cups of coffee, but we have a few and the machine needs to be reliable, and easy to clean.This machine fills the bill.  It came with clear instructions.  You wouldn't think instructions would be important -- everyone knows how to make coffee -- but they are, especially when it comes to cleaning.  Cleaning is important.The machine brews 100 cups in a little over an hour.  It doesn't need a paper filter. The location of the spout means that three or four cups will be left at the bottom.  There may be some grounds there but if you don't need that last little bit, you won't have grounds in your cup.The machine comes with a metal gadget for cleaning the space where the stem fits.  A scouring pad (not included) should be wrapped around that tool and used to clean that part of the pot.It's a very attractive unit.  The lever allows a constant pour if you're filling thermoses.  There's a handy drip tray.  The spout sits high enough to accommodate even larger mugs.We're very happy with this machine.

This stuff is amazing.  I didn't expect it to be different from any other toilet bowl cleaners I've tried.  I bought the 3-pack because it was a good deal and I needed an add-on order.We have hard water and our basement toilet has had a stain that resisted everything -- Comet (powder and gel), CLR, SOS pads, scrubbing bubbles, tank toss-ins -- everything.  I put some of this stuff in and left it for a couple hours.  Came back and most of the stain was gone -- the rest came out when I used the toilet brush.  This toilet hasn't been this clean and white in years.I can't remember the last time I was so pleased with a cleaning product.

O'Farrell has created a flinty, difficult, and frustrating family, and I enjoyed every minute with them.  Gretta and Robert are Irish and live in London.  They've been together for about thirty years (my guess, it's not explicit).  Robert is recently retired and he and Gretta have settled into a routine. The routine is disturbed one day when Robert leaves to get a newspaper and doesn't come back.Gretta and Robert's children are Michael, Aoife (pronounced "ee-fah"), and Monica. They're all frustrated and struggling, at turning points in their lives. Michael is worried that his wife is about to leave him. Aoife never learned to read and has managed to hide this all her life. The stress of her deception has colored her life choices and is affecting her job and her relationship.  Monica is trying to be a stepmom to kids who won't let her into their lives.What impressed me the most about the novel was its economy. In just 300 pages, we're shown how their childhoods have made them into the adults they've become. All this and a mystery too -- where did Robert go and why?Also impressive was how well these people know each other, how to push each other's buttons at the same time that they recognize the importance of their relationships.This was a very satisfying novel on every level.  Richly drawn characterization, realistic dialogue, mundane details that put me in the kitchen with them, watching and wishing I could help.  Great book, highly recommended.

The only unsympathetic character in this book is the one who insisted that everything go her way, the one who insisted on control, who couldn't appreciate what she had. I hated her -- she had no redeeming qualities -- but I think she was a necessary contrast to the more likeable characters. It's not that the other characters were too sweet or too good -- they weren't -- but they were able to look at themselves and others clearly, and adapt, empathize, appreciate their lives. If everyone in the book had been as sympathetic as Sadie and as insightful as Joanna, we wouldn't appreciate them as much.The older I get (I'm 68), the more I'm interested in the last stages of life, not just how I'll deal with infirmity (should I last that long), but what I'll leave behind, what's left undone, will my husband and kids and friends know how much I loved them.With that in mind, McCorkle's book is comforting. The residents of Pine Haven haven't crossed all the t's and dotted all the i's. They're living and dying the best they can, and that's all any of us can hope for.The book was a joy to read and I was glad to know these people.  All of them were interesting and well-done. You won't need the chapter headings (character names) to know who you're with. They're individuals and their voices are unique. I wasn't bored for a minute and wanted more at the end.  I can't ask for more than that in a book.

I selected this book because I'm interested in the post WWII time period, all the change and growth, the rise of labor unions, the influence of organized crime. I also enjoy mysteries, true crime stories, and the experiences of immigrant families. So this book was quite a trifecta for me.It's based on the real life story of two brothers who emigrated from Ireland, worked hard, and found success.  Older brother Charlie becomes Mayor of New York City after WWII. Younger brother Tom becomes a District Attorney.  The brothers are close, but they move in different circles and they don't share the same politics. Tom becomes involved in the labor movement, while Charlie courts the city's movers and shakers.Then comes a crackdown on organized crime, and a mob informant, under heavy police guard, manages to fall out a window and die. Tom is sure the man was murdered, and that his brother knows the truth.The story moves back and forth in time from pre-war NYC to 1953 in NYC and Mexico as Tom investigates the man's death. Baker evokes the places and the people (big and small) with rich detail.  The behind-the-scenes look at the politics, the games, the deals felt authentic.I would give the book 5 stars, but for the subplot of Tom's affair with Charlie's wife. Their scenes didn't feel real, but were more like something from a 50's melodrama. Maybe Baker added it to make Tom more human, more nuanced, give him a fault, keep him from being "too good".  Tom's character needed to be fleshed out.  He's more of a witness than a participant.At the end, I felt more connection with the places, and with the minor characters, than with Tom and Charlie.  Charlie was weak and ambitious, Tom had convictions but no strength. Neither are likable, which can be fine in a novel, but they needed to be fleshed out.I can find no fault with Baker's writing style though -- clean and gorgeous at the same time. I felt like I was there, and I feel that I have more of an understanding of that time and place.

I wasn't sure that stories this short could have much of an impact, but they do.  It turns out that we don't need a hundred pages of build-up to make a satisfying read.  Many of the stories left me wanting to know what happened before the story started.  With those, I made note of the authors' names so I can be on the lookout for their full-length works.The collection has a nice mix of suspense, comedy, and a little bit of horror.  With some, you can see the end coming -- "Aha! I know where this is going!"  That doesn't diminish the thrill. Some of the stories made me smile, some had me going "ewww".This would be a great collection to have on an e-reader.  Read for a few minutes, and when your number comes up at the DMV, you don't even have to mark where you left off.Highly recommended, lots of fun.

The writing style is Young Adult/Tween, which doesn't match some of the very adult subject matter.  It's too simple -- this happens and then this happens.  There's no depth to the language or the characters.  The reader is left with nothing to think about except what happens.  But a lot happens, so if you're in the mood for story, the book will satisfy.William is separated from his mother when he's five years old.  He spends the next seven years in a Catholic orphanage.  On a yearly outing to a movie theater, he sees a photo of Willow Frost, a singer/actress who William believes is his mother.  With his friend Charlotte, who is blind, he leaves the orphanage to find his mother.The story then switches to Liu Song/Willow Frost.  I thought the simple style might change when the story moved to an adult's point of view, but it didn't.There's a fairy tale/fantasy quality to the story, orphan boy with a plucky friend, Willow Frost as Cinderella complete with evil stepmother, bad people trying to hurt them, good people showing up at opportune times to save them -- lots of melodrama.If this is something that appeals to you, then you'll like Songs of Willow Frost.

This is the memoir of a young man whose mother was murdered by her fifth husband.  Nine days after the World Trade Center attacks, Justin's mother Debbie was shot dead in the trailer she shared with her ex-cop husband.  Justin was twenty.  Debbie was in her early 40's, an intelligent, strong, creative, hard-working woman with a history of success at everything but marriage.It's a common enough story -- husband murders wife, happens every day.  What makes this memoir uncommon is Justin's unflinching honesty, about himself as well as his mom.  There were times when he had some decidedly uncharitable feelings about his mom, and at the risk of sounding like an immature little s***, he shares those feelings. Speaking ill of the dead? Yep, he does that. But when he talks about the love his mom had for him and his older brother, you know he's not shining on.  He knew she loved them and that she did the best she knew how.  Still, he doesn't make a martyr of her, or of himself.  They both had flaws.The other reason I so liked this book was because of how well Justin describes his survivor experiences, dealing with relatives, reporters, detectives, support groups, trying to restart a life after such a traumatic event, and trying to figure out why it happened. I think knowing what he went through could be helpful to someone working their way through such a loss.The side story about Tombstone and the Gunfight at the O.K. Corral -- I'm not sure how I feel about that.  I suppose it ties in to the gun culture and the frontier, lawless atmosphere of that area.  Would Debbie have been shot if she and her husband had settled in Des Moines or Minneapolis?  I can't say, but I think yeah, probably.All in all, very satisfying and well-written.

Memoirs involving the extremes of family life and human behavior can be riveting, but there's a lot to be said for exploring ordinary families.  There's no incest, adultery, treachery, or murder in Lee Sandlin's memoir of his Midwest family.  Instead we're treated to a couple of small but intriguing mysteries: Why are great-aunts Hilda and Helen, great-uncle Eugene, and Hilda's husband Marty growing old together in the family home, and why do they never share anything from their pasts?Most families enjoy nothing better than talking about "the good old days", sharing stories of their youth, regaling the kids with their travels and adventures, passing down lessons learned.  Not in this house.  Oh, the young cousins who spent their summers in the family home got lessons, but the main one was "Don't talk about yourself."Sandlin makes that clear in the prologue -- the elders didn't share personal information -- it just wasn't done.  Lucky for Sandlin and for readers, he manages to flesh out their lives, beginning with GGG-grandparents who emigrated from Germany in 1850.  Sandlin traces the ups and downs of the family fortunes -- nothing spectacular but typically American.  He takes us through most of the 20th century, and it could be the history of any family. The daughter who never married, the son who went to war and came back changed, the unhappy marriage that lasted until death -- it's all so ordinary but so fascinating.Sandlin's prose is clear and precise and descriptive.  The book is full of everyday details that bring to life the time and place.  While he may have been puzzled by his reticent, sometimes cold relatives, it's clear that they were loved.  Well, except for great-uncle Marty, maybe.I'd recommend this to anyone, especially if you grew up in the Midwest in the mid-20th century.

I've enjoyed Franklin's three other novels -- all with different subjects but all with a deep understanding of the people and places he writes about.  I wasn't sure if this one would be different, what with having his poet wife as co-author.  Would the clean prose style change?  Would there be a plethora of unnecessary adjectives, flowery language, etc.?  (That shows how much I know about modern poetry -- which is nada.)Not to worry.  Franklin uses the Great Flood of 1927 as a backdrop to a fast-paced novel about revenue agents, moonshiners, and an abandoned baby.  The characters are believable, the dialogue is realistic, and Franklin's description of the flood and its aftermath had me holding my breath.I'd recommend this both as a thriller (of sorts) and as an historical record of the flood and what came after.

"Too much action" isn't a common complaint when I'm reading an adventure novel.  But when the action leads nowhere, or goes in circles, I'll complain.  Laurence and Temeraire and their friends and foes are all over the map here, literally.  They don't stay in one place long enough for the complicated plot to make any sense.Further, Novik introduces some potentially interesting characters in Kaneko and Junichiro, but never makes us understand their motivations. Kaneko is pledged to help a stranded traveler but then he has to kill himself or fight a duel with him?  What's that all about?And the amnesia?  Puh-leeze.  Amnesia -- especially such selective amnesia as what Laurence had -- it's a crutch and like a crutch, it should be used just for a short time.  This went on too long.I loved the first four books, was okay with the next three, but this one was a disappointment.  Three stars though, for short passages that reminded me why I love the series -- it's all about the bromance between Temeraire and Laurence.

I'm not tech-savvy at all so was glad to see that there were only three items in the box -- the router, the cable, and the power adapter.  The instructions were basic and easy to follow, both for connecting the router and setting up the network.  I appreciated that there were two options for the setting up the network -- manually and using WPS on my Kindle.  I'm using Windows 8 so it was easier to set it up using WPS and my Kindle.I haven't noticed any difference in download speed from my previous router (Medialink), but that's fine with me.  All I need is something that works.I also like the Netgear Genie App.  It's clean and easy to navigate.

That's about all a baker needs, isn't it?I worried that a cake would stick because all I had to grease it with was vegetable oil.  With other pans, sticking has been an issue.  Not with this pan -- not even a crumb left behind.The plastic lid is also sturdy and fits tightly.  The raised part of the lid means that frosting won't stick to the cover.I'm finding that cakes are getting done on the low end of the time estimate. If the recipe says 25-28 minutes, test at 25, or even 22.

I use this on the vegetable garden, and appreciate that it can be used up until harvest.  I also use it as an ant-killer.  I appreciate nature -- even insects -- but when they get inside the house, or too close to the house -- they gotta go.I especially appreciated the spray when it was time to pick tomatoes.  Whenever I'd jostle the plant, clouds of tiny white insects would fly up.  I have no idea what they are, but they were annoying.  So I'd spray an hour or so before it was time to pick, and I didn't have little white insects all over my face.

With some stamped cross-stitch blocks, the X's are too pale, too faint, which can be hard on the eyes.  This one doesn't have that problem.  The X's are quite dark and easy to see.You'll need 14 skeins to finish the 6 blocks -- 14 light and 6 dark.  I wish sellers would include thread requirements in the product description. It'd be helpful when you want to shop for thread at the same time you shop for the blocks.The instructions are easy to follow, although they're not really necessary, since you can see by the photo which color goes where.If you're new to stamped cross-stitch, don't do what I did with my first kit, many years ago.  I thought the fabric was too stiff so I washed it.  Washing it removes the stamped design.  Live and learn!

The pitcher is sturdy plastic.  The lid fits tightly -- if you want to shake your lemonade instead of stirring it, it won't splash or spill.  The lid can be adjusted to seal, pour, or sieve.  It makes a full two quarts without having to fill to the brim.The pitchers were wrapped in plastic and shipped in a sturdy box.  Good value, as with all Rubbermaid products I've used.

The sixth Ethan Gage adventure is my first.  I chose it because I love the Aubrey-Maturin novels by Patrick O'Brian and the Temeraire series by Naomi Novik -- also set during the Napoleonic Wars.  I was a bit apprehensive that this was sixth in a series, but as it turned out, I didn't need to be. Like other good writers of series books, Dietrich gives enough background so the reader isn't lost and confused.  I do wish I'd read the earlier books -- if they're as good as this one, I've been missing out.The writing is brisk and witty, peppered with appropriate quotes from famous people Ethan Gage has known -- most notably, Benjamin Franklin.  There's plenty of action, on the fields of battle as well as in the drawing room. Ethan is smart and competent, but not too smart. He has a high opinion of himself but it's mostly well-deserved -- I quite like him.My only complaint -- and it's more of an observation than a complaint -- is that there's very little tension.  For a novel set during such perilous times and with characters in such precarious situations, the survival rate is astounding.  I have little fear for Ethan and his family and friends, or even for his enemies. It's almost as if Dietrich doesn't want to abandon the characters and relationships he's created.  I can't really blame him -- the characters are wonderful and I enjoy reading about them.

I've been pleased with other Febreze products so was glad to see a carpet powder product.  I've used other carpet powders and the scents are too strong.The big test for this product was a corner of the living room, where an old much-loved cat had a few accidents.  Cleaning the carpet (Bissell machine and carpet cleaner) and enzyme cleaners and vinegar solutions would help for awhile, but I noticed that if the temperature and humidity were just right (summer), the odor would come back.  I'll replace the carpet someday, but in the meantime, the Febreze powder seems to be neutralizing the odor.I use it every time I vacuum, and there's no lingering scent of any kind.  That's what I want.

I was curious about "fangipani".  It sounds like an Italian dessert or a tropical fruit, but nope, it's a plant, in the plumeria family.  The scent is lightly floral, very pleasant. It lingers, but not for too long.It lathers nicely -- better than other brands I've used -- and doesn't dry my skin.

I chose Terro because it's the only product that solved my son's ant problem.  He lives in the Pacific Northwest, and I've seen ants crawling in a line on a wall in his kitchen.  He put out a Terro trap and the ants were gone overnight, and they stayed gone.I live in Iowa, and don't really have much of an insect problem -- our winters are too harsh.  But in spring and summer, we'll get tiny little gnats.  This season, they chose to hang out on the back door, on the inside of the door.  I sprayed the glass and the Terro killed the gnats on contact, but within a couple days, they were back.  So I'm questioning the residual effect.  If I have to spray every day, this product isn't much better than any other.I'll use it again in the fall, when the Asian lady beetles and the box elder bugs show up, and I'll hope for a better result.  If I can kill those buggers before they get inside, I won't mind spraying every day.One plus is that it didn't leave a messy film on the glass of the door.***Revising my review -- the gnat population has gradually decreased after two sprayings.  I haven't seen any for several days.  It could be a seasonal/weather/temperature effect, but I suspect it's the Terro, doing its job.Updating to add that I've been spraying the metal pole where we hang a hummingbird feeder.  Since I started doing that, there haven't been any earwigs in the nectar.  Before, we'd have earwigs almost immediately after filling the feeder.

Although the 1960 movie starring Robert Mitchum and Eleanor Parker was quite good, it raises questions about the actions of the characters.  As is usual, the book expands on the characters and explains their motivations.The Hunnicutts are Wade, landowner, legendary hunter, and womanizer, much admired by everyone except his wife Hannah, the ultimate martyr.  Son Theron idolizes his father and loves his mother.  When the story begins, Hannah has died.  Her coffin is taken to the graveyard, where three gravestones stand.  The stones mark the dates of death of all three Hunnicutts -- the same day, fifteen years earlier.  She's been dressed in a sequined gown from the 1920's, and in the coffin are written instructions that she be buried without ceremony.  Her grave had been dug years before but has to be cleared of leaves and branches.So you're hooked right there.  How did Wade and Theron die?  Why was Hannah's date of death the same as the others?  Why the sequined gown?The novel is set in a small town in Texas but could be a small town anywhere.  Humphrey gets everything right.  There's enough plot to keep readers interested, but it's more of a character study, focusing mainly on young Theron.I'd recommend it for readers of any age.  There's no explicit sex, violence, or language, and it's an excellent picture of life and morality in the 40's and 50's.

In The Shining Girls, we meet serial killer Harper Lewis and Kirby Mazrachi, the only one of his victims who survived his attack.  The story begins in 1931, when Harper stumbles upon an abandoned house, a house through which he's able to travel through time.  Harper has already been shown to be no stranger to self-serving violence, and the house allows (encourages?) him to feed his need.Harper chooses his victims by their "shine" -- they're special, if only to him.  He visits them when they're young, leaves them a memento, and tells him he'll be back.I almost didn't choose this book.  I don't like violence, blood and gore.  There's a lot of that in this book, but it's not gratuitous.  While I was reading it, I thought back to Stephen King's short story, The Body, the story on which the movie Stand By Me was based.  There's a set piece in the story.  One of the kids tells of a pie-eating contest that ends with everyone vomiting.  That's gratuitous -- writing for effect, to cause a reaction.  Beukes doesn't do this.  Her descriptions of the murders are effective -- we feel the victims' fear and horror, but it doesn't feel voyeuristic.The pacing was just right -- moments of terror followed by breathing space, and even some humor.  My only quibble is that I would have liked to know more about Kirby's recovery -- she seemed almost dissociated from what happened to her.I'm not sure I understood the ending, but I was satisfied.  I'm a big fan of time travel fiction, and this one is in my top ten.

Or True Blood meets Homeland!  This sequel is just as much of a mash-up as the original (Niceville).The story has a little bit of everything and it's all entertaining, thanks to Stroud's ear for dialogue, a pace that never flags, and realistic characterizations.  There are good guys and bad guys, good cops and bad cops, real ghosts and ghostly shadows, a bottomless pond, and bad deeds from the past that bleed into the present.The focus is young Rainey Teague, the boy from Niceville who disappeared from a sunny street after looking into a mirror and who turned up ten days later, alive, in a sealed crypt.  Something wants to be reborn in Rainey, and it's up to his guardian and her cop husband to prevent it.Along the way we revisit the players in the bank robbery from the previous book, and meet a few new characters, just as deadly, and just as interesting.  I especially like that Stroud's evildoers (some of them anyway) are almost likeable.Some of the story threads are concluded here but Rainey's story isn't finished.  I'm looking forward to the final installment.The story is safe for readers with delicate sensibilities.  There's a lot of violence but it's not gratuitously gory, and there's no explicit sex or bad language.

Actually, there's more than one implausible premise in Boyne's wonderful book.  The first is that a peasant boy is plucked from his village in 1914 and taken to St. Petersburg to live with the imperial family, the Romanovs.  The second is that he acquits himself quite well.  Despite having no formal education and no contact with anyone outside his small village, Georgy is well spoken, intuitive, courteous -- never a false step while living in the royal household.  He becomes a confidant not just of two of the royal children but of the Tsar himself. (The third implausible premise is for the reader to discover -- I won't spoil it.)I think the historical aspect of the story is simplified, but then Boyne's purpose isn't to tell the story of the ill-fated Romanovs, or the Russian Revolution.  It's a love story -- not a romance -- and as a love story, it's very well done.The story moves back and forth in time, and this movement provides the only real tension in the book, since we all know how things turned out for the Romanovs.If you can get past the implausibilities and accept the story for what it is, you'll be rewarded with a fascinating (but simple) inside look at life in that time period.  It can almost be read as alternate history, or as a fantasy (farmer's son fights the evil wizard).This is only my second Boyne novel, but I expect I'll read them all.

When the story starts, Scott McGrath, an investigative reporter, is on the skids professionally because of a television interview.  McGrath had become interested in the films of cult horror director Stanislas Cordova, and that led to an anonymous phone call from a man who told McGrath that Cordova "does something to the children."  McGrath became convinced that Cordova was a child predator, and he said so on national television.  Lawsuit. Career over.Five years later, Cordova's talented and beautiful daughter Ashley is found dead at the bottom of an elevator shaft in an abandoned warehouse.  Suicide?  Apparently so.  McGrath's interest is reawakened.  He revisits the material he'd gathered before and sets out to find whatever he can about the reclusive Cordova.  He's assisted by Nora and Hopper, two young people whose lives had been touched by Ashley.  The three of them try to piece together Ashley's last days.  They'll meet others who knew Ashley and who knew and worked with her father, and for me, meeting Cordova's people was the best part of the book.What was missing -- and what made me want to put the book aside several times -- was tension.  I was almost finished with the book before I started to care how it ended, and my caring was mainly curiosity about how Pessl would wrap things up.  The three searchers were invested -- they had to know what happened to Ashley and why -- but I really didn't care one way or the other.  I was curious, but that was all, and that's not enough.I was left with an empty feeling, like I'd been on a roller coaster ride, but one that had a very slow rise to a peak that was never more than a few feet from the ground.That said, Pessl's writing is fine, not overdone, her metaphors are apt, the dialogue is realistic.  A hallucinatory scene toward the end of the book was very well done.

That's how Jon Stewart described the book, when Mr. Packer was a guest on The Daily Show.  That comment, and Mr. Packer's wit, enthusiasm, and articulateness convinced me to try the book.I don't read much non-fiction, especially the socio-political variety.  It seems that most of these books -- the ones on the best seller list anyway -- are written by people with an agenda.  I don't want to be proselytized -- I want to be educated, and equally important, I want to be entertained.  Mr. Packer's book does this.I was most intrigued by Tammy's story.  Tammy is from Youngstown, Ohio, and she lived through the demise of the steel mills and the loss of thousands of good jobs, the destruction of a once vibrant community.  I worked in a factory for twelve years.  I wasn't on the assembly line but my job put me close to people on the shop floor, as well as management and the union.  Packer got all of that exactly right.  The factory where I worked closed two years ago, 2000 jobs lost in a small town.  Even though the plant was profitable, the owners saw fit to move operations to Mexico.Because he got Tammy's story so right, I have to assume the other viewpoints are equally accurate.  Connaughton's experiences in Washington were enthralling, and depressing.  I've never been so deep inside our political system.  Can we just throw them all out and start over?Readers who are more astute than me will find more to analyze in the book than I did.  But even for an average person, like me, who hasn't paid a lot of attention or who doesn't understand why we are where we are, this book will go a long way toward that understanding.  The writing is clear and compelling, and the people are fascinating.

The Son is the story of three members of a family that settled in Texas beginning in the 1830's and continuing to the present.  Meyer focuses on three outstanding members of that family:  Eli, the first white child born in the territory, captured in a Comanche raid when he was ten; Peter, Eli's son, a disappointment to everyone, including himself; and Jeanne Anne, Eli's great-granddaughter, born too late, who might have been happier if she'd been a male.All the praise for this book is well deserved.  I've read many novels set in the American West -- novels that romanticize and novels that wallow in the violence.  Meyer doesn't romanticize and he doesn't wallow.  He relates the story of the McCollough family with all their strengths and flaws, and they have plenty of both.As historical fiction, this is the best kind.  There's no unnecessary exposition -- Meyer doesn't explain, he shows.  This makes the book feel contemporary, like it was written by someone living in that time and place.  There is a lot of story in this book -- adventure, risk-taking, power-seeking, revenge.  I wasn't bored for a second.  There were scenes that made my heart ache, and Meyer wrote them beautifully.  There's also fun and humor, and some interesting tidbits about actual people, although they're not always named.  I chuckled at Jeanne Anne's encounter with a famous novelist.The story moves back and forth in time but it's not difficult to follow, and the story is well-suited to that structure.  If it had been told in a linear fashion, the revelations at the end wouldn't have had such an impact.  Meyer's writing style is clear and his dialogue is realistic.  He treats his characters and his readers with respect.I can't recommend this book enough.

Young Victoria McQueen escaped from Charlie Manx, who "rescues" children from "bad" parents and takes them to Christmasland.  Years later, Manx kidnaps Victoria's son.  Plot in a nutshell.I was relieved when the book began with Charlie in prison, and in a coma.  Whew!  He was caught. He can't hurt anyone now.  That was a clever way to start the story, giving the reader a feeling of safety, all's right with the world, it's okay to relax.  Story over?  So soon?  Nuh uh.Joe then takes us on some rides, with Victoria as she uses her magic bridge to find lost things, and another with Charlie Manx and Bing Partridge, Manx's henchman, as Charlie seeks revenge.  Along the way we get to know Vic and her family, and her friend Maggie Leigh, another young woman with a magical ability.The book is long but not unnecessarily so.  I can't think of a single scene that should have been left out.  Everything adds to the story, to characterization, to atmosphere. There are no plot holes -- everyone behaves logically, for them.  The ending is extremely satisfying.  (Read the Note on the Typeface at the end, after the Acknowledgements.)I was almost scared off from reading this book because of review comments about explicit violence against women and children.  I'm glad I decided to see for myself.  The evil of Charlie Manx and Bing Partridge had to be described, and Joe managed to do this without making it feel like a wallow.  Throughout the book, he showed sympathy for the victims -- more than what we see on the evening news.

I've used this for about two weeks, and am noticing that my skin does feel more firm.  Since I don't have access to whatever tools clinicians use to measure skin hydration or diminution of lines and wrinkles, I can't speak to that -- yet.  Time will tell, but the fact that my skin feels different makes me optimistic.The cream isn't heavy or greasy.  It absorbs instantly and leaves no residue.  I don't use foundation or powder. Someone who wears makeup might see a different effect.  The scent is so light as to be almost unnoticeable.I'm almost 70 years old, so any product that makes an improvement in my skin -- even if it's just the way it feels -- well, that makes me happy.

This bird "water cooler" is cute, and it's well-designed.  I like that the manufacturer made it with a handle grip -- easy to hold while filling, easy to carry.  The bottle is about nine inches tall and it's sturdy plastic.  It couldn't be easier to fill and use, and I'm hoping the birds like it.We also have a standing bird bath/water feeder.  It's heavy (made of concrete), and has to be moved when we cut the grass.  It also needs to be cleaned every single day.  If the birds come to this hanging feeder (and why wouldn't they?), I think I'll re-purpose the other one, maybe use it for a planter.UPDATE:  While waiting to figure out where to hang the feeder, I set it on the ground under the oriole feeder, and the orioles are drinking from it.  I might just leave it there.  We have an unusual number of orioles this spring -- counted ten at one time today, so we're getting a second oriole feeder.  Aren't birds fun?

I've read a lot of books about slavery but this was a new setting for me.  I was surprised to learn that the South African government imposed rules to protect slaves.  I wasn't surprised to learn that the rules weren't followed.  Somehow, the institution of slavery is made even more despicable -- that people in power recognized that the slaves needed protection but still allowed slavery to exist.I enjoyed most the chapters from Philida's point of view, especially when she relates the stories she grew up with, the myths and folk tales from her childhood.  She's observant and her observations are a joy to read.  The POV chapters from Cornelis and Francois were technically easier to read but more difficult because these people were less honest.This isn't a quick read, and for me at least, it wasn't a "can't put it down" kind of book.  Some parts move smoothly while others needed a more careful read.  And a map would have been helpful.  I never got a clear sense of where people were, and since there's so much traveling in this book, a map would have helped.

What a marvelous book.  Two mythical beings arrive in New York City in 1899, the Golem newly created, the Jinni just released from a thousand-year imprisonment. I didn't know what to expect and worried that this might be a standard fantasy romance. Nope. It's about living in a new world, free will, responsibility, control, hope, sacrifice, ambition, God, fear -- all that good stuff.A Golem is a slave, strong and indestructible, without a will of its own.  Otto Rotfield wanted rabbi Yehudah Schaalman to make him a wife, and asked that she have intelligence and curiosity.  Schaalman made the Golem and turned it over to Rotfield with written instructions on how to waken it and how to destroy it.  Rotfield boarded a ship for America, with the Golem in a box in the cargo hold.  He wakens the Golem during the voyage but dies shortly after.  The Golem arrives in New York alone, newborn in a new world.The Jinni likewise wakes in a new world, in the typical way a Jinni wakes - by being freed from a container.  He has no memory of who imprisoned him or how long he's been asleep.The first part of the story has us following the Golem and the Jinni as they adapt to living with people, hiding their true natures.  But the Golem and the Jinni weren't the only characters who had to adapt.  Their existence affected the lives of everyone they encountered, and it wasn't always for the better.  They helped and they hurt, they were thoughtful and thoughtless, responsible and careless - just like ordinary human beings.  They fight against their natures, just like "real people".The real people in the story are just as interesting as the two supernatural creatures, and they all have a reason to be in the story.  And there's plenty of story.  The Golem and the Jinni are pursued by a powerful man who knows what they are and has his own uses for them.Wecker's prose style is clear, simple, and smooth. It's almost too readable.  I'm a fast reader but decided to slow down, to more fully appreciate her word choices.If there's any justice, the book will be a huge hit.

Easy to assemble, just three pieces -- a two piece handle and the cleaning head.  The two parts of the handle screw together -- it did take some muscle to get them tightly together -- and the head just snaps on.I've used this every day in the week that I've had it.  I've used it on carpeted floors and bare floors.  It's especially effective on bare floors.  With other vacuums, even those with a bare floor setting, stuff sometimes shoots out the side.  Not this one.It seems to have plenty of power -- it picks up small rocks with no problem.  The 40-minute runtime is accurate.  I've used it at least that long and haven't had to recharge.What I really like is that it will lay flat, which allows me to get under things that I used to have to move.  What I don't like (and this is probably standard with stick vacs) is that the smaller head means more passes to cover a floor.  For this reason, the Rowenta will be my spot pickup cleaner.  I'll still use the big vacuum prior to shampooing, or when I have to vacuum the entire floor.The only reason I don't give it 5 stars is because of the price.
