Written Japanese is extremely difficult-believe me, I'm learning it-and the cultural nuances that are not voiced are very difficult to notice unless you already know Japanese. Thankfully, there are footnotes where necessary to inform you of things you should know, such as events in history or why a characters is speaking a certain way and WHY that is important. Methiliel truly deserves so much more attention for this and I cannot thank her enough.Now, the ROMANCE! XD In Japanese culture, PDA and such things are not so common. It's embarrassing and not done in public, so it is a HUGE deal when two character's set up as potential love interests touch someone-not in a dirty way, you dirty minded people! ;)-or let them cry on their shoulder, or speak in a tone too familiar or call them by their first name. Imagine calling your professor or boss by their first name without a title suddenly and without having known them for long. That's pretty awkward, so when Japanese people call someone by their first name, that's a HUGE deal. It basically implies that the speaker sees you as a true friend-or more than a friend-and is hoping that you as well reciprocate and will become more familiar with them. Sort of. It's really complicated but all you need to know is that this is a monumental thing. As such, there was no kissing in this book, but dear lord that sexual tension was enough to nearly set my computer document file on fire. They needed to do this. And I almost thought it would happen.Thankfully, what romance there is, is subtle and in no way overrides the plot. The characters all have a part and grow, and characters you think you will hate end up becoming better than you thought.My only complaint is that after I finished, there was no ending like in the movie. What!? Yep, I honestly believe the movie was better in the last part. As great as the original work is, this is one of those rare cases where the movie did something better than the book. We had this huge showdown. I thought it was going to happen because of what happened near the end, but nope. If you want a REALLY well done fight scene that has romantic tension, a kickass female protagonist, and a real sense of danger, see the ending part of the movie.

On my Goodreads:The blossoming love Izark and Noriko have for each other grow and we see the ups and downs to their relationship. Izark is anxious and overprotective and Noriko can't bear to part from him. And this all ties in to their past experiences so well that it makes this completely believable.After staying at a little village, the Seer declares that the evil is moving. Without hesitation, the two leave and are soon attacked by Keimos. And Keimos not only is stronger, but something terrible has consumed him.Lord Rachef has finally made his move. Whilst displaying animal cruelty, good looks and a stylish side ponytail, he traps Izark in a battle with Keimos. Izark tries to protect Noriko but she is taken away and when Izark catches up, new revelations are made.One of Lord Rachef's own appears as though he will betray him after the inhumane slaughter of the Chimos and Gorya replaces Tazasheena as Lord Rachef's personal Seer, much to her dismay.The fight scenes were well done. So well done in fact, that I started to think maybe this series was a shounen. The panels were fluid and sharp, with minimal monologues and just enough of everything to set the tone.Noriko doesn't shy away from violence either, ready to pounce on Tazasheena in order to escape. Unfortunately, it seems that Noriko has nowhere to go, for Izark is 16 miles away in Mt. Purple Spirit fighting for his life-and for Noriko. Yet, Noriko might just save him.

If you love Kpop, other cultures, hate racist characters, and want a very well done book about a girl who moves to Korea and gets involved with a hot guy and the Kpop industry...please look elsewhere. I hate giving authors bad reviews. They pour their hearts into writing, but sometimes it has to be done.I am sorry to say that like many others who were so excited about a book like this being published, that this book did not make me happy. I LOVE Kpop! I love reading about other cultures and experiencing the beauty of another culture with our main character...Grace was not the character for this role. I do not tolerate racism at all, so to read about a main character who had her head so stuck in her own little vision of how the entire world should behave sickened me. Yes, she is a teen, but she is still racist. I have provided some lovely quotes for you later on if you would like to see them.Let me begin by saying I really am glad that Kpop is getting more recognition and that the author is a really good writer. However, what she wrote offended me.There were a few good things about this book: The other characters besides our main were likable and had a lot of good to say regarding our main character's racist views on Korea. The writing was well done, and this is about Kpop! That's where the good ends.Our main character, Grace, is a girl who like many, is going through some tough times. To escape these troubles she literally googles a place to move and when she finds Korea she just leaves. She doesn't research anything about the country!!!! And then she begins trashing the Korean culture and trying to force her American ways onto Korea. At first I thought this was a flaw in her character and that she would overcome her mindset and embrace another culture...she did not. To make matters worse, she says a LOT of racist things that I could not believe what I was reading. I want to say that the author was trying to make this a coming of age YA romance, but Grace never matured.She attends a boarding school and obviously being in another country, they would not speak English!! (Or at least, not everyone since English is taught in school.) Grace cannot believe that there is another writing system other than the alphabet and that Korean people can read them. The romance was cute at times (which were seldom), but Grace was unbelievable. She chastises Jason-the love interest-for liking Kpop, calls Kpop a fad and refuses to say anything positive about it.Actual quotes to prove my point about Grace's racist thoughts:“But you think I should make it more like your American music?” he asks. “You say that like it’s a bad thing.”"I can't help but notice the obnoxiously neon READY TO WHERE splayed across her shirt, and I wonder if she thought it was ironic or if this girl has zero concept of the English language.""As we head to the dorms, I think back to meeting Sophie's brother this morning. He said something about a band room. Does that mean people play music here? I mean, normal music, like rap or hip-hop or folk. Or is it only traditional Korean stuff?""I'm not sure what I expected-that they would be good? Pop is the name of the genre. That never bodes well for the quality of the music. But I guess I hoped since they're a big deal, they would be more than your average bubblegum band.""I'm guessing that if you guys are famous like Sophie said, it's mostly based on pretty faces instead of actual quality of music."Grace refuses to acknowledge that any other music besides American music is a thing. She trashes Kpop and mocks it and refuses to adapt to Korea. And get this: Grace is supposed to know a lot about all kinds of music. Yep. Which is why she doesn't think Kpop is music and that all Asian music is just traditional....Not only that, but Grace tries to correct Jason and his band that his music is not American and therefore, not good. If they would only play American music, then they would be hits!!!! Too bad Kpop is a huge thing Grace, because your point is invalid. All music is to be appreciated and if it is not the music you listen to, then try and respect it at the least!!! Jason even yells at Grace and tells her to try and be more sensitive about other cultures! This is why I don't think the author intended to make a racist main character. Yet Grace never grows out of her viewpoints. And Grace takes his advice as an offense. She thinks that what Jason was telling her was that she needed to stop parading America around...are you kidding me?For us k and j-drama fans, Grace once again lends her opinions on the subject. She made me insanely mad. Naturally, getting used to a foreign culture is shocking, but Grace handled it terribly. She criticizes Korean food, the drama, the music, the language, everything that is NOT American. Girl, you signed up for a foreign country...what did you honestly expect?All in all, I really did not enjoy this book. I was so excited to hear a book about Kpop was being published. And then I get Grace and her unbelievable perspective. I wanted a book where a young woman explores another country and comes to embrace it. Instead, I got a book with a racist, closeminded, "white savior wannabe", stereotyping, white girl. As a white girl myself who really appreciates other cultures and loves Kpop and dramas, etc. I was livid. And it was not just because the book dissed Korea. No. This book made me extremely mad. Racism is a terrible thing that should not exist but sadly does. And Grace not only starts out racist, but she ends the book without having changed.I am very sorry if you love Korean culture, or other cultures and dislike racism. If you are one of those people, you might be very angry at the many things Grace says during this book. The only saving grace was the secondary cast who got mad at Grace and tried to get her to adjust her mindset-which never happened-and the writing. Some might be able to look past these ugly things, and I hope that if you still givethis book a chance that you find it much more enjoyable than I did. If you're unsure, maybe try the library. I cannot recommend this book.(One thing I have to say is that Kpop and Korean society is pretty racist too. Now please hear me out as a fellow lover of Korea and Kpop! There is always a darker side to every single country. Korea has it's flaws. And one of them is that Koreans( NOT ALL) are racist to those with darker skin color. Kai from EXO has been give a rough time as have members of SNSD who mocked one of their members for their darker skin. One of my best friend's moved from South Korea to where I go to school, and as much as we love dramas and Kpop and how much I love the culture, she has told me far too many times about this issue in Korea. I am pointing this out because I have been accusing Grace of racism when the same thing is pretty evident in other cultures. I am not bashing Korea, please hear me out. I am just trying to be fair here when I have already bashed on Grace -which should be addressed. Racism is a terrible thing. We are all human beings and respect is something we all need to give to each other. Racism is in every country and it cannot be escaped. However, we can make an effort to change how we see each other for the better. Thank you for your time. I apologize if you did not like my review.)

I received this early from a preorder at Rightstuf. Review is also on Goodreads. Very slight spoilers. I just go a little more indepth than the synopsis does.DISCLAIMER:If you have triggers, please be careful with this volume. Chapter 107 is very controversial and I believe this was handled maturely, but it will make some people very uncomfortable. Nanami is not raped, but she does get assaulted by Kirihito, and it is very hard to read for the few panels that are presented.Nanami has been growing as a character, and as such, I was expecting something to test her greatly. This is one of the darkest volumes Kamisama Kiss has presented. That gorgeous cover I praised earlier before reading disguises a volume that has a very controversial chapter.It begins with Tomoe and Nanami going to school and both of them realizing that in order to become a part of society, your academic standing holds a lot of power of you. This is very true in Japanese culture. Nanami wants to go to her first and last school trip with her class and after Mikage demands that she score 80% on all her tests to go, she studies diligently. We get to see Tomoe's thoughts regarding Nanami which adds a lot to their relationship. And it looks like Ami x Kurama might happen :DThen the volume changes when Nanami leaves with her class. A storm is brewing and their flights are cancelled. When Ami is kidnapped by Unari, claiming that Kirihito has stolen the Robe of Feathers from her, Nanami must agree to return it lest Ami remain a prisoner.Kirihito's life is slipping and he needs to get his body back. With the Robe of Feathers he can do so, but he is dying. He asks that Nanami be taken to him. Only she can help preserve what little life he has left-but in doing so, Nanami will likely die. Nanami is not stupid. She would do what any person would given her situation. She is forced to help him, and from there, the controversial moment I mentioned happens.The way it was handled is to let the readers realize that Kirihito/Akura-Oh is NOT a good person. If you were a fan of him like I was, it finally is clear that he will never change. He is selfish, vain and a brat. And I can guarantee you that this pairing will never happen. I don't understand why fans assume that any forced kiss or something like that means love. That is sexual assault, and the author makes it clear to the reader that this is not something we should be praising in manga. So many shoujo glamorize assault as being love, but this series draws the line. Nanami is not just kissed here. I will not go into details, but if you still ship these two, I cannot agree with you.If he were to start changing his life, doing his best to right his wrongs, etc. then I could consider him in a positive light. In volume 7 we saw that he was dealing with a lot of turmoil and I was invested in him. But he shows his true colors too many times later on for me to root for him.I am so glad that this series is not glorifying harassment or trying to make d-bag guys out to be love interests. This is a great example of a shoujo series that does it right.

Purchased at Rightstuf, review on GoodreadsAh Mutsuki...I really like him. He's the most complex of all the Rose Knights, but it seems the canon pairing is going to be Kaede x Anise.In this volume, we have a showdown to win an "Arcana Card" at an idol competition against Rhodecia. It's obvious from the first meeting with Yako and Idel that they are possible enemies and are up to no good. The way the competition went was just way too unrealistic. Anise and her group have to come up with acts on the spot, instead of practicing for them. I would think that a flyer would be given out before or online somewhere for them to prepare for it, but this is not the case.I won't spoil anything, but Idel and Yako obviously are enemies of a sort and have their own powers. Out of nowhere new enemies just conveniently show up to cause trouble at the perfect moment. And Aya Shouoto is starting to tease readers with many possible romantic pairings. Every knight gets his moment here-except for Tenjo-so if you are dying for some romance between Anise and one of the Knights, here is where that all starts.Here's the thing: I like this manga, but I don't ever think I will come to love it. It's enjoyable for passing time, but really, it lacks that "spark" that most series have that draws you in. Yes, Anise is a good heroine, but the way the plot is thrown in circles along with some poorly placed humor and sudden romantic teases makes me really annoyed. However, this a shoujo series that presents a very addicting kind of story so each volume you read makes you want to keep reading it. The art is absolutely stunning and I really like having this on my shelf. I am glad that this was licensed and I can see why so many fans wanted this released.This is not a serious manga. Earlier in my review of volume 3, I mentioned that this was like Ouran Host Club in that it wasn't trying to take itself seriously. If you are, you will be disappointed. Even if you don't take it seriously the flaws stick out so obviously it makes me wonder at times what the point of certain things are there for.I like the manga, but there are so many flaws. The pacing is all over the place with oddly timed humor and then romantic tension. If Mutsuki and Anise were the canon pair, as cliche as it would be, I honestly believe it would be a good thing for the series. He is a complex character-more so than the other Knights-and his initial dislike for Anise and slow acceptance of her is written well. Not only that, but in this volume he is starting to regain his memories, and it doesn't look like he has the best past. If he and Anise were to get together, they would have a lot of hurdles to jump. And I really want to see that, but unfortunately, Kaede is quickly becoming the love interest.If you are looking for more manga to read that are shoujo or fantasy, or just another series: Kamisama Kiss, Akatsuki no Yona, Requiem of the Rose King, A Silent Voice, From Far Away by Kyoko Hikawa, Horimiya-being released soon, Ouran High School Host Club, Pandora Hearts, Dawn of the Arcana, Library Wars, Noragami, Maid-Sama!, Your Lie in April, Emma, Dengeki Daisy, Orange-just announced to licensed, Skip Beat!

I am in shock. The good kind, because my ship not only set sail, it sailed the flipping world.So Noriko is finally told that "Hey, you know you're the Awakening" and she immediately realizes "Oh...no wonder Izark didn't let me near him. He's been suffering because of me this whole time, but he's been too nice to push me away!" And I was crying along with her because the FEELS were getting too intense.Noriko does the right thing. Izark is rushing to save her from this crazy self serving woman. Mind you Noriko was nearly sacrificed earlier and not only does she get away, but she freaking rushes over and embraces Izark who's gone almost bat-shit-insane. Thank goodness though that for some reason her Awakening powers snapped him out of it. Or the power of love. And don't worry, this is not done in a cheesy way.Crazy woman not only tells Noriko the truth but she intends to capture her. So Noriko goes all whoop-ass on her. She gets away and then BAM Izark runs after her. Crazy woman leaves the scene and Noriko basically tells off Izark for keeping everything a secret-and I agreed with her-and Izark tries to calm her down but he's in the wrong here no matter how you try to say it.And then BAM!! Noriko runs away cuz she ain't got no time for this-let's be honest, I'm sure we all would do the same-and Izark finally mans up and declares his love for her.And the BEST part? He cries!!! Do you know how attractive it is when a man can let out his emotions and be vulnerable? In the US, it's expected that men be men, so NO feelings! Excuse me. We are all human and crying is not limited to the female population.And LOST IN TRANSLATION!!! Yes, I am learning Japanese. No, my Japanese is not the best. However, as I was reading the scans along with my Japanese copy, I noticed some things that made a huge difference in dialog. When Izark is asking Noriko to stay with him and falls to the ground, he says "頼む" pronounced as Tah-No-Moo. This is a literal way of begging someone. So instead of how the translators made Izark say, "Please" Izark was literally saying "I beg of you!" or "I'm begging you!" THAT is so much more romantic.There were other nitpicks I had with the translations, but for the most part, those didn't really affect anything. I just wanted to point out that one dialog choice. I only own the Japanese copy for volumes 7, 9, and 12. As such, I had to find other ways to read those volumes, but I did support the author. VIZ REPRINT THIS SERIES

Dear God, this volume! SO, Noriko discovers that Izark is the Sky Demon (and this is NOT A SPOILER) and says the most adorabley embarrassing thing ever to him that night. Girl has guts. Later, some angst happens when one of the guys, Banadam, starts to make the moves on Noriko. I thought I wouldn't like him but turns out he's a pretty swell guy.HOT DAMN THE SEXUAL TENSION! Izark! We finally get to see more of who he really is. For such a badass, sexy young man, Izark has dealt with a lot of crap in his past. So, he is very anxious and doesn't know how to show a side other than his usual badassery. This volume deals a lot with progressing the romantic relationship between he and Noriko, and I have to admit, I was getting all them feels. Usually when shoujo tries hard to raise tension between two characters, it fails. But this was glorious. I squealed, I got my heart broken, I was yelling "Izark, do something!" and I was engaged.For once, I was not annoyed or angry when the whole "Rescue the girl to stir romance" arc popped up. I was ready for it, and then that last page. Like WTF!? OMG. Now, it's not a bad kind of WTF, but more of a genuinie HOLY CRAP WTF!? because I did not see that coming and like yeah...I'm kind of anxious. But it's super late and I need to sleep but the sexual tension between these two, and the plot and the FEELS are taking over my life right now.And can we take a moment for Izark and his obvious crush for Noriko? Like sure it was angsty as hell and he's soooooo in denial, but I can't help but freak like a fangirl over this. This is everything a shoujo should do. I feel what the author intended and I am shipping these two so hard, fleets will soon join.

Not only is Noriko a great heroine, but the love interest, Izark, is wonderful. He has a bad past but IT WORKS and let me tell you, I cried. When has YA done that to me? When has YA given me a troubled love interest with a dark past and made me FEEL, made me CRY etc? NEVER.So after escaping the White Mist Forest, I realized why I love the protagonist. SHE KNOWS HER LIMITS. She is smart. She knows when she needs to stay out of the way and when to act. This is something every protagonist in manga, books, or movies needs to do. They should use their brains as intended. Noriko uses it, and that's why she is successful and not an annoying character.And the romance!!!! It is not overwhelming or angsty. It is well done and made me shed tears already. As you probably guessed early on (and due to the blurb on the cover spoiling it) Izark is the Sky Demon. His parents didn't just raise him for money and ostracize him like I initially believed. His mother tried to kill him. And she scarred him for life and that's why he's such a precious baby that needs love and omadkgkdgjjg.It's pretty obvious now that Izark is hopelessly in love with Noriko and does not realize it. And after their little scene, Noriko discovers what Izark is, and you know what? She couldn't care less! It's like that scene in volume 6 of Fruits Basket guys. Exactly like that, except this time, there's a kiss scene.And that bonus chapter where we learned more about Izark nearly broke my heart.If you have never read this series, get out there and do so! Unfortunately this series is out of print (so some volumes can be upwards of $100), so I was lucky to purchase what I did. Viz has this on their digital store but I won't say no if you want to read scans. VIZ PLEASE REPRINT THIS SERIES!!!!

Izark is to be pitted against 17 men to save the reputation of Lord Nada, but being the suave badass that he is, Izark simply handles them like a boss. Of course this wouldn't be as awesome if we didn't start to see development with our heroine. And development she gets!Not only is she starting to fall for Izark without even mentioning it (we see her blush several times) but she is becoming even more adept at his language. SO much so, that when they and a group of unlikely allies enter the White Mist Forest and are faced with a terrible monster, she is able to alert the group and stop them from harming each other. Thank God Izark was there though, because poor Noriko would have been pounded into the earth by one of the group since he was losing his cool.Noriko and Izark make a very good team, make great friends, and so far are starting to show feelings for one another. Izark is that quiet and handsome guy that just becomes adorable when he gets embarrassed over Noriko. She messes up with the language as expected, and mistakenly calls him "Honey" when trying to congratulate him in an earlier volume, and since then everyone has been questioning their relationship. He thought leaving her with Gaya was best, but now that he is with her again, you can see that he secretly adores her-or really is dense and does not understand his feelings. Thankfully, the angst is not strong in this series. It's just written that well.Trust me, even if you are stingy about art style, read this manga. It has a very clean and pleasant style for an older shoujo and is easy on the eyes. Though I don't believe you should disregard something because the art may not be your thing until you've read it.

Much shorter because a one shot by the same mangaka was put into this volume.Izark reckons that he must drop off Noriko at a place that he trusts before continuing on with his life. Contrary to what he said earlier, it seems that he now trusts that Noriko won't let it slip that she might be the Awakening, and entrusts her to a friend of his. What follows is a very tear-jerky scene where Noriko thanks Izark for everything but he can't bare to look at her and leaves. Thankfully, we get to see his perspective and this clears up the confusion.Noriko has been in this world for 3 months and has made a HUGE leap in learning Izark's language, which really impressed and motivated me. I am learning Japanese and if I could learn to speak how Noriko could after just 3 months I would be very happy. It works though since she is surrounded by that language and has to learn it to survive and it's a breath of fresh air to see a complex issue being developed.Later, Noriko's caretaker is threatened when politics and stuff get in the way and soon she finds herself needing Izark to help. Too bad he's been taken captive by a Duke. And it seems Izark might be more attached to Noriko than he thought ;)

When was the last time you realized WHY you loved reading? When was the last time a possible couple in a book made you jump and squee and hope they fell in love and became a couple? And when was the last time a book sucked you in-completely?It's better than Vicious. I have read Miss Schwab's other works, The Archived and Vicious but NEVER have I really went WOW!!! Viscous was great-don't get me wrong, but A Darker Shade of Magic made me remember why I love reading so much. It was almost as if I was reading Harry Potter for the first time. It was entrancing, had memorable and loveable characters-but with this book, it had so much more.Schwab's talent has poured through her books, but I truly believe that THIS is the kind of books she needs to write. It seems so Schwab in style and how in-depth the world building was. I LOVED Kell. He has to be the most, suave, charming magician I have read about-think Howl from Howl's Moving Castle-and his relationship with Lila started out rocky to say the least.Eventually they become accomplices, allies and then friends...and TELL ME THEY DON'T HAVE CHEMISTRY. HOLY wow, I was just dying for them to kiss or get together-and I usually can't stand much romance in books because they seem so FORCED and bland and there is no freaking chemistry anywhere.I can't say much if you don't spoilers but what I can say is that this book surpassed the hype it built up. I LOVED IT. I took my time in the book, became a part of the world and felt that feeling of loving reading all over again. I forgot that I had a life LOL. I was so immersed in this book, only my college tests could guilt me out of reading for too long.If you haven't read any of Schwab's works, if you haven't read A Darker Shade of Magic, if you've lost that love of reading, pick up the cure. A Darker Shade of Magic is everything I could want in a book and more. And it just might be the same for you.Although...I wanted Kell and Lila to have more romance but what we did get was good.Keep in mind that this book was more on the action side than character side, but I never felt bored because Scwhab took care with the character's and made them interesting and complex. It was fairly predictable, but it was meant to be that way. Overall it truly was worth the money and the time to read it, and I loved every moment of this fantastic book.From my GoodReads.

On my Goodreads and purchased at Rightstuf:Requiem of the Rose King was one of my most anticipated manga of 2015, and it lived up to my expectations. Based on an early draft of Shakespear's Richard 3, this manga follows the tragic tale of a character named Richard, born into the world an intersex person. Richard is born with both the body of a male and a female, and for this reason, his mother cannot bear to look at him. It would not be an exaggeration to even say she fears and hates Richard, for she purposely abandoned him in the woods where witches are rumored to reside and accuses him of basically being demon spawn. THIS IS NOT YOUR  TYPICAL SHOUJO. THIS IS DARK AND GRUESOME AND VERY DIFFERENT.The story is set in medieval England against the War of the Roses, and our characters are stuck in the middle of it. Here, we follow the House of York and Richard's father, who is trying to take back his crown from Henry Lancaster, a devout Christian. The art is beyond gorgeous, and you can actually tell that the characters are European! The women are not damsels either, especially Queen Margaret, wife of Henry Lancaster. She takes charge of the war for Henry, who is tormented by the sins his soldiers commit.Joan of Arc is twisted into a mischievous spirit, and for those who are religious like me, it would be best if you don't take offense at a lot of the liberties this manga took regarding faith. Saying that, religion is a prominent part of the manga, but it isn't shoved down your throat either so both atheists and religious folk can enjoy the story. Regardless, this was set in a time where religion was a big part of life.For a shoujo manga, this certainly isn't your typical story. We follow an intersex character who is burdened with shame, depression and self-loathing, and a heavy focus is spent on the characters and how they are faring against their situations. The art is absolutely beautiful and I found myself staring at many of the pages for a long time, completely amazed. There were times where it even seemed very Tim Burtony in its style. It's not Vagabond, but it truly stands above most manga in art. If you like witty dialog and politics, strong women and controversial topics, breathtaking art and something new, I highly suggest you give this a try.If you liked: Rose of Versailles, Pandora Hearts, dark shoujo, medieval England, gorgeous art, Tim Burton, you will probably really like this!

From my Goodreads. I received this early from Rightstuf due to preordering this.Kiss of the Rose Princess isn't a shoujo that takes itself seriously. And you shouldn't take it seriously either. Most would agree that as far as shoujo is concerned, most of it isn't something to be taken seriously. Then we get outrageous, pun-filled series like Ouran and Kiss of the Rose Princess that really go far out to make fun of itself, the reverse-harem and shoujo in general. This is the shoujo I like. I want something to make me laugh, recognize cultural puns, and just relax. And most importantly-not have to nitpick the series because it's not trying to do anything to make you go "Wow! So original!"Then we get series like Kamisama Kiss, where the plot and characters are so vital to the series as a whole that I can both relax and enjoy it, but also take a serious look at the development of the series. And for a serious shoujo, Kamisama nails every point. I have no gripes with that series at all. (I am biased, lol).With this 3rd volume, Kiss of the Rose Princess once again tries to make a gloomy and depressing atmosphere only to twist it around and make fun of high school physical exams!! You know, the one where your measurements are taken? Nope? Yeah, only in Japan.And Tenjo steals this spotlight, but of course, this is all for a plan Anise put into action. See, Haruto realizes he needs to stop being a butt, and something happens that I won't say here since its spoilery. Most of this volume has a lot of spoilers I can't really go into, but what can you expect? LOTS OF ROMANTIC HINTS. Seriously. Anise finally learns the details of the "true contract" she needs to make with her Knights and it involves the good old romance present in just about every shoujo reverse-harem ever. But there's a reason for it, so I am not complaining.If you have a favorite Knight, you'll definitely be getting some feels and posting this all over tumblr since Anise looks like she'll be romancing them all. But...it's pretty obvious who her true choice will be.Another funny volume with gorgeous color pages in the beginning. Just don't expect this series to be too serious. Think "Ouran" and you'll most likely enjoy this!

From my Goodreads. I received this early from Rightstuf due to preordering this.I didn't expect to love this series. I never expected such a GREAT ending. Julietta is a GENIUS. This is the ending of the time-travel arc.I have read a LOT of shoujo, but it never hit me in the feels, and I always was annoyed with the heroine. Kamisama Kiss gave me a SMART, SPUNKY, LIKABLE AND ENDEARING protagonist that I wanted to see succeed. And it gave me a love interest that wasn't just the jerk with a heart of gold-he was so much more than that. I adore Nanami, and after seeing the anime-as good as it was-I can honestly say it truly doesn't do the manga much justice.The characters CHANGED and grew and I loved all of them! Even the side characters. I wanted the best for them all, and Nanami did not let anyone trample her. She stood up for herself and kicked butt, which is something rare in shoujo these days:(I never thought the mangaka could pull off such a complex story with ease. And I loved every moment of it. Thankfully, this series is continuing, but it truly felt like a conclusion to the series as we finally learn the secrets as to why Mikage left the shrine, who Nanami is, etc.There's comedy, romance, adventure, action, a PLOT in shoujo!!!! and tons of Japanese mythology. Add in great writing, art and characters, and I was sold. No really I spent too much on this series. BUT THAT's OK! :D

For anyone learning Japanese, it is ESSENTIAL to get the most you can out of what is offered. If you have Genki or Tobira or any textbook, you will eventually come to the conclusion that while they get you started, you are still lacking skills in that language. So what can you do? Pick up Japanese Sentence Patterns for Effective Communication.Unfortunately, this includes romaji right underneath the kana, so if you're trying to break away from that habit, you're going to have a difficult time unless you either cover up the romaji or black them out. If you are going to Japan and have no knowledge of the language, then this is basically your Bible. Take it with you!! Textbooks tend to cover the "polite" form of Japanese, which is nice but when that's all you know, your'e not going to be able to really voice your thoughts on something. This book definitely clears this up. I've had this for about a month now, and already I feel more polished in Japanese.What else can you get to improve your skills? Japanese Graded Readers. I have a review for this, and honestly, they have been extremely helpful! You are given a chipboard box with little books that are in color and written in Japanese. The difficulty goes up with each level and each set comes with a CD so you can follow along with the native Japanese reader. You can also pick up what are considered some of the best manga for beginners: Yotsuba, Shirokuma Cafe, and Chi's Sweet Home. Granted, as easy as they are, this will still be difficult for non-native Japanese. You probably won't get most of it right away, but don't let that deter you! You can do it!What if you don't care for learning from manga? Try a novel by Yoshimoto Banana like  "High and Dry" or pick up a picture book from a Studio Ghibli movie. I got Howl's Moving Castle in Japanese and it's a steep learning curve, but definitely helpful.

THIS is what I needed! I really am striving to learn the language, and when you are faced with reading, it is extremely difficult compared to speaking the language. This is for the ultimate beginner-except you NEED to know your hiragana!!! Kanji is included so you aren't bogged down with endless kana, but don't worry if you can't read kanji, there is furigana!You get 6 very short stories-somewhere around 13 pages each-and they are thin, portable and not too intimidating. The books are bright and colorful, and it's easy to understand most of it purely from context if your vocabulary is poor. The listed recommendations to succeed with these readers is listed on the back: For 0, you should know around 350 vocab and around 400 sentences. I don't use Anki, have only started to study with Genki and at most can read some Yotsubato and Chi's Sweet Home-but not the whole thing. THIS is what I needed.Since I have listened to a lot of music, seen anime and j-dramas, I was able to recognize a lot of the words and since this is very basic Japanese, it was very easy.I can read hiragana and some kanji, but the most difficulty I had was when I didn't know some words. A dictionary like Denshi Jisho is recommended if you need to look up a word.The stories: Sakura, Daizu-about Soybeans, A dad late for work, Ichiro going to school, Yumi and Maria, and the last is about your friendly policeman, Ryou-san, I really enjoyed the last one personally.The CD: can play on your computer. Don't know about the car, but I will update this review when I found out. The readers are native Japanese, and switches between a woman, and a man, and sometimes an old lady or little girl and boy depending on the story. Ryou-san in book 6 spoke very fast compared to the other readers. The voices were clear and I had no time following along.Is the price worth it? YES! Not only did I have fun reading, learning new words and reading out loud along with the readers and on my own, I found out how far in my studies I am. In fact, I felt really smart because I finished all 6 in around 3 hours, but of course the time it takes to complete it will be different for everyone. I happen to be a little more advanced in Japanese than I thought I was, which really boosted my confidence.If your'e taking the JLPT, in school, want to read Japanese, I honestly have to recommend this over Yotsubato and Chi's Sweet Home if you know your hiragana. The CD really helps your pronunciation, the stories aren't too long or too short, and you really feel motivated when you realize how far you have come! If you feel you aren't making much progress, it's most likely that you don't have enough vocabulary, grammar and sentences under your belt, but don't worry! You can only get better!! Highly recommended!!!

From my Goodreads: NO SPOILERSElliot...I am so so so so so sorry...I have no words to express what just happened to him. It was possibly one of the most tragic things I have read about, or seen on tv, or in real life. Death steals so much from you than just that person, and to know that someone close to you might be the cause for your endless suffering...what do you do?We watch how Elliot and Leo met, and it wasn't the best of impressions. But they have worked through their differences, and are no longer the "commoner" and the "aristocrat" or the "valet" and the "master." Despite what Elliot's family thinks of his friendship with Leo, they both care so much for each other. To fangirls of them, I can't agree with this pairing. They are like brothers to me. Or the best of friends.And Reim...oh Reim....Break is frustrated with himself, causing him to hurt others as he tries to make up for what he lost 2 volumes ago, while Oz and Alice are cornered in a dangerous situation.And I am sitting here, begging my characters not to die...2 already have, and yes, they are from the main cast...so NO none of them are safe. Anyone and everyone can be killed, and I just hope my favorites somehow survive.I want all of them to, but it's futile to wish for that, after seeing those people die. Another great volume, but riddled with sadness, death and betrayal.

From my Goodreads: Very slight spoiler for those that have not read volume 11. It's about Break.My heart just cracked.To lose your vision, that is my greatest fear. I rely on it so much, and to have it taken from me, I don't know what I would do. Break obviously has come to care for Sharon, so much more than he himself realizes...and he can never look upon her again. And this ballroom scene, it broke my heart. He realizes he needs to tell her, after faking his blindness, and when he does, he fears it will cause her anguish...and yet, it plays out so beautifully.Elliot accepts Oz as his friend, and shares a touching moment with Oz, while Leo faces his own monsters in the background.And to lighten the mood, Alice and Oz have a moment on the dancefloor.Pandora Hearts is going to ruin me should anything more happen to my characters. I proudly admit to crying during Break and Sharon's moment. I was dreading it, knowing it had to happen...and it was so bittersweet.

From my Goodreads:You know that the main characters are no longer safe when one of them goes blind, one has no idea who they are, and when they all suffer terribly some point in their lives. I am convinced now, that my characters are no longer safe from death, and that is why I am terrified to keep reading.Pandora Hearts has broken cliches in manga. It has put forth a strong emphasis on sticking to the plot as well as forcing the cast to grow up, change and become better people, or worse people than when you first saw them. It makes you see the whole cast as human, and even the ones that make me curl my lip and hope they die a gruesome death, have a painstakingly clear humanity to them.We see how Gilbert received the Raven, how Vincent is preying upon Ada for something we don't yet know of, and that the "Heady Hunter" is back. The Head Hunter was briefly mentioned in volume 3, and since then, has not been spoken of. Everything resurfaces, so when reading, make note of everyone, everything.And ELLIOT!! I knew that something bad had happened to you, that you couldn't escape the fear and loneliness of the cast, and I am sorry that it's true. The Head Hunter is after the Nightray family, and so much misunderstanding has come of it to haunt Elliot after it shattered his family.Sharon is suffering knowing that she loves Break dearly, and is doing all in her power to move forward and help him. She breaks down and cries, and she is human, and seeing her emotions stirs the others to do what they must. Even Reim san cares deeply for Break, and Break himself, the poor soul, feels tormented by his fading presence.I urge you to give this a chance. Pandora Hearts slowly unravels and breaks you apart, but don't worry-it's not all that bad :D

From my Goodreads, NO SPOILERS:Pandora Hearts, essentially, is a love story-of many kinds of love. And it's not a mushy one. It is tragic, dark and filled with violence, self-sacrifice and friendship, romance and betrayal. And it works.This volume, has to be the BEST I have read so far, and that's saying A LOT, since every volume thus far has been exceptional.Love and romance, friendship and trust is basically what Pandora Hearts is. It is a love story.Pandora Hearts is a series where you think you know the answer to something, but you don't. And it's a very well told story. Every detail has meaning, every word, everything, is connected. The characters all are so real, and I have become 100% invested in them to the point that should any of them die, I know I will hurt. All of them mean something to me, and that is something hard to do as a writer. To speak to your reader and make you root for them, even the bad guys...speaking of!!I thought I HATED Vincent-well, I still hate what he did, but WOW talk about character depth! I felt soooooo bad for him, I understood him, and the worst part is, he really wasn't at fault...I am very pleased with how this series has kept up it's superb story telling, art and suspense. It's been a LONG time since I have last become this invested in a series, but that wait has been worth it.

I actually read this book after I read the second installment of this series, Scarlet Heat (Born to Darkness), and I glad I did. It was not horrible, but the heroine at times made it unbearable. There were times that Addison seriously got on my nerves, and I did not understand Corbin's fasciation with her. He truly was a patient individual. My frustration came from her stupidity, or naiveté, and her selfishness. I understood that she felt guilty, but she was not at all realistic of the situation. It is as if she was blind to danger, and did not care the consequences her actions had on other people, i.e. Corbin, and even at times her best friend Taylor.I was able to get a gist of her personality in the second book, but to me this was a full on gust of wind in this one. At times I was like, girl! Seriously! Come on! I understand she had loyalty, but it was as if she had it only for Taylor and herself. A lot of us may not like certain people, maybe even to the point of detesting them, but we still know how to at least fake it. Even if we do not feel like faking it, we know how and when we should. She didn't! Even though she is not real, that is something that I really did not like about her, because she was aware of the stakes when it came to certain people, and it was as if she did not care that she could have ruined Corbin's life, even to the point of him not having one. That was beyond it for me, and therefore solidified it, for me, how much of an unlikeable character she was.Aside from that, the story was nicely written and super easy to follow. To be honest, even though she has great stories I wish this is how Laurann Dohner would write. Even if you do not like certain characters, you can always appreciate the written talent of Evangeline Anderson and how fluidly realistic her style is.

I really liked this installment of the New Species series. Moon is an extremely likable male protagonist who is definitely an alpha male, but is not an overbearing one. Joyce Yard is a likable female character as well, as she did not seem TSTL (too stupid to live) or get on my nerves like some of the female protagonists in previous installments of this series have.I liked reading the friendship between Harley and Moon. We saw that a tad bit in Slade's story, but for me it was the most personal that I have read thus far.I will say that I have noticed something about Laurann Dohner's books that I could not put my finger on, but I now know what it is and accept that it is just something I will just have to get used to. in a majority of the books in this series, I felt that her writing was not as smooth or as polished as it could be. But reading this edition, I noticed that what it is are the constant, back to back questions or statements that characters in her stories will make. To me, I cannot see a real life conversation being this way (especially when it involves those who are supposed to be involved as professionals in specific fields - i.e. doctors). I noticed it especially in Justice and Obsidian's books, though I have read it in a couple others as well. To make it short, there are constant paragraphs where one character will ask question-question-question, or statement-statement-statement. However, it is not read (at least to me) in any type of fluid realism. especially when it comes to those who are supposed to be professionals, I came away surprised at times for some of the questions they would ask. A lot of it was common sense, or did not require a statement of (obvious) observation.Nevertheless, I really enjoyed this book and thought it was a great follow to Shadow's story. To me, it is up there with the stories of Fury, Slade, Tiger and Shadow.

I agree that this game does have a likeness to that of Angry Birds in reference to strategy of game play. However, there is an obvious difference in quality. The graphics are ok, but they are not fabulous. What I wonder about and have an issue with is the mechanics of the game. Though the objective is easy enough, the maneuvering tasks are not. However, all of this was discovered on my first generation Kindle Fire, as playing this game on my Samsung Galaxy SIII was simply impossible, and my patience was limited.I give two stars for the music.

This game is a rip off of two incredibly popular games, but has nothing remotely close to any of the qualities that inhabits those games. This is basically an app of ridiculously lame pictures. Do not fall into this trap and waste your money on nonsense.

It is unbelievable that games such as these are not only able to make their way onto Amazon, but that they are able to stay on the site itself. This game is a rip off of two incredibly popular games, but has nothing remotely close to any of the qualities that inhabits those games. This is basically an app of ridiculously lame pictures. Do not fall into this trap and waste your money on nonsense. You have been warned!

This is such a simple and generic game. I can barely call it a game, actually. Essentially all you do is stand there and shoot at a target. There is no flexibility in movement, and there is no variety at all. Then there are the graphics...Spend your money elsewhere.

This is a very basic app. I cannot even say game, for all you really do is create your own superhero. But you are not even doing that. You start off with Batman, and all you have to do is add parts, or bits and pieces of other superheros into the one in front of you.This seems to definitely be directed to kids, but the options aren't varied enough. Girls can play if they like, but maybe they would not care to design a testosterone laden male one after another. There are female superheros, just saying.Also, I am not for an app with excessive permissions as these. You definitely do not need any access to my contacts, data or wallpaper. A lot of these permissions are just outrageous. Some people elsewhere have also commented that this app started to download apps to their phones or tablet, and I have no idea why a company or developer would think that I as a consumer would intrinsically be looking for.This is not even an app that would be worth it if it were free.

To me this story was all over the place. One thing I believe many who read this genre can appreciate is the length, because to find a story that is almost three hundred pages of this content and this price can be hard to find. But the story itself is something else.Firstly, the story was a little hard to follow at times. I was able to get through it, but some things just did not make sense, in regards to order of occurrence, actions of the main character, etc. Also, there were multiple spelling as well as grammatical mistakes. They were not overly overbearing, but once I kept seeing some of the same errors happening, my eyes were on alert.When it comes to the heroine of the book, Olivia, she was confusing to me a bit, which did not make her entirely likable. Even though she is captured by monsters and "gifted" to one, it seems as if she were more agitated with the few humans that were there instead of the monsters. Some may think under the circumstances she may fear one over the other, but in this situation she had no power at all, but she still felt a way to the humans, and instead did not even think to try and associate with them, or try to level with them so they could see her as a human being as well, and feel sympathy for her.Also, a lot was just not explained for me. How did the few humans get there, and why would they stay? Where exactly were they? What was going on with the portals? Where did they get Olivia's constant inventory of clothing? Then the ending to me felt a little rushed, and which was where Olivia ultimately got on my nerves. I do not want to give it away, but there came a point where she could have been actual help, but all she did was yell and scream; she would not even move out of the way. And then Leo was something I did not expect, and was dramatically rushed.Overall it was ok if this is something you are into, but it could have definitely been structured better so it actually flowed, and emotionally and logically made sense; to me that was not the case.

This game is just like Gingerbread Run, except for the fact that it is a dinosaur instead of a cookie. The graphics are not great, and the controls are even worse. There are even times where the ground is not very clear, so you could be falling off a cliff not because of bad trajectory or your own personal mishap, but because it is hard even telling if anything is there. I am sorry, but I cannot endorse this game. Also oddly enough, this game is free at the Play store.

This app is similar to the likes of Stickman Run, in regard to it being a blatant copy of Temple Run. However, Temple Run is free (besides the themed ones). The icon of this app is cute and crisp, but that does not translate to the actual game. It is very unclear as well as hard to maneuver. I would not recommend getting this game, let alone spending 99 cents to obtain it.*Edited to add*This game was created by the same developer who created Stickman Run. Go figure.

So this game opens up to a pretty interesting rocky background scene with the play menu in the foreground, which has the words play, options, high scores and about vertically displayed. When you click 'options,' you have the choices of changing your username, having the layout be left handed or right handed, customizing the joystick sensitivity, and then change the music and effects volume. Your name has to be six characters or more, however, for it to stick. There are also other things like visual effects and the ability to show hints that you can turn off and on.When you play the game, the decision to choose what level immediately pops up. There are 50 levels in the game; however, all but level one are locked. Each level also has a title, and the title of level one is aptly named "Journey Begins."So basically, you have to guide the ball to exit to complete the level. To move the ball, you put your thumb on the joystick below and slide to desired direction. Again, if you are left handed, you can change the layout within the options view. During gameplay, you can change the camera angle by sliding your finger horizontally around teh center of the screen.Verdict:This game plays great on my Kindle Fire, and I'm sure it will on my S3 as well. At first this game was a little confusing to play, and even though they had a few hints made available, those were only directional in regard to the objective of the game which is to navigate until you reach the next level. You have to play this game as if your Kindle, phone or tablet were a joystick. What I do like is the fact that each tile you are on is lit, so depending on the angle you have on the game it helps in determining where you are rolling, or in regard to the later levels where you are before you gauge the jumping range. I also like the fact that you can change it if you are left handed, which I think not a lot of people think about. Though you have the ability to change the sensitivity in the options area, there is no clear indication labeled to determine each extreme. It is basically a guessing game until you play the game. Even though I messed around with it, the controls were still not easy to utilize at the end of the day.Also, the rounds are timed so when you fall, instead of waiting for the visual to show the ball falling and then going back to the beginning, just click on the screen. That way you are not wasting vital seconds just looking at the screen.It is a good game, it is just the controls that bring it down.

This game is playing great so far. What I appreciate are that the controls are nice, and you get that 3D aspect where it feels like you are flying. That is one of the best parts for me, as it is amazingly fun, and I can see a lot of people gravitating towards this game for that particular reason. The music used in the game is beautiful and very soothing as you try to blast other planes out of the sky. The game itself is very easy to play, but going for all planes can be quite frustrating at times. It is worth the price and a fun time killer.

This train game turned out to be both enjoyable and challenging. It does sort of get a little hard to put down once you get the hang of it. This has the potential for hours (or days) of game play, especially if you are really competitive and would like to try and get a perfect score on each level. The new levels might cost a bit more to unlock, but I do understand the developer's need to generate extra revenue, but at the same time if I purchase this game, why should I have to pay more on top of that? It would be different if, like other developers, the actual game were free, but for unlocking and special attributes, you would have to purchase to obtain those. Otherwise, this is definitely a nice puzzle game. It brings challenge, but still has the ease of fun. Graphics are beautiful and fit the purpose perfectly. Only criticism is that the star rating for levels can be ambiguous. Most levels get 3* for completion, then 1 level is completed but earns 1* or 0*? It does get a tad confusing.

Great graphics, nice turn-by-turn pages, and crisp annunciation and language. This seems like a nice companion to what will surely be another children's blockbuster movie. I think it would be helpful for those who are especially younger to have the text that is vocally spoken to be highlighted at the same time. That way they can visually as well as audibly pay attention and follow along.Otherwise, this will be a great addition for those who have children or younger siblings.

I have previously never played one of these Slender Man games, but I can see that it is supremely popular, and after playing it I can definitely see why. After reading many comments and noticing the overall rating I gave it a go and am extremely for doing so. This is such a great game. I was missing a good spooky game in my collection and this does well. Good clean graphics and fluid navigation. First time through didn't make me jump but audio was spooky, which is nice.

This is a fabulous conceptual app that looks like it would fascinate and intrigue a lot of people, be it children or adults. I would have to say (or rather, write) that this application is more than a simple book reader. The book opens just like a regular book and the voice starts reading the story. After turning a few pages, the book reader stops to present an interaction of what is currently going on to the story; this makes it so the user is not just a passive reader. The user can do some rubbing or will be prompted to answer some questions related to what was just read or shown. I appreciate that this was included in the scheme of the app, because it helps whomever is reading to catch up on what has been going on thus far.

This is really an interesting game, with that I would say an interesting blend of a few other games, as well as basic physic mechanisms. It can get frustrating at times, but the challenging aspect is present which makes this a game that you really desire to beat, instead of one that is so easy that it is a walk in the park and therefore boring.

I wanted to like this antiperspirant as I was under the impression that it was really natural and worth it. I also just wanted to try something different, as I have been using Secret and Dove for years, but desired to try an antiperspirant for a change. But I suppose this just isn't for me. It went on easy enough, but by the time I got to work, I was smelling a little funky. It was not bad, but it was as if I had not put on anything at all. It was a little embarassing, so the next day I gave it another shot, thinking I had not put on enough, and it was the same thing. Considering that I was working a full shift, on one of my breaks I went out and bought a travel size Secret deoderant. I will not give up (yet) on antipersperants, but this one just was not the one for me.

This is definitely a high quality game worth playing! This is definitely going to be a favorite among the lovers of old arcade-type games. It is really retro in that aspect. This is a fantastic space shooter app. The controls are great, visuals and sounds are great, and the gameplay is fun even as you progress. I love the alternate gameplay views. Also, surprisingly there is no I.A.P. So there are lots of levels to unlock by actually playing and not paying! Really well done game.

Seeing this picture for this app brought me nostalgia, for I loved this book as a kid. When I was four this was my favorite book, and I was a bit surprised (though I shouldn't be) that almost twenty years later it is still one of the most popular out there, and has translated into the virtual market.With that being said, there are five levels in this game, level one being the easiest, and then it progressively getting a little more challenging, each one requiring more skill than the other. When you begin the game, there is automatically background music playing and an instructional voice that asks you to get the fruit, and how many times. However, you can turn off both music and voiceover if you like. In each level the number of fruits are also sequential, but from the options menu you can alter that as well, so it will be a random number of fruits instead of going from 1 fruit, 2 fruits, 3 fruits, etc.This game played great on my first generation Kindle Fire with no issues. So aesthetically, this game looks great and matches well with the book. At the end of the day, it is a pretty simple counting game. However, the age range says 'all ages,' but I am not sure if that is super realistic for those in the younger age range. In this game you have to follow instruction (from either the voiceover, written word, or both), and I am not sure how many three year olds have that patience. Also, after you are successfully eating the food, instead of it going to the next crop of food, you have to click the 'done' button. I think this is a good game for those who are, say, four-five years old or up, while parents should probably play with their children who are younger than that, so they can actually get through the game. I'm also not sure if it is worth the original price range, but it is up to the consumer.

What a disappointment. This could have been a great game if the time was taken to actually make sure the game simply worked. The controls are truly horrible; there is no way to adequately aim, nor is there enough ammunition to finish one a level. The game is a good concept but the execution totally fails. I also was not highly impressed with the graphics.I would have given this app at least two stars for the developers creating a game with this concept, but when you are charging three dollars for an unfinished, incomplete game, I cannot have that on my conscience.

I am curious to know if seven years is too long for Justin Timberlake fans, because I know for a fact that many have been feigning for what feels like forever for some fresh, new music from him. Many were upset (myself included) that we were hearing that only ten tracks were on the album, with an additional two if you purchase the deluxe version at target. However, word got out on the 18th of March (via ?uestlove of The Roots, then from JT himself), that more music from the recording sessions will be released later in the year, to complete the vision of the 20/20 experience.Pusher Love Girl - For a quick second, this beat reminded me of something that D'angelo would have used in his earlier music endeavors. I really like the beat and musical arrangement of this song. On the track, Justin sings about how he is so enamored with a certain girl's presence, that he has become "a junkie for her love." I can see this song fitting its way into many genres, and for that reason seeing it as definite single potential.Suit & Tie - I will be honest, I did not fall in love with this song upon release. I still am not in love with this song. I felt as if the inclusion of Jay Z did not mesh well, as they were not complementing themselves at all on this track. To me, it was as if they were on two total different tracks, speaking about totally different things. This songs succeeds in creating an urban-pop record where JT cockily proclaims, "I be on my suit and tie s***... let me show you a few things about love..." I am a sucker for big-band music (horns in the background), but I felt like a lot of different things were experimented in here (the chopping and screwing of the beginning and toward the end, etc). It is not my favorite.Don't Hold The Wall - You can clearly tell that this is a Timbaland production. I was immediately drawn it this song, where he sings about letting yourself go and dance instead of being somewhat the likes of a wallflower and "holding the wall."  This is a track that really allows the beat to be showcased, as singing parts are omitted in a few portions of the song. I immediately gravitated to it in the beginning, but felt like the seven minute song dragged a little bit toward the end.Strawberry Bubblegum - I did not imagine the result of a song titled `strawberry bubblegum' sounding like what I initially thought it would. With a fun and wacky name as the title, I imagined something loud and over the top. This song is surprisingly super mellow and clean. JT sings about loving the taste of his girl, and hoping that she will never change. Now, you can take this song metaphorically, or literally - that is up to you.  Simply put, he is intoxicated with this girl and does not know why but figures he does not need the answer -- he just needs his girl.Tunnel Vision - It seems like this boy is really in love! In this song, he sings about being so in love that even in a crowded room all he sees is one person. He is so gone in love, but it seems as if upon realization that he really is in love, he is a little scared. Maybe scared about being so gone, for he sings that "now that I know the truth, what am I supposed to do?" He can no longer deny it, which he also iterates, for he knows that she already knows his feelings. This is really an interesting song about finally having to come to terms with your feelings and emotions, and being ok with it.Spaceship Coupe - In Strawberry Bubblegum he begins the song by saying, "this song goes out to you, this is dedicated to you,.." while in Spaceship coupe he starts off similarly by saying, "hey, I wrote this song for you." It is a little obvious, but by this time you clearly see that this album is starting to have a certain theme. This song is about being alone with the one you love, just the one you love. He sings of obtaining seclusion with his love, the image of the two of them getting away together in empty space, and enjoying it.That Girl - Back to the big-band-like I was writing about earlier, thanks to JT and the Tennessee Kids. He is proclaiming that he is in love with "that girl" and does not give a damn what the opinions or stares of others are. She is his in love with his number one girl, and is already happy because she already told him that "she's in love with me." For some reason, I felt like this could be an answer to Alicia Key's song Un-thinkable (I'm Ready). Weird, I know, but I felt like these two songs are along the same themes and lines, where they both sing about no longer ignoring what is so obvious to them, and no longer caring what others think. Great song by JT and the Tennessee Kids.Let The Groove In - When I first heard this song, it kind of reminded me of "Señorita" from Justified. There is a lot of repetition that is so stretched in this song that I really did not care for, and he sings about enjoying the groove, and moving like there will be no tomorrow. Maybe this song will do well for a commercial, but I do not see it as one that I will have on repeat.Mirrors - Clearly this song is about the woman in his life, and how she is the better half of him. This is a pretty deep song about finally finding the one who completes you, and how he does not want to lose that person and how no one else could fill that place. He sings, "it's like you're my mirror, my mirror staring back at me." Simply put, he has found his equal in the love of his life.Blue Ocean Floor - This song is really slow, and honestly a little depressing. He sings about being able to understand some one so much, better than anyone else, for they are so in tune with one another that they are on the same "frequency." Nothing can incapacitate that fact, be it man-made or nature bound, is what I'm getting from this song. If you got a different vibe from this song, let me know. It is kind of a quiet song, reminds me of the ending of the movie Inception for some odd and random reason. Needless to say, not a favorite at the moment.I have got to be honest, I am a little confused at what Justin would consider himself music-vise, or what others think of him as. It is obvious that there are r&b related in some of the music he releases, but he is still considered to be pop. He definitely is Popular music, but I see this body of work as vastly different from what is considered as today's pop (i.e. Ke$ha, One Direction, Justin Bieber, whatever the heck else). This is even different (of course it would be) from when he was in his band days. With this album, you seriously see the growth JT has had as an artist, and how he has matured with age and where he currently is in life thanks to his marriage. Huge difference from his Justified days.I am eager to hear the other music JT and Timbaland have in store for us later this year. This is a pretty solid album, but does not get me over the moon excited after a 7 year hiatus from this man. However, there are plenty of songs that will be on my repeat list while I wait out for the completion of this experience. I am, however, if the other (currently unknown number) tracks will follow along the same theme of this album and will just be a continuation, or if it will be in a absolutely different direction.

This is such a class album. Seriously, it is that good, and even in 2013 it is still that good. I remember the cover from the cassette that my sister had purchased in the 90s, and after having to endure this for the upteenth time, I started taking it and listening to it when she was not home. To be honest I did not really understand everything that was going on in this album (in '96-97 I was 6-7), but I could still appreciate good music when I heard it, and to this day that is still the case. Jon B is one of the most slept on artists of all time which is hugely disappointing, but this album will forever be one of my favorites.

What a fun game! If some of you have played Call of Atlantis, this same has eerie similarities to it. But I still enjoy the concept, graphs and gameplay of this game. However, when I desire to have no hints, even though you manually turn it off they still come on.

Even after the length of time that this album was released, this is still one of the smoothest and greatest albums out there. There are not a lot of albums that I care to listen to it in its entirety, and this is one of them. With his sophomore effort Jon B reiterated his talent and skill, was catapulted this into a double platinum status. I heard about Jon B through my older sister because she had purchased his first album on cassette (ahh, the 90s; how things change), and both albums can still be listened to and enjoyed at this present day. I do not know why he is not viewed the same now as he was back then, but his talent will always be on wax for all to listen.

This app contains several different puzzles beautifully rendered and set to a creepy back story. All of the puzzles included can be found as separate apps, but now you can have them all in one gorgeous package. Hats off to the developers, amazing work. I love the variety of puzzles and difficulty levels couple with amusing graphics and ghoulish voice of the phantom looking host.I know, however, that app developers need to make money, but I know a lot of people are not going to be ecstatic to pay for hints, especially if they already shelled out the money to purchase the app in the first place. Nevertheless, it is not a requirement to purchase these hints, and at least the game is not structured in a way that you are forced to spend money in order to progress. It just depends on you in regard to how valuable you deem the game, to whether you wish to spend additional money on it.Overall, The Curse is a puzzle lover's dream come true. This is a great game with tons of variety in levels that are certainly not a walk in the park. The concept is not especially innovative, but you can definitely appreciate all of the work that the devs put into it, and I can see myself losing time in this app.

I purchased this individually at a local supermarket on a whim, and I am so glad I did! I have only used it once, but I am going to try and include it into my routine at least once a month. When they mention tingling, they are being honest! I have dry skin and a very dry scalp (it actually gets embarrassing, for I don't have dandruff, but flakes from my dry scalp), and I've had this scalp issue since I was young, so thanks to my mother I have used the gamut in specialized shampoo. But this one seems awesome and very promising for a person like me..

I saw this at a local grocer, and seeing that it was sulfate and paraben free, as well as in a different though unique bottle, so I decided to give it a try. I will say that I did not mind the texture of the shampoo. This is the volumizing version, and that is not really an issue for me for my hair is in an afro in its natural state, but this was the only version I saw at the store, and I suppose I was not paying attention to the "volumizing" portion. However, this did lather for me. Some mentioned otherwise, but it lathered up for me, at least on my second rinse.So I used this shampoo in the shower, did two washes as I usually do and immediately after the second rinse felt uneasy. Even though my hair was clearly drenched, it felt stripped to me. I did not like the feel at all. It was as if as if all nutrients were taken away from my hair instead of my hair receiving it. It was not soft at all. So afterwards, I conditioned my hair with a different brand, and then deep conditioned with Feel It Formula Deep Conditioning Treatment, Box of 12 (even though the link says box of twelve, I only used one) for an hour, and afterwards my hair felt immensely better.I want to give this shampoo the benefit of the doubt, for it was a wash directly after I had taken down my hair from extentioned twists (though it should really be irrelevant), but it turned out to be a huge disappointment. I will use it once more since I spent money on it without the added conditioning measures I utilized the first time, but if I come out with the same result I'm going to have to get rid of it.

It is unbelievable that games such as these are not only able to make their way onto Amazon, but that they are able to stay on the site itself. This game is a rip off of two incredibly popular games, but has nothing remotely close to any of the qualities that inhabits those games. This is basically an app of ridiculously lame pictures. Do not fall into this trap and waste your money on nonsense. You have been warned!

This is a nice game that progressively does get challenging. First thing I noticed was the sound of the game, which I liked. The graphics are beautiful as well. Although this isn't a strategy-type game, this game does have a unique concept that keeps your intrigue throughout. It is actually a really run game; however, there are plenty of times that you have to have the exact perfect angle to reach an area. The controls got me a little frustrated at times, so if Mediocre can work on perfecting that, it would make the game that much better.

This is a really awesome game for Android and Kindle Fire. Nice balance between buying stuff and collecting money. Doesnt feel like a money sucker. Worth a buck to spend in game on double cash. Also, game itself is good looking and a lot of fun. It's fun, addicting and beautiful. Hoping there would be a a sequel to this with more levels and more cool weapons!
Great controls, and a vast amount of gaming options available. Cannot complain with this app if you're in the mood to play a game, but not in the mood to boot up your laptop or desktop.
This brings pure nostalgia to me. This is the game of my youth! I love the fact that the music is the same as was in the game. It sucks though that you cannot control tails, but only Sonic.
This is such a great game. Great visuals, graphics, and gameplay and color. And I love the way it's been formatted to play on the Kindle Fire.

This is a great app. Ever since I was in the second grade, I have loved mathematics and arithmetic. I have realized however that I have let this go in my early 20s. Not being forced to take math courses like I was in K-12 really can show, and although I am not an invalid, playing around on this app I realize I am not as quick as I used to be.What I like:I like that there are different levels of difficulty that you can choose from. The options are clear, you can get playing right away.  categories are easy, medium, hard and expert. There are also different categories to play in so it doesn't get boring or redundant. These categories are calculations, bubbles and tables. You also have the choice to operate with the timer or not.What I don't care for so much:No real way to keep track of each time played so you can compete against previous scores in each category. I also don't care for the facebook inclusion, but someone younger may want to share this with their friends on the web.This is a great app that concentrates on reinforcing basic calculations and keeping these skills sharp. This would be an advantageous educational tool for young people, as well as those who care to keep their minds sharp.

This game has the dynamic of being a simple yet challenging game. I really came to like this game, but the controls can be a little bit confusing. Apart from that its a fantastic game. The graphics are pretty amazing, and I can see a lot of people losing hours on this app if it's your  kind of game.

This app is pretty freaking cool, and I'm glad it was the FAOTD.Firstly it worked very well in accordance to the GPS, so unlike some other applications, it seems that this will not be an issue while you're near or inside an airport as long as you have an internet connection. It was lightening fast to my local Airport, and I am probably 20-25 minutes away.The interface was at first a little confusing to me, but the learning curve is pretty quick. Basically, the flight numbers are in one column, origin in the next column, followed by the gate and arrival/departure time. You can easily scroll through the rows from top to bottom. Once you find the flight you are looking for, you click on the row and all the information you need expands.
