The labels are bright and fun and makes this treat an awesome gift giving product.The coconut flavor of this particular one is awesome.  It has a rich flavorful flavor and does not have that over processed taste to it.  The cotton candy is really fluffy and packed in so you get quite a bit of product in the container.  This is by far one of my favorite flavors I have tried from this company.  It has a great flavor and leaves you wanting more. I will definitely be back for more as gifts(and of course for my daughter and my little sugar addiction).  I received this product in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.

These socks are a great value for the high quality they are made with.  The material is very soft and there is quite a bit of stretch to them so they fit smaller or larger feet.  The prints are nice and these are great for casual wear or dress up.  I like that this company has many prints to choose from for mens dress socks depending on what type of pant or color you are wearing.  My husband said his feet did not get super sweaty in these socks like some of his other dress socks and they were comfortable to wear all day.  Great quality socks at a great value. I received this product in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.

These are great dress or casual socks for men.  I have never had any problems with bamboo material socks and find them to be quite a bit softer and flexible than regular dress socks that I have purchased my husband in the past. I have tried many cloth diapers and training pants and these are by far one of the very best I have ordered. The quality and effectiveness of this brand gives exactly what it promises with a lot of unique features. This diaper includes one bamboo charcoal insert which can be used two different ways. The inside has a snap, so you can simply lay the insert on the inside of the diapers and snap it in for easy removal, or you can stuff it in and it is inside the diaper so it does not move around. This is a great way to customize the diaper for you needs depending on the day or your child's needs. With the stuffing option you toss the whole diaper and cover into the wash, with the snap in option you can reuse the shell and not have to wash the whole diaper. This is a great option because you get extra uses out of the shell. I like this diaper because it can grow with your child so even if you have a tiny little one or a toddler getting ready to potty train this diaper is a great option. My daughter is two and starting to potty train. This is a great option for her because she is 25 lbs and we can easily switch out the insert if she has a little accident. This saves me on training pants and the diaper can be used for future children. I am very impressed with the quality and print also. The design is adorable and the colors are bright and fun. I have many of these diapers and all have washed well and have held up to MANY washes so far. Great value and a great quality diaper. I received this product in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.

This is one of the best water bottles I  have tried. The bottle is extremely heavy duty. It is very well made and washed easily in the dish washer.  The top screws off or can flip open.  What I love about this bottle is not only does it keep drinks cold for a very long time, but the insert allows you to drink your water/beverage and not get any type of pulp or tea leaves if you have that in your drink. I have a lot of infuser bottles and I can throw in lemons etc and have flavored water without all the extra steps. I just drop it in, drop the insert in and screw on the lid. I have tried this with tea and have had really great results also. I have used this with ice water and also hot tea. Both times I felt like it kept my drink cold and hot for much longer than my regular thermos and water bottles. Great quality bottle for many purposes. This magnetic makeup caddy is a great organizer for me to take on the go and for every day.  This palette has a removable insert so you can customize it any way you want. The large mirror makes it easy to do your makeup with ease.  This is the perfect size that I can have it handy in my bathroom with my every day makeup basics or to take with me in my purse if I need to touch up my powder or shadows. These pillows are seriously the squishiest pillows I have ever owned. I hate firm pillows and sleep on with very soft or medium soft pillows the best. I love the ideas of these sprinkle vitamins. My little girl is pretty picky about any type of vitamin I give her. Even when I give her gummy vitamins or half of a flintstone vitamin she does not seem to like the taste.  My daughter is a really picky eater so going without vitamins just is not giving her the nutrients she needs with her picky taste.  These sprinkle vitamins are literally undetectable. Last night for dinner I put the recommended amount on her macaroni and cheese and stirred it up. She had absolutely no idea I had put them in her dinner and she got her nutrients she needed!  This is a fabulous idea for those picky eaters or just for children who do not enjoy taking a regular vitamin. I love that there are probiotics and added iron also since some children's vitamins do not include this.  The amount you get is a great value for the price also. I will continue to use this and be back for more when we run out. I received this product in exchange for my honest and unbiased review.

These pads are easy to apply. They are large so they cover the whole center section on your chest and between the upper part of your breasts.  The set includes two large pads and they are packaged seperately.  The pads stick to your skin and stay put. They create a smooth platform so your skin does not crease together when sleeping. If there's one thing you can be sure of living the Apple life, it's that you can never have enough Lightning cables lying around. Third party cables are often wonky (frikkin' active circuitry just sitting there, JUDGING YOU), and even the properly certified ones can be rather fragile. (I can't be the only one who's had more than one duct-taped cable kept around long after it's been thrown out.)I'm not sure if this is necessarily a deal, although it's certainly cheaper than you'd find in a retail store, and Monoprice is a pretty well-respected brand, so you could safely buy this sight-unseen if you dared. The plug seems pretty jiggle-proof (a problem with many cables) and the 10-foot cable should be long enough to plug in your phone in the front seat and use it sitting in the back. Basically, this is a cable that does exactly what you want it to do. The one star deduction: after all this time, haven't cable builders figured out that the strain relief on virtually every Lightning cable on the market is absolute crap? This is slightly better than some, but I'd still expect it to start fraying sooner than later.

Simon Monk is a pretty well-respected author in the maker space, so it's fair to say this will be a decent enough book right from the outset. All things considered, this book delivers exactly what it promises -- how to learn Python on a Raspberry Pi. If you need an inexpensive textbook for a school computer class or are a rank beginner, this is a fine book to start with.I am a little torn, though. It's certainly possible to be too ambitious when it comes to a textbook, especially on an elementary/beginner level, but if you already know Python and want to get straight to the hardware hacking, this probably isn't the book to start with, especially if you're jumping right into maker stuff in the spirit of MIT's 6.01 EECS intro course, and it doesn't cover the use of the RPi as a media system at all, which seems like a strange oversight given that's one of the most popular use cases. On the other hand, if you just plan on using your RPi as a desktop system, this book gives short shrift to Scratch and no coverage at all to Mathematica; whether those are a concern to you may depend on your age group (Scratch of course skews young, while Mathematica is more of a college student thing).I'd say if you're fine with a fairly narrow, Python-based introduction to the platform and aren't overly concerned about projects outside basic game programming or the maker space, this will do the job just fine. However, if you need a more general Pi book, look elsewhere.

You grade memory on a pass-fail basis, and this is a pass.It underclocks effectively. It's standard SO-DIMMs without the gamer chrome you sometimes see; unless you're overclocking the hell out of your system and need the heat spreaders, you won't miss it. As I write this, it's pretty reasonably priced. Like most SO-DIMMs, they're probably a little heavy to use as earrings when you're done with them, but would make fine pendants. Finally, the package could be smaller, and you'll need plastic shears or a pocket knife to open it, which is never fun.

Seems like a decent enough whole-grain flour for coatings and quick breads. I'm not sure I'd try to use it for regular bread, and it definitely won't work for anything where white flour is needed (the color isn't too bad but the bran flavor is too strong), but it's still good for a few things.Also, I don't think I've ever tasted sorghum before. Assuming I'm not confusing it with the rice flour component, it's ever so slightly sweet with a wheat bran overtone.

What do you need to know, and is it worth the effort to do it? This book attempts to answer.If you understand electronics at least at a "Forrest Mims Engineer's Notebook" level, that's about where this book is coming from, albeit repair-oriented rather than project-oriented. It's a slimmer volume than you'd expect; if you were hoping for a Chilton guide to everything electronic, this isn't it. Which is fine; you're better off trying to search the Internet for any given service manual. What this book teaches is, essentially, how to read that service manual and what you need in terms of mise-en-place and basic electronics expertise to make use of it -- what you need for your workbench, how to solder, even doing what I used to do to old transistor radios as a kid (let's call it an autopsy) to get familiar with the parts you might run into. It also goes through many common household electronics, gives a quick summary of their internals, and whether it's worth the effort to try to fix them -- in other words, what you need to know to triage your brave little toasters. (Okay, not actually toasters, but there are other books for that.)This does not suffice as a complete reference for electronics repair, but like I said above, it doesn't really need to. It's enough to get you started and on your way.

I mean, good on you if you can make something useful out of this, but I'm not too sure how.Some people really like chaotic games. If you like that sort of thing, Fluxx Dice will be for you. From where I sit, this idea seems to be little more than a spurious-argument generator. If that's what you like, play hearts.

When I was a kid, model aviation was a very limited sort of thing -- most people just had paper planes and the odd balsa-and-rubber-band or styrofoam glider model; more realistic aircraft were the province of rich kids with nerdy dads. If you wanted something useful (ie something that takes pictures), you had to either have an Estes Astrocam rocket or an expensive RC plane with a jury-rigged camera... and no one I knew had either one. Things have certainly changed, haven't they?For better or for worse, Afghanistan did for UAVs what Mars Pathfinder did for hobby robotics, and while this book is maybe a year or two overdue, it's very welcome. The main focus of the book is on safe and legal flying and applications for your typical quadcopter drone; you are assumed to have already bought or constructed the aircraft you're going to be using; you'll get information on how to buy a drone and get up and running, but if you want information on how to design and construct a craft, that's going to be in a completely different book. There's a lot of information on law, support and communities (to be fair, this book is likely to be obsolete in a few years, so if you're reading this in 2020, don't try to save money and get the first edition, especially since laws are likely to have changed). There's even a section on proper battery handling, because let's be honest, NiMH is too heavy, NiCad is obsolete, and lithium-ion batteries have been cantankerous little bastards at the best of times, so pay attention to that part.There is a heavy focus on aerial photography, including some material on attaching a DSLR to your drone (assuming of course you're filthy rich and have nothing better to do with your money). It does discuss other matters, but not in great detail since drone cargo handling is an area that's still in legal flux. Overall, although it doesn't cover the design aspects as well as it could, it's definitely a must-read for a newbie drone operator.

This *almost* seemed like a good idea. But I think I'll stick with my Wusthof and Accusharp.I don't know who thought this was a good idea or how it clearly made it out the door with insufficient user testing, but this thing is downright dangerous. The sliding action on the sleeve is very stiff and the knife occasionally gets hung up on the sharpener itself. It's possible it might work better with other styles of knife like a slicer or utility knife, but this particular combination of sleeve and knife is outright dangerous.Two stars because the knife itself is okay. It's a fairly thick stamped-blade knife with your basic plastic handle, more or less the same as you'd find in any supermarket for about thirty bucks. But really, don't buy this. Just don't.

I picked this printer for two reasons: 1) it was on sale, and 2) it was Consumer Reports' best buy all-in-one for 2014. I haven't been disappointed by this yet.Considering it isn't really optimized for photo printing, print quality in general is excellent. All functions that I've tried work well, although the HP Connected apps (which you likely won't much care about) seem to work differently from the way they used to. Although still insanely pricey like most inkjet cartridges, the ones the 86xx series take are quite a bit larger than the ones HP's more consumer-oriented printers use, so they're a relative bargain. The web interface is pretty comprehensive and includes some interesting features, most notably the ability to lock ink carts to the printer so they'll be useless if stolen. The only downside I've seen is that the standard event logging interface leaves a lot to be desired. Scanning and copying work nicely, and print-by-email works as smoothly as ever. One oddity: if you're printing pictures off an SD card, you'll need a USB card reader; there's only the one USB-A port on the front, with no card slots. (If you're still using TWAIN for scanner acquisition, I actually have no idea if it supports a TWAIN driver; even if you don't have the HP utility software on your system, the scan-by-web interface makes it somewhat unnecessary.)All that said, this thing's a monster. This is not necessarily a problem in an office setting, as most offices will have an appropriate place to put it, but if you're a home user who (like us) keeps it in a common area like the kitchen so everyone can get to it, you're going to have to look around for some open space. Also, even allowing for the fact that this model is frequently on sale from places that sell HP printers, this might be a particularly bad choice for a dorm room, as it will literally take up half of the average dorm desk. (Of course, most college students are using laptops these days, so that may not actually be a problem.) It's probably not the greatest printer you'll ever use, and it's not even the best inkjet HP has for sale, but as far as bang for the buck goes, you'll do fine with this.

I have the speaker playing right now as I type this. It's surprisingly loud for its size, with respectable enough bass; it won't compete with a dedicated subwoofer, but it's not bad. Sound quality is acceptable unless you're picky about it; it is a little lacking in treble, but not so bad it'll annoy your ears.I'm not real crazy about some of the design aspects though. For one thing, it looks like it's supposed to drop into a car cupholder, which seems like one of those ideas that seemed good at the time but turns out not so good. Also, it lacks an obvious battery gauge, which is somewhat of a problem if you are indeed using it in the car. It does have an aux-in port so you can use it without Bluetooth, which is nice. You can't use it as a wireless external mic input; I feel like it wouldn't have been a significant expense to add that, but I don't design these things, so what do I know. It's no Ion Block Rocker, but it'll do.

I got this for our camper. It fit in one of the sink sides a little snuggly but fine. I agree with other reviewers that said the silverware dividing flap is very cheesy and does not stay put. It pops off and just gives the entire drainer a less quality feel than it would have if they spent a little more attention on that feature. Knowing it ahead of time though, I was not surprised and would still purchase it again.

I got this to hang in our camper closet, which had two closets that had only a hanging bar for clothes. Shelves are much handier and this was our solution. Worked wonderfully! I fit several rolls of TP in one slot, a roll of paper towels in another, aluminum foil and other wraps in one, a tissue box, as well as a small tool box to organize other supplies in with extra space. Happy!

This is a nearly perfect PT holder in my opinion. Doesn't get any more space saving. Works every single time. Looks good. Versatile mounting options. Well made and sturdy. I personally think this is ingenious. I got it to hang PT in our camper, where space is a precious commodity and this thing did not disappoint. If I had to suggest anything it would be to make the arm able to change direction and not have the mounting bracket mounted upside down...or so it can be flush whichever way the arm faces. Mine isn't flush because I had to hang it so the opening was to the left, but it still looks great and doesn't effect how it works. I would most definitely recommend and purchase again and again.

What can you say about a little dish pan...It fit in our tiny camper sink, which was the goal. It held water and worked for what I wanted it to. I will say that I wish it came in colors other than white. We cook on the campfire for most meals and white with black fire soot is just a pain. Plus nothing in our camper is stark white. Overall I'm happy, though

I think this may be the best purchase I made for our little camper! It was very easy to install the feet to fit our stove and was invaluable for adding some much needed counter space! Solid, looks good, and works fabulously.
Just what we needed for our camper shower! I was happy to find one that wasn't plain white/ecru/clear. It looks nice and fit perfectly, too.

These are great! I love the color :) I also like the banded ring around the edges. Good size bowls and mugs, too. It's camping dishes so you can't expect fine china, but these are a much better quality than the old set we had and the old set lasted for over a decade...and honestly still are fine...but I wanted this color, lol. We have no complaints

Worked wonderfully in our camper! We hung it on the cabinet door and had no problems. Plus it looks nice. We tried it with the RV TP rolls as well as regular Charmin rolls and both fit fine. You would have trouble if you buy the jumbo rolls of TP, though. Very happy and would recommend it :)

These look nice and I love the small space they require. They also do seem well made, but that's about the best I can say because they don't work very well and I wish I could return them. They are not easy to use one handed. I don't think I have small hands by any means and every friend who has tried them, as well as my husband, also has trouble. It takes too much pressure to press the plunger down with your thumb and we wind up holding it with one hand and pushing the plunger with the palm of our other hand. It's a good 1 3/4" from the top of the plunger to the top of the barrel. In addition to that, you don't get very good output and there is no adjustment for the grind. The little tray it came with is nice, but it does fill with spilled S & P since the opening is on the bottom. Also, because these are so small, you wind up filling them ALL the time! They only hold about a tablespoon of S or P. Overall, I regret this purchase and wish I had sent them back while I still could instead of "giving them a fair trial". These will be relegated to the camper so we don't have to use them more than a few times per year. I have already ordered replacements.

This was beautiful but flimsy. I wear my toe rings 24/7 and this just couldn't take it. I am very unhappy because it was so pretty. It snapped in two exactly 1 month after receiving it while I was walking across my living room. :( I got to wear it from June 9th to July 9th...a disposable ring is not worth the price I paid
My daughter is thrilled with her AGD swim set! She especially loves the shoes :)

These work just fine. They freeze quickly and seem to last a while. We also haven't noticed any leakage, which is always nice! We haven't used them in the heat of summer yet but if they don't do well at that time I will update this review. I like that they don't take up much space in the cooler or the freezer!

I can't complain about these...they fit my Ball canning jars and my Ball mugs and don't have a leak problem. I happen to use canning jars as storage containers so this is a great alternative for ease of use :)

I have long, thick, coarse, curly....ok ADHD, hair and my hairdresser said to try this. I am always reluctant to pay the price for hair products because...well...frankly they usually don't work. I am happy to say that I have noticed a difference in my hair since using this product. I guess you could say it's like Ritalin for my ADHD locks ;) This along with my Moroccanoil Curl Defining Cream are my hair's new best friends!

This is the second of this CD that we have purchased. The first one we grabbed on a whim from a bargain bin after Christmas over a decade ago! It has played it itself out and because we love it so much we came to Amazon to buy it again! It's a beautiful way to tell the story of Christ's birth in a musical play format. It has become a Christmas tradition in our house!

We had some trouble with the seller on this one...ours was shipped in the commercial box it comes in and not in a shipping box. First, this happened to be my Christmas present which landed on my doorstep just before Christmas in it's commercial box...surprise and happy birthday...my 8 and 11 year old daughters were SO disappointed that I saw my present :( Needless to say the first one was damaged and we sent it back after a bit of back and forth with the seller. They did send a replacement but again, not in a shipping box. The second one did manage to come through unscathed, however, and now that we have it and have been using it, I like this particular model. I will say it had a bit of an odor for a while...the oils maybe? But we have had no trouble with anything we have run through it, including credit cards, CD's and whole envelopes of junk mail. My youngest tried to run a book through it when I wasn't looking and it got stuck (obviously) but I used the reverse button and it popped right back out. This shredder is also quieter than the shredder we owned previously, (can a shredder be "quiet" LOL) though that shredder was a less expensive one and was several years ago so I don't know how this model sounds compared to other newer shredders in it's price range. I am not disappointed.

My daughter, age 11 and a half, came to me and said "Mommy, can you PLEASE get the other books in this series? This was the best book I've read in a long time!". How can you say no when your tween is asking for more books :)

We got these to go with the matching paper goods. They are fine but they are not the same color as the paper goods they coordinate with. It's not a terrible difference but it was instantly noticeable. I'm still glad we went with them

This is ok...I had more than enough letters to spell out what I wanted to and the cardboard quality is what you'd normally get from a party banner, however, the kit did not provide enough of the fasteners to completely assemble it. There were plenty of the back part of the fasteners (tiny clear plastic washers) but not enough of the front part (32). I had to use paper brads to finish the assembly which was disappointing. That being said...the fasteners they come with are not very easy to use...they fit tight and don't let the banner move nicely and my fingers were very sore after assembling just a few of the fasteners! The brads were SO much easier to assemble it with! I also think it would be better if they came with either more of the stars or all the same print...it came with 3 zebra print and 3 leopard print, but that's not a deal breaker. If I did it over again though I would toss the included fasteners and just use brass paper brads...I colored the brad head with a black sharpie to help it to blend in better.The letters it includes are as follows...4 each: A, E, F, I3 each: C, D, G, H, L, N, O, R, S, T2 each: B, J, K, M, P, U, V, W, Y, Z1 each: Q, X and numbers 0-96 Star spacers - 3 zebra, 3 leopardPlastic fasteners - Mine came with 32 front fasteners and WAY more of the back washers

I was incredibly hesitant to pay the price for these for my daughter. But it was mid-season and all the bibs I could find were not in her size. She is a petite almost 9 year old who wears a 7/8 and I bought her the size 8. I was thrilled when they came and I discovered they are i-grow! We can lengthen the cuffs and the straps by several inches! Plus they were already long on her so I folded the straps over at least an inch already and tacked them in place. These will last her several years...thus making the cost more than reasonable! I do not regret this purchase! She also says they are very warm! She plays outside for hours in the cold and we've had the coldest sub-zero temps in over 180 years this winter...yet she went sledding, snowmobiling, built forts, and played for hours on end without getting cold or wet. As an added bonus they matched her LL Bean coat perfectly..though that was not planned! :)

I used this yarn to crochet fingerless mitts and a scarf. It worked up very nicely but took a bit of time and yarn since it's a finer yard. I liked the finished product so much I kept them for myself :D
No complaints from us. Worked in the dog collar we bought it for so we are happy but the dog is not ;)
Took FOREVER to say it was charged and then once it did and the phone was unplugged it had no charge. It went right back

I wanted to love this case...but sadly it suffers the same problem all the other heavier/bulkier cases that I've tried suffer from....it's SLIPPERY! The whole case just looks cool and the pink color is bright and awesome and it fits good and tight and seems to protect well...but if I'm going to drop my phone because it's slippery...why bother...totally defeats the purpose. I'm pretty bummed.

This is a really great case! It fits really well and doesn't cover any holes or make the buttons hard to use. This is a very neon pink color which I love and is transparent. The edges are smooth but not slippery and the back has almost a slightly sanded feel...not smooth but I wouldn't say rough either. I think I would probably prefer the back to be the same as the sides as the sides feel a bit grippier than the back but I like regardless. The material is very much like the old jelly shoes...so it's flexible and easy to put on and not all that hard to get off. I like that it covers the entire edges. My favorite part...and the reason I wanted this kind of case, is that unlike all the bulkier cases I tried this is NOT slippery!! At the same time it's not sticky or hard to slide into my pocket or purse either! I had a similar case on my old phone and it held up the best of any case I have ever used which is why I sought out one like it for my S5. I would definitely order these again!

This is a really great case! It fits really well and doesn't cover any holes or make the buttons hard to use. The material is very much like the old jelly shoes...so it's flexible and easy to put on and not all that hard to get off. I like that it covers the entire edges. My favorite part...and the reason I wanted this kind of case, is that unlike all the bulkier cases I tried this is NOT slippery!! At the same time it's not sticky or hard to slide into my pocket or purse either! I had a similar case on my old phone and it held up the best of any case I have ever used which is why i sought out one like it for my S5. The one thing I did NOT like at all was the Kiss My Case logo on the back of the case...but I ordered it thinking I would slap a decal over it if I couldn't get it off. Well, I'm happy to say that the logo wiped right off using a little bit of acetone...more commonly known as nail polish remover! :D No damage to the case or left over discoloration from the logo either! I would definitely order these again!

I really liked the look of this case and wanted so badly to really like it. It protects well and fits well...however the one thing I can't excuse in a cell phone case is that it's SLIPPERY! Very slippery! Doesn't matter how protected my phone seems to be...if I'm going to drop it because it's slippery...it's not worth it to me as it defeats the purpose. I am really disappointed.

Ok...I love it! I previously used the peel and stick kind of screen protector and I liked them well enough. But you had to be so careful about applying them, This was SO easy and kinda fool proof. Even better it works! No lack in screen sensitivity and it's reusable. I would most definitely buy this one again

This was a recommendation from our local pet store. What can I say...it works! We used it on both our dog and cat to jump start our flea eradication adventure and it did the job very well! We'd use it again

This bra is ok. Not my favorite. I needed front close bras for after shoulder surgery and this was one of them. I don't think it fits great...I feel like I don't get the support I'd really like and the wire in the cleavage area tends to poke forward and can often be seen under the shirt I am wearing. Its not uncomfortable but has become one of my wear at home bras

I bought these because I wanted to replace all the plastic straw cups I had that I used for ice water and smoothies mostly. These are great! Good large size and they work perfectly with the Ball straws and straw lids I also bought. Canning jar bands work great, which was my goal! :)

This is a great size for my needs. I wanted a small board to hang in my sewing room and this fit the bill. I covered it with fabric and use button push pins and it's cute! The only draw back is the fact that you can't use about 3/4 of an inch around the whole edge because of the frame the cork is wrapped around. I hadn't realized this when I purchased it. that leaves about a 12.25" x 4" usable pinning area. Still works for my purposes but thought I'd make anyone aware who was looking to purchase it.
They are what I was looking for :) They serve their purpose so I can't complain.

I love this coat :) It's the length I wanted, it looks great and fits well. I am 5' 5" and wear a size 14 and the x-large fits me perfectly. It doesn't make me sweat but keeps me comfortable even when the temps are below zero. It's what I was looking for in a new coat.

I love these! They are exactly what I was looking for. I wanted canning jar mugs  for everyday use that I could use bands and lids with. I purchased the Ball straws and straw lids to go with them and also a Cuppow sipping lid. Both work great! I use one every morning (and sometimes a couple times during the day) for my coffee and have had no issues with the hot beverage. I would definitely buy these again!

I really liked this. It's the perfect size for serving vegetables in! Unfortunately my 11 year old cracked the lid after using it only one time. I would like to replace it at some point point and probably will but for now I am using it with the crack.
Just what I was looking for. This is bright and easy to read! I'm glad I got it

I bought several pairs of these gloves. Two pair were going to be used for riding and one pair for overnight eczema care. However, they were all too small. Neither of my daughters could get them on. They are ages 8 and 11 and I bought the XXX small. I returned all three and was only able to get one pair in the size I needed (XX small) so I got that one pair for my 8 year old for her overnight eczema care. They fit much better than the smaller size and the velcro at the wrists helps keep them on overnight. I will say that both my girls are small for their age.

This served its purpose. We had to put it on a window that was behind the stair railing in our church in order for it to pass inspection. It went up easily and you'd never know it was there. We also had no trouble sticking a Christmas candle to the window with a suction cup during the Christmas season. Very happy.
My daughter bought this with her Christmas money to go with her American Girl Doll. Both she and her sister love it! They especially love that the toast actually pops up :)

I was on the hunt for an adjustable ring to wear on my thumb that was injured several years ago. As a result of the injury the knuckle is large and the base of the thumb is skinny and it has always remained sensitive since. My mother suggested a spoon ring to "protect" the area a little bit and hopefully ease some of the sensitivity discomfort. This ring seems to have done the trick! No ring will be totally comfortable because of the injury but this definitely works to protect the scarred area and disguises the abnormally skinny base where there is nothing but skin. I am happy with this purchase :) I call it my thumb shield
This does hold a LOT of hair! I was actually surprised! I have a hard time finding clips that will easily hold ALL of my long, thick, wild, curly hair and this does :)
This did nothing for me. I took it faithfully but saw no difference in any way. I will not purchase again.

I am not sorry I purchased this ring. It is beautiful! I do wish it was a little more curved so it fit a finger better. The ends tend to poke out rather than form around your finger so they catch and snag on things. In an effort to bend it slightly to make it fit more and snag less, the weld holding the two branches together broke....effectively making it an adjustable ring :D Which I personally felt was better. As a result of the snagging ends I only wear this occasionally....I had hoped it to be a ring I would wear every day.

I like these...and they are pink! :) They do help with my long, wild, wacky, thick curly hair, too. My hair can stay wet for 24 hours and this has helped reduce the drying time and I love that they are light and not top heavy like when you use a regular towel. I simply squeeze out my hair as best as I can and wrap it up, then leave it for as long as I want to. I usually leave it while I dress, do my make-up and sometimes sit and sip a coffee, too, and it stays solid and secure the entire time. I also use one of these over a shower cap for deep conditioning, often for several hours and it works equally as well. I even used one for an overnight conditioning and woke in the morning to it still being secure...granted I am not an acrobat during sleep but I do toss and turn some. I wish I had bought these a lot sooner!

I bought this to organize my hair brushes and other vanity top items in and couldn't be happier with my choice! It's a great size for the top of my vanity and holds everything I want to have within easy reach. One back slot holds my hand mirror and a can of hair spray, the other back slot holds my paddle brush and round brush, front slots hold a small spritz bottle and a pair of scissors, two deodorants, and my regular brush and wide toothed comb. Perfect for my needs!

I bought one of these for me and then another and another to give away! Is it a high quality, rock solid piece of kitchen equipment? NO...it's plastic...but it is also the only one with a lifetime guarantee and I have already gotten more than $30 worth of use out of it! And if used appropriately I see no reason why it won't last a long time! I LOVE zoodles and have gotten my mother and several friends hooked as well! This made the PERFECT birthday gift for my gluten free friend, too! So happy I got this!

My husband had purchased one of these locally and when his mom said she would like a dry bag for Christmas he knew just which one he wanted to get! We got size 20 (Orange) and it's a great size! He has used his all season (plus) and everything has stayed dry. Both he and his mom are happy!

My daughter loves these! She was looking at a pair that were slightly less money but decided she liked the look of these better and she is glad she did! They are super adorable and seem a good quality! Her American Girl Doll will have warm feet ;)

Mine is gorgeous! It is solid and the varying grain is beautiful! I bought this to go on top of our Breville BOV450XL Mini Smart Toaster Oven and it is the absolute PERFECT fit! I don't think the feet on this board are silicone so I bought a couple silicone baking mats to go underneath it and I couldn't be happier! It looks great, makes more counter space, and protects it from my children's bad habit of preheating the toaster oven with things on top of it! I will also say the bottom of mine does not have any of the issues the reviewer who posted the pics seemed to have. No filler or glue or other nasties uglying up the under side.

I was immediately impressed by the ease of connecting to the device via Bluetooth, which is something I have noticed some difficulty doing with a Bose wireless speaker. However, I was almost as quickly disappointed by the sound quality of this device, because I have used a Bose wireless speaker.  It probably is not worth the manufacturer's recommended price, and certainly cannot compete with the more expensive Bose competitors.

They are okay. There is certainly nothing to gush about with these baskets. They have flexibility, so that if you want to put something in them that has an odd shape, they're not too restrictive.  They have an attractive appearance, but again, nothing to get one tremendously excited.

This may provide extreme protection, but installing it is also a bit extreme, since you have to unscrew 15 screws with an Allen wrench, and in my package, it was not provided.  Fortunately, I had the correct size, and was able to unscrew all 15, pull the case apart, cringing the whole way since it sounded like it was tearing, installed the iPad, and screwed all 15 screws back in.The ports are all defended by plastic/rubber pieces that pull out, except the volume control, which is really difficult to use, especially for a child, if that is your intended use.  The charge port is finicky, and will not accept all charge cords.  We have a few of the AmazonBasics usb to lightning cords, which are, in my opinion, better than the Apple cords, but will not fit.So, I had fun removing the iPad from the case again, and 15 screws after beginning that project, I discovered it is quite a challenge to get it open with the iPad inside.In the end, I discovered no iPad Air owner in my household wants to use it.

Where I come from, most people erroneously take it at face value that in order for there to be any belief in the resurrection of Jesus, said resurrection must have taken place. After many years of studying the Bible and much biblical scholarship, it is difficult to see much difference in the stories of the Bible and stories of other cultures. Many people I know cannot imagine that anything in the Bible could have been made up, thinking it is too complex for someone to do. If I ask enough questions, it becomes obvious those people are not familiar with other stories people have told from ancient cultures. Yes, there are differences between stories originating in the Middle East and those originating from other locales such as Greece, Rome, Scandinavia, Britain, China, India, etc. One would expect the stories to be different, because the cultures are different. I also tend to find that those people usually have not read their entire Bible, whereas I have read it many times over.I am not one of those that think the Jesus spoken of in the Bible is purely a myth. There are complex reasons to think the stories are based on a real person. However, I do not think there is any need to doubt the existence of Jesus, in order to realize one may doubt almost everything attributed to him in the Bible. There are very good and complex reasons for doubting most actions and words of Jesus portrayed in the New Testament. Plus, there are very good reasons for doubting that there are any scriptures in the Old Testament that predict anything about Jesus.There is a quote from Bulfinch's Mythology I would like to share here. "This is one of those mythological tales, says a late writer, in which there is reason to believe that a substratum of truth exists though overlaid by a mass of fiction." That quote is referring specifically to Jason and the Argonauts, but one which can easily be applied to almost all incredible tales. If one has read the Bible, one can recognize the incredible nature of the tales. If one is familiar with lower and higher biblical criticism, it becomes apparent that what is claimed simply cannot be true, because there are far too many inconsistencies. Inconsistency with itself, with science, with history, with archaeology, and so much else, tends to make questions of whether something happened not worth pursuing to most, since it is obvious most of it is simply made up.I usually do not read books of this nature, where someone examines whether some event in the Bible actually happened. Because of everything else, I would stand with Thomas Jefferson, and pretty much cut out anything miraculous if I wanted to formulate an approximation of the truth. Or I would stand with David Hume (An Enquiry Concerning Human Understanding, 1748), and say "In our reasonings concerning matter of fact, there are all imaginable degrees of assurance, from the highest certainty to the lowest species of moral evidence. A wise man, therefore, proportions his belief to the evidence." When Hume gets to the end of a lengthy passage discussing miracles, he states "The plain consequence is (and it is a general maxim worthy of our attention), `that no testimony is sufficient to establish a miracle, unless the testimony be of such a kind, that its falsehood would be more miraculous, than the fact, which it endeavors to establish; and even in that case there is a mutual destruction of arguments, and the superior only gives us an assurance suitable to that degree of force, which remains, after deducting the inferior.' When anyone tells me, that he saw a dead man restored to life, I immediately consider with myself, whether it be more probable, that this person should either deceive or be deceived, or that the fact, which he relates, should really have happened. I weigh the one miracle against the other; and according to the superiority, which I discover, I pronounce my decision, and always reject the greater miracle. If the falsehood of his testimony would be more miraculous, than the event which he relates; then, and not till then, can he pretend to command my belief or opinion."This is why the approach taken by the author of this book, Kris Komarnitsky, is effective. What he suggests may have happened at Jesus's alleged resurrection is far more likely than what is suggested by the Bible. Cognitive dissonance reduction as a mechanism of the beginnings of a religious belief is extremely likely. The examples he gives of other messianic cults that have developed show that this happens. Even if I think it may not be necessary to resort to the possibility that someone or several persons experienced hallucinations, it is evident that this is much more likely than resurrection, because hallucinations in grief, as well as in other scenarios, are known scientifically to occur. All other scenarios described by Komarnitsky besides these are also known to be possible, and that is the entire point. Perhaps there was just one early follower that was a sincerely mistaken, deceived, or even lying individual, or perhaps there was the harmless accretion of legend that can occur over the decades between Jesus's death and Paul, or even Jesus's death and the gospel of Mark. Much can happen in 20-40 years, especially in a primitive environment.Obviously, we cannot know exactly what happened that led to this story of the resurrection of Jesus, or any other resurrection described in the Bible. The strength of this book is to show the reader that one has options to consider other than blind faith, and though the scenarios described may not be what happened, they are at least possible and even probable considering what we can know, and therefore far superior to anything the apologists can throw at the author in criticism.I would be satisfied with these conclusions by reading David Hume or by reading perhaps the resurrection debate "Is There Historical Evidence for the Resurrection of Jesus? A Debate between William Lane Craig and Bart D. Ehrman" held at College of the Holy Cross on March 28, 2006. This is one of the references used by Komarnitsky, and happened to be a debate I read back in 2006. It is about 40 pages long, and was, I think, devastating to Craig, and I was a (doubting) Christian when I read it. I am sure most Christians thought Craig won, as is usual for debates, since most people never reevaluate their own thoughts. Ehrman's arguments simply made more sense, and Craig's arguments were filled with special pleading. I was embarrassed to be a Christian in that moment, and reading that debate was one of the many things that ended my blind faith.This book will be one of those things, like that debate, that will help some find their way from faith to reason, from darkness to light.

Minimalistic can be great, and I generally prefer that approach, which is why I decided to take one of these for free to review.It is a quality piece of plastic, and the cutouts for all the switches, buttons, and access points are precise, so Belkin has done a good job, as they always do.  It provides a snug fit for the back of the iPad Air, and will ease your mind about setting the iPad down wherever you are.However, there is hardly any discernible lip that would provide much protection for the face of the iPad, and that is not intended.  So, if you want something to provide like protection for the screen, you will have to purchase something in addition to this, like the Smart Cover from Apple or a knockoff, which would put you in the price range of the Smart Case.  If you want to use this in conjunction with a cover you already have after regretting not having coverage for the back, this would be a great option.Since this costs about thirty dollars currently, I would say that one might as well buy a Smart Case from Apple (or a knockoff) that has the back and front covers all in one.  It provides better protection, while not quite going overboard and getting something like an Otterbox.Plus this item has one negative that really irritates me.  Fingerprints show up on this plastic immediately, and do not remove easily.

Don't misunderstand.  This is an excellent case for what it is designed for, which is protecting the iPhone from falls, bumps, tosses, and perhaps the occasional hammer.  However, if one does not have a tendency to have these mishaps, it just seems like overkill.It makes the phone about twice as thick, an inch longer, and more than twice as heavy.  (Estimates)The built in screen protector works smoothly, but is ultimately unattractive because of the oily rainbow appearance it adds to the iPhone screen.Slipping this thing in and out of a pocket can be a real pain, which explains why they feel it mandatory to include a holster.The rubber plugs that block every single port are just in the way.  I'm not sure why these are necessary, because from other people I've known with Defender cases, and from these other reviews, this case isn't blocking any dust.In summary, this is wonderful protection for the accident prone or sadistic (or masochistic), but after using it for a while, and noticing any pleasure of using the iPhone get sucked away by the bulk and interfering rubber plugs, I can tell this is not for me, at least.Getting one for free to review has been a good thing, though.  I have had my iPhone 5 for over a year, and even though I am careful, there are a few tiny scratches and nicks in places, and in hindsight, it may be better to have at least enough of a case so that one does not have to worry about where one sets the phone down, and enough of a lip over the front edge to prevent accidentally nicking the screen.  Screen protectors are really not necessary in that scenario, and I haven't used them with any iPhones.So, Otterbox has convinced me to purchase an Apple iPhone 5/5S case, for just enough protection, but maximum elegance.  I think I'll go with RED for my iPhone and iPad Air.

The wallet case would be nice, if it were not so thick.The commuter case is thicker than the Defender case (without the Defender's holster), though the outside is more slick, allowing for easier insertion and removal from a pocket, assuming one can fit it in one's pocket.There is no built in screen protector, but one that must be installed.  Once installed, I did not like the appearance of the screen protector, because it has that oily rainbow appearance that happens with some, thus ruining the appearance of my iPhone screen.  So, I removed the screen protector and trashed it.The plastic sides that hold the softer layer in, which in turn holds the phone, does not mesh well with the soft layer, leaving the appearance that it is not completely in place.  I kept trying to make it mesh or snap in place fully, but perhaps mine is defective.If one absolutely has to have a phone case with the wallet feature, this may be one of the better options, because it has Otterbox protection for your phone, which is worth something significant to the clumsy among us.  If that is an unnecessary feature, but one desires the protection, I think the Defender is a much better option.

I have loved this series from the beginning, and Sam Eastland (Paul Watkins) has created one of my favorite characters in Pekkala.  However, the fifth book in the series is a dud, and I will explain this in the second half, after explaining a bit about the series, main protagonist, and order of the books.  The reader of the review will have to click on the "Read more" link to get the full review.Inspector Pekkala is a Finn in Russia, former top investigator for the Tsar, and top investigator for Stalin as of books 1-4 of this series. For me, at least, he is one of the more interesting characters I have enjoyed reading about for the last decade. There is a certain darkness about him, but that is not to mean he lacks a sense of justice. There are lots of personal demons he has to contend with, such as those caused by nine years in a Siberian prison camp marking trees, a job that killed others within six months.It is important to read the books in order, but one has to be careful about what they are buying, because the UK and US versions for the second and third books have different names. There are US versions for the first three books by Random House/Bantam, but it does not appear they are continuing US versions, since both books four and five are by Faber & Faber, the UK publishing house. It is no big deal if a US citizen is willing to read the UK version. One will see things like "boot" for the trunk of a car, "torch" for flashlight, "kerb" for curb, "tyres" for tires, and so on.  (A note on the author's site states there will be a US version of book five in May 2014, but no such note exists for book four.)I happened to purchase the Kindle version of book five before it was apparently pulled from Amazon's US market, and when I checked, even the Kindle version of book four has been taken down.  There are supposed to be six books in the series, and now, I wonder if the sixth book will even be available in the US on Kindle.Following is the proper order of the books:I. Eye of the Red Tsar (UK/US)II. The Red Coffin (UK) / Shadow Pass (US)III. Siberian Red (UK) / Archive 17 (US)IV. The Red Moth (UK)V. The Beast in the Red Forest (UK)VI. ?___________________________________This series, in my opinion, is better written and more engaging than most Russian oriented literature, such as the Arkady series (Gorky Park, etc).  However, this last book, The Beast in the Red Forest, is a disappointment, at least to me.The main reason I read the series is because of Inspector Pekkala.  He is the main character, the protagonist, the one I tend to identify with as I read these stories.  In book five, he didn't show up until 30% of the book was gone.  Until then, the protagonist was Kirov, his assistant.  Kirov is good comedy relief, but he is no protagonist, and in fact, becomes more disappointing when he is put in that position, since it becomes even more obvious how dull he really is.The rest of the book tends to focus on military politics between the Red Army and the partisans, which were groups that fought in WWII without actually being in the Red Army.  Nice history lesson, but there was little of Pekkala in this book, and the other characters are paper thin and not compelling.  Yes, there was a storyline that was specific to Pekkala, but it was so minor, and seems to have done little to add progress to the story.  Plus, it is a bit of a ripoff from the story of the first book (someone from the past plotting revenge against Pekkala), and has an ambiguous resolution.At the end of book four, it appeared Pekkala may have disappeared to search for his lost love, Ilya, that he was separated from at the beginning of the Bolshevik revolution.  In this book, it appeared that may have been his intention, but something changes his mind, and after two years of being gone, and embroiled with the partisans, he returns to Moscow, giving her up yet again.Maybe it is not Pekkala's destiny to have that reunion, and I am wrong to think that may be the author's ultimate intention.  Frankly, after almost 30 years, it may seem ludicrous.  However, because of the way the story has been told in previous books, and the way Stalin handled that issue with Pekkala, it seems the best way to steer the series is to have Pekkala reunited with Ilya.  Maybe there was not enough to write, and so book five shows Pekkala in a sort of limbo, waiting for resolution, while the author fulfills a six book contract.Whatever disappointment I may feel in book five, the series as a whole is excellent, and I have far too much invested in it to stop now, especially when the final book is the next one.  For now, I still recommend reading the series.

Montaigne's Essays are one of the more enjoyable massive tomes of renaissance writing available, and if reading in English, one has two major modern choices of translation, Screech and Frame.To start with Translation:  Both major translations are excellent in their own way, but some differences are of note.  When a translation is done, usually the translator will translate the major language of the text, French in this case, and leave quotes by the author from other languages, mostly Latin in this case, untranslated.  The translator will provide a note with the translation of the quote, and preferably the source of the quote.This is where Screech and Frame differ considerably.  Screech does what should be done, and Frame just translates everything into English with no significant notations other than the person quoted.  This means, however, that one may prefer one translation over the other based on this alone.  For example, one that wishes to take a more scholarly look will likely use Screech (or the original), and one that simply wants to read for pleasure may have no problem using the translation by Frame.  Also, Screech is British and Frame is American, so one may have other preferences for style.As for the Physical Copy:The physical copies of Frame's translation (Stanford and Everyman's) are vastly superior to the Penguin Classics Screech version.  The Penguin paperback is thick, but in keeping with the generally small form factor, the print is terribly small, and the paper is of a horrible quality, which is the reason I also purchased the Kindle version.As for the Kindle version:The Penguin Classics Kindle file is much more pleasant to read and deal with than the paperback alternative.  However, there are many errors in the Kindle version that are not present in the paperback version.  It appears some items get corrected occasionally, but still, it is not nice to charge so much for the Kindle version, and not have it completely proofread and ready for primetime.This actually lead me to have a conversation with a Penguin representative about the quality of the Kindle version, and in that conversation, I learned something I had not realized before.  Penguin does not produce the Kindle version.  Amazon does.  So, all of the quality issues I have noticed in the past about Kindle versions essentially are the fault of Amazon rather than the publisher listed.  I suppose the publisher only sells Amazon license to produce the Kindle file and sets price limitations, and Amazon does the rest.  This needs to change, because there needs to be more quality control.However, because of the limitations of the Penguin paperback, I would still recommend the Kindle version if one is to read Screech.Five stars for Montaigne's Complete Essays, regardless of which version one chooses to read.

In the original configuration, this is an excellent car charger designed for any micro USB device, including Kindles and most non-Apple phones, whether Android or just simple messaging phones that are not classified as smartphones.If one simply unplugs the original cord from the base, one can use this to charge virtually any USB device, as long as one has the USB cord that attaches to the device.  With 2.1 AMP / 10 Watt power profile, it provides an impressive, though safe amount of juice.And with Belkin, one can rarely go wrong.

This is a fundamentalist approach to surge protection, at least these days.  It is nice to have in an area like the side of your bed, or perhaps a reading nook, for protecting less expensive items.It would be nicer to have two rows of side facing outlets if you have plugs that are large, since very large AC adapters encroach into the next outlet space too far with this one - not a problem if you are using basic plugs only.
If you do, this is the Lightning cable for you, and why pay the Apple premium on an extra cable, when you can get excellent AmazonBasics quality for a fraction of the cost?

I have to say that I'm a little biased against this hub, simply because it has an AC adapter (with inconvenient arrangement, as previously stated), is relatively expensive for a 4-port USB 2.0 hub, and Belkin already has another one that does not have those disadvantages.Belkin USB 2.0 4-Port Ultra-Mini HubNow, compare that with this one, and see which is better for your needs.

Powell's translation of the Iliad is a good read -- modern, and a refreshing change -- but not quite as poetic as other options.  It is more like prose, wrapped at certain cutoff points so that it resembles poetry.Now, I have known people that have a hard time getting meaning from poetry, and for people like that, or for someone that just wants to quickly read the story without the poetic elegance, this is a great translation.__________________________ADDENDUM:I had much more to say, but when I wrote a whole paragraph of comparisons with other translations (names of translators, not quotes of translations), my review was not allowed.  So, apparently I am not allowed to tell you which translations are not so good, and which I prefer.This is the first time I have had an experience like this when trying to review something on this site.  There were no links, no profanity, no advertisement, or anything else that is not allowed, and no specific reason given for why not allowed.I only figured it out after deleting tiny pieces one by one until the review was allowed.  I was not even allowed to mention the NAMES of other translators.  WOW.

This piece is beautiful, though it is not expensive, and not really something I would buy my wife.  However, since I have a ten year old daughter, I thought she would like it, and she loves it.According to her, it seems flawless, except the center crystal seems to be a little recessed and off-center.  In my opinion, it is probably intentional to have it slightly recessed, and I can barely tell whether the crystal is off-center.Overall, I would say it is a very elegant necklace for the current price of sixty-five dollars.

Belkin car chargers for iPhone have been the best in my experience, so it was hard to resist this set when offered through the Vine program.One thing I like about the wall charger is that it's perfect for use in combination with Belkin Charge and Sync Dock with 8-Pin Lightning Cable Connector for Apple iPhone 5 and iPod Touch 5th Generation, when using the dock for simple charging rather than syncing.  It charges like a dream...lightning is the correct word to use for this combo.The car charger works about the same as any other 2.1 amp Belkin charger.  In my experience, I can get ~50% (actual, not relative) charge increase within 30 minutes of driving.  I will never consider anything with less than 2.1 amps, which can be used even for the iPad, if that gives an idea how well it works for iPhone or iPod.

This third novel by Matthew Dunn is by far the best Spycatcher novel to date.  I really have no idea what happened between the second and third novel, but Dunn has moved from being a quite average novelist to a top-notch writer of the espionage thriller.I despise giving many details of a novel above the blurb given by the publisher, because most readers dislike spoilers.  That being the case, I will say that Cochrane, Dunn's protagonist, encounters some serious competition...There is another Spycatcher in this novel, an SVR version.  Plus there is a German assassin code-named Kronos that is an awesome character.  Both of these characters are likable, and I actually hope to see more of them in a future installment of the Spycatcher series.One large difference I saw in this book is that Matthew Dunn's writing and literary skills have improved, and he is becoming much better at character development.  Before, it was mostly just two-dimensional characters and plot, with much to be desired in descriptive narration.  With Slingshot, he has improved on all of these components of the novel.I recommend this series, with the qualification that readers understand the steep curve of writing quality.  The second book is much better than the first, and the third is much better than the second.  Plus, this seems to be an exponential rather than linear improvement.

Of course, it is not necessary for most people to purchase this version of Office, if one feels it is necessary at all, and if one already has 2007 or 2010, I am not convinced moving to 2013 is at all necessary.  If one has Office 2007, it is difficult for me to buy any arguments for upgrading to either major versions since that release.Please do not get me wrong, but Microsoft makes a quality product, and for many people, it is the standard that has to be used in order to prevent compatibility issues that may occur if switching between two different office software products.It appears that the 2013 version does not have options for multiple PCs, as previous versions did...not even the Home and Student version, which is a draconian approach for Microsoft to take.I think over time, people will tend to switch to free alternatives such as OpenOffice, LibreOffice, Google Docs/Drive, and many others.  If Apple keeps up development on the iWork suite, I even think many people will switch to that, if they use Macs, rather than buying MS Office for Mac, which is still a big market.Microsoft, it seems, needs to adjust to the fact that though they make a quality product, other options are available with quality, as well.  Some are even more pleasant and solid to work with.  For instance, when typing a document in Google Drive, the document saves automatically in the background, almost with every keystroke, making it next to impossible to lose any work.  The same thing applies when typing an email with Gmail.  So, there are advantages to using those web-based systems over using Word or Outlook.Using a program that downloads email, such as Outlook, also has the potential to be unsafe when compared to using webmail.  Ever since I switched exclusively to webmail, I have never had a virus download automatically to my computer.  I can evaluate every email or attachment without opening it or having it physically on my computer.  There are advantages to using Outlook, of course, but I don't really miss them.In the end, it is up to the individual to decide which version, if any, to purchase, but I would not personally spend money on Office 2013, as long as I had other viable options.  (I received an evaluation copy.)

Of course, it is not necessary for most people to purchase this version of Office, if one feels it is necessary at all, and if one already has 2007 or 2010, I am not convinced moving to 2013 is at all necessary.  If one has Office 2007, it is difficult for me to buy any arguments for upgrading to either major versions since that release.Please do not get me wrong, but Microsoft makes a quality product, and for many people, it is the standard that has to be used in order to prevent compatibility issues that may occur if switching between two different office software products.It appears that the 2013 version does not have options for multiple PCs, as previous versions did...not even the Home and Student version, which is a draconian approach for Microsoft to take.I think over time, people will tend to switch to free alternatives such as OpenOffice, LibreOffice, Google Docs/Drive, and many others.  If Apple keeps up development on the iWork suite, I even think many people will switch to that, if they use Macs, rather than buying MS Office for Mac, which is still a big market.Microsoft, it seems, needs to adjust to the fact that though they make a quality product, other options are available with quality, as well.  Some are even more pleasant and solid to work with.  For instance, when typing a document in Google Drive, the document saves automatically in the background, almost with every keystroke, making it next to impossible to lose any work.  The same thing applies when typing an email with Gmail.  So, there are advantages to using those web-based systems over using Word or Outlook.Using a program that downloads email, such as Outlook, also has the potential to be unsafe when compared to using webmail.  Ever since I switched exclusively to webmail, I have never had a virus download automatically to my computer.  I can evaluate every email or attachment without opening it or having it physically on my computer.  There are advantages to using Outlook, of course, but I don't really miss them.In the end, it is up to the individual to decide which version, if any, to purchase, but I would not personally spend money on Office 2013, as long as I had other viable options.  (I received an evaluation copy.)

If one must use a case, one could do far worse than this Belkin case.  Belkin makes quality products, and their cases are no exception.  It is obvious when inspecting this case that it would provide top-notch shock absorption, and even makes it less likely one would need shock absorption, because it improves ability to grip the iPhone.The Gray/Navy case looks a little like gray/slightly purple.  One can tell this pretty well from the pictures, especially using the zoom feature.When putting the phone in, it seems best to put the left side in first, then push the top right corner in, and finish by sliding down the right side to the bottom right corner.  When taking it out, reverse the process, taking out the bottom right corner, then up to the top right corner, then pull the rest of the phone out.A reminder about charging:  If anyone cares to look into the official Apple information on charging iPhones, they stipulate that "charging your iPhone while in certain carrying cases may generate excess heat, which can affect battery capacity. If you notice that your iPhone gets hot when you charge it, take it out of its case first." Which cases? Doesn't say, so better safe than sorry.
